review_body: It is a must see attraction in Seoul that every visitors should pay a visit here. However if you are not immensly interested in history, peeping in through the front door is fine since every palace look exactly the same.

Huge open and garden area to walk and must love the architectural work to be indpired. You can have pictures takenwith the guards at entrance. Beautiful area to wonder and see the museum and new President building but don't lose your entrance ticket to re-enter the palace ground. Also the temple building just above the museum. Worth the visit and canter around the palace ground plus the emper throne. Enjoy the magnificent architecture.
Outstanding museum attached to the palace. The grounds and palace were very interesting. Took lots of photos.

review_title: Good for first timers in Korea
review_body: As Korea and Chinese has similar cultures, if you had been to Forbidden City in Beijing,then this is a dwarf version. However, if this is your first time in Korea, it would be recommended. One can tell that they put in a lot of effort to make the place interesting by adding a lot of cultural experience for tourist. Overall it's fun and entertaining and worth the visit!
It was great place to see the history of Korea- Josun Dynasty including good time and sad time. (the last King of Josen Dynasty)

review_title: Main palace among "Five Grand Palaces". UNESCO believes otherwise.
review_body: Gyeongbokgung is the main among "Five Grand Palaces" in Seoul – Changdeokgung, Changgyeonggung, Deoksugung and Gyeonghuigung. But! Its rival -Changdeokgung became UNESCO World Heritage from 1997. Why didn`t Gyeongbokgung become despite its historical meaning? Thanks to its history! It was twice destroyed by the Japanese during the invasion and occupation. Last time Japanese destroyed it as the symbol of national independence and sovereign power. That`s why most buildings inside are rather new. Not restored but built again. Palace is closed eaurly at 5.00. p.m. That`s why I could visit it just with 3rd attemt. We`ve lost 1-st day in Seoul due to Jetlag, 2-nd and 3rg days I arrived from Namhanseong and Suwon just at closure. I arrived just in time for the closing. And only in the morning before leaving for Busan, I was able to come almost to the opening. It was a weekend and the Babylonian pandemonium was in the Palace. But mostly Koreans participated in Babylonian pandemonium. According to the traditional attitudes of the tourist to look at the Palace of nothing. No furniture. Sculptures no. Paintings either. In short, not Versailles, and not the Hermitage. If this is your first Palace, a slight disappointment or confusion can not be. I already had one Palace of the big five and 2 UNESCO world heritage in Suwon and Namhansanseong, so I was not surprised. Once ambivalent sense it is necessary to visit: Gangnyeongjeon (King's Quarters), Geunjeongjeon (Throne Hall), Gyeonghoeru (Royal Banquet Hall), Gyotaejeon (Queen's Quarters). They are almost the same. But next place will be romantic - Hyangwonjeong Pavilion near small lake. After that I would recommend to turn to right (East) and visit Korean folk museum. You`ll able to understand that the technological victories of Samsung, LG and Hundai on the world markets are not random, but prepared by the whole history of Korea. Entrance ticket is the same as in Gyeongbokgung.

a must visit when travelling to Seoul. As Joseon dynasty's main palace, it is one of the most preserved palace, beside Changdeokgung. It is always packed with tourist. you can visit the palace for free if you wear hanbok. To learn more about its history, you are suggested to join the palace guided tour.

This was the second time I was here because of night entry. From 19:00 - 21:30 you could wander around the palace for night scenes. There were not a lot to see but the most important thing was to see the building above the lake. The mot stunning view I saw in Seoul. Definitely can't miss the chance for night entry!
Very scenic view for couples to stroll around. The spring Breeze and setting sun makes it so relaxing to walk! Should drop by the national folk museum of Korea as well since it just beside.

review_title: An excellent glimpse of traditional Korean architecture and royal life in the heart of Seoul
review_body: This palace is highly accessible to those who visit Seoul. The palace has many features that both shared with other traditional Asian architecture, and also unique for Korea. Like many other grand structures built by hand in other parts of the world, this palace made me feel in awe over the engineering and human effort required to erect such a building. Worth a relatively quick 1 to 2-hour visit for first-timers to Korea.
Historic Palace in central Seoul on all the standard tours so you won't miss out seeing it, very enjoyable

review_title: The cultural experience is still the best in Seoul
review_body: One of the things that I look forward to when I visit the country is the overall cultural experience. A lot of countries today are so westernized and modernized that they lose the culture and what is their country is known for.But for Seoul it is intact. The palaces and its history are preserved. Must see when in South Korea!

review_title: nice place to learn about culture and instagram photos
review_body: It is a beautiful place and good to learn about their cultures. You will be in best experience if you rent a hanbok from nearby store and visit around the palace, I felt like I was in Korean drama, had a lot of Instagram shots ;)
A must if you visit Seoul! The views and the palace is heavenly. Try to go on weekday as so many people are there on weekend and hard to see the performances!
We visited the Palace in the morning where there were no crowds yet. There were several buildings to walk by. We were awed by the guards ceremony. Amazing! So surreal!

If you plan to do just one palace in Seoul do this one. It's quite nice and grand. I'm general palaces in Korea and China are not as lavish as in India but it's worth a visit. Best if you go wearing a local Korean dress which you can rent just outside the palace

Plenty to see here . Maybe the first thing people look at in Seoul . It gives some history and there are many shrines or temples around . Where the royal family used to live and in 1895 where the Queen was brutally murdered by the Japanese . Maybe 30 houses around and a change of guard on display at entrance . Price is cheap to gain entrance . And worth it Also you can drink tea inside one of the buildings - looks like a tea ceremony Many dressed up in traditional dress here .

Sunny day to walk, lot of visitors with hanbok (Korean traditional clothes) which you can hire from 15000 won for 4 hours, you can find the shops closed by to hire the clothes, inside the palace have a lot of places for photoshoot, it's a nice day out.

This is definitely one place to visit. The main palace with the changing of the Guards in the morning. Changing of the Guards is a really colorful ceremony with Drums, cymbals and oriental trumpets. The palace is large but relatively new in that it was only restored in the last 150 years but rebuilt using traditional methods. here are some tips, do consider buying the Combo ticket if you are planning to visit two or more palaces. its cheaper using a combo ticket. a second tip, the combo ticket includes a visit to the secret gardens at Gyeongbuk kung. The Secret gardens are not open to the public, even with a Combo ticket. you have to reserve a place and then only be able to get in with a secret garden ticket or the combo ticket. The secret garden is quite magical . we booked about 6 days in advance. the ticket reservation opened at midnight and by the time of 8am the next day all reservations had gone. So stay up and book at midnight. :)

review_title: Lovely Scene on a Snowy Day
review_body: This Palace was located in a park which I would recommend going to see. The day we went was snowing and cold, but I think that only added to the atmosphere. While there were people there, the park was rather serene save for some passing tour groups. You couldn't go in the palace, understandably, but its good for a picture.

The palace was the main royal palace of the Joseon dynasty. Built in 1395, located in northern Seoul, South Korea.The place was very beautiful and it was mesmerizing soaking on the beauty of it. Take a slow walk and take lots of photos.
Enjoyed the visit here since it showcases the history and beautiful culture of Korea! Must visit especially first timers!

review_title: changing of the guard at Gyeongbokgung Palace
review_body: If you can try to time your arrival to see the changing of the guard by the main gate. Its easy ti forget yoh are in a busy mordern city as you spend a couple of hours exploring the buildings and gardens in the palace grounds. Its well worth getting a guide to walk you through. Lical residents dress up in traditional costume which adds colour and charm to the experience. my puctures tell a better story than what I can describe. Well worth the visit

Have been to gyeongbokgung few times. This is a really nice place to visit. My family loves it a lot as you can try on hanbuk for free and takes pictures in front of the gyeongbokgung. Not sure if they still have this service now. Anyways, its a great place that highly recommended.

review_title: It's a must to see this place
review_body: I've seen other palaces in Seoul but this one has a different beauty and character. You will imagine how grandeous of this palace in the past. You can see how the rulers lived and how they were served by their attendants. Somehow interesting. The gardens and the view of the mountain made the scenery more beautiful. It is a relaxing place to stop and reflect for a moment. You will consider the garden view as romantic, too.

review_title: A must go place in Korea
review_body: A palace in a city. I was stayed near City Hall subway. I was walking about 10 minutes to the Palace. If you are wearing Hanbok located outside the Palace (nearby shop houses, the rental price usually KRW 10,000 for 2 hours), then the entrance fee to the Palace would be waived, or else per pax for adult would be KRW 3,000 as listed on Korea Tourism website. However, I bought 3 adult ticket at KRW 4,500 on Sunday, which I don't know the reason why cheaper. There were some flea market stalls located all along the way to GwangHuaMen (I guess only available on Sunday).

review_title: Big palace and top tourist attraction
review_body: Basically a palace with an admission fee. If you're not fond of historic places, you may explore other areas. This is a walking distance from Gwanghwamun Square as well.

Large palace that requires several hours to walk around the grounds and see the different buildings.Interesting to see the ancient palace grounds and gain some insight into Korean history. The grounds are well-maintained and clean. Can be crowded at times. When we went they had some sections of the palace sectioned off for renovation/restoration.Somewhat disappointing in that it seems the vast majority of the palace structures were all recreations. Personally, I would prefer to have the actual historical structures, but just roped/sectioned off to prevent damage from tourists.Regardless, we're glad to have visited the palace and thinks it's worthwhile to go when in Seoul.
The palace is a beautiful oasis in the middle of a large, modern city, sparking your imagination eith ideas of what life must have been like 600 years ago in Korea, when kings ruled the country.

review_title: Interesting place to visit as nowadays do not have many of such places
review_body: One of the more popular palaces in Seoul, and it is a short walking to another travellers place known as Bukchon Village. Enter via the main entrance and you can see 'guards' dressed up in ancient times standing still, 'welcoming' you to it.

review_title: Great place to learn about ancient Korean palace life.
review_body: The palace guide was very methodical and informative, patiently relating each facet of ancient palace life, especially how the rulers lived. Snippets of stories to make the narrative interesting. Brought us to the various buildings and gardens, explaining as we went along. Even waited for stragglers to gather before she continued.

review_title: Interesting look into the Korean past.
review_body: Great and well maintained palace and grounds. Very clean and pleasant with so many Koreans dressed in their traditional clothes. Recommend accepting the school-children guides, they do it for school credits, are well informed and give you a really interesting tour of the palace. The guides do it voluntarily and do not accept any money, not even when you offer to at least buy them a drink. Interesting history. Recommend when visiting Seoul.

review_title: Worth to visit this very beautiful palace
review_body: To explore the whole surrounding you need at least 2-3 hours. Very wide and cool fresh ambiance around the palace. So many tourists when we went there. You can rent Hanbok dress outside but my daughter did not like to wear it coz it's thick & itchy. We walked about 10 to 15 minutes to reach the Blue house which is at the back of the palace. But very nice to explore

Bf was excited looking at the guard swapping. It's a cultural program with volunteers dressing up in ancient outfits. What amazed me was how many men and women walked around through the garden taking selfies in beautiful traditional Korean clothes. Apparently you can rent them somewhere. A lot of couples in love taking romantic pictures. There's a cafe and another museum within.

Wonderful palace to see. Take a guide as you will miss so much without one. Went into the King court and bumped my head on the curved rock for the doorway. Please watch out for the as my head still hurts.

Very popular palace grounds for tourists and history or drama-loving locals wishing to experience romantic or glamorous moments as a palace maid, concubine or princess. Costume rentals are available nearby for about 20000 won for 4 hours. An open traditional musical song-dance troupe performs nearby followed by free photo sessions.

This was my second time at Gyeongbokgung Palace. The 1st time was on a tour so we didn't get to see some parts of it. It's a beautiful place to visit which has lots of history & great place to take photos as well.

the must do in seoul, entrance cost 3000won (3$)really typical and nice,one tip : nowadays there are korean teenagers students (wearing yellow clothe) they can guide you around the palace for free. they just want to communicate in english, they speak english perfectly for teenagers, so do it, if someone ask you to get a student guide, just say yes!
Together with a guide a visit to this palace will give you a good idea of the history of South Korea. See the changing of the guard and learn about former dynasties.

Big area with not a lot of exhibit to hold your attention. We were there during their Royal Culture Festival, so there was more activities going on and lots of people dressed up, which helped add to the atmosphere. Can be pretty hot in May, not a lot of shelter in the grounds. Ticketing counters are also in the open. Paths are bumpy and rocky, making it difficult to push a stroller around.It's recommended to visit the National Palace Museum first to get a better understanding of the history of the place as there isn't many signages within.

review_title: Renovated and it is open the place where Queen Nyungsung was assassinated.
review_body: The kitchen area had been renovated for several years and it had been open. And the cocubines' residence are under the renovated right now.The place where Queen was assassinated is open now for the limited period. It was not open at all for long time, and we had chance to see it 2 days ago. There were many visitors wearing Korean traditional costumes, Hanbok, because it is free admission for them, who wear the costume. They said there are many rental shops nearby. That made the place garden more beautiful.

Unlike most Asian Palaces you visit on city tours, this one had a lot of depth and diversification to it. The palace itself is beautiful but it leads into so many more things, such as the gardens and and water features. I normally find this stuff a bit of a bore; but this time round I was engaged and interested by the surroundings.... your walking through the past, with a thriving 21st century city surrounding you; it's very unique!

review_title: A Must See Palace in Seoul
review_body: Of all the palaces in Seoul, I think this is a must to visit. The palace ground is huge and the scenery is amazing. Going to palaces can give you a glimpse of Korea's colorful history.
Beautiful palace and changing of the guard. English speaking tour guide gave good info. Also several museums.
Big and sprawling . Very spread out and lots of dust and open spaces. The changing of the guards was interestin

My wife and I visited Gyeongbokgung Palace earlier this year. At first sight, the palace is impressive. However, once you see the building...there really isn't a lot to do. The grounds could use some greenery and some flowers. There's lots of open spaces...maybe add a fountain or two?Allow 30-45 minutes tops.
A must visit! Great palace, very big area and many buildings, garden and museum inside. Very beautiful trees. You can feel real Seoul here!
Very interesting and amazing what mankind can do . Make sure u guys get tour guide to explain to you the building and what it was made for and who accuplied it.

We visited here with a guide on our one full day in Seoul. Happily our visit was timed so we got to see the changing of the guard ceremony which really added to our experience. Lucky to have our guide who explained the symbolism of the construction and feng shui. There were tons of Korean school kids there on field trips - apparently it's a thing for them to dress up in traditional costumes - very fun to see them. Many were also doing a scavenger hunt and "take a pic with a foreigner" was on the list so we are in several pics Very fun, enjoyed our visit.

We went to the palace with a guide (Ben Moon from Viator) who was not only quite knowledgeable about the palace but about Korean history and the city of Seoul. The Palace itself is quite impressive. An absolute must if you are in Seoul.
Beautiful palace and worth a visit whilst in Seoul.Easy to get to and lovely to spend approximately 3-4 hours just walking around.Definitely worth a visit!

The palace is an expansive display of royal living in Korea. Beautifully painted rooms, buildings and courtyards. The changing of the guard, with a band, is colorful and well executed - at 10:00 AM - get there a little early to get a good spot on the ropes. Don't miss the queen's gardens in the back.

review_title: Up close and personal with Korean culture and traditions!
review_body: It was like walking in to a time warp that transports you back in olden times. A lot of guests were dressed in traditional Korean attire. We even got to see the changing of guards ceremony which my kids particularly found amazing. So much to see, so many nice spots to take photos of.

I think a tour guide is necessary for something like this so they can help explain the history to you. There are not placards that do that here. Also make sure to be there for the changing of the guard.

review_title: Very beautiful but limited access without reservation
review_body: Beautiful. many young women/men dressed in hanbok taking pictures. consider looking into reservation for inner place prior to visiting for access. Also, during certain time of the year, they apparently open for night visit with performances.

review_title: Nice palace, but didn't get a look inside.
review_body: I just visited the outside of the palace as everything inside was either closed or needs a tour reservation one day in advance. The outside is beautiful enough to enjoy although most of the 'common' quarters do look a like. There is a free museum next door about palace life as well as some other museums nearby. The day I was there though it was very crowded with kids on school trips but if they get the same assignment as while I was there lots of those kids will ask to take a picture with you (assignment was take picture with a foreigner) which depending on your personality could be annoying or cute.

This palace is beautiful and serene, the centre is main building, very huge surrounded with a small palace, love the pond in the back. There is separate museum at the end, also one old traditional house which is interesting to walk inside to see how people live in the olden days. Tour guide is available at certain times, the changing guard ceremony is one of a good event not to miss. It is worth to spend half day to visit this palace.
Dont miss it as it is an important place in the history of South Korea. At the center of the city. Interesting.
This time, I visited the palace in the Spring, and as in Fall, the palace and grounds are just gorgeous. Interesting to see the change of guards.

Beautiful palace in Seoul. My very first time visiting a palace in Seoul and I was immediately captivated by its timeless beauty. Highly recommend to visit for first timers to Seoul, South Korea. Easily accessible via public transport.

The very first time for us to be here in South Korea and it such a great experience for us and we are having fun and wonderful city tour. Our tour guide was Mia, such an ideal tour guide who was very energetic, friendjy and knowledgeable. Almost all she recommended about food to eat and to have/buy when we are in Korea were followed. Hope and pray, i could come back in different season and i want to go to Jeju Island on my next visit!

In terms of "Palace Grounds", I think this is the most beautiful.I have read reviews that this place is nothing special and that there are many people walking around. Simply not true, well, the "not special" part anyway.There will be lots of people walking around, its a main attraction when visiting Seoul so I'm not sure what why you would not expect this.This place is great for photography. So many different types of plants and flowers and lots of buildings to walk around and explore.Yo will see many people walking around in "Hanbok" which is a traditional dress of Korea. Colourful and beautiful imo.Grab a leaflet at the start which includes a map, its free and will ensure that you don't miss anything. There is also a way to see the "Blue House" which is where the president resides. I missed this first time round.Entrance is cheap and you can buy a drink and some snacks inside. I recommend taking a packed lunch, find a nice spot in the grounds and relax.The changing of the guard is a must see.A great day out for all.

review_title: Nothing really special. Some other palaces are even more attrative imho
review_body: Nothing really special. Some other palaces are even more attrative imho. Main place of attraction for thousands of tourists but I would not say this palace is the best one in Seoul. OF course it is the biggest one, time is running fast, you can easily spend 4-5 hours here and at the same time you'll have a feeling that it was 40-50 minutes... strange, really!

there were many people, but not much explanation about the buildings on the site. it might be nice for a picnic for family, but too much walking to see buildings which are not given any explanation in any language.

Entry into the palace is free when you walk in wearing a hanbok, which was what I did! I rented a hanbok from the nearby Bukchon Hanok Village. It costs 15,000 KRW for a 2 hour rental. It was very fun soaking in the history of the place, walking around in the hanbok and taking many photos! However, there were very few write-ups of the different spots in the palace so most of the time I actually didn't know what I was looking at. Most of the palace is also rather empty and there are many places where entry is denied and you can only look at the building from afar.
best place to know about korean culture and their history. their past and how time have changed everything
There are many beautiful palaces to visit in Seoul, and many feel like they are the same, but this one has the extra beauty of water ponds, so it became our favorite.
A very interesting and intriguing place to visit, however, strollers are not recommended. Queue for admission tickets was quick and easy.
Its a must visit on the first trip to korea , renting hanboks while taking picture with the palace and the great atmosphere along with friends.
Very interesting place to visit in Korea. If you are like me who enjoys looking at ancient architecture, then visiting this place is a must. It really capture the feeling of being in that century.

Visited this place many of times and keep coming back with friends. It's great to see the historical attire that the staff wears and also the changing of the guard show. Everyone loves to take pictures with the guards and you will see a lot of people wearing tradition Korean attire that they rent from the local shops around the palace. A must visit in Seoul

review_title: Impressive grounds - don't miss the Royal Guard Changing Ceremony
review_body: The Gyeongbokgung Palace is quite impressive. The area behind the (restored) front gate is public and you're able to watch the very nice Royal Guard Changing Ceremony even for free.If you wanna enter the actual Palace ground it'll cost you the small entrance fee of about 3$ only. Sure worth it.The palace ground is quite big and impressive. Nice buildings and architecture. Lots of green areas as well. Many visitors are roaming the area in (mostly rented) Hanboks. A nice sight. Like I said, don't miss out on the guard changing ceremony. The Royal Guards change at least at 2pm and 5pm. Before the ceremony you can watch them train, just outside the walls (eastside). We went on a weekday and got some good spots to watch, not many visitors. It's enough if you show up about 15-20mins before (at least in spring). You also can take some nice pics together with the guards just outside the main gate.All in all a nice place to visit. A few minutes away only from the Bukchon Hanok Village, don't miss out on that one if you're in the area.Wanna know more about me and my trips? Check my profile.

The palace contained beautiful architect and history. We can rent some traditional hanbok at fair price to take photo here. If you want to explore everything here, you should spend about 2 hours or more.

We went to see the palace and a special "rehearsal" for a huge ceremony. Very interesting! Lots of people, lots of music, lots of heat. The rehearsal went on for over 2 hours starting around 11 am on Sunday. They worked on tiny parts of the ceremony over and over, yet missed glaring errors. However, it was very interesting to watch this changing ceremony, hear the very unique music. Costumes were incredibly elaborate. Don't know if this is a normal rehearsal done frequently, or only occasionally. It was not the normal changing of the guard After the heat became too intense, we went into the Museum It was free but there is not much there. They don't seem to have much historical memorabilia but they do have 2 very cool vintage autos in the atrium which seem like the center for all attractions. Only spent about 1 hr in the museum and that was more than enough time to cool off and sit for awhile.

We get to see the guard changing shift at 10am. It was an interesting ceremony ! The palace was big and there were many nice places for taking pictures. A great experience to visit the Palace when in Korea !
We managed to catch the Guard Changing ceremony and it's very interesting. If you watch K-dramas, you get an idea how the Joseon era was. The palace is huge with many people wearing the hanbuk.

review_title: must see palace & changing of the guards
review_body: The original palace of the Joseon dynasty, that has been destroyed & rebuilt several times. Very impressive. Try to arrive on the hour to see the changing of the guards, an impressive display with several lines of guards with flags & drums. We were there on a Saturday and there were lots of Koreans dressed up in rented old traditional costumes (taking lots of selfies). Great historical site.
You feel youself go back to the Ancient Orient when visiting it the way it is built reminds you of thr great kingdoms that were once in this part of the world.

review_title: Come early for the guard changing ceremony
review_body: We came way too late and the ceremony just finished. So sad. The place is worth your half day time. It's beautiful and you will get to know Korea'a history better. Hanbok rental available on the area. Lots of people, both foreigner and korean, wear hanbok and stroll around the palace

Even if we visited the place in a rainy day we enjoyed its magnificence and beauty. There are many areas to visit: the library, meeting rooms, garden, small lak, etc. all beautiful and kept in excellent form. It gives the right idea of how was living in a place like this during the historical period. Well worth visit.

The palace gave an idea of life several 100 years ago. The pavilion in the centre of a lake was most attactive and, on the day I was there, was the background for wedding photos. We saw the colourful changing of the guard.

review_title: Incredible setting for this historic palace
review_body: By far one of my favorite palace in Seoul, with mountains on the background, beautiful at whatever season, it is the symbol I have kept from Seoul.

This is a must see if you are interested in some culture while you are in Seoul. I suggest having a tour guide that can give you insight into the history. The changing of the guards is a nice ceremony and the art behind the King's chair are things not to miss.

Before heading into this beautiful palace, make sure you visit one of the Hanbok (Korean traditional dresses) rental places and rent an outfit to really feel like you've just walked into the Chosun Dynasty of Korea. We rented dresses for 18,000Won for 4 hours. If you dress up you don't have to pay for the entrance fee at the Palace! You can then add accessories to your outfit but getting your hair braided and adding a traditional headband and pick out a handbag of your choice. This dressing up made it especially fun for my 2 daughters, aged 8 and 4. The photos we took were amazing! Go early so you don't get caught in a flood of people.
Very interesting area of kings palace. I visited similar in Tokyo but this has different spirit. I would recommend to visit it.

It is large palace with different buildings and big park. You can spend hours here and you won't be bored, you will be relaxed. After 10.00 starts big noise with incoming groups. I don't know whether It was because of election or it was usual.

review_title: Quite a spartan palace - bit disappointed
review_body: Was there to visit the palace in Apr 2017. Location is central u can take a subway to the station named after it and a short walk will take u to main gate. It happened to be I think royal culture week so many Koreans dressed in traditional hangbok so it was quite a sight. Entrance fee is not expensive only around 1500 won I think. I rented a audio guide in English but on hindsight I would suggest to take the free English guided tour at specific intervals daily. As the audio guide was cumbersome to use and info was a bit of overkill. But it gives some background on the palace which was central piece of Korean culture. The place was definitely much smaller than Beijing forbidden city which I feel is a much better tourist experience. Probably because most of buildings were burnt down during jap occupation and the rebuilt ones had spartan deco within. And there wasn't much exhibition on ancient palace exhibits unlike the forbidden city. Hence my average rating. But if u haven't been to china, I guess it's still a good way to spend 2-3 hours of your time understanding the Korean history and the royal family.

We had a lovely day wandering around Gyeongbokgung palace - the grounds are fairly expansive so wear comfy shoes, but many of the buildings aren't reconstructed yet so it is definitely ideal to visit when the weather is reliably nice. Super cheap to enter (₩3000) and a nice way to kill an afternoon.

Amazed with the culture where traditions and the historical areas have been preserved. This Palace is really wide and you need a long time to explore. If you really interested in seeing the whole area, better come early.
Nice place to walk around for a few hours. Very pretty and we were lucky to see the flower blossom during the season. Can get crowded from time to time but overall is a must see in seoul

We went here the first day were were in Seoul, normally closed on Tuesdays but open for Buddha's birthday. Make sure you take the free English speaking tour. Very informative and educational. Loved seeing the teenage girls in their traditional Korean dress (Hanbok). I heard they get in free if they wear it. Adds to the experience, fun to see them doing selfies. So cute. The gardens were amazing, don't miss the water view in the back. Peonies were in bloom. If you go out the back gate you can see the "Blue Housea', the president's residence. Very highly guarded.

There really is not that much to see in Seoul, but you shouldn't be disappointed by this place, its big and cost around $3 to $4 Australian to enter, they have a office room you can go and borrow ( yes its free) traditional Korean costumes to walk around the site in, its fun to take photos
One of five great Palaces to visit.Close to metro station.Free entry for over 60.The architecture is stunning.Guide leaflets in English most udeful

I visited the palace as part of a weekend in Seoul and it was a great way to spend some time. The grounds are beautiful and the palace buildings are steeped in history. I would recommend getting a guided tour as we did not and so the deeper history of the palace remained unknown.

Without doubt Gyeonbokgung Palace visit is a must in Seoul. Gardens and the buildings are amazing !! I love to see people dressed with the traditional dress. If you go in the right moment, you also can see the cherry trees blossom !

review_title: My mom loved it and she hates history
review_body: TIP: Before going check the time of the FREE MULTILINGUAL tours! They provide interesting backstory and add some richness to the experience - highly recommend.We visited this place on a rainy day but it was still worth it. My mom and I came together because of the overwhelming reviews we read online but when we got here we were totally blown away. The structures were beautiful and in pristine condition, the backstories all interesting.

Went there specifically to catch changing of the guards which take place at 10am and 2pm. There are also other guard changing performances at different times so check the Visit Korea website for more info. Nice place to stroll around for an hour or so.
See the changing of the Royal Guard Ceremony-so colorful and enchanting. Take subway to Gyeongbukgung, exit 5.

This palace is the biggest palace of Seoul built by Joseon dynasty. It further includes many sub palaces, kitchens, utility areas, stables etc. that makes it a perfect palace. It was built about 600 years ago but destroyed in a fire, the present palace was restored a century ago. A well maintained palace. The changing of guards ceremony is delightful. A must if you have interest in history & monuments. Happy travelling!!
For 3,ooo Won this palace is a bargain. We spent a few hours walking around the grounds and the beautiful colors and paints were mesmerizing. Interesting place to visit,

Depending on how informative is your guide is, this is a must do historic site visit. We were here on a rainy day so it was cold and wet walking through the palace grounds, but our guide was very informative which made the visit interesting. We took a private tour as we had 3 kids in tow- but we did not reach there in time for the changing of the palace guards. Many tourist and locals were in periodic costumes which added to the lovely ambiance in spite of the wet day.

One of the grand palaces of South Korea. Very good place to visit, especially if you're looking for cultural exposure. Reminder to either bring umbrellas, or use sunscreen or both. :)It's also a bit (or a lot) of a walk inside so make sure you're wearing comfortable clothes and shoes. :)It has a connection to the National Folk Museum so you can come out that end and continue on to Bukchon Hanok village. And, if you're still not tired, you can go ahead and walk to Changdeokgung Palace (it -is- far, but doable). ;)
When I visited there was a rehearsal going on for a concert. It very enjoyable. I enjoyed the sense of calm, beauty and history of the palace.

Gyeongbokgung is the main palace of jeoseon dynasty. This ground had witness the birth of hangeul, modern society, until japanese occupation. The palace ground is really beautiful. Placed in the heart of Seoul. I watched 2 days 1 night korean variety show. They had episode where they explore the palace. From that show, i become even more fascinated by the palace
This place is huge. You'll find many locals and tourists wearing hanbok here. It does get very crowded so it's best to to get here early.
On tour, interesting to know the history of the palace. Fun to see a lot of people dressed in Korean outfit.
Interesting palace, a lot of people are dress like the old Korean days, and walking around. Not too good on a rainy day.
Your typical palace in the middle of the city. Crowded with other tourists. Good for what it is and helpful to have a guide.

The best point of this palace is its guard attractionThere is two kind of attractionGwanghwamun gate performance and also Changing guard performance. Both of attraction are an hour separated..So dont ever miss itNotes: when we visited this palace the attraction that we saw were- Gwanghwamun gate performance was at 1.00 pm- Guard changing was at 2.00 pm

review_title: The free guided tours are fabulous!
review_body: It's an hour+ and brings you to the key areas with stories and explanations, more than what I expected for a free tour. The guides are humorous and very friendly. Visit the palace website for timings.

This Palace is located in a super central area of Seoul. I went for the changing of the guard and spent about an hour walking around. Its not as impressive as say the forbidden city in Beijing but its beautiful and i love how locals and some visitors dress up in the old style outfits and walk around the palace. Its something quite interesting to see. Its walking distance then to Insa-dong and also the area street. Def must visit and if time is short, you really can get around this in under an hour.

This is one of the big attractions in Seoul, but I felt there is so much to do in the city and this just isn't a top memory. The palace and the grounds are basically a reconstruction because of various wars. I know it's not their fault, but it makes it less interesting to me. It is pretty, but many of the buildings just feel like the same thing over and over. You're probably going to see it, but with such a wonderful city, I would recommend seeing more of modern Seoul.

review_title: Leave time and wear good shoes!
review_body: We were welcomed by a teen guide working on her English skills. She was amazing and knew lots of details about the history of the palace. She explained that she did the tours once a month for school credit. The changing of the guard is a colourful must see. The only disappointment was that all you get to see are empty buildings. There are a few sticks of furniture - such as a replica throne and bed frame but not much else.

An ensemble of palaces and annexed buildings with a very beautiful gardenWe had some bigger expectations than changing the guard, but the process is rather tricky maybe because of the translation of the ceremony in 3 languages

Wear Hanbok to get free admission into the palace. You can rent them for about 15000 - 20000 KRW for 4 hours. Hanbok rental shops could be found in the neighborhood of Gyeongbokgung, you cant rent them from the palace itself.Sumunjang (Royal Guard) Changing Ceremony 10:00, 14:00 / 20 minutes per ceremony Gwanghwamun Gate Guard-on-Duty Performance 11:00, 13:00 / 10 minutes per ceremony Sumungun (Gatekeeper) Military Training (outside Hyeopsaengmun Gate)09:30, 13:30 / 15 minutes per ceremony

review_title: Huge Palace with lots of history
review_body: Beautiful palace which you cant skip if you come to seoul. Try to come early so you can see the changing guard which always start at 10am. The enterance fee costs 3000 won per person, which is reasonable to see all sides of the palace. Book the guide tour for the middle palace in advance so you can go up and see the inside bit. This will cost you nothing.

We booked ahead for the secret garden tour. One quick point-the website for this booking is great, even allowed us to change our times easily. Enjoyed the tour of the gardens, very pretty and less crowded. The Palace grounds were nice too, with the exterior of the buildings beautifully decorated. Enjoyed seeing visitors in their traditional Korean dress too, gives the visit a fun twist.

review_title: The Facade doesn't do it justice
review_body: Charming huge palace. Great to visit in the weekend because there's plenty of tourists who like to dress up and have their picture taken while wearing traditional Hanbok.The first area of the Palace doesn't do it justice. Go explore to the other wings and you'll discover beauty everywhere.

I love history so I always try to visit local historical sites to get a deeper understanding of a local history. Though the style was borrowed from ancient China it still has its own unique Korean features.
I find the history very interesting especially after visiting the Korea History Museum. The palace is amazing. Sat for a while to soak in the history I learned.

As the main and biggest palace in Seoul, Gyeongbukgong is a must visit attraction. You can get in free if you're wearing a hanbok.Got to see the changing of the guards at 10 am. I think it can be skipped, but if you're there anyway, it's still good to catch. With a map/short guide available, one can go around on their own, but would advise to take a guided tour since they offer it free anyway. It's a very big complex so it's best to wear comfortable shoes. Inside the complex is the National Folk Museum and you can get it there for free as well. So many beautiful historical sites in this palace - architecture, design and nature in one. Placed against a lovely mountain background, you will understand why this site was chosen as the main palace.
Enjoyed this place very much. Their is a lot of tourists so be prepared. If you wear traditional Korean clothes than you can waive the 5 US dollar fee that is required to go inside.

Today I have visited Gyeongbokghng Palace which is at walking distance from Gyeongbokghng metro station.The palace is huge is size and you have to walk a lot to cover all the parts of palace.The Korean architecture is full of colours & they use lot of wood for making building.The live music show during the visit was treat for the eyes ( girls playing drums).Also many local people were dressed in Korean colourful traditional dresses, everyone looking great.A not to miss place ..

review_title: This is a tour Guides manditary visit
review_body: When in Seoul all visitors seem to go to this old Palace as the center piece of Sth Korean history which indeed it was. Holds great attraction for visitors from Japan who seem to arrive here by the bus load. A great stroll though history

Gyeongbokgung palace was our first highlights of our Korean adventure. We higher a local guide that introduced to us to all palace secrets and stories and regardless that most of it that we so was a reproduction from originally made palace due to all destruction that happened, we had a more than clear and authentic experience in understanding the greatness of architecture, art and inventions that can put our European medieval knowledge and accomplishment at shame. Monument more than worth to be put on MUST SEE list!

I was lucky enough to visit here on the last Wednesday of the month when entry to public attractions such as this are free.The palace is beautiful and a great way to spend a couple of hours. The place is huge, much larger than I expected so make sure you have plenty of time to explore.

It was neat but it was busy, too busy. Would have been a better experience to go outside of the changing of the guards to experience the palace. Don't get me wrong the palace is quite beautiful but the crowds were particular busy at this time. The crowds did provide a great opportunity for people watching, a favourite travel activity.
Made it in time for the parade.The guards wore very colorful attire The palace was really huge so lots of walking to do if you want to see the grounds. Its very crowded as its a tourist attraction

review_title: A Palace in the middle of Seoul
review_body: This palace is located in the middle of town, surrounded by Seoul city, very interesting. I got here with a tour guide but I did not pay attention to the explanation, just taking some pictures which are beautiful. Well, a historical side in the city, very clean, and beautiful sceneries. But, you have to be ready to take a long walk.

review_title: Tea and changing of the guard
review_body: Make sure to catch the changing of the guard. It is a nice display of old Korean culture. Put notice to the many Korean visitors in traditional costumes. It gives the place a nice atmosphere. The tea house is rich decorated and serves Korean tea and sweets.

The Gyeongbokgung Palae is de biggest of the five grand palaces built by the kings of the Joseon Dynasty. The magnificant Gwanghwamun entrance gate is situated right in the hear of Seoul and one of its most famous landmarks. if you don't have much time for your visit to Seoul, this place can't be missed. The palace buildings are mostly reconstructions, because lots of the buildings were destroyed during the Japanese occupation. The Koreans took great care in reconstructing the building as faithfully as possible.The site is very big, so you'll at least need two hours to see everything. When in a hurry make sure not to miss Gyeonghoeru, a beautiful construction sitting on top of 48 stone pillars. reflected in the surrounding artificial lake. Likewise he trone hall (Geunjeongjeon) is a National Treasure which will leave a lasting impression.Don't miss the traditional changing of the guards ceremony!
Good place,good culture,but not much direction about a place in english writing.so much turn around to find what i want to.very big place need much time to around it

We spent a very enjoyable few hours at this palace. It covers a surprisingly large area, so you do need time to explore it all. The setting, with mountains behind, is wonderful and having so many locals dressed in Hanbok adds to the enjoyment. The combination ticket, which gives entry to 4 palaces and Jongmyo Shrine for W10,000 (less than £7) make it excellent value for money. Not to be missed.

review_title: Night tour and traditional music concert
review_body: The Korean Tourism Organisation post an announcement that the Palace has a special night opening. I went there and find a traditional concert in open air. superb.THe night view - superbDo join the Korean Tourism Organization facebook for notification of special events.

Visited this place... Beautiful and good for taking pictures.... There are many place in the city... Mostly similar... Its better to choose 2 palace only... Any two... Because almost all palaces are same...

review_title: Knowing more about Korea's Joseon Dynasty
review_body: It's kind of dry at first, now knowing what to expect inside. What you first see upon reaching Gyeongnokgung grounds is the largest structure. Once you're inside, you will be greeted with more old Korean palace, temples and houses and greenery. While inside the palace grounds, you can see this mountain that accentuates the whole scenery. Each area gives a new perspective, all equally magnificent. Don't miss this while in Seoul.

It's is always great and inspiring to visit historic locations like the palaces in South Korea, and this is one of the ones that have to visit.We were lucky to take pictures with local students who dressed up in traditional clothes who were visiting the palace on that day.

After living in Japan for 5 years, I feel that sometimes I get a bit oversaturated with all the beautiful things I've seen here, but this palace still managed to impress me with its size and beautiful gardens. It was so enjoyable walking around, very serene and amazing. Definitely a must-visit if you're in Seoul! If you can make it when the changing of guards occurs, you should definitely try as the ceremony of it is really cool to experience.
A nice palace, a bit crowded during our visit, but worth a visit and take a visit wearing hanbok, a traditional korean dress.

We enjoyed going through out the grounds of this Grand Palace. My favorite place was the Banquet Building. It was three levels high on the edge of a lovely lake surrounded by willow trees. Outside the palace there are businesses where you can rent a beautiful traditional Hanbok outfit to wear for the day. We didn't rent any of them, but really enjoyed seeing all the beautiful Hanboks worn by others, it really added to the experience. We also visited the National Folk Museum, which is also on the same grounds of the palace. I recommend going to it. As we were leaving we were able to see the changing of the guards. Highly recommended that you go here when visiting Seoul. One of our family members has problems walking great distances, so they rented a wheelchair. These chairs are very narrow in the seat. She isn't over weight but she had problems sitting in it.

review_title: One of the must see places
review_body: Went during the Lunar New Year. Admission was free and you get to go the Natural Folk Museum while you are there. There were cultural performances and activities all around the place you can do. I even managed to try on their traditional hanbok for free!
Really gave a feeling for the scale of a palace and the significance of the royal family. Very much and "outside" tour with little insight into the life in the buildings

review_title: Best sight - but its all relative
review_body: Visited with two young kids - you can tell an attempt was made to make the place wheel chair accessible but we had a really hard time getting the stroller across the grounds. . There's not much to see inside as most of its not original but reconstruction. If you been to the Imperial palace in other Asian cities (Beijing, Tokyo, Taipei) you will not find this site particularly impressive. On the plus side - admission is cheap and tourist sights are few in the city. Makes a relaxing stroll on a sunny day.Be mindful it closes on Tuesday
A great place to wander around and wonder and take photos. If possible make sure to take in the changing of the guard as it is quite special. A very worthwhile afternoon or morning!
It is a very beautiful place which definity needs a visit. It gives you a taste of the local culture and is definitely highly recommended

review_title: Most grand of the five palaces
review_body: We were fortunate to get there in time to see the changing of the guard which of itself would have been worth the visit. It has suffered from several fires and eventually was burned down during the Japanese occupation. Fortunately, it has been reconstructed several times and now brought back to its former glory.

No doubt the palace is a must see while in Seoul. Easy accessible by subway but if possible go on a weekday. I went on a Saturday and it was crowded with people. It seems that on Saturdays children from schools are brought here as a field trip so you have 5-7 years old running all over.  On the other hand, the architecture was so beautiful is amazing to see that even though most of the palace was badly deteriorated as a result of the Japanese invasion the efforts for reconstruction allows tourist to submerge in this wonder.

Haven't been to many palaces in my lifetime, but walking through this one certainly made for a nice, informative afternoon! Loads of people in Hanbok (admission is free is you are wearing one?) enjoying themselves. The buildings themselves are georgous inside and out. Heartbreakingly poignant were the residences for Empress Myeongseong. With the mountains looming on the one side and skyscrapers on the other, an overall interesting exploration of Korea's past. Maybe try to visit on off-peak hours, it got quite busy and crowded on our way out.

The architecture of the buildings are nice and too many Koreans wearing hanbok the Korean costume, so it gives you feeling of tradition and culture of Korea while you are there. The palace has many buildings and there are national folk museum and national palace museum also so you visit them all together and you will have very good Korean cultural experience. Don't miss the changing of the guards during your visit we watched them at 2:00 pm but i think they have another changing show at 11:00 am. You can join your visit with Insandong area which it is very near about 10-15 minutes walking and one stop by metro.

review_title: One of the best sight seeing in Seoul
review_body: We absorbed so much of Korean history when we went there. From watching changing of guard to viewing the palace.... I would recommend it to anyone.

review_title: A beautiful old mini-city for royalty
review_body: We arrived at 1pm when there was a guard duty ceremony, and then went on the free one hour English guided tour. People wearing traditional dress were everywhere. Beautiful guardens and interesting buildings and statues. With several museums inside too.

My wife and I went to Seoul so I could visit sites and locations from serving there many years ago in the military. We like the luxury of Four Seasons hotels but like the location of the Seoul Four Seasons as it was central to the locations I wanted to visit. My contacts with the staff started long before we arrived. I email the Concierge in relation to the locations I wanted to visit and how to best coordinate my travels. In a few emails we had complete a plan which included all sites within our limited time. The Concierge team is excellent. They continued to guide us after we arrived.When we checked in we soon learn this excellence extended though the entire staff from the escort to our room, dining staff, everyone. We felt very much at home and comfortable. We had a premiere room with a great view of modern Seoul. The room was very spacious, clean, modern and well equipped for any traveler. The first evening we ate a late dinner at the hotel. Great service and great food, a sampling of Korean dished. Each morning we ate at the breakfast buffet. We managed to eat light but walking and viewing all the culinary offerings is a tour in its self.An excellent exhibit of historic Korean royal architecture. Visit in the mornings around 10:00 am entering at the South Gate to catch the changing of the royal guards. Note the building techniques, colors and layout to the palace buildings. At extensive as these palace grounds are the represent only about 14% of the original structures.Make it a point to exit through the North Gate. The building straight head is the Presidential Blue house (named for its blue title roof). Korea’s equivalent to the White House.

review_title: Discover one of favourite film locations in Korean Drama
review_body: This is one of the old palace in Seoul.You will definitely love this place if you are a fan of Korean drama, you can find many familiar corners where movies were filmed. Wearing Hanbok , walking around the palace is a great experience for Korean fan too. You can hire custom some place such as Hanok Village , they allow you to hire it from 1 hour to 1 day.

I was there in late April , all threes were blooming inside and made this palace like a heaven , interesting views and nice architectures, many ladies and gents worn Korean customs and were roaming there I could imagine that I was in 500 years back , was such a great experience , don't miss it :)
Make sure you get to see the changing of the guard which happens at regular intervals throughout the day

Well kept palace with plenty of photo taking opportunities. Korean girls get in free if they dress in traditional South Korean dresses which adds nicely to the authenticity and they're more than happy for you to have your photos taken with them as long as they can have photos with you too.
This place is same location with national folks museum. I came here by walk from insadong and bukchon.Better you take pic here when using hanbok ;))
We came here on a private tour from the Incheon Cruise Port. Very nice place to walk around. I would come here again and spend some more time.

Its was nice and big palace. There are tour guide in english, japan & korea. Please rent hanbok and take picture in this area! there are walking distance between palace & national folk village. Bukchon hanok village also walking distance!

I've been to other palaces in Asia that has more information . This was just little halls after halls with no information and any cultural history. The architecture of the buildings are nice . So took some pictures but not worth the visit if you're looking for detailed tours. I expected to see some lovely gardens and rooms with beautiful furniture and information on how and what they used each hall for . So I was very dissapointed.

review_title: Must have been an awesome place when it was operating as a real palace
review_body: Had part of a morning spare in Seoul so went for a short walk and tumbled upon this palace, dating back to 1395. It sits juxtaposed against mirrored glass modern buildings but the serenity within its walls holds the modern world at bay. The outer walls are long and impressive but they nevertheless still hide the scale of what lies behind. One can but only imagine life within the cloistered palace walls and its inner and outer courts, gardens and lake. After reading about the destruction of the palace by fire during the Japanese invasion in 1592 and the taking apart by the Japanese of the reconstructed buildings during their occupation between 1910 - 1945, one must admire the Korean spirit and skill in ensuring such a faithful restoration of the Heungnyemun Gate, the Gwanghwamun Gate and the various royal and princely quarters. Walking through the palace grounds while there were so many locals wearing traditional costume/clothing during their own visits made it easier to imagine the daily bustle of a bygone era.An interesting place to visit.

It was absolutely stunning and bigger than I thought it would be. We had conveniently come on a cultural day (which is the last wednesday of every month) so entrance was free!! We also got a free English tour which I would highly recommend. She was super nice and friendly!! You can just find a tour there so look up the times when your language will be available. I learned way more history than I would've by just looking. Overall, a very beautiful place with lots of history

Gyeongbokgung Palace is arguably regarded as being the most beautiful and grandest of all five palaces. It also houses the National Palace Museum of Korea and the National Folk Museum within the premises of the complex.

We didn't get into the palace but only the square with two big gates. There were many tourists (probably) wearing hanbok, which make me think of the scenes in Korean dramas. A historic site but I only spent around 15 minutes taking pictures there.
Was really impressed by the palace and spent most of a full day there wandering around all of the different buildings.

We took the Airport Express Train from Incheon to Seoul in 50 minutes. Purchased the Express Ticket at the airport, easily followed the orange signs, assigned seats, off in Seoul. Short subway and a short walk and were at the Palace at 10 am in time for changing of the guards ceremony. Not to be missed. Very colorful and ornate. The Palace is huge. A court yard within a court yard within a court yard. Beautiful. Make sure to find the gardens. Gives you an idea of the landscaping of the past. Serene.

Wonderful complex enhanced by very knowledgeable guide who described the site and history entertainingly and clearly making the visit very enjoyable. The Palace is a 'Must See' for any visitor to Seoul.

We went by taxi from our hotel down past The Square on a Sunday - where 1000,s of people were setting up another protest for the day & arrived @ Gyeongbokgung Palace Gate to be greeted by 100,s of people all dressed up in various costumes taking pictures of each other.Gyeongbokgung Palace ls huge & overlooks The Square & the city buildings in the background.We took photos of & had photos taken with hundreds of attractive costume dressed young women from many countries - Singapore- Taiwan - Japan - China - Sth Korea - USA ,with eeryone having a wonderful time .A few men were dressed up albeit they didnt look anywhere as good as the women did.There is a changing of the Guard outside The Palace on a regular basis & the public are encouraged to have photos taken with the assembled Guards as they stand to attention outside The Palace Gate.More Photos with the lovely Cherry Blossom trees in the Palace Grounds & it was time to leave this picture paradise.Highly recommended & the best part of our time in this great city

Gyeongbpkgung is so beautiful and traditional. I think the best beautiful is the house behind the palace and some house middle the river. When I went there the water is bacame ice hahaah but it's look so beautiful.

I thought that this place was going to look like forbidden city, huge and all that. But It s not.This is a serene place with beautiful cherry blossom and scenic building. Dont forget to watch the guard changing ceremony, it was pretty impressive. And oh, free admission if you are wearing hanbok. So make sure you rent a hanbok nearby, there are so many choices.

review_title: Worth a visit but smaller than forbidden city
review_body: Nice stroll around Gyeongbokgung. Touristy thing to do... but we are indeed tourists. Decent gardens at the back.

This is a great place to learn the Joseon dynasty period of Korea. It is fascinating to see a huge palace complex in the middle of a city. The highlight of this place is the changing of guards ceremony, as if traveling back in time.

review_title: You can't miss on Gyeongbokgung palace when you are in Seoul
review_body: This place is a must-see, especially if you want to learn more about Korean history. The palace itself is stunning, but you can feel more like a part of the korean history if you wear a hanbok (korean traditional clothes) which you can borrow from a nearby hanbok rental.

review_title: Great way to spend a few hours.
review_body: Interesting part of history. Changing of the guards was worth a look. The gardens are lovely for a stroll.
Not knowing much of the Korean history the Gyeongbung palace is a nice visit..huge complex and with nice weather a god walk..

Maybe because I've been to the forbidden city in Beijing. This palace seemed a little plain, but is a great location for Korean-themed photoshooting. There's is an entrance fee of 3,000 Korean wons btw.
The palace is well maintained and very clean. Impressed with the palace building and their history. Very nice place to take photos.

Our tourist Guide told us a lot of the history of this place and we are so amused of the tale. I love the cherry blossom trees around the palace area. I just find it soulful roaming around at this wonderful place

An absolute must. I was here for the afternoon and wish that I had allowed a full day. Acres and acres of space and lots to explore. The photographic opportunities are in abundance here. It was extremely busy and a hot sunny day with blossom everywhere. Many, many couples taking photographs in traditional dress which is so stunning. Even though it was busy, you can still lose yourself in the grounds and find some quiet spots to sit with a picnic lunch if you wish. The admission for myself was only 3000 won which is super super cheap and makes English Heritage Admission prices absolutely ludicrous. I came away having had a super day with stacks of wonderful memories and photographs.

review_title: Great place to learn Korea history and tradition!
review_body: I would like to recommend this place to foreigners who visit to Korea.You can learn Korea history and tradition!Also, can feel Korean life style.You can get to there by subway No.3 (Orange line).

review_title: Great place to learn Korea history and tradition!
review_body: Korea Grand Palace "Kyoung Bok Gung"Great place to learn Korea history and tradition.You can get there by subway No.3 (Orange line).I've been to Old Palace in other countries, because, can know their history and tradition.Also, this place is same.Really different architecture and life style.I would like to recommend this place to foreigners who visit to Korea.

If you're visiting Seoul this is a must see! We loved this Palace and we're in awe of its beauty. My mother in law had a broken toe so this was a hard day for her but we did get her a wheelchair. A lot of Walking and uneven ground with some stairs made for a painful day for her but she made it! Stay for the changing of the guard ceremony if possible.

Nestled in the city centre of Seoul was the beautiful palace of Gyeongbukgung. The cherry blossom was everywhere in the palace which turned it into charm and amazing! Travelling to the palace by using public transportation was very convenient, just outside Exit 5 of subway station. Make sure you take time to observe the guard shift change at the main gate - so amazing!

review_title: A must visit place in Seoul
review_body: Korea's last dynasty's palace(Joseon Dynasty). If you are a foreigner or first time visiting abroad born korean, you must visit this palace. Use a guided tour. You will learn and understand the construction and the design. Don't forget to visit the museum. You will see the Korea's then and now.
great! It was a national palace of Chosun dynasty. Although I am not an expert at architecture, i can feel the beauty of ancient asian tradition.

review_title: Average but probably best thing to do in Seoul
review_body: The palace complex is not the original one. The former complex was ransacked by the Japanese when they occupied the land. Work is in progress to restore the complex. In general, it is not the most beautiful palace I have ever seen. It's pale comparison to palaces in Japan. However, it should be one of the best options in Seoul especially it's close the Bukchon village where you can have combined walking tour.

This was the first palace built in the Joseon dynasty and is where the dynasty's 500-year history began. There are five remaining palaces in Seoul and Gyeongbokgung is the largest. The palace offers visitors a glimpse into the Joseon's royal culture, life and architecture. You can also visit the National Palace Museum (located near the entrance of the palace) to learn more about the Joseon royal culture. To learn about the Korean lifestyle in the past, you can visit the National Folk Museum of Korea.Be prepared for a long walk if you want to explore the entire palace area, it was so huge! I visited in spring 2017 and the palace garden was so beautiful with all the cherry blossom trees. If you wear a hanbok, you can enter for free. The changing of the guards ceremony is also not to be missed!

Absolutely a beautiful palace that reflects traditional local culture and history. You may want to visit at the time that free English speaking your guide provided near the entrance- you can get detailed info visitor centers- to get most of the palace.

review_title: Beautiful palace with very nice view at spring
review_body: I visit at spring time when the flowers are blossoms. I recomend to rent a hanbok at street around the palace before enter the palace and feel like a royal family
Beautiful. Peaceful!interesting!Worth to visit I can spend whole day here !thats how beautiful it is!

I had such a great day going around the palace grounds. The grounds were fascinating and the crowds were average. It only cost approx $4 CDN to enter and enjoy the area for as long as you can discover.

A real highlight of my trip. The Palace grounds are amazing and with the mountain ranges in the background, make for some superb photos. I would suggest getting here early and purchasing the four Palace day pass as it's great value. Really, a must see.

The performance is great. It's wonderful to see how the traditions are preserved through such performances. The guards were very professional an didn't flinch even though tourists were all around them buzzing with cameras.

This is actually a palace complex since there are several palaces in the same area with the one in picture being located in a big pond while 2 other palaces are located on land. Very nice place to relax and enjoy the scenery in Seoul as even the surrounding area of the palace is nice with mountains, trees and modern buildings.

review_title: Wear Hanbok and free to enter
review_body: We were told by our Korean friends to wear Hanbok (Korean traditional clothing) and will get free entrance to Gyeongbokgung Palace. We rented 4 hours for 2 sets, total 30, 000 won near the palace. Many tourists and even locals wear the Hanbok in; we felt at ease. I would highly recommend to do so, great experience wearing Hanbok into palace and have a taste how the older times people have to manage.

review_title: Don't miss the Change of Guards
review_body: We enjoyed the Change of Guards ceremony prior to visiting the palace. It is a large area and we had a guided tour with English explanations that made it of much more value.
Cool place to see while in Seoul. Took a 90 minute walking tour and wondered around afterward.Tour guide was informative.

We went to the palace for the free english guided tour... it was very informative and Kim was very helpful and nice. The palace was BEAUTIFUL! So much details and beauty on the palace and its entire neighborhood esp for the photo geeks out there! it's a must visit place when visiting South Korea!

review_title: The Palace which open your minds and feels the history
review_body: We visit the Palace as it is one of our plan to view the history of South Korea. The Gyeongbokgung Palace is a huge complex area. They keep the traditional ceremony in the complex, e.g. exchange guard ceremony. If you have time you can rent Korean traditional dress outside the Palace, and took picture surrounding the Palace. There is lake also near the Palace which is so quiet and calm. A very recommended place when you visit Korea.
The palace was amazing.Being the onset of spring,the trees at the palace was covered in beautiful blossoms

This is the biggest and most impressive temple in Seoul. It has lots of different temples that are all beautiful. You can easily spend a day walking round here. A must do for a visit to Seoul. It's also reasonably priced and there are lots of locals dressed up in traditional dress.

I appreciate Korean Palaces so much because it shows how much they treasure their history. It was well preserved and strictly kept clean, and thus it has become a highly respected place. I wish the Philippines valued its history as much as Koreans did. :(
Go there for a good morning walk.Nothing much to see. Very empty palace. Lucky the entrance fee is not expensive.

The place is oozing with history and the Korean people should be proud of their heritage. Its vast place and well maintained even if there is a long walk everything was dandy and clean. Memorable experience

We go there and rent hanbok to use in the place...There so much old building with traditional ornament... as i am architect i like this place an a building concept... there are a hole to make heater for the king's throne...we should be accompanied by a guide to the history and forms to explain of building...

Catch the changing of the guard ceremony at 10am. Nice place lots of photo opportunities. Lots of walking required. The largest imperial palace built in the 14th century Gyongbokgung Palace. There's a marvelous changing of the guard ceremony at 10am and if you come in traditional costume, you get an entrance fee discount!
The palace is beautiful and a great visit while in Seoul. At 2pm we were fortunate enough to see the guard shift at the palace entrance. Definitely an amazing experience.

We visited the palace on Sunday morning in early April, just when the cherry trees starting to blossoms. We saw many girls, boys, women and men walking around in their hanbok. It was such a pretty sight to see. It felt almost like we traveled back in time during the imperial time. Unforgettable time.

review_title: If You Love Architecture & history , Then This is the Placr
review_body: If you want to learn Korea's roots, the Gyeongbokgung Palace is an amazing spot.Doing research, having an audio guide or a tour guide is a recommendation when you want to learn more of what you'll see in the palace & it is worth it. The architecture we saw was amazing and reminds us a tad of the Chinese culture as well. It is also an amazing spot for capturing photographs.PS: I heard from our tour guide that if you rent & wear a Hanbok, you get free entrance to the palace. :)

review_title: Very busy but still worth it
review_body: It's a very busy place during weekends, but I do consider it to be worth it. You have to pay a small fee for the entrance but can stay as long as you'd like to. You're able to rent some historical and traditional Korean clothes for enhance the experience.

review_title: Not much to see except the changing of guards
review_body: The reason why people flock to see this sight is because of it historical value. At the same time, they shot a popular korea novela here. But as my title mentions, not much to see except the changing of guards which happens only at 10am daily.

We visited this palace on a beautiful sunny day and it was great to see the change of guard ceremony. Try to schedule your visit during the change of guard ceremony which happens several times during the day. The staff even lets you wear the traditional outfit for free of cost and it's a great photo opportunity. Overall a great vibe and a must do when you are in Seoul. You will spot a lot of couples wearing traditional hanbok.

This is a must-see for anyone visiting Seoul. Try to arrive on a weekday when it's not so crowded. Be sure to walk Sejongdaero and visit the statues of Admiral Yi Sun Shin and King Sejong as you approach the palace. Beautiful and historic.

This palace has been preserved quite beautifully. Admission is a mere $4USD and quite worth it. We happened to be lucky enough to catch all the cherry blossoms and flowers blooming. Many people choose to rent the traditional Hanboks prior to entering, as it's quite inexpensive and makes a beautiful photograph.

Beautiful architecture. huge space to walk. a must place to visit when you go to Seoul. Can rent their Hanbok traditional outfit and take pictures at the palace. Do go during the time of change of guards which will be around 12:30 - 1pm.

Good place to visit for historical sightseeing. We visited the place in the morning and were intrigued when we saw ancient Korean dresses wore by both men and women. The place is big which is good for strolling around enjoying the palaces and the lakes

My husband and I had a chance to visit this palace. The grounds are very nice. Great spot for photography and learning about Korean culture and history. Have on closed toe shoes made for walking because some areas around the grounds are gravel or compact soil. Worth a visit when in Seoul!

review_title: Worth a visit and very near to major train stations
review_body: We went Nov 2016; was a interesting, historical kind of visit. If you like museums, history and sight-seeing, you should visit. There were other palaces but we decided to visit this one as it is one of the most accessible, being close to central Seoul. Furthermore, after this, we walked to the Gwanghwamun Square where we could see the protests preparation (during the weekdays)!
Excellent English language tour by knowledgable guide. Also free entry to museum kept us occupied for a couple of hours with a visit to the excellent cafe.

review_title: Amazing! Must visit free guard costume dress up area!
review_body: After around 15 mins after each of the four guard changing ceremonies during the day, there is the option to dress up (for free) as a palace guard. You get a choice of up to 4 different robes etc. And you can have a group size of up to 6 where you can all go in together to wander around the main square area. The 5 minute restriction time starts when the last member of your group is dressed!!We are loved this activity and we even had local korean students asking us to take selfies with them. The palace itself is very beautiful and worth the entrance fee to wander around the grounds. The lake is particularly beautiful.
One palace that should be visited is this one. Awesome blossoms and very beautiful!! Crowded but you still have your space.

Many of the buildings are restored with attention to the original. Make this a must-visit on your sightseeing agenda. There are a few free English speaking guides available. It is also one of the stops on sightseeing tours but they generally rush you, so I would recommend that you go on your own and enrich yourself with all the cultural and historical information. A Changing Of The Guards ceremony is particularly interesting. Nearby, also visit the Blue House, residence of the President.

This is such a nice and tranquil place where you have beautiful views, ambience, heritage, beauty of colors and calm waters all stiched together in one place where you can unwind and seek peace of mind. Amazing for photography too.

We were there to see the changing of the guards, in traditional outfits upon entering. Great place to take pictures. Grounds are very peaceful. Loved the ones dressed in traditional outfits, it adds to the experience. This also gets them free admission.

review_title: A very good place to visit
review_body: We could see cherry at the entrance of the Palace. The Palace is really big. Apart from different places or rooms you can see, the scenery inside is fantastic! I took a lot of photos of those beautiful scenes. It is really worth of paying 3000 won entry fee to have a look.
historical place and worth to visit.get to know the history of Seoul and the Joseon Dynasty.wonderful building structures.
Free entry if you are wearing hanbok. The palace closed every Tuesday. It's a good place to take photo.
Being here is like traveling back in time. Going through the palace you'll see and feel how they've lived.

If you want go to another 3 palace and Jongmyo shrine better you but package for 4 palace and Jongmyo Shrine and you can go in 1 day from morning 9.00 AM (South Korea - Seoul time) take alot of picture
There is an entertaining changing of the guards ceremony at certain time interval. You can took pictures with the guards too. An amazing historical palace to visit in Seoul.
