Great place to get the early history of Seoul and the Joseon Dynasty. Wonderfully restored buildings and grounds gives insight to what life was like during this time period. Get there for the changing of the guard ceremony as it is fascinating.

review_title: Walking around Seoul looking at the sites
review_body: Walking on a Saturday afternoon with limited time, went to this palace, terrific, just 3,000 Wan and there is a good 3 hours f sightseeing to be had. Well worth the visit and the walk to get there down the long avenue.

Worth a visit. It was spectacular in Autumn. This mostly re-constructed complex was historically interesting. The changing of the guards was contrived but entertaining enough. The real value was towards the back of the complex as the crowds thinned there were some very interesting buildings in the setting of beautiful deciduous trees which made for some great photos and memories.

We went with family and explored this amazing palace and were not disappointed. Spring is the best time--mid-April when the flowers are blooming. Be sure to visit the museums--I preferred the National Folk museum as it showed a lot more of the Korean culture. There are free guided tours in several languages during the day that start near the information center that last about 1 hour but we found just reading the brochure and taking our time the best way to go.

This palace is the largest among the grand palaces built by the Joseon Dynasty; so obviously very important part of SK's history and culture. It's huge and very picturesque esp the time we visited. It was in January this year. It snowed the day before our arrival and flurry on the day of our visit, and it covered the palace with snow and was very pretty. The visitors, being winter, were fewer, and so we're able to take beautiful photos. Also, the district where Gyeokbokgung Palace is located is my favorite. It's like the history and art district of Seoul. There were art museums, even the contemporary ones. Also it's near Bukchon Hanok Village. I really want to visit again and take more photos. Whilst the snow/winter made the photos we took looked amazing, it also cut our visit short because S.Korea's winter can be brutally cold! The snow slowed us down also as it was very slipper to walk.

review_title: Great place to visit! Very impressive.
review_body: What a great place to visit and see! Totally loved our tour of this site. A lot of cool history and a lot to see!

review_title: They are still trying to rebuild this
review_body: Except for central part of the palace, most were destroyed by fire or during the Japanese Invasion but be assure the rebuilding would take decades to complete.It will not be as grand as the Forbidden Palace but you can imagine the king's simple lifestyle. My guide told me, the kings were rather short-lived, died around age of around 45+ and do not have time for romance like what we saw in the korean serial.I spent an entire day here, joined guided tour in English as well as Chinese.Visited 2 free museums next to the palace as well.

review_title: Not to miss if you are in Seoul
review_body: Not to miss if you are in Seoul historical area. This palace was the main residence of the king for several hundred years.In front of the Gwangghwamum gate and in the inner courtyard you should also attend the guard changing ceremony provided at specific times. It lasts approx. 10 minsIt is recommended to get part of a free guided tour provided in several languages in order to learn about the historical aspect of the park and buildings .During spring time the trees are starting to bloom and everything becomes beautiful.The entry fee of 3000W (approx. 3$) is very reasonable.

review_title: beautiful palace surrounded by different blooms of spring flowers
review_body: Beautiful palace surrounded by various blooms of the spring. Nice place for a stroll and learn about Korea's culture and history. Exit at Gwanghwamun station Exit 9 and you can see King Sejong and Jung Yu-shin general statue at the Gwanghwamun Square on the way to the palace. If you are interested to know about their history, do drop by the King Sejong and Jung Yu-shin general Museum located just behind King Sejongas statue. There is a secret stairway leading down to the museum right behind the statue.

Make sure you stop by at the entrance of the metro in front of the palace in order to get some free traditional garb to wear. Bring an ID to leave with them. Attend the free guided tours. English was at 9am, 1130am, and 130pm. It begins right through the main gate on the right after where you have your tickets checked. It gets sunny! Bring sunglasses and some water.

review_title: One of the authentic places in Korea.
review_body: If i have a foreign frind ,I would take him or her to this place. This is because this place is one of our outstanding heritages in Korea and you can see the intact palace in the middle of city. Also,you can see the performances in the palace at certain times. There are guide services, which offer at certain times. You should check out the time on the website.

It is very near to Insadonf, Buchon. Walked non stop with rented Hanbok that gave free admission to a lot of UNESCO Sites. Inviting and great royal feel in the architecture and cleverly constructed engineering around us.

Interior of palace is a bit sparse but still a nice palace to stroll through.b Definitely go for the audio guide (only krw 3000) which will make it more meaningful. Beware that you have to leave your ID as collateral for the audio device. I was a bit hesitant to leave my passport but all went well. Maybe try offering them a lesser form of ID like drivers LIC.
Beautiful big palace with many sections that have been well preserved. We were lucky to have gone there on a nice sunny day. A few trees have cherry blossoms already.

A palace strongly reminiscent of the Forbidden City in Beijing, spread out over a large area with many different buildings. They have been nicely restored and you are free to wander about. There are many displays with information in a few languages, including English, so you can get a good idea of the history.

Gyeongbokgung Palace was amazing. We got there just in time for the changing of the guard, which was much cooler than I expected. The throne room was the most impressive thing I saw in the entire country. A must visit if you're in Seoul.

It was a pleasant experience. We even got to see the changing of the guards. Cons is only when we visited there are a lot of tourists as well so the place was too crowded and its hard to get solo pictures.

review_title: Definitely must go for the changing of the royal guards
review_body: Besides the magnificent structures and design of the entire Gyeongbokgung Palace and grounds, what really attracts people here is the changing of the royal guards procession that takes places everyday at 9.30am til 11am. Although they are not exactly real royal guards (like in Stockholm and London), the procession is very realistic and depicts very accurately the manner the changing of the royal guards would have been back in the days where South Korea was still ruled by a monarchy. Charges to enter the palace grounds are relatively affordable (compared to other palaces around the world) at KRW3000/adult and KRW1500/person 7-12 years. children below 6 years enters free. This is consistent with the fares charged at other royal palaces in Seoul. If you are a history buff, you would enjoy the walk-around and tour of the Gyeongbokgung palace as it is the other palace aside from Changdeokgung that has a very rich history behind it. Strongly recommend it if you want to learn more about the history of south Korea during the Joseon dynasty and if you admire the beautiful designs of traditional Korean buildings and structures. The palace opens at 9am to 6pm (depends on different seasons) so if you would like go during less crowded times, try to go in at 9am or towards the late evening to avoid the busloads of group tourists.

review_title: Very big palace, prepare to walk a lot
review_body: Beautiful big palace with many sections that have been well preserved. Be well prepared with good walking shoes. Tourists can rent beautiful traditional Hanbok/king costumes to wear around the palace to get the feel of the olden times. We were lucky to have gone there on a nice sunny day. A few trees have cherry blossoms already. Stroller rental available too. A must visit for all tourists.
nice n beatutiful palace in clear cool seoul.. we went there in winter...so this big palace look stunning with the snow on its ground...and the white mountain as background..
Nothing much to see unless you're into history and such. Guards changing ceremony was mediocre too. A few scenic spots and that's it.

Admittance was very affordable. Tour guide services was available and courteous who knew a plethora of languages. Bathrooms were very clean. Plenty of opportunities to take photos. Very serene and interesting. A must visit!
Large Palace with several courtyards and structures to visit. A great way to spend a few hours exploring.

It is a touristy attraction, changing of the guard has commentary via PA system in english, which makes the ceremony just a parade for tourists, but the palace complex is very nice and well maintained, incl. the museum.

Great heritage site to intake Korean history with a full standing historic site.The buildings and Architecture are interesting and a good look to understand more of how royals lived in ancient times.Spent approx 1.5 hours.Able to rent some olden day costumes to enhance your experience.Suggest to link it up with insadong and bukchan.

Massive complex of the restored palace, still a work in progress, but it is a lovely place. Huge area, museum just outside the grounds, easy to get to. Large numbers of people, but after you pass by the first buildings, it appears almost deserted. Buildings are quite beautifully done. Many areas make for lovely photos. Honestly, after a while it all tends to blur into on and another, as it all starts to look the same, but still a must see if you are in Seoul.
You can visit this place when in Seoul, but everything is recently rebuilt. You don't see an old palace, it's a fake.

I was planning the palace in the morning, but an accident waste 3 hrs. Basically, I searched for the palace name in one of the most famous map app and blindly follow the direction. The app took me on a train for almost 2 hrs before I realized that it's taking me to a different place. So I recommend anyone who plans to just follow an app suggestion to double check.Anyway, I finally made it to the palace, and fortunate at the exact time to see the guard change. A must visit place in Seoul.

Make sure you are there 15 min before they open 9am and go through the carpark entrance (right side street) you will see all the guards getting ready to start.Do not forget to rent a traditional custom for the fabulous pictures.. there's a lot of places near where you can rent them.

review_title: Would have been better With Less Tourist Bus
review_body: The overall palace ground is beautiful and its like a step into the past. However, the place is crowded with tourist and was quite noisy especially at the area around the main hall. The visit would be more worthwhile if visitor were allowed to enter into the buildings as most buildings are off limits to visitor and we were only allowed to view from the outside. Aside from that, there should be more description about the history of each buildings .

review_title: Very pleasant palace at the heart of the city
review_body: Entering the palace is like leaving the frenzy of Seoul outside and entering a place of quietness. Due to the policy of allowing free entrance if you appear in traditional Korean clothes enhances the atmosphere of entering a different world.The palace has very beautiful buildings giving a very good impression how the Korean Royal family lived and governed the country.

This was one of the highlights of our time in Seoul. It was easy to get to (unlike many attractions in Seoul) and we were more enchanted by it the more we walked around the grounds. There is more to see than you would expect and the photo opportunities are endless, particularly on a sunny day. We were lucky enough to see a procession come through which heightened the sense of tradition and culture. Definitely worth putting aside half a day for, especially as it's free.Just don't go on a Tuesday, as it's closed!

The place we visited is called Gyeongbok Palace & Folklore Museum, but Trip Advisor does not have an exact listing. Built in 1394 as the main palace of the Joseon Dynasty (1392-1910), the compound features typical rooms (women and men's quarters were separated), offices, meeting halls, works of art, funerary objects and items of daily life (including huge earthen pots for kim-chee, preserved cabbage).

It's an imense palace, surrounded by a peaceful neighborhood. You can walk around the palaces and trees, and enjoy the tranquility of the place. It's included a ticket to the Folklore Museum, an atraction that should not be missed.
I like the palace. If you like history you will enjoy being there but you don't need more than 20 minutes

Great place to understand Korean culture and history. If you get lucky enough or well organise try to visit it at the same time as the guards showThe palace is well maintained and there are free guided tours which gives you lots of information I strongly recommend this palace if you have only time for one

Lots of walking and lots of dull looking palace buildings. It'd be more interesting if there were more English signboards explaining the history of the building. I guess this is how tour guides make money. Do try to dress up in traditional Korean clothing but you have to arrive early to get a costume. Guard changing happens at certain hours. That's interesting to see. Exit at the Korean national folk museum to get to Hanok village.
Great place to visit. A ticket gets you in to three attractions making it very inexpensive. Very interesting place!

I went on tuesday and didn't browsing before go. And what i found it was closed on tuesday ㅠㅠCouldn't see gyeongbokgung inside just i spend time around this palace. Amaze with architecture and location on center of city. Next time i will come again not on tuesday

review_title: The most important cultural site to visit in Seoul
review_body: Originally built in 14 century but later restored in 19 century because of fire, Gyeongbokgung Palace is the largest remaining palace in Seoul from the old Joseon Dynasty. It houses many old palace buildings that are still standing today, some are national treasures. However, Hyangwonjeong Pond is closed to visitors for unknown reason.  The National Palace Museum of Korea is located south of Heungnyemun Gate but is currently being renovated, and the National Folk Museum is located on the eastern side which is highly recommended. The best entrance is through Gwanghwamun gate. There are performances of guards changing ceremony taking place every day. Please find out their timing before you go. Please remember the palace is closed to visitors every Tuesday. Do not be caught unaware.

review_title: Not bad, and worth one visit
review_body: Given the historical significance this is certainly worth ONE visit, but otherwise I was not that impressed.

It's beautiful. The best thing about it for me was that if you are wearing traditional Honbok of Korea they let you in without a ticket so you see many people walking around in the traditional Korean clothes

review_title: A must to visit for Seoul Cultural aspect
review_body: A great place to visit.. the entrance is around 3000 won .. The place is big and has manyhouses to see.. take a sun screen as it can get hot..There are many shops around the palace which rent thier traditional clothes for 2 hours and u can get them and visit the palace. . It gives a very authentic experience.. The folk Meusum is just next to the palace. . ( inside the premises ) make sure to go there as well..

This place is a must see. Do not be in a rush, you can spend a lot of time walking around and seeing all the beautiful buildings. There are plaques everywhere so you can read about the history of the palace.

We came on the last Wed of March so entry was free, but the entry fee isn't expensive anyway. The grounds are large so even though there were lots of visitors it didn't feel crowded. We enjoyed taking photos by the pond, and there were lots of people in Korean dress which added to the atmosphere. We found the gate to the road in front of the Presidential Palace (Blue House) by chance - just look for the security guards at the far end of the complex. We also enjoyed watching the changing of the guard at 2pm, those guys must have a hard time ignoring all the visitors who get photographed beside them!
It is a good place to visit if you want to know the History of the Korean King and Queen. It is a huge place to roam around and it can be tiring as well

review_title: Excellent views from center of the city
review_body: The palace is worth a visit atleast half a day and looks different depending on the season. In winter one can see frozen lakes inside the palace. The best way to see and know the palace is through free tours offered by Korea tourism board where you can book just a day in advance in their website. Palace has got a Rich history with separate kings and queens living places. Also you will most photographed spot in the palace where new wedding couple, kids take photo sessions. Don't miss the parade infront of the palace. National museum just outside the palace is good to visit for around 2 hours. Observe the dragons placed on top of the palace structure and paper windows. Also learn about underground heating system used during those times in the palace.
Can't be better.You can rent Han-bok (Korea traditional Clothing) from shop where close this Palace.Not serious place, but should be polite. because of Palace of Korea's.
A massive place to walk around. Lots of history. Lots of photo shots. Wednesday was free entry! It's quite close to the hotels. This place should be number one on your sightseeing list!
Is an eye opener as the palace is quite different compare to the China Forbidde city. 无论是规模还是气派，整个宫殿都没有北京故宫的气势恢宏, 而是崇尚自然的园景。
This place is incredibly beautiful from entrance to the end. There is an entrace fee but it is worth it. You have a free museum right next to it and many spots to get beautiful pictures.

Rather than book the 1 hour tour at the palace, we booked a 2 hour tour through the visitseoul.net website that is operated by the city of Seoul. The walking tour is free you just pay for your entrance to the palace. The volunteer guide, a retired banker, who took us through the site was excellent. Because of the impeachment, there was only two of us on the tour and the palace grounds were quiet. Jeon provided the background information necessary to bring the site alive. Korea has such a fascinating history. Would highly recommend booking the walking tour through visit seoul website.

pros:- a great place to learn about Korean historical site- great place for photos, walking around- dont miss the event of changing guard (traditional guard). please check the schedule- the location is nearby metro railway- you can see sakura if you're at the right timecons:- mostly are open areas, so dont forget to bring umbrellas and rain coat during rainy day- you need to pay for entrance- there are several location that may be troublesome for someone who is using wheelchair. - no proper restaurant within the palace. there is only one small coffeshop which can be easily packed with people- theres only one small gift shop within the palace - most areas within the palace are covered in dirt (not all covered with stone floor). so during a windy day can bring a lot of sand and dust. if you're allergic to sand and dust dont forget to bring mouth and nose cover.- it requires walking within the palace. theres no transportation inside palace

We went in winter and it provided the most romantic backdrop for me and my husband. it felt like it was our second honeymoon. We also managed to catch the change of guards ceremony and appreciated the english commentary explaining the actions of the guards.

We visited Gyeongbokgung Palace is the most important Palace and depicts history from the 15th - 18 century . The floors were heated to keep the royal family comfortable. The site is very large with numerous buildings and areas to explore . I would wear comfortable walking shoes and plan 2 hours to visit the whole site . This palace is located in the heart of Seoul . We visited on a Saturday which I would try to avoid . For 17 straight Saturday's there have been very large peaceful protest in support of the former President who was impeached and removed from office . These caused large traffic slowdowns and I would avoid unless you want to see democracy at work in South Korea . Gyeongbokgung Palace is a example of Korean history that was on my must see list .

Although everything has been rebuilt given the fact that it was all destroyed by conquering nations, this was a wonderful quiet and tranquil place that was in the middle of Seoul. What was most interesting to see so many young people that came dressed in old traditional costumes. Take your time and see everything.

Conveniently located at Gyeongbokgung Station, we arrived at around 10 am to catch the changing of the guards ceremony (10 am/ 11 am/ 1 pm/ 2 pm) - it only lasted for about 15 minutes or so, but was definitely very insightful. We bought our admission tickets (free for 65+) and went into the main palace. We joined the English speaking tour and our tour guide was very knowledgeable, providing us with insights into the history of South Korea and the palace.

Two thumbs up! Place to visit for tourists. The palace has some exhilarating views; lagoon, mountain, the modern buildings as back drop. One must avail a map and translator to help you go around the place. Would be advisable to bring comfortable shoe wear as the place is huge. There are also for rent traditional costumes nearby for the tourists for pictorial purposes.

Went here in the morning to catch changing of royal guard ceremony.Lots of tourist at this time. This palace is big so you need to allot more time to look around. Wear comfy shoes & prepare yourself for a walkathon

I was planning to join a half-day tour of the palace but realized the hop-on-hop-off bus stopped not far from it. Go in the morning to avoid the crowds. Don't miss the changing of the guards. It's a nice recreation. The grounds are pleasant to walk around. But there were too many tourists dressed in the Korean national outfits. A bit too cheesy for me.

review_title: หนึ่งในพระราชวังเกาหลีที่ไม่ควรพลาดค่ะ
review_body: I recommend to visit the palace when you are wearing old korean cloth and take a photo graph. the photograph will be one of your favorite.

Sprawling area with huge gates, stairs, separate zones for the military and the illiterate. Statues that depict some humour can be found in the compound. Heated floors have also been thought of to keep the King and his family and staff warm. A historical site, good to spend some time. Best use a guided tour or the audio guide to gain more insights. Worth the visit but need to wear good walking shoes as the grounds are massive.
Gyeongbokgun palace is definitely a place to learn and feel Korean history and culture. Guide was explaining very good, in detail. I wish I had more time there

Unfortunately most of what is original to Korea has had to be rebuilt. The lack of authenticity was excused when so many of the tourists visitinnworebtradional clothing. It is an interesting walkin museum

Viaited this palace in mid-March 2017 with my wife. We arrived at 2 PM and managed to watch the guard changing ceremony. We toured the palace with the free walking tour. Our guide, Mr. Chang, was very friendly, nice and knowledgable. The palace complex was huge. It took us around 2 hours to complete the tour. Different sections gave me different feelings. The main gate, the courtyard and the main palace building awed me. The beautiful pavillion at the back was so serene. Considering the relatively cheap ticket price and the whole experience, it was totally worth it.
Such a beautiful location. We learnt a lot about the history of Korean royals. Would highly recommend taking the walking tour.

Just like the other palace, you will see older building and not too many surprise ! But it is very good culture learning and beautiful gardening . We were there a bit too early , the weather is very cold. Suggest visit Korea after March .

review_title: Nice place to explore korean heritage
review_body: In Seoul city there are near about four Kings Palace. Among them the Gyeongbokgung Palace is the most important, centrally located and covers a larger area. The heritage palace is nicely maintained and depicts the Korean history from the 15TH TO 18TH Century. Please visit the palace prior to 4 pm otherise you cant by ticket to enter inside the palace

Gyeongbokgung Palace is a wonderful place to visit and a must when in Seoul. Truly magnificent. The view is spectacular and one should try to put on the traditional garb and enjoy relieving Korea's glorious past.

Let me tell you first, that the entrance fee to this place is only 3,000 krw (less than $3). This is incredibly cheap, considering how vast and large this place is. Also, if you rent and wear a hanbok from any hanbok rental shop near the palace, your entrance fee is FREE.I really recommend going here with a tour guide because it's really incredible listening to the history behind each building and architectural element, starting from the ondol floor heating technology dating back to the Joseon era, to the different symbolisms embedded into the walls, floors, and roofs of the palace. Much of the palace was destroyed by the Japanese forces during the Japanese occupation, and some buildings have still not been restored. You can also visit the residence and deathplace of Queen Myeongseong, who was assassinated by the Japanese in the 1900s.I would say Gyeongbokgung takes a good 2 hours to fully look around. But definitely, Gyeongbokgung is a must-visit for any travelers wanting to experience the history of Korea.

review_title: Seoul Searching: A solo traveler's diary
review_body: I'm a Kdrama fan and finally traveled to South Korea with the hopes of visiting significant places that are always shown in a drama. I don't know why but I'm into Saguek kind of drama with Kings (Wang) and Crown Princes (Seja) as the main characters. That is why my first stop is the Gyeongbukgong palace. I was imagining as i was there how the entourage of the king of about 20 or almost, would follow him wherever he goes and when he talks to any of his concubines let's say outside of their quarters, those entourage will look the other way and pretend not to hear anything. Although the palace was flocked by tourists everyday, i'm glad i was able to see it and its beautiful garden. I went there last autumn season and the trees were very colorful, needless to say, a sight for sore eyes. Just take the subway in going there. You can go down Gyeongbukgong station, which is the nearest to the palace or go down Gwangwamun station and see first Statues of King Sejong and admiral Yi in Gwangwamun square then head straight to the gates of Gwangwamun then the palace itself. The famous Cheonggyecheon stream is also nearby. Since i was traveling solo, selfies overload was what happened. Anyways i enjoyed every minute of it. Turns out it wasn't boring traveling solo afterall.

review_title: Watch out for the Changing of the Guards!
review_body: The highlight of my visit to Gyeongbokgung Palace is the Changing of the Guards ceremony. Make sure to schedule your visit or watch out for the actual changing of the guards schedule while you are the the vicinity of the palace. It is an experience that you will not regret! You may even take a picture or a video while the ceremony is taking place. Walking distance from the Gwanghwamun Square. Don't miss this on your trip to Seoul, South Korea!

Tour guide did a good job showing my friends around. Good time management and good explanation. Were really having a good time and will totally bring my friend here again. Winter time is the best to visit such place.

This place is accessible via subway (Gyeongbokgung Station) and follow the signs for the exits.There is an open area for you to take pictures at the main entrance if you just want a keep sake with some of the palace architecture in the background. However, if it is you first time, I would recommend paying a small fee to enter to see the entire palace ground at least once. This place is huge so be prepared to walk around a lot. But every corner was mesmerising. Especially if you're into those period dramas - you could picture what it was like in those days because some of the buildings have actual furniture (chairs, beds, vases, books, shelves etc.) so you get to see what the rooms might have looked like in the past. There is security around so it is pretty safe. If you're going in the day, bring your sunglasses because this place has lots of bare sandy ground and can get quite bright. Lots of photo ops and you can rent hanboks nearby to really blend in and get into the period atmosphere if you'd like. If you'd like a shot without too many tourists in the picture, there are many secluded spots towards the back of the palace. They have guided tours too that will help you to learn more about the history. In all, I would recommend to visit this place at least once.

review_title: Visit to the oldest palace in Seoul
review_body: My wife and I decided to visit the Gyeongbokgung Palace yesterday morning to acquaint ourselves with some culture and history of this vibrant nation of South Korea.We took a cab there for convenience instead of going by subway.We went there early at 9.30am because we wanted to witness the Ceremony of Gate Guard Change. This is held twice everyday at 10am and 2pm except on Tuesday when the palace is closed. The guards in full ancient soldier attire will march into the royal courtyard to the accompaniment of a marching band comprising, drums, trumpets and cymbals. It's quite spectacular to watch . This was the highlight of our tour . As for the palace tour , it is not as grand as what I have seen in China by comparison. There is an entry fee of 3,000 won per person and seniors above 65 enter free of charge . So if you are a senior don't forget to bring along your passport to show your age to qualify for the free entry.

review_title: Gyeongbokgung Palace, not anymore a dream!
review_body: When the KDramas were in bloom in 2000's, I was dreaming Korea as my home. I never expected that it became a reality. I love all the places especially where these historical destinations. I was really amazed when I got in the gate, there are 4 palaces to visit. This was the main royal palace of the Joseon dynasty. Best visited during Cherry Blossom seasons (in my opinion).

As you can see from the title, yes, free entrance is possible if you rent a hanbok (Korean traditional clothes). There's shops near Gyeongbokgong that rent out the hanboks. You can do some research first before going. And if you're like me, you've been there and just want to walk around taking pictures as well as seeing the shift changing of the gate guards, arrive there around 1:00pm or 1:20pm. If not mistaken, the ceremony starts at 1:30pm. For me, I've been there like 4 times and I've already know how the palace looks like, so I just walk around Gwanghwamun without paying a cent to enter the palace. Besides, there's a museum near the subway exit near Gyeongbokgong which is FREE OF CHARGE.
One of the tourists spot that you must not missed. A lot of foreigners wearing Korean costumes and have pictorial in the place. It's a vast place to walk so wear a comfortable shoes.
Great place to learn history. You should take the tour because you get to know more about the place. You also get to see the blue house where the current president lives.

review_title: Wonderful palace to visit during winter time
review_body: Is was wonderful to visit here , during winter time and u can see the ground is all cover with snow , very cold and I enjoy the scenery here and people here all are very friendly .

review_title: A good choice for a half-day city tour
review_body: 3 TIPS TO ENJOY THE GYEONGBOKGUNG PALACE1. Rent a traditional costume.You can get stunning photos while wearing a traditional costume within the palace grounds. Search online for where to rent a hanbok. 2. Get a map.Plan your route, evade the huge crowd of tourists and still cover all the spots of the palace. Maps are available before entering the gates.3. Wear comfortable shoes.You won’t want to be limping through your time travel or be distracted by a painful blister.

Visited the palace on a Sunday many korean people dressed in taraditional costumes. The palace is very grand and steeped with history. There are so many beautiful sections to see in apeacful environment.

review_title: Entrance is Free if you're wearing a Hanbok!
review_body: I definitely recommend visiting the palace wearing a hanbok. It adds quite an authentic look to your photos! Join the free tour which starts at the information center near the main gate. But join the earlier schedule so you won't be rushed in the afternoon as they close on time. The guards were shooing us away as we were still taking photos. We had to keep on running and stop for a bit to continue taking photos when the guards were busy shooing other visitors! Worth the visit only if you join the tour as this would give you an idea why and how the whole place came to be.

One of must visit palace in seoul.Their palace sure are huge..but this is the hugest palace and need lot of walk.for me once is enough, I walked for over two hours there.But very nice experience..Maybe will bring my family for tour, but personally i won't come back by myself.its easy to get lost

This is a don't miss experience for any tourist in Seoul. The palace grounds are extensive and the thing to be sure you don't miss is the changing of the guard ceremony, which occurs several times during the day. It's bright and colorful and occurs just outside the gate between the palace walls and the bus parking on the east side. You can hear the drums from anywhere inside, but they do block the entrance for awhile as the guard passes....the best photo spot in between the parade grounds and the bus park. There's not a whole lot else to do inside the palace but do walk it and get a feeling for the grandeur of times past.

review_title: A must for anyone interested in architecture and history
review_body: My mom is not a fan of museums and she was totally blown away by the structures and the interesting backstory. It is beautiful there and if you arrive in time you can join one of the free multi lingual tours! Highly recommend it.

review_title: Must visit, but keep walking if you have shirt time
review_body: We went to this beautiful landmark early in the morning to avoid the crowd. We only have a little time left in Seoul so we did our tour inside quickly. Many tourist in groups often stop near the entrance taking pics etc blocking your way lol so to skip this, keep on walking inside as the palace is huge. Not much description written on each room in the palace, or maybe we just had to take the guide book or something at the entrance. We did the whole palace in 1 hour by keep on walking and taking pics quickly.

review_title: A must see for first time visitors
review_body: Originally built in 1395, this complex was the seat of the Joseon Dynasty until destroyed by the Japanese in the 1590’s. Instead of rebuilding, the royal family moved to another palace site. In 1867-68, the Prince Regent sponsored a reconstruction. Unfortunately, it again was almost totally destroyed during the second Japanese occupation prior to World War II, and the events of the Korean War. Restoration work began again in 1989, but according to our guide, only about 50% of the buildings have been completed. Nonetheless it is a fascinating place to visit and easily accessible. Inevitably, one will compare it to The Forbidden City because of similar design, but on a smaller scale. Make sure that you see Gyeonghoeru Pavilion (on the lake), one of the structures that dates from the 1867 restoration. It was used for entertainment when important foreign visitors visited the palace. Another point of interest is the video that deals with the assassination of Empress Myeongseong by Japanese agents in 1895 (and her quarters). One thing that added charm to our visit was the large number of young folks wearing traditional dress. Evidently, the clothes are available for rental and this has become a “thing to do” on a date, or just a lark.

There's a metro station just beside the palace so it's very easy to go to. On the front gate, you may take your pictures with the royal palace guards. And every hour, there's a performance where the guards change their duty shift. Apparently, there's a little ceremony for that!Once the performance is done (roughly after ten minutes), the application for the use of guards costume opens. But you have to very quick because they only accommodate max of 10 pax per time slot. We were just lucky enough to be included!!! You may choose from the 4 costumes you want to try. Once you're on it, you can only wander along the ground but not too far! So it's just good for taking pictures. :)Entrance to the palace is 3000 won for adults. Palace ground is huge and very picturesque so it's worth your while to roam around. :)
Here is the large palace and it is big enough, there are the lake, garden, trees and the location is in city.We can go here using public transportation such us train, bus or taxi

review_title: nice place for a quick visit
review_body: Nicely maintained and serene atmosphere. People who have visited many indian palaces would find it too plain .. but worth the short time it takes to complete the same. enjoy

review_title: My favourite of the Seoul palaces
review_body: If you are limited for time then of the main tourists sites this would be my recommendation for the one to do. Located within easy walking distance of City Hall the palace is a juxtaposition of the surrounding modern buildings. Very relaxing to take a stroll around the grounds and when we visited in early afternoon the reflections of some of the buildings on the water were stunning. It is also worthwhile taking in the National Palace Museum which is located near the main entrance and is free to enter after you have paid your initial entrance fee of KRW3K. Great value for money and a wonderful place to great away from the hubris of the City and see the locals ( and some foreigners) dressing up in local costumes.

A beautiful historic site. Similar in layout to Forbidden City in Beijing but on a smaller scale. Beautifully restored and maintained buildings. This site must not be missed on any visit to Seoul. Not suitable for mobility challenged as considerable walking is required and some stairs. Folk museum is on site with excellent exhibits, gift shop and washrooms.

review_title: A must visited sightseeing in Seoul
review_body: Every time I've been to Seoul on business trip, I go to visit Gyeongbokgung Palace with different people from my countries. We usually have no tourist guide and our people are not good at English as well as Korean so I have to introduce them about this palace by myself. The more I visit this palace, the more I feel how great it is. Even it was burnt down once but Korean people rebuilt and re-act all the activity so people can understand what happened there several hundred years ago. It's also very good place to take a walk then you can enjoy very nice food so called Samgyetang at a very famous restaurant nearby.It's really nice place for visiting at any time of the year.

review_title: A beautiful place in the center of the city
review_body: The place itself was amazing! it's combined with nature and a very exquisite design..it was a great place to take pictures and to go if you're wearing hanbok. yes, i was there and wore hanbok. The pictures and the traditional place was a match made in heaven! You should try!..if you're into the architecture and design, this place is for you. but I guess they're trying to build up the new building when was there.

This used to be the main palace but many of the original buildings were burnt down. Nothing much to see except the pond and the little pavilion here. You can either purchase a single ticket for this palace or a combined ticket for all 4 palaces. All the palaces are connected. A secret garden is a must to see.

The palace was very designed and harmonised with the beauty of the surrounding nature. You could appreciate the creativity of the designers of the palace. At the end of the tour, I was most touched by the sad story of the Queen who was assassinated by the Japanese soldiers. Visitors are allowed to watch a video of the story, visit her rooms and imagine the atrocities happened in the past. Highly recommended.

This place is on a defifnite must-do list if it's your first time to Seoul! Filled with so much culture and history, you need to come here! Beautiful in the fall and the spring (but I also went in the summer and sweated and still had fun), it's a must-do in Seoul.

review_title: Beautiful palace in the city center of Seoul
review_body: Brings back memories of Korean dramas, not so big grounds, easy to walk around, good outing site for a bit of fresh air in a metropolitan city.

review_title: A place to experience history of Seoul
review_body: This is like the main palace in Seoul. Although it is very crowded with tourists, and this is the second time I've visited the place, I am still awed by the structure and how one can experience history in these modern times. It is inexpensive to enter and you can enter the museum for free.

Honestly, I had no time to walk around the palace i just walk only outside of palace but i could say i miss this that i did not go inside anyway even outside it really nice place, unique i recommend you to visit

Living in the Seoul area, I have visited Gyeongbokgung Palace many times with friends and family. It is BIG and accommodates all the visitors it receives from schools, tour groups, and explorers like me quite easily. There are so many things to photograph including the guard changing ceremonies at the gate and the procession that takes place in the large square. Although I have been here several times, I find that I am discovering sights I overlooked the first time, which makes it interesting for me when I accompany first time visitors. For extra fun, consider renting traditional Korean clothing to wear as you tour, because being in a historical location wearing historical clothing makes your photos even better! There is a small admission fee and you need to make sure the palace is open the day you go (it is closed on Tuesdays and the hours of operation vary by season). If you enjoy historic sights, interesting architecture, and beautiful scenery and if you don't mind walking (wear good shoes), this is one of the places to go in Seoul. Fans of historical Korean dramas should not miss Gyeongbokgung Palace!

Lovely place to visit. Shame the original palace was destroyed.But great that koreans are rebuilding it (as best as possible) to preserve their history. I guess in the summer it's even more beautiful.We we lucky that a high school student, Mary, offered to guide us. We got lots of information about Korean traditions, old customs and history.. And lots of information about the palaces history.We spend several hours there before heading to the Folk Museum in the area.

The Admission: 3,000 won.The Palace: One of the biggest palace in Seoul. Beautiful architecture!! This palace was the first royal palace built in the Joseon Dynasty. Sumunjang changing of the guard ceremony(twice a day) 10am & 2pm.Gwanghwamum changing of the guard ceremony (twice a day) 11am & 1pm.They also offer English, Japanes and Chinese guided tour.The Location: Subway Line 3, Gyeongbokgung Station, Exit 5

We went here late afternoon and spent atleast an hour. On our way to the palace, we passed by a group of uniformed students who offers FREE TOUR of the palace. We took that tour and it was nice of them to assist us from were to buy tickets to the palace which is 3,000 won to where is the best spot to take a photo of the palace. The tour is very informative and enlightening about the Joseon Dynasty. Tips:1. If you rent a Hanbok, you can have free access/entrance on the palaces. A lot of tourist local/foreign wore hanbok inside the palace.2. Take the free tour offered by the studentsDirection:Take Metro Line 3 Orange Line. Get off at Gyeongbokgung Station and take Exit 5. Walk straight ahead until you pass by the museum.Palace is closed every Tuesday

review_title: Once in Seoul you gotta visit it!
review_body: The place is beautiful, the mountains on one side and the modern buildings on the other makes this a unique sight! Combine a tour at the palace and it's surrounding buildings with a visit to the National Museum of Korean Contemporary History, just across the street.

Nice palace. Well maintained attraction. Very inexpensive to get in. The grounds are large, so on a nice day, this is a very nice walk. Would've been nice to see on of the buildings furnished as it would've looked during the period. So after looking at many buildings, we got kinda bored.
This place is so beautiful with unique building. I can feel korean historical culture there. I love this place soooo much. Of course, wanna visit there again one day.

A nice palace in the city with some photos spot. Don't forget to bring your camera with you as there are some other places of interest located nearby Gyeongbokgung Palace too. Easy to find and only few minute walk from Anguk Station. Went there on early March with cold weather, the palace was crowded with tourist and many people wear traditional dress. Entrance fee is KRW 3,000 per person.

review_title: Not to visit in cold months
review_body: This is not a place to go in cold months! You are practically all the time outside and keeping in mind that Korea has a pretty cold winter weather .... otherwise it's really interesting. Did you know they had central heating ....
i arrived around 10 am and at the same time with changing guard ceremony in the place. The view of nature was very beautiful with the snow was falling that day.
bring food and hot drinks, other than that we like this historic place, to get free entrance wear a hanbuk, confirm free, rent it or buy it just outside the palace

This Palace located near the hotel we stayed so we decided to visit it once. It was a great place to get to know about the Korean's history. You might need half day to complete this place. A beautiful place to see if you travel to Korea!

review_title: Limited time in Seoul? Skip this palace...
review_body: If you don't have much time in Seoul, this is one of the palaces you can definitely visit the next time around. Go to the Modern Art Museum or some smaller art galleries instead. The changing of guards at Gwanghwamun (the Gate at Gyeongbokgung) is OK but the group felt small, not sure historically if the number of guards would have been more. If you do choose to visit, it would be much more enjoyable if you joined a guided tour with your admission ticket. The guide is very knowledgable but you'll find a lot of the buildings have not been fully restored since the grounds were pretty much systematically demolished during the Japanese Rule in the early 20th century.

Gyeongbok Palace is the largest in Seoul, completed in1395. King Taejo also built Changdeok Palace completed in 1405. Yi Seonggye an army general that overthrew the government and took the name King Taejo. Yi started the Joseoy Dynasty which ruled from 1392 to 1910. ending with the defeat in the first Sino-Japanese War. He moved the Capital from Gaegyeong to Hanyang (later became Seoul). Gyeongbok Palace is not only beautiful, its history where all the social attitudes formed, powerful etiquette, and the cultural norms..

review_title: Beautiful reflection of Korean history - a must-see!
review_body: Gyeongbokgung Palace is the biggest palace in Seoul. It shows a very important part of Korean history, reflecting how people used to live.The gardens are pretty large, with many buildings in the area. As the palace is in a very historical area, there are many "hanbok" renters around, and tourists may dress in Hanbok for authentic experience. As for me, watching people around in Hanbok was very interesting. A not-to-miss is "the change of guards ceremony" - takes place at 10:00 and 14:00. This is a reenactment of the original ceremony from 1400's, takes about 20 minutes and they announce the actions in Korean and English.Also, you can dress-up as guards for authentic photos. The Gyeonghoeru Pavilion on Hyangwonjeong Pond the biggest pavillon in Korea, and it is a beautiful view with the mountains at the back.Strolling in the gardens of this palace and viewing the mountains, trees and ponds, I felt like in a movie from the old times.
Great to visit , cheap 3000 Won ( <3$) , tranquil, mountains one side & the city the other.Nice to stroll round & reflex.

review_title: Good spot to see Korea historical culture
review_body: The traditional buildings were very beautiful and interesting to see. The changing of the guard ceremony was also nice to see. There were lots of Korean young women in traditional dress, which was fun. I visited before spring had really gotten started, so the grounds were still brown for winter. I can imagine the grounds would be quite beautiful for walking in the spring as things start to get green.

review_title: great huge place to walk around
review_body: there is a small pond or lake inside this huge propertypalace is actually small but lots of open areas for walkingsecurity staff aplenty
I recommend seoul city tour. Excellent guides. Beware travelling on any Saturday. They are protesting against/for the S korean President. The traffic was literally deadlocked after 2pm.
It is okay for photoshoot. People came and rent Hanbok for nice pictures. The place are huge and need up to 4 hours to explore the whole place.

review_title: nice stroll on a sunny day with your hands behind your back.
review_body: We didn't learn that much as we didn't have a guide. Nonetheless, it's a nice thing to walk through if you're in the area. If you have no special interest in old buildings then leave it out if you're on a short visit. I would personally then climb a mountain instead.

review_title: The main palace of Choseon Dynasty.
review_body: It's easy to access there.1. Line no 3 - orange line - get off Kyong Bok Palace. gate no 5 to the palace.  it consist of several palace building. the most beautiful and greatest palace.2. you can also walk to there from Kwang Hua Moon or City hall. 3. in the palace, there is a museum. it's quite good place to go. 4. on it's right side, there is Sam Chung Dong. now it becomes a famous place  Korean Traditional style houses(Han Oak) village. it's good place of walking.
This is a great place to make beautiful photos and enjoy the local culture. You will need a lot of walking, but it's nice. I wish I took more photos. But I have a great time and memories.
The Palace was easy to go via the train.. the buildings were awesome and so old but well maintained. Amenities like toilets are clean.
Come and get the feeling of being in a place that hundreds of years ago the living history of the country were walking around. Great feeling, beautiful palace and landscape

You can't visit Korea without seeing this palace and witnessing the changing of the guards. Rich history and amazing architecture. I thought travelling at winter time would be a problem, but it ended up perfect, lesser crowd for one and nice to walk around when it's not hot.

Besides the main palace and the man-made lake, there's really not much to see here. Lots of empty space. Be sure to wear sunblock when visiting in summer. The National Folk Museum is in the palace if you're into museums. Changgyeonggung Palace and Changdeokgung palace while smaller, are much more interesting in my opinion. There is much more to see and appreciate in these palaces than Gyeongbokgung.

The palace is very large and is broken down into several sections depending on where you stand in life. Meaning Royalty, servants, and others. Royals also have several house within palace for safety reasons. And whT animals on the roof means and color of roof means. Your need a guided tour to learn everything.
either stroll around or, what I prefer, just sit and take in the scenery, let you thoughts do the walking and relax in the middle of a busy city

review_title: Some Peace, Quiet and Tradition Amongst a Sprawling Busy Metro
review_body: Missed this historical landmark and attraction with our first visit last year. Didn't want to make the same mistake this time! We were able to walk from the hanok we were renting to the south gate of the palace. The changing of the guards ceremony welcomed us which was fascinating to watch (It occurs four times daily). Afterwards, we toured the grounds and different restored structures and buildings - all beautiful particularly the lakes and landscaping around the buildings ! We spent most of the time in the National Folk Museum where it was not only WARM, it was marvelously arranged by themes and organized with facinating exhibits! Highly recommend!

This place is great for walking. It is big and beautiful. And so oriental. And there were a lot of young girls in national dresses. There is not only a palace, but also a park with lake. And nice trees.
The show is worth to see. Very traditional Korea. Highly recommended . Interesting place and a lot of tourist. Easy access on parking. Ticket entrance very affordable
Nice historic palace. The guide came free: very knowledgeable and friendly. We booked the guide online before going, and she arrived punctually and gave us an hours tour

We are so happy to heony moon at South Korea, we just only say 4 days at Seoul, whatever you go, you can see the yellow and red tree, look so romantic, you can take MTR easy to join the trip, there a lot of shopping hall, and the things is cheaper, we try to eat their Korea food of the （Gejang）soy sauce of crab, the crab did't cook, they clean the crab after they catch, put them in their soy sauce at less 7 days, this is my first time to eat the fresh crab, it's sweet and the sauce is good, the higlight you must put the rice in the raw crab, mix together eat, it's was delicious! The set for it many other side dishes see attach photo, 20000 won only.

This is the biggest palace and a must see when in Seoul and very picturesque. The architecture was grand, so ancient, and very impressive. The gardens were very relaxing and lovely in Autumn. Don't miss the changing of the guards ceremony at the main gate entrance at 10 am- 4 PM hourly. Highly recommend the free guided English tour offered daily at 11 AM, gives you insight into different aspects of the architecture and culture. The Korean Folk Museum inside was very neat if you are interested in Korean history and the the different Monarch's. Autumn was lovely time to visit. The palace grounds are so nicely maintained and very safe. I was there at the end of November and it was comfortable in layers during the day. Palaces close at 5 so dress warmly if you plan to be out and about in the evening.

Out of all the places I visited on my 6-day trip to Seoul, this is my favorite. Went there during winter and it was amazing. Wasn't able to cover the whole palace during my 2-hour visit. Would visit again if I come back to Seoul.
This palace is one of the largest and most precious ones in Korea. It is really easy to approach in Seoul.

review_title: Visit palace with Korean traditional clothing
review_body: Gyungbok palace is one of the MUST visit places if you want to have a tour in Seoul. if you compare with forbiden city in Peiking, feeling is very different with that one. It will be interesting to compare two different palace. Walking along the main building to the backside ponds with Queen's place, you can feel from the enormous authority to the relaxed calmness.Good fun with Korean traditional cloth,Hanbok, you can have free pass if you rent a cloth and enter the palce wearing Hanbok. This will give you much fun with good memorial photo.As Korea has 4 distintive seasons, different seasonal visiting will provide you totally different feeling as well.
Love the architecture and the fact that they make sure that the palace grounds are kept clean and restored! Popular place to see a glimpse of history.
One of recommended palace in seoul you can go there with subway to gyeongbokgung station. There is a change of guard ceremony every day at 10 am don't miss it.
An ancient castle, huge and amazing, very unique design and artful. Also here we can see how Korea perform the ceremony the royal army escort door replacement is carried out.
It was in same place with korean folk museum. Check to close day, in my opinion best time to go there is april or may, its so cold in winter and there is no flower

review_title: Worth to go and take pictures at this photo stop
review_body: Worth to go to Gyeongbokgung for sightseeing and for quick photo-taking. Will be much nicer if tourists choose to sightsee during autumn season. Attraction fee for each adult is KRW 3000. Tourists may purchase the one-day pass which includes the entry of all Korean palaces.

review_title: Amazing and peaceful place in the heart of modern Seoul
review_body: I visited this palace twice, once in the summer and another during winter and I can say that both experiences were amazing, since the scenery of lakes and trees makes the place very different. My only advice is during winter wear warm clothes with layers, protect your hands and head and enjoy the tranquility of this place.There is a change of guard at 10:00am every day with narration so the visitors will understand what the ceremony is about. Arrive a few minutes early to get a good spot to see it. There are other times during the day, check in the website. I bought the ticket next to the main gate and I also got the booklet with information. There are tours in several languages but I did not want to wait for the English tour that would start at 11:00am and just wondered on my own. It is very busy but don't get intimidated with the crowds. If you start the tour from from the back, you miss all the tours and have a lot of peace and quiet. I just wandered for 2 hours, contemplating, taking pictures and watching people. Some girls rent the Korean dress called hanbok to enter the palaces for free and it's nice to see them walking about in the palace it makes you wonder what life must be like in the old days. You also can use your ticket to enter the National Folk Museum of Korea.

Majority of the palaces may looked the same. But to me, the story is of the palace is the one thing that makes a difference to it - main royal palace of the Joseon dynasty built in 1395. The change guard ceremony was interesting! Recommend to make time to watch it. It happens at every hour from 10am-4pm (please check again before you visit).
Decided to hike to the top of the tower and was not disappointed by the view. There are buses and cabs that you can take if you don't want to do the hike.

This is one of several palaces in Seoul that provides a very interesting look in to Joseon dynasty history. Fascinating very large grounds with many buildings. We made it for the am guard changing ceremony. The ceremony takes place a couple of times a day and is a nice addition to the regular palace tour. Make sure to visit the national foll museum next to the palace grounds for an even more in depth look in to Korean history and culture.
You can't skip coming to see the Palace if you visit Seoul. History at your fingertips. highly recommended

A good place to know about Korea Palace and the history by joining the tour provided by the palace. Do visit the muzium nearby. Should try their hanbok dress cheapest is ₩13k rent for 2hrs and free entrance to the palace. Lovely experienced.
This palace is beautiful and a very big property. Wear good walking shoes as you will walk a lot and not all surfaces are even. Changing of the guards was fun to see as well
Fascinating building and premises. Only spent 10 minutes. Got there late. Palace closes at 5pm. Took some wonderful photos there.
Beautiful Palace tour with One Day Korea. This is a very historic palace in South Korea, definitely a must see while in Seoul.

If you have any difficulty walking or with stairs this is not for you. The buildings are all roped off, so the most you can do is climb to the top of the steps and look in. The changing of the guard at the gate which happens multiple times a day is worth the visit as is the museum which is next door.

We went to Gyeongbokgung Palace on the coldest day so it was freezing walking around. We were only there for 30 mins. The palace is smaller than I expect but The story behind it is interesting. Coming to the palace in early Feb is not recommended.

Our visit here started with watching the changing of the gaurds ceremony at 10AM. We weere lucky to watch it as it was quite freezing weather and at some point , in severe weather the ceremony is cancelled. The palace itself is a complex of beautiful palaces demonstaring the maginifecnt architecture and are a must-see whie in Seoul.
Some old surrounded by new in Seoul. Come at the right time and you will see a crowd watching some happenings at the front gate. Shame you have to pay to get in though.

review_title: To big to finish in one day
review_body: This palace i believe is the more popular one among the 5 nearby. It is huge and due to the hectic schedule we are unable to explore the place. Probably need like half a day to properly explore the area. There is a museum inside.

Be sure to join Gyeongbokgung Palace's free guided tour to better appreciate the place. It will only take one hour for you to learn more about Korea's rich history. If you plan to go to Bukchon Hanok Village, better ask information which gate you should exit. You might also want to check out the Blue House while you're in the Palace. They have an exit that will allow you to see the front of the Blue House. We weren't able to see the Changing of the Guards, but you might want to fix your schedule so you can see it.

The place was very beautiful because of the view with the mountain,ponds with fish..its interesting to come when spring season...im going there on summer still beauty, the places also open midnight but hard to get the ticket on midnight... go here if you want to watch the guard ceremony changing, it amazing, here also near to insadong and also cheodukgung palace and blue house, museum of kotemporary also there and musuem art king joseon also around there...may spend all day there.

This is a large complex of palace buildings with a two museums attached. There are some rooms which are furnished. We saw the changing of the guard ceremony. Lots to look at and do. This is manly outdoor - but the museums give a chance to go indoors.

You will not only be amazed by the decors of each part of the Palace , you will actually be amazed by how the Korean people are proud of and how they have been able to preserve their heritage ... something we Filipinos can learn from...

To know Korea from its core. It is unique in its style from those of China, and Japan. Chinese's is a castle in itself, and Japanese's is a fortress, indicating the nation's monarchaic living style while Korean is more of an living quarters with low walls and not much luxury.
" this place is very near our hotel, we were able to go by just walking, we really enjoyed taking pictures of the palace, in fact i made it as my profile picture' background".
not that great - unless you get those costumes and take pics. not enough info available on the diffrent sights station and the book is not informative enough.

Last time in june 2013 , i didn't get enough time to explore the whole palace. Now in january 2017, i can get fulfilled my wish to explore the whole palace. It was really awesome place to get know history of korean.

Go on a nice day and enjoy the home of former kings and queens. The extensive palace grounds and buildings take a couple of hours to get through, and they're totally worth your time. The architecture is impressive and varied, the gardens are beautiful and seasonal, and the mountains in the background are breathtaking. The entire place represents old Korea so well.If you take kids, they can run around outside which is nice too! It can be exceptionally busy, so be prepared to gently elbow your way through the busy areas.The subway access is good, and there's a museum attached to the station which I didn't visit but heard was good.

review_title: Great History and Perfect For Pictures
review_body: This palace is absolutely huge and you can easily spend you whole day there. I didn't see the change of the guard but heard it's a must see and will definitely get to it next time. There are so many beautiful pictures you can take of the place, this is a must see for anyone who visits South Korea.

Was there for the change of guard ceremony which was impressive. Otherwise didn't enter the palace ground per se but walked at its parameter which allowed views inside, which was at that point of time just okay. Maybe due to the late fall weather.
Very nice historical place to visit. What arrived the Guard change was interesting to look at with national dressing

The palace is extremely picturesque. I took some amazing shots here in the Autumn. The old architecture combines beautifully with fall colors. I think it's a fantastic place to go if you're looking for amazing photographs.
The history of Seoul is so unique and the people are extremely friendly. Very safe area. Lots of ex pats in down town.
The Palace is big and it is worth witnessing the change of the guard ceremony that happens multiple times during the day.

review_title: Be a princess at your own palace
review_body: This is my second visit and i really enjoyed being a princess in one day, where you can rent a hanbook (tradisional uniform) across the road.Rented fees is 30,000 won for 2 hours and we entered the palace with free of charge because im wearing it.Beside that, u can try the men traditional cloth for free at main gate. If this is your first time, you can join with others tourist as they provide English tour guide.I went there by subway,

Many beautiful scenery to capture by your camera. The place is huge. There are many temples to visit. Don't miss this palace when visiting Seoul. The changing of guards ceremony is also worth watching.

We began our visit at the Palace with the changing of the guard ceremony. I highly recommend being at the Palace in time to see this ceremony. It was so interesting to watch and afterwards you have an opportunity to have your picture taken with one of the guards. So fun!

The changing of the guard was really awesome to watch! If you're planning on going to Gyeonbokgung which I personally think is a must, be there during those times. I think there's a 10am and 2pm session and it goes on for 20 minutes. The queen's chamber was also a very interactive experience. We had to take our shoes off before going in and we were allowed to look around. It was probably the best thing there!

This is such a peaceful and beautiful destination to visit if you are in Seoul. The palace is massive and although you cannot step into all the houses you can visit the museum to gather informational pamphlets and walk through to learn about the imperials throne, traditions and view their clothing, tools and even see the structure of how the formation of the dynasty. I would not recommend you to go if you are not into seeing old museums or looking for adventure.

review_title: Nice if the weather is not too cold
review_body: It is quite big and has a lot of things to see inside. there's also a museum there as well. After you finish looking around there you can easily access buses or subways as well as many other attractions in the neighborhood.

second time visiting this palace, and it is still great. best place to learn the culture and history of korea. the place is really huge so prepare for a long walk! there is also museums to visit inside.for more fun experience, you can rent those pretty hanbok and get inside for free, i believe. it was very cold when i visited though so i decided not to rent one
it was a freezing day but it was a beautiful palace, just sad that I have see the guard parade. it's very easy to get there with the metro

review_title: A must do if you are in seoul
review_body: We made it to witness the guard changing ceremony at 10am. The palace is huge and we spent hours walking around. We managed to get discount as we were traveling in a group of 12 so it's Korean won 2400 per pax. Worth the money as we went in and took some beautiful pictures

The grounds here are large and beautiful. There were a lot of tourists groups but it did not feel crowded. There are amazing views and photo ops and it is just nice to spend the day outdoors in such a beautiful place. There was also a gift shop and cafe there. Stay for the traditional changing of the guard ceremony, it was nice and not too long. There is a charge to get to the grounds and a separate charge to go inside the palace, we opted not to go into the palace, there was plenty to explore anyways.

We went to this itinerary during winter. Some parts of the ground are very slippery. Several people slipped and fell.We have someone to guide us through the palace. Great and meaningful history.Must visit this historical palace and get a guide to explain the building structure and share it's history.

My daughter and I decided to visit the palace. I am so glad we did. The palace is so beautiful and we spent about an hour and a half waking around.It was freezing cold and it was nice to be able to grab a coffee during the walk.We also stopped to have traditional tea.It is well worth the visit. And a cab fare is really cheap if you take an orange cab. The black cabs are more expensive.

review_title: visited the incredible Palace grounds in the snow; totally fascinating
review_body: in spite of the cold we visited the palace and walked around these beautiful grounds as much as possible. It's a must-see, especially if you should be lucky enough to see the changing of the palace guard. We weren't able to - cancelled due to the snow, however, they were standing at the front gate entrance. Very colorful and fierce looking guys who didn't mind having their photos taken.The palace was built in 1395 and was the main royal palace of the Joseon dynasty and destroyed by fire during the Imjin War (Japanese invasion - 1592-8) and abandoned for two centuries. Mount Bugak is the backdrop and if you want to have a lovely view of the entire grounds, walk over to the National Museum and take the elevator to the (? can't remember; might be the 8th floor or higher?) where there is a terrace that provides a marvelous view.
The palace is great culture, good for pictures, and offers free English tours. The place is huge, and near other attractions, so I recommend planning your day around it.

We went in November. A bit chilly out but no queues and less tourists. Well preserved old palace with traditional guards in Korean dress. Changing of the guard ceremony was beautiful. Earlier in the day was nice as we were largely alone. If it is rainy day I would not recommend as there is very little in the way of shelter. Even in winter, the gardens were beautiful! In a truly busy metropolis, this was 2 hours of less noise and a hold onto Korea's past which is not always evident with the rush to modernity!

This was one of our very first stops upon arrival in South Korea. I would definitely suggest going in springtime, when the cherry blossoms are in bloom, and hopefully the lotus flowers in the pond are blooming too. You could easily spend half a day to a full day to see each and every piece of this area. We got some great photos, and definitely plan to head back again before our couple of years here are done!

review_title: Amazing and Beautiful! Good for all Ages!
review_body: Walking through Gyeongbokgung Palace was an amazing experience. All of the buildings are beautiful and full of rich history. Free tours run every few minutes in various languages. Our tour guide was extremely knowledgeable and kind!

A must go place!You may find it is a good to place to go in different seasons, go with a big group or good to go alone! A place where you can sit to enjoy the scenery, take pictures and to find out more the Korean Royal life.Go connection with Metro!

Don't miss this if you are visiting Seoul. The guard changing ceremonies are the highlight and performing daily in short and long sessions. Do at least stay for the short one if your schedule allowed. There are also free guided tours available in different languages. Head to the right from the main gate for the information center once you purchase the entrance ticket. The staff was very helpful! The palace was indeed amazing in winter. Many girls - tourists and locals alike dressed up in hanbok. It was such a beautiful scene. I've been to Seoul countless times but this was the first to the palace. I would totally come back again the next time to learn more about its history, and hopefully the weather won't be too cold so I can dress up in hanbok to take a stroll in the palace.
being over 65 years old we were very surprised that we did not have to pay for the entrance fee as seniors.Place was very grand , very inteersting and worth seeing

One of the best places for pictures! Lots of walking though and there's really only a few spectacular places. One is the pond in back the the small pagoda and the other is behind and to the left of the main throne room- it's a huge dinner hall in a rectangular pond. Find these and a few others and you're good. Otherwise it can get exhausting. Beautiful in winter, too.

We spent an hour to get to 'Jongro-3road' station, because we wanted to go to "Gyeongbokgung". Before we go inside of it, we could see a large door called "Gwanghwamun". We could see quite a lot of people wearing "Hanbok" when we get through the gate. The palace was absolutely astonishing. We couldn't see the end because it's vast compound. Also when we looked inside of the Hanok(Korean traditional house), we could see beautiful colored ceiling. We could feel that this palace is the history of the place. It was almost hard to take in. We felt overwhelming. Also there is a wonderful lake. This lake was surrounded by large trees. In the middle of the lake there is a small island. We were honestly, completely blown away by this. Because we saw this place, we become aware of the sheer wealth and power of the Joseon dynasty. Absolutely incredible place. I highly recommend to visit here. Visiting this place is just the same with seeing a little piece of a picture in the past. Tip : It spends more than 3 hours to look this palace. Also even if you are foreigner, you can go inside the palace for free if you wear a Korean traditional clothes. You can rent it $20. You can get a great picture with it.

We were there the same date as the korean celebrate lunar new year hence the new year decoration. Had lots of fun taking photos and most importantly we got to wear on Korean traditional clothes for photo shooting and it was for free!
The highlight was the changing of the guards, which was colourful. I loved the mountains in th backdrop.

This is the second time here. A lot of tourists as usual, but well manicured. Quite big, takes an hour or two to walk the whole palace. Must see if you haven't already, but probably not more than once.
We visited during winter. Beautiful palace. Definitely worth the visit! Better to wait to watch the change of palace guards.

I think i only explore 1/3 of the whole area as it was so cold during my visit. but the scenery that you can expect is beyond your imagination, i must say that this is one of the best place for you to visit. Great ancient architecture. Be there at 10am every morning to watch guard changing ceremony at the front yard. The palace closed on Tuesday. Admission fee is cheap, only KRW3000 per pax.

review_title: Impressive palace, try to see the ceremonies.
review_body: We were fortunate enough to be present for the changing of the guard ceremony (check times). It was very colorful, the horns sounded just like bagpipes!

This beautiful palace with history that spirals back to 13th century is definitely to be included in your top 3 to do items in Seoul! Located convenienty by Gyeungbokgung metro station,it come conplete with free guided tours in many different languages.Our English guide ,Ginny was very poised in her traditional costume and was never short in updating the group about the tiniest details of the Joseun dynasty from the smart palace architectures to its fate from invasion of Japanese occupation amongst other info...the view of the well preserved palace on the blue sunny winter day was breathtaking!The palace was also located side by side to the National Folk Musuem that houses a lot of historicsl artifacts.The many traditional activity booths set up there due to the Lunar New Year celebration made the visit all the more an interesting learning experience

Very convenient to travel to Gyeongbokgung Palace. Is just outside a metro station. Interesting palace to visit. Totally recommend for family who are bringing elderly. A slow stroll and a place to see their Korean palace culture.

It's large, impressive and historial. But a bit boring in the winter. Most of the courtyards are mud and wet after the snow. Very crowded with Chinese tour groups during the Chinese New Year holiday. Most of the buildings you don't enter and you just look in through the door or window. Might be more interesting with a tour group. Overall worth seeing if you have some time to fill since it's only 3k won for the general entry. But I wouldn't consider it a "must see"

Truly beautiful. Bit of a hike to get around and see everything there, but on a nice pleasant Seoul day well worth the extra steps. Interesting architecture and would recommend taking the time to just take a step back and take it in. A guide would be somewhat helpful, but a good tour guide book can be nearly as accommodating.

We went here during winter but it was still busy! We bought tickets on arrival then decided to hire some Hanbok (traditional Korean dresses) which were all located outside the palace on the main roads. We didn't know that if you are wearing traditional clothes you get to enter the palace for free! The ticket lady at the door told us to go get a refund for our tickets. It was simply amazing! All the intricate little details of the design was mesmerizing! Definitely a must see!

Had a short walk in the compounds before coming out as my aged father could not walk much. That said, the trees were barren and I think it would definitely be much nicer during spring and autumn.
