I went during Chuseok, which I recommend to everyone because of the broad array of events which were planned for the holiday. Gyeongbokgung Palace is just beautiful and a nice sunny day made the whole experience that much better.

review_title: Great tourist site and very inexpensive ticket
review_body: The site is close to Anguk metro station and has several courtyards and temples/palaces. Just keep walking north through each courtyard until one gets to the Royal Palace to see the King's throne. Your 3000 won ticket also gives you access to see the temple across the road to the right at the end of the palace and there is a free cultural museum there too. Takes half a day to see all.

Coming here during the summer is definitely a harsh time, as the ground of the palace is mostly soil/sand, and it would be terribly hot, should a sudden shower comes, there are not much places to go to. Night tour would be nicer I think, with all lit up.

This is the biggest palace out of the 5 palaces in Seoul. I went in November & the changing of the guard took place at 10am, not sure if changes so make sure to change. It was definitely worth watching. The palace is quite big but you can walk through the whole palace within 1-1.5hour. You get free entrance to the museum with your ticket but I didn't spend any time there because I was part of a tour.

This is not that palace that comes to your mind when you think of any palace. This is a wide spread area with center located prayer hall and small rooms around the area. Entrace and buildings inside are of typical Korean construction in their early stages. You may feel relaxed as if you were in Korea before 70 to 100 years
Nice view especially during Autumn. Nice weather. You can get in free when you are wearing korena traditional wear - Hanbook.
The palace grounds are huge and expansive - the sheer size of the atrium will surprise you - but the palace in itself lacks luster and nothing magnificent.

The palace is very similar to Changdeokgung Palace in many ways in terms of the immaculate grounds, buildings, etc. - but in some ways, it was more beautiful. The palace is huge, so be prepared for long walks. Also, there isn't a place to buy stuff to eat (although there may be a place to purchase drinks) within the palace. I would suggest going on a weekday as when I went on a weekend, there were extremely large crowds.However, the main attraction is the changing of the guard ceremonies. There is a smaller ceremony on the grounds at around 9:30-9:45, with the main ceremony at approximately 10 AM. The ceremony itself seemed anticlimactic and a bit uninteresting.The palace itself is beautiful. The palace did seem to get a bit repetitive after a while as the buildings seemed to look the same.Logistically, you may want to combine your visit with a visit at the National Folk Museum and Bukchon Hanok Village.
Beautiful royal castle and residence. Wonderful park grounds with lots to see and plenty of room for leisurely walks. Love it!

An extensive ground with many beautiful buildings and scenes. Spent 1-2 hours here walking around and taking photos. Perfect for a sunny day. The palace is closed on Tuesday's, and there's also free entry for those wearing traditional dress

The Palace showcases the extravagance of the monarchy in their time. It is a showcase of culture, fauna and architecture etc. if one wishes to learn Korean history etc. It is best to join an English tour guide who has knowledge of its history and significance. Try to catch the changing of guards ritual at 10:00 a.m. and then tour the palace. There is an entrance fee ... but if you are a US military personnel, this is one of the choices offered in a package.

review_title: historic palace in the heart of seoul
review_body: Great palace to visit to experience a bit of korean history. It is definitely a main tourist attraction that is worth the time to visit. Guard changing at 10am and another one in the afternoon.
its realy big The complex really big.Worth a walk all of it.There is a lovely lakeThere are also guides in EnglishTwo hours trip

review_title: Beautiful palace with a great tour
review_body: We were able to take a tour which was extremely informative. The guide was well educated about the grounds and history of the site. We also took the secret garden tour

review_title: Interesting - Changing of The Guard Most Interesting
review_body: The grounds and buildings of the palace are interesting but not spectacular. What is quite exceptional is changing of the guard at the main gate that was the highlight. A surprise that it was very reminiscent of the changing of the guard at Buckingham Palace and other places in Europe. Colourful and apparently historic according to our guide. It was very crowded so arrive early for a front row view.It is very close to a subway stop so should be very to access if you are staying close to the transit system.

We came here on the first day of our trip and what a beautiful place to start. This place is huge and there is lots to look around and see. The entrance price is more then reasonable. Just be warned if you leave through a certain gate you'll have to pay to get back in.

review_title: We had a lovely time at the palace
review_body: What a fun time. The grounds are lovely and there is a lot going on. The leaves were changing and so the fall colors were super pretty. There was a changing of the guards sort of ceremony and that was really fun to watch. There were lots of folks in their traditional dress and we just had a lovely time. There is also a really great shopping area nearby and that was nice too. I am not sure what the shopping area was called.

review_title: Interesting but not a lot to see
review_body: This is interesting, but nothing too out of the ordinary. The changing of the guard was the highlight of the visit.
The temples have been renovated . Allow yourself sufficient time to visit this site, there is a lot to see.
Away from the busy street and embraced the ample space and astonishing ancient architecture. I would recommend my family and friends to visit when they visit Seoul.

I was lucky because I got to see the changing guard ceremony when I was there. Two times this palace got destroyed by fire but now it stood so majestic in the northern part of Seoul. The palace itself represents traditional culture mixture with contemporary architecture. The palace has a huge compound with beautiful scenery that allows visitors to take endless photos especially if you are wearing hanbok. Inside the compound there are two museums, too bad I didnt get the chance to visit it.
Beautiful traditional palace in the nature. The tickets are reasonable and there is a free guide that takes you all around telling you abouy history.

review_title: Gyeongbokgung Palace in Seoul, South Korea
review_body: This was the main royal palace of Joseon dynasty. The first one was build more than six centuries ago, but was then destroyed and rebuilt a few times. The last one has been in the past century and is now meticulously rebuilt following the original project. The whole area offers several buildings to visit including huge gates, palaces, small and bigger buildings. Expect to spend at least a couple of hours to visit this area. This was the most beautiful tourist site that we visited in Seoul.

The palace is huge so just keep in mind that you will have to walk the whole palace. We watched the changing of the guards, took pictures with the guards outside. If you're going in the summer, dress comfortable because is was too darn hot! Not much shade unless you're near the palace and the other buildings. There is so much history there which was very interesting. Beautiful palace, a must see if you're a first timer.

The most famous palace in Seoul. Entrance fee is 3000 won. Combi tickets is 10,000won altogether. Free entree for those who are wearing Hanbok. There's free guided tour around the palace at certain timing. Visitors should check the schedule for changing of guards ceremony before going to this palace.

When I planed to go Seoul, South Korea, the one itinerary must put in my schedule that was Gyeongbokgung Palace. I had visited Seoul fifth times, but I had also went with different people in these fifth times which meaned I visited Gyeongbokgung Palace fifth times. It was because that I would like to explain my experience to them such as the feeling which was comfortable to me walk into Gyeongbokgung Palace and I wanted to share with them. In the recent time of I visited Seoul that was on June 2016 with my friend. As I said, I wanted to bring her to Gyeongbokgung Palace, she wasn't understand why we will go an old and non-shopping viewpoint. But she finally accepted this itinerary. On that day, we woke up early and went to Gyeongbokgung Palace. There provided many kinds languages of guided tour to introduce the Gyeongbokgung Palace, and we also joined one guided tour. When the guider started to explain, introduced and we was walking around the Gyeongbokgung Palace slowly. She changed her mind and told me that thanks my recommend. I was happy that she agreed with me it had a strong historical atmosphere in Gyeongbokgung Palace. In my opinion, I will suggest you walk slowly to see and visit that non-commercial, silence environment.

review_title: Interesting Place for understanding the korean culture and history
review_body: It was a good place to explore and understand the history and culture of the korean during old days. I would suggest for travelers who interested of knowing more about culture and history, shall spend at least 3 hours to complete the whole palace. A free guided tour in English, Chinese, Japanese and other language are available at selected time slot (may get this information from the website). The tour takes about 1 hour to 1 and half hour with a guide to explain and story-telling about the history and what are the building for. However, the free guided tour was a targeted tour on selected spots, therefore to cover the full palace, you may need to explore on your own after that and there is also a museum which you can visit for free admission. To make your money worth if you are a fans of understanding the history and culture, you may get the Royal Palaces Ticket which come along with secret garden entrance at 10,000 won instead of paying one palace for 3,000 won per pax.
We enjoyed watching the changing of the guards and our tour of the palace was really good. The architecture and colors of the buildings were amazing.
Gorgeous... wear the traditional hanbok costumes here and relive your korean dramas! Hahahaha! Beautiful..

A must visit place. Subway station is connected to the monument. Follow the directions and markings in the subway station. Last entry in the Palace is 1600 HRS. Try to be there before 3:00 PM. The Museum next to Palace is free. Museum is open until 6 pm. There is a good souvenir shop in the basement of the museum.
This place is good for the one who like to discover the Korean culture. It's large. Should go with tour guide to get fully knowledge.

review_title: A great taste of Korean history
review_body: Be prepared to travel back in time in Korea. Brilliant architecture (if that's what they call the palace artwork), intricate and delicate designs. Went here expecting nothing but just a palace but left with so much admiration with Korean history. Don't miss the changing of the guards, check the website for the times. you can take selfies with guards but they will never smile for you. When i went here, there were heaps of Korean kids in their traditional costumes which as beyond amazing! Very pretty and very traditional. It felt like I was in a Korean village from way back then. It gets very busy so goodluck with the crowd.
Plenty of marvelous historical strolling. Right downtown. Near Insadong arts street and near the main performing arts Sejong Center. Relax and get out of traffic.

We were disappointed with the Gyeongbokgung Palace. So many guide books put it as one of the top ten sites to visit in Seoul. The palace is not very well maintained, many rooms have no exhibits or furniture there. The only scenic spot is near the small ornamental lake.
An awesome place to visit and see some of the history of such a great country. The Changing of the Guard Ceremony should not be missed. If you visit this palace you will not be disappointed.
It's a sprawling complex so comfy shoes are essential. We used an audio guide which was very helpful in explaning the background of the palace.
At first, I thought that Gyeongbokgung is quite small, but then it is totally big which took me around 2 hours going around.This palace also provides night tour which should be bought in advance.

review_title: Nice palace and strolling around opportunities!
review_body: Nice palace located in the centre of Seoul. Come when they have guard changing ceremony, really great
Very nice Palace.. but you must have a tourist guide in order to understand the function of the selective buildings

It's the main Palace of Seoul. It's interesting to visit since it gives the possibility to learn some Korean history. I would suggest to take part to a guided tour, it takes about 60minutes and gives the possibility to understand the most important information about the history of the Palace.

we were lucky enough to come during their autumn season to watch the night illumination that only being shown specifically in the month of october to welcome the autumn season. it was good as everything was well coordinated and the show time was clearly written. real traditional dance with light illumination show combined, you cannot ask for more for the amount they charge. don't miss it if you are there in october next year.

As we are walking toward the Palace, we met some student volunteer guide in the subway. It was very helpful to have the guide with us so we know the history and stories of the palace. If I do go to the Palace again, I may consider putting on the Korean traditional costume. Many people were dressed up in the costume. It is a rather Big palace so please have a meal before you visit it.

With quite a few different palaces to visit, we decided on this one by pure luck. It's super easy to get to with a subway station nearby. We decided to wait for the English guided tour and it was definitely worth it! The museum that's onsite is also good. Plan on spending at least 2 hours there and wear comfortable shoes for all the walking required.

My friends and I arrived in time to see the changing of the guard ceremony which occurs every two hours - lots of drums, horns and costumes. Afterward we toured the site. Later, we took the free one hour guided tour in English (after general admission fee of W3000 for adults or in a combo ticket with 4 palaces for W10,000) The tour guide explained so much about Korean history that we didn't glean from the posted signs, such as the scenic panels, floor heating, foreign occupation. Do take a tour! Although there is a lot of walking on level ground. Tours are offered a few times a day in English and Japanese. There were also private guides doing tours in other languages. One can also rent traditional clothing onsite or at a local shop to add to the experience. Easy access from subway stops. Palace museum next door is a 30 minute stop with free admission. Closed on Tuesdays!

review_title: You can't miss this place, fancy a visit at night!
review_body: Lovely place just beautiful and traditional thing to see one of the most famous tour spot and it starts to open at night time with beautiful night lights you should plan your schedule for night visit if you like cultural sights and calm atmosphere.

review_title: Suggeted Itinerary For Visits To The Palace Quarter District of Seoul
review_body: Before visiting Gyeongbokgung Palace, the largest Royal Palace in Seoul, I would suggest that you visit Gwanghwamum Square which is easily access by metro. Nearby the square is National Museum of Korean Contemporary History and Sejong Performing Arts Centre. Right across the square is the Gyeongbokung Palace with beautiful Palace ground and two museums - National Palace of Korea and National Folk Museum of Korea. I was there in late October for the Fall colors of the Palace ground as well as floating Pavilion and Palace and another old Palace worth visitng.You will exit from National Folk Museum. Turn left and walk up to Samchenong -dong street . Contemporary and traditional in outlook with many galleries, designer shops, themed museums, restaurants and wine bars. Stop for tea brake or have lunch there.After your energy reload, proceed to visit Bukchon Hanok Village. Many interesting shops to browse.You last stop is Insadong where tourists flocked to buy arts and handy-crafts and souvenirs. Have a tea-break before browing around including visit to one of Korea;s most famous buddhist temple - Jogyesa Temple. There are metro stations near-by for your evening destination in Seoul.

It was a cultural experience for us. The palace compound was huge and it could easily take a whole day trip. They have nice sites inside and my friends and I were anle to take wonderful photos. It was like a throwback to ancient Seoul and it was a nice experience. We were even able to catch the changing of the guards which was a good exeperience. Bring water when you go here as stores and vending machines are far in between. Try to go early as it gets very crowded easily.

It was a Saturday when we visited and the palace was a bit crowded. Many locals in their traditional hanbok allow tourists to pose with them for pictures. The palace ground is huge with several structures on it. It costs $3 to enter the main palace but free for seniors if you show your passport. Be prepared to do a lot of walking, but definitely a must see. The changing of the guards is an added attraction.

Located right across city hall station, you will have to pay an admission to get in to see the sights and sounds of the palace. Great views and nice walks inside. At the entrance, there is a performance done every 2 hours or so by the palace performers and after, you could take pictures with them.
Absolutely cool. I could imagine King's movement at this place. Interesting walls, building shapes, especially the roofs. very interested.

This palace has quiet wide area. But you won't feel too tired to explore the whole building, because it offers a very beautiful scenery. If you like to explore the historical areas, this place is recommended!

The biggest of the 5 Palaces. Once stepped in, feel like you are transported back to the hundreds years ago. If you are wearing the traditional korean costumes, entrance is free, and your photo with the palace will look like you are in Historical Korean Drama. The inside of each building is very minimally decorated & furnished, big contrast with lavish style in Chinese Palace or European castle.Anyway, keep going to the back & towards the garden & you will see more tourist here than the palace itself. Snap a photo at the pond with the tower in the middle, & the mountain as the background. The view is simply stunning.

Palace is nice and big. Good photo opportunities as we came early November. The leaves are still turning brown.The change guards ceremony is recommended. If u arent interested in history or pictures and prefer shopping then skip this otherwise this will be a good sightseeing place. Entrance fees is cheap. 3000 won for adults. Children below 7 is free

I did not visit the other palaces around Seoul but this is definitely worth a visit. The palace grounds are quite large and it would take at least 2 hours to cover the entire area. We had a surprise visit from the 'Emperor' himself, as he walked through the grounds with his "Emperess' and 'guards'!Lots of local Koreans in their traditional costumes.
The place with many surprises..It a very big place and I was there for 3hours .Make sure you go with a tour or hire the audio guide at the entrance which is very helpful.
This is a must-see in Seoul. A huge place, very interesting buildings and lovely gardens. Great for people-watching too, especially on Sundays when lots of locals wear traditional Korean dress.

As Palaces go it is rather standard and the changing of the guard...Well there are other impressive places around the World to see the same sort of thing.However, it is worth a visit. The Changing of the Guard is at 1000hrs and at 1400hrs.The costumes of the guards are very interesting and colourful but probably not very practical!As In London, you are allowed to pose with the gate guards!

I was lucky to visit it on the country's National Culture Day, which they allowed the entrance for free! It's an amazing place to discover the history of South Korea, great for photography too, a bit crowded with tourists, at the time I went (1pm) the guards were there with their cool ancient uniforms and weapons which cool to see, also a lot of people like to pay to dress up on the traditional costumes and wonder around the palace, which I find quite cool to have that opportunity.

This Palace,is the residence of the Emperor during the Seong dynasty. It offers a great insight into the living style and architecture of the era. In terms of magnificence, it matches the Forbidden City in Beijing.

We booked a complimentary tour through Visit Korea's website and met at the ticket office at 10am on the day of visit. Our guide was a lovely lady who was a volunteer. It's impressive that locals would volunteer their time and energy to introduce their city to foreigners. She was very enthusiastic and spoke decent English. We started at the main entrance and walked our way through the whole palace. Extremely beautiful place with lots of history and unique architecture. Our wonderful guide explained the architectural aspects, history of the structures, and even some present day local affairs! We wouldn't have been able to understand so much without her. Time well spent and a must-visit in Seoul!
It's in Seoul but when you are there you feel miles away from the city, mountains in the background, a lake with a fab pavillion to look at - absolutely brilliant to look at and spend some time there
Nice palace with great view, great culture and great history.You will require at least 2-4 hours to spend time and roam around. Must see if you are tourist.

A visit to Gyeongbokgung Palace with a guide will give you a glimpse of imperial life during the Chosun dynasty. Total visit will probably take only about an hour at the most starting with the public areas and continuing to the private chambers of the king and the queen. The palace is located in the heart of the city and is quite accessible. In terms of grandeur, it cannot compare to the Imperial Palace in Beijing but we were told that this was intentional given the political situation at that time in history.

review_title: The largest old Palace in Seoul
review_body: I visited other 2 palaces before comming here, and found it's big, and I was very tired and hungry at that time, so I ended the visiting within 1 hour. exactly, 2-2.5 hours would be better.

Entering this palace is like we walk in the history.Trying to imagine what the live in the year of 1300 looks like.It's definitely a grand palace, huge complex with lot of green sceneery inside.Love the roof architecture.I personally like Hyangwon-Jeong pavilion, a royal residence of Emperor Gojong. Surrounded by lotus pond, makes this place so beautiful and serene. Direction to this attraction : stop at Gyeongbokgung Palace Station (Seoul Subway Line 3), Exit 5.Instagram : @adjimantoro

First off, don't expect to get through the grounds of the palace quickly. It is one of the most extensive palaces in Asia. Most of the buildings are only a few decades old, mainly due to ancient conflicts taking heavy tolls on them. That being said, they are very well done reproductions and do show how amazing the palace grounds must have been in their heyday. There is a changing of the palace guard every 15 minutes from 10:00 am - 2:00 pm which is a bit more colourful that some others I've seen, though not as extensive.One aspect that impressed me was that the English descriptions were quite detailed. This is something that is not necessarily encountered in other parts of Asia.I would consider this a must-see if you have an interest in the history of Korea.

I have been to Gyeongdong Palace a number of times.I also am from the US. This time I brought a visitor from the U.S.. We are both cabinet makers, so in visualizing the construction of the palace and other buildings on the grounds, we were impressed. That's not to say that there isn't an air of falsity about the restoration/renovations/reconstruction of the compound. The buildings are not that old. The grounds are not maintained as if they were still a living quarters. One is left wandering about without having a true grasp of the daily life of the palace grounds. There needs to be more visual and written placards What is important is with an imagination a person can picture how people moved about and how the city was laid. There is room for improvement. Drop your iPods, cell phone and other tech devices. Imagine 100 years ago. 200 years ago.
The main palace in Seoul and also attracts the most tourists. However, we didn't go in the palace since it has empty spaces only and most of the rooms were closed.

The palace is very easy to get to by Metro and the exit takes you right to the main courtyard of the palace. It gets quite busy although doesn't feel too crowded as the grounds are quite big. It seemed that a relatively popular activity was to dress up in local traditional attire which was available for rental. I didn't go for that personally but there were many families, school groups and also couples that did so and this somewhat added to the atmosphere of the palace.A striking contrast was the backdrop to the palace grounds where on one side you had the mountains and on the other side you had the tall modern buildings of the city. Aside from the main preserved buildings the gardens themselves provide nice photo opportunities particularly around the pond areas. There are also replica buildings that have been constructed that you can wander in to.The palace also has changing of the guards which I unfortunately missed so worthwhile checking the times and getting there to catch the ceremony.Note that the vast majority of the visit is outdoors and walking around the grounds so do be prepared.

review_title: Beautiful place to visit especially with locals in their traditional clothing!
review_body: There's quite a walk from the start to finish. We're on a tour in Oct and the weather was perfect for this site visit even though the temp climbed to 20 degree Celsius.

It was colder than expected as there was alot of open area. Dress warmly if you are visiting in late autumn or winter. There are ramps around so bringing a pram is still better than carrying baby the whole day. Do exit by exit 2 if you want to rent hanbok. I exited by exit 5 and there waa no rental booth there, though it directly linked to the subway.

I had to cross the main road (traffic lights road) to the main gate of this palace. Luckily we got experienced to see the morning " morning guard ceremony" with the traditional/ancient musics. And also there is Interpretation Services Offered Tours depart in front of the information center at Heungnyemun Gate.Duration: About 1 hr - 1 hr 30 min. If not mistaken, This palace were once destroyed by fire during the Imjin War but then all of the palace buildings were later restored during the King Gojong (overheard the explanation by interpretator). 3000₩ / enterance and closed every tuesday.. the opening hours is depends on the seasons. ~plan your trip peeps..hv a nice travel here in s.korea~

review_title: great place to visit for a couple hours
review_body: I stumbled to this place after walking through the insa-dong street neighborhoods. There is an entrance fee of 3000 KRW, about $3 u.s. dollars and it's worth the price. I did not join any tour groups, I explored and wandered on my own. The place can get dusty as the interior of the palace grounds are all light gravel. I visited this place on a weekday during the morning hours and it was somewhat crowded with mostly young kids on a field trip.The place could be toured with in 60-90 minutes
Visited the palace and garden on 30 th October 2016. Beautiful autumn colours. Don't miss live changing guard ceremony. Rich with Korean culture. Must see palace.

You can go there by train or bus and just a few walk to the palace. Entrance fee is 3,000 KRW and you should visit there since morning because it's very large. For women who would like to wear Hanbok (traditional dress), you can rent from shop near the palace before and go inside. If you buy ticket and go inside, it cannot re-entry to rent the dress later.
I learned a lot about architecture from visiting this palace. Also a lot about Korean history. It is well worth a visit.
The palace is huge but it's relaxing to walk around the area. Great place to understand a little of the history of Korea. Good place for photography.

review_title: Impressive palace in center of Seoul
review_body: Visited the palace and garden on a busy Sunday. Beautiful and well maintained palace, beautiful colors, clean facilities and nice shop. Certainly worth the visit!

It's a great place and it's well preserved. It remains intact and is situated in front of the Blue House, and behind the statue of King Sejong. If you want to know more about South Korea's history, this is the way to go.It only took us a 3-5 min. Walk from our guesthouse, (Guesthouse Korea). There was a performance for like every 20 mins or so? Where performers dress up as the way that people dressed before and did the rituals etc. To depict the old times. At the end of the ceremony, some performers stand outside the palace and station there where you can take a picture with them (Proper manners and gestures should be observed. They'll feel violated if you get touchy with them.)Inside, I can say that the overall palace is well-maintained. The comfort rooms are also great. Once you get out, you will see the front of the Blue House, you can also take a stroll in the side walks to enjoy the streets of Korea while enjoying the views of the falling leaves of the tree's

This is a good tour to learn historical Korea. You will find a couple of grand palaces in that big compound. If you come in before 10 am, there you'll see a live marching guard like in Buckingham Palace in Korean version. It will run for about 30 minutes. If you come in wearing a hanbok or traditional costume of Korea, your admission fee is free! To my surprise, quite a number of locals came wearing their hanbok..Those who wore them became instant Hollywood stars...why? They look cute & blend well with the palaces on the background so those tourists took advantages of those nice shots as souvenir! By the way, if you're interested, few hanbok rentals is just near outside the palace itself. Go for it!!

I'll admit I was lucky. I was there on the one(?) day of the year that those who wear traditional Korean outfits got in free. The site was abundant with traditional attire. That enhanced the tour. It's a non-rush tour. It was enjoyable, pleasant, had hidden places to sit and relax. A tour guide would be helpful to learn more, but wandering alone was fine. Go near all the way to the north to see the pond. Sit, relax and enjoy. Once you finish, visit the free museum just to the west, by the subway entrance. If you're a history buff, you'll enjoy.

Very nice place to take photos with traditional hanbok, did I mention you get free admissions too while wearing hanbok to palaces! You can see the change of guards ceremony, check out music performances. We went during the autumn season, so the trees were all turning red and it was very pretty.
One of the largest and oldest palaces in the region. Nice architecture. Very well maintained. Beautiful symmetry to the place.

review_title: Great place for sightseeing in Seoul
review_body: This place is a must go when visiting Seiul for the first time. The weather was nice and cool so it was very relaxing to walk and enjoy the beautiful scenery of the palace and nature. Bring a camera and take lots of pictures so you can remember how beautiful this place is.

review_title: Visit only if you have no where else to go in Seoul
review_body: visited the Gyeongbokgung Palace and it was the usual oriental palace stuff you get to see in China.Only interesting thing would be the change of Guards that was held at 2pm daily (heard it's 4 times daily thing).

review_title: A must see if you enjoy history and architecture.
review_body: A fantastic walk through history with some great photo opportunities. Lots of atmosphere. Much better on a sunny day.
Huge palace. Ancient buildings in the middle of very modern ones. This is funny and a great symbol of all the contrast that happen in this great city.

It was cultural day when we went to the palace. Hence, there was free admission and it was crowded with students. Nevertheless, some of the spots in the palace were very scenic with mountain backdrop. There was performance on the guards changing ceremony before we enter the palace and we also saw the fake king and queen doing their stroll in the palace with their guards. If you follow them, they will lead you to this pavilion with gorgeous backdrop for photo-taking. The architectural was beautiful and I love the lake especially. It was a good photo taking spot.
Went there during day time. It was crowded but still okay. I saw a lot of people wearing hanbok and it feels like I was in the ancient time. Nice garden. The place is well maintained and clean.

The Temple was very large but had nothing to do. It was however really pretty and there was a nice museum. The small giftshop was awfully expensive. The museum had a large variety of items but the signs with descriptiones were only simply and shortly translated into english, so I'd suggest that you get an audio guide.

Visited last October 16, 2016Gyeongbokgung Palace is the main palace. This is the only palace we visited during our trip. We toured the place and it was huge and beautiful. The walls and designs are lovely. Please dont miss the changing of the guards ceremony. It's a very interesting show.Try wearing hanbok so you can enter the palace free of charge.

review_title: Look out for their night tour ( Only 4 times a year)
review_body: Visited Seoul twice and finally made a visit to the Palace. The night tour was simply amazing and they only have 500 tickets allocated for foreign visitors each night. 3,00 won per entry and it is worth every penny. Check out their performances as well.

Didn't get to see the inside of the palace because we didn't realise it closed at 4pm. Was in the courtyard and the views were lovely. A mix of old and new as the buildings are nestled among the skyscrapers and mountains. We visited the museum exhibits instead which were well laid out and had some excellent animations for clearer explanations. The reading room has a booth with ports to charge your phone. Very useful.

It's a good day's fun, there are small streets with lots of small shops and places you can rent Hanbok (the traditional clothing) immediately to the East of the palace. We rented Hanbok and entered the palace as the admission is free if you're wearing Hanbok. It is also a trend among young people and couples nowadays to do it and take pictures while touring the palace, kinda like cosplaying in a way I guess?It was interesting seeing the changing of the guard, different architectures and other people walking around with Hanbok too.

Our visit was so interesting, no doubt because of an excellent English-speaking guide. She gave a good overview of Confucian traditions and the Joseun Dynasty. The grounds are quite lovely, plus there are two museums on the premises that are worth seeing.
My second time to visit the palace and it's still amazing. The changing of the guards is a must see. Try to schedule a visit during one.

The visit was during summer. It was hot and humid. Bring over umbrella to protect you from direct sun. The palace is very huge so expect to spend 3 hours to complete whole course. The guard march is at the courtyard before the palace entrance and make sure you find a spot near by the palace entrance to get clear view.

Very economical experience! The entry fee was very reasonable. Think it worked out to be about US$3. The grounds provide free tours in 3 languages at different times of the day. We took the English speaking one at 1:30 pm. A rich piece of Korean history and a lovely way to spend a couple of hours. Note the palace is closed on Tuesdays.

The palace is centrally located and directly link with subway. The entrance fee is 3000won per adult. In compare with the palace in China and Thailand, this palace seems not as luxury as others. There was not much decorations can be seen and just similar to a large park. There are lot of local people dressing in their native clothing and taking photos in the palace. The palace is a nice place to have leisure walks during holiday.
Interesting place to visit! See guard changing is a must! Opened every day from 9am to 6pm unless Tuesday!
Best time to go, I would say is during autumn. The palace has a small garden somewhere in the outskirts, the autumn leaves make it that much more worth the scenary.
Make sure to watch the changing of the guards in the morning. You may want to visit during a weekday, too.

review_title: A place to visit in any season
review_body: This is one of the places which we have visited many times in different seasons. There's a Hanbok rental shop which you just need to register and you can wear Hanbok for 15mins

Awed by the grandeur of the palace. The biggest and the grandest of all the 5 palaces.There were a lot of people from different nationalities. Saw the 3 buddhas. It has the King’s office, A huge kitchen, king’s hall where he entertains his visitors. I even posed with the palace guards. Truly beautiful!

Great stop in downtown Seoul. I stumbled across this as i had a couple of hours to spare u til hotel checkout time. It was a quick walk from my hotel, and I arrived just in time to see the changing of the guard. The compound is so big that the mass that had gathered to watch the changing of the guard quickly dispersed as we entered the compound. The fee was under $3 USA to enter--totally worth the proce. Fun total see the architecture and layout. I wish I had spent more time here!

review_title: Magnificent landmark within a modern City
review_body: We visited this palace, the largest of the 5 palaces within Seoul, in the morning and it was already teeming with tourists. There is so much history to absorb both in visual and audible form. The details on the decor, roof structure & building design are awe inspiring. Each detail, whether it be the shape of the roof, the colour combination of the ceiling beams, the setting of rooms (with heating options), is so meaningful. Like the other palaces, this is meticulously restored. You can almost feel the presence of royals and the troops within the palace. The place however seems squeezed by the sprawling metropolis though once within its perimeter, one can enjoy the peaceful and serene atmosphere. One thing notable is that unlike Changdeokgung Palace, which is of Korean architecture (entrance walkway is crooked), this palace is of Chinese design (entrance walkway is straight).

review_title: With sensible shoes, you will have a GOOD TIME!
review_body: How many times does one get to see a palace built in 1395? The grounds are vast and the dirt base can be uneven. It's a pleasure to walk around and see the history and beautiful architecture. I strongly recommend you let one of the High School students give you a free tour. They are perfecting their English (and other languages) while sharing their history. Very interesting.

Small, pretty, well-preserved. Worth visiting in Seoul. However, if you've seen the Forbidden City, then there is nothing particularly spectacular or grand about this place. I enjoyed it because I love Asian architecture, and enjoyed the animal sculptures throughout the place which are a bit different from the ones I've seen in China. Can get crowded with school groups visiting. Wear your hanbok for free admission.

The biggest palace in Seoul. A lot of beautiful buildings to see. Its strongly recommended to buy combined ticket for all the palaces (5) - 10 000 W and try the guided tour. Its free, all guides speak fluent english and explain all that you can see.

review_title: breathtaking view and good historical place
review_body: Love their free tour guide service. She explained well on the history of almost each building and kept it lively. however, we miss the guard changing ceremony

We had a wonderful time there. We rent hanbok/traditional korean clothes at a store outside nearby the palace to get free entrance inside the palace.It wasnt that crowded when i visited, so i managed to take quite a few good photos

Went by day and by night and preferred the night experience especially the light and dance shows which were very uplifting - left with a nice happy warm feeling!!Fascinated by all the locals dressing up to get their photos taken - was even tempted but too tight to pay the $50 charge!

Very popular with tourists. A lot of people but still very nice to walk around. I would take a whole day as the place very big.Around 2pm, there is a changing guards in front.Bring your drinks and foods to sit inside and have break. It would be a nice place to have some drink and food.

This is a small place to take a stroll....I visited here ten years ago and this time it was packed with Chinese tourists...shockingly many of them.And some crazy boys running here and there I simply couldn't enjoy this place..Visit here on week days..주중에 방문하실 것을 권해드립니다 주말에는 중국인 관광객을 비롯하여 떠들고 설치고 분위기를 해치는 요소들이 너무 많았답니다

review_title: great place to see. it is for half day at least
review_body: best parts were guard changing, museum for children, historical museum (how old shops, coffees, etc. looked in last centuries)
This is another gem in Seoul. Make sure to travel around the entire property, there numerous little spots that have to be searched for. Go early in the morning.
If you like temples and have the time, a wander through the gardens and temples is very relaxing. Autumn colors added to the interest this visit and I would visit again.

review_title: Impressive Palace, but lots of tourists
review_body: This palace is very impressive, however, it is the most popular one in tourists and therefore very crowded. This does not add to its atmosphere. If you leave the central parts of the palace and wander around in the park, it becomes much more solitary. If you like quieter spots, visit the other palaces in Seoul (which are impressive as well!).

review_title: Do the free English speaking tour
review_body: Very nice and interesting. Highly recommend the free English speaking tour which is daily 3 times a day. Only need to pay the entry ticket. Absolutely must see while in Seoul.

Gyeongbokgung is also one of the places to visit in Seoul. Not only is it beautiful to see, it is also easy to find and free of entrance! If you exit from City Hall (blue line) subway exit 2, walk down the road up until the end. It is aproximately a 15minute walk. On the way there you will find the statue of King Sejong (3rd king and supporter of Hangul) and Yi Sun-Sin (famous naval commander). You can also take the purple line to Gwanghwamun which is closer but does not go from Seoul station.
My second time here but this time during much better weather. It's a beautiful palace and we got in for free for wearing hanboks!

review_title: Visit this beautiful Palace first, the largest of all the palaces
review_body: Join the English guide and learn to appreciate the history and architecture of this beautiful Palace. If you are a historical K-drama fan you will now be able to see and experience the beautiful architecture, the Throne Hall and the Pavilion you see so often in the dramas. If you are in a Hanok you get in free of charge, saving 3,000 won. I visited the Palace after Bukchon Hanok Village and Samcheong-dong. All are within walking distance
Nice palace and greenery around. There were lots of people though so its hard to get a good picture with no one behind you. Also saw lots of youngsters dressed in their traditional costume.
Well maintain historical building and museum. We can find lots of Korean teenager wearing hanbok (traditional Korean costum), we can ask them to take a picture for free.
Fun palace, but the best part to me was the views of the mountains against the old buildings as well as the wonderful park/gardens around the perimeter.

Only $3 for tourists, must bring passports. This place normally closes at 5 so seeing it in the dark is cool. There was also a light show and traditional dance at the end around 9:30PM. Highly recommended as it doesn't occur often.

So apparently they do this night viewing only for a couple of weeks, dont miss it.They only give 500 tickets to foriegners so line up early if you want to get in, around 6PM is best.The place ia filled with young beautiful Koreans dressed in the traditional Hanboek, and the detail of the buildings are very clear in the splash of lights upon them surrounded by darkness of the eveningBut the best part was light and traditional dance Show at the King's Pavilion.When you step through the main gates it is as if you have been transported back in time lost in a beautiful ancient world of kings and beautiful people surround by the works of great craftsmen.The light show was an amazing display of Korean Technology mixed with their ancient dance and art.I was just wowed!!!I love Korea!!!!

Very lovely palace complex but there is not a huge amount to see apart from the buildings. It would be better if there were some exhibitions in it. I did take the audio guide but again would be good to have more detail etc on the guide.There was one very nice lake at the back but it just needs a little something more.

We arrived at 2:00PM just in time for the changing of the guards. I highly recommend seeing this ceremony as it helps one imagine what it must have been like hundreds of years ago at the palace. It is not abundantly clear but you need a ticket to enter the inner courtyard and you can purchase them on the far right of the outer courtyard. Once inside you can peer into throne rooms and walk around the grounds. We were treated to a concert of traditional instruments out in front of the coffee shop (note: every Korean tourist attraction will have at least one coffee shop). One other treat was the high percentage of people walking around in Hanbok (the traditional Korean garb). Wear your walking shoes. This place is not very wheelchair accessible.
We took the Free Korea Transit Tour to Seoul that included the Gyeongbokgung Palace. Interesting way to spend a morning. Nice introduction to Korea history.

I was proposed at this palace so this place holds a dear memory in my heart. This is a beautiful palace with lots of history! I recommend getting a tour guide to get a better understand about this place. The architecture and the colors are beautiful! It's a great place to wear hanbock and go on a tour. The admission fee is cheap and it's worth a visit!

I like this place. Walking around, exploring. Take a rest when feeling tired. Entrance ticket is KRW 3K, free if you wear hanbok. They also have free guided tour on certain time. Be sure to check out their website.

This is a year round good, must see palace when in Seoul. Beautiful grounds, even better when you coincide your visits with the guard changing ceremony. We were lucky to see the guard inspection ceremony reanactment and display of martial arts. Entrance is free if you rent a hanbok costume. Plenty of rental shop in the vicinity as well in Buchon Hanok village which is just a short stroll away. Or you can buy a booklet of combo tickets to all the palaces and jongmo shrine for 10,000 won. Don't miss the floating Pavillion on the left.

I think gyeongbokgung palace one of must visit in korea. But not suitable when you want "healing situation". When I visit, there a fan meeting or shooting program. Oh, so crowded with fans screaming everywhere
the palace has its history and is well maintained. good for first time visitor to visit... however, do try to go on weekday... it was super crowded on weekend.
Very nice park, rather large. Relaxing place for a walk. Some beautiful buildings. Shows a glimp of how korea used to be. Very touristic.

review_title: Fun thing to do -Also try the old te place
review_body: Beautiful place. You can go for a long walk - learn a lot and try the old tradition te. Very close to centrum.

A place where it tells you the history of the Korean Dynasty and how the palace was burn down. Do join the free guided tour to fully appreciate the palace. Do not walk on your own.They in the process of rebuilding the entire palace which is schedule to complete in 2045. Beautiful place to walk around and with many Korean in Hanbok. It's worth coming.

I've been here several times before but this is the first time I visited at night. We were lucky that on this trip there was a special night session for autumn. It's still the same admission price and it's open from 6-10pm but lines start forming at 5pm. There are limited stilts for both tourists and locals so be sure to come early. There were exhibits and a traditional Korean dance and program showcasing their culture and the story of King Sejong (?). It was held in one of the pavilions on the lake and with the full moon it was just breathtaking! There were a lot of young people dressed in the traditional hanbok because they get to come in free :-)
The Palace is nice but your visit gets better when you see the gardens. I was so lucky I went during Fall/autumn, so I could see the different colour of the trees.

First thing we did when arrived in Korea was visiting Gyeongbok palace. Good spot to start your visit in Seoul, where you can learn about history. Ticket is not expensive, and you can buy a special pass to visit all the temples and palaces in the area with a discount.

This is a must for any visitor to Seoul, the grounds are massive! Many visitors every day but as the are is so large it is not overcrowded. Many teenagers and young adults dress up in traditional costume for photo sessions, pretty entertaining.
Visited the palace and gardens with my wife and 14m old son. Great place to stroll around and to take some beautiful pictures.

This huge palace complex is stunning, comparable to the best in the world. Every courtyard or space reveals new treasures and, despite being crowded, peace can be found around many a corner. An absolute must-see if in Korea!

Gyeongbokgung Palace is a must-visit when you are in Seoul! Do note that the palace is closed on Tuesdays so avoid going on that day. It is extremely accessible via the metro (alight at Gyeongbokgung Palace station itself, Line 3, Exit 5). You can even walk to Bukchon Hanok Village from there. If you're in Hanbok, admission to the palace is FREE!
The palace is closed on Tuesday though. It's crowded inside. We managed to take better photos from the National Museum outside.

If you are a history buff and plan to visit any of the palaces, and if you have only a very limited time, I would suggest that you visit Gyeongbokgung.It is close to Insadong and Bukchon hanok village. You can sort of do all there in one day. Mind you, there is a lot of walking to do, so be prepared.I was not very impressed by the changing of the palace guard, but if you have the time go for it.Check out the timing for this, as they do this only twice a day, depending on the weather. However, do not avoid the palace visit just because you missed the changing of the guard.

As I rode the bus from Incheon Airport to my hotel in Jongno, I got my first glimpse of Gyeongbokgung Palace. It was way after midnight and the lights from the outer gate and just the presence of seeing a palace for the first time blew me away. I visited the palace and it was such a wonder to see.

review_title: The most well known (and crowded) palace of all five palaces
review_body: During our time in South Korea, being the history buffs we are, we purchased the Integrated Pass for Palaces, which basically gave us tickets and access for all five major palaces for 10,000 won, as compared to 14,000 won if purchased individually instead. From our visits, we could safely say that out of the five, Gyeongbokgung Palace seemed to be the most well known, and perhaps unfortunately, the most crowded too.We happened to visit during the Golden Week holiday period in China, and that meant hordes of Chinese tourists swarming the Geunjeongjeon, or Throne Hall. It would have been a little more ideal if I had been able to secure a slot for the night tour, where the crowd is much lesser and it is more beautiful for night photography. Luckily, it seems that most tour groups bring their tourists to the Geunjeongjeon area only. Beyond that, if you are willing to walk more and more further, you will be rewarded with less crowds.The architectural style of the palace is somewhat closer to the Ming Dynasty style, such as the Forbidden Palace for example. This is in contrast to the other palaces such as Changdeokgung Palace, which has a more traditional Korean style. It might look similar at first glance, but on closer inspection, some differences can be seen. The Gyeongbokgung Palace that is seen standing today is actually a reconstruction and restoration, as the original one was sadly demolished during the Japanese colonial era in 1915. Still, the amount and scale that has been restored so far is astonishing and must be seen first hand to understand the very soul of Korea better.The National Folk Museum of Korea happens to be inside Gyeongbokgung Palace and it can provide a respite from the heat with the building itself being air-conditioned. The exterior of the museum is quite beautiful and is worthy of some great shots. There is also the Hyangwonjeong Pavilion that is worth walking far enough for a great shot. You should not miss the royal guard changing ceremonies done by reenactors that take place at Gwanghwamun, the main gate of Gyeongbokgung Palace at 10 am and 2 pm. The ceremony takes about 20 minutes and it is an experience you should not miss. You can even take photos with the royal guards after the ceremony too!Do take note that Gyeongbokgung Palace is closed on Tuesdays and sometimes it may close if it gets too crowded, so do plan accordingly. A night tour would be even better if you are able to get a slot. This is an excellent place to see both the locals and tourists in Hanbok, the Korean national costume, since those in Hanbok get in for free. If you want less crowds however, I would strongly suggest Changdeokgung Palace instead if you only have time for one palace to visit.

Great place for pictures, go on a weekday if you can because weekends can get overcrowded with tourist buses. It was amazing to walk around and sight see. Very beautiful and it was very memorable. It is not very friendly to strollers, especially in the entrance areas. It will not be a smooth ride. I recommend baby wearing if possible.

This is right across from my office and have been staring at it through the window every business trip. Decided to check it out. The palace is ok not very elaborate like others around the world. A guided tour may have been interesting. The change of guards is good.

There are several things you need to do it in the palace or else you will regret in your visit1) Bring a good camera so you can take some magnificient picture of the Palace2) After pay the ticket, go right of the palace to check out the tea serving ceremony or rice cake ceremony so you can taste and learn some , as the class or ceremony is depended on the timing3) Have pictures with the soldiers there4) Have pictures with the pretty korean with hanok ( korean costume )5) Have fun jumping and running as it is really huge!The last thing is, visit every single corner of the palace and it is sweet enough if you can take some nice pictures with the nice scenery with your love one!
Its 600 years old. Made from wood. So many beautiful Korean design. But the most important thing is that the secret garden, It is amazing.

Came here with a private guide. The history was extremely interesting and well worth the time spent there. Our guide knew just when to arrive for the changing of the guard, is well worth seeing. The grounds are amazing. The guide explained the differences between Chinese, Japanese and Korean architecture which will be interesting to compare. A must see if you are in Seoul.

The palace itself is not so much to see. On a sunny weekend, you can find citizens/tourists wearing Hanbok in it, as if it is a movie studio. It's great to get some Korean vibe. Also, do visit the palace at night! The palace is glowing with some lights on. There are some beautiful pine trees besides the park.

The palace is open for public visits. And as with most of the palace worldwide, there is guard changing ceremony. If i'm not mistaken, it is carried out twice a day. Its an interesting ceremony and tourist should grab the chance to watch it. The entrance fee is quite cheap and inside, you can take pictures and learn many Korean's history. There is also some place inside where you need to pay extra if you want to enter. Fir me, i just pay the initial entrance fee and spent around 2 hour visiting the palace. To go there, its quite easy using the subway.

This was a great temple to visit and you could easily spend a few hours wandering the grounds. It's especially nice to see lots of people in Korean traditional dress as it allows them free entry, but also adds to the atmosphere.

September is not really ideal yet to visit Seoul. If one is lucky, a day may have temperature at below 30 degrees celcius.Tourists should loan the Korean traditional costume for photo taking within the palace compound. Enjoy!!!

You should visit this place during chuseok, although is a bit crowded, but many cultural activities, free hanbok experiences happening during this time! 香远亭就是所谓的宫内后院，也是我最喜欢的地方。。醉香桥，景如其名。。令人陶醉的独木桥与充满香气的莲花池左右作伴！那个朝代，这里应该是最让人舒缓压力的地方了！

A must visit when in Seoul. Stunning and well-preserved architectures. Love the vast gardens, walkways and ponds. During my visit, there was a stage performance going on. It was interesting to see people in Hanboks walking around.
Quaint and memorable palace in Seoul.When we went there it's a bit crowded but nevertheless it's one of the places you simply can't forget.

review_title: Gorgeous at night, night tour recommended
review_body: Previously when I visited gyeongbukgung in the morning, I was pretty unimpressed as it was very crowded and we didn’t manage to secure tickets to see the interior of the palace. However, this time round, we visited at night with a friend and wow, I prefer coming here at night than in the morning. Taking photos here is always pretty surreal – you have the mountains in the backdrop and the tall buildings around the palace and all that is just 10 times better looking at night. The night tour of the palace was really nice and I enjoyed the various bits of historical information we got along the way. There was a performance at one end of the palace and that was beautiful. Totally recommended.

Was here, there is some kind of park around the palaces, but nothing "wow", just a traditional-style buildings. Worth visiting once when it's your first time in Seoul, but I wouldn't recommend it as some great attraction

review_title: A must see palace in Seoul
review_body: There are 4-5 palaces in Seoul and this is a biggest and most famous one. There are many people wearing traditional clothes come here so it create a very special/different feeling when visiting Seoul besides the modern, shoppings and skyscrapers in other places.
Fabulous visit, beautiful place with stunning architecture & artwork. The adjourning museum us well worth the visit too.

beautiful vast grounds & well preserved structures. Very thankful for our Goodwill Volunteer Tour guide whose stories brought us back to the past amazing life of the royals and its people in the palaces.

A huge palace complex with courtyards and gardens and a gorgeous pond. While we were there it was a national holiday so people were wearing national costume and there was music and dancing by the pavilion. One of the highlights of Seoul.
Stunning buildings, amazing architecture and cute Korean girl wearing traditional dresses. You haven't been to Seoul if you don't visit this palace.

We are lucky to visit on a special festive day where entrance to the palace is free. We spent an hour or so walk around the palace and it was so chilly during autumn month. Beautiful gardens and clean environment, well maintained architecture & there are free tour around the garden (English speaking). Overall, this is a must-visit place if you are a first timer to Seoul, Korea.

review_title: Definitely a must see, but tour was too long for kids
review_body: Really interesting and huge palace compound. Try to see the small parade which is at 11 am and possibly 2 PM. There are so many building to walk around and see, and there is an English speaking tour twice a day at noon and possibly one later. Found it interesting but tour, at 1 hour, was too long for our Elem. age kids.

review_title: Great view into Koreas rich culture
review_body: Large estate where you can wander around or take a detailed audio tour Interesting to see the ancient dynasties. Lots of young girls in the traditional folk costumes also made for good people watching.There's also a number of art galleries nearby so check out modern Seoul as well as heritage sites.

The palace is huge and gives a good insight into Korean culture and dynastic lifestyle. don't miss the evening light and sound show encompassing several cultural events.( only foreigners allowed). make sure you carry your passports
Definitely a must-visit when you travel to Seoul. This palace is very well-preserved and they are continuing with the restoration work.
Good attraction, large palace, different structures, Korean heritage. Went on a day when there was a cultural festival going on. Lot of youngsters wearing traditional and colourful dresses

Nice place to explore. It's a huge complex so there are lots to see. The changing of the Palace Guards takes place at 11am. What I didn't like was the large number of tourists during the peak hours. Some of them, especially those bus load of visitors from China tend to get really noisy and aggressive when taking selfies. I saw a bunch of them man handle the Palace Guard so that they can have that perfect selfies. So the best time to visit is early in the morning or at night.
It was so great when Harry was teaching us about the history here in Gyeongbukgung Palace. I was amazed by how they maintain the structure of this place and the cleanliness too.

review_title: A short walk from city hotels.
review_body: Gyeongbokgung Palace is part of the itinerary of all the day tours in Seoul, which tells you that it is worth seeing, but as my husband and I discovered, it is an easy 20 minute walk from the City Hall neighbourhood where our hotel was located. In other words, it is possible to see come of the city's rich history even if you don't have much time to spare. The palace is an commanding structure and gives a real sense of the wealth and sophistication of Korea at the time when Europe was still emerging from the Middle Ages. But, the thing that we found most impressive was the pride and patriotism shown by the Korean people, many of whom were dressed in colourful, traditional costume. Gyeongbokgung Palace is the perfect solution if you are in Seoul on business and don't have much time but still want a taste of the country's history.

The palace is a must-go site if you are first time traveler to Seoul. We spen around 2-3 hour in this palace. However, minus point is that it always crowded. Small bonus point is you can rent a traditional clothes nearby and go into the palace to take picture
Since the culture is somehow similar, I'm not really interested in the palaces, but this one is nice, and if I must choose to go to 1 palace, it should be this one
They have this activity every day except Monday.The costumes of the guards are fantastic and then we took a tour of the palace

review_title: Cool but don't see all of them.
review_body: The palaces all begin to look similar after a while. My advice would be to go to the museum first (especially if it's a hot day) and then try to figure out which palace you would like to see.

This park had many interesting buildings and highlights. At only $1, it was worth it to walk through and look around. I wish there was more information about it that we could have read. Perhaps we should have rented the headphones.

This place is really historical, will every single things you had seen on Korean Drama. The most impressive thing is when we worn hanbok we didn't have to buy entrance tickets. It's the way Korea brings their culture to the tourists.
We really enjoyed visiting this palace. Its the best we saw during our stay in Seoul. Do not miss the ceremony when the guards change.

review_title: Make sure you stay for the guard ceremony
review_body: Lovely palace to visit but not a lot of information in English.If you visit this palace, make sure you watch the guard ceremony. They explain it in Korean then translate to English.It was great to watch.

Definitely worth a visit. The terrain and architecture, buildings and gardens are all well maintained and beautiful. The admission is very inexpensive...great way to promote your city and draw in tourist.

This place is breathing with history, which contrasts so much with tall modern buildings in the background. Met lots of local girls in traditional costumes here. In hot weather you'll feel like being barbecued here;)
Strongly recommended from me - love the palace and the morning Guards changing. Take me back to the old days...

review_title: Big palace situated surrounded by modern building
review_body: Really bring you to the past. Changing guard ceremonial is always interesting. The guards wear the traditional costume where guests would love to take pictures with them.

It's a grand palace with huge open space. Well preserved architecture. It's now free admission in conjunction with Korea sale Festa. Good for sightsee and photo taking. To experience it fully, suit up in their traditional costumes first! After this palace, do go to Changdeokgung's secret garden for 5000won per entry. 10-15 mins walk east of Gyeongbokgung.
This palace is located in the city and its just enormous. On the back it goes all the way back in to the mountains with a nice lake and park. The buildings are superb, its the highlight of Seoul.

Too beautiful place and all the place look like a picture too cause the tree and the lake If you are korean drama fans you will be crazy haha ;D cause you will see all the scenes in your eyes and you will know how big in gyeongbokgung palaceIt's very fun and beautiful place Full of Korea historical place and look :)Must do and come list in Korea!!!!

I had been to the palace in the day some years ago. Last week, I had the chance to go in for the night tour last week. Please go there at about 6:30 pm, to queue up for the foreigners' tickets, for entry at 7 pm (although they let the people in before then). The palace looked beautiful at night, because they lit it really well. It had a dance and a light show (every hour, I think). The reflections of the buildings and the trees in the lake were particularly impressive. Allow about an hour for the night tour and it was worth a visit. Pictures:

I would say a must if you're visiting Seoul. Or only is admission cheap but you get to go into the palace. I like going to historical places and they do have people dressed up as guards that you could take pictures with, also gives you access to the national museum.

We chose to visit Gyeongbok Palace over other palaces due to time constraint and it was a very worthwhile visit. We were marveled at the architecture in a very distinct Korean way and the detailed danchung painting of the roof overhang. In addition, Goenghoeru Pavillion in the pond was an outstanding idea to have a royal reception or celebration among noble people. Walking northbound, we were able to see a part of neighboring Chungwadae which is the residence of the Korean President in the backdrop of a mountain and it was absolutely beautiful. For the entertainment, there are changing guard procedure and military drill as the King watching. This can't be compared to the changing guard performance of Buckingnam Palace in London in quality, but it adds to understanding of the Joseon Dynasty. I highly recommend to visit the palace and the surrounding area. One can finish touring in as little as 1 hour or all day long.

review_title: A very pleasant place to visit . and Korean History . Also a great place for your great pic.
review_body: Went there with the tour from the US , and this Palace was one of the attraction, we love the visit ,See all Palaces the learn Korean culture and History and shoots lot of pic . it was just great.

Well worth a visit, mainly for the notable scale and architecture. The terrain, buildings and gardens are all impressive. The textual descriptions are spare, but there are free tours. Personally, I though the highlight was just seeing the buildings themselves. You can rent "hanbok" nearby and walk around in costume for an extra treat.

Come early morning as soon as it opens for a peaceful walk around and good photo opportunities. Gets crazy crowded and noisy as it gets closer to lunch. Also a good idea to set aside time to do the National Folk Museum here as it's just to the side of the palace. Must see if you have not been to Seoul before.

review_title: We chose this one out of the 5 Palaces in Seoul
review_body: We were in Seoul for 5 days but only chose to visit one Palace, and after research it was obvious to me this was the one to go to. My reason? It's the birthplace of the Joseon Dynasty. When the capital was moved to Seoul, this was the first Palace, and the entire walled city of Seoul at the time was designed around this Palace. We went less for the architecture and more for the history and layout- specifically, with the mountain as a backdrop and the pond in the rear. Walking thru and spending time in the adjacent dongs, all which had their own purpose serving this Palace, made their history all the more interesting as well. You can reasonably do the Palace in one hour, and there are free English guided tours available 3 times each day- check the times on their website to plan your visit.

review_title: Must visit for first time tourists
review_body: There are multiple palaces in Seoul so I would recommend to only visit Gyeongbokgung if there is any time constraint. Tip: admission fee is waived if you visit in Korean traditional clothing. There is a shop opposite the palace that you can rent from but I would recommend to rent them at Insadong as it is MUCH cheaper (40k vs 14k for 4 hours) :)

It might be boring to many people but it's amazing for history lover. It's very huge and needs time to walk there. Especially that there is also museum. I will recommend any one want to visit it 6 hours. يمكن ان يكون هذا المكان ممل للعديدين ولكنه سيكون وجهة تشد المهتمين بالتاريخ. المكان كبير جدا ويحتاج وقت للتنقل مشيا على الأقدام وخصوصا ان هنالك متخف بجانبه. انصح بتخصيص ٦ ساعات على الأقل لهذه الفعالية.
A nice palace with lot of history. Easily reachable via the metro. Just follow instructions when you reach the metro station and you will never get lost.

The palace is huge, with a lot of buildings. Walking is easy though, as it's mostly flat. The palace features the mountains as its backdrop, enhancing its picturesque quality. The ponds are beautiful, and we're built to reflect the mountains' beauty. Make sure to see the changing of the guard ceremony at 10am or 2pm. Go a bit before then as they also have a short parade outside the side gate with the guards making in formation.

Majestic palace which offers a glance to the splendour past. Several palaces with its history plus a leisure park and lake dotted the landscape. Be sure to watch guard changing ceremony. A refuge from busy city just a step away
The palace, the views -everything is gorgeous. I would definitely recommend people to spend some time here.

review_title: very nice palace- one of the stop from the city tour bus
review_body: we took hop-on hop-off tour bus and with various stops you can get off and get on, the route was pretty good and inexpensive..

Nice garden outside the museum and palace . The palace look nice but the facades and even interior looked so freshly painted and lacked historic feel but nice to see pretty ladies in traditional hanbok.

The palace is impressive in itself. Also impressive is the way it is taken care of, including keeping its background view of mountains, in center Seoul with all the high rises around it.A real monument to Korea's past.
Catch the changing of the guard ceremony, dress up in Hanbok, join a free tour, visit the museum afterwards.. you could spend the best part of a day just on this one location alone :)

The palace complex was actually hugh! The palace itself was really beautiful and grand. The architecture of all the buildings in the palace complex the really mesmerizing. I was particularly impressed with the Royal Guards manning the entrance. They were awesome.

Visited at the end of the day and it was superb. No large groups so the place was quiet, almost serene, the surroundings are lovely and the buildings interesting. Can easily find a quiet spot to read a book. I didn't go with a guide and later regretted as I believe it would have made the visit even more enjoyable.

As one of the most popular tourist spot in Seoul. Prepare for huge crowd of tourists and buses in the area. Very nice place to visit and add knowledge of korean history.There is a show at the gate once in a an hour (might change) where guards will perform a war march.

review_title: Big palace but nothing much to see
review_body: There are site with nice views but didn't offer much to see since most rooms are barred from entrance. Only peeking from windows are allowed.But quite a place to visit anyway. Love the lakes though.

Gyeongbukgung, or known as Gyeongbuk Palace. It was the main royal palace of the Joseon dynasty built in 1395. I never expected that I can be so fascinated by visiting palace, guess the details and the richness of the beautiful architectures drew me into it.

review_title: A Recreation of Korea's Past Splendour
review_body: As with all my reviews to sights in Seoul I will preface this by advising visitors to carefully check opening days and times and whether timed entry tickets are needed to access certain parts of the attraction and also the times for booking guided tours in their language of preference – bearing in mind that numbers can be limitedThe palace and grounds occupy a large open space and although the attraction gets very busy (especially with school parties) there are quiet places that can be found to enjoy the architecture and the scale of the palace. Most of the buildings are highly decorative and have been heavily restored and in some cases recreated. If staying in Seoul for some time I would suggest buying the "all in " ticket giving access to all the main palaces in the city

review_title: You need a lot of time
review_body: I've been to Gyeongbokgung a few times. My first was in the middle of winter, and not all of the ponds had water, no leaves on the trees.... It was all pretty bleak.I went another time in fall with my sister. We got there in time for the changing of the guard ceremony which is worth scheduling around if you can. My third visit was on a special evening opening. I had to book a ticket online. I went, like most others, with a tripod and my DSLR to try and get some sweet pictures. There was a full moon that night, so we weren't disappointed.
A half day well spent surrounded by friendly and smiling local visitors. Monuments descriptions could be more detailed though if you have any interest in the actual historical facts

this is one place you should not miss when visiting seoul even for the first time. it has a lot to offer and don't forget to bring an umbrella or a hat to protect you from the scorching heat. too bad there was no personal tour guide to explain to us the different features of the palace.

Wow--for a limited time (24 Sep-28 Oct 2016) they are offering special night tours of Gyeongbokgung Palace. If you've never been before or have only visited during the day, I highly recommend trying to get down there. It was the best 3,000 won I have spent in Seoul!!!! Called the "Bridge of Time" there was a spectacular light and dance show at the Gyeonghoeru Pavilion. Don't ask me how they did it but the building kept changing colors--it was so impressive I had to watch the 15-minute show twice. They also had a portion of the show dedicated to a traditional dance in front of the Pavilion, all the while with the lights changing. Plus, upon entering the complex there was another light show as you crossed Yeongjegyo Bridge in the bed of Geumcheon Stream. I read in the local press this is the first time they have had this kind of light show there. The tours run from 19:00-22:00 with the final admission at 21:00. When I was there people began lining up around 6:00 pm and I was told they begin selling the tickets around 6:45 pm. 500 tickets are set aside for foreigners, which are bought at window #1. I arrived around 7:45 on a Sat evening and was still able to get a ticket but may have been lucky as there was a big firework show going on that same evening elsewhere in Seoul. While still crowded, I suspect it was less crowded than normal. Cost was 3,000 won, which is the normal entrance fee. While only a limited part of the complex is open it was nice to see everything all lit up and provided a different perspective to my daytime visit. The special light show and dance performance at Gyeonghoeru Pavilion were done four times and lasted about 15 minutes: 19:20, 20:00, 20:40, and 21:20. I arrived at the tail end of the 20:00 performance and could barely see anything there were so many people. I opted to wait the 25 minutes between shows and got a position in the front center that was great for photo taking. Afterwards, I wandered around a bit and was passing by in time for the last show which was the least crowded so watched it again, it was that good. Anyhow, I was super impressed and plan on recommending this night tour to others. If you are in Seoul right now, go...it will probably end up being one of the favorite stops you make!
I went at 9am before the crowds. A delightful way to spend and an hour or two wandering around beautiful palaces and even some wildlife to see!

review_title: Must must visit if you're visiting Seoul!
review_body: Geongbokgung Palace is majestic! This is a must visit if you're visiting Seoul. If you can visit during night time (only open few months of the year), it's absolutely beautiful.
