With a view of the mountain in the background, it's a paradise for photography enthusiasts. Lots of history behind this palace and if you time do checkout the museum to learn about the history. They have free guided tours in English.

It's a one of THE places to visit if you only have a limited time in Seoul. Huge palace grounds and gardens to explore. It can get really crowded at times so avoid the weekend crowds or school holidays.
Scenery is good.But, it will be pressed against the historical recognition.Good things will be on the bad.I will not revisit absolutely.

review_title: Lacks a historical feel and rather repetitive
review_body: As one of the top sights of Seoul was looking forward to history and beautiful buildings, but rather disappointing.It has been destroyed over the centuries, however it looks totally new with little in evidence of its history to bring it to life. The site is also bare and feels empty.

Only seen palaces in kdramas but visiting and seeing first hand is awesome. i was literally in awe. the designs and architecture is definitely . Aside from the shopping, you need to set aside time to visit this

There are quite a few palaces in Seoul. The sheer size and scenic location within the city with the mountains in the background, as well it's historical significance make it a must-see in my opinion. It's located fairly centrally and easily accessible via the metro. There are also quite a few other museums located nearby. Our ticket allowed us free entry into the Folk Museum (or Children's Folk Museum? or both, I can't remember). You can spend hours walking around here. You can't enter the chambers or rooms but you can walk through the main structures and there are a lot of them! Wear good walking shoes.There are many ramps around so it's also very wheelchair and stroller accessible. Clean bathrooms with toilet paper, soap and water are also on site. In order to visit the pavilion, I believe you need to make an advance reservation online. A visit to this palace can be as short or long as you want, but if you want to see most of it (at a leisurely walking pace), you should allot at least 2 hours. It's felt smaller than the Forbidden City in Beijing China, and the restorations seemed more apparent. Still, the buildings and layout were beautiful.

review_title: Must place to visit when you are in Seoul
review_body: This is typically a king palace during old time. When you experience Seoul in the first place, give a chance to come here and spend aprox. 2 hours to stroll around to the palace and national museum. If you happens to like history and place to photos then you might be spend more time there. For me, it is good to go and take a look of changing guard ceremony at their official site or any blogger site available.

review_title: Huge massive palace, lots of tourist
review_body: This palace is quite massive, when I first saw the image in TripAdvisor, I thought it was just one building and that was it. I was quite surprised by how huge this palace is. Most of the tourist are just in the front area of the building and probably left thereafter.If you want to see the entire palace, be prepared to walk quite a bit and spend at least 2 hours there.The palace is quite beautiful and well maintained. I highly recommended to visit this place.We were there on Oct 2. which was a Korean holiday, lots of people dress up in traditional clothing and take pictures in the palace, quite interesting to see.Looks like some tourist also dress up and take pictures against the palace.We arrived around 2 pm and there were so many tourists there, I wish we arrived earlier, it would probably be nicer and less crowded.

Beautiful grounds to explore filled with heritage and history and pride for nationality. Photographers paradise. Beautiful gardens, seemed to be a popular place for children and teens to go dressed in traditional clothing to take photos - which I was told would be as gifts for family. As a young western woman a lot of the young girls asked for selfies with me which I was happy to oblige and I returned the favour they looked stunning in their traditional dress. In places it did feel a little busy- lots of people around. But at no point did it feel overwhelming. I got used to the fact that Seoul as a place was densely populated so figured everywhere you went would be people in large numbers. I loved the juxtaposition of the placement of the place cradled between modern buildings all around was this nugget of history within the city. Make sure you go with a full battery on your camera or phone. Much needed. You can enjoy a traditional tea ceremony too. Plenty of literature also to inform all those niggling questions. A great day out. A lot is in the direct sunlight so if there in summer bring suncream and some coverage but once you get to the gardens there is plenty of cover in the shade.
I like the reduced design compared with chinese palaces, even it is quite similar this one is worth visiting

Kingdom in the middle of the city. Tourist crowds at this attraction because of its beautiful structure and interesting facts about Korean history. The palace does really get crowded with different tour groups so it's really hard to find a good spot for beautiful shots without tourists around. Overall it's interesting and worth the visit!

Gyeongbokgung Palace is very historical. Our tourist guide said that it was the main royal palace of the Joseon dynasty built in 1395. I was so amazed when i knew about it that this palace was so old yet the structure is firm.

This is a must see if you are visiting Seoul. It's beautiful and full of history. Very inexpensive stop and you can take endless photos. You will also see many people dressed in traditional outfits walking around. I loved it.
we only spend a short time to see a couple of palaces and this one had a nice changing of the guards
its was really interesting to see the Gyeongbokkgung Place. Whit the Metro its just to easy to find it.

review_title: Amazing place but not for me
review_body: I give this 4 ratings because objectively, it is an amazing place though, honesty, it is not my favorite. Why? this place is crowded (like really crowded) and way too large (it takes hours to go round and check out the castle area). If you are really interested and eager to visit this place, plus you are a history geek, go ahead. But if you only want to take a beautiful picture in a typical Korean castle so you are able to post it on your social media, you'd better check other castle (e.g. Changdeokgung Palace). Other castle is just as beautiful and way less crowded. But, the thing is, this palace is like a must-visit-place when you are in Seoul, so it's all up to you. Once again, it's nice place but not my personal favorite.

review_title: The Home of the Korean Kings
review_body: This Palace is very renowned for the Kings of Ancient Korean Dynasty, its a Must Visit Place to know the Korean Dynasty History and Their Culture. The Ticket Prices are very Low and make sure you go on a Weekday, weekends are usually over Crowded.

Quite a cool place for pictures, palace is quite big so some substantial walking is needed. Has heritage and convenient mountains at the background while taking pictures. Good that there were no high rise buildings on that side of the city

The area is very big and alot to see. But it's hard to take a good picture at the gate because it's always full of people. The sightseeing inside much more tranquil. I was in there at 11a.m and got a chance to see the guard changing. They only walked a few feet long so if you want to take picture, you have to be very quick

Gyeongbokgung Palace is the perfect place to go to learn about Korean history. It's 3,000 won (about $3) per adult and they have English tours at 11am, 1:30pm and 3:30pm. The palace complex includes two museums. One is about the royal families and the other is about the commoners. They do have activities/buildings you need to book in advance so look into that if you want more than the walkthrough.

review_title: Beautifully restored and with a visit
review_body: The Gyeongbokgung palace is nestled slightly north of Seoul and is walkable if you are staying in there myeongdong neighborhood of Seoul. The palace has several layers and houses multiple palaces. If you continue to walk in, you will enter the folk museum. Great place to hang out and enjoy history.
I did the self guided audio tour and was very happy with it. The palace and grounds are beautiful. I was there very early at opening and the crowds were small on a Saturday morning.
It was a very nice palace to be around in seoul,with absolutely gorgeous nature and history of korea..Its must see if some one visit seoul.

Not to be missed in your itinerary when you go to Seoul. You should go early to witness the first changing of guards which is really amazing. They have a free fit of guards costume. Affordable 3000krw for entry.

review_title: Huge area with lots of Palaces!
review_body: OH MY GOD! This is a huge area with lots of palaces all connected to each other that makes the whole place feel like a maze!The biuldings are beautiful and the architecture is superb. The decorations are really nice! Just one problem though, there wasn't enouh info about the places in this palace. We didn't want to walk with a tour and wanted to look around on our own pace so we didb't get much info.There's a good resting place with food and drinks and souvenir shop at the entrance. you can get a hanbok and wear it while you go around.

The guard-changing ceremony in the first courtyard (with the ticket sale counters) would be quite worthwhile watching.The entrance to the palace grounds from Gwanghwamun gate looks quite ordinary, but once you get past all the initial buildings and explore the grounds, it's very beautiful with all the trees and lakes. There are very signboards explaining the buildings' histories or usages. If I had gone with the free tour (set times), I'd probably have been more interested in the buildings!
Beautiful place, great to visit on a sunny day. Free English tour is available. There are also nice performances, so you will enjoy your walk.
We visited the palace during the Thanksgiving period. Free entrance was a bonus, but would willingly have paid the admittance fee. What a beautiful, relaxing, serene place. Wonderful!!!
You should go and see this place. It is like movies.nice and good for walking. It is really big as well !
Lovely palace to walk round on a beautiful day.There are many buildings and a secret garden.Very cheap entrance fee.

This is my second time visiting. This palace is the biggest, oldest & main of the 5 palaces. This palace is huge so it takes a couple of hours at least that you need to wear comfortable shoes! It's located the center of seoul & surrounded by high buildings. You would enjoy relaxing & seeing the gorgeous palace!!

review_title: To watch the changing of Guards at the Palace
review_body: Been here a couple of times but not in Fall. We manage to watch 2 series of changing of Guards at 12 and then at 2 pm. It is worth the stroll and stay to visit the palace. It is a very big palace, make sure you are in a pair comfortable walking shoes if you want to comb every corner of the palace. This is a ticket paying place of interest. Check out the timing of the performance and the translation guide and price before you go.  It is very interesting naming of the each courts in the palace. As both my Friend and I are in the management position, we identified these names and derived that the King needs to hear, think and consult before making a decision based on the proposals submitted by his officials. We love the doors and took some great pictures of the doors of each courts, the libraries etc. Go with a narrator so you can understand the history better.

This place is an absolute must see in Seoul. Its a huge palace complex with lots of history. Should be combined with Bukchok hanok village and Changdeokgung Palace since these are close by and will give a great portion of historic Seoul.If you really are someone who likes to walk I would recommend the following route.Start from Gwanghwamun station (or City hall station and pass Gwanghwamun gate) and follow the main street towards Gwanghwamun Square. Here you will see two huge statues, The statue of the Admiral Yi Sun-sin and Statue of King Sejong. Then just walk towards Gwanghwamun Gate and into Gyeongbokgung Palace. Then take trip into the The folk museum of korea and head up to Bukchok Hanok village. when you get back down from the village, have a nice lunch and head into the Changdeokgung Palace which is just next to the village entrance. When you're done go passed Anguk station and straight into Insadong. Do no visit insadong early in the morning. Go all the way through Insadong and down to Cheonggyecheon Stream. Follow it to the right(towards city hall) and you will eventually come back to your starting point.
A very beautiful palace and garden, even our 4 yo daughter loved it much!! A must visit when in Seoul. Come earlier as this palace gets very crowded with tourists
There is so much to see but start with the changing of the guards at 10 am. This palace like many others has so much history but the grounds, though rebuilt also retells its history very well.

review_title: Knowing what you are seeing will help: get a guide who speaks your language!
review_body: I love the Palace - but I've been before. The place is wonderful, historically important and deeply significant for everyone to visit. Be sure to get a proper guide to the architecture. Be sure to get a proper guide for the historical significance of the place. Make sure that whomever gives you a tour has a good sense of the history, architecture, and significance of S. Korea within Asia. Knowing what you are seeing adds very much to the experience!

This is one of half-a-dozen Palaces and holy places you need to visit in Seoul. You can buy a serial ticket to five attractions for 10000 Korean wons. It is truly amazing to see how these old buildings fit in with the otherwise so modernized city.
Just a beautiful historical i am amazed by the culture also keeping the palace well maintain i would love to come back !!!!

We went to this palace at 9am. It's the perfect time to go as it isn't very busy at this time. We got an audio guide as well as the guide book. It was very informative and we found it sufficient. It took us about 2 hrs to walk the entire grounds. They also do have a free English tour at 11am however it is busy at this time with a lot of school groups.

I did a quick visit - ($2.50 USD each) overall worthwhile with the travel tours as well as the changing of the guards. Definitely worth a visit and even more so if you have kids. I would definitely say its worth the value!
First royal palace that you have to visit if you come to Seoul.Do not forget to take selfies with its guardians!

A good place to hang around. You need to buy tickets to enter. Currency exchange also available near the tickets counter. This palace is large and to see everything you need to do a lot walking. You can try out the traditional costumes of the palace FOC. They'll dress you. You can find costume changing location is in your left side after passing the main entrance.

Gyeongbokgung Palace is a great place to explore and learn more about what it was like back in the day, there are also free English tours available.There are also 2 free museums located in the palace as well. I was lucky to have gotten in for free, I don't know what event it was but that was very nice. A really gorgeous place.

As the main palace complex, Gyeongbokgung stands as the biggest. There are a lot of things to see in this complex; thus, a guided tour is recommended if you have time to spare. As my friends and I were pressed for time, we just spent around an hour walking around the palace grounds while waiting for the Gate Guard Change Ceremony. Avoid visiting this place on sunny summer days, as the heat may be too unbearable. The complex also houses the National Palace Museum of Korea which has interesting exhibits and a quirky gift shop/cafe where you can stay in to cool down from the heat.

We spent a few hours here this week. Its a truly massive place and its quite busy with tourists. Head through the main gate, watch the changing of the guard (though this is not official - just actors) then spend some time in the museum to get a good overview of the place. Then my suggestion is go further back to get away from the people. You'll enjoy your time here!

The palace complex is so huge~~ only walking around, it took 2hours to finish! But the palace was really beautiful and could see Korean's art and culture! I loved the pond and the small library at the back of it. It was Hyangwon or something. It was really beautiful! Highly recommend to visit here! Go~~!

Needs ability to walk and climb stairs huge property . Lovely grounds I went there during choseok and we were not charged a fee or else you have to pay a nominal amount to get in. Next to the palace is a Museum which is worth a visit. The Korean people are very gracious and helpful.

Well, this palace area is really big, a lot of similar looking palaces and houses and a lot of tourists too, because it's the most famous palace in Seoul. Nevertheless, I think it's mandatory to see this when visiting Seoul. Plus, you get free entrance to a nice museum, to escape the heat like we did when we visitied.

review_title: See only this palace..the others are similar but less pretty
review_body: We had a Seoul pass which meant we could see all 5, we saw this one third after spending alot of time walking around the other two, which we felt we could've skipped and just go to this one.

The palace is located at the centre of the city and accessible by subway. The opening hour is 9:00am. It would be better if you could get there in early hours, as tons of people visit there and it gets quite crowded. It is very interesting to see a bit of old times and culture. There is a big building near the water that you can go inside and take a look, but it requires a reservation at least one day prior. If you would like to see that building, I would recommend that you should check the information in advance.

Hanbok is Korean traditional costume and you can rent it around the palace and Insadong. I rent it at Insadong. The reason I mentioned it is I strongly recommend to visit THIS palace in Hanbok if you want to life long valuable picture in Korea! Also entrance fee is free when you are in Hanbok. Go to the ticket box and ask the tickets. Then you will get free tickets. It's very special experience walking in the historical site in tradtional costume. It was very exciting! The building was very great and felt that I was back in the days during Joseon Dynasty! Oh also this place is huge! Keep in mind !

review_title: nice place to see n understand the history
review_body: remember to wear shoe to visit this place, as u need to hv long walk and the floor is not flat. sometimes u might need to climb abit and downhill walking.alot of scenery that u might want to take picture, standby ur camera n memory cards. hehe. If you want to see some palace activity like changing shift, make sure to be there before 10am.

Gyeongbokgung Palace kept my attention for several hours when I visited. Its grounds are large and the palaces are beautiful! The entrance fee was $3 which enables a visit to their museum as well. It was well worth the time and $3.

review_title: The biggest palace in Seoul... Simply picturesque
review_body: This palace is simply awesome. If you have less time in Seoul to visit other palaces, this palace should not be missed out. The area is very big and the architecture reflects korea's tradition.Changing of guards in different time slots is worth to see. Entrance fee was affordable as well. If anybody wants to hang around the palace in Korean traditional dress (hanbok) either men or woman, I would recommended to hire it and wear before you enter the palace from nearby renting shop.

review_title: This is good place to visit in Seoul
review_body: "When you go there, you might get surprized at it since it's located in the center of Seoul! for me it was great to see since you can find modern and old at a time there! Gwanghwamun? is the main gate of this palace and you can find guards in traditional costume! looks cool to take picture with them! Change of guard ceremony was 10am, it's something! Don't miss it! When my family went there, we dressed up in Hanbok which is Korean traditional costume! If you are in Hanbok, then entrance fee, 3000KRW is free!Anyway it's really fun to go around the palace in Hanbok! We got really good pictures for life! I never forget this special experience

review_title: Big place lovely to see but nothing in it ??
review_body: Loved the sight of it as my taxi went down the long road to the main gates and lucky enough to catch the changing of the guard. The place is awesome but there's nothing in it !!! Not their fault as the Japanese burnt it down when they invaded years ago and it took em 200 years to put it right but still a must see and glad I went, and so were they at the end !!! Only joking they loved me
A vast area to visit. Not so recommended on a sunny day. It is quite a nice place to visit. The change of guard is also something that cannot missed.

Maybe for a western visitor like me not used to see places like this it represents an unforgettable experience and for all the visiting time it is like you travel in the past and it is possible to imagine most of the events that until that moment you have just seen in a movie!! real suggestive I higly recommend a visit.

This place is really nice to see, is it really pretty and when they do the dances and other shows is really pretty and so much culture. There is a lot of walking, it is bigger than it seems when you first walk in. Side note: If you go during the summer like we did, make sure you take an umbrella a lot of water and sun screen.

review_title: A must see in Seoul, especially during change of guard
review_body: Visiting royal palaces in South Korea produced in me in the long term the same effect of visiting many Buddhist temples in Thailand: they look like very similar, even though size of buildings inside may change. However Gyeongbokgung Palace deserves a visit especially for the very nice entry gate and the change of guard ceremony (held twice a day, at 10am and 2pm), the last one being very solemn. I visited the palace during the day and I must admit that the atmosphere was not so enticing as it could be during night. Free guided tours in English are also offered, which I found very useful to understand a bit more the history of royal families in South Korea.
If you only have time to visit one palace in Seoul, this is the one you should visit. I recommend checking the time the royal guard will change, so you can watch the ceremony.

Gyongbokgung Palace is located not far away from CitiHall Station, walk only 15 minutes north bound following the modern road at the down town Seoul. It is the popular destination of Seoul visitors. The environment of ancient palace of Joseon Dynasty is well maintained and fully restored. The most waited attraction is palace guard changing. The complex is vast and need some time visit and to understand the historic means of the palace.

I went there in the weekend it was busy and full of people. it was very large that you could enjoy taking pictures of different spots. three different performances are presented a day, attending one of them is enough they all seem the same and very simple. I would command the large changing ceremony. the palace is recommended for people who are interested in history and architect.

The first of Seoul's palaces we visited, and by far the most impressive. Incredible architecture & fantastic English guide, who explained so much in so little time. The changing of the guards ceremony was also worth staying to see. Really worth visiting.

The place is just marvelous. This is where no-filter IG-worthy pictures are made of. You can join the tours and watch the changing of guards. The entry fee is cheap like around 2,000 won only and there's a lot to see here.
It's been there over a thousand years in spite of the Japanese burning it down twice. There is a free tour with an English speaking docent that I highly recommend.
We got the audio guides and walked around by ourselves on a sunny Saturday. It was fabulous - definitely a must see.
This was very informative about Korean culture and how they lived and suffered from the Japanese. What a major historical reconstruction effort for the Korean people. This is worth a visit.

Geongbok palace reminded me Korean Historical Dramas, I was walking in the palace in Hanbok which is a traditional costume which is so beautiful, and you know what? If you are in Hanbok then no entrance fee :) 3000krw though Highly recommend to visit in Hannok

We had a private guided tour and this of course was extremely helpful. It is a large complex with a museum - good written explanation as you go with some interactive displays. Very informative and interesting for a European with little knowledge of Korea and its history.

Visited last September 17, 2016. If you are a sucker for history and architecture, then this shouldn't be missed when touring Korea! All the palaces are instagram-worthy! The palace is so huge that an hour is not enough! It's like a Mini "Forbidden City in Beijing" STUNNINGLY BEAUTIFUL!

review_title: The Most Beautiful Palace of Korea
review_body: One of the most amazing places I've been in the world. If you can, go early during the day since the afternoon is crowded.

review_title: Nice photos to take, but if without a guide its boring
review_body: Nice photos to take, but if without a guide its boring, however i guess you can read about it beforehand so that you can enjoy more. Takes around 1 hour to 2 hours depending on how much photos you take :)There is an option of a combo ticket for 4 palaces and a temple, but although i bought it i do not recommend you do it unless you really enjoy this repetetive rooms and buildings :)May be just one palace and one temple would be ebough, so no need to pay for the combo ticket Try not to miss the guard changing ceremony and take photos witg the guards. So do go early (not after 1:30 pm) to be able to attend one of them (held each 15 minutes i guess)

It is one of the most important places in Seoul! If you are intersted in history and Korean culture in general dont miss it! They do English tours for free to explain the hlights of this great plalace! You will see many Koreans wearing traditional clothes which is super cool!

review_title: Nice Palace in the Seoul city
review_body: Its really easy to reach this palace. You can take subway then stop at Gyeongbok gung palace station. The interesting thing is you can rent Hanbook and you can feel as korean woman/man. Don't forget to watch replacement of bodyguard of this palace in the morning and also noon. Really recommended.

review_title: Totally worth a trip to see
review_body: This place is great for all types of travelers. It allows those who like history to be able to read and see about a Korean Dynasty. For those who like architecture and cool structures, it gives you a ton to see and lots of detail to explore. And those who like to just go and walk for a little while, it gives you freedom to explore to your liking. Our favorite part was seeing the changing of the guards and the guard performance at the front gate. And not to mention all the children dressed in authentic Korean clothing while on their school field trips....just adorable! We would totally visit here again.

review_title: One of the major palaces in town -
review_body: Gyeongbokgung Palace is one of the five (5) major palaces in Seoul. If you can, avoid the visit on a weekend as the place becomes very crowded.

We visited the palace as it's a must for tourists. The palace wasn't huge so it only took around 45 minutes. (Disclaimer: we didn't have a guide or book tour so it was just purely browsing)The guards at the front gate were interesting and the shift swap process was entertaining. I would recommend a visit.

review_title: Great place if you enjoy history and architecture
review_body: The buildings are amazing and gorgeous. The place is ginormous, so be prepared to walk if you want to stay a while and venture around. There is also a free museum that doesn't require a ticket to get in, unlike The Palace. It would have been nice if there were placards or even a recording in English to understand what each building was used for. Either way, the grounds are beautiful. We went on the wrong day, it was during the holiday and it was packed! We probably would have spent more time there if not for all the people.

I was taken here as part of an organised business tour. The palace is well worth a visit, covering extensive grounds. We arrived in time to see the staged changing of the guard, which was a great spectacle. I most enjoyed the lake and gardens.

There are a few palaces in Seoul and i believe this is the most significant. There is a museum outside of the palace and it is a good way to relax in the museum after wandering around in the palace under the sun.

review_title: Try for an evening visit - beautiful
review_body: Great for a visit during the day - take in the changing of the guard. Even better if you can visit in the evening - the Pavilion lit up with the sunset over the mountains was magical. We managed an evening visit when there was a musical evening. Very atmospheric with many visitors dressed in traditional costume.

review_title: A must if you visit Seoul
review_body: It's amazing being able to visit this palace thanks to major restorations and rebuilding. It is a small version of the Forbidden City in Beijing which reminds us of China's historical and cultural influence over Asia.The admission was free because of Korean Thanksgiving when we visited but I would say it's worth it. There is not many historical sites inside Seoul so this one is a must.The metro stops right at the entrance.

review_title: Good to see but don't spend too much time
review_body: The grounds here are beautiful and the structures are as well. The insides, the ceilings particularly are very intricate and colorful but nothing is original because 90% of it was torn down during Japanese occupation which is a shame. The restoration and rebuilding of the structures is very nice, so it is nice to imagine how it would have looked. There are also plaques all around that explain the buildings and it is worth looking up online before you go, but I wouldn't pay for a tour. I was teaching in Seoul and took my family (who was visiting) here in July of 2015 and they enjoyed it but once you have seen one palace in Korea you have seen them all. Doing the hop-on-hop-off bus tour is your best bet! Then you can spend as much time as you would like and move on.

We arrived just in time to watch the guard change over. Three mins in it chucks it down leading them to canceling the change over. Don't want to get their costumes and props wet I guess. Still worth getting a ticket as the palace is huge and the foreign escort place surrounded by water was pretty. The folk museum was good too.

review_title: Good place to learn about Korean history
review_body: Please join the free guided tour so that you know the history of the palace. The place is quite big, you can spend the whole day inside. You get free entry if you are in hanbok.

review_title: A nice palace with a rich history and cultural root!
review_body: This is one of the main and most visited attractions in Seoul, a large palace ground that depicted the rich and long history and culture of the country.We came by here as part of our city tour and it was crowded when we arrived with mostly foreign visitors. The palace is nice with lovely architectural building designs of the ancient times, to some extent, similar to the Chinese versions (no doubt because the country was with good ties with China in the ancient times and thus more or less being influenced by it), nice lakes and ponds with lots of greenery.What is interesting is the schedule of the "change of ancient guard" ceremony at selected timings where soldiers who were dressed in ancient and traditional Korean costumes, marching in and is impressive and usually this scene attracted most crowds. One can also change into these traditional costumes to walk around and take photos.Many visitors here would like to compare it with the other Changdeokgung palace (please refer to my earlier review here too), that is also located nearby. The latter is smaller in size and has much lesser to see but overall with similar themed buildings. We were told by the guide that the reigning king would stay in the former palace while retired king would reside at the latter.However, do take note that the palace is closed on every Tuesday (while Changdeokgung is closed on Monday).It's an interesting place to visit and be prepared to spend at least 1.5-2 hours to be able to see substantial things here and remember also bring an umbrella, hat and bottles of drinking water as it was very sunny and warm during our visit there. (there is also guided tours but do check out the specific timing of the tours at the information counter)Recommended.
It's big, it's beautiful but if you shall get the most of the visit you should be there before 2pm and get a good spot to watch the change of the guards.

review_title: Was disappointed as it was closed on the day I vidsited
review_body: Looked very lovely - but should be open all days . I arroved in Seoul on a Sunday, but was wrecked. So was all geared up on Monday for a day of sight seeing - Nothing open. Plan ahead. Not too disappointed as this was a business trip and so sightseeing was not the primary reason for visit!

Eat. Sunblock. Comfy Shoes.The place is huge. Starts at 0900. You can try on the traditional dress and roam around the palace for free- just the dress. Entrance cost around 3500won. Afterwards, chill inside the national museum. If your lucky, you can watch the marching of guards. And so you know, tourist swarms all over the area.
The guards at the entrance very interesting. There is not much things to see inside. It was not crowded and probably you need 15 minutes to view the whole palace.

review_title: Good piece of history, at most.
review_body: I'm not sure if its because I went on a slightly rainy day or if I didn't get to see the changing of the palace guards, but I didn't find Gyeongbukgung as spectacular as I'd hoped. Don't get me wrong, it's absolutely beautiful, larger than life, and really takes you back to what life was like back then for anyone living in the palace, but besides looking around and getting that blast from the past, it was just a [beautiful] building.However, it's worth a visit if you've never been to a Korean palace! It's always great learning about origins of great nations.
The fee is about 1,000 won =$1 USD. There a English tour in the palace but schedule time. Nice places to take pictures and nice ponds.

review_title: An amazing peak into the Korean empire that once was
review_body: Though smaller than the Forbidden City in Beijing, there is quite a bit of the same sense of Asian greatness of this palace. On a quiet morning visit, it is easy to imagine how this place was once the pinnacle of a civllisation now transformed.The palace is located smack-bang in the middle of bustling Seoul, and although the megacity outside the walls is ever active, noisy and effeciently moving on, time somehow slows when inside. The noises of everyday-life are muffled, and a sense of awe is ever present.

The guard changing ceremony happens 4 times a day and I was lucky to watch it the moment I arrived. The place is huge but the buildings are quite similar. I can't enter any of the buildings except for the one in the picture. But that one visitors have to reserve entry a day before. There are a few explanation stands on what the building are but make sure to get the brochure from information counter so you get more understanding of the buildings from the visit.

review_title: Be sure to watch the changing of the guard
review_body: Who knew that the Korean dynasty was so old or that the 4th king created to Korean language or that it died out because the 27th king was infertile?
Be sure to rent all a costume at a street leftside the palace. Ask the info for directions and get a 10k won discount coupon

review_title: Stunningly beautiful palace with lots of walking paths
review_body: I attended a group tour with Koridoor tours to Gyeongbokgung and several other historic sites around Seoul recently. Gyeongbokgung was by far my husband's and my favorite place on the tour. We enjoyed the changing of the guard ceremony when we first arrived, though it was crowded and a bit hard to see the action. After the ceremony, we toured around the palace grounds and were blown away by their beauty. This is a great place to take photos, relax, picnic, and get a history lesson. We plan to return to see the palace in more depth. It is a serene sanctuary right in the middle of Seoul!

review_title: If you have time for one palace, pick this one
review_body: You can spend 1 hour or half a day here. It's really up to you. It is very large and on the premise are also the Palace Museum and the National Folk Museum. The palace is beautiful. There are a lot of people wearing the traditional Korean clothes around and it is really nice. At two o'clock, there is a "guards changing" ceremony. If you happen to be there, I recommend it, but if you miss it, I don't think you should be sad. The two story structure shown requires Internet reservation a day in advance, so I was kind of bummed that I did not get to go in. I just walked around and took my time and worked up a good appetite for the yummy Korean food I had later.

This is definitely the must visit palace when you are in Seoul. This place is huge so be prepared to walk a lot. Entry is free if you are wearing Hanbok. If not, 6,000krw per pax. Hanbok can be rented from shops near the palace. We rented our Hanbok for 4 hours for 15,000krw per pax from a shop nearby.Be sure to take lots of photo of the palace.

The oldest and largest of all 5 palaces in Seoul. We signed up with the Seoul Tourism Board free walking tour and we had an English speaking guide. The guide gave us a detailed introduction of the whole palace. It is highly recommended that you visit the palace early as it got hotter during the late morning and there was no shade.
This was my favorite of the Seoul palaces-- don't miss it. Very large grounds to walk around and very impressive to look and and for photos.

review_title: An ancient historical place in a modern city
review_body: The actual palace can only be observed through a wide opening. One cannot actually enter the palace buildings, one can just walk around them and get an impression how the royalty functioned in ancient times. The Koreans do their best to keep up old traditions and it is fun to see the guards dressed up in traditional attire and to see the Changing of the Guards ceremony. In the area there were many patriotic young Koreans walking around being photographed in traditional costumes that it is possible to rent for a few hours at the Hanok Center nearby. The colorful costumes and the Changing of the Guards make the place more interesting. When we were there it was very hot and there is very little shade. Take big hats/sunshades...

review_title: Come here early in the morning to avoid huge crowd!
review_body: This is the number one place to visit for all first timers. Guaranteed you with lots of group tours and people with kids learning about the history. Huge place that takes up to 2 hours for a visit! Get the palace and jongmo shrine pass for easy/quick/best value access!

We visited five palace areas in Seoul, and liked them all. Gyeongbokgung palace is huge, and the scenery behind it is beautiful (mountains look gorgeous)! We ended up sitting by the pond with my friends for hours, just chatting and laughing. At one point the park guard had to come tell us to leave, because the park had closed. The atmosphere was very relaxed.Make sure to get the palace pass which gets you into all the five main palace areas in Seoul. It costs 10,000 won and can be bought at any ticket counter near the entryways.

I like this place very much. Learned about Korean history. It was very pretty and well kept. It was huge and exactly what we expected to see since I have watch lots of Korean movies and see the palace on screen before

review_title: Be there for the Changing of the Guard
review_body: The Changing of the Guard was a great photo opportunity. The palace itself is interesting and a nice contrast with modern Seoul right outside the walls.

A sprawling complex with many buildings. Take the tour. That is so helpful. One thing that we found enchanting was the presence of so many young Korean people dressed in native costumes. It was like stepping into the past.

On exiting the metro station, I was approached by a group of Korean youngsters offering tours of the Palace. My guide was a 15 year-old girl speaking perfect English. She was excellent. She refused a tip - said they were not allowed

This is one of the Seoul "Top 10" attractions, but the reviews on Trip Advisor are not unanimously good - so I went wondering if it would be enjoyable, or a bit of a let-down. Well I'm pleased to be able to report that I thoroughly enjoyed it. I had a good walk around Gyeongbokgung Palace and also popped in to the Korean Museum of Folk Culture next door.I found the Palace very interesting and rather impressive (I did not do a guided tour, I just walked round by myself). Entry is 3000 Won (around US$3, GBP£2) which is absolutely excellent value for money. There were quite a lot of locals there in traditional and very colorful dress, which really brightened the experience.It took me 2 hours to have a really good look around and take my photos. The Folk Museum I mentioned earlier I do not recommend. I spent just 5-10 minutes in there and it will certainly be of much more interest to Koreans than to visitors. Nevertheless, entry was free so I'm not complaining... just advising!I notice more than one review comparing Gyeongbokgung Palace with the Forbidden City in Beijing. Gyeongbokgung Palace is much smaller (although still occupying quite a large area) but quite similar in its layout and appearance. Please don't go to Gyeongbokgung Palace hoping or expecting to find an equal of the Forbidden City, but I think you will find something equally as interesting although rather less dramatic in scale.The day I visited the weather was sunny. I would not advise going on a rainy day, I think that would totally spoil your visit.Overall, very highly recommended.
Nice overview place to begin first visit to Seoul from the US. Good review of the history in many languages. Enjoyed the guard change ceremony. Never saw so many selfie sticks used in one place.

Fascinating and majestic palace - well restored. I love that it has the mountain range as backdrop, beautiful lakes within the compound and located in downtown modern Seoul. Easily accessible by public transport or taxi. We missed the cultural performance but saw the performer in traditional costumes - very colorful and pretty!
A very nice place to visit, be with the historical atmosphere, go through Korean history with English translation device.outside there is a folklore singers with old tradition dresses.
Having seen the palace in China, the Gyeongbokgung Palace is really nothing in comparison. But it is still a history of Korea.
A good interesting day and a real feel for ancient Korean culture, the temples look amazing, can get busy and hot depending on time of year but certainly worth a visit if you are in Seoul.
The palace was very popular. The palace is kept in good condition and provides a good perspective on life in the palace when it was inhabited.
I was so looking forward to seeing this palace but ended up feeling underwhelmed. Compared to palaces in Europe, this palace is very Plain and underwhelming, with lack of displays and information.

review_title: It's OK to kill some time
review_body: It's quite a large place with lots of buildings but not a hell of a lot else. There's not a lot of information about the place historically or otherwise which is a real shame and some of the information is only in Korean. Definitely not a place to keep kids occupied.

review_title: Definitely a Must visit place in Seoul
review_body: The palace is situated in middle of the high rises that gives you a sense of the Korean culture and how it has developed over years with skyscrapers on one side and this well preserved Palace in middle.I would suggest to at least take the audio guide but guided tour should be preferred,this helps in providing the context of the history for the palace.Overall this is a highly recommended place to visit in Seoul.
Amazing temple. So big. The statues, the main gate. Everything looks beautiful. Really nice historic place.

review_title: Worth visiting on your first visit
review_body: If you're looking for something that will introduce you a little bit of Seoul in Joseon Era, this is it. Quite crowded but guard-changing ceremony is worth-watching.very near two museums and accessible by subway or bus
Provides an excellent example of Korean architecture for the period. A wonderful historical experience to see how Joseon royalty lived. Well worth visiting - very unique.

Sept-2016) Great palace. It was a little too much walking for our my 8-yr old in addition to taking subway both ways...but he loved it. We got the audio guide for 3,000 won. The subway exit off line 5 (purple line) is gorgeous. You exit by Admiral Yi's statuei (?)...lots of photo ops.
For only $3 CAD can't go wrong to see a massive palace. It is very large with several buildings to see. You also get free admission to the folk museum. Very nice.

Huge grounds, interesting history and stunning architecture. We did not take the guided tour, but wandered the grounds on our own, it is the oldest palace in Seoul. Expect to spend at least half a day here as this place cannot be properly seen in an hour. Insadong shopping neighborhood is about a 10 minute walk from the palace and is a must see in its own right as well.
Grandious! Historic! Summarizes well the past o S. Korea, a great example of how old meets new in this wonderful city!
The palace is huge. There is museum. You can engage a local guides, he's very good telling you the history of the emperor and the people of Korea.

review_title: Gardens not as extravagant as expected
review_body: I went to the royal gardens after reading a New York Times feature on Seoul. The tour guide was good, but the heat made paying attention difficult. The gardens were nice, but I felt like I was in a park and not a royal refuge. I'm not sure what I was expecting, perhaps something more extravagant.

review_title: well, Royal Palace I expected more
review_body: it was a really nice palace, but not as splendid as i expected for the royal palace. Especially after visiting the other palaces, i need to say that it's not really that different.IT's worth going to the palace, but there is no need visiting more than one. I was done with my tour after 1 hour. I was a little bit disappointed that you could hardly see inside the building.It's very easy to get there by bus and you should also visit the Bukcheon Village close-by.By the way renting a Hanbok (in some shops nearby) costs 10.000 (i think for 1 hour), but in summer it can get really hot wearing that.

I think the Royal Palace really is a must-see during your visit to Seoul, since this is a most spectacular building complex. I admire the wood-paintings, the structures of the roofs and the pavilions as such, since the inner decoration & the furniture has been destroyed wuring the war. The restoration of the building is done very well and it is nice to walk through the estate. The entrance ticket is not expensive - paying around 15 € for a family of 5. If you rent a hanbok you are entitled to free access. On a hot day it is quite tiresome to walk and make sure to bring some water.

It covers a large area with lots of buildings that cannot be entered. We did it without a tour as we were too late. So, walking around on our own with scant information did not meet its our expectations.
Very grand and full of history. The palace grounds are well maintained and the architecture preserved. Weather was great and we had a good stroll and introduction to the grounds!

review_title: There are 6 timings for the changing of guards. Go for the one at 1000 and 1400 (as per Sept 2016). 20 mins performance.
review_body: We watched the 20 mins performance at 1400. As you can imagine, due to the heat and sun, people are having their umbrellas out. We decided to stay in the shade, by the side entrance. No regrets, as we didn't get poke by the umbrellas. Pics turned out to be not as bad, as we had the full view of the performance.Be sure to arrive early, if you want to try their Hanbok tradition costume, FREE OF CHARGE. This privilege only applies to first come first serve basis for the first 10-15 guests.
Worth the visit. You can watch the changing of the guard and then do the tour of the palace which is 3000 WON per person. Much to see and takes about 2 to 3 hours.

I visited this palace many times,still I feel good hereIt has long history of Joseon dynasty. Plus you can see many people in hanbok,which makes the palace more special. I recommend to visit Gyeongbok palace.

Built in 1395-- was the main palace of the Joseon Dynasty. Amazing structure and history. I missed the Changing of the Guards, but wish I had seen it. I went on the free English tour and picked up a brochure with information which added to the experience. The National Folk Museum of Korea is right there and worth visiting as well- no additional admission charged. The museum explains a lot about life for Koreans over time.

We didn't go inside the palace, but watched the 20-minute show of the changing of guards. And of course took the chance of photos next to the guards. We could also wear the Hanbok and had photos too, absolutely free. The staff serving us was very nice in helping us to put on the Hanbok and took nice photos for us.

Of course, it's the biggest of the five palaces in Seoul and the one with the largest parking area for the Chiniese tour buses. So, if that is your thing, come her. Much better alternative is the smaller, more manageable Changdeok Palace, a km up the road

review_title: A beautiful palace. A must visit!
review_body: I've visited three palaces in Seoul and this is my most favorite. It's a big place with many beautiful sites so be prepare to walk. We took our three teenage girls and found so many places to take pictures. Recently, my girls traveled to Korean and decided to go here at night or at dusk. They ended up taking great shots and it was much cooler in July. Summers are a challenge to go sightseeing in Korea because of the heat and humidity. Visit in the fall or spring if you can.

The palace is a good way to start learning about the heritage and culture of korea, it offers tours in different languages including english, chinese and japanese, it also has different museums inside with awesome galleries, some even has an interactive feature, i will definitely come back here! Ps. Make sure to see the changing of guards parade infront of the palace gate!
Very interesting place to see and make sure you don't miss this one. We try to wear Hanbok and taking photos too.

This is really an incredible palace that is set right in the middle of the city. It's crazy how the palace just keeps going and going, much more than it appears from the outside. It's pretty cool to see the changing of the guard as well.
Definitely a nice to see, but not a palace that will be remembered by us forever. Great architecture and good location, but nothing further.

This palace is huge and lots of walking on pebble road. There are some stairs to go up to see interior of the palace. It's recommended to wear the comfortable shoes. The guard exchange ceremony is interesting. Taking photos with the guard is a must!!

Absolutely beautiful wandering the grounds, watching the changing of the guard. We happened to be there on the hottest day of the year which meant we did not wander as far and as much as we wanted. Be sure to see the Folk Museum there.

Pros:You get to go many places at once when visiting this place. For the best route, I would recommendInsadong-Samcheongdong-Gyeongbokgung palace- Tongin marketOr vice versa**Insadong, you get to see Korean traditional food, coins, things used. It's like a vivid museum. Quite unique place to visit as this is the only place that all the shop names are written in Korean, even Starbucks.**Samcheongdong is a must go place for people who love to take photo. There are old houses, built in a traditional Korean way, Hanok. However, its a residential area so if ever you visit, Id recommend you to keep quiet there.**Gyeongbokgung, the palace, is nice place to chill, walk around, and take photos with family or partner. There is entrance fee. Free for Koreans below 25 and discounts applicable for disabled, elders, and kids. For foreigners, 4,000 won fixed.There was a package that allows one to visit all the palaces (7 if I remember it right) or special programs done inside the palace with limited space. You can register online and check up the website for those things. Im not so sure if there is any additional charge. Maybe not?**Lastly, Tongin market sells Korean food in affordable price. You can change 5,000 won to 10 old coins, purchasing food in some assigned stalls. Quite cool experience and just nice to have a grasp of some Korean food.Parking lot of the palace is quite cheaper than other parking lots in Seoul. First two hrs is 2,000 won fixed. So I got to go around without any pressure.Cons:More like a side note, the palace closes once a week.(I think it ks Tuesday) so better be aware and not waste your time.There is not much things to do inside. More like learning about the Korean history, taking photos and walk around. If you want something extreme or very active, I wouldn't recommend this place.
Visited this palace on a very hot day. make sure you take lots of water! There are some shady places to sit but not many. It's a beautiful palace to visit.

review_title: beautiful blend of korean and chinese architecture
review_body: We visited this palace mainly to see the changing of the guard ceremony, but were pleasantly surprised by the beautiful architecture. It is the largest of the five (5) palaces and was built in 1395. It was destroyed by fire during the Japanese invasions in the 1500's, but rebuilt in 1867. In 1915 the Japanese returned to destroy most of the palace buildings, and built their colonial headquarters here. Many of the building and gates have been recently restored.It was very peaceful at 9am and there were no crowds, so we were able to view the architecture at our own pace. The most impressive building was the Geunjeongjeon (Throne Hall) which had twelve pairs of stone markers outside and a huge throne to the rear of the building.It will take approximately an hour to view the palace. The National Palace Museum is located outside the palace walls, but was closed (on Monday) when we visited. The Folk Museum is to the North East of the palace complex and admission here is free.After viewing the palace grounds and visiting the folk museum, we got in position to view the changing of the guard ceremony which began at 10:30am. It was well choreographed, and we were able to take videos and photos of the entire ceremony. It is advised to get to the roped area as early as possible, as there was a huge crowd. The ceremony is done daily, except on Tuesday.Admission was W3,000 for adults and W1,500 for children. It may be easily reached by taking subway line 3 to Gyeongbokgung Station, and using exit # 5.

review_title: A good look into the grand life of the Korean dynasty
review_body: Huge grounds and lots of walking. Beautiful architecture and preserved or rebuilt buildings. We had the advantage of our own tour guide and that made the experience ever so better as there are very little explanations for self travellers.We learned a good understanding of Korean architecture and engineering. Also the garden at the back is beautiful with the lily pad filled Lake... Certainly worth a visit

The admission fee is reasonable $3 but my advise to read about the history before you come which will give you sense to what you will see as international tourist. Choose a cloudy day in summer to avoid heat.
Great for a morning walk, especially in the gardens. Read up on the history a little before you go to get context. Also try to see the changing of the guards.

review_title: Changing of the guard at 10 am or 2 pm a must see
review_body: Very nice palace grounds.Tips:Need to pay to go into palace grounds.Changing of guard is free in the front courtyard and so is the palace museum.Enjoy!
This palace is a must visit...very well maintained..n very affordable..wish there are more signs boards to explain more about thr palace

review_title: if you are visiting Seoul its a must place to go to
review_body: sorry man, you cant visit Seoul without visiting this place,its a great place to taste some of the Korean history- the palace where the king himself set and ruled.if you are not that interested in history- still, it is a beautiful palace with great stories to tell. it also have many nice places to sit and have rest with your date or friends.

This was a beautiful palace but was starting to look a bit run down. It was very spacious and i wish we'd hired a guide to tell us about it as i inagine thete is a fascinating history. Worth visiting.
The most iconic landmark in seoul. U must go here if going to korea. The entry fee is cheap. Nice for backpacker

Gyeongbokgung Palace is one of the most iconic places of South Korea. The whole palace area is huge. It was build in the 14th century AC and destroyed heavily by fire during the japanese invasions. Since then, it has been restored and destroyed numerous times. English guide tours are available at 11:00 (starting point is at the right side of the entrance in front of the information office).There is also the Museum nearby, which is also very interesting and a nice coffee and souvenir shop. Just be there!

The Palace is a def must see in Seoul. Although you're not able to visit the inside and it can be extremely hot and crowded, the colorful buildings are beautiful. Don't forget to walk behind the main buildings, but also visit the gardens behind. Used to be the area for the concubines. Peaceful and still with some very pretty sites.

Go in the morning and take time to enjoy as it is huge palace and you may want to join the free guided tour provided. Do check the schedule at the Tourist Information Center after the Gwanghwamun Gate.Catch the "Changing of Guard" at 10am and "Gate Guard Duty" performance at 11am

I went there with friends but we decided to split in several small groups. I walked around with one friend and it was really calming. But if you go there make sure it's not too hot, I couldn't enjoy it to the fullest because of 37c° and not even a single cloud. You should go there in a Hanbok and take some pics ^-^

. Must visit place . located in the city center so you can see how the history met the future . big palace beautyful park check when the gyeongbokgung palace changing of the guards very beautyful ceremony
I went there just this Monday. Definitely a must-see if you visit Seoul but try not to go here during summer because it's freaking hot here right now.

review_title: Beautiful but only for the first while
review_body: Overall:- worth going to (spend at most 2 hours)- beautifulPros:- cheap entrance (around $3 CAD)- huge area for you to explore in- easy walks and lots of photo opportunity- free tours in many languages to learn about the historyCons:- you cannot enter any of the buildings as they are blocked off- it is only beautiful for the first while because buildings look similar and since you cannot enter them, it might get boring / repetitive- most buildings are not the original (a re-build) so it's not the most interesting for those who are looking for the "true feeling of emerging in ancient grounds" - Good to know: the Gyeonghoeru Pavilion (building in the middle of the pond) cannot be entered as it requires reservation in advance

review_title: An important chapter of Early Korean History
review_body: The Gyeongbokgung Palace has been well-maintained over the centuries that have passed since the end of the rule of the Joseon Dynasty! The attention to detail, with regard to the the patterns on the roofs of the buildings, is flawless. If you are lucky enough to visit the Palace during the morning or lunch hours, you may be fortunate enough to watch the changing of the Royal Guards ceremony. There are also ample opportunities to take beautiful photos to preserve the memory of your trip.My reasoning behind the 4-star rating as opposed to 5-stars, is the signage in and around the palace. The number of signs explaining the significance of all the numerous buildings is very limited. For a tourist hotspot, signs written in English and Chinese were few and far between. This is, however, a symbol of a very important chapter of Korean History and in my opinion, an absolute must-see in Seoul!
They have change of the guard at 10am SaturdaysMuch recommendedBlue house is right behind the palace and is beautiful

This is the biggest of the palaces in Seoul. Be prepared to spend 3 to 4 hours to see most of the area. They provide free tours for foreigners and locals on site so if you want to learn a bit about the history it's a great way to do so.
You learn about ancient Korean culture, architecture and history. Having soldiers in costumes also help in describing life in this palace during that time. Very interesting.
This place is huge and there is so much going on. Although I didn't get to see it because there was a bad rain storm and it was still raining a little, I still enjoyed walking around this huge place.

Royal Lee dynasty is the longest regime in the world history: over 650 years.Every buildings is still under reconstruction as many were burnt down during tough period of the Royal Lee dynasty. There is also a National museum which dusplays Royal Lives of Kings, Queens, Princes & Princesses inside of its territory that is free to all the visitors either local or foreign. May others items which shows its detail of lives in the palace.
It's a nice palace, but when compared to the Imperial palace in Beijing, this one seems very small and plain. However, the guard changing ceremony is neat to see.
Quiet and calm, worth a walk around the grounds to take in the structure and the landscape. Nice alternative to the busy city streets.

review_title: Not good to visit during blistering summer days
review_body: It was such a hot month that watching the changing of guards (they have my sympathy) and walking around the huge palace grounds sapped all our energy - even with an umbrella. We perspired so profusely that we decided not to visit every part of the palace. It would definitely be much nicer to visit during the cooler months although not too cold. Having said so much, I would still recommend this place highly for a visit.

review_title: Fall in love in Korean culture
review_body: Gyeongbokgung Palace is their primary palace. Tour guides are for free, you just have to wait for their schedules :) They're great, they explain everything in detail. The palace is not yet done for re-construction coz Japanese armies burnt down the whole palace except for the main hall. Will take them decades to rebuild everything. Approximately has 500 buildings inside the palace.

The palace area is quite large and nicely decorated. The colour scheme and pattern painted on the buildings reminded me of peacocks and I overheard a tour guide saying this to a tour group. The buildings are quite pretty and there's lots to look at. You can take some really stunning photos with the mountains in the background. It's pretty busy most of the time, but it's such a big place, it doesn't really matter.We went in the summer at around 10.30am, so it was quite hot and there is nowhere to buy drinks within the palace gates, and only one drink fountain. It would be a good idea to bring your own water/drinks and a hat/umbrella to protect from the sun.Of course, the highlight of the visit is witnessing the guard changing ceremony and taking a selfie with the unnaturally still guards afterwards. It really is something to see. You don't have to be there at 10am to see it, there are smaller ones occurring at each hour as well.Visiting this palace can also be incorporated with a trip to Bukchon Hanok village, the other nearby palace and then Insadong. They are within reasonable walking distance of each other and makes enough to see for a whole day.
set in a very peaceful park setting great architectural with a mirrored lake you certainly will need your camera has a controlled walk to view all aspects of the Palace

review_title: Good to have 2 hours time to visit this palace during late morning
review_body: Experience the guards changing ceremony at 2pm. Go early like 11am, end of the palace there is a museum. You will need at least 1 hour inside to explore. Interesting place to go. Come out to the main gate of palace by 1.50pm get ready for more. summer time get ready your umbrella.

review_title: Fantastic and awesome building with great history
review_body: It's really huge palace, as far as I remember, it took about 1hour to go from entrance to blue house behind the palace, absolutely walking slowly, hearing some explanation from tour guide, though. So during summer, you may need sunblock or umbrella! Anyway buildings are so beautiful and it become real with history in mind. I can tell anybody ' don't miss this palace '

Beautiful central palace. We visited it once in winter, when it was really cold. We will visit it again for sure. It is very well maintained. Most of holidays the entrance is free. Otherwise the prices is around a couple of dollars.

The Gyeongbokgung Palace is definitely worth a trip if you are prepared! It is quite large and gets very hot in the summer months. Comfortable shoes, water bottles, and sun hats are a must. We were lucky enough to catch the changing of the guard, which included a small parade of fresh guards and drummer. We had to buy a ticket to go up and into the upper section of the palace entrance, to be honest, there was not much English around to explain things. Definitely read up on the history of the Palace, maps are available on site. The farther you go into the Palace the more beautiful and lush the surroundings become. We also ventured into the Korean Folk museum on the property, a welcome retreat from the heat and chance to grab a cold drink. At the very end of the property, just outside and behind the palace, The Blue House is located. It is the executive office and official residence of the South Korean head of state, the President of the Republic of Korea. Outside the palace back gate is a wonderful photo opportunity if you have interest in The Blue House. We took the path down between the Palace and The Blue House and came to large intersection which had a beautiful fountain and free museum across the street.

review_title: Great place to visit to know more about Korea's palace history
review_body: If you're someone who enjoys watching historical dramas (like me hehe), then you will definitely love this palace. However if you're not, fret not. This palace's sights will still take your breath away by it's magnificent architecture, and not to mention how amazing your photos will turn out.Be sure to catch the royal guards changing ceremony, and try not to miss it as they only have certain timings for it. To add on, it is quite interesting to see how they can manage to play instruments and/or march in sync in those long uniforms of theirs. You can also take pictures with the guards that are standing at the entrance of the palace (if you're lucky, they might even smile for your pictures!).

This palace is amazing but the Secret Garden tour is well worth it! It's very inexpensive and the docent is extremely knowledgeable! It was super hot out (August) but the shade offered along the path makes it bearable.
It's very cheap to access and very quiet and reflective. I liken it to a smaller version of The Forbidden City.
Perfect place to walk around and discover the Korean culture. Don't miss the Korean couples dressed in traditional clothing.

review_title: Pretty to look at, but no English
review_body: So we went to the palace and it was only 3,000 KRW to get in which is really reasonable. When we went to get a map and info leaflet, there was no English. So whilst everything was really beautiful to look at... we didn't stay for long because we just didn't know what we were looking at. If you are really keen, I think English guides are available.

One of the most iconic sights in all of Korea. Tips: 1. Reach Gyeongbokgung Palace before 10am2. Do catch the Palace Gate Opening Ceremony & the Guards Changing3. Try out the traditional costume experience!4. Take a lot of beautiful pictures!

review_title: Great place to see this place. Don't forget to watch the parade.
review_body: This vast area would give you a good understanding of Korean culture. The colorful parade showcasing the different traditional costumes of their soldiers in the olden time. While the palace is good, the only thing that disappoints me is the buildings built around the palace that for me is an eye sore. Other than that, everything is perfect. :-)
The palace is very beautiful with mountains as the background. We also get to see the changing of the palace guard ceremony at 10:00 am. Very interesting! It was like returning to the past
i really love this. i felt like i went back in time. really must try this if your visiting seoul. learn a lot about their history .

review_title: Don’t miss the grounds and guards of Gyeongbokgung Palace
review_body: Gyeongbokgung Palace is the first royal palace that was built during the 500-year Joseon Dynasty. It is the largest of the 5 grand palaces in Seoul and my family and I visited this restored palace on a sunny Thursday morning in June. Getting there and fees: Take Exit 5 of Gyeongbokgung Station on the Line 3 Subway. Upon exit, National Palace Museum is on your left while Gyeongbokgung Palace is on your right. The entrance fee is 3,000 won for adults and 1,500 won for youth. This Palace is closed on Tuesdays.The Palace: We were there just in time for the 20-minute Changing of Royal Guards Ceremony at the square between Heungnyumun Gate (inner gate into the Palace) and the Gwanghwamun Gate (outer gate) starting at 10am. There are altogether 6 guard changing ceremonies starting every hour between 10am and 3pm. To me, the Guards ceremony is the highlight of the Palace since it’s a great opportunity to experience the re-enactment of a historical ceremony or scene in traditional Korea. The guards’ colourful uniforms, the emblem-laden and colourful flags that they carry and the musical instruments that they play are a fabulous feast for the eyes and ears and of course the cameras and handphones! And not many people know about a costume experience in wearing one of the four military uniforms – sumunjang, gapsa, jungbyoung, daejol – free-of-charge at the Sumunjangcheong Building next to the Gwanghwamun Gate entrance. We had 2 lady staff who put on the uniform for us, and after that we had only 5 minutes to take photos (hence it would be good if you have a companion with you). This is only available within the half hour after the changing of the Royal Guards ceremony, which is good since all the tourists would go into the Palace grounds. Also, don’t forget to take photos with the stationary guards on duty outside the Gwanghwamun Gate. You could stand next to them but just don’t disturb them.While the historical Palace is located in the midst of modern Seoul, I also saw that it is located with imposing hills as its backdrop. The walk in the Palace courtyards, halls, pavilions, gates, buildings and gardens is also something not to be missed, as it would enhance your understanding and appreciation of the Korea culture and history. It would be good to be part of a free guided tour in English (do check their timings). Depending on the extent of what you want to know and see, it would take at least 2 hours to cover the entire Palace.I am tempted to compare Gyeongbokgung Palace with other renowned palaces outside of South Korea, but it would be comparing apples with oranges. Suffice to say, we enjoyed visiting Gyeongbokgung Palace and would definitely recommend this attraction when you are in Seoul.

review_title: Beautiful (AND the main palace of the last Korean dynasty)
review_body: Def a must while in Seoul. Very beautiful and huge!! You can spend hours wandering around. You get to see lots of buildings and gardens. A few times per day there's a guards change (check website) - recommend! Get an English tour (it's free, btw, and only 1 hour) - there are few per day. And the National Folk Museum of Korea is within! Also nice and not too big.

We followed a private tour around the palace, which was great! Oh, and rent a Hanbok and walk around the palace - the admission is free, and heaps of people will want to take photos with you - see what it's like to be a mini celebrity for a day!

I went as the palace was in the centre of Seoul - I had already visited the Secret Garden and C'bok Palace earlier in the trip - so didn't expect to be overwhelmed in comparison. To be honest - I think this was my favourite Palace in Seoul. Firstly the scale is immense when one considers it is slap bang in the middle of the city. secondly - when you are expecting to just wander through labyrinths of palace buildings, you stumble across beautiful gardens and pools of water - the gardens themselves are extensive and astonishingly pretty. I found it very peaceful and a refugee from the Seoul summer heat. I would advise any visitor to take themselves off for a visit and at Won 3,000 for an entry ticket, it was incredibly cheap compared to the prices to visit palaces and castles at home in the UK.

If you are in Seoul, you have to go there. This place is amazing. It's HUGE so be ready to walk. The gardens are breath taking. Very beautiful and peaceful. Can get really HOT in summer, so bring water, sunglasses or a cap. I learned a lot about Korean History just by visiting this place. I highly recommend it.

This palace have about 15-16 pavilion (i forget about the sum exactly ).....From the gate...if you get the right timing, you can see the little ceremony of guard changing...After passing the gate, prepare your energy to walked around the palace. You also can visit the blue house (just in front the gate) and the museum (free) around there.

review_title: Interesting but be sure to get a tour and go after the weather is cool!
review_body: Not much signage so, I would recommend taking a tour. Be sure not to go in the heat of the day. There is little shade and the summer heat was brutal.

Much to explore and one of the great many places to understand the history and culture of Korea. It is good to note the different time slots for the guided tours to help plan your trip. There is a 3pm English tour.

Gyeongbokgung Palace was my second favorite palace in the city. Its so huge that you really don't have to go visit any of the other palaces as they are all extremely similar. I probably spent around 2.5 hours walking around and admiring the beautiful architecture and natural areas located within the palace grounds. There was a free show performed by the locals as I entered the palace gate, which was quite interesting to watch as they were demonstrating a scene from the past. The National Folk Museum of Korea is located on the same grounds, which was a nice pit stop along the way. I'll keep my review short by saying that it was worth the visit as the palace is rich in culture and history and it's so big that you can get the full palace experience!

review_title: Huge palace to visit in Seoul
review_body: Gyeongbokgung Palace is a great place to see houses of royal family members and to know something about their history and lifestyle. It has a huge beautiful territory, it took us about 2 hours to walk through the palace. It also includes admission free museum and a small cafe/restaurant. There are ceremonies for the Opening and Closing of Palace Gates and Guard Changes. Several times a day there are free guided tours in Korean, English, Chinese and Japanese. Tip: it may be hard to walk through all territory in hot sunny day, better take an umbrella and at least one bottle of water.
Love the free tour, great presentation, nice and expansive gardens on site. Also has traditional concert at night during the summer months. Usually closed on Tuesdays.

Mighty structures from Joseon dynasty. The palace area is really huge and will take time to cover. So must go there with time in hand & it is definitely worthy. Big palaces. signature designs, and so organized. The whole area is highly well maintained. Souvenir shop and food is available inside. The Museum will brief the amazing past of the royals. This place very near from Changdeokgung Palace and can be visited together. Walking would be the best way from one place to another.
Mosth popular place in seoul, the grand palace. You can learn about the history of korean people. In the morning, there is also change guard ceremony.

We all know if you are in Seoul you will end up there, to make best use of your time 1- Go with a free tour, English tours are scarce but sure its better than walking by yourself, check the time in their website2- Watch guard changing, the time is about 13:00 ish I guessEnjoy

We went there 9 am and no cue so going in for a visit different palaces and building inside. The museum was nice . It show part of the history of Korean dynasty. Soldiers exchange was 11 am in main entrance.

review_title: View Palace and Changing of the Guards
review_body: Get there at least 10 minutes before the times to see the changing of the guards. We liked this Palace the most.
Beautiful architecture and peaceful gardens offer some respite from the madness of Seoul's traffic. Lovely to see so many school children in traditional dress- hanbok.

review_title: The Josean Kings Palace - worth a look.
review_body: The Gyeongbokgung palace is definitely worth a look if you are visiting Seoul. Set at the north end of the city against a mountain backdrop, Gyeongbokgung is actually one of three Joseon dynasty palaces that formed a palatial precinct before it was systematically broken up during the Japanese occupation in the early 1900s. Much of it has now been restored or rebuilt.The original throne hall survived the destruction and is a relatively open building so you can usually see inside, even if the palace is crowded.
