There are some beautiful gardens and quiet courtyards that I found I had to myself despite visiting in the middle of Summer break. There is also a guard in traditional dress at the main south gate. It routinely changes with great ceremony during the day and the accompanying narrative is interesting. You can see most of Gyeongbokgung in about 3 hours but if you have more time, wander a little further and see the nearby palaces of the Queen and Crown Prince.

This palace was massive!!! It goes on and on and on and you have to walk a lot. I suggest getting a tour guide when you go here otherwise you won't know what the several palace buildings are and what's going on. Go at night preferably as the place is lit up.
Old palace, historic site, well serviced for travelers! It is a little bit hot to visit during the day time in summer.
Also called the North Palace, this is a beautiful palace, where the guard changing ceremony is a must-see.

review_title: Just some palace buildings and nice scenery
review_body: Basically without a guide, I think I'll be pretty lost without her telling what the different palaces are for; and the uses of the different structures and how it came about. On the other hand, having the guide gives you much inside on the palace; and I definitely recommend using the guided tours (since they are free; just checkout the timings). Currently, they have a promotion that if you wear a hanbok to the palace they can waive your admission fee; not sure how long it will last.All in all, it was a nice place to take pictures (do lots of walking) and is convenient to visit the nearby attractions such as national folk musuem, national palace musuem or the bukchon hanok village in anguk (all free, and are within 10 min walking distance from the palace)

review_title: Oasis of calm in bustling city
review_body: Very nice, in particular in spring, guard change real fun for children. Well maintained and interesting to roam around.
It's a lovely palace and very expansive. For photographers, it is an excellent venue both day and night. I can't remember how much the ticket was, but probably around $2 usd.

This palace is a must visit place in Seoul. Recently it is open for public at night for a certain period of time. I enjoyed the night tour. There is a museum beside this which is also a good place to visit. I recommend to search the website and go there when night tour is open... Late afternoon would be good time to visit.

this palace is one of most interesting places in the world as you can enjoy the feeling of the ancient times and the joy of seeing the amazing costumes of the Korean people.you must see the changing guard cermony.

It is very accessible from our hotel since it was a few blocks away. And we were able to have a quick tour of the palace in between our business meetings. At least plan half of your day when going here. Because the palace is very wide. You will appreciate the beauty of their structures and also their garden. You will be lucky to have a photograp with gilrs wearing their traditional dress costume without a cost. And also before going inside avoid touching the palace guards because it is prohibited.

Enjoyed the walk we did through the amazing gardens and old buildings. Very peaceful setting and interesting part of Korean history. Seoul is a very busy city and this land mark is nice break from all the hustle and bustle
Try to go on weekdays. Crowds can be fierce on weekends. Korean grandmothers are often quite pushy in queues -- no news to Koreas but surprising to westerners.

Great Stuff, do not miss the Changing of Guard Ceremony 2 timer per day ( Selected )Another great place visit and also another building located inside the palace ( National Folk Museum of Korea ), please go in and feel the history.Huge place that must be go .....
Accessible, with tourists even the cold season, it helps you realize the history of Seoul and South Korea.
This palace is one of the most amazing places I've visited. The mixture of the great architecture together with its surroundings was just something out of this world.
The place was huge. The whole are is wonderful. It's better to come with a guide so you can hear the history, but there's signs everywhere with the story of each section of the beautiful palace.
It was a great way to look at Korea's past and looking at the way Koreans lived in the past especially the royal Koreans and how the architecture of the palace.
Gyeongbokgung Palace is the historical of korean, this place is so many people but when we walk to hidden garden, I'm feel peacefully and relax.

An extremely interesting place to learn about Korean history, culture and architecture. Quite big so ideally need 2+ hours to see it all, especially if you take the time to stop and photograph each area.

review_title: A lot of hype but not as impressive
review_body: I visited the palace once in 2015 during day and once in July 2016 at night. I have to say, the first time I saw the architecture of the buildings I was impressed. The second time around was not as impressive. I would recommend the palace to first time visitors to get a better feel for Korean style buildings. If I go back to Korea, the palace will not be on my list to do.

review_title: Symbolizes Korea's borders, language and culture
review_body: It's a miracle this place still exists, considering the unthinkable brutality and genocide Korea had to suffer through during the Japanese colonization. Besides witnessing the pagoda's and old palace's you will come to learn why Koreans take such pride in their heritage. I enjoyed learning about how the Kings used to walk in figure 8, symbolizing wealth since you could afford to feed yourself lavishly. Go check it ou.
One of the places to see for a historic tour in Seoul, Korea. It is a big palace and has nice gardens. You could take a stroll and feel at peace. It is worth going and seeing

This is an ancient palace in the middle of very modern city. The site has been restored quite heavily but remains very interesting. there are two museums on site, we visited one of them the museum of Korean Life. A great little museum.
It was a really big palace. Highly recommend you to go if you haven't been there. It is a place that I think one must go in Seoul.
Much larger than you would expect, so come with adequate time to enjoy yourself. Walking through the gardens was particularly enjoyable.
Fantastic spectacle. Watching the guards march to and from the courtyard took me bak in time. Ladies in local dress in evidence too.
Is a great cultural site. You can spent a lot of time in the Palace. Good place for the family to visit.
A interesting place to visit. If you like old places full of history this is a must go in Seoul. I liked it!
Unfortunately, there was a lot of tourists visiting gyeongbokgung and it's quite difficult to take a nice picture with all of these people as the background.
Great place to know more about the culture and history. Appreciated the tour guide's stories, but if you want to soak in the entire place, be ready to spend half a day, at least.

Really great place except for the fact that it was reaaaalllyyy hot cos it was summertime. MASSIVE place. Guided tours were available but I didn't think the English would be comprehensible so decided to stick it out on my own. Overall good eye opener to their culture.
It was a really big castle and I have the chance to watch the garde parade, it was a unique show we can only see there I think. It is a really touristic place but a must see in Seoul !

This is a must-see if you go to Seoul, especially to understand something of Korea's cultural history. The palace is actually a huge complex of buildings square in the midst of downtown Seoul's business district, so it's accessible by car, bus, or metro. Parking is at a premium,however, so use public transport if at all possible. Be advised that this tour requires lots of walking due to the size of the complex, numerous buildings & gardens, etc. If you're there in summer, except it to be HOT, so be prepared. An umbrella is a good idea, both in case of rain & for shade if it doesn't rain. The buildings are serene & beautiful outside & surprisingly plain inside. On our visit there were numerous Koea-American, Koean-Canadian,& Korean-Australian young women there in full traditional dress, which is beautiful & adds to the charm of the place. It's kind of a pilgrimage for them, apparently. Don't miss the excellent museum adjacent to the complex. Nice & cool in there, & the exhibits are interesting & help you understand what you're seeing outside. (I suggest doing the museum first, then the complex.) The restaurant adjacent to the museum offers a limited Korean cuisine. If that doesn't appeal to you, there are numerous food outlets in the near downtown area, but that will involve more walking. You should allow at least 3 hours to tour the museum & palace complex, more if you intend to stop for a meal. But this is a great place to visit, highly recommended.

A very nice experience, also accessable with a stroller (once you manage the metro). The guards with their plastic toys look funny at its best (artificial would probably be a better description). If you are there, try to make use of the free app provided (free wifi everywhere) or the english guided tour. The adjoint folk museum is interesting and provides aircondition to cool down during high season.
Small but beautiful palace! Cheap and easy to go by subway with a direct access to the Palace. The moment we left, there was a ritual ceremony at the gate, it was beautiful, a must visit place.

Great place to take your time and walk around the palace grounds. If you can time it just right, watch the ceremonial changing of the guard first. This will last about 15 minutes and then you should explore the grounds.

Ok, so this is a nice place to visit and is really interesting to see such history in the middle of the city. There are very many people walking around, but I never felt too crowded as the ground are really large. The buildings are all very similar (as was the theme of the other palaces we visited), same architecture, colors, etc. there were so many little rooms which had no explanation. The grounds of the palace were mostly gravel, with the exception of the building in the middle of the water, but we could not figure out how to enter it. Nice experience, but I would not spend too much time there.

review_title: THE palace to see in Seoul
review_body: This is the best palace (of the 3) in Seoul. Strongly recommend to take the free language tour (check times on their website) or book one with Seoul walking tours (free as well)...w/o someone to explain the deep history / lifestyle its just a bunch of building. The guard changing ceremony is okay nothing special.

review_title: A bounty of history and culture in the city of Seoul
review_body: One of the most beautiful palaces I have been to. The secret garden was worth the extra fee. I felt transported back into a time of princes and princesses. Vast courtyards and beautiful gardens where the royalty once escaped to find peace from the outside world. Cherry blossoms were in bloom to make this experience even more magical.

review_title: Stunning history & grounds in city centre
review_body: This formed part of a private tour we'd organised, so we didn't need to buy tickets or think on timings... we simply were guided, informed and enjoyed.The changing of the Royal guard was stunning and brilliantly translated over tannoy :-) Our guide explained many many interesting facts about the architecture, history, residents and traditions relating to both the palace, residencies and grounds. In the grounds is also the National Folk Museum... Well worth visiting with its excellent exhibitions and Korean history timeline board... please stop to read it, rather than just walk past, or you'll miss out on knowing so much!!There is also a children's museum, so all ages catered for.

It was my first time to be there and it is a really a comfortable place to walk around and get to know about the history of Korea. Highly recommend you to go if you haven't been there. It is a place that I think one must go in Seoul.

The first time i went to Gyeongbukgung Palace it was raining. But even if it's raining, you can still explore the palace with umbrella and don't be afraid because the ground won't be slippery, the ground designed with rough sands and rough steppingstones deliberately so that people can't walk fast in dynasty era.

review_title: Very good at any time of the year
review_body: I have visited Gyeongbokgung four times in the last few years, the latest was this spring. The area is massive and I would highly recommend taking a tour if it is your first time to get the most out of the experience. The workers are very friendly and the changing of the guards is always fun to watch. Also make sure to check out the free National Folk Museum in the northeastern section of the complex.
Very nice if the weather is good. Lovely surroundings and plenty to look at. Good for all types of travellers to see Korean history.

review_title: Beautiful place, not comparable to similars in China
review_body: This is a very nice palace, and I am glad I visited it, although you have to adjust your expectations if you visited similar ones in China. For example, there is no comparison with the Forbidden City! Having said so, I think you should visit it while in Seoul, and from there walk to the Bukchon Hanok Village to continue a day tour of the city.

review_title: Gyeongbokgung Palace (and the National Folk Museum)
review_body: Our hosts took us to this lovely palace when we first visited Seoul (in May 2012). We enjoyed the historic buildings, the beautiful gardens, and the changing of the guard ceremony. We also visited the National Folk Museum nearby and really enjoyed that as well. (Note: The folk museum has a good gift shop where we were able to buy some lovely gifts to take home to our family.)

Vast area. Majestic main entrance. Beautiful compound. Very good for pictures.You can see tourists / locals wearing traditional emperor era clothing when they visited this attraction. They actually make the whole experience even better because it gives you that "feel".Be sure to walk all the way to the end and to also go into the museum. You get to learn a lot about the Korean culture and way of life from those days (way back). Enjoy!

Three generations enjoyed the 2 hour tour of Gyeongbok Palace in sweltering heat. A group of English speaking enthusiastic teens met us as we emerged from the Metro with an offer to show us around for free, and we really appreciated their tour! Their historic stories helped us to see more than just just a collection of old beautiful buildings. At 2 PM plan to be in the big entry courtyard for the changing of the guard reenactment ceremony.

review_title: The most important palace in Seoul
review_body: No visit to Seoul would be complete without seeing the most important palace in the country. Expect huge crowds during the summer. We had a private guide and learned about how the rulers lived, etc. Easy to access as its right in the middle of town.

review_title: Let your soul wander through Korean history
review_body: A brilliant set of palaces and gardens. Really essential if you're in Seoul, the complex is well preserved and full of Korean old skool flava. You can wonder and wander for hours through the gardens. With a little bit of effort you can escape the crowds and find some serenity.

This is the largest palace of all Seoul. Too big and hot on summer days. If you would like to see a very big palace with great expansion this is it. If you would like a more manageable place with more trees and vegetation I would recommend going to the Changdeokgung palace.

I wish I had more time to spend here by myself. My 80 yr old mother and I visited here and she couldn't walk the grounds all day. (suggestion - provide benches for people to sit). We were lucky to be there at the change of guards in the morning. It is only 3000 won (about $3 US). Not a bad picture to be taken. Our hotel was in the area and personally I think the best time to visit is early morning and late at night (the gates are closed but it is less crowded and lit up at night)

It was the first monument we visited while travelling in Korea. It was gorgeous from the beginning to the end. We took the subway to get there and we appeared inside the palace. Fantastic!The entrance fee is very cheap and you can walk all over the huge palace. With this fee it is also included a visit in the National Museum, inside the palace area.A great visit to do in Korea, watching the contrast of the traditional buildings and the brand new ones coexisting in the same city.
The grandest of palaces in Seoul. I arrived when they were doing a traditional guard ceremony demonstration which was great to watch. Not much to see there but nice to wander around the buildings.

There are tour groups available, but we decided to take our time to stroll around ourselves. The pavilion in the pond is a must see, and walk deeper in to find secluded/ less crowded parts of the palace it truly is beautiful. And you can't leave without watching the changing of guards march. I don't know how they stand so still even through the Korean winds (brrr....)
It let you know more about the old days in Korea. Spacious palace with beautiful pool and garden. If you wear the Korean Traditional clothing, the entrance fee is free.

review_title: Nice place to just look around
review_body: Its a palace inside a city. You see buildings surrounding the palace. You have to pay to get further in the palace but outside is good enough to take nice photos. Location is very good with a train station just beside it!

Very beautiful place. Palace grounds are huge therefore allocate at least 2 hours when visiting. My favourite part of the palace is the Hwangwonjeong or the pavilion in the middle of a pond and Jibokjae which is the library/cafe on the far end. I recommend people to buy the combination tickets to save money.
i had the opportunity to go on a night tour of this palace with a Korean friend and i can highly recommend it. the lighting of the structures and the overall atmosphere was something special.

We walked the whole are of Gyeongbukgung. There is a small forest trail right at the end, overlooking a beautiful and serene lotus pond. Entrance to the folk museum inside the palace is free and is a good visit.
Worth a visit. The grounds are huge so be prepared to walk and bring a map. We did not have a tour guide. It's a fantastic place to take photos.

review_title: Planned for 2 hours and still wasn't enough
review_body: Really enjoyed wondering around the palace grounds. My family split up and agreed to meet back after 2 hours. Even still, my son (15 y.o.) said it wasn't enough time and he had to rush back shortly after discovering another area. Very beautiful place.

review_title: I don't think I'll come back
review_body: It was nice but the only reason for me to go back there would be to exercise since its got huge grounds.A lot of the buildings were renovated (basically all of them)so there was no feeling of deeper history.

I went with a group of people in a bus, Tour guide was Korean lady fluent in English.After arriving there was too much walk and talk, we were not allowed to enter some places so we only sneak peek from outside
Very interesting place to visit and great area to walk around after the visit. A must when we visit seoul

A beautiful (if a bit threadbare) palace that is still being rebuilt after the Japanese destroyed large parts of it during the imperial era. Crowded by Chinese tour groups but a worthwhile visit nonetheless, rent an audio guide for 3000 won to hear the history behind the buildings, and check out the recreation of the traditional guard changing ceremony. There's both a mini practice one and the real deal on the hour.Including the folk museum, should take you under three hours.

We got a chance to visit the Korean palace. Plan on staying at least 2 hours. It is one of the best places in the city to take your family and to take pictures. It is pretty inspiring. We were lucky to have a guide explain the whole place. It is well worth the investment.
There is a lot of history to be seen and learned of at this palace. I would highly recommend it for those visiting Korea who want to learn more about the country's rich history.
My wife and my son enjoyed our visit here. The place is quite crowded when we were there.Architecture was superb and magnificent.A place that should not be missed when visiting Seoul.
This place is very beautiful in autumn. Its close to the city, easy to use public transportation. Free entrance fee if you wear traditional Hanbok.

review_title: Vast array of Palace Buildings and Gardens
review_body: If you visit Seoul then you must visit this palace! It is a very vast assortment of old buildings and gardens so be prepared for a hike! Some of the visitors are as interesting as the buildings! The juxtaposition of old against modern is striking.
I have visited the Palace a few times with my South Korean students. There is so much history there! It is amazing and all South Koreans know a lot about it.

review_title: The main palace in Seoul city
review_body: Personally, I prefer Changdeok palace than Kyungbok palace, eventhough both of them are really beautiful korean royal palace, Kyungbok palace was distroyed by japanese people during 18-19c when japan colonized korea.Anyway, It was really nice to travel this place with my german friend. We can get in the palace for free(even my german friend), cuz it was a cultural day! (It's the last Wed of every month). Usually, it cost around 3$. I recommend to make a reservation for the pavilion in the palace, You can make a reservation for that free through the internet website and it's free. It was the best expirence for me and my friend to go inside of the pavilion called 경회루 where used to held big party during the summertime. And of course, Most of the buildings in the palace was really good and they has free museums, one is korean palace museum, and another one is a korean folk museum.

An Amazing place. A little gem nestled between the skyscraper of Seoul. Excellent value for money especially when one buys the combination ticket for all the palaces even if one only visits a few as I did.

This is our second visit to the palace but our first time at night, it is very different from the day view, it feels very mysterious and the entrance looks so magnificent across the road. It's a good place to learn about korea's history and culture if you join the guided tours.

review_title: Impressive and very very beautiful palace
review_body: It is truly THE palace to visit and marvel at the beauty presented to you! For an adult you only pay 3000 won and get an overwhelming display of the past. Although, yes, there are a lot of tourists, but considering the size of the place you don't mind them. Wandering around the grounds there will be many couples and singles in hanbok taking a lot of pictures. It is a nice addition to the whole experience. I suggest to go there when it opens so you have some quiet moments there as well!!

review_title: Wear a hanbok and you'll get free entrance ^^
review_body: This is my 2nd time to Gyeongbukgung and the palace has never failed to impress me with its palace structure and scenery.Arrive around 10:30am before the changing guards ceremony at 11am. The entrance fee is 3,000 won per adult and if you want free entrance, wear a hanbok. The changing guard ceremony takes about 30 minutes and you can consider having lunch at Insadong as it's merely 5 - 10 minutes walk from Gyeongbukgong.

Excellent palace, worth the 3000 Won ticket. I visited this on Saturday and many young Koreans were dressed in the national customs and happy to have their photos taken. The gardens also good to visit and good photography opportunities of Seoul skyline.

review_title: If You are Used to European Palaces, these are very Different
review_body: This was the first Korean palace we visited - it is a 5-minute walk from the Gwanghwamun subway stop. The admission fee is minimal ($3.00 I believe), which is appropriate. It was hot as blazes - be sure to dress for heat and bring an umbrella - not for rain - but for shade! You can look in to the palace, but visitors are not allowed inside - you have to peer-in. The palaces are interesting, though after you see one or two, they begin to look very much the same. I would recommend choosing two to visit and then move on to something else.
A grand palace with impressive architecture. The palace ground is large and the trees give it a cool ambience. You can visit the museum, the traditional house and take lots of pictures.

review_title: Impressive palace grounds on a big scale
review_body: Gyeongbokgung Palace did not disappoint. There was a lot to admire and the size of the palace grounds was very impressive. There is also a shop within the grounds which had beautiful handicrafts and served amazing drinks.

With a beautiful backdrop of green mountains, the palace is an exquisitely restored (and partially reconstructed) monument. It's history, with successive destructions and recontructions, speaks to the resilience of the Korean people and is a testament to their coming of age as a unified people. The grounds offer a serene walk through compound after compound of simple and delicate architecture, decorated internally with vivid colors and patterns. I also highly recommend the museum!

While this is definitely nowhere as pretty or interesting as similar places in China and Japan, it's still a nice place and you should definitely visit as part of your trip to Seoul. Its a cultural attraction and it's important to learn about the history of the country

I suggest to visit this place with a free tour guide available there. We were approached by a student who volunteer to be our tour guide and we really grateful to had him in our group as we get to know more details about every single history of this place.

I visited Gyeongbokgung with a group of friends, it was beautiful weather in March, so I thought it would be very busy....but because the palace grounds are so expansive, even with a lot of visitors it is still quite serene and easy to find some peace and quiet. We didn't visit the museum that is within the grounds, but there was still plenty to fill in a number of hours. I would highly recommend this to anyone visiting Seoul. It's easily accessible and breathtakingly lovely.
It is one of the only realy cultural things you can do if you ask me so you have to visit it. But i wasnt that impressed, all the buildings looked the same. The pound is nice though.

We rented hanboks from OneDay Hanbok and it was pretty affordable. This grants you free entry and you get to take nice photos in the palace grounds. Many people will wear their hanboks there as well and you can take photos together in all your pretty outfits. Do note that if it's summer, youre probably going to sweat a whole lot.
very interesting palace of the kings + queens changing of the guards in full ceremonial clothes colourful site .
Mostly watched from outside, we were very impressed changing of the guard ceremony accompanied by a military-style drumming, Especially exemplary order and discipline.

review_title: The only palace you should see in Seoul
review_body: Such a nice place. Im so into historical sites so this is definitely my most favourite attraction in Seoul. The lake inside the palace looks serene and the breeze is so refreshing esp when you visit in summer. Be prepared to do a lot of walking and photos.Before Gyeongbokgung, I went to several palaces. The buildings kinda look the same. Only this palace has more things to see like the lake, the pavilion, the folk museum. They have the combination ticket ( 10000won for 5 palaces or so) but nvm if you dont have enough time to take a look at all 5 as i think gyeongbokgung is enough! In case you wanna have a nice photoshoot with hanbok, probably visit other palaces. They are not as crowded as this place so people will not ruin your perfect photos.
Very reasonable costs and regular changing of the guard. The gardens were good with lots of seating in the shade. Great views of the mountains

Rich in culture. Magnificent view. We could see many koreans (and non koreans) wearing traditional korean clothing. Informative and helpful guide. Guide was available at certain timings and in different languages. This is the most famous out of the other palaces.

Walkable from train station. Just before the stairs up from station you can get dressed in royal robes for free, was a fun activity. You can walk through the palace leisurely in your own pace. Good architecture in display, preserved well. You see lot of young couples walking around dressed in traditional costumes, lovely. Plenty of open park space inside. The food shop sells a cold rice sweet drink (non-alcoholic) that was tasty.
This is a great attraction and you can get a free guide that will make the tour much more enjoyable.

Must see when in Seoul! Unfortunately it was a sunny sunny day when we visited so husband got tired of walking in the sun and stayed hiding in café. I walked around and took many nice pictures. Amazing feeling to walk around in this peaceful getaway and imagine how it used to be. You have a lovely mountain view in background and other sides surrounded by modern buildings outside the walls.. Inside walls pure pleasure and there is a café inside, and near museum. Not adjusted to walk with stroller or wheelchair from what we could see. Easy to reach by sub and taxi. Recommend it!

This was a wonderful visit as it somewhat shows you how the Korean people used to live and you can imagine what day to day life was like back in those times. It takes you out of the city even though you are literally in the center. A must-visit when in Seoul. Do be aware, it can get very crowded during busy times.

review_title: One of the Most Touristy Place in Seoul
review_body: I went there with my family and we only walked into the front yard. We did not enter to the palace because we think there isn't much to see and they are not as nice as the Summer Palace in Beijing. However, if you are interested in these kind of places, you got to visit this Palace.
A good place to relax and enjoy the nature. Come to see how the korean royal lived in the past and the architect of korean palace. A place should visit when come to Seoul

review_title: Beautiful Find on a Rainy Day Surrounded by Tour Groups
review_body: I was walking down Samcheong-dong and found the entrance to the palace and decided to go in. It was pouring rain that day and really should've gone into the National Folk Museum but I wanted to see this palace and it would be closed the following day. The people were still there despite the rain! This palace was huge with so many grounds and so many buildings, I kept walking and walking and walking. I have to find my pics because my favorite area was this small lake with a small wooden octagon shaped building on an island in the middle. It was so beautiful and since I did not join a tour, unsure fully the history of it or what the purpose was. But, thought that would be a lovely place to go relax in if I had lived in that palace!
very beautiful palace, interesting historical building, nice to visit around spring.we came just in time for guard changing ceremony.
Huge, beautiful, grand, cheap to visit, very korean experience, next to metro, can spend 1.5-3 hours.
I enjoyed visiting the palace complex. It is worthwhile to time your visit to coincide with the changing of the guards. The re-enactment added a great depth to the tour.

review_title: Beautiful, Large and worth braving the heat for
review_body: The day we went it was sweltering, humid and hot...so it took away from the experience a bit but the Palace is truly awesome in it's size and beauty. It was a popular destination for groups of girls and young women to take shots of themselves in their full hanbok (traditional Korean dress) But they do have a small coffee shop where one can at least get a cool refreshing beverage. Lots of green space which is missing at most of the temples that sport the same beautiful architecture.

We especially enjoyed the architecture and the changing of the guard ceremony. When we visited (on a Sunday), there were so many people, that the photos we took were not as nice as the ones already posted. If we were to visit again, we would visit on a weekday when it most likely will be less crowded.If you benefited from this rating, please click the helpful button.
This beautiful palace was a beautiful trip through history The English speaking tour guide was great. We learned a lot and enjoyed our experience.

review_title: Great Palace with great history one of the faos place in korea
review_body: Good architecture of past korean building, there is free guide for every hour that will explained the for every building in this palace, in english.
This place and the changing of the guard is not to be missed. Choose a good sunny day to visit this spot. Feel the pulse of past korean History

The English tour is a must! the guide was so passionate about the topic and so informative. The palace its self is very breathtaking and has copious amounts of history behind it, a must when in Seoul!

Travelling to Seoul will never be complete without visiting this grandest palace. Going to Gyeongbokgung Palace is really very educative and enriching, indeed an eye opener to Korean culture especially in their way of life and government in the past.Every nook and corner of it is rich in history and breathtaking. However, be prepared to wear comfy shoes as you are expected to climb steep stairs.

The costumes are real, the place have a fresh paint job, a lot of history in the place. We went for an afternoon visit and was worth the walk. Everything is new and fresh. We were able to watch the changing of the guard which was colourful and energetic. Many tourists wearing traditional costumes added to the place and the realism. Go for a visit.
It should be for free because nothing special there except the guards ceremony ,but you can walk along to city stars surrounded by great buildings and ...

review_title: just a short visit but worth it.
review_body: I visited on a semi good day. the visit was short but good. Sadly it started to rain heavily when we visited the museum. It is a good cover when the reain really tears down.
This is a Main Palace at Seoul area. Very Big area, with many rooms and variety usefulness. We should go arround this palace for minimum 1-2 hour. Take Picture in several Big Building.

review_title: Reminded Me of Beijing's Forbidden City
review_body: We entered the palace through, I think, the Southern Gate and watched the changing of the guard ceremony. The grounds initially are pretty stark, though once we walked close to and past the palace, the grounds were filled with colorful flowers, gardens, trees and life. Worth seeing!

GyeongbokgungA must visit when you visit Seoul. To reach there, take Subway Line 3 to Gyeongbokgung Station and take exit 5. Simply follow the signs in the subway to the exit. Once you have exited, you will see the Palace Museum on the left and straight ahead will be entrance to the Palace. The palace opens 9am to 6pm and earlier during winter. Do check opening days and hours. You need to pay an entrance fee of 3000 won per adult. Free guided tours are available at the entrance at specific times. We managed to catch the Royal Guard-Changing Ceremony between Gwanghwamun Gate and Heungnyemun Gate. Do check the timing as it is interesting to watch the ceremony as the guards are dressed in traditional garbs. It is a great opportunity to experience a traditional scene in Korea, something that we probably only catch in Korean dramas.Bring your camera, your hat (and umbrella or poncho in case of rain) .The palace grounds are big with many residences, halls, pavilions and gardens so it might be wise to follow the free guided tour of the grounds. We were fortunate enough to follow the palace guide of a mandarin-speaking group which had just started. At least you get to learn about the history and the significance of each building instead of wandering around on your own looking at structures that do not tell any story. She also told us where were good photo spots.The Palace guide had such a comprehensive knowledge that I ended up learning so much! Be warned to pay attention as there were some who were wandering, talking on the phone and when the particular section were over, they asked her the same question of what she had already explained coz they clearly missed it doing their own thing. She doesn’t repeat if she know it is because you have not been paying attention and not due to non-comprehension!Unfortunately it was raining a bit when we were there. We would have loved to stay longer and wander a little more to take more photos. Do pop by the Museum before heading for the subway and send a post card home from the Museum shop (you can buy the postcard, stamp and even post it there).

There are quite many people visiting this palace as it is the largest one in the area. Some of the buildings have furniture in them so you can see from the door how the people used to live. I personally preferred the Changdeokgung palace as it has more trees and flowers in the palace area and is more peaceful. But why not visit both?
Join the free tour if possible. Detailed explanation. Don't miss the changing guard ceremony! It's a nice watch. Enjoyed the walk overall

What started as a hot and humid June day while we were visiting the palace, turned into a monster storm in no time that stranded us midway round this palace. After some 40 minutes of solid rain, we extricated ourselves at the expense of wading through deep puddles as we swung around the various buildings of historical interest. Be careful crossing the courtyards between buildings as we found the stone paths quite slippery on our way out. Viewing was restricted from outside looking in to dark halls and rooms, so it was a shame not to really be able to embrace everything our enthusiastic Korean guide was telling us about the palace history.Bound to be better on a dry day there.

The highlight of the visit was the flag changing ceremony with the soldiers wearing traditional Korean dress. The surrounding and palace is beautiful with lot of historically important details. It will take around 1 hour to see the palace fully...
It is a very beautiful place to visit. A must see in Seoul. Near the public transport. Multi language tours several times per day.

review_title: Peaceful and pretty if away from crowds
review_body: Most of the palace is packed with tour groups, but luckily it seems the tours only see certain parts of the palace. I was able to find a beautiful area where I was completely alone, and it was very peaceful to sit and think, or just admire the architecture.
A good place to visit at any time. Shop and cafe available. Interesting displays inside and attractive walks outside.

For what this is advertised to be, I must be honest and say I left feeling quite underwhelmed.Let's get one thing clear: The palace grounds are beautiful. No denying that. But as I was looking for a more informative destination, this wasn't the place for me.Sure, there are english tours, but few and far between. And there is an app that provides an audio guide, but the initial app had me downloading another app, which then asked me to download another service, at which point I gave up.I personally found the Korean Folk museum on the other end of the palace MUCH more interesting and informative (and it's free).And even for nature folk: Changdeokgung Palace seems to be the better option than this.
Very beautiful place & lots of place to take picture. But it closed at 6pm.Ticket fee for adult 3000/personVery recommended for tourist when visit seoul

review_title: Get in Free with Hanbok! Good place for photoshoot!
review_body: This is a very big place, we spent 3-4 hours there and it was a lovely long walk. If you're wearing hanbok (Korean outfits), you can just go to ticket office and get the tickets for free.

I was informed that there are 5 most famous palaces in Korea and Gyeongbukgong Palace is one of them. Located in the middle of Seoul, it is definitely easily reachable by the subway. The entrance fee was really cheap and you can enter for free if you wear the Korean's traditional clothes called Hanbok. It was definitely worth a visit to the palace.

Went to Gyeongbokgung Palace the very first day of my trip. It is very beautiful and large cultural spot. There are a lot of nice places in the Palace to photograph. Really liked walking in Gyeongbokgung.

review_title: Make sure you are there for the changing of the guard
review_body: Everyone says that because it's true. Go for the long version and get there early enough to get a front-row stance. The music, the pageant, the colorful uniforms are a real visual and auditory treat. The rest of the palace is very interesting and clean, neat and tidy. I have visited way too many Asian palaces, shrines, temples and Buddhas and so I can't be trusted to do it justice.

We visited the place at the end of May and it was a little hot and sunny but it was a beautiful place to visit and take photos. You see young girls and guys dressed in hanbok taking photos around the palace which adds a nice touch to the place and the gift shop is also a nice place to visit but it could be a little on the expensive side.

This is our very first place to visit in Seoul. It was really nice to walk around in the palace and there were also other museums nearby the palace such as the Children Museum.Free admission fro the Children Museum.Children can watch the Korean animation of the folklore story of Moon and Sun.This is one of the museums located inside the Gyeongbokgung Palace.But you have to pay for the entrance fees at Gyeongbokgung, the rest of the museums inside are with free admission.

review_title: The number one tourist spot in Seoul.
review_body: The largest royal palace in Seoul. Built in 1395 (Joseon Dynasty), when Korea was largely influenced by Chinese culture. It is a beautiful palace. The architecture and layout resembles the Forbidden City in Beijing. But in a smaller scale.One of the most famous spectacles is the Royal Guard Changing Ceremonies. The performance takes place in front of the main gate at 10 a.m. and 2 p.m.A must visit in Seoul.

Gyeongbokgung Palace is a nice and big enough cultural area to explore and photographed. Rent 24 hours package of hanbok and wear it when u come to this palace. It is placed in one area with Bukchon Village and only few steps away in front of Insa-dong market.

The Gyeongbokgung Palace was the first place we went to. If you're a tourist, this is definitely a must go. Correct me if I'm wrong, but I believe that the K-drama "Princess Hours" was shot at the Gyeongbokgung Palace. You'll see the "changing of guards".

It's beautiful palace, nice garden, we have learned lots of history. It has been took by China before. They had build the dragon inside to believe that China never got the Korea before. It's beautiful garden, lake and surrounding. It's totally the center, it's not far away from the Mydeong distric by train 15 mins.

This old palace and the gates are very impressive (built late 1300s) and it is absolutely amazing that the admission is only about $1USD. The palace grounds are quite extensive, so you can easily spend a few hours here if you want to see it all, or just a short time if you only want to walk through the gates and up to the palace.I recommend good walking shoes as the paving stones are a bit uneven in places, and bring water and a hat, as the grounds are quite open with lots of sun.

Went to Korea for a Rotary International Convention in 2016. Took an extension tour after and this palace was included on the tour. Fascinating place. The water you see in the cover picture would freeze in the winter and the locals used to ice skate on it!

If you are a huge fan of Korean historical drama, there's no better place than this one where you can enjoy every little details about Korea's past. Try rent a Hanbok, a traditional costume, so you can enter the palace for free! Guide book and audio guide are available for purchase and rent. Free guide tour is also available.

It is really amazing place. Very cheap too (only 3.000 won and you get a free tour of 1:30h). The place is huge so wear confortable clothes and shoes. If you are coming in a sunny day do not forget to wear sunscreen and caps because except for the gardens, there are not much shadow or trees to hide from the sun. You will probably spend more than 2 hours walking. You can also rent an audio tour if you do not want to wait for the next free tour. Beautiful buildings and story of Joseun Dinasty.

review_title: Past, Present & Future glory at display here.
review_body: This is the first Royal palace built in the Joeson Dynasty 500 years ago. The is largest of the five grand palaces remaining in Seoul. It provides a glimpse into Joeson's Royal culture and architecture. Great place to go back in time and know Korean history and how they evolved over the years to a modern county while deeply rooted with their traditions too. You can take pics with girls dressed in traditional Korean dresses too. Best time to visit is around 4pm as after you can enjoy the evening in Gwanghwamun Square.Admission is 3000 won.
Large palace to explore. Very nice to walk around and admire the structures and the ground. You can spend hours here.

review_title: This tour is touted as free but it's really a $3 entrance fee and the tour is free.
review_body: These grounds have over 50 buildings, but you only get detail of about 10-12 during this tour, which is more than enough. It took about 70min to see the buildings we did. Lots of detail and interesting history.
Make sure you have time,It takes about a two hours to see the whole thing. It is worth it though! Must go. Go to the museum prior to your entrance too!

Gyeongbokgung palace it is good tourists attraction in Seoul because it is the largest palace built by Jason dynasty. The royal family who ruled Korea kingdom in 1392.I don't recommend to stay long time because the heat of summers. The best activities is the ceremony of change the guard who wears historic dressed.

We went on the last Wednesday of the month which was designated as a culture day, so the entrance to the palace was free. We grabbed a guidebook for KRW500 from the ticket counter as soon as we entered. There're various pavilions, halls and gates in this huge palace compound, so plan your route and time accordingly so that you can maximize the time.We managed to view the Hyangwonjeong Pavilion with its reflection in the pond. However, this reflection disappeared over time. If you wish to snap a picture with the reflection, it is best to head to this pavilion as soon as you enter the palace ground early in the morning. Do check out the schedule of the changing of the guard ceremony. This is a must watch if you've not watched it in Deoksugung. The paint of the the buildings looks new and well maintained. Exploring this huge area brings you back to a different era. It is rich in history so it'll be good to do some reading before visiting. The landscape should offer different kinds of beauty in different seasons.Spend at least half a day because there are 2 museums here. If you plan to tour a little more in depth, you might need a full day. We did not visit the museums since we continued our visit to Cheongwadae (Blue House) in the afternoon.

First of all, this place should be called 'Gyeongbokgung' not 'Gyeongbokgung Palace'. 'gung' means palace in Korea. I think that Gyeongbokgung is must-see place if someone never had an experience to visit. It's a full package of Korean traditional culture. The palace is beautifully designed and technically built. If you can borrow audio service device, try one. You won't regret it. It's much more interesting when you know the background.  Its admission fee is reasonable like KRW 3000(= USD $2), but it's free if you wear Korean traditional custom. There are many rental shop near the palace. Don't miss it.  There are few shade to hide from sun outside. If it's hot outside, visit this place some other time.

Gyeongbokgung Palace is a must go in Seoul. It's one of the main palace. The grounds are beautifully kept and the buildings are characteristic. Try to join the guided tour and spend time appreciating the settings, history and culture of Korean.

It must be have a lot of history here. So large, amazing and hot weather this month. But its amazing to come here. See a king palace. See some girl and boy use a traditional korean clothes. Good, must visit place in seoul

Although each palace has unique features this was by far my favorite palace in Seoul. The architecture is wonderful and being able to see the Blue House was neat. It will take a long time to explore, so make sure to take your time.

The place is so extensive. When you step foot on the grounds, it immediately transports you to a different era. The area is full of ancient looking buildings and a lots of history and stories embedded in the architecture. The highlight for me was the beautiful pond within the vicinity which was covered in lotus plants! There is also a free museum within the compound which apart from its historical value, also is fully air conditioned and comes with a cafe. A great place to take breather.

I highly recommend booking a hanbok rental around the area (about 25-30usd for whole day) before coming here and entrance will be free. I believe they provide tours but I went on my own so I could take my time. This is a great palace to come if you have time to spare. I had a wonderful time and my pictures looked lovely with the palace back ground.
This Palace is huge, might want to allow yourself enough time to wonder around and see everything it has to offer.
gyeongbokbong Palace is a nice place to have a day long excursion. You can easily access it by subway. There are many great restaurants nearby. The kids will enjoy this place!

You have to arrive about 15 minutes before 10 am to get a good place to see the changing of the guards. It is worth the shirt wait before entering tha grounds which are nicely kept. The place was rebuilt in the 90's so it does not have the same character as the other palaces. The gardens are worth the visit with great opportunities for photos with the family.

review_title: Worth to have a look at
review_body: Visited the palace and it is a nice area to walk around and see the korean style buildings and parks. Relaxing enviroment in the middle of a buzy city.

review_title: A Majestic Palace of Grandeur & Immensity
review_body: A fine display of Korean history. Huge complex of ancient relics preserved nicely. Two relevant museums are there just next to it. But the facility is not wheel chair friendly.

To truly appreciate the Korean people and their history a visit to the Gyeonbokgung Palace is essential. It is a huge site easily accessible by the Seoul Metro. There is a very nominal entry fee equivalent to about $3 that goes towards restoration and upkeep. Seniors are free.There is a free English guided tour that commences at 10 am and well is worth it.The palace is really a group of several separate residences and gives a feel for life in the Chosun Dynasty.Many sections have been restored and it lacks the opulence of other palaces, but does depict the reality of life in a bygone era, at very beautiful location in Seoul.

Visited in June with my family as part of a land excursion off a cruise ship. The tour essentially showed the important buildings in the grounds and the museum. This cannot be done in an hour but would need around three hours minimum. Although there is great historical significance on the site, the attraction is just a series of ancient buildings, clean, tidy and well sign posted. The museum is excellent but you will need time to enjoy all the exhibitions. My children were bored with the experience. This is an adult attraction.

review_title: Very Touristy. Here for the changing guard ceremony
review_body: I personally prefer visiting other palaces as Gyeongbokgung can get very crowded and very touristy. Huge area, free tour guide available (u can make reservation frm their official website). Spare at least 2-3hr if u wanna cover all areas thoroughly. ChangingGuard ceremony musnt be missed. Hanbok rental available just in front of the palace entrance. Wearing hanbok lets u enter palaces (this one n others) forFREE ! :-)

This place is huge and you must expect to spend 4 to 5 hours appreciating the historical significance of the place. Take your time and walk leisurely at your own pace. There are English speaking guides available if you want a fast pace around the area. There are many restrooms available.
One of the must visit place when you are in Seoul. In this place you will learn the korean culture. Never miss the Guards changing ceremony when you visit.

rainy gloomy day which took away the colours of the photos, but not the grandeur of the place. Majestic and pretty, it was really a fulfilling of real life witnessing of drama scenes.Joined the free guided tour and it was an informative 1.5hours.IMHO, better changdeokgung

This tour is absolutely nice !!! We loved everything, especially the greated tour options. Thanks for all of your good suggestions. I also appreciate your guiding me as I really appreciate Seoul and Korean culture so much now! Thank you for everything.

There are few exhibits but the size, grandeur and history is apparent over the extensive grounds. The buildings are a mix of old and many authentic reconstructions, as apparently Japanese colonial occupiers burnt them down several times of the millenia. Definitely worth a visit and English-speaking yours are free.

This is my favorite site in Seoul. It is the largest palace and grounds, with many buildings. 1. Do watch the changing of the guards at the front gate. It happens in the entry courtyard so you don't need to buy tickets to see it. They say it is done hourly, but I read elsewhere they do larger "shows" at 10 am and 2pm. We saw the 10am and it was very cool. They explain things in Korean, so we missed some of what was going on. However they did have some explanations in English. I could understand how they checked the new guards credentials, handed over the keys, etc.2. Do the tour. Most of the buildings do not have furniture, so you are mostly looking at the outside and seeing the interiors from the outside. The tour really added to understanding the palace, it's history, how it was used and its significance to the Korean people. It is only 1 hour long, and worth it. Plus, it's free! English tours at 11am 1:30 and 3:30.3 I recommend getting there for the 10am changing of the guards and then doing the 11 tour. It is likely to be a bit cooler and maybe less crowded. 4. At the back of the grounds are the buildings where Queen Min was murdered by Japanese assassins in 1895. These buildings are not brightly colored like the others and I could feel the sadness King Gojung must have felt. 5. Also at the back you can catch a glimpse of the Blue House compound, the home of Korea's President.

review_title: Beautiful for Photos, Vital for Learning History and Culture
review_body: Visually, this is an overwhelming experience because of the sheer size and variety of structures and landscapes. Some of them make for some of the best photo ops in Asia. There are also museums on the ground. But what I think is most rewarding -- and important -- is the history that you can learn and the perspective you can gain. As an American who has lived in Asia since 2004, I find the ignorance of my fellow countrymen about the world -- especially Asia -- to be embarrassing. The story of this place takes you through the history of Asia from a Korean perspective: subject first to China, then the various brutal invasions by Japan. Koreans feel an enormous sense of pride in their culture and their strength. As a tiny country surrounded by giants, you really appreciate both when you visit here. Take your time when you come.
A nice place to visit, large open area with historical architect and palaces, don't miss the guards shift change at the front gate.. I think its in each one or two hours..

I was almost expecting a life changing experience because of all the ratings. It was ok. We saw the changing of the guards and walked inside the palace... Meh. It looked like many of the other palaces we've seen in Korea. If this was there first one we had seen, maybe I would be more enthused. We also walked into the museum and ate at the cafe. The food was great and reasonably priced.

I would recommend entering at the front gate during the changing of the guards. I can't remember exact time it happens. But was a great experience to see the whole ceremony. Once inside, there is so much to see. So be prepared to walk a lot and take lots of pictures. Really beautiful palace.

This is a popular destination especially on weekends. Would try and go on a weekday to avoid larger crowds or early morning. There is English guided tour at 11am which usually attracts a crowd but is worth it to get an overview of the highlights.There's a peaceful tea shop in the back corner behind the lake. Also the museum cafe has nice teas and deserts and a nice ambience.Changing of the guard at 1pm and larger performance at 2pm but don't disrupt your day for this.The folk museum has lots to see but is s bit repetitious after visiting the national museum.Metro drops you right at the front on the orange line. Seniors over 65 are free.
Loved all the people in traditional dress & watching the changing of the guard. Maybe the gardens are beautiful in spring, but not so well attended in June. Does anyone pick the apricots?.

review_title: The Great Place Of Korea Land
review_body: If You Got Koren Land already; You Must To Go This Place For Pray To The King Of Korea for Pray for Good ucky In korea Alive !

One of the important places in Seoul must be visited .. too much big and too much beautiful .. you feel there you are one of the old Korean people .. full of history .. I like it and want to visit again

A very beautiful and big palace. We spent one whole morning walking around the palace and taking photographs. We were not able to cover the whole area. There is also a museum there but we did not go in. We also saw the guards changing ceremony.This place can be reach by taking the subway to Angguk.
Its a nice and big palace. Needs time to visit. Completely korean culture show.ok-ok place. Enviourment is Nice

Go early so you will enjoy the guided tour in a smaller group. The place would get crowded at a later time. Spend at least 3 hours or up to half a day there to tour around the palace, the National Museum (near the palace entry) and also the Folk Museum inside the palace. Consider getting an integrated ticket for foreigners at krw10,000 to access other palaces and Jongmyo Shrine as well, which certainly save u some entry fee if you are planning to visit most of them.

This is a beautiful palace which you must visit at least once when in Seoul. Do watch out for the guard changing ceremonies and free guided tours. Worth the trip to understand the history of the palace. Palace is also very near to Bukchon Village area and the famous Tosokchon chicken soup restaurant (same station). Must visit.

We are in Seoul for a conference but whenever we travel we love to do museums/palaces/temples. This was wonderful - calm, beautiful, historic. It seemingly goes on forever but definitely as a respite in the chaos of city life in Seoul!

review_title: Its like you walked into a old school Korean dynasty
review_body: Live in person. Its stands at the end of the square over looking all this modern Seoul and its a site that cannot be missed. I went with a guide and he told me more details I wouldn't have known otherwise. Just watch out for the busloads of tourists who don't care that you would like a picture with the giant drum too.

The palace complex is huge, with a myriad of buildings and acres of grounds to explore. Firstly don't make the rookie mistake we did - visiting on a Tuesday, when the palace is closed! On returning on Wednesday we were pleasantly surprised to be told that entry on that day was free (not sure that this applies to every Wednesday). In fact, anyone wearing traditional dress gains free entry, but tickets are not expensive at 3000krwon per person over 18, with a small discount for children and teenagers. This is a restoration / reconstruction project on a massive scale, which is being done sensitively and artistically. Photo opportunities abound, particularly changing the guard and the traditional tea ceremony and, of course, the people (mostly very pretty young ladies) wearing traditional Hanok dress, who are only too happy to pose. There is a sparsity of shade, so do take this slowly in the heat. There are cafes and toilets around, but a few bottles of water per person is a must as the heat and humidity can become overwhelming. Allow two to three hours and do try to make your way to the back of the complex, where there are ornamental lakes with pagoda.

review_title: If you have time to see just one palace, I'd recommend this one.
review_body: OK, where to start. Allow min half day or more. Come bright and early for the changing of the guards ceremony. Bring plenty of food and water, don't forget to charge your camera and good shoes. Not much refreshments available on the premises so come prepared. If you want to wear a hanbok dress, there are plenty of shops where you can hire them for 1.5hrs - 2 hrs outside the palace. I believe the prices start on 15000 KWR for 1.5hrs. It's a great opportunity to take your pictures in this wonderful setting and "IN style" throughout the complex. Definitely worth a visit is also the Folklore Museum with its wonderful restorations of Korean past. The Korean Folklore village's reconstruction is very illustrative and worth a visit for every foreigner. The museum is within a complex and the entry is free. If you need to wind down, there is a small garden towards the north of the complext where you can e.g. let the kids to let some steam out. It's very tranquil there and with offers lovely views. Free 1hr long guided tours are offered on the hour at the entrance. We left the palace by one of the side entrances and enjoyed a well deserved meal in a small restaurant in Bukchon. Great day out.

review_title: Must see on this trip. Don't miss the changing of the guards!
review_body: Make sure to get a tour guide to take you through this amazing Palace. You get so much more out of exploring this sprawling complex with someone giving you context. The changing of the guard is colorful and filled with drums and music. Very cool.

It was easy to get to by metro to gyeongbokgung station, and was a pretty good place to spend an hour or two. It's actually really big and I'm not sure if we managed to see the whole place as we weren't given any maps, but the buildings were pretty repetitive after a while. It's probably a good idea to go in hanbok (that you can rent in lots of shops in the area) so you get in for free (although it's pretty cheap anyways), and take cool photos. We went during midday in summer so that wasn't really an option, but in milder weather I definitely would have done that.

Great to check out the changing of Guards before entering the palace. Entrance fees are very economical at 3000 won for adult. If the main palace is too crowded , it would also be interesting to move to the side palaces or gardens. You could witness the kitchen where servants cook or royals have their meals. Gardens and lakes are so beautiful. The entrance fees also entitle you to enter the folks museum which is worth a trip as well ! Overall, we spent about 3 very enjoyable hours here just strolling on the grounds. Highly recommended !
Beautiful palace of the Emperor, there's a free guide that will take you around in 2 different times of the day, very interesting!
Enjoyable visited to Gyeongbokgung Palace, one of famous tourist spot to go if you are planning to going to Seoul.

Nice Heritage Site. The Changing of the Guard Ceremony is worth a trip. Watching the young Koreans in their traditional clothing (they can enter for free if they are dressed traditionally) was interesting.

review_title: Remind me of Kim Soo Hyun
review_body: This palace reminded me of The Moon Embraces The Sun! The water is so calm that the reflection of the palace looks stunning in the water! I like that the back gate is accessible to the Blue House.

review_title: Same structures over and over and over
review_body: Yes, it is big, and yes, it is quite impressive at first sight, but that is about it. As you go in all you'll see are the same structures over and over again along walls that are the same. The place is HUGE so you will walk for hours seeing the same thing. Another thing I don't like about the palace is that everything has been repainted so the whole place looked too new, and that is not what I want to see in a historically significant place. There are also wire nets fitted on the under side of the roofs (presumably to prevent birds from nesting and ruining the new paint job?) and that, again, ruined the otherwise beautiful structure. I didn't even want to take pictures because of the ugly nets and brightly coloured paints. In my opinion, Namsangol Hanok Village was a much better place to spend your time. Just go to Gyeongbokgung Palace for their mid-day ceremony (takes about 20 minutes), take some pictures on the outside (which is similar to what is on the inside anyway) and go somewhere else. Yes, the admission fee is cheap but the time you are going to waste isn't.

Very easy to find from several metro stations, and at only £/$ a ticket it's incredible value for money.You can also get a small guide book for pennies which is a good help as you walk around. Can easily spend a few hours there or blast around in an hour without stopping in the museums (Palace museum being the more interesting and informative).Only real criticism (and not the Koreans fault really) but as it was torn down by the Japanese during the occupation, it's only been recently restored (started in 2001) and so there's a lot of concrete in places where there would not have been hundreds of years ago.However, despite this, beautiful gardens and a worthwhile way to spend a morning/afternoon!
This is a huge palace, and worth a visit. But it is very popular by many tourists, so be prepared for a crowd.

review_title: Combine this with the surrounding sights
review_body: I had literally just been to the Forbidden City in Beijing so this did feel a bit small. It's beautiful and worth visiting along with the Folk Museum which is on the same sight. From here you can also walk to nearby Buk Chon village. If you combine all these activities then I'd rate this five star. If you're keen on trying traditional Korean cultural dress you can hire costumes near to the palace - then wear your costume and get free entry. You'll also get lots of tourists asking to have photos with you.

review_title: Massively sprawling network of beautiful buildings and landscapes
review_body: Amazing positioned just a few minutes walk from City Center, this Palace is amazing. There are so many different structures that you need to allow a few hours minimum to see it all. We went on a Saturday and there were many people dressed in traditional period clothing (albeit with Nikes and Adidas for footwear :) ) which allowed for some fun photographs in black n white. The colors and fluidity of the outfits added to the timelessness of the grounds. Being Saturday, it was indeed crowded but not overwhelmingly so as the Palace grounds are just soo big. There are nice places to sit and relax and enjoy the surroundings. We were able to find a quiet spot without any modern skyline visible. The feeling was tranquil and powerful at the same time. There is also a nice museum just outside the main entrance that was very good to0.

review_title: Best spot for Korean dramas' No.1 fan!
review_body: If you are a big fan of Korean dramas (especially if you've watched "Rooftop Prince") you might come and visit this gigantic palace! Come to the place earlier in the morning or around 2p.m. then you might be able to watch the soldiers changing their duty. If you are luck, you might get to see some performance through out the day! Remember, Tuesday is closed and the admission fee is $3000 won/person.

review_title: Tradition and modernity next to each other
review_body: is is excellent that middle in a modern city, suddenly you reach a part of tradition in best condition . when ever you have a travel to Seoul, donot miss this place

review_title: Impressive palace in the center of Seoul
review_body: I'm not a big palace visitor, I need to be dragged along most of the time, but Gyeongbokgung is really worth a visit, and if it's just to take a stroll in its vast gardens at the back. Many people take the free tour, we opted to just read what was in the brochure and on the signs. A lot of Koreans visit this site dressed in costumes of the era, which makes it a really more authentic and colorful experience. Worth taking a morning or afternoon of your time in Seoul to explore.

We visited without a tour guide. I would recommend getting one to help explain what you are seeing. Get ready to do some walking. The grounds are mainly covered with course sand. The National Palace Museum is nearby withing the grounds and a good place to cool off on a hot humid day and get a drink. Beautifully restored structures are well worth the time.
Beautiful palace, a must-see in Seoul!You can rent a traditional hanbok near the entrance, which many tourists do to take pictures.
The palace is a very well organized and it is close to the museum. We can visit the real Korean's traditional performance there.

review_title: A palace in the heart of Seoul
review_body: I visited four palaces in Seoul and this was the best one to visit. It was the largest one and our guide was friendly and very good in explaining things. The great thing about the palaces in Seoul is that they have tours in Korean, Mandarin, English and Japanese. If you go early, you can watch the changing of the guard ceremony and even take pictures with them. In addition to the palace, the National Palace Museum of Korea and the National Folk Museum of Korea are conveniently close and free (you can't beat that!). Even the Blue House where the President of South Korea lives is within walking distance but I didn't go there. The Gyeongbokgung subway station is by the palace but it's also within walking distance from Anguk and Gwanghwamun Stations.
It's big so be ready to walk. You can tell the palace was renovated...probably due to the war. But still very beautiful and serene. It's a MUST SEE if you're in Seoul!
My family and I highly enjoyed this palace. My 9 year old son thought it was very fun and educational, and we all enjoyed the attached museum. It had beautiful grounds and we learned a lot!

You could spend all day here but we took about 2hrs to scroll through. We took lots of pics and listened in to a couple tours but we didn't take one. It cost less than $3 to enter per adult. Not good for a rainy day as everything is outside but you can see inside through windows and doors.
Th building is beautiful and has a lot of history - not very much liked by the Japanese because of the way they treated the koreans in the past.

had a wonderful 4-5 hours here and joined the free English Speaking Guided Tour. Our guide was great, good clear diction, a sense of humour and history information which was important. Tour can be booked inside Main Wall and is free for Seniors

ive been a fan of korean drama but seeing the palaces brings happiness to me. though not a magnificent as i previously pictured in my brain but it is so spacious. the pavilions were intricately designed. how i wish i lived in thosekind of era. Nice seeing tourists wearing national costumes and have their photos taken

I visited this place on May at 1PM and it was very hot outside. You can take picture with the palace guard but please be careful not to disturb or touch him or they could be mad. This palace consists of many buildings inside. Make sure your feet are ok and your stomach is full before coming here bacuse this palace is soo biiigg. I got very tired eventhough i were not explore all of the buildings inside.

A little disappointing as we expected majestic architecture and beautiful gardens since it was the touted as the most beautiful of all the 5 palaces. We gave the other palaces a miss because of this reason. It took us less than an hour to view the grounds that were opened to public. The guards at the front entrance were however very obliging so we have some good memorable shots.
As seen in the korean movies: nice place to visit, to see korean culture and tradition. A lot of korean pines around.

review_title: Stunningly beautiful...just like all the major Palaces in Seoul!
review_body: You can't go to Seoul without taking in the historic atmosphere with relaxed strolls around Seoul's Palaces!
Wonderful day not a fan of guided tours but this is a place that needs to be explained a must see 'Holiday Tours and Travel Korea' run an excellent tour and thanks to David for his guidance

review_title: A quick stop is all you need
review_body: Come see the guard change, stay to walk around the palace. We had a hard time finding a tour but it was good for a quick (< 1 hour) visit.

review_title: If you see just one attraction in Seoul you should see this
review_body: I had just a couple of hours at the end of a business trip and ended up here by serendipity. For a mere $1 above the price of the $3 basic entry to Changdeokgung Palace, it combined a lovely walk in the park, the historically interesting palace and the beautiful wildflower garden. I did not have time to explore the palace closely or to even enter the Great Greenhouse so I hope I get a chance to go back.

An interesting recreation of the palace. It would have been better if more of the original structure still existed. As it stands, it is still a decent place to visit. You can sometimes see traditional costumes and ceremonies.
Not much to say since we didnt go into the Details. Nice place to take some photos. Everything was clean and the place itself was worth seing.

review_title: changing of guards is a must see
review_body: get there early. Seniors are free! lovely grounds and palaces are beautiful. MUst see the colorful changing of guards. YOu are allowed to take pics with the guards at the front gate .

Time your visit well to see the terrific change of guards ceremony, and the guided tour. Our tour guide was very informative and it was great to get to know more about the history of the lovely palace.
Amazing place, the architecture, granduer, history.English is on each explanation board.Enjoyed myself, i am a History buff.

Interesting attraction, with a lots of locals visiting the place, wearing the traditional clothings. The place was huge and need to walk quite abit. Beautiful place to take photos with the flowers in the background.

review_title: Must visit this beautiful historic place
review_body: One of the major attraction in Seoul. Probably not as big as China's Gu Gong Palace but since you're in seoul, why not.Most impressive is probably at the front as you enter from the main Gate. As you walk further in, palace gets smaller and more smaller living quarters and they are all look similar. Entry fee is very reasonable ($3,000 WON) and it's pretty easy to get to via subway station. Overall it was a good experience to see the real thing compare to korean drama on TV. :)

The palaces, quarters, ponds and gardens are beautiful. And it's interesting to learn the parallel historical timelines. While the Renaissance started in Florence, Italy in 1350, Gyeongbokgung Palace was built in 1395 during the Joseon Dynasty.

Beautiful site and visit! We took the english tour. We loved our visit. Take all the time necessary to do a complete visit of the site and the gardens and as well make sure not to miss the changing of the guard show. We took such beautiful pictures and made memories we will forever cherish. A must see during your visit to Seoul!
We liked it quite much. Beautiful place, worth the visit. It closes at 5pm we were there at 4pm, still enough time to wander around :)

We stumbled upon the palace while wandering around Seoul. It was a great experience, we got to see a traditional Korean performance and wander around the grounds. We saw a lot of museum static displays and a ton of art.

Just check the time of free guided tours and guard changing ceremonies before you reach the palace. With the guided tour it was quite lovely. View is nice, the palaces are similar to Chinese architecture but a bit different as they are based on Confucius' teachings.

I highly recommend a visit in this palace and join the tour with your language.Our tour guide was truly wonderful because she was able to explain to us well about the history of every corners of the palace, her sense of humor was a bonus because we never had a boring moment especially talking about history.A fantastic experience with the tour.
Nice palace to walk around on a sunny day. Just by the blue house. Take your time and just wander and then check out the neighborhoods nearby for cool trinkets
We were fortunate to arrive just before the changing of the guard so there were no crowds. It was avery colourful event and fun to watch as it was also fairly short.

The site, the palace structures and the gardens were beautiful. However, I would say there wasn't much to see. Most of the palace housings were locked and those that were open had few or no exhibits within. Going free and easy without a guide will not give you much insight into the Korean traditions or palace life. However, if you wear a hanbok to the palace, you will be granted free entry. There is a hanbok rental a few minutes walk from the train station. If the weather permits, wearing a hanbok would be a really good idea as you can be assured that your pictures will turn out fabulous. There is no need to feel embarassed as well as many visitors do that :)

visited this palace during our recent trip to seoul. we watched the change of guards ceremony which is scheduled on every hour. after which, we had fun wearing the general / commander / guards costumes for photo taking etc - this is FOC. all these activities are at the outer court only.if you want to visit the inner court, you need to pay the entrance fees.
Truly a wonderful place, it was a step back in Korea's past but I would advise you to visit early as you will encounter thousands of local school trips.

review_title: Guard exchange ceremony is worth gg for
review_body: Palace is really well maintained... had a nice lovely walk through the palace. Caught the guard exchange ceremony which should not be missed.

review_title: Nice to visit, beautiful contrast between old and new.
