review_body: Nice palace, lots to walk around, very nice gardens, easy to reach, and very nice to see young Koreans there visiting on their weekend and wearing their beautiful traditional cloths. Recommended to visit.

review_title: Definitely go with a tour guide, the information made the difference
review_body: We. I sited the palace in Dec 2015 and again in June 2016. Our June trip was with an English speaking tour guide which made a huge impact on our enjoyment of the tour.
Enjoyed watching the historical changing of the guard and the fastidious work that has gone into developing the Palace.
The Koreans have worked hard to rebuild this culturally significant complex of buildings after the destruction of the 20th Century. Its a kind of forbidden city on a smaller scale.
The free show showcasing the ancient guard changing ceremony is worth visiting. It is near the Metro station, we strolled by another 150m near this palace for the Gingsen Chicken Rice.

review_title: Locals add color to fascinating palace grounds
review_body: Don't know if they are always there, or if it was a special occasion, but the palace grounds were crawling with locals dressed in traditional Korean attire. It made visiting each house on the grounds more authentic. The grounds are massive, so give yourself a few hours, and there is a political museum on site that we barely peaked at since we arrived to close to closing time.Take your camera!

Once a complex of 500 buildings destroyed by the Japanese, and though not as large as the Forbidden City in Beijing, Gyeongbokgung reconstructed still manages to awe visitors. It is full of Koreans and tourists in traditional Korean Hanbok dress (free entry!).Be sure to come for the Changing of the Guard ceremony at 1000 hrs and 1400 hrs because even the guards are in ancient costume. There are other ceremonial performances, the times of which can be found at the Visit Korea website.There are free tours in different languages, and two museums attached to the palace complex. We went for a tour in English (only 3 a day) and it was most informative and helpful. Our guide explained the underfloor heating, the tiered Queen's garden and showed us where Japanese assassins murdered Empress Myeongseong in 1895 and burned her body. I was quite shocked to learn of this barbaric act. But that's the thing about this palace - it immerses you in Korean history.Write in for permission in advance if you want to visit the banquet pavillion, which is otherwise closed to visitors.

review_title: Must be first on your list
review_body: Start off your trip in Seoul with a visit to this palace. While it was summer for locals, weather was still pretty good for us. Reco to rent Hanboks (traditional Korean wear) so that you'll have free entrance to this place.

A very nice place for people who are interested in the history of Koreas monarchy.The place offers beautiful temples and quite a bit of beautiful nature, in form of secret garden for example.All in all a place to visit when you want to learn a little bit of Koreas history

review_title: A huge palace but very beautiful
review_body: We could have spent a lot more time here, especially with the Folk Museum attached. The weather for us during our visit was very hot, so we looked around and took pictures and appreciated the beautiful buildings.

review_title: One of the main sights of Seoul
review_body: Visiting the palace as part of an organised tour and quite enjoyed it. To fully take in the place suggest 2-4 hours.
Very accessible and near a city station, The palace is a great place to immerse yourself in Korean culture and architecture. :)

One of the few major monuments open on a Monday, which coincided with my first day in town. It is a relatively large site, with extensive gardens as you move through. Exit on the north end to catch great views of the presidential complex and you can soak in the government district on your walk back to the metro.

I took a subway to this palace and the train system in Seoul is very convenient as the instruction and announcement is in English, Mandarin and Korean. Even the ticket vending machine is on 3 languages so it's pretty easy to get around and you won't get lost. Ok I really enjoyed the beautiful scenery at Gyeongbakgung but it was freezing cold in Dec. There are English and Mandarin guided tour around the palace at certain time. It's pretty interesting to learn about the culture and some ancient beliefs.For people who can't tolerate with extremely cold weather, I would advise you not to visit the palace during winter. Strong wind and the cold could dampen your spirit to walk and explore further
They are not really set up for tourism just yet, but if you are visiting South Korea, make the effort to visit ALL the cultural sites; you will be gob-struck at the history. Just stunning!

Before we went to the palace, we found out that if you wear the traditional costumes you will be able to enter for free so we rented our Hanbok from a nearby shop. The rental fee was about 30,000 won and we can return to them by 5pm. What a fun experience wearing Hanbok and walking around the palace and taking photographs. The palace was a really beautiful place and I am sure it will be better if you follow the guided tour. It is quite a big place and can get quite crowded from early morning to afternoon so be sure to go eariler and please put on sunblock and bring your umbrella along, most part of the pathway are not sheltered. Keep in mind that there is only 1 cafe inside the palace so you may want to bring some food and drinks along while walking around.

The buildings are nicely maintained. The place is spacious with trees around. A lot of chairs for people to take a rest when visiting. Yet the side gate bear Gyeongbokgung Station does not allow exit so we have to walk back all the way the the front gate to get to that area, which is a bit inconvenient.

review_title: Caught the changing of the Guard
review_body: Large Temple set in the center of Seoul, small fee to enter, is somewhat accessible for people with physical disabilities
Beautiful, historic palace and grounds in the middle of the city. I was surprised at just how big the property is. Plan on spending at least a few hours
Nice Walk, and photogenic! Be sure you go with a guide, so you will receive very important information.

The visit at night is very different from day time. There's no guided tour and no guards-changing ceremony at night but it gives you a feeling of tranquility. Besides some buildings being lit, there was also a play with various lighting effects and musicians playing live music. We spent nearly 2 hours there.The place opens at night on dates 29/4-1/6, 16/7-19/8, 24/9-28/10 and between 7 and 10pm.The 3,000 won entrance fee would be waived if you go in traditional Korean clothes.We loved the locker facility provided. We left our bags in the lockers available on the left hand side right after passing the admission gate and traveled the palace light. The 100 won coin deposited would be returned to you when you open the locker.
We loved this place, it's amazing! Tips: Go to this in morning, could have many beautiful pictures. There are many people wearing hanbook, you can take many shoot with them.
Very interesting and beautiful palace. Near the "Blue House"--residence of the current president. English tours are available.
Very very very good.I like the historical castle.It's very huge. If you're lucky you can catch some wonderful and remarkable festivals.

Gyeongbokgung Palace is one place you have to visit when holidaying in Seoul. It is wonderful to see a historic place in the middle of the city. Getting there is easy too. We took the train there on our own and the palace is within a minute's walk. You can catch the change of guards ceremony at a few timings during the day and you can dress up in beautiful traditional Korean costumes to take nice photo shots too.There are guided tours available at certain timings and I recommend you follow the tour if you want to learn and understand more about the place. As I walked and explored the palace on my own, I missed out alot of stories behind the many halls in the palace.

review_title: Beautiful palace in the heart of downtown Seoul
review_body: The Gyeongbokgung Palace is conveniently located in central Seoul - just down the main road from City Hall. Its a beautiful palace and worth visiting!

review_title: A beautiful palace and its huge!
review_body: Make sure you wear comfortable shoes when you will visit this palace. Its really wide spread and you will need to walk quiet a bit to see everything. Please keep at least a few hours in hand to see everything. There are a few guided tours available that you tickets for.

Great place to visit when in Seoul. Hard to think that this can be found in the city with sky scrappers on one side and and mountains in the back ground on the other side. Not very big and can probably only want to spend an hour there but definitely worth a visit.

review_title: Make sure to watch the ceremony of the changing of the guard
review_body: Gyeongbokgung Palace is a beautiful palace with lots of history and is sure not a place to miss. It must be on top of your things to do while in Seoul. Be especially mindful of when the ceremony of the changing of the guard occurs as it is a sight to see. It is easy to find and take some walking shoes as there will be a lot of walking.
I enjoy visiting the palaces. I was fortunate enough to visit on Memorial day and had the opportunity to see a lot of young couples in traditional dress.

review_title: Interesting busy dusty and some sameness
review_body: Huge palace lots of crowds and girls in national dress all having their photos taken little information provided but some hints of history in the queens death at the hands of the japanese. Many of the bildings the same but the large hall and thrown immpressive.

review_title: Huge place - be prepared to walk...a lot
review_body: Magnificent place, lots of history in this place. Recommend to get the free guide to walk around. Having the understanding will make the trip more meaningful

Went to palace and viewed a lot the museums as not bad it's inside the palace there is a lot to see things to do the changing of the guards and people wearing traditional close people from all over come to See one of the many palaces In Korea it's a sight to see

review_title: Beautiful palace, don't miss the Changing of Guards parade
review_body: Well maintained palace that is easily accessible, and close by to Insadong, Bukchon Hanok, Gwanghwamun square and Cheonggyecheon so you can visit all these plus go to the famous Tosokchon for Ginseng Chicken soup in one day. The highlight for us was the Change of Guards parade although I think the pace can be a little quicker, we also got to put on guard costumes after the parade for free at a little stand to the right facing the gate. We were allowed to take pictures outside the hut but no kids sizes were available. Palace is not very stroller friendly even though the ground is mostly flat because it is not concrete flooring and pushing the stroller along creates a cloud of dust. All our shoes were dusty after the visit so keep your best shoes at home.

a must see in seoul. walk thru the huge complex and imagine life as the emperor. the locals get in free if they wear the traditional korean wear so we, as tourists, get to see young men/women inside the palace, enhancing the authentic experience.

Location 10/10Take the local subway (Gyeongbokgung Palace stop) and the palace is just right outside the station. Not much walking needed to reach. EnvironmentLove the environment as the front of the palace is facing the government buildings and the back of the building situated the hills. Mixture of old n new culture of Korea! Great place to snap plenty of photos. The palace guard pictures is a must! They are so colorful and gigantic! FoodNo obvious eateries around the palace. Do not go with hungry tummy! Price 3000 Korean won for adult1500 Korean won for children(groups get discount)FYIYou did not visit Korea if you didn't visit this palace!!

review_title: Beautiful Palace in the Heart of Seoul
review_body: Recommend going for changing of the guard and then doing a guided tour. The grounds are really big so allow a couple of hours and bring a lot of water.
just skip it if u are not into palace. it required entrance fee but you can easily sneak in during peak hours. for me just taking a photo at the entrance of the palace is more than enough of my time.

Well maintained building. Entry ticket is 3000Won per person. During certain hours, you can see the changing guard ceremony. Can reach here by subway using the Gyeongbukgung station which will bring you out near the National Palace Musuem.

Gyeongbokgung Palace is huge historical beauty. Nice place to go around for pics. U can time urself for free guide available in English as well. Even without Guide its worth a tour. Give min 2 to 2 1/2 hr for complete tour of palace. Its in heart of city and easily accessd by subway.

This is the bigger of the 2 imperial palaces. Personally, I like the other one. Go see this one just because that's what you do; just like one visits the Statue of Liberty in nyc because that's what you do when you are in nyc. Just a bunch of buildings that very much resemble Chinese palaces. One cannot go in the building, just stand outside and look in through the openings. They do try to make up for it by having re enactments and "changing of the guard" type ceremony.
Very interesting palace dating from 1392. Beautiful buildings and very well maintained. We had a free guide.
Huge place to visit. Allow for at least 1.5 hours to go through the whole place. the library was a nice place to stop for a cup of tea as well.

Being a Palace it shows the grandness of the royalty of the past with the touch of frugality. The structure has signs of Chinese architectural influence. From Gyeongbokgung Palace, you are a short walk to Insa-dong.where you can experience artique art, book stores and craft shops.

A stop at the palace is well worth the cost of admission, as is the audio guide. Budget about one to 1.5 hours here, and enjoy wandering through. There are not many shaded areas, so if you come during the hot months, plan your stop for the morning or for the last entries of the day, otherwise it can be tiring.
Great tour that you can do on your own or with a guide. You can easily spend a half day just touring the grounds. Be sure to visit the guest room in the Blue House. Very good history lesson.
Well-maintained palace where the highlight for us was the 10am changing of the guard which our kids were enthralled with.

Visiting the palace is a great way of partly knowing the history of Korean dynasties. It is easily accessible and few minutes walk from the train station. I took advantage of the free tour guide services being offered by students. Their desk can be found just before you get out of the train station.

The place can be extremely crowded during weekends where you have to squeeze to get around. Outside of the main palace it is still pretty quiet where you can sit and truly enjoy the beauty of the palace.If you want to understand the palace, a tour is a must as there arent many informations shown in the booklets.

review_title: Good upkeep and great place to take photos
review_body: If you are someone who loves history, this place is worth visiting. Otherwise, going there is also worth the trip if you are looking for places to take pictures with buildings on the yesteryears.

review_title: A historical show case of Korea
review_body: Gyeongbokgung Palace is good for those who are interested in the history.Those going to this place must visit Insadong market (very near,just outside the palace) , known as "Art Street" of Seoul.

review_title: Well worth a trip and great value
review_body: The palace was interesting to walk around and take in, and gave a good amount of information about the lives of the past royal family, even without the free guided tour. Easy enough to spend at least a couple of hours here as the grounds are huge and the various buildings spread out. The highlight for me was one of the pavilions in the centre of a moat which was incredibly picturesque and peaceful, against the backdrop of mountains. The only problem was it was very very busy, but likely due to it being a great value, essential attraction for visitors o Seoul.
A very good place to spend a weekend morning, looking the beautiful palaces and gardens, with good oportunities to take a lot of beautiful shots..

We went twice. It was too hot in the day. But in the evening it was beautiful. Even more so due to the large number of people wearing traditional clothes. A limited number of evening tickets are made available for foreigners each day and only become available at 7:00 in the evening, so head there at 7:00 and grab some evening tickets! We were lucky enough to go on a Saturday and a great show was on from 8:00. This was my favourite event in Seoul. It is also definitely worth catching the changing of the guard ceremony. Watch from inside the main gate.
Just a beautiful palace where you can sit down and appreciate the history and architecture at the same time. Definitely worth a visit!

Spent hours here with my mother and grandmother. There are many different types of traditional Korean palaces you can visit along with a museum that houses old Korean artifacts. Take your time her and go at your own pace. That's the beauty of this site. Don't forget to visit the section on the east that have models of an old school Korean village. Admission was free when I went but I think there is a fee normally.

been here for 2nd time and still impressed with the size of the place and its historical stories. Found out more history from local guide and every little detail in these buildings holds a lot of interesting meaning. Would suggest to get local guide to bring you around in private tour to understand and explore more about Korean culture and historical infos.

review_title: Very bautyfully restored and maintained buildings, a true way back into the Joseon period
review_body: Anyone who is interested in the countries history must visit this place and escape from the noise streetsof the city

review_title: A good first stop for Seoul visit
review_body: This palace makes a good first stop for Seoul travel. It is considered the heart of Seoul and it served as the ruler's palace for many years. Nearby are the palace museum and the excellent Korean folk museum.

review_title: Interesting palace in the middle of urban Seoul.
review_body: This palace was interesting not only for it's historical value but because it was also in the middle of the city. You could literally take a picture of the palace with Seoul's myriad skyscrapers as a backdrop. Reminded us of some of the palaces in China.
it was very nice to see gyeongbokgung ceremonial on that autumn, they have a beautiful view and huge building
ensuring the traditional palace is maintained is good that too in the middle of the city. At one end you see the palace and the opposite side you see all the modern sky scrapers. good visit

You can spend 2-3 hours here pretty easily. Take a leisurely stroll, and check out all the buildings within the palace ground. You can also get access to the National Folk Museum as well from here with the same ticket.
the place is too big to walk around.. lots of big and small palace plus ancient stuff.. the palaces were amazing! ancient korea!
This palace has been completely restored to its original, even though it has been destructed twice in the Japanese attacks on Seoul. It is of great beauty and should not be missed!

review_title: Hanbok wearing locals give a traditional feel
review_body: Easily one of the prettiest sights of Seoul with the mountains as the backdrop. On a Saturday evening I saw many Hanbok wearing local girls which gave traditional feel. The palace reminds me of the forbidden palace in Beijing. With large and nested courtyards. There is an entrance fee to this place and the ticket counter closes at 5 PM. Easy to get to on the metro. There are many nice places to visit after a tour around the palace.

It was a hot sunny day n there was a guard changing shift ceremony when we arrived at the Palace's main gate (b4 entrance). Some tourists made the effort to rent hanbok n wearing it to the palace to have photos, which was really nice. There is a Pavillion on the waters which tourists can reserve 1 day in advance (pic attached) to get access to go in n have photos. There r certain guided slots which r in different languages acc to the ticket counters.

Booked a free Seoul walking tour for this palace. There were a lot of people over the weekend. However the palace is beautiful. The tour enhanced the palace experience adding much depth to the visual experience of this place. Although this palace was restored it doesn't diminish its importance to Korea and how crucial it has been to the existence of this nation.The changing of guard ceremony is something not to be missed. It provides an experiential bridge to its glorious past and is one of the highlights of this palace visit.
Gyeongbokgung Palace was the main royal palace of the Joseon dynasty. The architectural principles of ancient Korea were incorporated into the tradition and appearance of the Joseon royal court.

review_title: A palace you cannot miss - worth for the price
review_body: A grand and big palace. Lots of walking but worth it.Don't miss the changing guard ceremony and check their new schedules before visiting. Now, they only have two shows at 10:00 and 12:00.They have a big show running when we visited there. Because it was their Golden week in the first week of May, free entrance for all visitors to all palaces on that weekend. Also, if anyone wearing their traditional Korean clothes, free entrance are granted.After visiting the palace, you can take this opportunity and enjoy their famous Ginseng chicken soup. That most famous restaurant is 10 minutes away from the palace, but don't go there during lunch hour, you will find at least 200 people waiting before you. We wait until 3pm, no waiting is required.

review_title: A palace that summarized the others (if you dont have time to visit all)
review_body: In Seoul there are 5 (if I'm not wrong) palaces but Gyeongbokgung is the the biggest. If you dont have time to visit all, this is the best choice to summarized Korean's palace characteristic. Enjoy the walk around the palace - the hexagonal pavillion in the middle of an artificial lake is my favourite, especially during Spring when the flowers are blooming. Tips:1) Spare a couple of hours if you really want to tour all over the area (its bigggg and still expanding) - make sure you have your comfortable walking shoes.2) Take note it is closed on Tuesdays.3) Check out the guard changing ceremony (twice a day) and you may have some wefies with the guards after the ceremony.4) If you plan to visit more than 1 palace - get the combo ticket value for $$5) If you are a fan of Korean Drama, have fun checking out the spots where some of the dramas a filmed here. My friends and I made a quest of these spots and we had fun as if going on some treasure hunting (haha).6) During spring season there would be special night session - look out for the notification in their website

one of the palace in Seoul, we purchase royal palace ticket which we can use it for different palace, however the palace was really crowded, and little bit dusty, u can find museum at the back of the palace, well we did not stay long....

review_title: A Must Visit When coming to Seoul
review_body: Visiting this primary palace when visiting Seoul is a must. Take the guided tour given at 11:00, 1:30 & 3:00 to get the most of your visit.

review_title: A big palace with beautiful moutain scenery
review_body: It is a beautiful palace and nice to go for a walk. However, in terms of architecture and beauty, there are other places in the same region that may be more beautiful.It was nice to see guard changing ceremony in the front of the building.

It is a worth place for the price.We got the 10000 won tickets to visit the 4 palace and the garden. This palace was the only one with free show. There's 3 kind of so you should check the time.For us it was at 13h to 13h30.
This historical Palace is worth the trip. It's so huge and splendid. It's a must to visit the palace when going to Korea.

We joined a free English guided tour of the Gyeonbokgung palace and enjoyed learning about the history of Korea as well as lovely views of the palace. At the end we also had access to the museum and we took the time to look at the exhibits as well.

Historical place and it is spectacular. Free tour guide provided and there is performance in the middle of palace. The palace is connected to the front area of Cheong Wa Dae. Love the view so much. There is a museum with the coffee counter, you may get a rest here with free wifi. It is worth to spend 2-3 hours here and then go to eat ginseng chicken soup after this.

This palace is so large that you feel like you will never be able to see it all. The buildings are beautiful and very well maintained. It is amazing how extensive the complex is and the different buildings you see throughout the grounds. We highly recommend visiting this palace if you are coming to Seoul.
The Korean palaces are really really simple and peaceful. Beautiful gardens and halls, but nothing too ornate. Should visit at least one of the palaces if you are in Seoul

review_title: Huge and made out if wood
review_body: It was fantastic to visit this palace. It is made out of wood mostly and amazing how it is not damaged after 100s of years. We did not go inside the main part which needs ticket but we're able to see a lot in free ticket zone.

review_title: Historical evidence of a remarkable past centuries
review_body: Nice place to visit in Seoul. for people from Europe this is a relatively young historical place, but for US and other citizens - it is old enough to be amazing. in very good condition, full of young people, nice and calm place in the middle of a 10 million-citizens town. great architecture
It was pretty much a muchnes although changing of the guard really good. Inside was sparse and for me just ok. The museum however far more interesting as it depicted life to the present
Since traveled a lot in Asia i wasnt blown off my feet. but it is a nice place to visit.spend there 2 hours MAX
A most interesting location. I was impressed with Korea's maintaining their history, yet at the same time, staying up to date in their new architecture. Place it on top of yourplaces to visit.

review_title: What a amazing palace in the middle of town
review_body: This palace is massive. We were lucky enough to be here on a day that featured a Korean song and dance group. It felt as though we went back 200 years.

The Gyeongbokgung Palace is an interesting place to visit especially if you are interested in Korean history and the way of life of royalty during that era. I cannot say that I could identify with much of what I saw as it was not an area of the world that I know very much about and so did not appreciate a lot of what I was seeing and was being told about.

review_title: Breathtaking beauty and history in the middle of Seoul
review_body: I had visited the Palace when I lived in Seoul nearly 20 years ago and the opportunity to return was worth the wait. Numerous and ongoing restorations have been taking place since 1990, the latest having been completed in 2010. The serene beauty of the Palace is in start contrast to the surroundings of bustling Seoul. A breathtaking experience.

review_title: Nice to see an old palace
review_body: There are a few palaces, we decided to just see 1 and chose this one. Easy to walk to from myeongdong, 3000 entrance fee per person and you can join a free tour in English (as at the info office) it's also nice to see the changing of the guard. If you don;t want to take a tour pick up a map at the info office just after the entrance and follow it to visit all the main buildings, we were there for a couple of hours - take a break for coffee in the library (i think it was building number 9 on the map). I think it is worth a visit. We went on a Thursday at 12:00 and it was not at all crowded.

review_title: Wonderful place to learn Korean History in One day
review_body: Visit this place if you've been to Changdeokgung Palace and only if you've no other place to visit.Changdeokgung is far more beautiful of a palace than Gyeongbokgung. However, Gyeongbokgung has it's charmed as well. Visit during children day and you'll get free entrance for a day
Marvelous palace in the heart of Seoul.The changing of the guard ceremony is interesting and it was lovely to see young people in their traditional dress.

This is a must visit while you're in Seoul. I would say this is one of the major highlights when visiting. You have to pay a small entrance fee of 2,000-3,000 won (roughly about 2-3 dollars US) and once you get in, you are free to roam around. Theres actually a lot of areas to explore in the Palace. Gardens, pond, areas of hanoks and temples. It can get pretty busy and might be difficult to take pictures, so I recommend going early morning. You can also wear hanboks and walk around the Palace as well. Theres also an art gallery close by (outside the palace gates) with lots of traditional Korean restaurants, cafes, shops, etc.

Its huge!!!!! i needed more tan 3 hours to do the Speedy gonzalez style tour, (walk fast, few pictures and keep going), dont miss it, just try to go early morning and weekends to avoid large groups and school trips groups
Lovely scenery. It is very well kept, entrance fee is low, free for elderly. I really enjoyed the walk, relaxing and beautiful. The museum was very interesting too.

review_title: If you wear Hanbok, you get free entrance!
review_body: Interesting enough to spend time to visit. My sister & I rent Hanbok for 4 hours (cost less than 15,000 won/person) and had free entrance tickets. Changing the guard parade is really interesting. I considered we were lucky to see the march!

review_title: Trip to Seoul will not be complete without visit this palace
review_body: Having a day tour around Seoul, this palace is the first and maybe the most important place to visit. A big complex of palace that reminds me of Forbidden City in Beijing, not only show the richness and uniqueness of Korean architecture and history in the past but also offered the visitors with some attractions from Korean kingdom (which unfortunately I did not have enough time to enjoy).

review_title: A great day in the palace
review_body: A great day to spend the day. The museum is worth visiting and the have free performance to enjoy and the comfort of A/C. Stroll around the grounds and enjoy!

We had an opportunity to watch the ceremony before leaving. The place is quite big and we only stayed for only a few minutes since it was winter and we went there on our last day. But it is definitely a place to visit when going to South Korea.

This place is very nice. The palace is very spacious. You can imagine walking along the path where kings and queens have and marvelling at the gardens and scenery.When you have bought your ticket for the palace you can go to the National Folk Museum for free when you show your ticket on the same day.

review_title: Interesting place to learn about history
review_body: A good place to visit to learn about the history of Korea. There's a guard changing at 1pm and u can take photos with the guards. There is also a museum nearby to understand more about korea's history

This largest palace in Seoul (or Korea?) is conserved extremely well, though the narrative signs can be a bit more lively and in-depth. I visited on a Saturday morning and the place saw huge crowds - tourists, kid groups and girls wearing Hanbok!
Nice walk, plenty of photo ops. Servant quarters are cool. A lot of people come dressed in costume. Only 3,000 W.

Like all the other palaces i have visited during this travel , you can feel the history of this nice country the architecture is splendid . Don"t forget to borrow the local national dress from the reception and walk around wearing it , you will feel like you are one of the soldiers or guard of the palace . All facilities are also in , like coffee shops , toilets , museum ... . it is really a nice place to visit in Seoul .

review_title: Palace with not much of history
review_body: Beautiful Palace architecture but then stripped of all its goods and wealth,.. feel bad about colonial rule which korea also suffered.. and the damage that Japan did to the history of this clean, strong economy ....This country needs to get back its history by collecting all its artifacts from various collectors and restore its history ... because with out ones heritage one cant build his future...Well kept and simple... building ... well feel it less only because I am comparing it with the Palaces of India...but its different here....

Our visit to the palace was perfect. There was an event (Royal Culture Festival) being held that time and we were able to see and experience the re-enactment of the Royal Feast of 1892. Locals dressed up in traditional outfits complete with props. The event lasted for about an hour, it includes a Korean, English, and Chinese narrative of the event. A very colorful and lively place, it's a must-see!

Located in the northern part of Seoul city, this palace has many beautiful buildings and nicely landscape garden. Ideal place to make many photos. If you are visiting Seoul, It's better to combine the visit to Palace with other tourists attractions in the area like Folks museum, Samchongdong, Insadong, Jogysa temple etc.

You can only admire everything from the outside. Buildings and surrounding areas are perfectly maintained. Even if you are on a tight budget and /or a tight schedule you should take an extra ticket to visit the gardens. Try to visit this place early morning when there are not too many students about. They sometimes make such a racket that it's impossible to understand the guide. It happened to me this time whilst on an afternoon tour . When you are at the palace, don't miss the next famous landmark worth a visit : the old traditional Hankok Village which starts a couple of streets from it.I highly recommend Changdeokgung Palace. If you can visit only one palace, visit this one .. with a guide. Some guided tours are free. Enjoy!

Its a historic walk in to the ancient and rich history and heritage of Korea. One can't help but marvel at the architectural genus of this palace and respect the cultural heritage of this great country.

Timing our visit to the Royal Palace with their free English guided tour made this very enjoyable. If you want to do it on your own, bear in mind it's huge with very little English explaination. Wear good walking shoes and bring lots of water.
Another one of those spots on the Soeul "must see" list. Worth the entrance fee, lots to see inside.

Take the free English guide at 13:00 and don't miss the guard change ceremony. Also visit National Folk Museum. Amazing place to relax and drink your sweet potato latte or green tea latte both are amazing.

The place to visit in soeul. Where you can see how the olden age tradition of the soldiers how they communicate and changing the shifts. The music and slogans was impressive. The big drum was highlight. The ticket price to get in to the palace is 3₩. Its in the middle of the city. The scenic from the palace is astonishing. The must visit place and know about the kirean traditions.

review_title: The one and only to visit.
review_body: If it is your first visit to Seoul, make sure to visit Gyeongbokgung. Just this will do, no need to visit others. Ticket price reasonably at krw3,000 per adult, if you wear hanbok, it will be free entry. If time allows, join one of the free tour guided by English, Mandarin or Japanese speaking Korean lady, they provide good insights and some history for your easy understanding. Thereafter, you can explore more on your own. Do note that the palace closed on every Tuesday.

review_title: The place is nice but nothing much to see
review_body: We did this free transit tour by the city of Seoul and while the place itself is amazing, there is nothing much to see especially if you have no background on korean history like i did.
The palace is very beautiful but you must wear rubber shoes since the palace is very big. There are lot of photo ops in Gyeongbokgung Palace.

Went on winter time . On a clear blue day. The palace is really beautiful . Walked all the way in to the quiet lake - the scenery is good. enjoy the quiet grounds, far from the grp tour. lots of small palaces / "departments" within the palace ground .Visit the National Folk / palace museum at the same time if you got time .opp the palace (back gate) is the president blue house.

review_title: Beautiful garden, cultural experience, architecture tour
review_body: Studied this during architectural history class so it's fun to walk around.I arrived around 3:30 and was just about to catch "changing guards".There are local students who would like some "language exchange" experience that would give free tours.I was told by the local that if you want to, you can get to try on the traditional korean costume for free in the information center. I didn't have to time to do so, but you could go and see if you are interested. There are quite some girls wearing and walking around and a few guys too.

The main reason I wanted to visit this palace is because they filmed Rooftop Prince and other periodic Korean dramas here. This place is beautiful. The architectures are amazing and the beans to hold the roof have very intricate drawings on them. Some of the doors were locked but I was still happy to visit this place. Kings and queens walked the paths I walked. History and laws were created and made here. Its amazing to see that, most part of the walkways around the palace were just dirt. Amazed me that the kings and queens were frugal. Paintworks were beautifully preserved and same goes to the building. Love the scenery because since its spring, the palace flowers blooms and highlighted the beauty of the place even more. If you have a toddler, be sure to wear walking shoes because you will mostly be walking on dirt, just like the royalty who used to lived there. Beautiful...
Visited this palace as part of a tour. It was also a school holiday so there were so many children and teenagers there. It was very beautiful but I wish we had more time there.

Been here 3 times - 8 years ago first time. Awesome place. However, I have taken the English tour and found it great. Not so this time. The palace grounds were extremely crowded. There were so many people on the tour that many times you could not hear the guide or she started talking before everyone could actually get to her location.So many people that it was hard to look inside some of the structures. There were huge tour bus parked outside the palace - so hundreds of people are swarming in at once. I was told by a local that evening when I remarked on the difference experience I had that there is a big uptick in Chinese tourists and these tour buses are everywhere. So just note that the English tour may not be that great. But the tour is free with palace admission so just try to stick close to the guide and return to explore the buildings when the tour is done. The place is amazing and worth it.

Gyeongbokgung Palace is the palace all first time visitors should see. Plan to spend some time there, a visit to the National Palace Museum which is on site is very interesting and can take up a good part of your time. Keep track of your time as you would want to see the changing of the guards ceremony.

When we visited we saw the change of the guard at the main gates. I'm not sure how frequently this occurs but it's worth checking out to see if you cancoincide your visit. The uniforms of the guards are colourful and flamboyant and you can take photos with them much the same way as you can with the guards in London. There was also a lot of young Koreans visiting in traditional dress when we were there. The grounds, lake and palace are nice - you need to set aside a couple of hours

review_title: A Must see attraction to visit on Seoul
review_body: We spent about three hours at this lovely palace, which we thought was the nicest in Seoul. It was very good value to get in, and guided tours in English were included in the price. The gardens were beautiful and the old traditional buildings full of character. We loved the way a lot of Koreans dress up in national costumes to visit the palaces, adding to the atmosphere. We got some lovely photos while here and thoroughly enjoyed our visit.

Have been to Gyeongbokgung Palace 4 times. It is an interesting place that you are allowed to explore without a tour guide. There are many buildings on the large grounds that you can walk into and take pictures. Most of the signs are in Korean as well as English. At certain times there are performances done by Koreans in costumes that date back to when the Palace was occupied. It is very interesting!

A stunning reconstructed palace in the heart of Seol.₩3000 to get in and a further ₩3000 for an audio guide and definitely worth it. Not a whole lot of information to read so I recommend the audio guide.Take some time to sit and take it all in and then hit up the nearby shopping district afterwards.

Just go there to relealise this. I had been here more than once. Roam around or just sit. The serene environment and the peace and tranquility will embrace you. If you like History, you will enjoy the years this palace has stood by. If you dont, you will enjoy the Nature here that will help you to be with yourself.

Our first tourist site visit on the trip. It is right at the station that bears the same name. Best exit to use is #5 and then you are right there. We were able to see the changing of the guard. The palace was built in 1394. It is from the Joseon Dynasty. Good for wandering and taking pictures.

Enjoyable tour of the palace given, free of charge, by students of the local language college wanting to improve their English. If asked do say yes to this service. It really is free and you'll get much more out of your visit. Lovely kids.

review_title: Great palace to visit on my first trip to Seoul.
review_body: This is a great palace to visit for site seeing and photo taking. However, the day I went with family, was Korea Culture Day and it was overcrowded with locals and tourists. Also, without a guided english tour guide, we were quite lost in the palace. I prefer the Changdeokgung Palace over Gyeongbokgung Palace.
Great place to go for a little cultural and historical experience. Some of the locals came dressed in the traditional hanbok cloting.

This was my third visit and I love it everytime. If it is warm and humid then prepare to sweat as you will be walking a lot.If you plan it right you can also get in for free as we did this time (by chance), but the downside is having far bigger crowds than usual.Make sure you also see the Blue House which is at the back if the park.The palace is beautiful, very traditional korean. The ponds and park also make this a great outing. For a better experience try to come during the change of guards or other special events to be fully immersed in korean traditions.If you are in Seoul and you only have time for one palace then this is the best!
Awesome palace...just like in the kdramas I've watched. Great sight and for picture taking as well. A myst see change if royal guards.

I happened in Seoul a bit out of accident, but have loved this city. It's important to mix a bit of culture into a trip and the central location of this palace did make it an easy visit. Admission is also quite cheap. The guards dress very vibrantly and ate stationed on the front gate. Have your picture with them, just no touching. Time spent here is dependant on the individual, I grew restless after a few similar looking buildings and some nice gardens and completely missed that there was even a gift shop, the place is quite vast so if you want to see every nook and cranny than budget a couple of hours. Also be prepared for the school tours and a fair number of people.
its a big palace, you can imagine how to lived that dynasty, how they communicate without gadget cause this palace is very big and quite far from other place to the other

The place is very big and beautiful. Take the map on the information centre and walk around. I haven't got a guidedd tour but it was ok as I had my Lonely Planet guide in hands. Go there with sun otherwise it might be a bit boring.

A short review for a huge place! I cannot imagine how amazing it would have been when it was built. As this is a replica, there is a little let down. Still beautiful grounds & buildings from the 1800's

I read a few strongly negative reviews, so that sort of inspired me to write a less nasty one - for balance... I do not know if I was just lucky, and went there at the right time of the right day, but there was virtually NOBODY else around, outside of my immediate party. Of course, that could possibly have had something to do with the company that I was in, as my friends' father was a high ranking Korean military hero? He was sort of leading us around this venue, and I suppose that may have been the reason why nobody else was around at that time, but I think it was a neat place, and I'm glad I got the chance to see it. It was a splendid photo-op, to mark of my checklist.

Beautifully restored after a tumultuous history that left large parts destroyed, the palace is a monument to the resilience of Koreans and the importance of their history. More understated and elegant than the Forbidden City, the palace can be enjoyed as a stroll in an hour or as a full half days' exploration activity. For future visitors: there is not much shade (particularly in the central parade ground area where the changing of the guard may be viewed) and it can be very hot in the summer months.

review_title: The first place to visit in Seoul
review_body: The most impressive and very large palace in Seoul that you have to visit if you have a day time. For me it was the first stop. At the end of the visit I enjoyed the changing of the guard ceremony. Must go!

Cant help but give this one top marks. It was nice and peaceful in the palace grounds which was great away from the hustle and bustle of the city. But we really lucked out...to celebrate the 94th anniversary of childrens day entrance was free so seeing as we didnt even have to pay i cant not give it top marks.
It's definitely a must see when you're in Seoul. The entrance ticket is cheap and its more cheaper when you get the combo tickets for the 4 Palace.

review_title: Nice to stroll around when it's not raining!:)
review_body: It was crowded with both local and tourists when we visited. It was difficult to see all the sites in the rain as it was muddy between sites. Nevertheless, it was grand. It was however not my favourite. I prefer to walk around the secret garden at Changdeokgung.

The first day we went there was not actually a good experience because we were not aware that the palace was close on Tuesdays. It was disappointing but they let us visit the Palace Museum instead. The next day my sister and I still went positively hoping we could get in. And finally we did and for free! I was about to pay at the ticket booth when the lady told us that they were holding their National Culture Day and that admission was for free. Visiting Gyeongbukgung was on top of my list even before we arrived in Seoul. It was spring so the air was cool, cooler than the day before and we were glad about it. We took hundreds of pictures from the gates to the pots and stairs of the temple. It was like remembering all the Korean dramas I had watched before. But what I had realized was, I was setting foot on the same ground where kings and queens of Joseon walked and stood. It was a very happy experience!

Totally unintentionally we came to Seoul during the lantern festival. As a result we received full entry and were also offered an English tour by a group of school children (as part of a club activity). We took them up on their offer and were extremely glad we did. They took us around the palace, explaining to us a great deal about its history and cultural significance. The palace itself is very similar to many others and is still being reconstructed back to its former glory. However, the reconstruction is very realistic and it is possible to still gain a feel for its original significance. The gardens at the back allow strolls into the quieter regions of the palace providing a welcome break from the inevitable crowds.

Visiting the Palace is definitely a step back in time but the destruction wrought on it by Japanese forces at the time meant that little of the original structure remains. Still, the restoration work is excellent and walking the vast grounds is one of the most pleasant things to do in Seoul. Admission is about $3.00 however I strongly recommend you hire the audio guide for an additional $3.00. If you see Koreans wearing traditional dress walking around the Palace, many do so because they get free entry. I did note that there is good wheelchair access throughout the site but be prepared for a bumpy ride across the central courtyard.

great palace which has been rebuilt for may times. When I was there no so crowded so I was able to explore more, took some nice spot pictures. Affordable entrance fee with lot thing that can we expect

Loved this palace. It is right smack in the middle of seoul, so it is very charming to see a traditional palace, surrounded by the modern technologies of high rise buildings and cars. If you are visiting, don't forget to stop by tosokchon which serves the best samgyetang. Go inbetween lunch and dinner times or you'll be in for a long wait.

Visited Gyeongbokgung Palace during winter, summer and spring. Different season different feel. Entrance is free if you're using hanbok. Every side of the palace is worth for a memorable picture. Good for a romantic walk among couple, an educational trip for families and great for group of friends to enjoy pictorial scenery. Dont forget to watch guard changing ceremony. A unique event.

Went there on a weekend and it was extremely crowded. A lot of your groups all around. But it is still worth visiting to have a look and feel of KoreA's history. A few locals (I assume) wear their traditional clothing to walk around which made our visit a little more fun when we spot them. Managed to catch the guard changing ceremony and they are really very professional considering that these people are doing it to 'showcase' the history and not the 'real guards' from the past.

Had wonderful time there, the place is very well-maintained. It is quite big so I recommend to reserve at least 2 hours to enjoy all the little bits there. I also really liked almost one hour traditional music show there, no idea whether it is part of their normal schedule

Second time to see the palace. Absolutely love it. I don't know much about Korean history but it is still well worth the visit. Admission is cheap. Very picturesque. Not grand and awe inspiring like Beijing's forbidden city but certainly more picturesque. Museum within the grounds worth a look as well.

Make sure you go on a tour. There are free tours, you just need to register online. I was on a tour with 3 other girls. Having a tour guide gives you a lot of information about their history. Its not boring nor purely political. They gave us insight on how the royalty lived, even their personal lives, and some tragedies that happened in that palace. It was interesting. Long walk, but the place is really amazing.

I have visited this palace before. I did not realize the ground was so huge until I had to enter via the National Folk Museum entrance. I was wearing hanbok and I got in for free. This palace is on the must-see list of all tours. It can get crowded especially shortly before and after the changing of the guards. Come early to avoid bus loads of tourists.

The palace is simply mesmerizing. Whenever you step in, you'll automatically grab your camera to capture the beauty.Tip: 1) be there on 10 am to watch the guardian-changing ceremony. 2) take a photo with hanbok-wearing local. 3) don't waste too much time here, there are other palaces around.
One of the Main Korean Palaces that must be visited during your stay in Seoul. There is a free English Tour guide and you should catch the changing or guards ceremony.
I recommend to visit this place which is very interesting for you to discover South Korean history. Enjoy it.

review_title: Definitely a place to visit! Beautiful palace!
review_body: Very beautiful exterior and the areas are big too... we had a guide so he explained a lot on the history and which houses belongs to who... you start with the palace and ends with the museum
Attractive palace with enormous well kept grounds. Particularly impressive is the Temple of Fragence. Changing of the Guard ceremony is, to western eyes, unusual

This is a must see if you are in Seoul. The building is not accessible to the public on most days and is used for official functions. It is a beautiful example of traditional Korean architecture and stunningly beautiful. I was very impressed.

Visited the palace as part of the free Incheon transit tour. The place was huge and offers a glimpse on Korea's past.spent around an hour here, would suggest a longer stay to fully appreciate the place.

We came to Seoul from Japan so have seen plenty of shrines/temples, especially around Kyoto.I have to admit the palaces in Seoul aren't as wow in comparison. Additionally I thought Changdeokgung Palace was actually better to visit as it was considerably less crowded and looks remarkable the same as Gyeongbokgung except smaller.

review_title: The nicest palace of them all
review_body: I have visited this Palace during the Lantern Festival so it was free thus I cannot comment on the ticket pricex. It has the nicest localisation of the all Palaces as you can see beautiful green mountains in the backgroun. I'd say that if you have time to see only one, see this one.

We were approached by a free English speaking guide group at the train station who offered to take us through the palace and the grounds, we were hesitant at first but went ahead and found it very helpful and informative. The palace and private buildings of the royal family and officials were amazing and the palace grounds are massive, definitely a must see if ever in Seoul. Make sure you go on a clear day so you can get the best view of the palace.

review_title: One of the most fabulous spot in Seoul
review_body: Up until recently there was a night time openning event.Normally it is operated from 9a.m to 5p.m.So when you grab a chance of night time opening, it will be great.You can enjoy the traditional architecture style of Chosun Dynasty through from 14th to 17th century.You can't imagine there still stands a beautiful palace by the downtown of Seoul.It's the symbolic scenery of Seoul to get along well with tall buildings and historic palace. Those complexcities are the feature of Korea.

Nice for a wander around on a nice sunny day. Not at all expensive for how much of the palace and the grounds you get to walk around. Can easily spend a few hours walking around the palace and the gardens. Definitely worth a visit, an absolute gem in amongst the high rise buildings of central Seoul

review_title: Juxtoposition of Old and New Korea
review_body: A huge park of old palaces right next to modern buildings. In a way it symbolizes both the old and new Korea.I recommend taking a guided tour. Our guide was excellent and provided background and perspective to the palace grounds. Specifically how the Kings/Queens lived during the Joeson Dynasty. Especially when you compare this to today's modern sensibilities.There is also an audio guide, but I did not use. Perhaps the next visit.

I wouldn't be expecting that the palace is wide and with two museums that can be visited after. Got amazed with places surrounded with almost blooming lotuses. The tranquility and the fresh air ease away the problems and anxieties. Truly educational and relaxing at the same time.
There was lovely parade, nice atmosphere there, a place you must see if visit Seoul!!! The palace is big, there is an interesting museum which just opened. Great to learn their history.

This entire place is awesome! Its a very beautiful and nice place to go but be warned, it can get a little tiring to walk around as it is extremely big. You can rent a hanbok (Korean traditional costume) and walk around to get the experience of the olden days. If you are lucky and are on the right time, you might even get a chance to see the guards changing 'shift'. It is highly recommended to visit this place!

The Gyeongbokgung Palace is one of the most famous and largest palatial complex available in Seoul. It is well located above the Gwanghwamun Square and close to Line 3 Metro station. It is fairly well preserved and reconstituted, while some areas are not accessible, some others clearly showcase the way of living during the Joseon Dynasty with different rooms spanning each building serving as quarters for either the King, the Queen, the Court and Guests at the Palace. It gets a little repetitive as the buildings were duplicated in different sizes but the overall ground is magical and includes performances, the National Palace Museum, the Folk Museum, etc. Get patient as not everything is well indicated and perhaps a group tour would be better. Note that you'll get free admission if you dress in the traditional costume, which seems to appeal the young generation!

This palace and grounds are kept immaculate, you will not be going around saying "that looks shabby, they should fix that up", nay! You will be impressed by their upkeep and slight modernisation (the electric light!).Lots of good looking young ladies walk around in traditional dress (some men too, but it's a minority), peacefully enjoying the gardens and place, making you think upon olden day times whilst they are taking selfies and posing in duck face...Must see.

review_title: The best place to visit in Seoul
review_body: For best view, avoid dust storm periods in Spring. It can ruin your day. Also, winter may not be best. There are restaurants inside but they are only good for light meals. Also, try their tea shops. These are fairly good. There is underground parking but you must arrive very early. The spaces are quickly gone. Also watch out for so many tour buses. One good thing is that it is very close to downtown.

I wasn't expecting much because I had been there before on a tour package (too rushed). But this time I went free&easy with friends and had time to explore the palace grounds. There was such a beautiful calm as I took in the sights of the palace architecture, the trees, ponds, mountains...that my heart was moved. I will recommend a leisurely pace to explore the place, then walk to tosokchon for some good ginseng chicken soup.

It's a beautiful place, you can almost see the grandiosity of Korean nobility of old. Confucian kings ruled for more than 500 years until the beginning of 20th century. There are two museums in the complex. Palace museum is great and folk museum's shop is worth a look. It's quite a long walk though, and not for rainy days, because inside there are no pavements. You shogun check the time for guided tours in English, when I went it was 11:00. And you should plan to go there at the time of presentations usually held at the afternoon, it was 14:00When I went so I missed them. There are presentations of royal guard exchange, martial arts and others, at different times.

review_title: visit this place first among other palaces in Seoul..
review_body: My cousins and I did visit the place first before going to other nearby palaces in town but because of too hot weather we never stayed long actually.. The best time to visit this place is when the sun sets.. We went to this place at noon time and we never had our hats and umbrellas and so the scorching heat was not fine for us..But never, never miss going to this place when you go to Seoul..

This is the largest of all the Seoul palaces, though not the most charming (Changdeokgung is). What makes it the best single choice is the fact that it also contains the National Folk and Palace Museums (both free).

After visiting Japan, we visited koreas main attraction. We were met by rude staff at the ticketing box as well as upon entry (not surprised after experience with the locals there). You payabout $3 usd to get in and you are unable to actually enter the palace, you can only see from the outside. The other surrounds are mainly restored buildings that were equally as unimpressive. The grounds are all rubble upon entry so expect your shoes to get dirty. Overrated!
One of historical place that must visit while in Korea. Try to rent Korean traditional dress and walk around with it. Better come in the morning as at noon too crowded

Not too special! Only a big famous place for a walk. Many korean girls wear traditional hanbok for selfie or go along with professional photographer. But it is good to go once if you haven't been to there.

review_title: Definitely a must see for history buffs!
review_body: I'm a fan of history, art, and architecture, and the Palace was a wonderful way to experience all three. We went during December, so it was rather chilly. The Palace tour takes about an hour if you go with a guide (and read reviews of tour guides before going to an attraction - ours was rather pushy and made us feel like schoolchildren), and we would've enjoyed this more had we done it ourselves with perhaps a guide book. However, the history of the palace is very interesting and a lot of the centuries-old work is still intact. You will definitely enjoy the daily Changing of the Guard (at noon)!

The palace was not open for public to go inside and roam the halls, but the site was well-kept. Traffic was pretty tough heading towards this area but thats only because its a tourist attraction. What we did was have the van we came in, drop us from a distance and pick us up at an agreed location when we were done touring.
Nice place but kinda bored as only sight seeing and have to walk a lot as the place really big. Not able to catch the ceremony, coz my frenx told me is an interesting show. :) overall nice place :)
It is much smaller than Beijing's Palace but similar set-up. Many Korean came here with traditional costumes on that day and friendly enough to take photo with us. Thank you!
A must see if you are in Seoul. Beautiful landscape and architecture. Similar to the palaces in China but it is worth visiting!

Gyeongbukgong palace is in the middle of the city hall district in Seoul. It's the biggest palace (if im not mistaken) in Korea and was once home to the Royal Family. The buildings and environment are preserved so well that you actually can't help but think that you have managed to time travel and wound up back into the Joseon Era. Overall a Wonderful and beautiful place. A must see for any tourist!

review_title: Majestic; don't miss Change of Guard ceremony
review_body: Gyeong-Bok-Gung Palace (Gung=Palace): The biggest of 5 palaces in Seoul, open from 9-6 PM on most days, and closed on Tuesdays. Huge courtyards and large scale halls with thrones and decorations to go. Must visit at a time close to the change of guard ceremony, done twice daily at 10AM and 2 PM (lasts about 40 mins).

A must visit place when you are in Seoul. Walk around and experience the atmosphere and the actual buildings within the palace walls in the city. If you have the chance, see the guard rotation at the main gate as well. Recommend you to buy the combination ticket, even though you don't need to see all the 4 palaces.

Be sure to catch the changing of the guards. I was there during the weekend so lots of people and school children. Buildings are beautiful to look at and some parts are so tranquil. I was lucky to catch the tail end of the cherry blossoms.

review_title: Go for changing of the guard
review_body: Loved this palace especially as we timed it for the very colourful changing of the guard at 10.am . If over 65 bring your passport for free entry
Really nice architecture and color. It's interesting to see this ancient building with the backdrop of modern Seoul. Cool visit.
Was lucky enough to see the changing of the guards ceremony, very colorful! This place is Amazing, so much to see. Make sure you read all of the information plaques.Very highly recommend
A must see. It is better to go with the tour. They have a microphone so easy to listen to. They have tour in Korean, English and in Japanese.

review_title: Good to visit and know the history.
review_body: It is similar to some palaces in China. But as the most beautiful palace in Korea, it is still worth of visiting. I personal think you need a tour guide to tell you the history of this palace.

Beautiful palace in middle of Seoul. We hired han-bok at a near by store and walked around, taking photos, which was a lot of fun Some beautiful sights. However my memory is rather faint (after about a month) what the differences are between Gyeongbokgung and Changdeokgung other than the latter was bigger and had a big garden (Secret Garden-Biwon) - so if you are pressed for time, you could do either one of them rather than both.

review_title: Amazing buildings as you can see
review_body: A tremendous place to see a real palace inside a metro city. Entering the front gate you will be welcomed by a majestic palace gate. You will ejoy the old building with great maintanance effort make sure you explore the whole complex with a tour guide which will helps you understand each building function and how a royal lived on that era, including technology on those days which affect modern korean people

This is my 2nd visit but its much different as compared to winter period. Do not miss the change of guards and be all out and rent a hanbok for great photo around the palace. Of course take a tour if you are interested in the history as this is the grandest palaces in Seoul.

You haven't been to Seoul if you haven't visited this palace.Glad to have visited this place on my first day in Seoul. It somehow enlightened me in an intuitive way of the present way of life of the people. It's something I can't put into words but just felt and understood. Sense of pride for their heritage,history and culture is very evident in the Koreans. I'm glad to have patiently waited for the English guided tour. It gave me a deeper appreciation of Korea's culture and tradition.Highly recommended for history buffs and even better when touring with a guide.

A nice place to visit and you could spend a whole day here as it is a vast site. Many authentic buildings and alot of open space with ponds and lakes. There is plenty of information to explain the original site.A nice experience when visiting Seoul. It only cost about £2. For the ticket so is good value.

Beautiful palace, check the times for the different tours in different languages. You can purchase combination tickets to three palaces and a shrine and the tickets last three months so they are a good deal. I was able to use all he tickets in the combination during my two week stay.

Be sure and time your visit for Changing of the guard. Very colourful and ceremonial pomp. Beautiful ponds and grounds - worth a walk about. Understandably busy and popular as one of Seouls top attractions. Cheap to get in & take an escorted tour in the language of your choice, if your time allows. There were cultural music presentations as well.

Main attraction of Seoul, you can easily spend half a day there around the gardens and looking inside the buildings. It's worth it to join a free guided tour, make sure you check out the schedule in advance.

review_title: Interesting place, worth getting on a tour
review_body: Went on the free English speaking tour (you have to pay for entry though), which was very interesting and made it a worthwhile visit. Nice looking palace and gardens.
Crowded with locals and tourist but this and Changdeokgung Palace are the ones that you really must visit if you are interested at all and your time is limited.

review_title: Massive palace complex with lots of photo ops
review_body: The sheer size of the place is impressive and one can easily spend 2-3 hours exploring the grounds. The place is very very popular and when I visited it was full of guided school and tourist groups. Unfortunately the crowds detract from the serenity of the experience, so it might be worth visiting at opening time to stay ahead of the flood of tourists...

review_title: A good cultural visit after some crazy shopping
review_body: A good way to experience the traditional culture of koreaSaw some girls renting hanbok and wear it to visit the palaceBut as usual the palace is flooded with loud tourist group

review_title: Nice but a dry and dusty place
review_body: Most of the precincts of this palace looked dry and dusty. Compared to the Indian palaces I have seen, this palace looked too basic. The best parts were the ponds that we saw.
Lovely palace but very crowded , most of the time,but worth going as we get to see the old charm of Korean history , the garden are just amazing
Magical night walking around the palace after dark. The concert at the Pavillon showcased classical Korean music and dance. I enjoyed it even more than wondering around in the day.

We visited during peak festival time as a family of three, with a 2 year old in a stroller.Overall, this is a great place to visit. We would have enjoyed it more if it hadn't been so busy, but obviously as we visited during a festival it was to be expected.Good:Huge. Seriously. You could probably spend two full days here if you saw every inch of this place.Very interesting. Lots of signs in English. They also have audio tours available in English (and other languages) if you like that sort of thing.Lots of other things are connected to this, including a children's museum. If you like museums, you could spend several days going through all the ones surrounding this Palace.Bad:Since this hasn't been much restored, the ground is very uneven. It is very difficult to push a stroller or wheelchair over it. The staff do their best to help by putting ramps over doorways, up stairways, etc, but it is still difficult.Not necessarily bad, but be careful about going here on a windy day. The sand/dirt on the ground is very loose and will blow into eyes and noses.Definitely a must-see if you enjoy/are interested in Korean history.

review_title: Worth going, its huge and English Tour at 3.30pm was free and well conversed
review_body: The 3.30pm tour is quite good. Lady spoke English well. We could comprehend what she said. Thats a lot in KoreaTicket full price is 3k Won. Thats it worth.

Gyeongbokgung was the first palace I visited and I was awed by the sheer size of it. Set aside about two hours to fully enjoy the sights and catch the changing of the guards ceremony if you can. It gets really crowded at certain parts because of tour groups. Closed on Tuesdays and costs ₩3,000 for admission for adults.

This is my first time visiting Seoul, and most of friends and relatives told me the Gyeongbokgung Palace is super tiny and simple, comparing to Chinese or Japanese ones, and not worth a visit. We visited it anyway, and it's totally worth it. PROs: It's easy access from the subway station "Gyeongbokgung," about 5-10 minutes walk. We joined a free English tour, and I highly recommended. (The English tour is offered at 11:00, 13:30, and 15:30.)Yes, the palace is small, comparing to even an ancient Chinese nobleman's house, but it is still a beautiful palace full of Korean history and culture for the visitors to learn. The tour guide spoke good English and was very informative about the traditions, architecture, and the history of the palace and the royal families. There is a beautiful garden at the back of the palace with a small pond. CONS: It could get quite noisy and crowded with lots of tourists and students on field trips.

We arrived the Palace early as there is guided tour of the substantial palace grounds in different languages: English, Mandarin (and possibly French?)The guide has done a great job in showing us bits of history, and even teased us with couple of questions to keep up the interest.A most enjoyable experience but prepared to walk for an hour of so, and some of the grounds were a bit uneven. If you're concerned, then bring a walking pole to be on the safe side.

review_title: Wonderful site, recommend going with a tour
review_body: Enjoyed seeing the palace complex, I was glad I was with an organized tour group since I learned a lot of history that made it much more interesting

Personally, I like visiting places of historical and cultural value, especially palaces. Gyeongbok Palace is conveniently located from Metro Station and it gives an insight to the Imperial Korea in the past. I am quite surprised with how well maintained this palace is, given the fact that it was set up in the 14th century. For those of you who like taking pictures, this palace offers many spots to capture 'those' moments.Even though Gyeongbok Palace was the main palace of the Korean Emperor, I find that it somehow lacks the grandeur of other palaces that I visited.

review_title: If it's one palace you can visit this is the one
review_body: Watched changing of guard practice then the full works. There is English, Japanese, Mandarin audio explanations broadcasted so it's easy to follow. It's open in evenings without enaction. Beside it is the museum which is free. Also it's best location to walk towards Blue House and Buckhon Hanok Village.
The entrance is W3,000 & English earphone guide W3000. Just soend an hour will do. Can head for Hanok village for lunch & visit Insadong after this.

If you're first time in Korea, I suggest you start exploring the history & culture first, (shopping and entertainment can come later), because Seoul is rich with it. They presevered their culture well. I personally love the palaces. I went straight here after I check in my luggage, just in time for the changing of guard ceremony at 1pm. To go here, I use metro line 5 to Gwanghwamun station and used exit 2. I started at Gwanghwamun square, where Statues of King Sejong and Admiral Yi are and walk up to the palace. it doesn't take long. Tips: at the ticket counter we bought a combination ticket for the palaces + Jongmyo Shrine for 10,000₩. These include The Secret Garden at Changdeokgung Palace. If you buy separate tickets, entrance fee to each palaces can be up to 3000₩ (and The Secret Garden had an additional fee of 5000₩)

If you ever go to Seoul, you have to go to Gyeongbokgung Palace. It's great with friends or as a solo traveler. Easily accessible from the subway. Makes for great tourist photos. Truly a piece of Seoul you can't miss!
good place to learn about the olden days of Korea. was expecting more exhibits though. the guard changing ceremony was pretty awesome. take pictures with the guards too!

review_title: Below Average, don't expect too much
review_body: I love visiting historical places but not this one. The look and style of this palace is very similar to the Chinese one, so, you can still take some good pictures here. But this palace is kind of empty and there is not even a single sign to explain the history.
It's like you went back in time! For me it's like I've been to my favorite Korean period dramas. The Changing of the Guards Ceremony is a must see. Lots of photo opps for, I guarantee you!

review_title: The Grand Palance of the Korean Emperor
review_body: We spend about 1/2 day here exploring the castle and its lovely grounds. Don't forget -- It's closed every Tuesday!
The palace offers some great photo opportunities and lets you wander freely and explore at your leisure!

The best of the old palaces here. While it will greatly underwhelm those who have been to the Forbidden City in Beijing, Gyeongbokgung is still a pleasant place for a tourist to visit for an afternoon. Definitely check out the changing of the guard ceremony. Also, you can get a photo with the presidential palace in the back.
I've been here before and it is great to see. Take into account that it's closed on Tuesdays. The palace has been rebuilt several times.

review_title: Gyeongbokgung Palace at Seoul, South Korea
review_body: THE GYEONGBOKGUNG PALACE AT SEOUL, KOREAThe Gyeongbokgung Palace was set up in 1394, and was the very first palace of the Joseon Dynasty (1392 to 1910). The four other royal palaces in Seoul are Gyeonghuigung, Changdeokgung, Changgyeonggung and the Deoksugung. These palaces are UNESCO World Cultural Heritage sitesGyeongbokgung was built by King Taejo, founder of the Joseon Dynasty, and is the grandest and most exquisite of all the palaces in Seoul. It is one of the finest examples of Korean architecture. Entry to the palace is via the main gate known as Gwanghwamun. It is made almost entirely of granite and is surmounted by a Korean-style twin roof. The palace buildings, on the other hand, are made almost entirely of wood, and are aesthetically painted with Korean motifs. Many of the royal family’s possessions have been transferred to the National Palace Museum of Korea, on the same grounds, where they continue to be on display. Thus, the main palace building is virtually unfurnished. The main palace building was the former residence of the Korean royal family. Alongside is the beautiful Gyeonghoeru pavilion and the well-manicured palace gardens, both of which retain their original charm. At the entrance are guards, as well as palace “officials” dressed n various colourful period costumes – primarily reds or greens. Tourists love to have themselves photographed by their side – such pictures having high souvenir value. However, the icing on the cake is the very elaborate ceremony of the Changing of the Royal Guards, performed three times a day. It is a journey back in time, to an era of pomp, glory and grandeur.The National Folk Museum of Korea,covered in a previous item, is also on the palace grounds. Hormuz P. Mama

Loved seeing this beautiful place nestled in the heart of such a cosmopolitain city. The architecture was breathtaking, with so much to see for a really affordable entrance fee. There were so many hidden areas to take photos without tourists all over. Had a great time.
Our visit was timed perfectly... not a huge crowd and pleasant weather. We enjoyed venturing on our own and seeing the beautiful gardens.

review_title: A huge palace in the middle of the city
review_body: The palace is huge and it takes time to go around it. There is a museum located inside, where you can see the history of the nation and what the ancient Korea looked like. Make sure you do not miss the shift changing of the guards at the gate of the palace. You can take photo with the guards as well, they wear the traditional clothing. Do not use selfie stick though, the guards will forbid you.

review_title: Impressive example of Korean classical architecture
