My husband and I braved the cold over the weekend to take an hour tour (in English!), and we are so glad we did! Our guide was knowledgeable, and it was exceedingly helpful to have the sites pointed out and the history and significance explained.
been here 3 times. each time i came back to visit i still got blown away. i love the architecture, the landscape, everything. would be nice to be come during spring or autumn!

I went on a tour of Gyeongbokgung Palace and it was amazing! I learned about the architecture and culture of Korea while learning about the history of the country. The palace is beautiful and offers a wonderful step back into history while one is completely surrounded by modern buildings.

review_title: Great place to start your korea trip
review_body: Make sure you join the 11am free english tour. Very informative and the best part it is free. Get to connect this with the gwahamun square, king sejong statute, admiral yi and the folk arts museum tour which are all interconnected.

review_title: Palace Attraction in the Heart of Seoul
review_body: If you have a few hours to admire nature and old buildings, do visit the Gyeongbokgung Palace. Be ready to walk though because the place is huge! You may want to come early to witness the changing of the guards at palace grounds at 10am and also play dress up with traditional royal guard costumes.

Hi. I was at this site on October 22, 2015. It's an amazing place which records the history of an important period of Korea history. The empire history. There are a lot of wonderful buildings with its old art and very special coloring and painting. Specially the throne Hal and the Emperor Hal and rooms. Also there are many statues and gargoyles. And many girls wearing the traditional clothes.
Great place to wander around. Lots of great people watching. Easy to get too. Well maintained facilities. Beautiful place to take pictures.

review_title: Probably the Seoul Palace you need to see.
review_body: Seoul has 5 palaces. This is the biggest and most important one, so if you want to see a Palace then this is the one to visit. Its pretty large with lots of beautiful buildings. I don't know what more to say about this place..We did pop into the adjacent Folk Museum which is included in the ticket price. This had some interesting things and worth an hour of your time.We bought some street food outside on the road after leaving the folk Museum. One type was like a round bread that is hollow in the center and the others were small round cakes with a jam inside. Both really tasty and cheap. This may have been the highlight of the Palace visit.
The place is amazing, what happened in the past wasn't so amazing, but the whole building itself is amazing.
This is one of several fantastic palaces around South Korea. It has been well maintained and is beautiful!

Gyeongbok Palace is a historical palace that been used for King in the past time. This palace is very big and consist so many building. Here we can see the Place for held a party, meeting, room for King & Queen and also rooms for King's Concubine. Here we can see so many important building.

Large territorial palace grounds with many gates to enter. I enjoyed walking around, though, I did not have enough time to see it all as it it huge. For that reason, I would recommend having around 3-4 hours designated for the palace and its ground. The palace consists of many courts, pavilions, bridges, gardens and walkways. It also houses the National Folk Museum and the National Palace Museum of Korea which I would recommend to visit as well.This Palace is very historical as it is main palace of the Joseon Dynasty. As the grounds are large, it requires a lot of walking; however there are benches and cafes around. It is wheelchair accessible.
One of the 4 Seoul palaces. Absolutely stunning. Located at the end of the big boulevard running from the city hall. Huge place, many buildings, all beautiful.
A place that must be visited in Seoul. You can sense the historical values as you walk in to this palace. Well preserved and interesting historical architecture.

If you wanna get nice pics of you and your friends in Seoul, this is one place to go. Make sure you go there on a good bright day, to get Instagram-worthy shots. There are always kids wearing traditional garbs, and they'd be more than happy to take pictures with you, which is nice. There is a big famous square right in front of the palace get, and you can continue the photo sessions there.
The photos speak for themselves. It was an enjoyable experience. A must see for those interested in Korean traditions, history and culture.

Seoul has the most amazing temples. This one was my favourite it was set out with a lake front with its reflection glittering off the surface. The architectural design of the temple was amazing with such detail put into each area of the temples it was truly outstanding.

review_title: Beautiful and full of history palace with an amazing pavillion and garden
review_body: Entrance fee was 3000 Won for adult, I somehow get a black and white guide book at the admission counter at 500 Won, don't do it, by you can get a briefer colorful version inside the second gate. Also there is a National Palace Museum of Korea which you can enter from the palace. If you want to go inside the museum, and walk around the palace a bit more, make sure you get back into the palace before 16:30 hrs. Otherwise, they won't let you get back into the palace again. The palace close at 17:00 hrs.

I loved all the palaces in Seoul, but this one absolutely exceeded all expectations. Well preserved and stunning architecture - colorful buildings with many interesting details. Beautiful gardens. Need few hours for a visit.

This palace is a must during any visit to Seoul. Friendly staff and very informative signboards help you navigate your way around the beautiful grounds.Make sure you exit out the back gate and take a look at the presidential residence.

review_title: Great place to visit in Seoul
review_body: Easily accessible attraction. Short walk from Gyeongbokgung station. There are many photo opportunities in the palace. Move further in there is another Korea Folk Village inside Gyeongbokgung Palace, free admission. I find the Korea Folk Village better than Gyeongbokgung.There are also free costume rental (5 mins) for you to wear and take photo near the Gyeongbokgung entrance. Limited pax for each time slot.Do stay for the guard changing ceremony. There are also free guided tour in the palace. Please check their website for more details.

We did the Secret Garden tour which was quite funny ("you have 3 minutes until we move on"!) and pretty interesting. The gardens were covered in a light dusting of snow as we were there in January and the stream was frozen, it was very pretty

I have an opportunity to visit this place on my trip to south korea. This place is so amazing! As a fan of some korean dramas like Jang Geum and Ju Mong, I really enjoyed the place. Like ive been in some history book or something. Admission is free during lunar new year, so i expected it to be full of tourists.

review_title: Historic and not to be missed
review_body: Maybe it was the fact that this was a somewhat spontaneous visit without detailed planning and we happened to hit it at the perfect time that the changing of the guard was starting, which was exactly when we arrived. Maybe it was that the weather was bright, sunny and perfect. I think it was more than that. This place felt magical. There was a peaceful presence that can't be explained but we both very much enjoyed it. I found the free English speaking tour also enjoyable and informative helping to bring me up to speed on the Joseon Dynasty. If I had one complaint, it was that the English speaking tour guide had a quiet voice and the sound system didn't help her much. The site is beautiful and historic and not to be missed in Seoul.

review_title: Plan ahead to make the most out of the visit
review_body: While it is possible to roam through the grounds on your own, I would suggest joining one of their free tour if possible to get the most out of the visit. Timing of the tours can be found at English website royalpalace.go.kr/html/eng/guideMaybe because this palace is pretty accessible, it is crowded with tour groups and visitors even though it is not a UNESCO site. So between Changdeokgung & Gyeongbokgung, I actually prefer Changdeokgung though Gyeongbokgung is more majestic for those structures which are completed (our tour guide says that it is only about 30% restored after being damaged during war times) You can get a combined ticket for 10,000won to visit 5 of Seoul's major cultural sites (Jongmyo, Changdeokgung, Gyeongbokgung, Gyeonghuigung, Deoksugung) which is more economical. Just remember to ask for it when you make your purchase at the ticket booth or the attendant will just dish out the single standard ticket. Alternatively, if you happen to be in Seoul during the last week of the month, you can gain entry to all cultural sites for free on Wed as the last Wed of each month is designated as their cultural day.

review_title: First day of korean new year- free!
review_body: It was the first day of the korean new year, hundreds of people flowing out of the underground to the palace- because it is free. The palace suituated right at the stop .There was a traditional dance going on, music with drums and a simple dance with people in hanbok. Then go into the musemun for a walk, it is well organised and worth a look.Insadong is situtated not far away so spent sometime there as well.

This palace basically composes of many temples, pagodas and more standing on sand. It just looks like an abandoned desert. They don't let you go into the palaces, so there's not much to see from the outside. The similar characteristics of different palaces and the lack of background information makes it a tourist site that is not recommended.Remember to follow a guided tour to have a better understanding of the functions of different structures. Or else you will find your visit boring and meaningless.

A beautiful main palace in Seoul. Several attractive shows are : the changing of Guard, the children museum (One of shooting location of Daehan Minguk Manse when they visit palace and Minguk get annoyed by the Train driver :D).The area is huge, so it's better to spare around 2 hours,especially if you bring many friends. The buildings're typical,but pretty. Not forget to mention the small lake located inside.

review_title: Very cool seeing history that did not start in the 1600's
review_body: Very large grounds with various out buildings. Seoul is such a modern city that there is very little that is "old" so it is a nice change of pace.

The palace itself was quite large with many separate sub-palaces. There was not many things to see within each small palace. However, the architecture was quite nice and great setting for photo taking if that is what you are into. There is a huge garden behind the palace. However, we could not afford the time to cover that.

review_title: Be amazed and understand South Korea's history with Gyeongbokgung Palace
review_body: Gyeongbokgung Palace is truly an amazing place. Once you get there, you will definitely picture out in your mind the setting of the King's feast, gatherings, important events and various historic activities that happened hundred years ago. It is such a wonderful and well-preserved tourist spot in Seoul. Though hundreds of people visit the place everyday, the people of Seoul makes a great job keeping the place clean and tourists friendly.

One of the main palaces in Seoul that every tourist should visit. The Changing of Guards, the Main palace and the grounds are a must see. You should wear thou a comfy pair of shoes since the area is wide. Great photos of the place are unlimited. Not recommended on small kids since they may not enjoy the whole experience.
We went to the Palace and the secret garden. It snowed for a short time and it was magical.The tour guide was excellent and we had an amazing time.

A beautiful structure that has been well-preserved and highlights the beauty of the ancient Korean dynasty that shaped the modern society to where it is today. Fascinating folk museum is right beside this palace and it is in reach of Insa-dong (the shopping area), restaurants and other interesting places, too.

review_title: Definitely beautiful, but similar to other landmarks
review_body: It's definitely beautiful, but if you have already visited other palaces in Seoul you won't be too impressed. Definitely worth visiting and taking some pics, but not a place to stay much, just a walkthrough.

I have been living in Korea for a few years now and am not particulary impressed with a lot of the temples in Korea. Most are not original and the result of mass reproduction. However, if you're going to see any temples, i'd suggest this one. Its one of the largest, with beautiful grounds, particularly in the sping and summer . The ticket prices are also very cheap to enter.
A place that you can find traditional korean culture. Hanbok wearing is fee of charge to get in.

Came here during the lunar new year. Entrance fee is free as its a holiday. So maybe if you do not want to pay for he entrance fees then go during holidays time. However no guided tour is conducted. Think it's because of the holidays, there is also stalls set up for both adults and children to make craft, eatery, writing wishes. Went to children's museum- if families travelling with children, it's another place can go and experience some of their games and play.
It was my first time in Korea, I love everything I've seen. Hopefully, I will have a chance to be there again.
Awesome place to go! You can see historic palaces and watch the changing of the guards. You can even rent a hanbok here and imagine you are apart of the history there.

The palace is so big and full of traditionally scenic paintings in its walls, attic, and rooms. From the tour guide, we could hear explanation regarding the reign and fall of the dynasty. We also could understand on how the relationship of the royal family and their warrior as well as their workers. On the palace yards we also could see digital brief explanation on the development of Korean people from the early stages in a museum, and we also could try playing traditional children game i.e. Circling a Top with skin-band, running a thin wheel with its steel guider, pointing steel-head wooden arrow to small steel basket, a swing, see-saw as well as playing a 'Katepok' (shuttle cock like game) with our ankle. This is great to reminding our children of the old fashioned game apparatus. The most interesting is the Palace provide us with traditional Royal Hanbok clothes for taking picture as a King and Queen of the day.We could also see how the traditional meals are cooked and served on the digital explanation in the Culinary museum nearby the Children museum in the Palace yard. By taking boxes of certain kind of meals from the cupboard, screening the barcode on the media, and we could see the meals prepared, cooked and served on the screen in front of us.
this palace located in the heart of Seoul,try to visit this Palace in the morning to avoid crowd.total time required to go around the complex will be around 45 minutes
It is an outdoor experience so I wouldn't recommend it to families with young kids. It is still amazing to find out about how the history was built in Kore.
Nice to wander around and to check that box. The changing of the guard is the most interesting part.

We arrived here a few minutes before 1 p.m. and were lucky to be in time for a FREE English speaking guided tour with the low price of paid admission. Allow at least 1 hour and wear comfortable shoes. HIGHLIGHT was all the other visitors from other Asian countries who wore special clothing gowned clothing to their tour and we took photos with all of them
Just a short walk from the Gyeongbokgung subway stop on the #3 line. Take exit door 5. You can spend a day touring the palace grounds and enjoying the museum. Seniors can enter without paying a fee.

My friends and I have this in our itinerary and I'm glad we did it. This Palace is so huge that I suggest that you should wear the most comfortable walking shoes you have! The entrance fee for the Palace is 3000 won and there is an additional fee for the secret garden. There's also a coffee shop in the middle of the Palace where you can rest and drink some tea. They also sells some souvenirs.
I whish come here once a time 'cause I love historical places and because of that I love Korea and living there.
If you have a chance to visit this palace, or I think you must visit while you are in Seoul. Guardian Exchange ceremony and Wearing Korean tradional costume are good to have experience.

review_title: Good to visit even if it has been reconstructed in the 20th century
review_body: This is a pretty impressive palace even if it has been reconstructed after centuries of destruction. Great layout and reconstruction but it gets extremely busy so go early

You can spend hours here, walking around, lapping up the grounds and buildings. It is really mesmerising to be immersed into the past, with huge skyscrapers towering over one side of the grounds, and mountains at the other. There are English speaking tours available at certain points of the day, and you can also watch the changing of the guard, which is pretty cool.The only reason I gave 4/5 is because if, like me, you have seen many temples in Korea, they all begin to look the same ha! This is definitely one of the very best to visit though - a must see for anyone exploring Seoul!

The area is big. But most of the building is closed. So much to see, only outside of the building. The only building we could see inside is the Throne, but the dragon on the ceiling is nice. There is a museum inside which has a nice display.

As I was born and raised in Seoul for 22 years, I can't be more proud of this beautiful palace of my city. I can surely recommend this place for who you are, where you from, and what you're looking for.

nice palace, to visit, you can see amazing korean architect.at the gate there are dressed up Guards- try to catch the changing of the Guards.there is also small village at the end of the place to see the tradition life of ancient korea
The palace provides visitors with a strong flavour of Korean history and culture. Let the guides take you on an extraordinary history lesson.
Its worth a visit to see the well preserved historic palace and to hear about its history. great wall painting on the ceilings.
The palace grounds were very expansive and maintained really well. You would need at least half a day to cover everything. We visited during winter so it wasn't too crowded.

review_title: Travel Back in Time, Great History Lesson
review_body: Our family really enjoyed the visit to the palace. Glad we joined the free volunteer guided tour which helped us learnt more about the palace, than just touring the surrounding. The palace is really huge, from outer court, to inner court, to every little corner of the palace, it tells us so much about how the royal family lived in the olden days. The tour guide was very patient and explained in great details of how the emperors lived, how the palace was managed, and how the princes/ princesses were brought up outside palace. We learnt a lot through this visit, and fell in love with Korean culture even more :) A must visit place, for someone who loves history - like me :)
Had a really good time here. Do wait and stay for the change of guard parade. Tradiotional korean costumes and drums.

We love to see the palace especially since we watched Korean dramas a lot. The admission fee was not expensive too and we really enjoyed ourselves there to see the rooms, structure, and architecture of the palace.Awesome place for tourist!
This place would look eerie and sad during winter. I've seen photos of this temple during spring and it was beautiful! I would prolly go back some other time when the flowers and trees are in bloom!
Definitely a must go to if you are a traveler visiting Seoul. Not too much to do though- you just walk around and look at the buildings and cant go inside them.

review_title: The Palace To See In Seoul
review_body: A large and beautiful palace complex in the heart of the historic district of Seoul. To make the most of the visit you must take your take to absorb the beautity of the place and understand its history. Large enough to spend several hours and be sure to catch the changing of the guards as well!

review_title: Not a must visit in Seoul but is okay to spend some time there
review_body: Largest palace in South Korea but for me is quite normal compare to the palace in China . From bukchon Hanok village , you can visit the Korea museum and finally the gyeongbokgung palace . If you are lost , you can ask the people around there , they are friendly and nice but not all of them understands English
We came at a very untimely visit. Temp is at -18. Can't feel my hands and my face. But the cafe located near the palace is great. Great souvenir items. You can buy a book if you're a bookworm.

This is the biggest palace in South Korea, if you really wanna explore everything and learn its history you could take up to half a day. I was lucky to be able to witness the guard changing process while also exploring the beauty of this palace. Going there in Winter also allowed me to slowly explore it without having to worry about the heat. If you're into history and culture, this place is for you

I visited this palace several times during my stay in Seoul actually but in August I had my favorite experience with an exclusive night visit! The park and main buildings are the most beautiful in my opinion and its location makes it the center palace even if Changdeokgung is supposed to be the biggest and most important one. I especially love the building surrounded by a lake next to the main one and in the park behind, the little tea house is just too cute for words. I totally recommend going there at night if you can catch the special events they're doing for this opportunity and coming at different season as well.

We visited on one of the free airport tours. We had a great guide who gave us some great information, but we were a bit exhausted to take it all in. I did enjoy the beautiful buildings (especially the colourful roofs), and the peaceful grounds. Definitely recommend a visit.

I went here because it was #1 on TripAdvisor's list for Seoul. I managed to arrive just as an English language tour was starting. The guide was knowledgeable and pleasant but she didn't really encourage questions. Of course it was cold and windy outside so that may have affected everyone. The tour and the overall exhibit are all outside so the weather on a particular day may affect your appreciation.I felt that I learned a lot of Korean history, especially the story of the invention of the Korean alphabet. Well done!

This place is for those seeking peace and serenity yet has a knack for Culture and History. Magnificent structure, no longer 100% original yet eloquently restored. It speaks a lot of the Korean ancestries' creativity and style. Learned a piece of their history even for a short span of time. Didn't know even the pavements speaks how they protect their royals.
If you are in Korea on vacation, you should definitely visit Gyeongbok Palace. Even if you live in Korea it is a great place to visit in the spring and fall.

review_title: Seoul Historic Tour through Koridoor tours is amazing!!!
review_body: I went on the Seoul Historic Tour through Koridoor tours on the weekend. I was going to like traditional Korean places, so it was so much fun. First, I went to the Jogyesa Buddhist temple, and I could understand of Korean Buddhism. There were also a bunch of great flower-decorations It was nice to see the temple in South Korea, and then we went to gyeong bok palace. Tour guide was explaining to us about Korea Choseon dynasty which was so impressed. We went to national folklore museum and then we went to the blue house and sa-rang chae. It was exciting to see all the presidents from the very first and currently one. I would love to go there again, when my friends visit to Korea next time.Thanks Koridoor Tours!!!!

Thsi is a great place to learn about korean history if you didnt know.There is a english tour around the premises for tourists and the tour guide speaks good level amount of englishits quite big but also you can go up close to some palaces and look inside- very interesting! i recommend visits! :)
You must visit. Strongly Recommend. Beautiful sight and palace. No need to explain. Only 3$closed every tuesday

review_title: Beautiful History in the Middle of a Metropolis!
review_body: I'm kind of a nerd for this stuff, but I really enjoyed touring the palace and watching the attendants reenact the guard changes and things. It's easily accessible through the metro, so if you're being a tourist in the city you have no excuse! But really... why would you want to miss this magnificent place for free anyways? The courtyard costs nothing to enter, and that's where the aforementioned reenactment occurred. Next to the palace is also the National Folk Museum of Korea (With FREE entry [which I separately reviewed]), which adds a little depth in exploring the history of this rich culture!

review_title: Yes, live your Korean Drama dream
review_body: If you can explore it for the day, try, its a lot of rooms. I have gone to China to see palaces, but this one had so many functioning rooms. We laughed as we walked recalling the Korean Dramas and we understood what "living outside the palace" meant. tons of rooms, different levels.. and adorable
A must visit place in Seoul! Amazing architecture and nice walk in the palace! Enjoy the dynasty feel and historic building.

review_title: Must See Palace While in Seoul
review_body: Wintertime is probably not the best time to visit but if it is your only option this palace is recommended. I thought this was the loveliest palace in Seoul. Due to limited time and it being a very cold day we only saw a small portion of the palace grounds. It is recommended that you bring cash to pay for the entrance fees as the credit card machine was not working the day we visited. We visited on New Years Day and there were many visitors. After visiting this palace walk south to visit Gwanghwamun square.

The palace grounds were a sight to see. If ever in Seoul I think it's a must. In a city that is full of innovation it's good to see where all can from. The grounds are vast and you are able to roam freely. The structures and mountains in the distance are ideal for pictures. And anyone of any age would enjoy this visit.

This was my first time to visit Korea, especially its capital city, Seoul.I wanted to explore by myself, but I didn't know where to start. So I looked it up and found good tour called 'Seoul Historic Sights Tour' provided by Koridoor. It was a small group tour with a group of 5. During the tour I have learned a bit of Korean History and the current Korea. Tour included one of buddist temples and the main palace then Blue house. It was great. Thanks to nice tour guide from Koridoor, I spent my time efficiently in seoul.

Gyeongbokgung is a huge place, and has a ton of buildings across it. The ones that can be seen into have gorgeous floors and some have authentic furniture to show how the residents lived. I just wish you could go into more of them, because there's only a handful you can even look into, so for the most part, you're just walking around inside the huge maze of buildings. When the flowers bloom, it's absolutely beautiful though. We have been several times and it never gets old.

review_title: Step back to see how Korean monarchies lived
review_body: Highly recommend visiting this stunning palace. Spend hours walking through the living quarters and palace grounds. The changing of the guard is also a must see.

Both of the times I have visited Gyeongbokgung Palace, the guided tours have been wonderful. The tour guides are funny and very well informed, and the traditional outfits they wear are beautiful. The guards out front keep a straight face even when you're taking pictures, and they look great. The palace itself is beautiful, and definitely worth the visit! Definitely wear sunscreen if you visit on a sunny day though!

review_title: Cater for one full day for this attraction
review_body: Gyeongbokgung is a huge palace in Seoul. Do cater for more time time to explore the palace. Join in the complementary tour to gain more insights into the various parts of the palace. Join in a tour of the secret garden in this palace, spaces are limited for this secret garden tours daily.
I love the Changing Guard Ceremony.Very lovely place and tour guides really hard to provide best services. Love it!!

review_title: History in the middle of the city.
review_body: A guided tour early in your visit to Seoul gives a basis and understanding of the history and culture of this proud nation. Easy to access and to move around, I appreciated the explanations of features I was given.

review_title: My wife wanted to see it...
review_body: As my wife likes history and has been watching some Korean dramas relating to this period in time, we had to come and visit when we visited Korea. We watched the changing of the guards and spent an afternoon looking around. It was okay, pity you can't actually go inside the buildings (which are empty). It would be nice to visit here in the summer months.

I joined the trip and english tour guide accompanied myself during the trip. From her explanation, i can learn many things about korean histories. They are also on the way to renew and rebuild the building,since some of them destroyed several times based on the history. It is a must have place if you visit seoul.

First time to Seoul and first time to their Gyeongbokgung place to let me have a better understanding about their Korea culture. This palace was a huge place, how the lifestyle of being a royal family. If you have not been Seoul before, visiting the palace is quite a good experience besides shopping. You can spend at least 2 hours or more there. To see their engraved geomancy rooftops, warehouses to store their stuff, traditional dances and their culture.

review_title: Beautiful visit as part of Incheon airport free transit tour
review_body: Loved this place. Beautiful palace. Watch the changing of the guards at 10am if you can. Can easily spend a few hours here. Very peaceful.

Visited this palace just two days ago and had a great experience. When I arrived, I was not allowed inside and quickly realized that I had gotten there just in time for the changing of the guards. It was a great site to see. I wish I had done the tour, but was satisfied that my admission allowed me inside the National Folk Museum.

review_title: Seoul Historic Sites Tour with Koridoor Tours was awesome!!!!!
review_body: I joined the Seoul Historic Sites Tour on yesterday, 20, Nov. It was so great time for me to learn about interesting history about Seoul. We went to Jogyesa Buddhist Temple and our tour guide, Haley explained about many concepts about Buddism and the palce as well. Visitng Gyeongbok Palce is one of the best moments for yesterday. Haley explained really well about Korean, especially Seoul histories, legends and even scret stories of each builidings and many things around there. Also, I felt like being in Chosun Dynasty when i was seeing the Royal guard change ceremony. The palaces and whole palace area looked sooooo beautiful it almost looked like a huge beautiful garden in the middle of this big city. So, this tour made my day yesterday and i want to join another tours which i could learn more about Korean culture and history.

There are a number of palaces in Korea, but this is the best of the best. It is the largest and is beautiful. They offer a daily changing of the guard show right inside the gate (free), but there are a lot of great photo ops and it is a wonderfully quiet place to enjoy, away from the noise of Seoul.
You just have to come here. It's one of the most picturesque places I have ever been in... Try to come early to avoid the crowds

review_title: Try and catch the changing of the guard!
review_body: Unfortunately most of this palace was destroyed so it's been rebuilt within the last 100 years. Although it's not 'original' it's very interesting and picturesque. We visited in the afternoon and got some amazing pictures at dusk. It's quite spread out so plan to be there for a few hours. There's a free walking tour in various languages at different times, I highly recommend it!! We arrived part way through the changing of the guard which was a bit of a bummer as its really theatrical. If you go look up the times and don't miss it.

The grounds and buildings are very well maintained - especially the gardens and detail paint work on the buildings, making you feel like your stepping back in time. The changing of the guards is a must see ceremony with the traditional uniforms that the guards are wearing.
For history lovers, this place is perfect for you. So many beautiful palace and its scenery. This place is so big, be sure to have a lot time to walk around this area.

review_title: Don't miss the changing of the guards!
review_body: Beautiful palace in Northern Seoul. Don't miss the daily changing of the guards ceremony. Entrance to the adjacent folk museum is also free and worth a visit
nice to spend 2hrs walking around. Do plan to time your visit along with the change of guards. it's on the hour.There's also free trying of guard costumes.

review_title: Best attraction for first time visit
review_body: Gyeongbokgung place is the best attraction for first time visit. It is located in the center of Seoul. Convenience transport and cheap admission fee.
The palace is beautiful, try to see the guard change it is really impressive and beautiful, colors everywhere.

review_title: Beautiful palace, pay little to take traditional Korean pictures.
review_body: There is a shop outside palace to rent Korean clothes for an hour to take pictures in palace which is worth and fun with great memories.
You much visit all palaces in Seoul. Palaces are must watch. The structure and the piece of art is something that you will admire. It is very peaceful place.

This was my second visit and it still takes my breath away,truly beautiful.There is a wonderful museum on the grounds and it is worth making sure to see the guard changing ceremony which occurs at 10am 1pm and 3pm. Closed on Tuesdays and entrance fee is only W3000 and museum is free,allow plenty of time as we were there most of the day as it's so big. Subway to Gyeongbok station Line 3 Exit 5 which takes you right outside.If you only visit one palace this should be the one.

So glad we were able to see this amazing palace in the center of Seoul with its fascinating history and beauty. Free English guided tour provided at different times of the day that last about an hour (last one was at 1430 the day we went) and covers the important points/areas in the palace. Go prepared to do some walking - large palace grounds - and early to avoid the afternoon crowds too!!!

Once you've visit Seoul. Do not forget to visit this palace. It's the best. There are some more interesting inside too, eg. National Palace Museum, Korea National Folk Museum, Korea National Children Museum.

We were visiting rainy day. It is beautiful and i really like palace's small lake and boat. Also palace ´s buildings are like a korean drama. It is so interesting. Myengdong street and king's (i don't remember king's name )square are very closer from here.

Very touristy yes but since this palace was like in the middle of city, it's kind if stepping back to old time. The must seen was the changing guard scene. The palace quite big spend like 2-3 hours there's a lot things to be seen if u into the culture type if not about 1 hour should be enough.

Even in the freezing winter days, this palace is still a worty place to visit. Quite a big ground to cover, its interesting to see inside the museum and when you re lucky enough they will open some of the palace doors to let you see whats inside. Its not much, but still interesting.

My second visit to Gyeongbokgung palace in Dec 2015. I was initially planning to visit Changdeokgung to see the secret garden but missed the guided tour for 2 days. Hence I took my friend to Gyeongbokgung - since it's the first palace built. Magnificient as ever and that again explains why I love korea. A mix of traditional within a modern city with lots of history and rich culture in it. This visit to Gyeongbokgung really got me so interested that I found myself reading up on the palaces, history till present day, traditions and culture about the charming city! ( It's the first time I got so interested in history).

Though this palace is worth visiting, I need to remind anyone who wanted to visit the sight should really wear enough clothes. The palace is not surround by any tall buildings so is cold inside. As for the free tour guide provided by the palace is good. One should go there if interested in Korean culture.Most important the guards exchange ceremony is something you dont want to miss. If you dont have enough time to enter the palace, do drop by to the exit of the palace and watch the ceremony. Is really traditional!

review_title: Probably the best royal palace in Seoul
review_body: Very large and well-maintained complex with multiple living areas, temples and garden areas. Worth visiting if only for the lovely large lake and wooded areas !
I love the changing of guards, I'm curious if they put make-up in their face and if their beards were true. And one thing, the guards and the police in Seoul are cute, do you agree with me guys?

review_title: Very nice palace, but filled with tourists
review_body: Highly recommend the guided tour for a better appreciation of the palace grounds and the various functions served by the buildings. They are free, so plan your visit to ensure you can catch the guided tour.There are also guard-changing parades at designated timings, so try to catch that too!The boulevard in front of the palace (GwangHwaMun) is also a very nice place to walk, with the famous giant statue of the King Sejong and an underground museum beneath it.
If you have free time in Soul you can visit for one hour ..but you should be careful about the weather

review_title: Back to the pass and dream to the amazing story
review_body: The palace devided into many parts. You can start from the main gate or from another entrance. The pavillion and all royal resident are really nice. You can walk arround and relax at some corridor. You can explore the palace within 2 hours or more.

Gyeongbokgung Palace is just amazing and was the definite highlight of our trip. There is a free English tour and our tour guide was really lovely and she talked us through the history of the palace and kept our group of around twenty people interested.
Try to read up a bit before going there because most of the information board/sign was shown in Korean. Overall, worth a try ! 3000 KRW entrance fee for Adult.

I've seen a lot of palaces in my life. This one is nice, nothing special about it. Of course that doesn't mean it's not nice... The buildings are very nice to look at and you can imagine the work needed to carve and paint it.

a lot of stories happened in this palace, i did the search for my luck , the place needs a Guide , you pay for the entrance also and remember doing the tour in the Palaces in SEOUL, take your Hat with you to kill the sun

We got lucky and visited on a Saturday when there were volunteer tour guides available (and they spoke English). It was amazing! We learned so much while we were there and the palace itself, even though it had to be reconstructed (that is a very sad part of their history) is absolutely stunning! It is amazing they were able to build such a place.

Some will tell say that there are other Joseon palaces in Seoul that are prettier than Gyengbukgong, but it is the biggest, grandest, and the archetype fr all others. The grounds with the various buildings are enormous, and we find new nooks and crannies every time we go. Make sure you leave time to visit the palace museum and folk art museum adjacent to the palce grounds.
Be prepared to walk for miles. This place is huge and beautiful. Lots of history in this place. You just have to be patient since they are spread apart. It is like a small city in a city.

review_title: Palace Structure and interesting and area is huge
review_body: It is interesting to see some of the palace building structure was built small and short older days and the interior was very detailed and colorful.The area is huge and do have your lunch before you go as you may need at least 2 hours to cover the whole area.Do ask the taxi to stop you at the main entrance not the side entrance to save time. There are a few modern buildings near the main gate to explore.

Definitely worthwhile to spend an hour or two visiting and take a break from all that shopping. You should try to sync your visiting time to catch the guards changing performance and follow through with a free guided tour of the palace.
The Gyeongbokgung Palace was so beautiful. My family and I were lucky to be able to visit the palace in the autumn. All the autumn leaves added even more beauty to the scenery.
I really loved the palace! The museum was really great. The show in the front courtyard of Palace was cool! Totally recommend. Very educational and tons of history.

This palace is the most famous in Seoul. One is really after not how the palaces look like but the fantastic ceremonies and shows which come with the palace. There are schedules for the changing of the guards and sword exhibitions in the morning and afternoon. Check their website for the exact time. We came in at 2pm and was just in time for the ceremony. Full costumes, parade of colors, and the use of rituals depict a lot of authenticity and appreciation for Korea's colorful culture. This is a really must-visit for history buffs, families, Korea drama afficionados, and those who are interested in Korea's interesting culture.

It is an eye opening to see the former Palace for the Joseon dynasty ruler. Though there are not many things to see within the inside those palace buildings, at least we can appreciate how the Korean wanted to preserve part of their heritage . The present day Gyeongbokgung had been rebuilt due to fires during the Imjin Waeran Japanese invasion 1592 -1598 and systematic destruction by the Japanese colonial govt from 1910 to 1945.

We got to the palace just as they began the changing of the guards ceremony. If you have the chance to see that, it's worth a wait. Behind the walls there are a lot of buildings, many of which are similar in design/structure -takes a while to walk around but I enjoyed seeing the traditional Korean buildings set against a beautiful mountainous backdrop on one side and the city skyline of Seoul on the other.

A nice palace, and also the change of guard duty are interesting. Also, you can try on to be the guard duty by trying their uniform! It's cool! But wearing the uniform in cold weather made me shivers so much. The palace is huge and has nice interior and exterior for photo taking.

The Palace is big and takes some time to walk around. While it is popular the really isn't a great deal to look at.An audio guide is available to hire or you can pay to dress up in traditional clothing.Pictures are available for free with the Sentry's standing at the front gate

review_title: Catch the Changing of the Guard!
review_body: I've been spoilt. Having lived and travelled in China for a few years, I have been fortunate enough to see a range of magnificent and quirky palaces and temples. This one is interesting enough, but not to the same degree (sorry, S. Korea). It has all been nicely restored and there is some interesting architecture but it appears to be a collection of similar buildings in a big dirt courtyard. Perhaps it was the time of year or because we didn't take a guide, but most of the buildings were shut and the open ones had little inside. No nice lakes, gardens, peculiar buildings or shrines and we felt we'd seen enough after about thirty minutes. HOWEVER, we were then trapped inside by the changing of the guard. The front of the Palace is guarded and the costumes are amazing. If you are that way inclined, you can get selfies standing right next to them. The changing involves many more soldiers than just the seven out front, all led by a traditional band that includes someone blowing a conch shell. Explanations are in English too so you can follow what it going on. One of the highlights of my trip.Note that it was free on the day I visited but I'm not sure why. Ticket booths were closed.

Whether it's your first trip to Seoul or you've been several but have never fit a trip to Gyeongbokgung Palace you have to visit. If you've been but never during the night, go again. The night views are the things postcards are made of. See the shows - we saw a drum exhibition. Excellent!!

There aren't many historical sights in Seoul honestly, but this is the main palace and one worth seeing. The guards staring straight ahead is a cool sight to see, and especially when the guard come out and do their routine. Cheap admission fee and a lot of space to walk around through. Go experience!

review_title: A nice walk in beautiful surroundings
review_body: This is an excellent place to visit for a good outdoor walk while taking in the sights of the beautiful palace. We loved all its colors and the views of the buildings with the hills in the background. It's only 3000 won per person, including the folk museum, so it's absolutely worth it!
Big and beautiful palace. Would be good to participate in the guided tours which would make your visit more meaningful

review_title: A traditional Palace nice to visit
review_body: Taking a metro would be the best way to reach Gyeongbokgung Palace, although I had some difficulty checking the right metro , & language is one of the obstacle.But I had a good time watching the parade, & drum performance - it's worth to spend 2-3 hours getting around .It's huge so take your time to take pictures of the Palace & surroundings. Bring some snacks or fast food.I enjoy visiting the Palace.

if you like traditional architecture and photography,this is the place for it. make sure you are wearing good walking shoes and bring some water with you and take your time. you can either follow a tour or go on your own.

We visited this place just a few days ago. We appreciate the intricate patterns of the roof tiles, the detailed balustrades and the stone paved courtyard. Very nice!. Koreans can always go back and learn their history as their ancestors painstakingly chronicled and preserved those write ups.
Fee apply. If you happen to visit, do spend more time here. The place is BIG that require a lot of walking.

There are too few cultural offerings in Seoul. And that is a pity. This is a work in progress and one that should be visited when in Seoul. Guided visits are particularly instructive and educational. This is definitely a beautiful monument that marks the history of the country. Go see it.

Love these historic sites, but the Northern Palace is severely lacking in signage. I suppose this is to help promote their tours and guided visits, but as a visitor who likes to independently wander, this leaves me with a sense of "...huh?" Nonetheless, I love that it's not crowded, and also very inexpensive (3000 KRW only, or about $3 USD). The Folk Museum admission is also included. Note to self....Perhaps I should have opted in for the tour....
Our family enjoyed the beautiful palace. We went on a weekday so it wasn't so busy and to my amazement there's free wifi :) on the property
Stunning relic, beautifully preserved. If visiting in winter, wear rain-appropriate footwear. Allow more time to inspect the exhibits in the Folk Museum, which is situated inside the palace.
If you're interested to know more about traditional Korean culture and experience the 'feel' of the olden Korean times then this is definitely worth a visit.
Nice day out to walk around the palace grounds. I find the explanation a bit lacking. If you did not have a guide, you would not be able to appreciate as much of the history
Very huge palace, so prepare yourself for the next 2.5 hours to go around the palace.Beautiful, and I love the attraction they have for changing guard.

We were late after a long walk from the bus station and could only see the last minute of the changing of guards. Already worn out, we only took some pictures with the guards standing there and walked in a little to get the feel. A place worth to explore more and we shall come again on our next trip to Korea.
do visit for a glimpse of korean palace history. I enjoyed the hour long palace guided tour tremendously. do check for the various timings available.

Came there as it's a tourist attraction. Although it's quite small, it's possible to know more about Korean culture. Anyway, it's a good place to take some photos for your vacation. In addition, you can get free entrance if you wear the Han-bok when visiting Gyeongbokgung Palace.

Came to watch the Changing Of The Guards Ceremony but was quite disappointed at how boring it was, considering the hype and other reviews. Felt cheated that I queued and bought the entrance tickets when so many others simply walked in without showing theirs due to how crowded it was. Beautiful place rich in history but not that great an experience.
Don't miss the guard changing ceremony at 11am, 2pm and 4pm.Take pictures with the guards at the main gate.It is also easily accessed via mrt line 3 to Gyeongbokgung Exit 5.And enjoy the palace.
The palace is so full of history and the Korean culture is so interesting. I spent half of day capturing it through my camera lens and could have spent another day.

The entrance fee is just $3000 Won. Very big had a few toilet which was very convenience for such a big palace. We meet two Korea ladies who also came to take photo in their nice Korea clothing, they are very friendly and we also took some photo with them. We have a fruitful outing to the palace.
They offer free tours several times a day. One might have a little problem understanding the guides English pronnounciation. Otherwise, it is a beautifull palace.

The palace is old and as advised by the tour guide, many areas were destructed in wars and the remains were not as grand as before. The place is not too large and touring can be done in an hour or so. However as the most popular tourist spot in Seoul, seems a must go. Don't miss out the change of guard every hour near the front gate. You can also walk to the Blue House at the back of the palace which is now the president's office.
Beautiful palace. Make sure you you're there for the change of the guard, as it makes the whole thing more special. The National Folk Museum is inside and also worth a visit.

review_title: Easy to Do on your Own
review_body: Do not join one of those tour package to join Gyeongbokgung Palace with the Blue House and the Yogyesa Temple. This is quite easy to do. You are there once you get out of the metro. Be there 11 am for the free guided tour in different languages. And close to lunch time (please check the exact time) you have the changing of the guards which was quite nice as they wear local costumes. Make sure you keep the tickets too as you will need to show this to get back the Palace ground when you go see the Blue House.

We visited the Gyeongbokgung Royal Palace in October 2015. Due to our limited time we did not enter the palace which I think requires 1-2 hours to explore. So, even if you are in rush, you may still wish to consider visiting the exterior part of the palace to admire the architecture and history. You can reach the palace taking Subway Line 3 to Gyeongbokgung Station. It is directly connected to the Palace and to the National Palace Museum of Korea (less than 5min walk). I recommend buying “SEOUL CITY PASS” ( 25,000 won per person for 2 days) which allows you to use the subway and trains for up to 20 times a day and also allows unlimited use of the public buses.

This is the main palace in Seoul. The grounds are vast and it contains multiple rows of buildings and walkways. You can spend several hours strolling through them and taking pictures. The mountains in the backdrop make it for a very picturesque scenery that allows the photographer to experiment with different angles and light. I truly enjoyed the experience, despite the bitter cold and lack of greenery in early December.
Not to be missed when you visit Seoul. We recommend that you do the free guided tour which is very useful to understand the historical background and the architecture.

review_title: A great place to get a feel of traditional Korea
review_body: When visiting the palace, you should definitely time your visit so that you will get to see the changing of the guards. It's on multiple times a day but you better check the current schedule for it. The location of the palace is great, as it's right in the heart of Seoul - easy to find if you can find the statue of Sejong the Great.The whole area of Gyeongbokgung is huge and there's a lot of place to explore so go early and take your time. At the end of the palace grounds, there's also a museum that's definitely worth a visit. Insadong is within walking distance with it's shops and restaurants, so you can easily spend the entire day around this area.

Exquisite artwork stunning architecture and a great way to learn about Korean history. It's dead center so you can enjoy the historical aspects of Korea and then walk down street and find a really amazing restaurants

review_title: Pleasant place for a morning stroll
review_body: Check the timetable for the free guided tours. Although the scale of the palace is rather small, but definitely worth visiting for a quick korean history class.

review_title: Quite large complex, but expecting more
review_body: This was a great place to visit but I was expecting just a bit more. Maybe more luxury or Artistry than other places I've been. Don't get me wrong, this place is great to admire. I was banking is spending at least 3 hours and I was done by 1 1/2 and that's included the change of guards. Bring your comfortable shoes and don't worry about the collection of dirt and dust

review_title: A must visit for all tourists!
review_body: A beautiful serene and tranquil place to get away from the city though surrounded by buildings. The place is decorated with a beautiful past of the Joseon Era and superb place for phototaking. Don't forget to watch the guards changing ceremony at 1pm at the main square. Conveniently located near a subway station. There are other museums nearby if you have of plenty time to walk around.

review_title: Easily accessible, grand and huge area
review_body: Easily accessible by subway at Gyeongbokgung station.Grand palace and huge area to walk around. You can go to the National museum next to it and there's a cafe next to the museum for you to fill your stomach.

The train station (line 3 - orange line, exit 5 Gyeongbokgung Station) leads you right to the palace grounds. It was so convenient. If you time your visit, you could witness the changing of the guards. Also, connected to this is the National Museum and outside the gates are the monuments of King Sejong and Admiral Sunshin Yi.

The Royal Palace is a must see when in Seoul but give yourself plenty of time because there's a lot to see. Upon arrival, don't be discouraged if there are a lot of people out front. Once inside, you won't notice them because the Palace sits on a sizable amount of land. It's also incredibly quiet inside, which was amazing because there is much traffic and noise right outside. There a many buildings to see when inside the gate and try to see the pavilion in the moat off to the left. This is a beautiful area. Make sure you look up while looking inside the buildings as well and outside the buildings. There are many detailed carvings and paintings all around. The grounds are beautifully manicured as well and very clean. We didn't receive a map when we arrived so you may want to get some info off the internet before you go. I believe there are several hundred buildings to see. There is a gift shop and museum. There are also live soldiers posing out front as statues.

For a small fee you can enter the main complex and you may even catch the free english (or Chinese) tours. There is a the changing of the guard ceremony which occurs a few times a day. The complex is large and you can easily spend hours wandering around.

We arrived at this palace around 3.00 p.m. We watched changing guard ceremony. We thought our kids will be bored to see that, but they loved it. The palace are so big. If you don't have time to look around, just visit the gate (gwanghwamun), geunjeongjeon, gyenhoeru, hwangwonjeong. There is national folk museum and national palace museum in this palace.You can reach the palace by using metro subway, stop at gyeongbokgung (line 3) exit 5.
It's my third visit and this place never fail to impress me. I was here during Spring, Summer, Autumn. Avoid the main stretches as it will be filled with tourist crowd.
The palace is soooooooo big and that we didn't finished it by 3 hours? Omg. Well, it's really a worth place to visit and I enjoyed a lot there especially inside the museum in the palace!

review_title: A good experience of history within the city
review_body: The visit is not free but I feel it's worth visiting. Always nice to know how the people in the past (rich or poor) lived and how they contributed to what we see today.

Interesting tradition displayed.You must know the specific time of the guard exchange ceremony. Otherwise, you will have to wait for a long time. Visiting the palace is considered incomplete without seeing the unique ceremony. A good thing is that the announcements made are in 3 languages - korean, japanese and english language.Don't forget to bring your sunglasses...
As a part of your tour to Seoul you have to go to visit the palace . I front of the palace there is an exhibition try to visit it is free of charge and open until 6 pm . The palace is closed at 5 pm

Gyeongbokgung is an excellent place to visit not because it is the oldest, grandest, prettiest or historically most relevant. It is an excellent visit because you are allowed to roam around to explore the palace without many "keep out", "do not enter" signs. You can see how the whole palace is put together by looking at it from different angles. You must also make sure to book your guided tour to the Secret Garden. We were there during the Fall and the color of the leaves brought out the best of the garden. If you have time to read a little about the Korean history, it will definitely add to the experience.

review_title: Nothing much to see. Free tour guide gives more insight
review_body: Well, there is really nothing much to rave about in this palace. Maybe because I have been to other asian palaces and therefore have high expectation. Though I must say that the free tour guide provided at the information centre is very good. It gives an insight to the palace and gives understanding to some of the building structures, such as chimney towers that are not noticeable. Heating under the building provided via tunnels. To its defence, I supposed because the palace was burnt down during the early Japanese/Korean war, much of the original details in the palace was missing. There is not much grandeur that you would expect from a royal palace. It is still a good place to visit to understand the historical way of life of the monarch during that time. Check out the free tour time table to ensure that you do not wait too long.

An incredible place that is so peaceful! Definitely a must see when in Seoul! This place is exactly what you think of when you think of Asia, beautiful palaces on a tranquil pond and if you're there during early spring during cherry blossom
Beautiful palace walk and nice photo shoot. This place is easily accessible by the metro, ask your hotel staff for directions.
My sister and I enjoyed visiting the palace. We took a free English walking tour of the place and this helped us to learn about the history.
Not a place for kids for sure but those who love to take photograph, it provide vibrant colour and excellant architectural piece.

Went on a chilly December Saturday. Lots of people there but it's a big place. A volunteer tour guide met us at the subway station and walked with us, explaining in English what we were seeing. She was great, and only 14!Chinese style palace, so you keep walking through more and more court yards, each dominated by a higher and more important building. Nice, natural setting with mountains in the background. Particular features are the roof decorations and the underfloor heating systems. Thanks to our young guide for pointing them out.Look out for the pavilions that stand on ornamental ponds. Imagine yourself in the palace's heyday, enjoying the views and relaxation of these pleasure pavilions. Unfortunately, you need to imagine, as only the reconstructed buildings and the mountains are left.Easy access from the subway station and a couple of museums nearby. Together they can fill most of a day.

review_title: Go on the free guided tours given in multiple languages
review_body: This was our first tourist stop in Seoul. Many great photo opportunities and unless you read up ahead of time the guided tour worth it to explain the layout. We went early am to avoid crowds. As we left, the tour buses were beginning to pull up.

Gyeongbokgung Palace is centrally located near the heart of Seoul, is inexpensive, and is a wonderful example of the beautiful historical Korean architecture that epitomizes the ancient Silla Kingdom. A great place to stroll if the weather is good. Try to time your visit to include the changing of the guard.

review_title: A historical palace in the center of city
review_body: It's a big palace complex make sure to wear your comfort shoe. Not a lot to say since I compare it with Tiannanmen in Beijing. The feeling more or less the same with slightly diffrent characters of building.

We going for winter vacation on december in Gyeobgbokgung palace korea, wheater 1 - 3 degree celcius. Bring your therma jacket along, hand glove , hat to avoid cold here. Their service is only to 5 PM then close

Well if you like walking around and looking at some nice Buddhist architecture, this is a cool place to go. It wasn't a huge thrill or anything so you have to be into the history and the meaning of the place if you want to get a kick out of it. For me it was a nice place to take pictures.

review_title: First time a night visit to the palace
review_body: I was surprised to see that the palace was open for visitors at night. all the buildings were illuminated. I had a very good opportunity for very good night shots of this magnificent place.

It was a cold rainy day on my visit, so it kind of ruin my visit. The guide armed with an umbrella seemed oblivious we are getting wet and cold . So, we tried to keep up with her and wishing for shelter and hot coffee . The structure is beautiful but also sad that a lot of the buildings were destroyed before. ... do come , on a nice sunny day. There is a nice walnut pastry shop from gyeongbokgung stn exit 2 ...cocohodo....its absolutely delicious and you can walk down further to Tongin market for their famous dosirak lunch tray

It's Seoul's Northern Palace and subsequently also the largest palace in Seoul. There isn't much to say about the Palace other than that you need to go if you're traveling in Seoul. The grounds are huge and the buildings are beautiful. Yes, there are quite a lot of people, but that is to be expected. If you really really dislike crowds, I would suggest the Changgyeonggung Palace (just east of Gyeongbokgung) however this palace is not nearly as impressive.
An interesting place to visit, they said that in ancient times the square represents the earth while the circle represent the sky...

Gorgeous views all around at this palace. A lot of people were here, but the grounds are so large that they were spread out pretty well. We went in November so the trees were those wonderful fall colors and made for spectacular pictures. The admission is cheap (3000W) and the tours are free if you wanted to do that. One problem was that there aren't any signs around to explain to you what each building was. Therefore, we were going to do a tour, but as my boyfriend could read the Chinese above the doors, we didn't actually need to do it. The palace is right next to the Bukchon Hanok village, Samcheondong, and Insadong so we visited all of these places in one day. For those of you that count steps, you get a TON of walking doing this haha. So definitely wear comfortable shoes. All in all a really great tourist attraction. I recommend visiting in the Fall.

we went there with my husband during summer time.i wouldnt recommend going there summer time as it is super hot,dry and humid. You'll be walking so much. I love seeing the palace and walk around but i wish they had more stuff inside the big palace for us to see and we could go inside. But this place is a must! Just go one time.

review_title: Make sure you see the guard changing ceremony!
review_body: Guard ceremony at the entrance is definitely something to plan your trip around. The palace grounds are beautiful and we learned a lot about korean royal history. The audio guides are great. There's a museum inside the palace, which takes around 45 to 60 minutes to walk through. Highly recommended!!

Large grounds. Tough with a toddler in a stroller over some terrain but lovely buildings. Thought there might be more gardens etc but overall very picturesque and a must see. Audio guide worth doing. Wear comfortable closed in shoes. Can get muddy. Changing of the guard also good to see.

For those who are taking their first trip to Korea should really visit this place. Lots of history, lots of nice preserved architecture and you get to see what's it like back in the days because the staff would wear the traditional outfits as well a small ceremony performance.

Our First tour of Korea is the visit of the Gyeongbokgung Palace. This historic palace was once the home of the Kings has several small palaces scattered in a large area and secured by high fortresses. Our Tour Specialist, Kris, of This is KOREA, told us that the main palace was destroyed by fire and was rebuilt to its original grandeur. The interiors made of big planks of hard wood of the main palace is very simple but the roofs have very intricate carvings and paintings. I'm fascinated with the in-house heating system located beneath the palace floors. They burn wood to create fire that will provide the heat. Don't miss also the Queen's garden located at the back of the Queen's quarters. The palace is located with a picturesque landscape. There's a mountain at the back and the moat around one of its palaces add to its beauty. If you're lucky (just like us) you can witness the exchange of guards ceremony held during the specific time of the day. It was almost lunchtime when we saw this ceremony. You can take pictures with the guards after the ceremony. Near the palace is the presidential mansion of Korea. Also called the "Blue house" because of the color of its roof. You are just permitted to a certain area where you can take pictures. The mansion is highly guarded. The Palace has enough space for parking small vehicles. However, I saw Tourist Buses parked outside along the side street. There's also money changer inside the premises beside the Ticket station.

review_title: Beautiful but gets really crowded in the main area
review_body: This palace was beautiful! As there are so many palaces around in Seoul and we were pressed for time, we only managed to visit this one because we spent a longer time there than expected but no regrets! The grounds are massive and if you can spend the time, don't rush and walk around to discover the gardens and other smaller outbuildings. We spent some time in the Crown Prince's garden (towards the right when you just pass the main building) and it was just beautiful. You can even pack a lunch and have it on the benches under the pretty trees if you like (we saw some locals doing it).
A well maintained temple that offers a glimpse into the history of the country. A large spread out area with many buildings to see, so make sure you allow a decent amount of time to get around

The palace is huge!!! It has interesting architecture and beautiful garden. There are also various cultural and art performance, including the change of guard ceremony that is very delightful to watch.

This place is super cool. It's about $8 to visit. English yours are available and the culture museum is included in the price. The walk around the gardens and grounds is perfect for a warm sunny day. Make sure you stay and watch the changing of the guards and get a pic with one of them.

review_title: A cold December day but a great find
review_body: We visited in early December. It was cold enough that the ice was frozen over on the pond. We arrived just as the actors were coming out and putting on their show. There was no crowd so we got a great view. Walking through the facility was a joy and you can go just about anywhere in the facility. Parking was easy and it was relatively cheap. I don't remember what it cost, but it wasn't even a second though to pay.
This palace is really huge. The architecture is awesome. If you are lucky, you can see live changing guard ceremony.Only pay 3000₩ for entrance fee.Please wear something comfortable.

It's huge, so prepare the most of the day for taking the tours. Make sure to bring water with you. Bring a lot!!Read about the palace in advance so you can enjoy your visit. It's worth all the time and the tickets are cheap. Btw. Buy a group ticket for all the great palaces because it's a money saver. Also bring your Korean friends with you, they can enter for free if they're under 25, and accompany you even on English tours.

review_title: Difficult to appreciate if going on your own
review_body: i don't know Korean language so i hope that when visiting a historic site, i would have english signs to read, but i don't foun many except name signs. you will have free map and a small guidance to look at, an if you have the patience you can open it, see where you are standing and read about it though. still, many buildings look ...just the same for me and i dont really get the sense of it.but the place is very broad and it were hard for me to do so when one hand is busy holding the umbrella and shopping bags .it was rainy and i found the walk quite exhausted. so i don't recommend shopping before going to the palace.
This is nice place to stroll even on rainy days. Make sure you either get guided tour or audio translation. You will learn history and behind story related to each sights.

We visited the palace when it was snowing. Although the guard changing parade was cancelled due to the snow, we were not disappointed. The snow transformed the palace and its ground to an amazing sight! We joined the English tour and it was very informative.
if you can get a local of hire a guide...would pobably help...my friends knew what was happening and the different buildings ...great day
This place next to the national folk museum of Korea. i didn't really enjoy this place because i came to this place at the end of november and already cold and windy.
great spot for photo opportunity. accessible by subway thru anguk station. i think the entrance fee is about 3,000 kwn per person. not too large but good enough for a brisk walk around.

review_title: Beautiful Palace. Nice 'Changing of the Guards' show. LOL!
review_body: DATE VISITED: November 18, 2014PROS: Amazing place in the Heart of Seoul. Beautiful Palace. Wait for the Changing of the Guards at around 3:00/4:00pm. It's worth watching!CONS: Too many people. Some tourists don't know how to follow order to discontinue from walking in and out of the site where Changing of the Guards took place. Geeez!LOCATION: 5/5PRICE: 5/5HOSPITALITY: 4/5ATTRACTIONS: 4/5

It is autumn season when i visited, lot of beautiful leaf and plant.. breath taking garden and building. Tips: It will be free entry if you are wearing Hanbok. So dont be shy, try to wear Hanbok and visit this place. it will be a lot more interesting.

Elegant little palace in the heart of Seoul. Find tranquility from madness of Seoul in the quiet grounds of Gyeongbukgung Palace. Must remember though, Korea was never as big as China so it's no Forbidden Palace but beautiful and significant all the same.
A place definitely worth a visit if you are in Seoul. It is however a pity that you as a tourist are not allowed to enter any of the buildings.

The palace grounds are huge. Don't try and do this on your own. You need a guide to explain the layout and importance of the architecture and history. Be warned - the steps can be high and tricky. Wear comfortable shoes and take it at your own pace. Visit the Korean Folk museum to get an overview of life. Also, there's another museum by the main gate that features some of the royal cars. The changing of the guard is impressive. Don't expect the huge pageantry of Buckingham Palace. This is a much smaller ceremony worth viewing. If you walk all the way to far back corner, beyond the lagoons, you get a great view of the current Presidential House. Be sure to keep your ticket with you.

Visited the palace in November and the autumn leaves were simply stunning. Also recommend catching the tour - it lasts about an hour and gives you an overview of the various buildings within the grounds.

review_title: Not good for wheelchair old folk
review_body: This is not easy for wheelchair although they provide wheelchair. The rocky uneven road made difficult to push the wheelchair.
Really nice place.. If you love the story of Korean Joseon dynasty, here is the must to visit in Seoul.. You can try Korean hanbook for free here..

review_title: Plan 1/2 to 3/4 of a day if you want to see everything at Gyeongbokgung Palace
review_body: Gyeongbokgung Palace (₩3000 for adults) is the first royal palace built during the Joseon Dynasty. Recognised as a UNESCO World Heritage site, this large compound provides several hours worth of grounds to explore and enjoy during visits to Seoul. Opening Hours are 9am to 6pm daily. Highlights of Gyeongbokgung Palace include the imposing Gwanghwamun Gate, the main entrance into the palace grounds. This is also where visitors can witness the Changing of the Guards ceremony several times a day (11am, 2pm and 4pm). Entering Gwanghwamun Gate, you find a large open courtyard and ticket office. You then proceed through Heungnyemun Gate to begin your visit to the palace grounds. The complex is laid out on a central axis, creating nice spacing and harmony between the palace buildings, various structures and waterways. You will want to see the centred Geunjeongjeon Hall. This is the Throne Hall building. Like most buildings within the palace, you can't enter. However, there are openings so that you can peer inside and take a few photographs. Do take a few minutes as well to admire the building and courtyard architecture. There is much symmetry in the design and delicate nature to how the buildings were decorated. Of the other national treasure buildings here, we much enjoyed seeing Gyeonghoeru Pavilion which is based on a small lake. This is a lovely setting and enjoyable place to rest at a lakeside bench and just admire the views. For those who enjoy water and gardens, in the back of the palace grounds, you will find the delightful Hyangwonjeong Pavilion, which is on a bridged islet in a middle of a small pond. This is another of the lovely places to see at Gyeongbokgung Palace. If you are a fan of museum visits, there are two within the Gyeongbokgung Palace. These are the National Folk Museum of Korea and the National Palace Museum of Korea. These provide opportunity to learn more about palace life and the role of the royal families in shaping Korean history. Overall, Gyeongbokgung Palace is a must-see World Heritage area in Seoul, especially for first time visitors. Due to its scale, you should allow at least a couple hours for your visit even if you are limited in time. If you want to visit leisurely, you could easily spend 1/2 - 3/4 of day here. Note: There is a particularly useful Royal Palace website with map and diagram of the various palace buildings, gates, halls and pavilions which you can browse around and see at Gyeongbokgung Palace. It is well worth investing some time on the website prior to your visit if you want to be best prepared beforehand.

I think 95% tourists visiting Korea will go to this place! The palace is very beautiful and it's really close to another attractions such as Gwanghwamun Square, Insadong, Bukchon Hanok Village etc.Make sure you check the ceremony schedule for royal guard changing in front of this palace, it's really exciting to see tho.

review_title: A must see palace in Seoul
review_body: This is one of may favorite places to visit in Seoul. It's beautiful and steeped in rich history. The guided tours in English are wonderful. I would definitely recommend going.
A stunning palace experience. It was pure joy, wandering around the grounds and looking into the buildings on the Gyeongbokgung grounds. A must visit for anyone in Seoul.

Close by to our hotel in Jongno-gu. We could have gone by subway or chosen to walk. As we arrived there was a changing of the guards. Make sure to have a photograph taken beside a guard. The inside of the palace grounds is enormous with an attractive lake like area at the rear. Be sure to allow an hour or two to wander around the surrounds. The entry fee is quite reasonable and you will find an appealing cafe/gift shop towards the centre of the grounds.

Had a friend guided us here which is wasn't far from our hotel in Myeongdong. It was a good walk and we just arrived in time for a guard change. We didn't make it around the whole place but it was great to look around a traditional area and landscape. It started to rain so it was cut short and could only spend an hour before close but I would like to visit again. Took some really nice photos.

This is well worth the effort to see while you are in Seoul South Korea. Make sure you go to the front and watch the changing of the guard. A few minutes before the changing of the guard they march in the side yard.
It's a lovely palace located in center of Seoul. To get there you can just use the seoul subway line 3 exit 5. The view is so amazing, and you can see the attraction also if you are lucky.

This is a majestic palace. It basically is the 'heart and soul' of Korea. There is a historical significance to the palace that makes you stop and think about the history that took place in the palace. It was a worthwile half day excursion and I do recommend going when it is nice weather - not too hot or cold.
If you like historical places, try this. A huge place and connected to the Folk Museum of Korea. Very interesting.
