We had previously visited the Changdeokgung Palace and felt that this palace was pretty much the same only larger with far more tourists. My conclusion is if you have time for only one palace, go see Changdeokgung instead. It's only about a kilometer or so up the street. Anyway - we did enjoy the visit here and found some spots not completely mobbed by tourists. There were lots of teens in hanbok which leant an old world authenticity to the site.

review_title: Great Palace in the center of Seoul!
review_body: Conveniently accessed by public transportation and close to a bunch of other attractions like Bukchon Village and Cheonggyecheon Stream, I would suggest to head out early to Bukchon Village, enter Gyeongbokgung Palace and head out to Cheonggyecheon Stream for the evening. The palace is beautiful but can be very full at times, but try to see as much of the buildings as possible, especially the Gyeonghoeru Pavilion and don't forget to see the re-enactments of Korean royal guards in the court yard.

review_title: Great place to start your adventure in Seoul
review_body: I love this place . Tuesday are off so better come other day . Entry fee is 3000 KRW. Amazing palace I like the environment here surround by tree and u can see the magpie and squirrel. U can rent the hanbok there and take pic .

So much fun, what a great piece of history! Do the guided tour to learn more about the culture and how Korea became. There is also a area where you can dress up as a guard right when you walk in on the left... Must do!! Find the falic garden.... Great place for pictures!

This place were huge. Nothing much to see or do here. Empty buildings, dull ground. There are beautiful lake and small cafe. i went here in spring season . Weather kinda hot. This area will be hotter in summer because the surrounding are plain desert.

This is one of two main palace in Seoul but is more prominent. I would choose this location as it is closer to other sites such as samcheungdong and everything can be done in a day. There's a little confusion to where the entrance is as we were looking for the ticket counter. That is actually inside and there are many ways to get in from the front and southeast and southwest area.
Like the every bit of the view and the palace. What a technology and I liked the way solders shifted their timing.

It's worth to pay a visit here. Quite a big compound with scenic view and historical buildings. Get ready to spend 2-3 hours walking around. Remember to take along the brochure at the ticket counter if you were interested to know the history as there is no notice board that put aside for you to read. Do plan your visit to align with the guard changing ceremony. One thing disappointing is some of the buildings are closed for visit.

Visited on a rainy day so maybe that is part of the disappointment.Other than change of the guard did not see anything too exciting other than the main area.Very little offered in English so had difficulty understanding the context.I you have to choose one, go for the Changdeokgung Palace instead.

South Korea is very much famous of its heritage such that it will always be a good idea when visiting to this country to go to the palaces. Gyeongbokgung Palace is one of the famous palaces in South Korea. The place is big and you can explore. It is good to go there in the morning. There is an entrance fee of 3000 KRW.

I love to see history and building structures and all.However, I am slightly disappointed with Gyeongbokgung Palace as most of it places are close to public.Noone is allowed to see what it is inside. So for me, it is a turn off.This trip is more of like a trip to see building, lakes, and park, and nothing about the palace.

This was a palace in the era of Joseon Dynasty which is well maintained. There are two lakes with gazebos: Kyunghoilu and Hyangwonjeong. These two lakes are very beautiful. From time to time, this place is open to the public at night times and you should book at the designated dates if you want to see it. Especially, the night views of these two lakes are the most beautiful. Many photographers gather to take pictures of them.

The palace grounds was very huge but every check point is about the same.the king's chambers, the queen mother's chambers then the concubines' chambers. They all look the same. I was a bit disappointed to find out that almost the entire place is rebuilt, it's not the original palace but it was burnt down during the Japanese invasion. and they're not done adding on new segments of the palace. entrance fee is pretty cheap. the architecture seems pretty normal. probably the more interesting thing to do here is to try on the palace guard uniform for free and witness the guard changing ceremony. give this a miss if you are not into touristy stuff.

review_title: Glimpse from Korea's Past - Is it like a Forbidden City?
review_body: Great place to visit and have an early morning walk. Easy to reach, but not too much to see. This palace is not that huge as you may think but its architecture and design is quite interesting. It feels kind of empty but the scenery is beautiful. Recommend for first time travelers to Seoul.

review_title: The grounds are just as worth visiting as the Palace
review_body: We enjoyed the buildings all around Seoul, but what was even better were the grounds of the palace (trees, lakes, etc.) - especially in mid-November as the leaves were all changing to incredible colors of red, yellow, orange. Endless incredible photo opportunities.

Was there in mid September, the weather was just nice for a morning stroll of the palace. Nicely replicated buildings n landscaped gardens filled with rich history. We joined a free guide tour when there. It was an informative tour indeed ... You get to learn not just the history but the clever olden days architecture design of the buildings catering to the different Seasons of the year, and the interesting culture of the palace.Do go there in the mornings when there's lesser crowd. Do check out their Seoul tourism website on the timings of the free guided tour and the days which the palace is open at night for visits.After visiting the palace, do pop over to Samcheong dong which is east of Gyeongbokung ... just a short distance from the palace. It's a little quaint Neighbourhood filled with little art galleries, shops, cafe, restaurant. Be prepared to do walk hard as it's road are straight but has many slopes.

review_title: A wondrous place. Great for photo ops.
review_body: I walked to Gyeongbokgung Palace early morning from my Lotte Hotel (Fantastic Hotel by the way, one of the nicest I've stayed in anywhere in the world for a reasonable price). During the week day in early morning in the October there was very few people inside the walls of the palace. Made for a great morning visit of solitude, learning history and photo opportunities. As the morning progressed the palace became more crowded with tourists and school tours. If you are in Seoul the Changdeokgung Palace is a must see.

Suggest to visit this Palace on the first few days of your trip and walk all the way towards the back where the pond is located. The palace is very well maintained. Looks very similar to other Asian Palaces. There is a train station entrance by the museum beside the palace too

While I was looking forward to this trip, I did not have any expectations whatsoever so as not to ruin the mood. This is the second palace I visited, and it lies just in front of two statues, one of the admiral and the other King Sejong, seated in a chair, and founder of the Korean alphabet. The ticket entrance was 5000 won, a bit hefty if you ask me. The tour started and I joined a tour with an English translator, kudos to the translator for really trying to explain the history and details of all the buildings. The architecture and style can somewhat be likened to those found in Shanghai and Beijing, maybe because of cultural influences. I was a bit disappointed though because of the lack of English descriptions of each of the place. Signages are also scant in the area and be ready to endure long walks! I suggest going here in the morning or early lunch time so that you can have time to visit the blue house which the guide said was one gate away only from inside this palace. Unfortunately, I didn't see the blue house. In total, I find this palace, nothing special, an average if you ask me, but I commend the departments involved here for really making sure to preserve the edifices. So, in going to Seoul, choose wisely which among the palaces you'll be visiting. This one would not be in my list again.

Visitors should put this Seoul attraction on their list. For amateur photographers, it's provides a good opportunity to experiment and compose picture perfect shots. Take note of the schedule of the very colorful and ritual-driven Changing of the Guards as this is one activity that visitors to the attraction musn't miss.
This is a very huge complex of buildings, accessible from the Geongbokgung station. Ther is also a folk art museum and a palace museum inside.

It's a very big palace, you need at least an hour to walk inside and see whole area however it's beautiful especially during spring / autumn. It's better to visit in the afternoon so you can see the beautiful mountain view.

This palace was one of the most important during the Joseon Dinasty, from 1392 to 2010. This palace is well preserved and it is possible to see the role of the king over Korea Peninsula. On that time Korea was only one country It was not divided like nowadays. In front of the main entrance it is possible to see the change of the guard, two times a day. If you are in Seul, you must go there.

After all the 5 star reviews, I was anticipating a nice historical museum. However, there are few signs, no description, very little furnishings in any of the buildings. Perhaps six rooms were setup. It was hard to get an idea of what life was like. We got the audio guides but they were not that helpful because there were no artifacts to look at! Not at all comparable to theForbidden Palace which has extensive exhibits
Definitely worth a stroll - beautiful palace and all its buildings, the park in autumn is fabulous. The highlight are the palace guards and the change of guard ceremony.

review_title: The Grand Palace not to be missed
review_body: The palace had recorded many dynasty of Korea. Rent the audio guide if you come by yourself. There is many gates into the palace and how its expended over dynasty. A must for history lover.

review_title: Regrettably short visit of an interesting place.
review_body: We got to Gyeongbokgung Palace on foot from Bukchon in mid afternoon and caught the changing of the guards which is one of the attractions. It was quite fascinating and impressive and worth the visit. We were unable to visit the entire palace.
+ easily reachable by subway within 1-2 minutes walk + even though there were lots of tourists bus loads of them, it felt quite uncrowded inside the palace due to it being huge

Went here at the palace with my fiance and my sister November 2o15. It was the perfect time because it was autumn. We arrived at the palace before 1 PM. We waited for the changing of the guards ceremony to start. Watch the whole ceremony which was 15 minutes long approximately. I had fun watching the changing of the guards ceremony, i was looking forward to watching this.

This is 1 of the highlights in Seoul and is really worth a visit. The architecture is awesome and the palace itself is beautiful. Loads of great photo opportunities and if you are into culture and history it really is s must visit
Oustanding place to visit, the palace was pretty and very clean check many other places and was such a good nice trip

It very much reminded me of the Forbidden Palace setup in Beijing, but felt much more extensive. The fall colors on the trees were fabulous. It seems to be more beautifully landscaped in Seoul. It was big enough to feel you could get lost. We did not do a tour, but many people were and you would learn a lot more by taking a tour.
Come at time of change guard ceromony. Huge palace, good if you like history. come earlier to explore close at 5 pm

were here for leisure, 3 of us really enjoy the beautiful scenery, clean place. visited in early morning, this place open at 9 am.All tree change colour of leaf make it refreshing your eyes.Only rainy that stop us to enjoy more, also don't miss the guard palace parade. with those cute guard

review_title: An insight into rich korean history
review_body: This place is must visit when you are in Seoul. It gives you an insight of Joseon dynasty architecture. Once you are here then dont miss the changing of the guards at the main gate.

review_title: One of Best places of Joseon dynasty.
review_body: It is in central city of Seoul. And the palace is Main and First palace of Joseon Kingdom (1392 ~ 1910). It is comparably new relic, instead Gyeongju city is from BC57 of Silla Kingdom (BC57 ~ AD935). Anyway it has many merit to visit because it is inside Seoul, easy access. :)

Located right outside Gyeongbokgung station, entry into the palace costs 3000 won. You can also exchange currency there. Architecture of it all is amazing. Don't forget to bring your camera or you will regret it ! :D

As much as I've enjoyed the forbidden city in Beijing, I had a good time exploring Gyeongbokgung Palace with my camera. historical architecture and beautiful garden walk which I often seen in Korean period drama! It was very very crowded when I was there.

You will love Korean history here and will start to watch Korean historic dramas afterwards.It is so big that you may ramble in its labyrinths for hours, it seems like desert even if there are many visitors.Don't miss the change of the guards: feel the rhythm of the drums.
Such a stunning place, visited late in the afternoon. Park closes at 5 sharp so give yourself plenty of time to venture around the grounds.

A lovely palace to see. Easy to walk around for all ages. It's inexpensive and if you keep your ticket the museum is free too. It was so beautiful on the day I went and the leaves were changing colors.

This is one of the most famous palace in Seoul that played important roles during the era of the Korean royalty. There are so many activities to be done here. One can enjoy the stroll along the well cared and manicured gardens or appreciate the history and beautiful Korean architecture. There is also a children and folk museum that displays exhibits relating to the Korean traditional folk culture. My husband and I visited during the autumn season and the whole complex looked stunningly beautiful. There were also not that many people when we visited during the weekdays and slightly later in the afternoon.Do not miss the colourful guards changing ceremony prior to entering the complex. You can check the palace's website on the processions timetable. There are also English guided tours conducted daily which are worth joining. You can enquire about these tours when buying the entrance ticket.Overall, this place is a must visit for anyone who visits Seoul and I recommend it for everyone.

I went here on a Thursday which I think was good because it was not that many people there as I would expect it to be on a weekend. Very easy to get there by metro and the entrance is only 3000 won, a little less than 3USD.The park is really nice especially in autumn with a lot of different colors and a lot of space. Defiantly worth a visit. There is also a museum of Korean people and history connected to the palace where you get free entrance if you went to the palace. It was also good for those that doesn't know that much about the development of Korea and its people.

I went there during the national holiday when you can visit for free. Very good place to know more about korean culture.If you go to this place, don't lose the opportunity to visit the museum with the history of the country.To know the Gyeongbokgung Palace, walk around and go to the museum you have to spend few hours.

review_title: beautiful palace, not enough time to go around
review_body: We didn't get to see much of the gyeongbok palace because our tour was in a rush. But they had an interesting architecture & heating system which was explained by our local guide.
The fall is the best time to visit this palace and Seoul. Do not except a fancy place cuz you will see a simple and quite buildings but it has the Korean style which you like
A sprawling area with beautiful gardens and trees. The change of gaurds takes place everyday at 11:00, 14:00
This is the best palace amongst all. If you have the time, then you should visit this. Quite nice but this cannot compare to the magnificent Forbidden Palace in Beijing.
Its the best time now ...autumn,cooling but not too cold.You can visit the museum n garden furst n option to enter the palace.

The Gyeongbokgung or imperial palace is a must visit for visitors to Seoul. The main entrance is impressive and visitors can see the parade of the royal guard behind the compound of the gate at fix time interval of the day. Inside the palace compound visitors can appreciate the beauty and majestic setting of the various sections of the palace. The throne chamber is very impressive and visitors can also get to see Korean in traditional dresses. A must stop itenary for any visitor to Seoul.
Nice place for a walk back to the past.Nice scenes and lots of greens and flora.Check out the museum nearby if you like history.

review_title: Beautiful recreation of the reach history
review_body: Very impressive and beautiful structures. Perfect place to walk around and enjoy the scenery for an hour or two.There are local high-school students - "volunteer guides" who will offer to walk you around for a small tip...it is fun but if you have an access to Wikipedia, you would learn more...I suggest against the museums there. They are underwhelming.

review_title: Beautiful Palace - Such Intricate Detail Everywhere
review_body: This palace was huge and amazing. The buildings had such intricate detail to them. I have never seen anything like this before. [This was my first and only trip to Korea, and Asia for that matter, as well.] The palace was built in the year 1395, and apparently was fully restored in 2010. You will not believe how intricate the details are on the walls and ceilings - it rivals anything I have seen anywhere. If you go to Seoul, this palace is a must-see.

This is really a very beautiful place. The only drawback was that they were doing some major building in one area. Lovely autumn colors and a very easy place to navigate on your own. Also very close to some great museums.
I love the huge area of this palace. Love the structures of the buildings. Love the surroundings. Love the scenic views of the nature inside the palace area. This place is damn relaxing!
I just love Korean culture. Visiting this place is a reminiscent of the Korean royalty. It's just sad that they don't exist today :(

review_title: A must visits when in Seoul
review_body: I had a great time here, I spent a couple of hours slowly taking in the atmosphere, beautiful buildings and fantastic autumn leaves.

This is one the tourist recommended site so we decided to give it a go. It is situated in quite a large area, we are not allowed into the building so we have to view it from openings that have been built for tourist I reckon. The man building which I supposed is where the King reside is beautiful, looks like the bernal building is handcrafted, with so fine detail and beautiful Colours. There are other buildings but we are not allowed in. With the autumn leaves falling and trees turning brown accompanied by cold weather, it was a pleasant trip.The highlight is probably the changing of the Guards, not as elaborate at the one in Buckingham palace but still pleasant to watch. Overall it's quite nice and I would recommend everyone a visit to the palace,

review_title: Must visit place no matter what the season is
review_body: Spring - Summer - Fall - or Winter, in each season the palace will have its own beauty. If you should choose only a "gung" to visit, this is the one.

The Palace was great. We had a beautiful day to walk around the grounds and enjoy the scenery. When we were there, there was a lot of young girls wearing the traditional dresses. The hanbocks were beautiful with lots of bright and vibrant colors. Nice to see them.

review_title: The Changing of the Guard at 3 pm
review_body: We got lucky with our DIY tour to the G- Palace, as we arrived at the outside palace square we saw Koreans fully dressed in gala uniform only to find out that the changing of the guards was about to happen-3:00 pm. Wonderful ! So the best tip -- be there before 3 pm , long walk to toilets-- it's by the parking lot! The walk between Bukchum to the G Palace had a Redtaurant with the famous chicken with ginseng soup dish - must try at least once in a visit to Seoul. Add Salt &!pepper to taste :-)

review_title: Historic palace in the heart of the city
review_body: Although it is rebuilt from the ruins the Japanese invasion left it is an impressive insight in the historic king's palace and with a 1 hour tour in english you get all the essential information.

Viewed the change of guard ceremony twice. Many peole wear Hanbok in the palace. They are very friendly & allow tourist to take photo with them. After the entrance, at the left entrance, there is free guard dress service for tourist to try on. 4 types of garment to choose from.

review_title: Good historical site with beautiful gardens
review_body: We went as a family with an elderly using wheelchair. Firstly, the Palace is good to visit as it is rich in history and the changing of the guards is great to watch. The palace has a beautiful garden on the side and a beautiful lake too. The colors are just wonderful in Autumn. Toilets are available before you go into the palace and there are toilets in the palace too. There are cubicles with sitting toilets. However, I can't say that the palace grounds are exactly wheelchair friendly because the ground is sandy and certain parts are paved with very large slabs with huge edges and not convenient to push a wheelchair. We ended up pushing the wheelchair through the corridors and into the side gardens and lake. Plenty of places for good photo shots. There's really no need to join a tour. You'll manage visiting this place on your own.

It is free for seniors. It was bigger than what we expected with a lot of walking. We were rewarded with a colourful autumn foliage at the other end of the palace ground. The guard changing ceremony was also worth watching.

Went on a lovely sunny day first thing in the morning when the palace opened so it was quiet and pretty. The grounds are huge so lots of photo opportunities. The museum attached is free to enter and also worth a visit.

review_title: Large and nice place in autumn.
review_body: Its really large for visiting. U should spend at least half of day here. There are many beautiful sights in autumn. And the street around the palace is also nice, too. The ticket included 2 museums also.

This was a MUST SEE for us and should be for you, too.VERY reasonable admission ticket...about $2.50US. They offer tours in English at 11AM each day they are open....closed Tuesdays. I would also assume they offer tours in other major languages during the day.WEAR comfortable shoes/sneakers, as there is a lot of standing and walking involved. Some stairs, uneven places. Our guide was very good, a charm, really. Magnificent buildings, colorful and well versed by our guide. Just walking around on your own might not give the same presentation...TAKE A FREE TOUR, if possible. Allow just over an hour if you take the free tour. Food shop is small but offers the basics and more...water, iced coffee, tea, GREAT ice cream, etc. Tables outside and inside. VERY, VERY reasonable. Then, on your same ticket, you can go right next door to the Folk Museum and see that. A very good deal.Very memorable and again, a must see while in Seoul.

review_title: See the changing of the guard if you can
review_body: The changing of the guard ceremony is three times per day and about 15 minutes long. It is an impressive sight of color and music. We enjoyed it. To enter the second gate to the palace you need to buy tickets. It is beautiful and quite large. It could easily take an hour + to see it all.
I love how we seemed to travel in time. We were early so we were able to enjoy the place to ourselves.Free to the Public on Wednesdays.

Enjoyed it, not as much as the secret garden and other palaces or the shrine, but definitely the largest and most visited temple. Skipped the tour and walked around on my own. Not much to see except the very spartan buildings, all the area around has been cleared sort of, very little vegetation.
Recommended for visiting ,know more about Korean culture and history ,spend times to walk and see each beautiful building

unbelievable what has been built centuries ago, and is still in such a good shape. I believe there is a lot of energy spent on keeping it in good shape, but it makes you feel how it has felt in Korea in the 13th century

It is recommended to spend around 2 to 3 hours . There is a ceremony of changing guards around 10pm which take around 10 to 15 mins . Administration is quite cheap . But the building structure is almost the same , you will lose interests after 2 hours .

The wide courtyards and the architecture of the palace kinda gets you back to thinking how it was 700 years ago. Must have been very regal. What I loved most was the gardens at the back of the palace which were full of autumnal colours. You can easily spend 3-4 hours here and don't miss the food at the Gyeongbokgung café. It was my first Korean meal and the Tteokbokki and Veg Bibimbap was amazing!Not forgetting the Kimchi!

Gyeongbokgung palace was an absolutely stunning place to visit. We went on the last day of Chuseok so it was very busy with school groups and visitors for a festival. It's very large but there's lots to see with several old buildings open to view and walk around. There isn't too much to say other than it was a truely breath taking place.
The Palace is a lovely place to spend an hour of 4 with nice buildings and a lovely Garden. On site is also the Korean Folk Museum.

If you're looking to learn a little more about Korea's history and enjoy some historic oriental architecture this is a great place to start.The palace itself is within the city so it is a comfortable find (public transport will get you there easily). Within the palace there's plenty of space to relax - especially if you venture beyond the palace rooms and into the garden area.Makes for some great photographs and a relaxing break.

review_title: Best historical and cultural attraction in Seoul
review_body: This is the only Palace my husband and I visited in Seoul. It's a large complex so prepare to spend 2-3 hours to explore. Admission was free when we got there but rented audio guide cost 3000 won. There is free guided tour (English, Japanese, Chinese) starting at Heungnyemun Gate (2nd Gate), make sure to check the time if you planned to follow. We just missed it. My favourite spots are Hyangwonjeong Pavilion and Gyeonghoeru Pavilion.

review_title: Don't miss changing of the guards
review_body: We loved visiting this palace! Very well signed for an American tourist. Don't miss the opportunity to see how the ruling class lived.

I've been to this palace twice--first time was in October 2012 and the second time was just recently, October 2015. I didn't enter the palace ground anymore on my second trip because it's going to be the same. I just wanted to see the "Changing of the Guards Ceremony" again. This time, at around 4PM. The ceremony I witness before was the one in the morning--the complete/full version. Although the one in the afternoon was much shorter, it didn't really take away from the experience of seeing these men all dressed up in their soldier/warrior attires. If you've been to the inner palace once, you don't really have to spend money on another ticket to see it again. It still the same palace building and, architecturally, looks very similar to the other palaces. Most definitely a good place to visit for first-timers in Seoul. A good stop the second time around; however, I don't see myself going back here on my third trip to Korea. I'm giving it a 4 out of 5,nonetheless. Still a very beautiful place to view.
Ancient place, we can see many historical palaces which is in every palace has a different story. They have a schedule to "changing guard" if you are lucky you can see that.

Spent couple of hours here, enjoys the historical architecture, ambience, dressing up with old costume.I have a good times here and liking the army performance. Ensure you comes with a pair of walking shoe, sitting under the trees, enjoys the fall season.

Visiting Gyeongbokgung Palace is definitely a must if you are in Seoul! Try to visit the palace when the change of guards is happenning, it will be an awesome experience. We also wanted to attend a free English guided tour, but since the group included 50+ people and the guide's voice couldn't be heard, we decided to discover the palace on our own. If you don't attend a tour, it's better to be prepared on what you will see and read descriptions, otherwise after some time the visit can be boring. For us it was a great experince!

review_title: Man, did this place get so busy!
review_body: We arrived just in time to watch the changing of the guards. This place is a beautiful gem amidst modern buildings of a metropolis.Entrance fee is quite cheap considering that your really just walking, looking and taking pictures. The last time I was here was the same time of year about 5 years ago and it wasn't nearly as busy. The visit itself takes about an hour then we were on our way to other tourist hotspots.

review_title: Go all the way in to the back ! A veritable Oasis!
review_body: Took the train to the stop just in front of the palace also named after the palace. Try to get there by 10 am as teher is a changing of guards parade which is quite fun to watch. you can also take pics with the traditionally garbed guards at the South main gate. Much like the Beefeaters, they cannot talk and will not move. make sure to line up and be orderly!the palace was well preserved and there is much space to walk about and roam despite the tourist hordes that were everywhere. We went in all the way till we arrived at the back garden sanctuary which feature ponds, trees and small hillocks. this was a gem of a garden in the heart of Seoul and a great place to just sit down on the grass and imbue the tranquillity of the place. The looming hills just beyond the walls were a magnificent backdrop as is the pond to the east where there was a picturesque pagoda on the island in the centre. Many shutterbugs were capturing the beauty of the place.Do take the exit where the National Folk Museum is ..take the EAST gate and from there you can take a leisurely stroll past arty shops to Insadong where u can have a wonderful lunch in one of the traditional eating houses in the side lanes!

We got to watch the ceremony sharp at 3pm everyday. Actually they have 3 times everyday. In morning, 3pm and late evning if i'm not mistaken. The largest palace in Korea it is, with beautiful original hundred years of architecture! Not to forget, do try to don the guards' uniform for free! The place to try the uniform is near the front gate.

Nice palace with colourful guard to take picture. It was raining that day therefore did not take any photo. I prefer Cheongdeokgung.However it's directly link to metro. Easy to find.It's also near the museum where it's more informative.
We had a tour guide to show us apround but just going by yourself would be fine too. It was very busy with kindergarten kids everywhere but I think it would have been so busy other than that.

review_title: What a beautiful palace in the middle city
review_body: I love this place, you can caugth many things when you walking around the palace. A beautiful natural view, traditional culture touch, guards atraction, try guards costume, and feel like a part of kingdom. Really touching and i promise that i'll be back in autumn.

A vast area with a lot of very pretty but closed buildings. There were some you could look into, but most of the buildings seemed like empty shells. Very beautiful buildings though. Not many places to get something to eat, and not really much to see. Maybe a guided tour would have been more informative, but I really loathe guided tours - so that's not an option for me. It didn't feel like totally wasted time, but I will never visit again.

review_title: A place to visit in Seoul
review_body: Nice place worth to visit and walk in Seoul, where one can familiarize himself with the Korean history and culture. It is good to know the schedule of guided tours before you go to visit. Usually the free guided tours in english are available two or three times per day, but you need to know the time. However, even without a guide you can easily understand the meaning of each dwelling by reading the information tablets. Also there are many nice places to take a photo.
Can easily be done in an hour. Only $3USD. Good photo opportunities. Not much history or displays or artifacts. The buildings look the same after you see a few but definitely Wow for a while.

After watching several historical dramas, the palace exceeded my expectations. It is larger and prettier than it appears in the dramas. Several areas were closed and we missed the guided tour, so we most likely didn't have an ideal experience.

This is a beautiful place and is a must-see during a visit to Seoul. It's interesting to watch the changing of the guards and the museum is also worth a visit. My mother and I were able to enjoy the place without a tour.

Gyeongbokgung Palace is a huge palace with a lot of space to walk in. The atmosphere felt OK but there were too much people in the palace. Also, the palace is covered with sand and I rather prefer changdeokgung palace.

I only had time to glance into the palace by oh boy it was impressive as nothing I ever seen with the mountains in the background. There was a sense of grandeur and warmth that was unlike anything I ever saw and I didn't even really get to go inside to look properly. It's a must see in Seoul for a reason. I only gave it a four because I didn't have the time to go inside. But I urge you to make time and go see it. Booking a tour is probably a good idea too.

This is a must to see if you are in Seoul.Great to see some Korean heritage. This is a well maintained part of history and a very large palace area. You can get a voice tour which is operated by touching there guide map and it tells you all on the location. After the tour one can relax with a walk around the lovely gardens. It is a very serene and tranquil place in the heart of the hustle and bustle of Korea.I would recommend to go early in the day as it is extremely popular with coach tours and school parties

My third time at the gyeong bok gung palace - always fun to visit and have a peaceful walk through the palaces. Takes about 1.5 - 2 hours to complete the walk from entrance to the exit. From the exit you can see and take photos of the Cheong Wadae (blue house). I would also recommend Chang Deok Gung which is pretty scenic too.

This was the number one palace and the ground are large and used four times a day for the changing of the guard ceremony. We went to the 3pm, less people. Times change best to check. The museum outside is worth a visit, bit the exhibits have no English explanations.
High light of Seoul. Great to visit in a beautiful day. you can ask for tour course. Closed on Tuesday.

This is one of those place you have to visit while in Seoul to get a glimpse of days of yore. It can get packed with tour groups so quite difficult to get clean shots without photo bombers. Check out the changing of the guards and have your photos taken with them.
You get to observe the march & changing of guards at the main gate of the palace with a closeup photo allowed standing next to the guard
Went to Gyeongbokgung Palace on a cloudy day which made it not so good for photo shooting. Worth visiting if you want to know about Korean history.

review_title: Interesting start of our visit to Seoul
review_body: This was a surprising start of our visit to Seoul. Free entrance due to some school holiday, excellent digital guiding system, impressive location ... Close to subway station with the same name, good café at the subway entrance.
Time it so you see the main changing of the guard, allow at least three hours to see all it has to offer
The palace was very big and luckily we went there when it was sunny, so it was a nice day out. Also there is museum inside the complex

We visit 3 palace in seoul during our trip, I found this palace is worth to go.Direction: stop at Gyeongbokgung station (line 3) exit 5Admission 9am-7pm weekend; 9am-6pm weekday (closed on TUESDAY)Ticket: KRW3,000 for adult or combine ticket KRW10,000 (Free entry for those who wear Korean costume)There are free guided tour in English/ Chinese/ Korean/ Japanese you can check the time on their websiteFree Gate Guard costume experience starting from: 10.15am, 11:10am, 13.15pm, 14.10pm, 15.10pm, 16.10pmGuard changing Ceremony at 11am, I am not sure about other timing. (if you don't feel like going into the palace you can still watch the guard changing ceremony that is free at the main gate before the ticketing counter.Try to go earlier before it get too crowded.

review_title: Poor staff and ticketing agents ruined the day
review_body: Our group of 5 from Europe had our last day in Seoul and we got to the palace to see the grounds. The main palace closes very early at about 5:30pm. We got to the door at 5:30 which is the last ticketing time, and the man would not let us through. Our guests had never been to Korea before. The ticketing man and other man who guards the entrance were both so cold and without feeling. As a local, I led the group there and tried to explain in Korean, and was rebuffed so coldly. There's no ombuds service and no customer service in Korea to help improve this kind of poor service, which is too bad since people come with the expectation to be delighted by their experience here.This is one of the main palaces which most tourist try to see. There is a lovely queen's garden, and a good museum all in once place. The servants quarters is a little like a maze so fun to wander through.
Palace is gorgeous to see at night. Beautiful reflection of the palace from the lagoon that will give double effect which is very picturesque.

Most probably the most famous palace in Seoul. And also the biggest. Large area, with a lot of beautiful, colourful buildings. Good to visit on Monday, when the other palaces are closed. Free guided tours are available, but you can enjoy it on your own, as well, especially if you have got a basic knowledge about Korean history. If not, read the panels all around the place. Check for evening visits, as well, for a more misterious scenery. Accesible by metro. Visit the museums inside.
Very interesting trip. enjoyed the tour. Invest in the audio unless you are on a tour with a guide. Was interesting to learn some of the history of Korea.

We went during Mid October 2015. Ticket prices 3000 Won per adult which at the time was equivalent of less than £2. Gyeongbokgung is very easy to get to by the MRT on line 3. It is closed on Tuesdays. Recommended time spent in this attraction: 1.5 - 3 hours.Firstly, before entering the actual Palace, on the left side of the entrance, there is a free service where you can wear the costume/uniform of the ancient imperial soldiers and take pictures for five minutes. There are timed slots where you can queue up and I think they allow up to 10 people per hour to borrow these costumes to take pictures.I didn't note down the times, but it was something like 11:15, 12:10, 13:15 etc till closing. I highly recommend this as it really adds to the overall experience.At the entrance you will see guards in the ancient soldiers uniform standing guard and patrolling (much like the Queens guards in London) You can take pictures with them (but not if you are wearing the borrowed uniform - it is forbidden, we saw a girl get told off for doing this). Inside the palace, though it's not as big or as grand as the Forbidden City in Beijing, houses the ancient architecture with the big halls for the Emperor, his Queens and officers which are beautiful and inspiring. The stone sculptures on the stairs and the roofs look amazing and the artwork inside the halls are exquisite. I definitely recommend a visit to Gyeongbokgung for anyone passing through Seoul, if not for the history then at least for the art that is the palace itself.

The palaces are beautiful, but this one is the largest, and is just amazingly beautiful. There is so much to see and the pagoda in the pond I spent hours looking at it. I went here twice, each time I found inner peace. Cheesy yes but true.
You should visit this great ancient Palace. It's located in Seoul and it's very easy to get there. Subway Gyeongbokgung Exit 5.

Very easy to find. We went to a weekend and there were still no queues to speak of and it was not very busy. The palace is so large that you can easily find a space were there are no other people, which makes it feel like a real escape from the city. It is also very interesting and beautiful. I have been to many similar places but because of the size, setting and few clouds I would say this is definitely one of the best, well worth a visit.

Korean traditional palace, flowers and trees are very beautiful in autumn.Historical palace in the historical district within Seoul CityCatch the changing of the guard ceremonies!Inexpensive admission fee of 3,000 wonFree English tours are apparently at 11am, 1:30pm and 3:30pm. World heritage site by UNESCO
gyeongbokgung palace is absolutely beautiful. its a must visit if you are going to seoul. make sure to wear comfy shoes and clothes as the palace is huge.

I've been there in winter days, and enjoying snow.! It's my first time to playing in the middle of snow, and I'm happy that time.! The place are very broad, but there is no restaurant or shop if you want to eat something.!

I was fortunate to tour the palace with a local Korean business man. Not only was I able to view the palace using the interactive guide, I also was able to get commentary from the local Korean business contact. It was a gorgeous day and the trees were turning in the fall. The Hyangwonjeong and Geoncheonggung were highlights of the tour.This is a must see when in Seoul. A far better tour and more elaborate place than the forbidden city in Beijing, but also shows the cultural differences.

Bring comfortable shoes because this place is HUGE!!!! Make sure to check the times for the changing of the guards ceremony at the front of the palace. Incredible to see the incredible artwork and detail that went into building the palace. We didn't get to make it to the center to the blue house due to our children being tired but make sure to try and visit.

i've seen many tourists during our brief stay at the Gyeongbokgung Palace, although we didn't stay that long, it's worth the visit, probably we'll go back there if time permits on our next visit in Seoul!
You must try the free palace guard outfit! Its refreshing here. I love the nature. And the history. There is a free english tour guide every 11am. Try it.

It's really worth visiting, the grounds are huge! It houses the National Palace Museum and Folk Museum, worth a visit too. They provide a quick (1hr, believe me it barely scratched the surface) free guided tour, just be at the meeting point at specified hours. The Palace Guide book can be bought (W500) at the information counter before the entrance.

i went there on OCT 2015 with my sister and my cousin (total 3 people), my sister already pre booked the free tour guide in English for 2 pax, and we add 1 more pax during arrival, we really highly recommended to join this free guide if you are interested in the history or story behind each building. strongly suggest not visiting on OCT since it is picnic season and the place is full with students. the tour using free guide took 2 hours in total.

It is a very huge park. 2 hours are not enough to walk through every corner in this palace. The architecture is unique and colourful. Free to experience the costumes. Limited only 5 mins to take picture for each person. The view is awesome in the palace is awesome. Actually it is quite similar to China Palace.
This is a Magnificent Palace and is a must visit when you are in Seoul.It has various sub-palaces / theme architecture and you just have to visit them all.

review_title: Palace is located in a huuuuuge park, put 2 hours aside
review_body: Breathtaking palace, it is in a giant park that is lovely to walk around. Free English tours are apparently at 11am, 1:30pm and 3:30pm. 3000 won admission. You get about 30,000 wons worth of wow factor though :) The folk museum is in same park (free admission). Go go go.
large open area with different palace buildings and nice ponds, very relaxing. easy to get around, signs in english.

Great place to check out for a little taste of the old Korean housing. The area is enormous so your not right on top of other people. There are a lot of big groups coming throughout. Great photo opportunity area, dress warmly. Lots of walking around.

Beautiful scenery surrounded the palace. Colourful autumn leaves was definitely a stunning background photo. It wasn't too crowded during weekdays. Easily reached by public transportation. A must visit place in Seoul.
It's a beautiful place ! It allows to have a taste of Traditional Korea Culture. The national palace museum of Korea inside Gyeongbokgung is worth a visit as well.

review_title: Great experience due to guided tour
review_body: I actually enjoyed myself even though the buildings look similar after a while. Place was huge so the guided tour helped a lot. The changing of guards ceremony was nice too. A couple of pretty spots for photo taking too.
If you like history this is a good place to go. There is guards dressed and standing at attention when you enter the Palace. I would suggest going on their tour.
Watching the ceremony is a must.The palace is beautiful. And the surrounding area is so neat & beautiful. Many art galleries & so clean..

The huge size of the palace complex is quite overwhelming, but exploring each quarter was never boring. The buildings are beautifully preserved/restored. The gardens are well maintained and clean. We were there just in time for the guards changing ceremony, which was interesting to see.
Nice place for photography. The best time for picture is around 10 am on a sunny day. There is another pond close by.

review_title: Palace that did not meet our expectations
review_body: The palace grounds is on a large piece of land in the middle of town but the buildings were rather disappointing. They looked to be refurbished in a rather rough way although the main building had an interesting ceiling and roof. We were there during the changing of the guards which was an interesting cultural experience but it does not enough to make a visit there worth while unless you really have spare time on your hands.

review_title: A lovely place to wander away from the busy-ness
review_body: The mountains provide a lovely backdrop to Gyeongbokgung (although the city is right behind you too!). It's easy to get to and makes for a nice wander away from the busy city streets. I arrived early and it was so peaceful, but the crowds tend to draw in as the morning goes on. They hold ceremonial changing of the guards at set times through the morning - apparently the guards are military personnel who 'drew the short straw' - some of their faces might give this away :-)

When we arrived, we walked right into the start of the royal guard ceremony. It was indeed rewarding to watch the event. The palace grounds were crowded and we were indeed fortunate to be able to take photos with the young ladies in their hanbok costumes.

review_title: Get close to traditional Korean Culture
review_body: I naturally connected to the Gyeongbokgung Palace after watching a Korean Soap back home. The palace is an excellent place to connect to original and traditional Korean culture without living the city centre.I was able snap pictures with traditional guards who looked like statues, I never knew they were alive until they moved.While many tour companies do tours of the palace, you can go there yourself, buy the ticket and walk in.

review_title: Big & Clean But Like A Shell
review_body: There is no doubt that the palace is grand and it covers a large area. I did get the feeling though that it was a shell and that outside of foreign tourists there was little else going on there. The buildings themselves that surround the main palace are all empty and you can only go inside a couple of buildings that were furnished by the Spartans.I think if you goto Seoul, you do HAVE to visit but don't expect too much apart from a clean pretty palace with nice gardens.

review_title: Beautiful gardens, some very old trees. Thousands of school children having a great time.
review_body: The name means "Palace Greatly Blessed by Heaven."A nice place to visit. The palace was first built in 1395. The entire complex covers 250,000 square meters. We saw the Presidential Residence at a distance.
This place offers such a breathtaking view... Really nice place for photos too! It's a little like a maze. Best to go when weather is not too cold so you can explore the place better :)
Much of this palace has been recreated following destruction, but it is very much worth seeing. The structures as well as the gardens and grounds make for a wonderful experience.

review_title: Did the free one hour tour
review_body: Very pretty especially if you haven't been to China or Japan. Skip the other palace across the street unless you like walking in a big park.It's rebuilt recently the architecture and design is quite similar to Chinese palaces. Worth a couple hours if youre in the area.

We didn't get to go this year because it was closed Tuesday, the day we set aside for the 2 palaces near each other. 4 years ago, the 11 of us (grandparents down to youngest 4 years old). We didn't do a guided tour which was great at the other palace this year but it was still beautiful.

This is a charming palace and well worth visiting. I would highly recommend that you take a guided tour to get the full benefit of your visit. Due to the time of our visit we were unable to seen the Secret Garden as you have to take the site guided tour which is offered 4 times a day (in English). Our private guide indicated that it is a place well worth visiting.

review_title: A Beautiful and Peaceful Piece of Korean History
review_body: I have visited here many times over the years as I enjoy the peaceful strolls through this Korean historical cal site. The many traditional palace structutes, well manicured grounds and the serene location in the heart os Seoul make this a great escape. My favorite part is the lake which is in the center of the palace grounds. It has a beautiful pagoda and is filled with lillies. It is easy to get lost in thought and imagine how beautiful this place was long ago. The entry fee is inexpensive. You can buy a ticket book to access here, three other nearby palaces and a temple for 10,000 Won. That is under 10 US and is a bargain.

The palace is tremendously pretty, colourful and big! Lovely place for pictures and lots of Korean teens in their traditional gowns taking selfie! Very fortunate the day of visit was the only sunny and hot day in the week! Spent about 4 hrs walking around, could have been more had the National Palace Museum offered more English translation of the displayed items.

review_title: If you only see one site in Seoul, make sure this is it
review_body: A huge sprawling complex, recreating the richness of the centuries of Korean royalty. Best with a guide as it is massive and busy! Loved it. Make sure you see the stationing of the guard gates. Terrific.

Visit this palace 2nd time. As the last 2 years autumn there are many people visiting this palace not only tourist but the native koreans as well taking chances to go out and enjoy the sceneries before winter coming. Today im so lucky as there are act perfomances from the past dynasties. And also lots of beautiful koreans high school students are wearing han bok and walk around the palace. This is a must kept historical place at korea.

This spot is accessible to public by Metro and it is at the Seoul city center where major activities take place just opposite of it. Oct 9 street performance and may art activities make the surrounding lively. One who visit Seoul the first time should not miss this tourist spot.

If you had to pick just one palace to visit in Seoul this should be it. It is a wonderful place with grand sweeping views. At night (while closed) the front is lit up wonderfully and perfect for night photography. If you're going during the day do so by noon and avoid the weekends if possible because of the crowds.

review_title: One of the top ten Seoul tourist attraction !
review_body: It is one of the top ten tourist destination in Seoul so don't miss it if you are here for the first time. It is big place and offer free museum entry, although you will need to pay 3000 won to get to see inside the palace but it is worth it absolutely. Very easy access as it is connected to the Gyeongbokgung station, just walkout of the station as it is right in front of you ! Can spend just one hour there to have a quick tour if you are not into too much history !

Well if you ask us the history and what the guide was talking about , we were actually not much into it, but the beauty is too good. One of the main attraction to be visited when you in Seoul.Change of guard ceremony was interesting we were there I think 3pm or 4pm and we got to see it!

review_title: Supreme among Korea's 5 palaces, restored & should be on one's short list
review_body: To understand Korea's 5,000 years of history & ties to Confucius theology, one needs to set aside some time & wear comfortable shoes to walk thru these grounds, see the restored beautiful and best of all five palaces - much like going to BJ to see China's Forbidden City. Our escorted group tour took us via the back by way of the Blue House (Presidential compound - like America's White House) onto the vast complexes - once housed over 7,000 rooms in its 500 buildings, ancient & historic designs in harmony with nature, haven & earth - and how once Imperialistic Japan virtually nearly destroyed SK's rich history and artifacts. The performances, special showings and the daily changing of the "costumed" guards are extra bonuses when timed - otherwise, there's plenty of see, visualize and appreciate - of a nation and its people, proud and mindful of its past while steering ahead of its destiny - despite its modern day South-North separation and threats of war.
An ideal place to spend 1/2 the day. I recommending getting the audio guide, it is cheap and a good way to get the details of what you are looking at.
Palace is one of the most traditional thins in Korea. The most important palace for the royalty. Very romantic. Big. There is a museum also which worth a time.

You can see the guard changing ceremony and take a picture with them. Very historical. When I was visit there, there was a place for try their guard clothes. Not hanbok, and it is for a guy. But they are allow women who want to try it too.If you have only few days in Seoul, you can't miss out this place. Actually there are another palace but in my opinion, this is the most famous palace.

This is one of the must see places here if you are in Seoul. It is one of the most beatiful temples in Korea and it has a great Changing of the Guard ceremony. You must see this if you are in the area, but you have to be there before 12pm or you will miss it.

This is a fantastic place to visit on your first trip to Korea. You can see how royalty lived in ancient times. This is one of the most well known palaces along with Changdeokgung. There were 5 royal palaces during the Joseon Dynasty. There is a museum that shares the same location as the palace. It would be best to visit the museum first. When you exit the museum you can purchase a ticket booklet that will allow you to go to all 5 of the royal palaces and a nearby shrine.

Either read up,on your history or go with a guide to get the full understanding of this site. The king's quarters, the queen's quarters, the different lanes for walking, the meaning of the colors in the building, all need to be explained etc. The history is very interesting and the grounds are large with many buildings
Go and check it out theres free English tours as well Make sure you wear comfortable shoes from outside it didn't look that big but you walk abit Great to take photos
There's changing of royal guard ceremony at the entrance and free tour guide. One of my favourite place to see in Gyeongbokgung palace is Hyangwonjeong! It is so beautiful!

I went to Gyeongbokgun Palace last winter. There's a pond inside and it was frozen, just like a mirror. The palace was so big that I walked around 1 hour. I experienced the buildings there and thought about the drama I saw before. There were so many toursits there, as it is really a must-go place in Seoul.

It fell a bit short of my expectation - unlike the palaces in Europe where you get to see the interior. But if you appreciate architecture, this palace won't fail you!The gardens of this palace was gorgeous though, maybe except for the Empress' garden. It looked unkempt.Free guided tours in few foreign languages are available throughout the day which is great. Our guide was cute :)

review_title: A "must" if you only have a few days.
review_body: I like Gyeongbokgung Palace the best of all the palaces in Seoul because it has the most history and it is the original (and first) palace of the Joeson Dynasty. There is a very good free English Tour that starts @ 11am every day (subject to change) (and 2 more in the afternoon) and I like that it is where the King lived most of the time and met with his military and civilian leaders there.

If you want to know more about Korea's culture this is a good place to visit. You'll see the structures of their Palace and the guards too. It is muddy when it rains so it would be difficult to walk in the place.. It would be helpful if you have a guide with you so that you would learn more about the structures, what the buildings are.. what they where.. etc.

review_title: Centered Palace to breath from the busy city
review_body: Living 5mn away, I went multiple times there, during snowy winter, chilly fall, warm summer and beautiful spring. Year around, the place is nice. Don't expect to see anything similar to Forbidden city in Beijing, this is different, this is much smaller, but very enjoyable. Do the Folks Museum, this is very under rated, and quite nice to learn about Korea. I enjoyed nearby the Queen Palace very much, best in WINTER to see the white landscape. Enjoy your time there and forget/relax from the busy city around.

review_title: A good convenient walk from city hotels next to city hall.
review_body: Loved all the lovely colours on the buildings. Culturally rich. Good for business travellers on short stay for a 1/2 day outing.

There were guided tours in the different languages, but you must check the timings before you go, otherwise you might miss it. Otherwise, everything in the Palace has been reconstructed. It was something I did not expect. I peered into the many buildings and was empty inside. However, as it was autumn and the palace grounds were quite serene, we managed to find a spot on the grass to chill at. The whole scenery of the place is also very peaceful. You might spot Korean girls in their traditional Hanbok, walking around to snap photos in the palace grounds. If you would like to know more about the history of the place, I would suggest you find a tour guide, otherwise, it might not make any sense to you.
I love these. My Korean friend helped me to visit one of the best sightseeing. At the first time, I had a few time thus I will back here soon.

review_title: Free guided english tours at 11am, 1:30pm, and 3:30pm
review_body: This is one of five grand palaces in Seoul. You have the option to purchase the tickets by the entrance. There's a package that cost 10,000 won for admission to all 5 palaces including the secret garden. If you generally want to visit Gyeongbokgung, then it cost 3,000 won for an adult ticket. This place is open everyday from 9am to 5/6pm depending on the time of year and closed on Tuesdays. You can join a tour and follow a tour guide through the palace or you can simply roam freely.

We bought the package which include the admissions to visit other palaces for ₩10,000, and is valid for 3 months, although we were only in Seoul for four days but we did go to other places on the next day.There is a free guide tour and we joined the English tour at 3.30pm.

A must in our itinerary when visiting Seoul is to visit Gyeongbokgung Palace. Rich in history and culture of the Ancient Kingdom...Each structure inside has a story, and the best time to visit is autumn.

review_title: Part of a large complex of temples and shrines
review_body: lovely setting - needs a whole day to fully explore all aspects of this stunning, vast inner city temple area....... go on line to view pics

Easily reach by metro station with few mins walk. If you have been to Forbidden City in Beijing, this palace might be a little small and empty. If you have not been there, this is a good place to go. Some comments said its very Korean. I'm not too sure have they been to China's palace? I personally find that they have lots of similarities. If you are there, just do remember to check out the guard exchange time table which i think this is one of the highlight. They have long exchange ceremony and short exchange ceremony. Besides, they also have a costume booth at the left corner before you heading out. You can put on the exchange guard traditional clothing for picture and they are for free.

review_title: Better than many larger palaces in the world
review_body: The Forbidden City in Beijing covers 12 times the land area of Gyeongbukgung, but I find the latter more beautiful ( I included a few photos). It was burned down by Japan in the late 16th century, and not rebuilt until the 19th. Behind the palace is the mountain, and in front Sejong Daero, a large boulevard with statues of two of Korea's historical heroes. Also right by is a performing arts center, and a Palace Museum. It's at the heart of Seoul.

review_title: Large compound but not a lot that will linger in your memory
review_body: Let me start at the beginning: Gwanghwamun. It is picturesque and photograph-able from both Sajikno as well as the nearest traffic island on Sejongno.Try to visit early to avoid the hoards of children on day trips from school and the tour bus crowd.Once inside, if they are starting the pomp of the changing of the guard, I would use that as an opportunity to get a head start on the above mentioned, unless you're a huge fan of such proceedings.The complex is quite large and some of the structures imposing but it sits on barren land (which I doubt was the situation when it was in use) which gives you the sense of emptiness.Since it is a sprawling complex without a lot of reference points, I'd recommend either turning to the left or right once inside and working either clockwise or counter-clockwise, respectively, along the periphery. If you walk up the central path, there's a lot of nooks and crannies that you will miss.Personal highlights were the Hyang-wonjong Pavilion at the far north of the complex and the view of Gyeonghoeru from across the water. The National Folklore Museum is supposed to be worthwhile but I was too hot and tired by the time I came upon it. It is scenic in its own right, with a 5 story pagoda perched on top.The entrance fee is not that high, so it provides a good return on your investment.

review_title: Great place to learn about the history, especially emperors of South Korea
review_body: I signed up for a free tour from the visitkorea.or.kr website and thoroughly enjoyed the place. The guide Jun, a retired South Korean volunteer, was excellent in giving our small group of four the background to the palace and use of different buildings in Gyeongbokgung. I learnt so much about this palace and its inhabitants during the Josen era in the two-hour tour, from why there are three entrance gates and why they have different heights to the different uses of the different kitchens in the palace. It was really intriguing to also see the sun dial invented during that period by one of the scholars and more importantly how it is used. Do I recommend this place? Yes but especially if you have a guide to help you fully appreciate the rich culture and history this palace embodies.
It's very Korean!!! A must see attraction to visit downtown Seoul! Near to a Seoul Metro station very convenient and accessible to visit.

If you visit Korea there are numerous temples available to see, but this is as it states, a palace. The scale and workmanship is impressive and the changing of the guard is a spectacle worth seeing. Very peaceful place in the middle of a hectic city.

If you visit seoul you must go to Gyeojgbokgung. It is very beautiful and very huge so prepare yourself with water and snakes if you have to but my advise is to eat well then go. It is much better to visit it early in the morning or after 11 I'm not sure which times it opens but after 4 pm will be so crowded

This is one of the most visited Palace in Seoul. I would highly recommend visiting specially during the change of guard happens. I went twice during my trip because the first time it was raining and the next day the weather was beautiful so I went back to enjoy the sights and palace.

The biggest of the 3 main palaces in Seoul, it does stand out from the rest. It has late endless compounds . While the palaces seemed clean, they were hardly big or grand in comparison to some of the other countries like those in Thailand or India. The good thing was that the place was maintained really really clean../"still if you are in Sepul, worth a visit
I preferred the Changdeokgung palace. This one felt more commercial. There was a huge platform constructed for a musical event. The changing of the guard was not waht I expected. Very disapponting

Watch the traditional Palace guards changing ceremony performed at the entrance. The palace grounds were massive, surrounded by situated at the foot of the northern mountains and great to exercise your feet. The buildings were beautifully restored, demonstrating the rich heritage of ancient Korean dynasty.

There is a small fee to get into the palace complex but it's well worth the money.We were lucky enough to arrive just before the changing of the guard. It is worth watching this exercise, both very colourful (Costumes and flags) and very precise, which takes around 5 minutes to complete. It attracts the crowds every hour on the hour.From the large esplanade, you proceed to a collection of buildings, one after the other. it was the largest of Seoul's palaces and built during the Joseon dynasty and where their history unfolded over the next 500 years.Allow a couple of hours for your visit.

From far away the palaces felt majestic and remarkable, but going closer to the buildings one could feel that most buildings of the palace are replicates, given that the Japanese and the Korean War have destroyed most of the buildings.There were tours given and if you did not have time to catch one could walk around the palace compounds and there are signs which give a brief historical summary of the uses of buildings. Walking to places that were not allowed when guards were not looking was interesting. You could see the empty interiors of certain buildings and how they do not look authentic from the insides. On the other hand, there were some places not refurbished recently that gave the scenery for photography an authentic feel with aged wood and discoloured paint (after all, the original palace was not as colourful as it is today with the advent of modern dyes that were more vibrant).
Is a big place, to really enjoy this place you need a bout 2 hours. If you like to take photos, you may need to allocate more time in this area.
Beautiful palace and a wonderful walk through history. I thoroughly enjoyed my visit there. The changing of the guard is short in timespan, but the colors were beautiful.

Gyeongbokgung is a must-see for a visit to Seoul. The palace is rather large and has a couple of museums as well as an area for children. Depending on your level of interest and how long you spend walking around, you can easily spend an afternoon there.

I enjoyed this palace. It is a very big area and you could be there for hours. There are some guards at the entrance in traditional dress so that is interesting. If you have been to China, this is very much the same as sites there. I visited quite a few in China, so just this one would have done me. If you have never seen anything like this then you must go.
Good for history buff and also to witness the change of guards. Accessible by train (gyeongbokgung station exit 5) but shouldn't spend too much time here.

My parents and i visited this Palace on the last Wednesday of the month and entrance fee was waived! We also enjoyed free traditional music performance at the National Palace Museum (which was also free entrance) and had an interesting time at the Folk Museum within the compound (which was also free entrance). You can easily spend a whole afternoon here if you enjoy photography of outdoor architecture and korean culture, or if the weather is good. I visited in September when the weather was turning from hot (with occasional rain) to cool (with sunny days) so if I could visit again I would prefer to go in early Oct. The palace is more beautiful than Deoksugung and much larger as well. You should also visit Jongmyo Shrine for a complete historical learning experience. Wear comfortable shoes (some of the paths are uneven and difficult to walk on); advisable to visit the toilet when you come across one as you are exploring the palace grounds, because toilets are not very conveniently located (only 2, one at the entrance and one at the exit, as well as at the 2 co-located museums which have cleaner toilets). You may wish to bring along a bottle of drinking water; if you need a refill, there are free drinking water fountains within the compound near the toilets and even in resting areas.

The palace is renovated and offers a glimpse into the life of the royal family in the old days. The guard ceremony is spectacular and worth the while. For those who purchase tickets you get free guided tours at 11, 13:30 and 3pm in english. Highly recommended

review_title: A great place for traditional photos
review_body: The palace is set on beautiful grounds, with some water and old trees. The colors of the buildings are beautiful, and you're able to peek inside the buildings. There is a map that tells you about each place.

review_title: Like the Forbidden City, better gardens!
review_body: We had a nice visit here - got there just in time for the ceremonial changing of the guards which was fun to see. (Happens a few times a day out front). The palace area is quite similar to the Forbidden Palace, lots of hallow structures with open space - wear comfy shoes! At the back there's a very nice garden. In addition, your ticket gets you free entry to the Folk Museum, so hold on to your ticket!

We visited the palace during Cheusok. It was fairly busy but the visitors were fairly pleasant. I don't know if it was due to the holiday or not, but there were quite a few young people in their traditional dress wandering the site. Their presence gave an authentic air to the visit that was exciting.

review_title: A small scale palace; worth a visit
review_body: One of the few palaces in Seoul, a favourite amongst tourists. It is small in size and if one has visit The Forbidden City in Beijing, this palace is much smaller in scale. It does not have the opulence and grandeur as normally seen in a palace.Must understand the history behind the palace and how it was largely destroyed during the Japanese invasion and the palace was only rebuilt in the 1990s due to shortage of funds. So what we see now is a rather new landmark. To make it interesting, one can also enjoy the walk around the palace in the traditional costumes i.e. hanbok but the rental shop isn't inside the palace, One has to rent from the shops outside the palace.In my visit, it was really enjoyable to see a few local girls dressed in colourful hanbok, and they welcome picture moments with you.

review_title: like going back to the old time
review_body: its like going back to the old time in Joseon era. like in the drama.the place is sooo good.dont walk too fast. you need to enjoy your time here..

review_title: Beautiful palace grounds filled with photo ops
review_body: My wife and I really enjoyed the two hours we spent wandering around the palace grounds. The price of admission was low and the grounds are gorgeous. It is a wonderful place to walk around and soak in the beauty of the grounds and the landscapes around the palace area!

review_title: Worth Seeing Again and Again and Again
review_body: I enjoy walking the grounds at my leisure, soaking up the ambiance of the Joseon dynasty. Being on the palace grounds helps brings all those Joseon-era kdramas to life.I have been to Seoul twice in the last 2 years and I have visited this particular palace both times. 2/2=100%
It was a lovely early autumn visit, the surrounding trees just starts to turning yellow. A beautiful historical place to relax and enjoy.

I strongly recommend a visit to the palace. We visited wirh out 4 years old son and had a lovely time. We started with the National folk museum and visited the palace on the way back to the metro station. I recommend this because you will experience much shorter waiting time to purchase a ticket
Interesting Palace - free to over 65's! Lot of walking as it is very spread out. Worth a visit to aquaint yourself with it's history.

The grounds of this palace are expansive and you can wander around for hours, seeing the gardens, ornamental ponds and many palace buildings .You can also witness the colourful changing of the guards ceremony which is staged at regular intervals, or participate in a free english tour (these depart 3 or4 times a day). It does tend to lack a little character because basically all the buildings are new and there is nothing much inside the buildings to see (it was "restored" after being destroyed in the distant past). It also does get very crowded. However the entrance fee is a modest W3000 (or you can get a combined W10000 ticket and visit 4 sites within 3 months) and it makes for a pleasant diversion. You can also visit the folk museum at the side of the palace (for free) which also has a very interesting open-air section of historic shops, buildings and statues. Certainly worth a visit when in Seoul.

An interesting look at how the King use to liveI went in autumn and the scenery was really beautiful with the different coloured autumn leaves. The nicest view is one where the pavilion is.They have scheduled tours but if you would like to walk around on your own but still get to know the history of the place, I would recommend to rent their audio tour where you can easily point to what you want to know (on the map) and listen to the historical facts. This is available in several languages.
Nice museum and beautiful palace grounds! Reminiscent of the forbidden city in Beijing. Good for a half day adventure!

We managed to catch the first changing of guards ceremony, which was quite interesting. The area is quite big and can get very crowded as well. The interior was alright but the view from the palace was awesome! I was told my the locals that this is not the most beautiful palace in Seoul though.

review_title: i fell in love with Korea here
review_body: i don't know where or when but the moment i walked out the train station for this palace, i was in love. i had come just as the changing of the guards happened, it was so amazing. i can honestly say, i enjoyed everything, from the random pots of flower to maps in the floor. i had so much fun just walking around and taking pictures. you were able to view into the palace rooms but they were still in preserve. everything was perfect.

Plan to visit 2 + hours and it is so fun to see the changing of the guards. Displays are good and the grounds are beautiful. We did this palace one day and the West Palace another day. Bothe were great and worth seeing but do it in in separate days to keep it from being overwhelming.

It's a beautifully restored and maintained palace. And behind there's a wonderful garden with walking tours led by guides. English- and Japanese-language tours available in case your Korean isn't so great.I particularly appreciated the architecture; lots of interesting details and intersections, angles and views.And while it seems strange to say, I encourage you to try out the public restrooms. Amazing.

review_title: Easy to get to in Seoul
review_body: We took a taxi from our hotel to the palace. IIRC it cost about $30 round trip. We arrived in time for the changing of the guard ceremony which was nice. Also took a guided tour. We enjoyed touring the palace.

This is one of the palaces in Korea. It's very big, picturesque, and calming. Getting inside is not a problem at all. We went as part of the Incheon tour in between connecting flights. You can find them at strategic locations at the airport. We only paid around 5-8 USD for food. I highly recommend going via this tour if you ever find yourself at their airport.

review_title: Large - historical korean palace middle in the city
review_body: Amazing with this Palace, it is very big place, we can see traditional korean palace with background modern korean skycrapper.But too many tourist/visitor as we visit

review_title: Nice place to visit, a must go for tourists
review_body: The Gyeongbokgung Palace is a beautiful place, well preserved and tourist friendly. You can practically take pictures anywhere, and at the same time learn about where the emperors of Korea used to hold their meetings and banquets. Place is huge with lots of touristsand be sure to bring a decent camera, as there are quite a number of things you should take photo of.Families with young children might want to consider bring a stroller as place is really huge and only transport is by foot.

The palace has so much history. It is definitely one of the most famous palaces in Seoul that one has to visit.getting to palace is quite straightforward. Spend more time in the palace and explore all the rooms.

This place is really BIG but it was worth the visit! We joined the free guided tour so as to really understand the buildings in the palace grounds. Be prepared to do a lot of walking and follow the guide closely.
