Because of the size of the crowd that turn up on the day of the tour, sometimes the guide cannot afford to wait for everyone in the group to catch up since they have to keep the tour within the strict time slot.

In a previous visit, I actually saw the museum and some of the palace, but I went back for a second visit to finally see the whole ace properly, and I'm glad I did. The queues o get into the main palace were very long, but pretty fast, and be sure to have your ID and stuff with you when you go, just in case. The whole place is beautiful, gardens, buildings and everything, with many photo opportunities. I stayed 'til after sun down and saw the lights come up and then it was a different beautiful all over agsin. Definitely recommended.

A beautiful place to walk around and take in the history and gardens. Time your visit for a guard changing ceremony to experience the theatre of the ceremony. Refreshment facilities are available but it's best to be self sufficient. There are plenty of places to stop and rest, but no substantial food to purchase. The gift shop offers some lovely options for souvenirs also.
A very nice place! It reminds of the Forbidden City in Beijing, China. But this place has a much more beautiful architecture.

Information points are in english as well. Take the tram tour when you get there. It follows the wall and allows you to cover more points in a shorter time. There are other guard towers that you can walk to and once you've seen a couple, you've seen them all, but it is a pretty cool experience. Their are random personnel dressed as warriors which makes it cool as well. At the INformation center where the tram drops you off at there is an archery range where you can pay to shoot a recurve type bow and arrows at wood targets. There is also the gift store with the archery range. Pretty cool experience overall.
Huge palace. Beautiful infrastructure. It would've been good if they could place international language boards at each sight.
The palace is nicely preserved.The entrance fee was trivial but it would be good to have a guide to explain the different rooms.

This place is expansive! I had imagined it would be one or two buildings, but it's practically a town in an of itself. And inside each room, the details are incredible!The entrance is off of a downtown hub, so it's quite a transformation going from tall, modern city buildings to ancient walls, bricks, and tile. The part that I found most interesting was that looking north you only saw history with a mountain as your backdrop. You could get lost in time, but if you turned around it was so striking to see the juxtaposition of towering urban buildings just beyond ancient wall.
Very amazing Korean architecture that has intricate details and I was very eager to see and understand more! Glad we got a guide for the tour to bring us around!

review_title: Changing of the guards was fun to watch!
review_body: Interesting history and especially when the King had guards watching when he defecated and smelled and tasted it to make sure he was healthy! THe changing of the guards was fun to watch as well.

review_title: An interesting palace but very similar to palaces of this kind in Japan and China
review_body: It is a very beautiful palace that you should visit - by all means it has that old historic beauty you will enjoy. Having said that, it is similar to other Asian palaces you may have seen in Japan or China. Yes, the tapestries, paintwork, sculptures will be a little bit different but in the end it is the same or very similar grounds layout and style. I have enjoyed spotting some finer differences between what was in this palace and others I saw in Asia and you can surely spend a couple of hours within its walls to explore more.

Traditional palace located middle of city.There is performance on certain time. Its free and looks nice. In front of the 경복궁, there is a 광화문광장. I tried 한복 for free! Its not the traditional way to wearn but enough to get experience of wearing korean traditional clothes. It was really awesome.

If you set aside the history part (which is worth it in itself), it's absolutely beautiful and so big! The colors are unlike palaces in other countries. They also have free guided tours. Definitely worth it!
YES !! i have visited Gyeongbokguang palace at night!This is a special event when august..We so lucky got a chance to visit night view with gyeongbokgung palace !

This is great way to savor the culture of Korea, our group had a local guide who gave us specific details of the architecture and history of the palace.The Palace guards are very accommodating for photos.

It's a must to visit this wonderful place for any one who come to Seoul , here you will find the palace , monuments of the ancient loyal family , the wonderful park behind the palace , it's so good time you take for the family and any tourist who travel
If you are in Seoul its a must see. I suggest doing a palace tour day which might include a stop in Insadong. Take the subway as its cheap and easy to navigate.

review_title: OK but very crowded and busy
review_body: Got there just on changing of the guards so there were bus loads of tourists which made the area very crowded making what should be a peaceful place rather hectic. Had a better experience at other palaces.

Start at the gate and try to catch the changing of the guard..check for times.. we were able to don the uniforms after the change in the courtyard..tons of fun. Then stroll around the massive complex of structures and visit the adjoining museum to get the history of the dynasty. Walking further through the grounds will take you to the folklore art museum which was included in the price. Overwhelming and informative.

review_title: Our first tour day in Seoul
review_body: We got there just before the changing of the guards, so we were able to see the ceremony. A photo opp.The palace was interesting. There's a lot of history behind it, so I hope you have a knowledgeable tour guide.
very interesting and stunning introduction to traditional Korean architecture. Definitely good to purchase a printed guide (inexpensive) or take a guided tour.

Well worth a visit while you are in the areaExcellently maintained and spotlessly cleanWe arrived just in time to catch the changing of the guard with this adding to the magic enchantment of this beautiful palace

There's not much of ancient Korean history you can see in Seoul. And this palace is a must see. However it is less well maintained and less impressive than, say, its equivalents in Japan. (I realize that 35 years of Japanese colonial rule may have contributed to the comparatively poor state of Seoul's palaces). I would also replace the thin sand with gravel (grass?) as ground cover. Otherwise it feels a bit dusty.
The palace was overwhelming but I completeley enjoyed the tour. It was very informative in terms of Korean history.
Worth visiting if you want to see beautiful palace grounds but could only look inside the windows. Also, I wish tour guide spoke better english.

review_title: The most impressive of the 5 palaces in Seoul
review_body: This is the biggest and most impressive of the 5 palaces in Seoul. Its also the most visited, and does get pretty busy. Its totally worth getting an audio guide, to learn more about the buildings and the grounds. And make sure that you dont miss the guard changing ceremony. According to my guidebook its happening every hour, but actually its only every second hour, so you may want to check this in advance.

It's a perfect blend of nature and hystorical place. The place and palace it self is a very iconic, it's a must take a selfie spot. Inside, you'll see a beautiful lake and a scenic mountain. For a first timer in Korea, this is a lovely place. Get your camera ready and load it up with lotsa pictures!

A must for anyone's visit to Seoul. Access to the entire Palace grounds is provided so that one can experience at their own pace the lifestyle of Korean royalty. See the conservative nature of the Confucian royalty. From throne room, to living quarters, to the changing of the guard dressed in traditional Korea military garb, the visit to Gyeongbokgung Palace is a pleasant adventure.

review_title: Pretty palace, but overrun with crowds
review_body: 1 hour tops. Zip through. Take a few photos. Read a few signsZip out. I love history, but not with thousands of people elbowing me.
Changing guards ceremony was amazing, it's a colourful event with flags, trumpets and a loud drum. definitely a must see attraction, combines the harmony of nature and the orientalist architecture.

Gave us opportunity to see the changing of the national guards, the colorful clothes they wear and the ceremony that went with the changing of guards. The palace history is likewise awesome as well as the architectural styles during that time.

This is an awesome palace, not unlike the Forbidden city in Beijing, in terms of its design and magnitude. We were fortunate to get there just in time for the changing of the guards, at the front of the palace. The guards with their uniform fake moustaches and goatee beards were a funny sight to behold. There was an entrance fee involved, but good to know that anyone over the age of 65 gets to enter free. There were 3 main pavilions leading oneself to the back, where the kitchen and living quarters were located. My favourite building would have to be the one standing on v high stilts, surrounded by a moat /pond......absolutely beautiful and tranquil. We were able to appreciate the stark contrast between this complex of ancient buildings and all the futuristic skyscrapers in its backdrop. This palace is very well maintained. And worth a visit.

i found place quite boring to walk around if i'm honest, whilst it is cheap to get in, there isnt that much to see as all the historic stuff has been rebuild with new materials hence taking away some of the buzz and ambiance!
beautiful palace, with lily ponds, and gorgeous views of the mountains behind, this is a gem, glad we took the time to go visit!

Gyeongbokgung is a huge palace in the city center. I took subway there. Unfortunately I cannot wait for the guided tour so I just look around, quite not fun and uninformed. There is a photo spot for you who want to wear palace guide uniform. They also have the Guard Ceremony several times a day which is, for me, is the highlight of this place. Suggestion: make sure you come in the right time for guided tour (depends on your language) because it makes huge difference for your visit. Moreover, the museum next to the palace is said to be good but unfortunately I did not have the chance to visit.

This palace was so beautiful. It is a large property with many different buildings to see. It is a well visited site with many people in attendance each day. Very interesting place that everyone should see.

review_title: Definitely must see (in Seoul), but not amazing
review_body: I know that I am in the minority here, but if you have visited other palaces in Asia - for instance in Beijing - then this place will definitely pale in comparison. It is still interesting, and the architecture is beautiful, but it is a style that is found in other palaces. If this is your first trip to Asia, this will be interesting.

The Palace is a very popular spot with Tourist,so it is crowded all day.Take a pair of good walking shoes with you,because the visit takes about 3-4 hours on foot.If possible , try to visit around lunch time, between 12-13:30,when most of the Tour groups would be on lunch break.

Beautiful palace and was lucky enough to catch the changing of guards process. On the general Seoul tourist website, it only mentioned the time was at 10am, but it changes guards 3 times a day. !0 am, 1 pm and 3 pm.

Changing of the guards is at 11:00am , 1:00 pm and 3:00 pm. It’s nice to watch the changing of the guards as it will give you an Idea on the Korean culture. There are scheduled tours around the palace with different languages. Get ready to walk and walk and walk under the sun (it depends on the season as we went there during summer), but it’s definitely worth it.

review_title: Changing of the guards in traditional clothing
review_body: Free to see the changing of the guard which happens several times a day. Long parade with Korean music and traditional costumes to get the guards in place to make the changing of the guards. Those 65 or older can show passport and get free admission ticket at the ticket booth.

review_title: Don't miss changing of guards and free folk museum tour
review_body: The changing of the guards is worth the visit. It is a large place and wheelchairs are available if needed.A college student offered us a free folk museum tour in English which was very thorough and interesting.
It is great to visit the palace. The guides are good and it is so large that you can feel the silence everywhere..even when it is very crowdy

review_title: Must catch the changing of the guard
review_body: Very cheap admission although a bit disappointed that none of the buildings had any furniture in them, unlike when visiting a British stately home for example.

review_title: A Step in to Korea's Royal Past
review_body: I have seen the Gyeongbokgung Palace several times in Korean dramas, and was really excited to visit this palace. I visited the Palace on a weekday, in the early morning where there were less people. At the ticketing office, a cheap information booklet is sold for 500won that offers a comprehensive walking guide to the palace. I spent the day walking around the palace, admiring the architecture of the palace, including the huge Gyeonghoeru. The Hwangwonjeong was also a very serene place to take a break. The palace was linked to the National Museum of Korea where a huge collection of the Royal History of Korea is housed. Their gift shop also offers a huge selection of Korean history and culture books in English, of which I got a few.

The Gyeongbok Palace show us the respect and importance Koreans gave to their King, the palace had lots of space combined in elegance and grandure, the rite of Changing the Guards was equally a sight to see.. It showed us the discipline instilled among Koreans.. But i really admired the spacious grounds that made up for the beauty of the place..

Have been twice to Gyeongbokgung Palace. It's a very cheap attraction--around 3 dollars. You can easily spend over an hour exploring the palace and the grounds. Definitely a great place for photos.It's very refreshing to spend time here away from the hustle and bustle of Seoul. This is easily on my "must do" list for Seoul every time I come to the city.

review_title: A part of Korean's rich culture and history
review_body: The palace complex is huge, and the entrance fee is relatively inexpensive. Walking through the palace complex allows for one to experience the rich culture and history of Korea.

There's a museum there, and other museums nearby too like the Museum of Contemporary Art within 2 minutes walking distance which you can pair with this trip.The weather was good when we visited and it was lovely walking the palace grounds. The museum is a 3 level, informative place that brings you back to the olden times with many real artifacts nicely preserved.Titles and descriptions come in Korean, English and Mandarin and the place is spacious and neat.Definitely worth the visit here to learn about Korean history.

The Palace (in the centre of Seoul) is huge and worth doing with a guide, if you can. It's a replica, as previous versions were destroyed during the many invasions. As previously mentioned by another reviewer, the rooms within each building can become repetitive without the benefit of a guide explaining the rooms and how they were used.Still, it's worth seeing checking out some of the rooms and then watching the changing of the guards in traditional Korean attire. There's a museum deep inside the grounds of the Palace, which offer a great reprieve from the humidity on a hot day.

This is the replica of the palace from the last Joseon dynasty since the original structure was destroyed during the Japanese occupation. It's about 3 dollars to enter and they have free English tours available which takes about an hour . The changing of the guard parade is really colorful and you can take pictures near the guards but you can't really touch or get too close to them. It's really big and in the summer can really get hot so bring provisions. At the back there's a gate where you can pass to get near the Blue Palace for some photo ops.

Worth visiting. Come just before 1pm, as this is when the change of the guards ceremony begins. Then, you can have a guided tour (about one hour, but worth it to get some explanations on the palace and its history.) There's an English tour at 1:30 pm.

Even though the palace is a reconstruction, it has been beautifully recreated in every detail. I arived there early as to avoid the crowds as by the time i left it was started to fill up. The whole palace complex is HUGE! It does take a bit of time to walk around it. There some wonderful buildings here.

review_title: A lot of buildings, but they are all the same.
review_body: The area of the palace is very large, so it takes a lot of walking to visit everything. I used English audio guide, which told me details of every building and gate, what was it's purpose, when it was destroyed and rebuilt, but I missed general history of the palace. Buildings are very pretty and well preserved, with beautiful paintings on the wooden ceilings and walls. However, they are all very similar to each other. You can't enter them, but you can look through the windows, and they are all almost empty. The best for me were ponds and garden. You can't even get close to the buildings on the ponds, but even from the distance you can tell it's something different. It took me over 2 hours, and it was hot day. If you visit on such a day, don't forget to bring a bottle of water.

I used the Free English tour. You learn a little history - get told your ticket gets you into the folk museum next door (which I actually found more interesting).The Korean psyche has zero time for the Japanese who raped the country and its occupants over a 40 year period until they got nuked.During this period this Palace which once comprised 550 buildings was reduced to one or two so what you see is a reconstruction in progress. Something you have to get used to because if the Japanese did not blow it up, tear it down or use it for target practice then fire will have reduced it to cinders at least once and possibly several times.
A great place to walk around, especially in the fall or spring. Large tours visit regularly on weekends, however.

review_title: A nice place to walk around and enjoy
review_body: It's so neat to see the historic restored houses/palaces set up in the middle of the city. It's a larger area than I had expected. Good for an afternoon trip.

If you are a Korean history craze or k drama fans, you may not find it interesting. It is clean, well kept but simple and small scale if compare to China. Should visit once but won't go back. It is close to the famous ginseng chicken soup place. Can walk there after your visit.
I was completely in awe of this palace. We spent hours exploring the grounds and taking pictures. The architecture and history in this place are not to be missed!!

I went here first thing in the morning. To beat the crowd but even after every one showed up it was still fantastic. Alot of temples and history. Expect to spend about 3 hours including the museum, which is a must sea as well.

A vast, sprawling and frankly uninspiring estate of allegedly very old palace buildings, of which all were empty inside, and which had been so thoroughly refurbished in and out it looked as though they'd been built last year. There are vast open flagged spaces between each of the buildings, and probably the least unattractive is the one in the picture on Tripadvisor. There is the changing of the guard - a bit of a Disney luridly-coloured 'show'. with the actors not looking as though they're enjoying it much either. What saves it is the intricate tilework, soffits and external dressing of the buildings, which are worth photographing. There are barely any cafes inside so bring plenty of water.

I did my daughter's first birthday photo shoot here. Well maintained. Huge. too much walking and too much to look around. Best to visit in fall or spring. Palace tours available in different languages.

need to relax and free your mind from shopping and eating, this is the place to be for a little peaceful getaway, very romantic and photogenic place, it does require walking as you would in the shopping mall but the difference is, you are actually spending quality time with you loved ones and bonding with your soulmate.

We spent a couple of hours looking around this beautiful palace. I've not seen anything like this before right in the centre of the city. The architecture and the gardens are amazing at every turn. You really get a feel of how things used to be and you forget you are in the biggest city in South Korea!Highly recommended especially if the weather is good.

Cheap to visit at 3000KRW! The place is huge and a lot of walking is required. Interesting change of guards every hour from 9am to 3pm. You get to see the Emperor's court and his throne, concubines' rest quarters, servants area, a beautiful lake and a museum. Good place for photography.
inside center of the city,you can find such a beautiful place to explorer.good place to relax when you tired of noise and shopping.
a palace that you should see. Very easy to reach, because the subway connected directly to the place.

review_title: Top palace to visit in Seoul
review_body: Definitely the top palace to visit when in Seoul. If you go, the morning changing of the guards is a must see (longer than the rest). A great expansive property to explore and hard to believe it's only 10% of the size it once was!
wonderful place, romantic, great to take pictures, in the middle of the city center, also special night visits possible
Would be better if some description can be put in front of each of the rooms. I asked for digital guide but the staff seems did not understand.

Wow, beautiful palace and so unique. We didn't go inside but we're already so much impressed with the beautiful and immense outside. Watch the nicely dressed guard in their original costumes at the front gate. From you walk in 10 min to Insadong

As a local people in Seoul, I think from time to time what place should I recommend to foreign people visiting Seoul, Korea. Several palaces, and Jongmyo Shrine is the first places to recommend. Korean palaces are relatively small compared with palaces in other countries (for example, the forbidden city in Beijing). So for someone who think size matters, this palace is not an impressive place. I just hope tour guide can properly explain the history, culture, and architecture of this palace.

It is a beautiful palace! With a nice park around the palace. But the other famous palace which is bigger looks exactly the same. I recommend going to one of the palaces if you don't have that much time.
Plan on spending at least a few hours at this extensive and very picturesque location which comprises quite a number of buildings, plus a museum on Korean culture and history.
I would recommend visiting here if you are in the area!! We had a lot of fun and really enjoyed our time here. LOVED IT!!!
Great palace to visit -- Would recommend to more detail in English or English speaking tour guide to get full effect of site -- Beautiful Palace

It is undeniably a must place to visit in Seoul, it is unique because it is an ancient palace surrounded by the skyscrapers out there. You can see a contradictive view. The only downside is that tourists can just have a look at the building but not inside the building. I would like to see how does inside look like for bedroom and kitchen.

review_title: Never expect visiting a Palace to be interesting
review_body: There is a reason why this place does not get an excellent review from me but let me tell you about the Pro's first. A great place to be for families who wants to visit and explore the palace and while many think that the place is just touch and go, you are wrong, this place is fairly huge. My cousin and me walked around the area for at least 2 hours before we decided to go. At certain part of the day, there will be some performance by the Korean citizens to portray how the guards used to do during their change of guard ceremony. At certain days, you can even try out their traditional clothing.The cons is that it is closed on Tuesday and although I have been here for 3 times, the traditional wear area was always close. Not sure if it will get open anytime soon though. This is the only downside but overall, I would recommend anyone who has never visited an ancient palace to come and visit
This building says it all. A traditional palace with a great structure, great architectural concept and great art.
IfFyou travel to seoul dont miss this one. And the ceremony too.Its really large area i think,but its nice

review_title: A must-visit if you are in Seoul
review_body: Very traditional palace, with beautiful gardens and constructions. Inside there is an interesting museum about Korean history and culture worth the visit. The guards of the palace dress typically as in Joseon Dynasty.
Definitely a must see attraction if you've travelled once in Seoul. Combines the harmony of nature and the orientalist architecture. Take your time to walk around. Sit down at the pond and relax.

A must see whilst in Seoul,amazing history and the buildings are stunning.Take your time and see everything,it was very hot while we were there so take a lot of water with you,having a guide was also a must have as the knowledge they give you is something you could not get on your own. We so loved South Korea.

review_title: Can skip if itinerary is full
review_body: The palace is big but nothing much to see except building structure. Almost nothing to see in the palace as well. Perhaps a guide tag along to explain the historical would be better
Changing of the guards ceremony was amazing. All the uniforms were so colourful. Don't miss this event. Not sure how often it happens each day.
Went during winter. Its beautiful and amazing. The snow, frozen lake and etc. Would love to go again on other season.
The change of guard procession was interesting. Bring a hat and plenty of water when visiting during those hot days. A must-see when visiting Seoul.

I took the english tour. I think they are open everyday and every 2 hours. It took about 2 hours and it was very informative. The palace ground is very large and beautiful. You can take the tour and ask questions or leave and wander around yourself. It's a good way to meet new people in your group who speak the same language or take pictures for you. Very recommended. I got great photos from it

My perception of Seoul before actually visiting was that is a largely artificial city with no real history or culture relative to places like Hong Kong. Seeing Gyeongbokgung Palace and a some of the other cultural sights during my visit proved me wrong.I happened to arrive around when an English language tour was about to begin, so I joined up (it was free). I won't give any spoilers, but the guide helped me understand why Seoul might not have quite as much of its pre-modern history on display compared to some other cities.Further, the on-going work to rebuild Seoul's heritage sites is impressive and uplifting. I'll look forward to future visits to see it unfold.

If you visit Seoul and don't see this palace, you need a doctor. It's like visiting Beijing without seeing the Imperial Palace. Try to check the times for the changing of the guards. It's a colourful event with flags, trumpets and a loud drum. Kids will love it. The best views are are on the left side or near the front gate.Guided tours are handy, but it's fun to stroll at your own pace. The palace grounds are greener near the left side at the back, cwhere you'll find a small lake. This area also has more ornate decorations and several gates and doorways.The palace rents out baby strollers, but the large cobblestones will give your child a serious massage.
A nice place to visit especially for viewing the changing of guards. Unlike other countries, the guards there are dressed in very beautiful colours, A must to visit and no entry fee is required.
It is one of the main attractions of Seoul together with the Seoul tower and other famous neighbourhoods like hongdae, gangnam and itaewon
This is the biggest palace in Korea. So large that it took hours to complete the sightseeing in the inside of the palace.

I recommend a tour because I regret not getting one. It was still interesting and worth seeing. The temples have a lot of beauty and great detail to them. I expected more greenery but I'm assuming that's too much for cost of upkeep

Visited this palace with my aunt.It was big and beautiful and although filled with people it just felt desolate...like just imagine how it was when a dynasty lived there. Just open space.Like all palaces the design is colorful and bright with flowers in the cut outs and trim.The changing of the palace guards was a big to do...there was this whole official ceremony and everything and that was really amazing to see.

I love Korea culture so i was so happy to visit here. Many places I seen in movies and very large. I spent many hours here. People were friendly and I loved the folk museum. It can be crowded so go day time.

The grounds are well maintained and extensive, you can spend hours walking around and exploring. As we were walking through, we were trying to read up on the history and find out a little more. My impressions were just that everything was very bare...although it was a nice quiet walk, I found it to be rather uninteresting as a palace. Walls and nothing more but nice scenery.

review_title: Free admission and plenty to see
review_body: From entering this palace... you are just in awe of its sculptures, scenery and the colourful guards... You will see many building types, including pagodas, a huge museum of korean life, a street village and plenty of gardens for picnics.. Its amazing. Well worth a visit.

A beautiful palace in the middle of Seoul. This place has some amazing photography options. They just opened a new part on the east side which is great for the photo lovers. You could spend all day here if you wanted. And dont forget about the free museum in the back right of the Palace.
This is quiet and neat place If you want to feel korean culture You should visit hereMust visit place

review_title: Amazing and extensive palace and grounds, right in the city
review_body: This is a massive complex on the edge of the city centre. It takes a couple of hours to do it justice, so dress appropriately and don't forget the umbrella.
Well maintain palace with a picture perfect view! Need to purchase a ticket to go in and worth every penny. The palace is big and there is a tour in the preference language but please check the time!

review_title: Feels like going back to Dynasty era
review_body: A prominent tourist attraction, this palace is on the A list of most tourists. The palace and its surroundings are kept to be pristine so as not to damage or harm its antiquity. Hence, tourists can only observe the palace from outside although they can still wander around the site. The weather is very humid and hot in summer esp. because of the lack of trees around the complex. Still, this palace is worth the while.
This is closed to insa-dong . One can walk this palace before walking around insa -dong, and some of the old ancient looking house. Sovereign is better price here.
i like walking in this palace, ever though sometimes its kind of busy but still a good place for talk a walk, growing the inner peace and taking a photograph esp in the spring and autumn

The palace was really easy to get to if you take the subway. Entrance was 3,000 won. You could purchase a combination book that included tickets to other palaces for 10,000 won. The book is good for 3 months. The grounds definitely involved a lot of walking, so make sure to bring some water! Great tour!

review_title: Well worth a visit of a few hours.
review_body: Very interesting to learn a bit about Korean history. It was well worth waiting for the free English tour. The guide spoke English well and was very obliging.

Suitable for many types of visitors as it is park-like and relaxing as well as chock full of amazing history. It's a beautiful place that's romantic for couples or interesting for families. Well worth the visit! Anyone going for the first time would benefit by reading up on it's history first.

review_title: Check to have the tour to know the details
review_body: I highly recommend it. All the temples that you can see in Korea are simply great and all of them have English tours for free. It could not be better.

It is not the most beautiful palace of Joseon Dynasty, but it functioned as the main palace. You can feel the Joseon in the palace. Don't forget to dress up as Korean Traditional, Hanbok. Free admission!! Public Transportation recommended.

A wonderful surprise when you first glimpse the palace across the courtyard. Colourful guards defend the front gates. Such a spectacle. Miles of buildings and then out to the park at the rear. Cross to the folk museum for another look at the history of the Korean people. A great day out.

histirical beautifully constructrd koearian palace, nicely dressed soldiers and the gardens sorrounding the complex give you the feeling like you are traveling in time and live with ancient Korean kings.there are good tour guide who lead the tourists and give information about every single corner of the palace, free of charge.

review_title: Younger brother of the Forbidden City
review_body: Although its a 1990s reconstruction of the 14th century palace, it is well worth a visit. Very reminiscent of the Forbidden City in Beijing in a better location with mountain views and surrounding parks

This is a great place to spend a couple of hours. The history is fascinating about the Japanese occupation and impact on this site. Beautiful lake and a very calming vista over the waterlilies, especially on a hot day. Architecture is interesting to see how the Korean's design their palaces. It is also free to visit on Liberation day, 15 August. The locals love it as well, so it can be a bit crowded on the 15th.

Most of the buildings you see at this palace complex, including the main throne hall and the famous front gate, are recent reconstructions. This palace is in fact one of the least historically authentic ones in Seoul, not to mention crowded. As a Seoul resident, I mainly come for the 2 museums on the palace grounds, the National Palace Museum and the National Folk Museum. The former has a good restaurant and a brilliant shop.
Busy road to cross to get to the palace. Enjoyed seeing the changing of the guards. Large compound which was impressive to walk around but busy and pushy crowds to go into the actual temples.
This is a must visit palace and garden. Really worth it! Middle of the city! For small kids it can be a bit to big as you can walk around for hours.
Worth to see.Not too old.Needs lots of walking to see all the palace areas and many uphill and downhill..

Right in the heart of Seoul, this is a must-do if you are interested in learning about the history of Korea. The palace grounds are beautiful. Be sure to do yourself a favor and hook up with a tour guide so you can learn as much as possible. And bring your camera because the sites are amazing

It was very big and and very empty because I went during the MERS scare. Beautiful architecture. If you want a tour guide, you have to call ahead. I got to go to a small building that is normally off limits.

One of the main attraction in Seoul, no one shall miss it. Be sure to witness the changing of guards, takes place at 10:00, 13:00, 15:00, three times a day. For those who like more detailed information of the palace should join the free guided tour (English, Japanese, Chinese). For English free guided tour, at 11:00, 13:30, 15:30.
If you have not visited a palace, you can go visit this one. Otherwise the Forbidden City in Beijing or the Meiji palace in Japan are much more classic and full of untold stories.

cultured and heritage always one of the best thing/place to visited especially when they have and related with long great history. the scenery was awesome and the environment was really harmony. as advise, you should have more than 3 hours if you want to finish visit this place or maybe more than that.. its really big and really nice...

This palace was visited as we had 10 days in Seoul. I personally found that when you visited the first couple of temple's everything seemed the same. There were some nice lakes and an interesting museum to look at the history of south Korea however, 2 to 3 hours was enough for me.The war museum is a must. It deserves to be no 1 on trip advisor.

review_title: A highlight of our visit to Seoul
review_body: Great place to spend some time imagining how life was like. Excellent museum of the palace as well, just to the left when you come in the main gate. Try to catch the changing of the guard for a ceremonial treat!
This is a very beautiful place to visit and take photos (you do not need a long time there)our tour guide from "Korea private tour" was great

The Korean people lost generations of culture and history though the Japanese occupation so what you see is not original but its also not to be missed. Please visit as it gives a wonderful insight into a Korea in the past. If you are familiar with Chinese or Vietnamese architecture it is worth gettin an informed guide to explain the subtle differences between each culture. They may look the same but they aren't.

Cultural heritage never seized to amaze me everywhere I go to a palace or castle. Preserve well, and the details is superb. The museum is a breeze and easy to learn.. Need more english explanation though.. Must visit...

A really nice place to go to, when I went there it wasn't to crowded so it was really nice to just walk around and enjoy the scenery, see all the old buildings, see the gardens and the ponds was especially nice and quiet.

review_title: It's neat, but not the original structures
review_body: It's very neat; however, since the Korean War destroyed nearly all the original buildings, it didn't have the same effects.

If you are into the history of Korea then this is a must see. I am not, but I learned alot on the tour about the history of korea, the living conditions of royalty as well as the servants etc. The architecture was amazing, the amount of detail in the painting was impressive. Glad we went.

review_title: Obviously one of the must to see places
review_body: Importnat and one of the five palaces in Seoul. Very typical structure for Corea and exciting structure.

review_title: Back in time of Joseon Dynasty at Gyeongbokgung!
review_body: Just back in time after they completed the hardwork on the main gate. This place was offering me romantic and gigantic at the same time. If you are big fan of Korean series, don't miss this spot.
Amazing photo opportunities with a wealth of history and culture. Definitely a must see location of South Korea. Interesting architecture and stories of the past.

review_title: Hot but amazing and well kept
review_body: I was so impressed with Gyeonbokgung Palace. It is very well maintained and very easy to get to. Take a subway ride, come up the stairs and there you are. Truly amazing how they have kept this beautiful piece of history in the middle of skyscrapers and buildings. They offer free guided tours and I really suggest taking one. If you go in the summer months be sure to take lots of water, an umbrella and a hand fan as there is no shade. Pictures will not even do justice of how amazing the palace was.
Very beautiful with lots of history and a lovely garden, located very centrally so other attractions around. Don't miss this if you're in Seoul.

A must see when traveling to Seoul. There is much history in beauty in this palace! The Joseon period is a huge part of Korean history. I highly recommend doing a guided tour; they're free and happen multiple times everyday. The tour guides know a lot about the place and its history, and you see a lot of the palace without getting overwhelmed by its complexity.
Immersed ourselves into this really ancient romantic palace! Wearing the "hanbok" taking photos! The roofs and exterior façade were exquisitely done up! Check out the Pagoda nearby!
Must do visit of a stunning, over 700 year old main Korean royal palace in central Seoul. Closed on Tuesdays.

Basically everything in Seoul is crowded, and this place is no exception. There are some lesser-known palaces around the downtown area that are equally beautiful (if not as huge). I prefer them, actually, over this palace. (Changdeokgung)Insider tip: if you're visiting in the summer with little kids, let them play in the fountain directly in front of the palace. It's a bit of a hike from the front gate, but a great way to avoid a kid with a case of the grumpies.

This was a great experience, i thought the arhictecture was so interesting, and gives a real feeling of traditional korea. even though it was very rainy, there were still many tourists which is understandable as its an outstanding palace. I would recommend not going during monsoon rainy season though if possible.

We went there free of charge since there's a summer promotion in July 2015. My first time being in a huge magnificent palace and there were so much to explore! We were there by 1pm and witnessed the royal changing of guard! The guards could stand so still despite the hot weather! We were deeply impressed! The palace is huge and it requires good stamina and great deal of time if you wanna explore the whole site. Furthermore, it's connected to the National Folks Museum, and there are also small little houses for you to enter! Try to enter all of them, some even provide free photo taking services and you will be surprised! Haha.
Very nice park. Beautiful building, with 2 descriptions: English and Korean. Enter cost 3$, I was on Saturday day and it wasn't full of people.

review_title: Very good place for knowing more of Korean Culture
review_body: You can introduce by yourself in Korean History, you can feel in the time of these palaces and close your eyes and to imagine beeing inside the palace some hundreds of years ago, really is phantastic to transport in the time, all you need is imagination and to look slow every passage of korean history and to read and understand the texts of every place in the way.

review_title: Worth the visit - Especially for Changing of the Guard.
review_body: The visit to Gyeongbok Palace was one of the highlights of my trip. I was able to be there at 10AM for the changing of the guard. I loved seeing the colorful uniforms and hearing the traditional drum being hit. Later I was able to sit near the pond where the King used to entertain and throw parties. The architecture is wonderful, as well. Lots of walking. I recommend bringing an umbrella for shade during the summer months.

well. you're not going to Korea if you're not going to this palace! it's true guys, i'm not kidding. I've seen a lot of korean palace in korean dramas, but never thought the history behind it. lucky me, when i was there, there was a free english tour guide to lead us about this palace, it's really worth my time

Very similar to the Forbidden City in Beijing in terms of structure and designs. Grand and resplendent. Saw the changing of guards in the morning and beating of the traditional Korean gong. I could have spent a day exploring the grounds. National Folk Museum is located here as well.

On a glorious sunny early summer day, I had the opportunity to enjoy some of the sights of Seoul, that bustling Korean metropolis that is surprisingly (for a Westerner) full of unexplored history.My first stop was the Gyeongbokgung Palace just near the Presidential Palace and the centre of the business district around Jongno-gu.A bit of history from the official guide. The first palace buildings were built in 1395, three years after the Joseon Dynasty was founded by King Taejo (Yi Seong-gye) after the capital of the newly founded dynasty moved from Gaeseong to Seoul (then known as Hanyang). The entrance is a grand courtyard, similar to the classic imperial Chinese design for the Forbidden Palace, it is breathtaking!After then, a range of buildings, temples and garden lakes were constructed and which survived until the Japanese occupation resulted in almost all buildings being dismantled.Now, lovingly rebuilt, they exude peace and harmony with a dose of tranquillity around the gardens and lake.A great place to visit during a free couple of hours and in the heat of early summer, bring plenty of water..

Stunning in size and culture. One of the top two palaces to see while in Seoul. Make sure to get in before too late in the day when they stop letting people in, you need sufficient time to visit around!

The gardens in this palace are very lovely and relaxing place to walk around. We came here on the weekend and although it was a bit crowded, you did not get the crowded feeling while walking in the gardens. The infomation about the history of the palace was a bit limited.

A true icon of korea. To really appreciate this country, you must most definitely need to see the palace! A lovely place. Plan at 3 hours to get around the big place. I love it here. Been 12 plus times!!!!!
Beautiful architecture and a charming man-made pond inside. Perfect place for k-pop fanatics to visit.

We visited the palace and we're lucky to start by watching the guards change performance. The visit was enjoyable. At the end we entered the attached museum which was fascinating. The only problem was the hot weather did not help us to enjoy the palace outdoor.

I visited this place with my host. She told me stories of how she use to come here and played when she was a kid. Then she told me stories of how she brought her kids here. I think hearing her stories and hearing about the history of the palace gave me more of an understanding of what this palace meant to Koreans. It was a really wonderful place. It is the perfect place to see and feel the past, present and future.
The palace was so clean and the staff are very polite. They have museum as well before we walk ard the whole palace i suggest you can visit the museum.

The Palace is the largest in the Seoul and dates back to the late 1300's. The grounds are large with many buildings and 2 lakes. It's a marvel to see the work of all artisans that created all the buildings and landscaping. It's like going back in time...

This palace is so big and aroubd every corner there is a hidden teasure. It's rich in history and stunning to strole through. Little kids can run around but will get bored after a little while since there isn't much that will facinate their brains. If you visit keep in mind that Jul/Aug is Monsoon time so it might start raining whilst you're there. Take an umbrella incase and go enjoy. You could also have a small picnic there i think.
Golden roof of Kings Room is totally amazing. Excellent guide and well described. Number one place to visit.
Definitely worth a visit, nice buildings and if lucky get to see change of the guard in the traditional gear.
The biggest palace resides in the heart of Seoul.Entrance fee: about 5 US$. Free guided tour in English - check the information for details. Fabulous building and history

review_title: Well maintained but more trees for shade, please
review_body: Please plant more trees for shade. It's quiet beautiful but sometimes it just get's too hot during summer.

review_title: A quick breeze through is enough.
review_body: If you've been to other grand imperial palaces, like the Versailles or the Beijing Imperial Palace, this was ok. It was well kept, but it could use more contextual explanations.

Beautiful Palace and Gardens. We also arrived just in time to see to changing of the guards. Very spacious so be prepared for a lot of walking. Museum next door provide very educational historical background of Korea. We went during July when all public tours were free.

review_title: The most beautiful attraction in Seoul
review_body: The Palace is very beautiful and worth a visit, it was in my opinion the most beautiful thing I saw in Seoul. At the entrance to the palace you can see the traditional guards and there are various events during the day that you can watch, such as the change of the guards. At the entrance there is a sign with the timetable for these events, it is worth to wait for one of them!

Had the opportunity to see the changing of the guard and English speaking tour of the palace. There was a special tour of the Gyeonghoeru Pavilion - Korean language only. But the guide found me prior to the tour and gave me an overview. This tour is only available for a short period of time - so glad I was able to see this peaceful palace.

Very beautiful. The best out of the 4 palaces in Korea. It is optional to buy a group pass to visit all 4 palaces. I will not recommend it unless you have plenty of time to visit all 4 palaces. Its pretty much the same.

review_title: Don't miss the changing of the guards!
review_body: This is a very beautiful palace and is worth the visit. We just arrived at the end of the 10am changing of the guards and you should make a note to arrive to see the whole thing. Apparently the ceremony is conducted several times a day and is full of pomp and noise, but is fun.
Magnificent palace. Very large grounds. Was free in july when I visited. There is a folk palace on the grounds as well. Good way to learn of Korean history.

review_title: One of the most beauty and Wonderful palace.
review_body: I was so lucky to have the opportunity to visit this palace and also able to joint tour guide inside the palace ground. I was also lucky to watched the Royal Guards Exchanging at 14:00. Of course this take place 3 times per day.I would recommend anyone that visiting Seoul to come here and take this guided tour. It was a really interesting and educational to learn about the Korean history.

review_title: That is really grand stoned rectangle surrounded by the many palaces !
review_body: From our hotel Biwon, that was not so far to get on this royal great place. It is one of the five Seoul and surely Korean sites,that count as the World Heritage Centres of the world. We headed along the Yulgok Road and got in the front of the main gate of the Royal Palace, that is, Gyeongbokgung Palace. Before we entered inside, or within the great square, stone paved, we witnessed to such great royal ceremony, that was done by the royal guard in the very beautiful red and blue costumes. Many of them carried the spears and royal flags. Took some pictures. Inside we found ourselves entouraged with tipically korean architectural design, presented by the buildings at one or two storeys, the wood fences, the stairways, that led to the doors of these houses of high noble men of old Korean royalty. This palace was built by the Joseon dynasty in 1395, one of the most important dynasties throughout the whole history of Korea.On the site there are five grand palaces. This place have had the turbulent history, the palace was two times demolished. First time it was during the Japanese invasions of Korea (1592 - 1598) and second time, it was in the more recent history, that is, in the years of repeated Japanese occupation of Korea, from 1910 until 1945.Really immense square, with the great blue sky above us, elegant, nice coloured palaces all around and large stone plates under the feet. Here again we saw the Royal Guard, this time in the procedure of changing the posts.The very beginning of our stay in Seoul, and how it was impressive !!

The biggest and historically most important of the many palaces in Seoul. Watch a changing of the gate guards and take a guided tour -- much to see and appreciate. Prepare to cringe a few times if you're Japanese -- the history includes some serious unpleasantness, like the occasion when Japan sent 60 guys to assassinate the empress. But you'll still enjoy the tour -- I think! The guides are friendly and knowledgeable. As an American with almost no knowledge of the Korean language, I certainly liked the tour.

More than the palace itself, the grounds were beautiful. Since we visited in spring, there were flowers everywhere and the weather was perfect. I would also recommend taking the free tour to get an idea of the palace's history. There is a lot of walking, so make sure to wear comfortable shoes.

We went with two kids 9&10 and we limited our visit to 1-2 hours max. Really warm (36*C) and afterwards we went to the DDP that was designed by Zaha Hadid. Great contrast to see traditional vs modern. But of course we love modern art...

review_title: Beautiful palace on a grand scale
review_body: Our family traveled to Seoul in June, 2015, at the height of the MERS scare, so our experience is pretty atypical. That said, even if you didn't have this magnificent palace basically all to yourself, it would definitely be worth a visit. After a quick look around the museum, we headed outside with our tour guide to explore the compound. The buildings are all gorgeous, with colorful painted details and airy, furnished rooms to peek into. The buildings are so large and imposing, it really evokes a sense of grandeur. This is a great place to get a historical perspective on the hyper-modern city of Seoul.

I've been to all the other palaces but don't think I can pick a favorite. What's nice about this one is the size (it's the largest) and even though it tends to be the busiest there's a lot of ground and buildings so the people get spread out. A trip to this palace gives you the opportunity to visit the National Palace Museum or the National Folk Museum. I've been to both museums and don't consider them "must sees" but are nice if you have the time and if you only have time for one I would recommend the Folk museum over the Palace museum.I've been here twice, once in the Spring and again in the Fall. Both times were beautiful because there was bloomed cherry blossoms in the Spring and colored leaves in the Fall.9am-6pm, last admission at 5pmAdult 3,000won (about $3)7-18 1,500won (about $1.50) 6 & under freeOther Info: watch changing of the guard ceremony and have your picture taken with one, special night time openingsPalace Website: www.royalpalace.go.kr
A must visit place in South Korea to have a glimpse of the country's rich history. Do not miss the royal changing of the guard when you visit.

I had just arrived in South Korea to live and this was the first tourist attraction I visited. What I saw of Korea before entering the gates of Gyeongbokgung Palace was all modernised. What I saw in this attraction was the Korea I've been eager to meet. The rich history. The detailed architecture. The stories. Gyeongbokgung is MASSIVE! It took me the whole day to walk around atleast 85% of the area before my legs caved in lol but a trip I would definitely recommend to anyone that visits or lives in South Korea. Wear comfortable shoes and charge your phones. You'll be taking so many photos.
In chosun's palace is remains now. also there is so clean insid. Many drama is in this palace and maybe half thousand of history. I like this palace

review_title: Seoul's biggest royal palace has a wonderful museum
review_body: Gyeongbokgung is the largest royal palace in Seoul and was the main royal palace for much of the Joseon (Choson) dynasty; that alone may or may not be enough to appeal to potential visitors. There are two really great things to see here, though: the changing of the guard with Joseon dynasty-costumed guards and the National Palace Museum, which is really worth an hour or two, filled as it is with interesting and beautiful art and artifacts. After you see Gyeongbokgung, make sure to see Toksegung (Daeksogung or Duksoo) Palace & the Secret Garden (Piwon) of Changdaekgung Palace as well. But just outside Gyeongbokgung's gate, Gwanghwamun, is a huge plaza with statues of King Sejong and Admiral Yi Sunshin, Korea's two greatest heroes; there's a small museum focusing on them located below the plaza that's worth an hour. And you should go back to Gyeongbokgung at sunset see Gwanghwamun at dusk, when it is at its most beguiling and photogenic.

review_title: Amazing palace worth going for a nice peaceful stroll
review_body: Palaces are always worth visiting, try to plan your visit around the ceremonies that are held to experience the culture.

some of buildings are not original due to sad invasion history. there are many signs with good information on most of buildings. there are few museums right next to palace. take your time will take approx. 2~4 hours
So good to see the palace in person. We saw this each time we watch historical Korean Dramas and being here just made it more real for us. So good that they maintained this.
A glimpse of Korea during a different era. Make sure you are there for the changing of the guard ceremony

In retrospect, this place probably requires a tour guide. At least for the front section it's just a series of very open assembly spaces on sandy ground. We missed any gardens to see the changing of the guard (a bit anti-climactic). The price was right, though (thanks MERS). Perhaps a couple more information stations would have brought the place to life.

review_title: Memorable place of my Korea visit.
review_body: This is one of the encient place in Korea. I have stepped up to this palace afternoon lazily after my tiredness of visiting Lotte World. But once i arrived there i become refreshes with this historical monument and it made worth of voting there. I would like to recumbent people to visit there once you are there in Seoul.

Our tour to the palace was fantastic. Already a fan of Asian imperial dramas, it was fun walking in the 'footsteps of kings' and imagining life in the past. The near by Museum was educational without being too encompassing and we were able to take in both before lunch.

review_title: Must see, don't forget the national folk museum next door
review_body: This is the Forbidden City of Korea. From an architectural perspective, very fascinating! It is quite similar to Chinese royal architecture, but there are plenty of differences to make it distinctly its own. If you like architecture, you will love wondering around this palace, and the tiny doors everywhere are so cute.Don't pay for a tour! All of the sites in Seoul have free English speaking tours, the trick is to find out the time, and to be on time for them. I found these tours to be fascinating, enjoyable, and full of information, so I highly recommend them. In the back is a gorgeous garden, with the Bukhansan Mountain as a backdrop, especially during the autumn, breathtaking. Stop by the Blue House (Korean version of the White House). And you have to spend a good hour in the folk museum which had a bunch of traditional and cultural artifacts, an ancient Hanok home, and a ~1960s style shopping street.
Nice place. High recommended to visit in Seoul. Be ready to do lots of walk. Many nice photo spots inside.
A must visit, Parade ceremony is a definitely not a miss.. have ample amount of time to visit the palace.

First time that i visited this country and city, and everyone told me "you need to visit this palace". They were not wrong. The palace is huge and is the best way to understand about the culture, the past and the difference between South Korea and the other asian countries. The entrance fee is not high, and also can buy one ticket that includes the visit to other palaces. Use comfortable clothes because you need to walk a lot but the views and buildings are amazing. Inside you can also visit one museum that is really nice. Amazing place for summer or winter!

Other than the huge amount of visitors in the afternoon I have nothing bad to say about this palace. Very large, beautiful buildings and gardens. Especially the area around the pond is beautiful, quite easy to spend an entire afternoon exploring this palace!

review_title: Rich culture experience that should not be missed....
review_body: Coming from a very young modern country, visiting ancient historic sites like this is an eye opener. It is so enriching to learn about the rich culture of another country.Gyeongbokgung Palace is a beautiful place to visit , a must see. It is a huge place, so be prepared to do some walking & spend some time here.But it is worth it. After all, there are no better places to learn about another country's culture than actually visiting their historic sites.

review_title: Place of culture and history learning of old Korea
review_body: A place to learn about the history of Korea in the Joseon Dynasty on the different palaces where the King worked and lived. Scenic cultural place with many stories told by the official guided tour, a great learning experience about old Korea. You may also want to watch the guards changing ceremony at the entrance of the Palace at designated timeslots and engage with a tourguide or audio guide yourself to hear about the tales of the Kings.
Liked how they keep it looking the way it look over 500 years ago.I liked the English tour, very informative.

Great palace - try to go so that you can see the changing of the guard. Seemed like Fridays are the day to go if you aren't part of a tour group. We roamed here for 2 1/2 hours and still didn't see everything! There's no food sold here so bring a picnic/snacks if you plan on taking a break towards the back of the palace where there's benches to sit and eat under the trees.

Real great palace that you cannot miss even short time visit in Seoul. Be sure to go on the Secret Garden tour as well.Also walk autside and around this Palace because you can find small but nice places where to eat with really nice local people.

Yes it is one of the best attractions in Seoul. It is a very big palace with huge garden. Don't forget to wear very comfortable shoes to walk in. And if you have a Korean customs to wear this is the best place to take some photos while wearing their beautiful dresses It is very recommend to visit it during the guard change to see it.

review_title: If you visit 1 of the 5 palaces go here
review_body: I also saw Changdeokgung. You really only need to see these 2 palaces. Of the two this one impressed me more. I was able to watch the guard changing ceremony and explored the extensive grounds.Try to hop on an English tour as you won't understand or know much about the architecture and significance of the buildings or their purposes.

review_title: A way to get immersed in korean culture
review_body: Make sure you have a chance to catch the royal guard changing ceremony. Admission and the ceremony is free (for the month of july). Alot of walking as the buildings are spaced apart. The palaces are more grand here but i found Changdeokgung (the other royal palace in walking distance) to be more scenic as the gardens were more elaborate and the mountains were more visible in the background. Try to catch the tours and it does it more justice then walking and looking on your own. The tour was free as well.
Great priority palace to visit in Seoul. Be sure to go on the Secret Garden tour as well, then explore the neighborhood afterwards. Nice small eateries in close proximity.

As you'll read in other reviews, this place is huge! You can easily spend an entire afternoon here which should allow you to see everything. There's quite a bit of walking, but you get a good idea of the architecture and culture.

Went there at april 15But if u want to see some sakura leafsI suggested u to go somewhere elseThe place is hugeInside there are castles, folks houses, museums and also hanbok rental in the front of gate.Plenty of tourist when we went thereIn my own opinion, i prefer to go to japan temple's or japan's castleBut it still a place to go if you want to sightseeing at seoul

The Palace was rather big, the atmosphere around the palace was very nice despite the large crowd. I think this place would be best visited in spring or autumn when the weather and temperature is just right.
Its a very big place.. if you walk alone make sure you have your guide book or internet,so you will know what is the palace all about and you will not lost.. ^^

review_title: Great sight to immense in Korea culture and history
review_body: We went to all the palaces in 1 day. This palace was pretty closed to where we were staying. This is considered the second most huge palace in Korea. On the day we went, there were free entrance for all tourists. I guessed this has to do with the recent MERS cases. There were not many people there. Was quite empty. Reached in time to see the changing of guards. Was pretty impressive with it. The changing of guards last around 15minutes. After which we headed inside the palace and it was HUGE!! You can view the beautifully structures of the palaces, the building of the home of the King and Queen. We spent an hour walking around and had our rest at a café in the palace itself.

The Palace had massive grounds. There were many different parts to the different aspects of palatial life in ancient Korea. Be prepared to walk. There was a beautiful pavilion, Gyeonghoru Pavilion, located in the middle of a large pond. Although I couldn't go onto the floating pavilion, I believe you can apply online to go onto the floating pavilion. The palace officials had a list of names who were permitted to enter. At the entrance of the palace, I was fortunate to catch the reenactment of the changing of the palace guards. So, check the performance times so you can make it there. There are also English speaking guides available free of charge to guide you around the palace.

A pretty big palace. it's not as big as The Forbidden Palace in Beijing but it was nice. It definitely had the Korean architecture and culture. The pavilions were nice but pretty empty. Worth a visit!
I was able to visit during a business trip and loved the beauty and history this provided. I did not get a guided tour which probably only adds to the experience but will loved my visit.

review_title: There may be more to it.
review_body: I spent little time there, mostly due to the great heat of the day. The palace seems to be mostly grounds (though I could be wrong about that). There are great local places to eat nearby.

review_title: Join the guided tour for a more rewarding visit
review_body: The guided tour helps you understand and know what the palaces were about, the tour guide I had have good English but her voice volume was a bit too low.
Could not get in, all closed up with construction inside. Disappointing although some good traditional Korean restaurants around the area.

Gyeongbokgung Palace is absolutely huge, but after a while all of the buildings start to look very similar. The first part of the palace is the most interesting: Gwanghwamun Gate, the large paved courtyards and the throne room are truly impressive. After the first 3 or 4 buildings I got bored very quickly and found that the rest of the palace consisted of nothing more than empty rooms in near identical buildings. The only features of interest past the initial cluster of buildings were the small lake with the garden island (behind the main palace) and the large pavilion for official entertaining on a large lake to the west of the main section of palace buildings. A lack of clear signage made it hard to find where to go next. I spent an hour and a half wandering around until I lost interest but you could easily spend much more time here if you wanted to. I was a bit disappointed that the palace is largely just empty buildings you can only see from the outside - it is hard to appreciate the rich history of Korea when one buildings looks the same as the one you just saw. Changdeokgung Palace had more character and was much prettier. The Changing of the Guard happens regularly and is a good show, but not as interesting as the one at Deoksugung Palace.

Beautiful! I went with an old roommate that I had while studying abroad in Korea. She was able to explain the details of the palace and give me some history. It is really pretty and I highly recommend it.
A nice place to spend a couple of hours just walking around, taking in the lovely gardens and historical buildings. Highly recommend it!

review_title: The one to visit if you don't have much time!
review_body: Let us say that if there is only a palace to be seen or if you have little time in Seoul, it is good that one that it is necessary to visit. Attention the palace is closed for the visits on Tuesdays. Opening hours are from 9am to 6pm. Cost approximately 3'000 Won for entry and half for children until 18 year old.The palace dates from the 14th century, and it extends over 40 hectares, it is a city in the city, count 2-3 hours to see the main buildings. A project of restructuring is in progress for a duration of 20 years reason why all the structures are not accessible.NB: every hour there is a change of the guarding in the entrance of the palace which deserves to be seen with its traditions.

This palace is huge, you could literally spend all day there. The changing of the royal guard ceremony is fun to watch at the very front. The pond is beautiful! We were able to walk through and take pictures in front of the blue house and see the national folk museum of korea. If you can only see one temple in seoul id highly recommend this be the one!

review_title: King private garden opened to the public
review_body: This amazing old hunting park used to be the King favorite spot to chill. Now the public can visit this place and enjoy their time. The place is massive and tour guide are available. You can see the old Korean building and nice swamps. I highly recommended this place. Please wear sport shoe as it might be a long walking there.

The place is huge! We spent about 30 minutes looking at everything. Absolutely worth seeing as it's convenient and is in the middle of town. We were in a rush so didn't go into the museum but it's definitely worth seeing if you are pressed for time and can only visit one palace.

The palace grounds are huge! Each building is so beautiful and unique, they're similar but completely different to Chinese or Japanese palaces (if that makes sense). There's a museum inside the grounds which you can enter with the palace ticket. There is a changing of the guards display every hour on the hour at the entrance. The palace is so easily accessible by metro, there's no excuse not to visit!

Enjoyed a walk through this palace, partially with the English tour that`s included in the entry fee. The palace is really nice. The guided tour was informative and added to the experience, although the guide did go much in the detail neither followed a chronology.The only real disappointment is that you need to book in advance to enter the palace building on the west side (surrounded by a small pond).

review_title: If you pick just one palace complex to visit in Seoul, make it this one
review_body: After wandering through all of Seoul's major palace complexes, I've picked Gyeongbokgung as my favorite. It is a huge complex with a number of beautifully designed buildings as well as a wonderful garden at the back. Although the garden at Gyeongbokgung Palace is not as big or as English-garden-like as the one at Changdokgung, it is a very pleasant an beautiful place to stroll through. Make sure to take the free guided tour and then wander around on your own as well because the tour doesn't cover everything (although the tour lasts for about an hour, the complex is just too huge). Try not to miss the guard changing ceremonies because they are a treat. The times are clearly marked at the notice boards as you enter. You can also try out the guard costumes at the building to the left as you enter through the main gate. It is open just before and after the guard changing ceremonies. Spots fill up quickly. Among all the palace complexes, this is the most archetypal, the biggest and perhaps the most majestic. Changgyeonggung has some of the most beautiful clusters of buildings though. There is no entry fee during July 2015.

Being the largest of the five palaces, I would say this is something you definitely should set aside time to see. The National Folk Museum of Korea is also within the premises, so make sure you have a few hours available. We spent 2,5 hours but didnt get around to see all the different buildings.
Much of the palace is reconstruction which lends a feel of in authenticity. Nevertheless, it is a lovely place to wander. A tranquil spot in the heart of Seoul.
this place is awesome! Dont miss the changing of guards program. Everything is well kept, will make you feel like you were transported to a different time.
Great to visit and walk around when you are visiting the city. Beautiful gardens and well manicured grounds as you see all the history inside.

review_title: Nice palace to visit while in Seoul
review_body: This is the biggest palace in Seoul, and definitely worth a visit if you're in town. It's not the most amazing thing I've ever seen, but it's a very scenic and pretty palace with a massive area to walk around on a nice day. Also it was free during July 2015 so that's a bonus! Go now if you're here this month.

It was great! We took lots of pictures, because of course the place was beautiful.There were also free tours on specific times in different languages. It was a long walk back, because from after the tour, you have to go all the way back. there is no other exit, except from where you came in. We tried to find one form another way, but there was really none.It's a HUGE place.

Great palace. We bought the booklet ticket to see all 5 palaces plus the Secret Garden & Jomyo Shrine. But after the 3 palace, it just feels like we're revisiting the same place over n over. Secret garden is great but requires a lot of walking (slopes & steps) continuously for about 1hr. Very beautiful though.If you don't have a lot of time (or stamina), just pick 2 palaces and maybe the Secret Garden. Check schedules for change of guards. I recommend Gyeongbokgung & Changdeokgung plus Secret Garden.

In most places, the historical sites are usually a bit out of the way from the city. But not in Seoul, it's really interesting how the old palaces are intertwined in the very modern architecture. I went during a heavy rainstorm with thundering, so not the best time to go, but also allowed for some quite dramatic photos! Definitely worth checking out!
I visited this historical place during winter. It was a peaceful place and we can see the traditional architecture in this palace.
Definitely worth visiting! Beautiful, historically important location in the heart of a modern city. Tranquil, green, and pleasant.

The largest palace complex in Seoul. It has many buildings and each has its specific history, of course you'll have many photo spots. Don't miss the guard change ceremony at the gate. It is also near to the National Folk Museum. You'll need 1 to 2 hours to cover the whole complex.

Not a great palace but one of the must see. It represents Korean traditional architecture. When you see other palaces around the world you might say this is not that great but definitely worth a visit

One of the best things to do in Seoul. The palace complex is large and reminds me a lot to the Beijing Forbidden city. The good things is that it is not obercrowded like the Beijing one, so you will really enjoy it!

Gyeongbokgung is SUCH an incredible piece of history-and I totally reccommend taking the English audio tour. I've been there twice now and I really feel that I find something new to admire each time. Plus, the museums on the grounds are very interesting in and of themselves.Highly recommend bringing some snacks and water and just walking around the grounds in the back of the palace, especially during spring/summer. The view of the mountain is nice and it's very relaxing/peaceful.

I've been to this palace in all the seasons and like all the palaces in Korea it is best in Autumn. It's easy to get lost here but it doesn't feel like you're in the centre of a city at all. It is so peaceful.

I like visiting historical places, and this one was no exception. I found royal Korean customs interesting when our tour guide narrated the events that transpired in the queen's chambers. Of course the traditional architecture was also something I really marveled at.
Similar to the Forbidden city in Beijing, but without ponds or water streams.It's well restored. The visit could take to you about 4 hours if you want to go into all the quarters.

Architecture at its best. You will find peace within yourself when you spend at least two hours in this place. Take some fresh air at the park and entertain your eyes with magnificent assets from the past at their National Folk Museum :)

This was our favourite palace in Seoul, it was close to our hotel and we were there in the morning when the guard change happened- don't miss this one (they do it few time a day). The palace is enormous but easily accessible even without a guided tour as we did. We bought a brochure where we bought the entrance tickets and it had a map and all the necessary information about the palace in it.

I went to the palace with a korean friend. The tour lady was very good, and let go a couple of funny jokes to lighten the atmosphere. The tour is 1h long, because the palace is so big. The architecture is beautiful. Simple yet refined, the wooden structures are assembled without any nails or metal and symbolize asian acient design. I think this is a classic visit on the Seoul To-do list.

I happened to be here during July which apparently all the palaces and museums are open for free!!! and also coincidently to have enjoyed the free guided tour provided by the palace, all of which has made the whole experience so much better!

It is a beautiful historical Korean temple. We had just come from Beijing and went to the Forbidden City before arriving in Seoul, so in comparison, it is less impressive. Nonetheless, being Koreans from Los Angeles we were still very glad to have seen it.
Not to be missed. If you are in Seoul, try coming here even if you only have a few hours to spare. Beautiful buildings and architecture..
A great palace to walk around. It is a part of Korean history. Even it is a replica, the original one was destroyed.

review_title: Very pretty for a walk, but not too much to see aside from buildings
review_body: This palace has been destroyed, twice I think, so what you can see today has been entirely rebuilt. The grounds are huge and nice for a stroll around - but there isn't too much to see here in terms of exhibits, etc. The changing of the guard ceremony has interesting music and costumes and my kids really enjoyed seeing it.

review_title: Don't bother to listen to the guide about the history of the place...
review_body: The whole area where the palace stands is wide and the buildings are quite similar in architecture and design. It is just awesomely handsome.
