If you have a guide tell her/him not to hurry the tour. You 'll miss some places inside the perimeter if you're in a hurry. Take your time and take pictures as many as you can. Tour guides have the habit of telling the history of the place longer than it may seems eating away your time for an extensive tour of the place. Instead of listening, go your own way for taking photos as fast as your group can but be sure to follow your eyes where your group goes. There's the possibility that you'll loose them because there are plenty of tourists. The history of the place can be gathered from the internet so, don't bother listening to your guide the history of the place. Go, take pictures. It's your only chance.
This is a palace worth visiting. Main Royal palace of the Joseon Dynasty, this has a lot of architecture and numerous palaces rooms inside. One of the biggest palace in Korea.

Seoul at night is like a teenager who just discovered life after school. All of those who spent hours working, chasing deadlines, staying in on piece after meetings and reunions are the same that cluster bars, restaurants, plazas and more, giving this city an unique sense of dynamism and restlessness. That is why from time to time it is more than necessary to breathe and relax, and believe me, there is no better place in town for this action than the gardens of Gyeongbokgung Palace! Want to contemplate Korean architecture while promenading away from the intense rhythm of town? Well, think no more, this is your place.
Enjoyed a free walking tour. The history and architecture is well worth the visit. Wear good walking shoes.

Today I visited the palace and to my surprise the entrance fee was free. A sign was posted that named the other nearby palaces also as free for the month of July due to MERS. This palace was just as beautiful as the others that I visited on my trip to Korea. I also enjoyed the Korean Folk Museum which is also on the same grounds.

Decided to do a palace tour via the subway. Subway was right next to the palace. You can buy a multi-ticket whilsy there. Gives you access to other palaces in the city. Worth it if you see 2 or more places. Good museum at the entrance too.

review_title: Capture a bit of royal Korea in this downtown palace
review_body: Located in the heart of downtown Seoul, Gyeongbokgung is an easy must-see visit. The Changing of the Guards ceremony welcomes most visitors. The first portions may have more visitors, but be sure to wander to the back parts as well. I especially liked the Parujeong building. Pavilions by the waters are particularly beautiful in spring and peaceful after an occasional snowfall. Amisan chimneys are noteworthy. Do visit the free Folk Museum, connected to the palace grounds.
Cheap admission (~ 3 USD) and worth to see the traditional face of Seoul and Korea. However, do not expect anything breathtaking.

review_title: Great option for overlay at the ICN Airport
review_body: My husband and I had a 12 hour overlay at the ICN airport. This is a great way to spend the time and get a chance to visit Seoul. We signed up for the free 5 hour city tour. Apparently this is the most popular tour of all, I made reservation online (ICN airport website) 6 weeks prior departure and I was lucky I got the last 2 seats. The tour includes a simple Korean lunch which is $10 (mandatory). Transportation/bus is free, courtesy of Korean government. Tour guide is a volunteer and very funny. Nice to walk around the city after a 15 hour flight. The only thing I dislike is the lunch. We were given 2 options: bibimbap (rice) or beef stew. We ordered 1 each, the stew was too sweet to eat for me. Tour was great. I will try other tours next time.
The gardens inside the palace are really beautiful, reminded me a little bit the forbidden city because of the roofs. But it truly reflects korean philosophy of respecting an caring nature.

Overall, the Palace is well-maintained. It's easy to navigate your way around, even without a map since there are signs leading you where to go next. There are also descriptions of each structure, in English, Chinese, and Japanese, so it's easy to get to know the place even without a tour guide. However, there are also maps available at the information area, but for a fee. Don't forget to wear your rubber shoes since you will be doing a lot of walking. Before you start touring the palace grounds, be sure to catch the changing of the guards ceremony just outside the main palace grounds. Ticket area is also nearby. If you love nature photography, this is a must-go place in Korea, especially in spring and autumn since there are a variety of flowers in the area. Plus, don't forget to have your photos taken in the iconic parts of the compound (the structure with a pond, the rows of traditional houses or building around, the entrance) since these are commonly shown in Korean dramas :). You haven't gone to Korea without those photos! After your tour around the palace, you may also want to visit the museum behind it and also have your photos taken with the other statues/structures outside (i.e. the zodiac characters, the tikis (guards of villages), and traditional houses of commoners). I will never get tired of visiting this palace!

Visited this place a few years back during my month visit to Asia.The history of the palace tells of fascinating resilience and survivor of this amazing complex from the Joseon Dynasty down to the Japanese rule of Colonial Korea. The complex is not expansive but you can easily spend a few hours here.A very essential must visit while in Seoul.
Make sure to catch the changing of the guards in the afternoon! Love the ceremony and brightly colored attire.This is closed on Tuesdays, by the way, so plan your Seoul itinerary accordingly.

Such great history that sits here. I have heard wonderful stories of this place, and being able to put those stories to comparison of what I have seen is so beautiful. Enjoyed the walk around the culture.

A must visit for Seoul. See the changing of the guard and the elaborate show for tourists.The grounds are nice enough, but not very large. Back then, it seems the Koreans were not that affluent when compared to China or Japan.

The best palace in Seoul. Gyeongbokgung is the largest and so I'd recommend choosing this one over any of the others. You have the addition of the National Folk Museum once you're inside. Tickets are dirt cheap! The palace isn't open on Tuesdays which I thought was a little odd but other than that, we had no problems getting in.

I enjoyed walking around in the palace. It gives me a rough idea of the rich culture of Korea. Nice place to do photo taking and what makes me happy theres a free palace guard uniform wearing. My whole family manage to try the guard's uniform. We were able to watch also the guard changing ceremony. There is the restaurant and souvenir shop at the palace ground. Must see place.

If you are first timer in Seoul, include Gyeongbukgong Palace. Tagged as Palace blessed by the heavens. The largest among palaces in Seoul. One shouldnt miss watching Changing of Guards ceremony.. Relieve olden times and Be amazed looking inside Kings throne. They are just a few things to visit when youre inside the palace.
Beautiful Palace for Korean standards. However, if you have been to China or Japan you will be slightly disappointed. Nevertheless, definitely top of your list if visiting Seoul.

It was quite boring as I not a history lover.The palace was well maintained and the area was quite big.Nice place to take pictures to proof that u had visited Korea.I watched the guard changing ceremony and it was quite nice so I gave this attraction three stars.
hundred years building, is a landmark of seoul, how well the palace is, and very easy to go, follow by train.

The palace is decent & all the block looks similar.The palaces are devoid of many rich artwork found normally in palaces( at least not visible form visitors gallery).Only some chambers have beautiful designs & color work. The layout is same for all palaces in Seoul.Be prepared to walk a lot

Gyeongbokgung is a great place, right in the centre of Seoul where you can spent hours walking, exploring and taking pictures. Make sure you have comfortable shoes. Don't miss the change of guards. Guards are dressed in traditional attire and the ceremony is narrated - it is a great experience. If you arrive right before the ceremony you will see the training beforehand. This is a must when is Seoul.

Gyeongbokgung is a great place, right in the centre of Seoul, to spend an hour or so wandering around and taking photos. The halls, pavilions and courtyards are really pretty, and it's an interesting juxtaposition between them and the modern city that surrounds them.

review_title: Keep in mind the closing hours
review_body: Beautiful,the museum is wonderful,if you visit during the autumn it's a bonus it looks wonderful with all the different colours

This was our first stop on a sight-seeing tour. We arrived just as the changing of the palace guards was taking place which was very nice to see. This is a ceremonial event that takes place twice per day. Guards are dressed in traditional attire and the ceremony is narrated through a public address system in different languages including English. This is an expansive property and a lot of walking should be expected (including some stairs which are fairly steep). Palace dates back to the 13th century and has been well maintained (and restored numerous times over the decades). The palace includes 4 gates and a number of buildings. At the far end of the palace, (and across the street) is the "Blue House" which is the current residence and government buildings of the Republic of Korea. This is an excellent attraction and would recommend visit by tour guide for explanation of the history of the palace. This attraction can be done over several hours or a full day could be spent here. Definitely a must see in South Korea.
Glorious palace surrounded by a mirroring lake in a beautiful garden, this is what it is. Everything is so pristinely clean. Would not mind going back.
This complex is huge and expect to wander through here for a day. If you're lucky, you will see reenactment of the palace guards and see it all lit up during the annual lotus lantern festival.

review_title: Great way to see a little history of Seoul
review_body: The palace is gorgeous and the ceremony of the change of guards is very entertaining and educational. Closed on Tuesdays but on all the other days the times are 9:00, 1:00 and 3:00.Would recommend to those who want to see a little bit of the history of Seoul.
must see !! the garden was designed very beautiful. you will feel suprised with the pool, mandarin duck & birds inside the garden. even it's artificial garden but it's still looks natural.

Just like any countries it is best to visit historical places . It is a huge place. The paintings on the wall of the place was intricate . They were able to preserve some of the furniture used in the olden time. However the bad side is that you can only look from the open windows as visitors are not allowed to enter the rooms. Make sure to visit during the change of Guard! During morning and the one we watched was during the afternoon at around 3 P.M.
I love how clean it is remained and how easy to come here. Just take a train and you'll get it here. Do explore outside gyeongbokgung palace for some street food

review_title: Amazing place, full of history and culture
review_body: Biggest palace I visited in Seoul. Is worth paying the admission tickets and walking through. There is a lot to see. The architecture is amazing, leaning about the culture is fascinating. The changing of the guards is a great show. This place is a must see in Seoul.

review_title: A 1000 Years Old Palace at the heart of Seoul
review_body: This palace captures the glorious history of Korea. This is very close to the Business Centre of the city and business travellers also can visit this place with just 1 hour break.
the palace was the last home of the last remaining korean royal family.a place that has a lot of history and tragedy. its beautifully maintained

review_title: Be sure to see changing guard; beware, closed on mondays
review_body: It is a very nice palace, and gives an interesting glimpse of the Korea history and culture. But, to me, the most interesting thing was the changing guard ceremony. Complete, with drums, music, everything. Just fantastic, do not miss it. Site has schedules. Beware, it is closed on mondays - not on tuesdays, as site says.

I recalled all the K-dramas I watched set in the early history of Korea. It's a very huge place and it's great to note that reconstruction is currently ongoing at some parts. It's good how they continue to rebuild some of the parts of the palace. It shows how important and how they value the preservation of their culture. Changing of guards is one of the must watch activities when visiting. Tourists can also try to fit in the guard's costumes near the gate.

Visit this palace several times already,watch out for different exit.I always hear something new from tour guide when we visit this place so I always curious of any other story. You will see a palace complex with different usage, size and form. People in the old days really have great passion as you see on the building. This place is big and may be windy so prepare a jacket, March can still freeze you in this place. Take pictures with some buildings and as you walk out some dust may fly so walk slowly. For 1395 built, this palace still look amazing.Never iss this when you are in Seoul.

review_title: Iconic place and a great introduction to the culture of Korea
review_body: I and my family members enjoyed visiting this palace. And we had so much fun wearing the guard costumes and having some great photos, too. It was nice to see the moment of of guards changing the shifts.
every hour they change their gate guard and they performed guard changing ceremony, so nice and snappy to see. the palace was great and nice to visit.

review_title: Great place to spend a morning or afternoon.
review_body: This is definitely worth a visit, but you will enjoy exploring the palace more if you read a little about its history first. The lakes and gardens are a good place to take a break and rest a little while contemplating Joseon history.
Easy to get around and the actors and costumes were a nice surprise addition to our visit. (These are not the original buildings but cool to imagine them as if they were.)
We were there at sunset and stayed until dark. It was the perfect way to see it , since after dark it has a special magic. This should be on your shortlist if you are in the area.

review_title: A lot better than Tokyo's Imperial Palace
review_body: So I came to visit this palace after visiting Tokyo's Imperial Palace 3 days prior. This one is a lot better and looks more authentic. There are free tours for various languages throughout the day. Make sure you get there on time, but even if you don't you can just search for the tour group and join them midway. They tour guides are very knowledgeable and they teach you a lot about the history of this palace. In my opinion, you need to visit this place with a guide otherwise you won't appreciate it's history and what each building represents.It's better to go on a weekday. I did and there were plenty of areas where you can take photos without anyone in the background. Bring bottles of water with you because you are outdoors and it gets hot. There are no vendors except inside the museum, as far as I could tell.

The temple isvery nicely located and full of peace the architecture is very beautiful and needs personal attentin The area is fully covered by beautiful old trees The templealso reflect the life style of the king

I went with my mum to visit Seoul and for the pair of us we knew 0 Korean. It was definitely very easy to find the place and getting tickets was as easy as it could be with English and Chinese signs too. The first thing we saw when we got there was the guard change over - I believe and it was really cool to see. The actual Palace itself was huge and you are free to look at most part. I really like it!

look to your left and you see a skyline of skyscrapers, look to your right and you see an ancient palace. We were luck to catch the changing of guards ceremony at 10am. We also had a free walking tour (you can book this on Korea tourism sites) he showed us all the different parts to the palace and explained the history to us for nearly 3 hours! We walked from our hotel in City Hall to the Palace and it took 20mins- very centrally located. Also theres a station right outside if you need it

review_title: A must see place in Seoul
review_body: Gyeongbokgung Palace is the biggest palace in Seoul located in the center of the city.Most of the area in the palace including the Throne Hall has been burnt but rebuilt is 20 century. You need at least 2-3 hours to walk around and to enjoy the great local Korean atmosphere with also group English speaker tour guide provided by the palace and it is free of charge. At every 2 pm the also have the guard patrolling show available at the main gate which worth to see and taking some photos too.Within the palace, there is 2 museum available one is National Palace Museum and the other one is Korean Folk Museum, if you only have enough time to choose one only, the palace museum is what I would recommend.
Largely reconstructed but still stunning. Do not miss the National Palace Museum, which displays a lot of stuff from this an other royal palaces.
The palace is an interesting place to visit to learn about some of Korea's history. Make sure you arrive for the 'changing of the guard' ceremony.
buy the multi ticket admission for all the palaces to save money on entry. if you go to one palace head to this one.

review_title: Ancient history within heart of city
review_body: If you love to visit castles , you would love it.Very huge area to cover, hence get ready to spend 5 hours if you visit it completely.Other than structure , you may enjoy festivals there (if they are scheduled), museum is also next to it which is very well maintained.Points to be noted :1) Not a fun for young children2) Have good energy to walk for long distances3) Combo ticket is available for all palaces but if you are visiting this one only , specify while purchasing4) Good cafes in museum5) Do not miss traditional parade

Magnificent and beautiful architecture. You can simply walk around and experience the beauty but no enter is allowed. Sometimes can get very crowded. Bring a nice camera with wide angle lens and dress with colorful costume are always a good idea.

First visit was done alone and stupidly i covered the first part of the palace and left before exploring the back part of it. It was sooooo amazing to see the lake and different parts of the palace which really brought me to the history of how the palace people lived in the past. Take some time to sit by the lake and absorb the surroundings. You will really feel as if you were brought back into history. Go to the east side of the palace after you end the museum visit. There is a vintage corner which shows a tiny vintage cafe, photo studio and how the commoner lived in the past. Definitely worth that 3000won ticket price and I'm sure it's better with the english language guide to understand the history of the palace.

I have been to palaces in Beijing and so this is not really as interesting as to what I anticipated. I would recommend having a tour guide otherwise it will not be meaningful to walk through this. Guard changing ceremony is worth waiting for and definitely one of the key attractions to watch.

review_title: Loved it, definitely coming here again.
review_body: You should have a good camrea with, great for photo-shooting.Don't miss the gate guards changing shifts every hour, it's great.

review_title: A fantastic look into the Seoul of the past.
review_body: Be sure to take the English guided tour to get the most out of your visit. It's free of charge (inclusive in the access fee) and very insightful.

Nice way to spend an afternoon wandering around beautiful parks and little pagodas, etc.Get an information pamphlet (like 500 KRW) so you can add some history knowledge to your gazing. They are available next to where you buy the tickets.

This is one of the must sees in Seoul. Easy to reach with public transport (subway station Gyeongbokgung or Anguk from where you can walk through some very nice streets), you can spend half a day walking around the palace grounds.Be aware that most of the buildings aren't original, but are restaurations from 19th and 20th century. The overall setting of this palace within super busy Seoul is amazing.

I had a long layover at ICN, so took the train and a cab over to see the palace and surrounding neighborhood. It will take about 5 to 6 hours to do this including train time.The first thing to understand is that this palace has been burned down (not completely) and re-built over history. Many if not most of the structures are faithful recreations of earlier versions.The layout of the grounds is remarkably similare to the Forbidden City in Beijing if you have been there, reflecting similar culture and heirarchy.With that pre-amble, I had a great visit and would recommend this as a worthwhile excursion. Between the palace grounds and the adjacent folk museum (which is free) I learned a great deal about Korean culture and history.Across the street, there are two art museums and a wonderful walking neighborhood with a number of quick restaurants.

review_title: Prepare for a lot of walking
review_body: Do not be fool. This palace is amazingly big! I spent an hour and a half and still.didn't manage to cover all the grounds. Still, the lake area is amazingly peaceful. Pretty much own time own target too.

The natural beauty at the palace, it's manicured lawns, sprawling campus, the beautiful backdrop of hills were truly impressive. Having seen the magnificent palaces and forts of India, I didn't get awed by the palace buildings. Most of the structures had a similar build, simple but beautiful wooden structures. The palace is very well maintained. The most beautiful building was two storied structure built in the middle of a pond on the western part of the campus.There is a museum with Korean cultural artifacts, nice to spend some time here. There is also a theme park based show casing a Korean village, nice for kids.
Love the place and people in traditional costume were professional. The hourly ceremony is interesting so don't miss it!

review_title: Pretty interesting place, if your are into this sort of stuff
review_body: Basically it is a old castle with a big open court yard. There will be a lot of tourists getting off of fleets of buses. Lots of large tour groups, some with matching hats and tshirts. There's not a lot of shade, it will be wise to bring some water, an umbrella, a hat, and some sunscreen. It is close to a lot of bus and metro stops.Overall, it is something to visit after eating some ginger chicken and taking a breaking from shopping.

Well,maybe because i expected it too much so when i got there i was disapointed. If you wanna go there,it is not far from the station. But i forgot the station's name. It is kinda confusing to reach it,you must really remember the station's names since typical station in Korea are almost same. It costs about 3,000 won.

This place is huge, we spent 3 hours with a guided tour and we visited the buildings and grounds that are very important and have a royal history significance but architecture wise words could not explained how intricate and beautiful the place and the history is amazing. It is must if you visit Seoull very accessible by public transportation or do hop on hop off bus and that is one of the stop.

I was on a 1 day trip in Seoul, Ms. Guide was very nice and funny, she spoke very good English, so there was no problem to understand everything she said. Probably single trip would be more interesting, than in a group of random ppl, but I didn't have time for organizing everything by myslef. The company picked me-up from the hotel, so I didnt have to worry about anything. Unfortunately I dont remember how was the trip called and via what company. I've ordered it from the hotel.Palace is beautiful, very big, a lot of interesting places with museum, where you can learn something about history. The place is amazing but, like all places in this type, very crowdy, so it's very hard to take a good picture without random ppl.
Although the palace is recently restored, it's on a huge site with beautiful parks and lakes between the buildings. The folk museum is also worth a visit

Its good to be here and witness the guard changing ceremony.. we are lucky when we went there is a parade and also flea market held opposite of the palace. Great place for photo taking.. I prefer to came here durong winter. As summer is too hot to handle in an open area..

If you visit only one temple this should be it. It's part of a larger complex but this was the center of power in its day. Here you see how the royal family lived and discover the power of the King's mother. She chose the next King. We were there to see a procession of the King and his entourage walk down the path from the temple to the gate. The King approaches in a sedan chair carried by eight husky men and then alights and strolls with the group for a short distance. Everyone is in red. This event is held periodically, so visitors should check with a guard to find the schedule.

review_title: seek a travel guide to appreciate more the beauty of Gyeonbokgung palace.
review_body: For those wanted to explore and to know more the culture of Korea,I highly recommended this place. Everything here is picturesque especially during autumn season. Got to appreciate more the colorful history of Korea.

After a few hours of sleep, and just a tad hungover, we started our adventure to the historic Gyeongbokgung Palace. This palace was on acres upon acres of land. If you visit at the right time you’ll get to witness the guard ceremony at the front gate. We noticed a lot of visitors doing their usual “peace sign” photo ops at the front of the palace and then leaving the grounds which caused us to wonder whether or not we wanted to spend the 8000 Wons to go in further since no one else was going inside. I am so thankful we opt to pay. Once we were inside everything just seem surreal. It was honestly like going back in time, and the architectural details of the reconstruction of the palace and its surrounding buildings were magnificent. And quite frankly, after a long night of partying this was the perfect way to detox.

review_title: See the changing of the guards
review_body: Where is the best place to see the changing of the guards? It is outside the gate, where you get the closest to the guard. Do not go into the big yard inside the gate. They will pass through it and the actual changing of the guard is in front of the Gate.

review_title: Free Seoul City Tour from Airport
review_body: This is the first stop on the Incheon Airport Seoul City Tour. It is an amazing place but we were only there for about 45 minutes. If we are ever in Seoul for a couple of days, we would likely go back and spend at least a half day there. But if you are at the airport for a long layover, coming here on the 5 hour tour is sorth it

This palace in my personal Seoul palace rating gets well-deserved 2nd place. It doesn't differ much from acrhitecture point of view from other palaces, but nonetheless it's beautiful and impressive. Guard ceremony is interesting. You can check times of ceremony at the gates - there is info sign with schedule and type of ceremony.
An excellent palace with so much to see... the change of guards ceremony is a must see as it reflects the local Korean culture and is colourful...

I ended up going on a day when there weren't any performances going on, but they did have guards that were traditionally dressed at the entrance. It wasn't too crowded, but it was fairly difficult to get a good view of the blue house because a good amount of the tourists congregated at the viewing area. The palace grounds were gorgeous, and getting to go to the Folk Art Museum was also great. The girls I went with and I just kept looking at the museum from afar until we finally worked through the palace grounds and figured out what it was. The mock village that was set up was pretty cool too.

review_title: Pretty cool palace, but not that old.
review_body: Unfortunately wooden structures tend to burn down over the centuries. This is a neat palace, but it's not that ancient. The free walking tour in Seoul (found at the official Visit Seoul web site) was nice, because they guide explained what we would have otherwise missed.

Accesible via mrt Gyeongbokgung Palace Station (Seoul Subway Line 3), Exit 5. Do catch-up the "Changing Guards Ceremony" at 10:00, 13:00 or 15:00. Avoid morning in the weekend as it was super crowded and it's hard to get good pictures with the only background of the palace.
if you a Saeguk K-drama fan, u should come here to get the feeling. subway station: gyeongbokgung station, anguk station also can

If you only have time to see one palace in Seoul make it this one. There are free tours everyday: Tours depart in front of the Information Center at Heungnyemun Gate (흥례문). Duration: 1 hr - 1 hr 30 minTour Schedule: English: 11:00, 13:30, 15:30Japanese: 10:00, 12:30, 14:30Chinese: 10:30, 13:00, 15:00The entrance fee to the palace is 3000won. You can also buy a combination ticket for 10 000won. This will give you entrance to the following four Palaces: Changdeokgung Palace (including Huwon, Secret Garden), Changgyeonggung Palace, Deoksugung Palace, Gyeongbokgung Palace and Jongmyo Shrine.Please note that Gyeongbukgung is closed on Tuesdays.The changing of the guard is also worth seeing so make sure you time your visit with that. 3 times per day, 10 a.m., 1 p.m., 3 p.m.After visiting the palace you can walk to Tosokchon restaurant to have its its signature samgyetang (chicken ginseng soup) made with glutinous rice, gingko nuts, ginseng, garlic and jujube, as well as 30 different types of medicinal herbs and grains. The line at the restaurant might be long but it moves fairly quiclyk and it is a must have when visiting Seoul!

review_title: A preserved palace to keep history alive
review_body: We made sure to visit the Gyeongbokgung Palace on our visit to Seoul. We wanted to visit during the changing the guard which happens every day at 10 and 11am. A parade of sorta marches through in vibrant uniforms, holding flags, and being rather stoic. It was a pretty procession.After the guard we went onto the grounds. It's a pretty large place. It was built in 1395, destroyed by Japan in 1592 and rebuilt in 1867 and a true restoration started in 1990 with completion in 2010. We were impressed and glad we arrived after the restoration was complete. There are many different buildings to the palace. The entire place is surrounded by a large sturdy wall with four gates. There were places for official regal affairs, living quarters for the king, living quarters for the king's mother, along with living quarters for princes and princesses, and the queen (which was separate from the king's) . There is a nice garden, a reception hall, and a beautiful pavillion surrounded by water.There was a small admission fee, about $3 for adults, $1.50 for kids. There were free tours, offered in Korean, English, Japanese, and Chinese. Hours vary for the site throughout the year but it always opens at 9am and closes between 5 and 6:30pm. They are open Wednesday-Monday, being closed on Tuesdays. We took a free guided tour and our guide was quite knowledgable, but our group ended up being quite large and it was a little difficult to ask questions.The buildings looked very nice. The rooms where one might have a meal included settings and was very nice. The pavillion surrounded by water was quite impressive. It was here that it was the first time that a family asked to take a picture with our blond son and wasn't the last, but it was interesting.There were great printed guides about each building in the place with lots of information in good English. There were several other languages available as well. It included stuff about the gargoyle type imaginary creatures on some of the architecture, how kings and queens were to be addressed, and information about South Korea was the first culture to use a sundial, invented in 1434. This is a well maintained look at history that isn't very expensive. Definitely try to make it for the changing of the guard.
Most amazing place for foreigners. Architecture and history combined at one stop. Not to be missed when in Seoul.

Originally visited in July 2011. Had a 12 hour layover in Seoul and took the opportunity to book a half day tour that brought us primarily to the Gyeongbokgung Palace. We were able to witness the changing of the guard ceremony and explore the grounds for quite some time. The colors of the clothing and architecture were memorably vibrant. Following our palace visit we went to the nearby museum to learn more about Korean culture and history.
I come here with my parents in winter season have a lot of tours.here have good view for take a photo with couples and family.
Gyeongbokgung is the most interesting place in Seoul. You will see Korean traditional architecture in this palace. You can enter the area for free if you wear traditional clothes, Hanbok.
Try to go at 1pm to experience the changing of the gate warriors - so colourful! Took an English speaking tour which was very informative.
Interesting, but arrive early to avoid the heat. The changing of guards was interesting. However the sand at the forecourts was uncomfortable when the wind blows.

Huge palace with loads of history behind it. Good to have a rent a audio guide which is available at the information counter for a small fee of 3000 won. The palace is repainted every 30 years. Thus, might look a bit too surreal depending on when you visitChange of guards ceremony can be viewed at specific time. And need not purchase the entrance tickets if you just want to view this cause it happens outside the main entrance.

It was pretty nice, but a little dull and hard to find a nice path through to see everything. A lot of the buildings look the same. I found the insides more interesting than the outsides, but, of course, you're not allowed to go inside, you can only look through the window.There were a lot of school kids there on field trips, but I didn't find it annoying. We were used as props in pictures for what we figured was some kind of scavenger hunt, which was amusing.Unfortunately, we came on a day when there was a concert, so we didn't get to see the changing of the guard :(

it reminded me of the Forbidden city in Beijing, just amazing, big in scale. it takes some work walking around it, lots of stairs. to really understand the history some additional background might be helpful, a tour book, or printed content from internet research. the gardens around it were nice too, especially since we visited in the Spring, during the flower bloom season.

review_title: Beautiful well preserved ancient history and culture
review_body: Must watch the changing of Guard...superb experience...10 am everyday except Tuesday...close on Tuesday...walk the huge ground and do not forget the garden around the perimeter....

review_title: visiting to pecfectly different palaces ; Gyeongbokgung palace and Changdeokgung palace
review_body: I and my family were so excited to visit to Korea.I got strong impression when I had company trip to Korea several years ago. At that time, I decided to be with my parents. Especially I was comfy with strong security in Korea and Korean were quite kind and warmhearted. Anyway it is very recommendable to visit Korea with your family.... I went to two palaces as my guide's recommendation... actually she preferred 2nd palace named Changdeokgung palace.Gyeongbokgung palace is representative, I was told it is the biggest one... it looks like forbidden city but it was built up around 30 years later than Gyeongbokgung palace. I went to Chankdeokgung palace as well. it is 2nd palace... there are 5palaces in Korea. the second palace was completely different.. it is also recommendable with many interesting history.SEEING IS BELIEVING.My tour guide was very enthusiastic and her story telling was so helpful to understand ,catched our concentration and touched us.. it was one of my strong impressing in Korea until the end day.. My collegue let me know one tour agent in Korea. We stayed for 5days, except for one day, we joined guided tour with her. she was very proud of their company(tour agent).. she was professional.When you travel to Korea, I want you to be with a good tour guide with very forsure agent.The agent name was very unique.. Anneonghaseyo Tour.. haha..It was available to have costomised tour with very reasonable budget...I was told it was handled by family that's why I could trust much more than other contries for trip.If you have any plan to travel to Korea, contact here.. I have business card of that agent..Everyone will be satisfied with ...
One of the places worth a visit if you want to know the history of Korea. The tour guide is very good in speaking English.
The way the emperors lives was pretty cool. Take the walking tour, it is very helpful. Lots of stairs and walking but it is very beautiful, The guards do not move, just like the UK.

This place is huge! Palace buildings have intricate designs with beautiful surroundings (ponds, trees, etc). The guard changing ceremony is a must-see, an amazing experience indeed. The official English tour provided for free is also very helpful. Highly recommended.

review_title: Excellent place for a walk while knowing Korean history
review_body: I visited the place with one of my Korean business partner and he made a digestive short history of the palace, king and following Japanese occupation. The palace has been restored to a very original condition and there are plenty to learn if you want to understand Korean pride.

review_title: One of Most Scenic Location in Seoul
review_body: Went here mid of May with my wife and friends. The place is so huge and very rich in history. We went early and were very fortunate to see the change of guards ceremony. You will see men in Korean traditional soldier uniforms including their weapons. Inside are structures but for most of them you can only glance from outside. Tips: - Wear appropriate footwear. The place is huge you'll do a lot of walking.- The ceremony starts around 10am. Be there early and go to a good spot to watch.- You can try the soldier uniforms. Area is near the first gate if I'm not mistaken.- May is cold but very sunny so bring umbrella.- Bukchon Hanok Village is like 20-30min walk from here. You may want to consider walking as the streets outside were also nice. The palace wall are great from outside.

If there is one place that you can visit when in a long over in Seoul... Its Gyeongbokgung Palace. My daughter and I took the ARES train to Seoul Station and just follow the train map we downloaded to find the next train going to the palace. When we were there, its was a free entrance day too. Not much tourist so we got to take awesome pics. We did not stay too long, but was able to see the Changing of the Guard and went inside for some pics. No complains, its enough to feel the Korean soul.Don't miss going to Gyeongbokgung Palace!
we got to watch the changing of the guard at 10 am . there are some rooms you can enter, which is unusual in these palaces. also, there are some gardens and a beautiful pond area.
Kinda waste of time and money for visit.. probably i duno how to appreciate wide "empty" palace. Simply nothing for me to see. Less than 10mins, am outta of this place

If you would want to see only one Palace. This is the place to go. I have seen the Changdeokgung Palace but still prefer this one. Bigger and more attractions. Only downside side is the Chinese hordes of tourist who push and shove and it is hard to get a photo with the family with a lot of photo bombs. Very easy to get to by subway.

Tried to explore all area of the palace and strolling under huge ginko tree really made my day. No need to hurry if you want to find hidden gems in here.If you visit with hanbok, you don't need to pay admission fee.

review_title: A lot of Korean history under the King Sejong statue
review_body: The palace is very impressive, especially being in downtown Seoul. The best part was underneath the King Sejong statue in front of the Palace gates. There is a huge museum underneath, with a lot of cool Korean history. There was a good Turtle Ship section with a big 1/3 scale model you could go inside. Overall the palace itself was too packed for me, but the museum under the statue was fun to see.

review_title: a good place to people watching
review_body: A tourist destination for everyone. Large complex and very interesting. The entrance is very colourful with the well dressed guards. Don't miss the change of guards at midday. A bit dusty path on a dry hot day. Ensure to have a hat or umbrella.

If you were to go to one of the palaces, i recommend this one. We went on the weekend and there were some students who offered to be free tour guides (to practice their english) . Spent about 3 hours on the palace grounds

Never fails to be impressed by the architecture and history of the place. Going there on a Saturday means jostling lots of people. Easy to get to the place using the subway. And from the palace there are other attractions nearby, notably the "Stream".
Good for travellers who would like to learn much about the Korean traditional matters. The free guides were polite and helpful.

My friends and I were lucky that we arrived just when the changing of guards ceremony was about to start. The ceremony was impressive, though it was pretty funny how the guards had way too obvious fake beards. The free tour was really good, very informative.
The buildings are superb .The gardens are outstanding, and although there are lots of tourists there is plenty of areas of peace and quiet to be able to contemplate the serenity of the Palace
big palace with great architecture... changing guard ceremony, you have to see it.........................

review_title: Changing of the Guard is a Must-See
review_body: We visited this palace as part of a group tour. The changing of the guard occurs daily at 10:00, 13:00; and 15:00 (**double check these times before going as they may change!!) Huge crowd at the 10:00 ceremony but still able to see and enjoy the program. There are numerous "outbuildings" scattered throughout the grounds. You can probably cover everything in an hour. Also, the "Folk Museum" is co-located with the palace and admission was included with admission to the palace grounds. The museum has a decent sized collection and is definitely worth seeing. It can be accessed once inside the palace complex (as well as from the street). Plan for a good 2.5 hours total to see both the palace and the museum; 3 hours if you want to soak in the museum exhibits.

review_title: One of few Palaces worth for visit
review_body: The palace was worth for visit to understand the emperor history of Seoul. The building design reflected the emperor living style.

this palace is quite huge and has so many colorful buldings. the details are amazing. gyeongbokgung is the largest palace in korea. if you like history and culture, i suggest you to buy integrated ticket for palaces, including jongmyo shrine and secret garden guided tour, only for KRW10.000

For the equivalent of US$3.00, you get to view a restored palace district that is spectacular. From palaces, to summer houses to lakes and gardens - this is a refreshing change from the modernity of Seoul. I had taken 100 photos before I knew it. It is an absolute must on any Seoul itinerary!

This quite large and well kept palace consists of large wooden ornate buildings in a park like setting. You don't need to go on a tour to visit any of these sort of places. Taxis in Seoul are really inexpensive and will get you to where you want to go for short distances. For longer distances the Metro is fantastic. But I advise you to make good use of Google Maps to get you around the system. But be aware that Maps quotes the stations names in Hangul characters. I ended up with my own special way of recognising parts of the characters!!!The palace is a hot and dry place so ensure that you have water with you. There are some relatively steep sections in parts so if this presents a problem be careful to allow plenty of time.
Just a walking distance from King Sejong and General Yi Sun Shin statue. The place are massive and really enjoyed the ambiance. Just 3000 for the entrance fee and it worth to visit.

First time visiting a palace. Amazing view, the palace was so big. We checked out the king and queen staying area. There is one house that was like in the middle of a small pond or something. Many people there, talk to some local school kids also on school trip. The scenery is super nice as theres mountains and trees (I went during the spring time). Great Visit, will be visiting again. Got many photos and videos there. Youtube - lolsia2000

It is the biggest palace out of the 5 palaces in korea. The admission ticket cost around 3000 won per adult and it is easy to walk around even without tour guide.. there will be royal guards changing ceremony and we can either watch it from in front of the entrance or inside..it's quite interesting and quite a sight..nice..

I came here because it is among the top of the list for Seoul attractions. For me Seoul itself is just a hype. Maybe due to k-wave. You don't have to enter the castle. Just stay outside to see the performance around 10am.

review_title: One of the best UNESCO site in Seoul
review_body: I visited Gyeongbokgung Palace few time. As I go free & easy without a guide in Korea. I have realised that it was so easy to move around in Seoul with the metro. I did some research before I arrive Korea. They have all the difference time for changing guide at the main gate. It take about 30 minutes with all the parade in traditional costume. The Palace provide difference timing for free tour with English & Chinese Speaking guide daily. The tour will be guide you through the Palace and gave you the detail explanation of the Palace. Please make use of the free service and you save a lot of money.

review_title: King's palace in the center of Seoul City.
review_body: If you visit Seoul, you can see the King's palace, Gyeongbokgung Palace. It is located near the city governent centers. Walk slowly just like a queen(or a King) and feel the calm beauty. See the beautiful curve lines of the Korean traditional roof tiles.If you should visit just one place because of the short time, just go and see the real unique beauty of the old treasure.

It is definatly worth a visit but don't expect too much. Korea is still rebuilding and getting their sites back to their former glory after the Japanese occupation. It was good and it is worth a visit but I would recommend a walk around changdeokgung palace and it's secret garden if you only have time for one

review_title: Magnificent Tradition elegantly preserved in a Palace Complex
review_body: Everyone who goes to Korea must visit Gyeongbokgung Palace. It's right at the heart of Seoul and the current city government centers are still around the area. The 3 pillar entrance and animal statues that "guard" the Palace offer a starting tease at what lies inside. Once you enter the complex, the intricate ancient walls, wide spaces, and stone paths all draw your attention to magnificent palace buildings where the monarch of Korea used to hold office and receive guests. The best building to see is the banquet hall. It lies on top of a pristine pond and with mountains at the backdrop. Truly spectacular!Make sure to bring comfortable shoes since you will definitely want to walk around. A camera is a must to capture the beauty of the place. It can get sunny so bring sunblock/moisturiser if you want. My family went there on a weekend it was really full of people. Try to visit on a weekday perhaps so there are less tourists. We spent around 1 hour going around but it wasn't enough for me. I think you should spend at least 1 hour and 30 mins - 2 hours or so. Other attractions are close to the area such as the National Museum, Blue House, and the Cheonggyecheon stream.
If you've been to the forbidden city I would say skip this palace. Being newly built, It feels more like a movie set than a walk through history. Maybe in a hundred years it will gain some character.
The well-preserved palace is a must-see attraction in Seoul. Be sure to take the time to wander around its extensive grounds.

This place is so amazing for a history lovers, tourists or even if you want to spend some time close to the nature. The scenery is great! The organization inside and outside the palace is good! I really enjoyed. They even have some self-managed mini-cars (looked alike the ones for golf) for the elderly people. That is so cool! So everyone can go to the place and have fun!

I had been to the palace before during the day and it was very nice, but this time there was a week where it was open at night time (normally closed at night). It was 3,000 won for a ticket, but was well worth it! Only 300 foreigners were allowed to get tickets.The palace at night was very different and a different experience. If you are lucky and visit during one of the few times it is open at night, GO.

Took my son's fiance and her dad when they visited last week. Palace is big and will take at least 2-3 hours to see it all, so plan accordingly. If your visiting in the spring or summer have water with you. There are tours in various languages (English 3 times a day) and they are part of the fee. Plenty to see and more is being added as the restore the palace.
One must go for it. It is one of the Korean traditional cultural places.It has a garden as well where you will find various colorful flowers and trees.Very nominal entrance fee.Visited October 2014

If you are looking to be temporarily immersed in Korea culture while in hustling-bustling downtown Seoul, this palace is a must-see destination. The palace grounds are hardly tucked away in some obscure corner of the sprawling metropolis of Seoul, for they extend over several hundred acres, and do offer some quietude compared to outside the gates. You will find numerous buildings that are splendid in their grandeur, and also old, twisted pines that represent the long-time suffering of the Korean population under colonial rule. One of the most captivating scenes is the grand lake, which begs for photos during cherry blossom season, the colorful autumn, and also during the evening. In closing, KNTO (Korean National Tourism Office) offers a pass to three palaces all within a few Kms of each other, which is a highly recommended to take in these incredible venues for a taste of tradition in the midst of one of the most modern cities in the world.
Very well staffed palace and grounds it is worth it to take the tour of both the palace and the secret gardens.

It is huge and wonderful. The best time to visit is in May, because they open it at night, and there will be Royal Court Festival, so you feel like really thrown back into Joseon dynasty. And the have free tours in English, Chinese, Japanese, Korean, so you better check the time. Otherwise it would be difficult to know which building was what. If you missed the tour, I suggest to buy the handbook for only $0,5.

review_title: Beware of Scorching Hot Weather but Interesting Cultural Sights!
review_body: Go and enjoy the traditional Korean cultural sights in the palace! But prepare for the scorching hot weather. Also some steep steps and all to climb. Worth a visit definitely - especially if you are interested to view some traditional and cultural artefacts!
Visited the palace twice over the past few years.it's the largest of all the palaces in Korea, and where some well-known dramas get their locations filmed.Nice walk with a pretty view.

review_title: A magical palace- the best in Seoul
review_body: Without doubt this was my favourite attraction in Seoul. We arrived just before 1400 meaning w could enjoy the whole change of the guard ceremony. Great fun.After that we wondered into the palace and genuinely were in awe with how beautiful it was. Of course the clear blue sky and nice weather helped with the atmosphere.Closed on Tuesday's so plan accordingly. To access use Subway line 3 exit 5, or just wonder through this beautiful city and arrive when you arrive :-)

review_title: Historic architecture contrasting with the modern architecture of Seoul
review_body: Nice palace, and a big site with extensive gardens and a folk museum (think history of Korea), to visit. Only cost a couple of quid, definitely worth it.

review_title: Largest of all five palaces, nice walk
review_body: Gyeongbokgung Palace, the most beautiful and largest of all five palaces.free guided tour provide and well explains the culture and building structure.

I visited the palace in the first week of april 2015..such an amazing traditional korean palace and a must see if you are planning to go to Seoul.You can imagine what stories happend behind those old doors during the royalty days

It was the first royal palace built in the Joseon Dynasty and where the Joseon Dynasty 500 year history began. It is the largest of the 5 grand palaces remaining in Seoul. You should plan to visit it together with the 2 museums in the palace grounds, National Palace Museum and National Folk Museum of Korea. We bought a combined ticket to the palaces which also includes a guided tour of Jongmyo Shrine and the Secret Garden, Changdeokgung Palace as you save money. However be prepared to walk a lot as the different buildings are spread over a large area. Do also make time to see the changing of the guards ceremony on the hour from 10am to 4 pm at the grand main gate, Gwanghwamun. After you have reach the end of the palace grounds, you can catch a glimpse of The Blue Office of the President. The office is situated just across the road with Mt.Bugaksan in the background. The only setback is that there are very few tall trees to give shade, compared to the other three palaces.

For people who are patient and have enough time...This beautiful palace has a hidden gem! If you enter the palace and have the folk museum on your right make sure to go to the left ( west) You will enter the garden grounds and tour pick up point. The garden is beautiful with temples in the lake!

If you are a fan of arts history and culture this is definitely the place for you. Very serene palace with a hall exhibiting tea ceremony live. Please find out when is the free guided tour as it is only available at certain time or you will end up not knowing any of the history accurately. Entrance is 3000won(I think) and to the museum is free :) enjoy!

I was staying in an apartment right in front of the Palace.This royal palace is imposing by its size and its majesty. There are tour guides to take you around the palace.Everyday, at every hour between 10 am and 3 pm, soldiers in costumes of the time when the palace was created (1395) march in musique for the change of guards. It is fun to watch.

We visited the palace whilst attending a family wedding. We had recently seen a program on TV documenting the rebuilding of the palace and to see it in reality was just awesome. At the time of our visit it was during Korea's Labour Day celebrations with various displays taking place. A spectacular none of us will ever forget.

We went to one day hanbok (http://www.onedayhanbok.com/where) to rent hanbok. We wear them to gyeongbokgung palace (very near from hanbok rental place, juz few station away need change 1 time but very less walking needed) and we got free entrance. Its kind of special experience and we feel awesome when other foreigner thought we are korean and asked to take picture with us. There are so many nice scenary to take photo with. It leaves me an unforgettable hanbok and palace experience. If only time allow, can wear hanbok to other palace and hanok village too. It is advisable to experience this during spring because summer will be too hot and winter to be too cold, though winter is the most beautiful.
Was a fun place to walk around and look at the housing that the king lived in . There is a museum on site as well that is worth walking thru!

review_title: Had To Visit Twice - That's How Enchanting This Place Is :)
review_body: My first visit was after 3.00 pm. I entered from Sinmumun Gate and couldn't cover the whole area of the palace. By 5.00 pm, I only managed to visit the northern part of the palace and the National Folk Museum ( a very quick walk inside, and grabbed a cup of latte at the cafe).It's just amazing that beautiful palaces like Gyeongbok and Changdeok are right the middle of this huge metropolitan city. Upon entering, I felt like I was walking into a different era. My next visit was in the morning a few days after my first visit, and I entered from Gwanghamun gate. The majestic palace, the gates, the whole area, the landscape were just breathtaking.The garden, the architecture of the pavillions - you'll have to go there yourself to see how beautiful the palace and its area are. I hope you will find a time to visit this place if you plan to go to Seoul and be ready to fall in love with this palace.

It's a beautiful palace, huge and peaceful compound. If you really want to reap the benefit of the histories behind, grab the free tour guide available near the ticket counter. Walk around, take your time. Visit the place in the morning or later in the evening since it's more comfortable. We went there near noon approaching end of spring, so yeah, the sun was not exactly nice to us :D.
Nice place and very large place, very good for exercise ..There are free guides for foreigner and Korean...Clean and tidy

review_title: Excellent palace and grounds and museum
review_body: This is a huge place including a Presidential Museum which is worth seeing. Beautiful grounds and buildings. A good few hours are required to see it all and it's well worth it
Nothing much to see. The guards are unusually dressed in red and blue and are worth a look. The palace is a series of bulidings in a large walled compound with gardens and plenty of gravel.

this palace was the biggest than other palace, seem like Forbidden city at Beijing but it's smaller. We visit at rainy days but lucky we are to seen they are beautiful on rain. the Palace including couple buildings for King, and you can buy the maps only for 500 Won at information. Entrance fee is 3.000 won and I think it's cheap. inside the Palace you will found the King home and many buildings with Korean architecture and cultural. And it will finished at Folk Museum. For me it's little bit boring since I not a historical person, but the garden ruins it.

review_title: A beautiful and peaceful place in the middle of Seoul
review_body: The palace complex is huge with many beautiful buildings. The grounds are usually quiet which is a rare delight for a location in the middle of Seoul. The history about the palace is well explained and very interesting also.

review_title: A great piece of history in Seoul
review_body: A "must do" while in Seoul. If you're really into history you could easily spend hours here, but you can also breeze right through and snap a couple pictures. Very affordable.
You should visit during guard change hour. It's quite nice to see the tradition ceremony. The palace is quite big and worth seeing
The palace is located at central Seoul and offers english speaking guide. its easy to go there (metro and taxi).

review_title: must-visit when you go to seoul.
review_body: interesting and indeed a must-visit place but at the same time there's nothing too much to see. the palace complex is huge and beautiful, though.

This palace is amazing. It's absolutely humongous, with a large park around. The buildings are beautiful, and provide a nice insight in past Korean building style. Also, the clash between the palace, The mountains and the 21st century city is entertaining. We went on a Sunday and stumbled upon a Taekwondo demonstration at the Folk museum, great fun!
Having seen a number of Palaces this was by far the best as we were in time for the changing of the Guard ceremony. It is extremely colourful, loud and bewildering but a great experience.
This place is quite large, clean and well managed. Old buildings reflected the royal life of the Korean leader long time ago.

review_title: The Night Tour is a Must See
review_body: This is by far the best bang for your buck! For ₩3,000 (price for non-Koreans), you can see a traditional dance, a light show, and see all of the grounds shown at night. It was truly mind blowing. I took about 96 pictures from all of the fore mentioned. The night tour is offered in the spring and autumn. My girlfriend and I saw the traditional dance at 8:00pm, saw the rest of the palace from 8:30pm-9:30pm, and watched the light show until 9:45pm. Make sure to eat dinner beforehand if you don't want to get home too late.

review_title: Have to see even on short visit to Seoul
review_body: Great history and architecture.Don't miss costume parade. Also see the Folk Museum nearby. Facility accepts credit card, but the entrance fee is very nominal.

review_title: One of those "Have to See" sites!
review_body: This palace is somewhat like a "mini-Forbidden City," and is definitely a must-see. If you do not view the Changing of the Guard ceremony - about an hour, it is most difficult to convince your friends that you have actually been to Seoul.

review_title: not a definite must-go place in Korea
review_body: Nothing much interesting to view at palace. too touristy place. don't really feel the culture when stepped inside.

(Pro-tip ~ all cultural attractions are free every last Wednesday of the month in Korea!). I highly recommend spending a good hour or two here, getting lost in the beautiful, intricate architecture and painted eaves. There are some informative plaques scattered about, and the 500 won guidebook is very interesting.

- The guard changing ceremony is very fascinating and educational. - Try the guard changing costume. What an experience! - I just love how the staffs of the palace wear traditional clothes. - Easily accessible by subway. Just 10 minutes walk from there.

Don't miss the change of the guards because here there is a commentary for explanation of what is going on. And the colours! I've never seen such splendidly clothed guards. Loved it! Entry is free when you wear a hanbok.The palace area is huge and you will spend about 2 hours here. There is also the National Korean Folk Museum in which you can learn a lot about Korea, it's culture and historical development. Then, there is a little area to see how the houses on the palace grounds looked throughout the ages. It is right next to the Children's Museum. You see, you can visit a lot of places here and will definitely see a lot of old houses.

We had a guided tour for the morning, if you can get there in time to see the change of guards is a awesome experience. This place is nothing short of amazing. It is VERY big! Take at least 2 hrs to get around it all. Great richness of Korean History. Great value for money.

review_title: Amazing site in the center of Seoul
review_body: Beautiful palace of the empower. Very extensive compound of old buildings and relics. I wish we'd had a tour guide to tell us more about the place, but it was still pleasant. Very in expensive to visit. Be sure to go all the way to the back where it is more green and there are beautiful koi ponds.

review_title: Quite a huge and impressive place
review_body: I thought I was just going to spend a few minutes looking around this place. Well, I didn't realize how large it was until I spend hours trying to just explore it. The place had several buildings (not just the main palace) and it had really nice gardens and bodies of water. Then it was quite a surprise to see a really awesome view of the mountains at the back of the palace. What's just as amazing is how accessible it was. All that you needed to do to get there is to get on to their really convenient train system and hop off at the station right next to the entrance of the palace. Really a must see. If I had to visit only one place in Seoul, this would be it.
Great place....and bring along your handycam... record the changing palace. It did have certain time... and the place is so nice. Especially during spring.

the palace is sooooo big. You'll need maybe 2 hours if you want to look carefully at the palace or taking picture in every corner of the palace. I think the palace is very photogenic and beautiful.If you come on Sunday, there's a flea market infront of the palace, it's worth to visit.
Nice clean grounds and some beautiful buildings. Palace is well kept. Very busy, long queue to get tickets.

We took the subway. Long walk coming and going.Nice buildings. Did not catch the changeing of the guards- I dont know where to find it. Place was huge! We just enjoyed its beauty - I did not get an audio guide. Bring water, lots of sunblock, sunglasses, and wear comfortable shoes.After, we tried to catch a taxi. Unfortunately no taxi stands that we knew of. So walked back thru subway.

review_title: Great palace and a history trip
review_body: Palace is huge and gives you good idea how kings lived in Korea back in the days. Great historical experience. Guards change is highly recommended - happens only couple of times a day so make sure to visit at the right time.

review_title: Beautiful place with loads of history
review_body: Were lucky and got a personal guidance by a guide trainee. Made us stay much longer then planned but well worth the extra time. Had to skip the Secret garden but will come back soon.

review_title: Go during the change of guards
review_body: So many school kids were there when we went so it was packed along with the tourists. Very interesting but remember that this is not the original which burned down.
If you choose just one palace to visit in Seoul, choose this. It's beautiful and in a huge area so be prepared to walk a lot. There is also a beautiful lake with a little island and temple.

We were lucky to be there to see the changing of the Guard although I believe it happens hourly. Beautifully kept, a really stunning place with gardens teeming with cherry blossoms in springtime . An absolute delight!
Time your visit to coincide with the changing of the guard, Korean style and the English language guided tour. At the end went to Korean folklore museum which is at the far end and was a nice ending.

On our first day in Seoul, my spouse and I visited this Palace which we came to know as one of the five largest palaces in Korea and was the main royal palace of the Joseon dynasty. The palace was aptly named Gyeongbokgung Palace - "the Palace Greatly Blessed by Heaven". This palace has a remarkable history as it was destroyed by fire during the Japanese invasion and it took years to rebuilt and restore this palace. We feel blessed too to be able to see this majestic and beautiful palace. We toured the numerous rooms such as the Throne room, Pavillions, the Pond, part of the Queen's residence where the garden of the four chimneys of Amisan are located. The distant Mount Bugaksan and Mount Namsan can also be seen from the Palace grounds.

review_title: Feel the Richness of Korean History
review_body: This is where you can feel the richness of Korean History. The palace is beautiful, ancient and well preserve. You can take a lot of good pictures in this palace, there are many hidden details to catch, like the window locks and wood frames. It was Thursday, 11:30 am when we visited and almost every ground in the palace is already crowded with tourist and kids on excursion. We got lucky to see the changing of the guards in the main gate. It is very interesting ceremony. This is a must see!
it was my first impression when I first saw the palace. It is really hige and grand where it needs a huge effort to maintain its condition!

You can easily spend a few hours roaming through the buildings. Very impressive, especially the maze of walls, courts and small buildings in the northern part of the complex. Free entrance to National Folk Museum is a bonus. And all for a mere 3$.

The changing of guards ceremony is like a scene in a Korean darama series. The experience will bring you back to the past. The architecture of the structures and the huge area will give the tourists a good view of the history and stories from the early dynasty and the King's life.
Spacious, beautiful, worthwhile seeing.Minimal cost as it be seen with 4other palaces for 10,000 won. Great value.Take time to see the museum as well.

review_title: If you had to choose 1 palace
review_body: This would be the place in Korea. While I didn't use a guide they have foreign language guides available. Gyeongbokgung Palace subway station will let you off at the palace right by the National Palace Museum attached to the palace grounds. The palace itself is very nice and buildings are spread out for an enjoyable walk. I don't think there was a fee for the palace museum but it costs a few thousand won (about USD3) for the actual palace entrance. On the other side of the palace grounds there is also the National Folk Museum. I believe it was also free and worth checking out. If you have bags i.e backpacks, they have lockers in the National Palace Museum which is really convenient. I don't remember if they had any convenience stands inside the palace area, I don't think they did so you may want to bring some snacks and drinks. At the entrance they have a changing of the guard ceremony. I forget the times and whether it was everyday, you may want to check. It's interesting. They also offer a discount if you're planning to visit multiple palaces. Gyeongbokgung is a must see in Seoul.second is Changdeokgung which is a short walk away. The other palaces...meh. If you're going to be in Korea for a while...give them a try. If you're here for a short visit, the other palaces are probably not worth the time since they look pretty much the same.

My family and I were very lucky to be able to see the Changing of the Guards. It was huge and beautiful! I am so amazed by how they were able to preserve the palaces with minimal modernization (well, minimal from what the eye can see). Should you visit, make sure you're at the palace by 1pm or 3pm. They have the Changing of the Guards and it's such a sight to see.
There is the guard change 2 a day. The museum provided good English guides and labels. There is a museum shop at basement - good prices equal to common shops but better selection.

We've been shocked when we found out that nothing, not even the main gate is original. The Japanese destroyed everything twice and the Koreans decided to build it up the the 90's - and it's still not completely finished. I even don't know if they've build it up according to which decade. I'm very sorry - but you can't rebuild history. Better to build something new, impressively - to be history in the future. But this fake palace we didn't like, even it's a nice park to walk around.

review_title: Beautiful and huge, lots to explore
review_body: We (me and my husband) came here around 11am on a Monday, so we avoided too much crowd. There were still enough people to keep it exciting, kids too! The ticket is 3000 won per person, which is great value. We did not purchase any audio guide or English guide book, we felt like exploring it ourselves. It was actually quite fun this way, lots to explore and it was a very different palace architecture with lot of open bits inside the palace too. I liked the roofs and doors design. We spent about 3 hours there and we just took a stroll and wandered - not sure if we saw the whole thing. The weather was beautiful and very sunny, although my husband who is white got sun burnt as we were out in the open for most of the time :-) so make sure you apply plenty of sun screen if you don't want to be burnt. There are boards with information in English too, which helps. Attached photos!
we went to see this place with my daughter and worth the trip. we are there early morning not much people so we have a good view of the place

review_title: Time your visit at Gyeongbokgung Palace
review_body: Make sure that you arrive before 10.00 am. ( 1.00 pm / 3.00 pm ). That's when the Changing of the Guards takes place. Try to bag a vantage point near the big drum ( near the ticket kiosks ). This is where the guards will enter the palace grounds. This is no ordinary changing of the guards. It is a vista in Korean traditional military uniform, traditional instruments, traditional weapons and flags. Plus the whole pomp and ceremony of it all. Note: You can watch the arrival of the relieving guards or you can position yourself in front of Gwunghwamun to witness the end of the ceremony. Then you can wander around the inner palace, after which you can opt for a free guided tour ( English ) at 11.00 am. After this, if you still have the energy, the Palace Museum is just next door and definitely worth a visit. ( Look out for the royal placenta jars !)

review_title: very good place to experience korean history.
review_body: Highly recommend it.. Best time to go early AM because much less tourists around. Very good place to see and experience Korean history

This palace is huge! There's a lot of nice grounds around the area. It was more fun to take the English tour in order to find out a little about some of the buildings, etc. It was a free tour, just check for the times. There are a couple of museums in the area that you can go to also, which were well done, but not the most interesting museums, to me. Also the blue house is outside the gate and there's cool areas of Seoul all around the palace.

review_title: Like Being in the Middle of the Joseon Dynasty
review_body: You get to walk around freely around this well preserved historical palace. Wonderful and mesmerizing.

I thought this was going to be a 15 minute activity, max 30 minutes. See the palace, take a pic and get out. So mistaken! The grounds of this place were huge! Go on a clear day and you get views of the mountain in the background. There's a free folk museum too which is rather interesting (coming from someone who doesn't really like museums...). Get away from the main temple because that's where the tour groups gather.

Really not much to see, except the changing of the guards ceremony. Should have English explanation of each area and building of the palace. The ground was dry and not much shrubs or flowers. I have been here a few times and it is about the same. A disappointment.

The complex was great to see and explore. Most things have an english translation, so it is very US tourist friendly. I did the audio tour and there was a good bit of history, but not as much information about how the buildings were used as I would have liked.

This is a very large palace. It is often the most commonly cited palace but make sure that its not the only one you see if you are time-constrained. The Changdeokgung (UNESCO site) is a more balanced better choice. If you intend to see at least these two, save some money by getting the all palace pass.
This palace has so many story i heard.This is not huge mega palace but you can read it what is the palace.
Attracts many so plan early if you want good photo ops, else enjoy the people. My second visit here and it was only average. I believe I would enjoy it more if I had a historical guided tour.

review_title: A sample of the old Corea
review_body: Although a small amount of buildings are original, most of the buildings on the palace are actually rebuilt after they were destroyed throughout history (fires, japan invasion, war ...). They still accurately show the way of life and style of the times of the emperors.I advice you to take a guide, otherwise you'll be a bit lost like we were, looking at gorgeous buildings but without knowing exactly what they'r history is.

The place very accessible by metro and very interesting guard changing ceremony (traditional costumes) that performed hourly. Free guided tour in different languages are available, just look out for the time slot. The tour about an hr and the guide was knowledgable. The last stop was at the pavilion which is the shooting scene for Kdrama (Moon embracing the sun). The musuem is free entry with good details of Korea history and culture.
Lots of people from different countries. The place full of history, very beautiful, very colorful, must see! Children will certainly like it.

review_title: A good visit for historical place
review_body: There are free tour guides on selective hours for selective languages to explain on the building, cultural and also history of Korea. You can feel the atmosphere of being in a palace during the ancient time. It is definitely worth a visit to know more on Korea history and also the beautiful scenery is really great.
We were there at the time of a changing of the guard ceremony and it was very interesting. Definitely a must see part of Seoul.
Stopped by the museum and learned a lot about Korean history and culture. The grounds and very nicely landscaped and the buildings very grand. This is one of the best places for photo opportunities.

review_title: Massive and Nice Start to Touring Seoul
review_body: You can't possible visit Seoul without making a stop here. The guided tours are free and interesting. And the photo opportunities are endless. Make sure you walk towards the back which includes a pavilion situated in the middle of a lake and accessed by a stone bridge.

On the Seoul tourist board site, you can reserve a free guided tour (in english) of Gyeongbokgung Palace. We met our tour guide in front of the ticket booth and were fortunate to see the changing of the guards at the palace (check times and dates). Through our helpful guide, we learned about the Japanese administration building that was built during the japanese colonial rule symbolically at the main gate of the palace. It was only destroyed and the magnificent gate replaced in the 1980s. As you walk through the imposing buildings which are elaborately painted, we learned the paint was imported from China and at times cost more than the buildings. Don't miss the interesting sun-dial in front of one of the king's main rooms. Nearby Gyeonbokgung Palace is the traditional korean neighborhood (Hanok Bukchon village) with nice small shops, art galleries and restaurants.
Went there during winter and it's quite good for taking pictures. But other than that, there's nothing much you can do there

All of the palaces in Seoul are amazing. We were fortunate enough to enjoy our visit this time during cherry blossom time. The history is very interesting and the place very peaceful and relaxing to just stroll and spend time.

Unique and gives an insight to Korea's history and its architecture. Has a nice museum that contains a lot of interesting information about their culture and their past as well.
