Wait for the changing of guards at the entrance, grab a brochure while waiting, it will tell you what the guards' attire represent.

The area of the palace is pretty big and very nice to walk in. My "minus" is, that the temple as an attraction itself is not really old, but newly built. In my opinion, there are more beautiful, authentic temples in Asia...Awesome during cherry blossom season (which lasts only for about two weeks ;))

review_title: Huge palace and interesting guard change ceremony
review_body: It is a huge palace but basically looks the same after awhile. Interesting to see the guard change ceremony. Probably the only one that worth seeing, the rest would pretty much be smaller scale than this one.

review_title: Largest of the Five Grand Palaces remaining in Seoul
review_body: I guess if you are in Seoul you will almost certainly go to this famous palace complex. It is apparently the biggest and seems to be the busiest and most popular with tourists and Koreans alike. There is also a regular 'changing of the guard' ceremony, which is fun. Entrance to the enclosure is primarily from the south west or south east, although the ticket office is at the south east.Entrance is cheap (free for 65 year old or over) and an excellent English (or other language) small guide book will cost you just 500 Won.The extent of restoration testifies to the turbulent history of Korea but the extensive site and many buildings are well worth a visit and will keep keen photographers busy.Access to the National Palace Museum is at the south west and the National Folk Museum is at the north east (you get your hand stamped if you want to visit the museum and re-enter the palace).One of the 'essential' sights!

The palace was so beautiful. There were several lovely buildings including one on the water. The roofs and beautiful decorations under the roofs were incredible. The grounds were quite peaceful and I could understand why there were so many visitors. We were lucky to be there on the weekend when they have guard marching ceremony. Quite colorful and enjoyable.

I went there with a guided tour for a hole day that included this magnificent Palace. Located north of downtown dn near the Cheokbokung Palace. There are so many different beautiful buildings in this áreas de the different trees in Bloom, ( before entering They Tokyo us to de National Folk Miseum which is very nice!), you really need a lot of time to see everything, but we were so walking so fast. At the end is the principal "keep" with the little lake around it that made an idillic pictures! Wonderful! Entrance is 3000 son (2400 for groups of ten or more persons); children 7-17 pay 1500 ( or 1200 for more than 10) under 6 and over 65 are free. Closed on Tuesdays and always open At 9:00 a.m. . Closes between 4-5:30 dependiente on the month. This is a MUST visit while en Seoul!

If you just want to have a sticky beak without paying for a ticket (though they are VERY cheap - 3000 or 4000 won I think), you can go inside the first gates and walk around the courtyard area.It's quite a lot of walking, and bit rough for the pram/stroller, but doable none the less.
Such a beautiful place of you love history. There's also a resting place where you can drink coffee. Changing of guards also happens during weekdays. My fave place is the Museum.

We had a luck to see guard change with all their ancient picturesque costumes,we joined to free English guided tour , there are few such tours each day ,it take about 1.5 hour,and we spent another 1 hour there to make pictures. Thicket cost 3000 won seniors elder 65 years free.

review_title: Still a great tour, even in cold weather.
review_body: We toured Gyeongbokgung Palace with a guide Who was certain to get us there in time for the colorful changing of the guard! Despite a chilly gray day, we enjoyed the ceremony along with a huge crowd.After wander through of all the buildings/grounds, we also stopped into the Korean folk history museum that lies just beyond the palace grounds. Good way to spend a few hours of your tour-time in Seoul.

I came here just thinking to take some photos and have a look around. C'mon, what much can you see in a castle compound? Wrong. There's a lot to see here. And plus, the place is so huge and buildings are placed quite far apart, so there were lots of walking. Ended up I spent about 4 hours, barely covering the few main buildings and the garden with the lake in the middle.Lots of photospots, either the Maingate, guards, main courtyard, inner gate and the list goes on.. it just never ends. I went on a warm and bright autumn day, so it was good. All the time spent here will be outdoor, so if you're going in the winter of in the colder days of spring and autumn, then better be prepared.
This, I think, is the best and most well-known palace in Seoul. Changing of the Guard is cool here. Photo ops are awesome, to include the background of the 10,000 won bill.
During weekend, there are guard changing ceremony. Very cultural sight. We rented audio guide. Great value and we learned a lot (even our 7/8 years old kids)

I ended up spending 5 hours here. It was great. They have the changing of the guard several times a day which is quite dramatic. I took a free English speaking tour at 11, but they have them at various times. Then I went to the Folk Museum at the end of the palace complex, and the National Palace Museum at the front of the complex. Great way to spend the day for only $3. Highly recommend.

I traveled here as part of the Free Seoul City Tour available from the Incheon International Airport tourism department. Our group of 20 was guided by a very well versed and knowledgeable guide. The grounds are absolutely beautiful and very well maintained, as is the palace itself. The backdrop of mountains and cherry blossoms certainly add to the mesmerizing experience here.

The palace was quite huge. However, I didn't feel tired of walking as the surrounding was very captivating. Enjoyed watching the change of soldiers and also the architecture of the entire building. Totally a must-not-miss place of visit

Well maintained and proudly displayed - this palace and its' surroundings are a must do while in Seoul. You can have a sense of the history and pride of the Korean people. You can spend a lovely afternoon on a 'date' or with your entire family. Was only 3000 KRW (3 bucks). Highly recommended
Discover the very first palace in Seoul, explore the different parts of the palace and don't forget to have your photo taken with the door guards.
It is not glittery, rather simple for a king.Yet it was an enjoyable place. Sit around the lake and enjoy the view and cool air especially in spring.

review_title: Royal Palace with Historical and Modern Cultural Tour
review_body: The visit of the Gyeongbokgung Palace is definitely nice with guided Chinese Tour (as my mum is visiting). The guide is FOC as per ticketing but you need to follow the timing if you are visiting. There are four languages namely Korean, English, Chinese and Japanese.The areas inside those palace are forbidden to entry as more Chinese Tourists are visiting such places, they like to touch the historical structure which will damaged them. As the structures are slowly built due to fire and war damages.Overall, the guided tour is good. After the tour, you may exit the back door and you will see the Modern Korea Prime Minister Office and Ministerial Offices.You can go back in to the Palace with the tickets. Right at another corner is the Museum of the old Korea where you see items from the different Dynasties to the old villages of Korea.

One of the few palaces you shouldn't miss-out during your holiday is Seoul. The buildings were quite magnificent. It opens from 9am till 6pm...but it's great there's free guides tours conducted on English @ 11am, 1:30pm & 3.30pm. The changing of guard was amazing...dress in their traditional regalia with sound of drums. Explore all the different buildings & grounds ...would take me a good few hours. This place captivates me... Ending ...by reaching to a main road right across is the Blue House.

review_title: A beautiful palace that makes for a leisurely walk.
review_body: Do not forget to catch the changing of the guards. We caught the 4pm one at the main gate, and it was such a colorful treat! There weren't a lot of people when we went there, so we were able to go around and enjoy the serenity of the place, especially the part beside the pond/lake. Read more about it in my blog: https://jeffer.wordpress.com/2014/03/23/south-korea-pt-2-a-dose-of-royalty/

review_title: includes a guided tour in english
review_body: the large compound of mostly reconstructed buildings is worth a visit and the small admission fee. guided tours in English help visitors understand the historical significance. it's a great spot to take pretty photos of the typical Korean architecture.

The main palace in the Joseon Dynasty! Be sure to visit all places within the complex! If you are lucky, come around 1300hrs for guard changing ceremony. It is one of the three times daily they change the guards.

We arrived rather early and could tour the palace and ground before having a free guided tour in English. Both approaches helped us to get an extensive view of that central monument in the history of (not so) ancient Korea. If you can, do not miss the changing of the guard!

review_title: Full of rich and sad history, but fantastic and beautiful architecture
review_body: As a Korean who is born and raised in Seoul, I don't like Seoul. The city is too much developed without integrating our traditional culture and architecture style. No taste, only Samsung and LG and Hyundai all over the city. However, I love this palace. It's one of few places left to Koreans, standing there for hundreds of years, holding our pride.Though, I think one day is enough to enjoy Seoul and here is the plan I recommend to travel Seoul.1) In the morning after breakfast, buy a back of snack (there is a small supermarket outside on the left side of the entrance), enjoy the palace and walk into the deepest part of the palace. There is a pond you can take a rest. Sit anywhere and throw some snacks to pigeons and gold fishes in the pond. It's quite fun :) 2) There are some museums too, so if you have time and energy, enjoy them.3) eat something simple outside the palace (there are some restaurants around Gwanghwa-mun subway station)4) go to Changdeokgung Palace and buy a ticket for the secret garden (if you can, book it online). It is the best in Spring or Autumn when the leaves turn into yellow and red (too hot in summer, nothing on trees in winter). There is a souvenir store outside the entrance and there selection is much better than most stores on Insadong street. 5) go to Insadong and have late lunch or early dinner (Bamboo-cooked rice with some beef/port would be good) and Korean tea after. Enjoy the street food if you want (try Yong-Su-Yum, it's a sweet), and buy some souvenirs. 6) take a cab, and go to N-Seoul tower. Enjoy the night :)If you have time next day, I recommend Buk-Chon (North Village). Actually, there are some traditional style places you can stay, and some places serve very good Korean food. The location is good, so I recommend you to stay in this area (but not close to a subway station).I think that's almost all you can enjoy in Seoul for 2-days. If you have more than two days, I strongly recommend you to travel outside Seoul. But you need a tour guide. Hope you have good time in Korea!

review_title: See the palace of King & Queen stay
review_body: Nice place to visit as you can see the old architecture design of Korean palace. From there, you can learn more about their King & Queen buildings. Interesting to see how ancient korean guards warm themselves and how the smokes are channeled to another buildings. Amazing too to see how they maintain their buildings (nets are around the roofs, or sharp small sticks around) to prevent birds droppings on the wooden roof).

review_title: Visiting this palace is a must when you're in Seoul!
review_body: Gyeongbokgung is more for sight-seeing as the rooms around the palace are mostly enclosed. The sceneries surrounding the palace is scenic especially when I visited during winter. Don't miss out on the changing of guards ceremony which is the main focal attention of Gyeongbokgung. There is also a booth for you to try on hanboks. For those of you who are expecting a museum-like setting with artifacts and exhibits, this palace is not really like that. For that, you may want to visit Unhyeongung, located quite nearby to Gyeongbokgung. Unhyeongung's rooms are more open-concept with artifacts and multilingual (Korean, English, Mandarin & Japanese) descriptions of every exhibit.
Since this is the biggest palace in Seoul, of course you should see it. Lots to see and photograph, even though it is much reconstructed.

A vast piece of awesome architecture coupled with unique and authentic South Korean Heritage. Love seeing the Palace up close. Reminds me of the Forbidden City in China. One of the best tourists spots in Korea!

review_title: A fantastic slice of Korean history
review_body: The palace is without doubt a fantastic spectacle. It's gloriously cheap (3000 won for an adult) and can easily fill a morning or afternoon. The main palace, rebuilt in the 19th century, after it was destroyed in previous centuries by the Japanese, is in excellent condition. Further to this the grounds are quite extensive and we were surprised to see more structures, ponds and walkways after every corner. A true highlight is of course the changing of the guard which happens 3 times a day. If you go earlier on each one you can see them practice outside the palace.Being my first time this Far East, it was a hugely fabulous place to behold and is by far the best of the palaces in the city. Visit!

review_title: Historical palace with many interesting features around.
review_body: We visited the palace and found ourselves walking around the place to view the many interesting architectural details and design. We spent about 75 minutes walking around until the rain pushed us onward to our next tour. Worth the visit.

Whether you have 36 hours or a more extended stay in Seoul, you should definitely stop by Gyeongbokgung (gung = palace). There are several palaces in Seoul but this one has the largest compound. If you don't much about Korean history, I would recommend the guided tour (which I think is free) and is offered in several languages and throughout the day. It's interesting hearing about the function of the different buildings and getting a sense of Koreas's imperial history. Definitely must see/do.
Beautiful, impressive and interesting. Be sure to catch the change of guard. This season is great since most of the trees were in blossom.

review_title: Put this on your Seoul bucket list
review_body: We planned to join an English speaking tour (two or three are conducted during the week and note that the Palace is closed on Tuesday's) This is the only way to see the grounds, to enjoy its splendor and beauty. The tour was a quick one hour, but sufficient to give one a firm overview of the palace and history. It is the largest palace in Seoul and if you can only see one, then this is the one to see. Also adjacent to the palace is the Korean Folk Museum and there are other sites nearby. We went on a Saturday so it was crowded, but not overly so.

The palace is of course a must see. It is an awesome sight that shows a lot of the history of Seoul and Korea, However, it doesn't "breath" this history as you would hope. Large parts of the original buildings have been destroyed in the past and are now rebuild. So it feels more like a life size museum or rebuild than like an ancient place. If you set your mind to this, you will still be able to see the beauty of the place.
If you are into political and historical sites, i recommend to see this place. It will bring back how the culture was formed and shaped years ago.
It was absolutely lovely, entrance fee is only 3,000 won and it is nice to spend half the day there slowly exploring the beautiful architecture!

This palace is pretty crowded, but for a reason. The architecture is stunning and the detail in construction is remarkable. It is big and will easily take up a lot of your time if you wish it to. If you come to Seoul, you have to see Gyeongbokgung.

review_title: Beauty and History rolled into one
review_body: When visiting this palace, you should join the tour as this will help you understand the story behind the palace and the Royals. Schedule your trip before hand so that you can try the free Hanbok wearing, watch the changing of the royal guards, and tour of the Palace on half day. Visit the palace in the morning as there are more people in the afternoon.

Headed here on an organised tour. The palace is huge while you could happily wander through here alone although a tour guide adds so much more to the history and way the place was constructed and operates, I would recommend it.The changing of the gate guard ceremony is at 10am, worthwhile seeing, lots of flags music and colors. The palace gets a bit crowded after this time as all the tour groups start to go through. It wasn't that crowded though.We visited, at the end of March, the cherry blossoms were starting to come out, though will in full bloom in a week or twoDefiantly worth seeing.

The site is huge, and there are so many aspects of the property that the best thing is to join a free tour so that you can learn as much as possible about life in the palace. Certainly worthy of a visit. Plan at least 2 hours.

review_title: Beautiful Grounds - Changing of the Guard
review_body: This Palace was so much larger than expected. Saturdays you can see changing of the guards in traditional Korean uniforms from Joseon Dynasty Period. For cost of admission (1.50 US) you get access to Palace Museum. This is a primarily outdoor walk through of the grounds- be prepared to walk quite a bit but plenty of areas to rest. Beautiful parklike setting in center and Folk Museum close enough to visit as well (separate admission).

review_title: The one that you shouldn't be missed
review_body: I'm a history freak. After knowing that it was a grand palace back to 1800s with more than 200 constructions before it was burnt down by Japanese invasion. I wasn't hesitate to visit this place. After the renovation in 1960 Gyeongbokgoong finally come back to life again. With the spectacular scenery behind of mountains this place is wonderful. Not too big to survey around in 2 hours. Plus there is a free museum about history of Korea inside the palace. And every 10 am 12 pm and 3 pm you can enjoy the guards shift changing marching ceremony.

review_title: Big, beautiful, and you need a tour guide
review_body: Enjoyed a half day visit to this palace. Entrance cost was cheap, but would get more from the visit with a good guide - I recommend one for best experience. Changing of the guard is quite nice and very colorful attire.

review_title: Awesome, just like in the historical dramas :)
review_body: There were guided tours in English! The place was huge so even after the tour there were more places to explore. the tours have set time so you can explore and come back to join the tour.
Its a must to visit. This place is full of culture and history. Best to go with a guide so that they are able to explain every details

review_title: One of the most interesting palace
review_body: clearly one of the things not to be missed in SEOUL, if you are into monuments. I have lived 5 years next to the palace to know it quite well under many different seasons, Winter can be quite nice with SUN and SNOW. Expect people but the palace is big, however not as big as the FORBIDDEN City in BEIJING. There is a FOLKS museum inside that is worth visiting (you need 1.5 h) and you can have a lunch there, quite nice to take a break from the busy city. Dont expect to see much furniture into the buildings, Korean Palaces are always very barren...the whole thing makes an enjoyable experience for a half day.

I've traveled all over Europe and visited my share of castles, but the grand scale of the grounds and buildings included in Gyeonbokgung cast a shadow on everything I've witnessed before. It is massive and a bit daunting. Make sure to wear comfortable walking shoes and grab a guidebook (offered in several languages) or hook up with a tour guide.The main (most famous) gates of Gyeonbokgung are right off of Gwanghwamun Square, not far from the notable statue of King Sejong (which is another must-see when in Seoul). It's very easy to get here by subway, bus, or taxi; although, I suggest taking the subway - it's super inexpensive, and is possibly the BEST subway system I've ever experienced, EVER. (Very safe. Very clean. Very easy to navigate, even if you don't speak Korean or read Hangual.)We exited the subway (sorry, can't remember which line or number), and it spit us out right by a museum/gift shop that had a side entrance to the palace. It worked out perfectly! We walked in the gates and were in the main, large open courtyard inside the main gates (that are on street level in Gwanghwamun Square).The palace is always teeming with tourists from all over the world. It's bustling and dizzying and amazing all at once. Unlike European castles, there isn't just one, central building; but instead, multitudes of buildings with similar architecture scattered throughout the grounds. Some are open to be viewed (like the private rooms of the royal family members or the throne and state rooms) while others are boarded up and can only be viewed from the outside. There are beautiful flowers and water areas in different parts of the complex. My favorite part was Hyangwonjeong Pavilion - an "island" in the northern grounds of the palace connected by a wooden bridge to the rest of the grounds. You're not allowed to enter the island, but it's magical to look at.If you want to be extra thorough and make it to the back of the complex (where the servants and guards quarters are), you should probably allow yourself 3 hours or so to meander around. This is not the type of attraction where you are in and out in an hour! There is so much to see, you could easily spend most of a day here or split the grounds up and visit on two different days.Although built in 1395, the palace was been rebuilt in the late 1800's due to fire (the buildings are nearly all made of wood); but the Koreans took great care to reconstruct the palace as it originally stood.It's open most days from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. but is closed on Mondays or Tuesdays (can't remember which, but it was closed the first time we tried to visit) and holidays (check the website (http://www.royalpalace.go.kr/html/eng/main/main.jsp) to make sure it will be open when you intend to visit.An absolute MUST-SEE. You will not regret visiting, and I suggest taking a walk through the nearby gift shop I mentioned. I'm sure the items are more expensive than elsewhere, but I never saw things they had for sale anywhere else but there. Worth it if you're looking for a unique memento of your visit to Seoul/Korea.

review_title: Grand Gem in the middle of downtown
review_body: The Gyeongbokgung is a treasure of culture and history in the middle of downtown. It has epic buildings, beautiful architecture, SO much to see, and history coming from every piece of timber. Go early to avoid crowds and also because it gets pretty hot in the morning. You don't need a tour guide as everything is well sign posted.

review_title: Felt like you were traveling back in time
review_body: What an amazing experience to see up close many of reconstructed and existing palatial buildings. I was also impressed at my tour guides knowledge of history. I just wish that the Japanese army had not detroyed, desecrated and simply made such a mark on these grounds. The grassy patches near the Queen Dowager's residence really made me feel sad. You must visit these palaces while in Seoul!
The palace consists of many, many buildings. Design, painting and architecture of those buildings are almost the same. The main gate and the place hall are the most beautiful ones.

Definitely recommend getting the guide book and really taking your time to read about the incredible stories and history of each hall/temple. And see the changing of the guards - very cool fashion statements!

Gyeongbok Palcae is the rebuilt (circa late 1800s) palace of one of Korea's kings prior to Japan's first invasion of the country. It is large, with a variety of buildings from the homes of the queen and the crown prince, to the dwellings of lesser staff and a government work building. It isa good look at Korean history and a remembrance of the Japanese war atrocities that required the reconstruction of buildings like this throughout Korea.

review_title: Visit to catch a Glimpse of Korea's past
review_body: Seoul and Korea itself has many palaces scattered all around. Gyeongbokgung Palace is unique as it now has a change of guards routine and also reenactment of guards training all about its compound. You pay a fee to enter the palace compound and you can have a guided tour in various language. If you are not a museum/palace sort of person, just enjoy the attractions outside the paid palace compound.

You would never believe that you are in the city when you are browsing round these temples. There are many more cute temples in the surround area which your ticket includes. It is a great place to visit.

Enjoyed walking the grounds and seeing the beautiful painted buildings. Some have furnishings you can glimpse from the doorway. If you are 65 or older it is free to enter. There were many tour buses when we arrived but it was not over crowded. You can also watch the colorful changing of the guards. Enjoy!

review_title: Great temple I the middle of Seoul
review_body: Very big temple area, try to get there when the guards change. This area is very big and you can easily spent 2-3hours here. Remember to bring good walking shoes and not clip claps. You can buy a guided tour, or just go there yourself, easy to find. If you have the time go visit the folks museum next door.

review_title: Rebuilt a few times but good depiction
review_body: Take a walking tour to get the most information about these many buildings and how people lived here. Catch the changing of the guards.
Not much info onsite, so I focused on architectural details instead. In this part of the world, there are truly grand examples of this style.

We went there to check out the palace but then we figure out something else. Every hour, they would have guard changing ceremony. about 10-15 people march out with drumroll. they replace the guard then goes in back. I could remember when is the last change but probably about 4pm. Anyway, if you are interested to try their guard's clothing, do stand infront of an isolated building on the compound 10 min after the guard changing start. they only accept few people but it was open every hour. If you missed once, you still have next hour. do go in 3 person or more. As the person in charge wont help you to take picture. If not, you only can depend on selfie~I couldnt talk bout the palace as we ran out of it to watch the guard changibg ceceremony. Afterwrd we couldnt go in back. So if you wanted to check the palace, come early and watch the guard changing, then only you should go in. Sharp on time ok?

review_title: Worth a visit - time it to see the changing of the guard
review_body: Gyeongbokgung was within walking distance of my BnB and a great place to walk around. You can complete a decent circuit on your own in about 30-45 minutes. Try to time things so that you can be at the Gwanghwamun gate on the hour between 10am and 4pm. The 10am, 1pm and 3pm times are the extended show while the other hours only show a shortened version. Since the whole reenactment is only about 15 mins long, I'm not sure there is much at all to see with a shortened version! You don't need an extra ticket to see the changing of the guard, you just need to be in the right place at the right time.

this is 1 of the 2 palaces you can visit in Seoul, it's probably the main one people visit, it's truly magical and picture perfect. it gives you a great sense of how the royalties lived and there's so much history in this place, even though a lot of the buildings were not the original as some of them have been destroyed by fire, but they did a great job of reconstruct them to their initial appearance. I enjoyed it a lot and spent about 2-3 hours there :)

We were amazed at how beautifully presented all the buildings were. They were lacking in information though, even the tour guide didn't tell us much. Great place. Must see. Do some research before so you know more about it.

If you're going to see any of the many palaces in Seoul, I would recommend this one - only because it's the biggest, most popular, easily located, and around a lot of other landmarks/monuments. Honestly, if you've seen one of the palaces, you've seen them all. Nonetheless, it's a worthwhile visit.
I really reminds me of the Drama RoofTop Prince, and that's the reason we're here too.#MickyYooChun #MyInspiration

This is, if not the most beautiful and biggest among the 5 grand palaces in Seoul. Go early as it does get busy around mid-afternoon. You can spend a few hours in here getting lost in the beautiful traditional architecture and the atmosphere. That and you are standing where in the past royalty have been.

Surrounded by the modern city buildings the Temple is a haven of tradition. Close to the Metro it is easy to get too.The Temple is a traditional Asian style of open spaces and exotically roofed buildings. I do always feel that more could be made of the internals of the buildings. With traditional furniture and features.Well worth a visit when you are in Seoul.

Gyeongbok Palace is a must see if in the Seoul area. It's still in process of being restored but well worth the trip. Not overly exciting but nice. If you time it right you can get the tour in English or Japanese.

must visit attraction when you are planning to go on holiday to visit Seoul, you must visit it twice in the morning and at night when they open the light, also during the day you have to watch the ceremony for changing the palace guards

Went to Gyeongbokgung as our first destination during our Korea Trip. It was winter, and was really cold. We saw the changing of guards session. The place is quite huge and it wasn't crowded during the winter
It's a beautiful antique castle. They have people dress up and shows of how they use to dress, and march for war. Definitely a place to visit in Seoul.
It's a large beautiful palace with a mountain as it's backdrop (sorry, I don't remember the name of the mountain). We were lucky there was no entrance fee when we went there!

We were there when it was the peak of autumn, and the beautiful palace garden was filled with bright colours. As many other reviewers would point out, it would be good to come in time for the guard-changing ceremony, where you get to see the different units marching around in the main square. You can plan in advance with the ceremony timings here: http://english.visitkorea.or.kr/enu/SI/SI_EN_3_2_1.jsp?cid=292853.The grounds are clean and well-maintained, although I wouldn't wax lyrical about the sights (other than the garden yes). I might have unfairly compared this to Beijing's Forbidden Palace, but if you have been to Beijing, you might get what I mean. Nothing that much to see when you really look into each of the halls or rooms here.It's a short walk to Samcheongdong (use the eastern exit, and work north for 7-10mins), so you could always plan to have lunch or teatime at one of the cafes or restaurants there.

review_title: Don't miss the Changing of the Guard
review_body: You really haven't seen a "Changing of the Guard" until you've been to the Gyeongbokgung Palace. Strolling around the grounds gives one a lot of photo ops...but the Guards themselves were the highlight for me!

We had joined a free guided tour in English. All very well organised. It was a very crowded day as it was the last Wednesday of the month and entrance was free for that day. Beautiful grounds, historical and very Korean. Be on time for the changing of the guards.

A definite MUST for all Seoul travellers. Wonderful views into Korean history and mindset. Kids love it, adults love it... what's not to love? Palace area is accessible even with wheelchairs and prams so everyone is available (though there are some steps).

A lot of things to see and visit. Be prepared to do a lot of walking because the grounds are very vast. Our kids were interested in the first few buildings but after seeing the rest they were bored. We ended up letting them run around in the open fields outside to tire them out. The palace is well intact and gives you a good idea of how life was back then. Definitely recommend seeing the palace if you're visiting.
Beautiful place! Easy to get there. Have some information in English too. Impressive buildings and vivid very artistic decorations.

review_title: Beautiful palace even if largely a remodel
review_body: Due to the history with Japan, much of this does not date back to the 1300's but instead the 18/1900's. Regardless it is very cheap to tour and the grounds are beautiful/massive. Worth the 2-3 hours to do it justice. Try to catch the changing of the guards.
It was the main royal palace of the Joseon dynasty. Today, it is the most beautiful and grandest palace of all. Must see during visit to South Korea.

review_title: Cool Palace, Would Like More Info
review_body: If you're a tourist visiting Seoul, the palaces are a go to attraction. I was only able to visit one palace and I was glad it was this one. The place is also next to a museum which would make it convenient for people who are interested in history. This place is huge! Their is a lot of walking involved. If you're there at the right time, you can also view a changing of the guard ceremony at the main entrance.

You've seen one palace, you've seen them all. There are sooo many dam palaces in Korea that I felt I had to go to as many as I could. I'd have to say this is my favorite but they all look the same with little differences... This one is special because they have people in costumes at the front and around the palace. I went during winter so I don't know if the other palaces just didn't have people in costumes because of the weather or because I was there so early or if they just didn't have them. But it was great seeing the customes and wondering how they were keeping warm in the freezing weather.

It's a must-go spot for tourists and that means you have to share the beautiful palace with thousands of people. It is really an astounding structure of building and the lake and trees are pretty as well.

review_title: Korean Traditional Outfits was the Highlight
review_body: We got to try on the Korean traditional outfits for free. It was up for grab. We, four of us, put on the outfits, which I forgot the name, and took a photo. The photo seems like we were a fuzzy family, but, all of us were just close friends.

review_title: Only for the changing of guards
review_body: There are several palaces in south korea. I personally prefer this one. I didn't buy the package that includes tours to several palaces. Best time to go is during the change of guards where you can snap photos of the guards in traditional uniforms.
Beautiful Place. It was winter so there wasn't much greenery but it is still very nice. Also got to see the 'Changing of the Guards" ceremony. Very informative. Can't wait to go back in the summer.

Many palace has been greatly preserved. This palace on the other hand has been abandoned, damaged and destroyed systematically. Currently, many of the building within the palace is planned to be restored to original condition.The palace is very popular with tourist so it is quite crowded but the garden area is quiet.The palace have north and south entrance gate. North Gate also shows the current President' s building.

The palace and grounds were rebuilt after Japanese occupation ended in 1945. For me this dropped it to a 4. A bonus is the grounds are next to the seat of government and a small museum that is a quick history of 1945 forward.

review_title: changing the guide in front of the main entrance
review_body: Very good spot to visit in Seoul. It is very interesting place, changing the guide is a great ceremony, don't miss it!

Entrance fee is not expensive. You can look around limited places in the palace but it's big and there are many places to see. There are some performances in particular time so check it out before you go this place.

review_title: Light up of the palace is beautiful
review_body: Went when the palace was lit up for one night. It was beautiful. Definitely worth taking someone there on a date, or for pictures.

The Palace is spectacular, huge and majestic. Its a good place to learn about the History of Korea. It is also considered as a well maintain historical tourist spot. However, if you are not into historical or culture then it is okay to give it a pass.

If you read my other reviews on the palaces in Korea, then you will know that it is a good first step if you have never visited other Asian palaces in Japan or China. If you have, you may feel disappointed because Korean palaces lacks the grandeur of their Asian neighbours. I never got the "awe" factor.
Amazing place for some photography skills practices, its vary huge place you might need double battery pack ;)

Tours in English run at set times. Definitely worth doing it as there isn't much signage and what would seem like a whole bunch of buildings would be unappreciated without the history and stories.Not ideal destination in the rain as there's not much shelter.

review_title: Lunar New Year at the Palace
review_body: Absolutely breathtaking with the presidential palace in the background of the south gate. The palace is a lot less crowded at the south gate which is quite nice. During the new year there were tons of extra activities going on within the gates with many people in traditional dress. The foliage isn't in bloom but it was not too crowded so traveling here in the wintertime definitely has its bonuses.

review_title: This may surpass the forbidden city of Beijing
review_body: Fantastic palace; This place is very similar to the forbidden city in Beijing, it goes on and on, with each section opening new insights into the life of its inhabitants. Great architectural detail, and perfect place for some great photos.

Join the free guided tours for a more thorough appreciation of the beauty and the magic of this place. It's not just a pretty photogenic palace. It's a well preserved place steeped in Korean culture :)
You can't stop in Seoul and not make a trip here. We came during a changing of the guards ceremony. The colors and action were amazing.

We reached the place nearly 3PM local time. It is the right timing where the guard changing ceremony was about to begin. It was awesome!! After the 20min changing ceremony, we were quickly run to the booth where you can try on the guard outfit - for FREE!!! have fun!!
Period attire along with very well preserved site signage in Korean and english, Tour guides are there to help and explain
It's a "Must Visit" palace if you come to visit Seoul. Very nice and big. Before going inside the palace, you should visit "National Palace Museum" in the front first.

A big Korean art traditional architecture style; Located in many station exit but i chose exit5 from Gwanghwamun station; As i came early opening 9am time; So wandered around at Cheonggyecheon canal area before heading these place. The palace itself very big space area; with many complex building inside; the Korean colorful rooftop style is so delicacy and charming; combined with Korean National Folk village museum; where admidssion fee already plus these 2 places visit with costing 3000 KRW from the palace entrance.

I've been in the palace last 2012 but then I decided to go again as I'm with my friends who are first timers. We went there at a wrong time as it was closed but instead, we stroll around the outer grounds of the palace. It was my first time in that area but I love there! We play under the big tree! It's winter but you can still see orange trees/ leaves around the area! We came back here the next day. We arrived just in time for the ceremony. It was so colorful and by watching this, you will be amazed of their traditions and culture.We availed the English tour and it lasted for an hour. Very helpful indeed to understand its history and the place itself. How I wish I can turn back time!In 2012, we went there in Autumn so it was full of color but this time since it was winter, the trees were already bald. But nevertheless, the beauty of the palace is still there. Big palace, Rich history, Beautiful scenery.. perfect! :D
There are a lot of palaces in Seoul, but this one is the biggest and easiest to visit. Nice scenic walks around the grounds, changing of the guard ceremony, nice buildings... ticks all the boxes.

My 3rd time visiting this famous palace. I never get tired of coming here as there are so many areas to see and explore. Be there early as by late morning, hoards of tour buses arrived and it really didn't help that the tourists who arrived in bus crowds were all talking or shouting at their loudest. If with friends, can arrange a picnic and enjoy a splendid time exploring the palace. It is especially beautiful during the spring or autumm season. totally recommended.

This is easily accessible and full of culture. During the changing of the guards and on special days it can be crowded, but at other times it is peaceful.(I visited around 2012, but the questionnaire doesn't allow for dates from that long ago.)

I had a good time at Gyeongbokgung, but I had my camera with me and was having fun shooting flowers and birds and walking through the museums. The changing of the guards was a fun experience too, and there were some groups of younger folks playing some old traditional music as well. But I don't know that it would hold the attention of the young un's very long. the monument itself is a real short visit and the rest is walking around the grounds, so I think it just needs to be your cup of tea. It's in a good area to branch out and do other things too. Don't miss the little statues on all the corners and pedestals around the palace, I found them particularly intricate and interesting.
I loved visiting here. It's directly off the Myeongdong/Dongdaemun subway--very easy to get to. It's also very cheap to visit. I had a great time walking around the temples here.

review_title: Wait for the Changing of Guards
review_body: I went alone exploring Gyeongbokgung Palace because I want to see the changing of the guards. So I went around lunchtime and waited an hour. There's not much to see unlike the other bigger palaces so I sat and read for a while. The place is rather peaceful and there was less tour groups.

It's cold in the courtyard as the winter wind just sweeps across the open from the mountains. Put on extra during winter time and go with a guide or something because it can get really, really boring looking at the same buildings again and again.

Doesn't look really old, but the place ground are huge, went there last week , I didn't rent an audio guide because I didn't think I need it. But when I heard a tour guide explaining the history of the palace it immediately caught my attention! So rent an audio guide if you really like history!

I liked how well arranged this museums decorated. It has a very detail memorabilia about Korean culture. Despite its small building of museum (due to the main attraction is the Palace), you will still be amused. Inside the Palace, you can take a picture (for free) with girls wearing national costumes of South Korea. The toilets need some upgrade and somehow I do amazed to see a woman house cleaning staff simply enter male toilet and Korean male seemed not to be disturbed by that (ithough i felt a bit awkward). My tour guide said this Palace better visited during fall

review_title: Go with a guide (don t DiY) !!
review_body: If you a DiY, the palace is within walking distance from Insadong across the boulevard. The palace ground is humongus and you will need good pair of walking shoes. Though less comparable with the great palaces of Beijing, Tokyo and Osaka, nevertheless they have much to offer in terms of the nation's history.Toilets are not abound so make you attend to your needs before wandering around. I love the ornate roofs and the well preserve timber frames but again will not be drawn into comparison with the Forbidden City of Beijing.The other dampener you will face is this place seems to be a must visit for every tourist to Seoul. The result is this could get overcrowding including the q for the women's toilets. I did not see the changing of the guards as we were on a free transit tour but that would be somewhat colourful as with when they are filming costume/period Korean dramas.

review_title: Mostly newly rebuild; does not feel old.
review_body: The palace grounds are huge, but after a while, all the buildings start looking the same. This is not like European palace with lavish decorations. Korean palaces seemed to have been very austere in the same-same sort of way. Or so it seemed after visiting Gyeongbokgung Palace. Plus, most of it has been rebuild not long ago, so it doesn't exactly look ancient.

This place offers the window of the rich culture of this magnificent country or should I say city. Well preserved historical palaces and noticeably clean environment makes this place a must to visit. The place is located inside the city itself so there will be no problem in getting to this place. There's a large parking space for tourist bus and private cars

review_title: History rebuilt in the middle of a metropolis
review_body: Visiting Gyeongbukgung Palace is a great way to start off a trip to Seoul. Conveniently located near a train stop or bus stop, you can step through one of the gates from the modern world into the past. With the admission fee being very reasonable (₩3,000) for an adult, you can explore on your own or take advantage of a free guided tour. I recommend taking the tour which lasted about about hour to get more of the history of the palace then take another hour or two to explore and watch the activities of the Palace guards. Additionally, if you want to make a day of it, the National Folk Museum and Palace Museum are next to the Palace and a free attractions to round out your visit.
Nice Palace right in the middle of Seoul. Looks and feels just like a scaled down forbidden city. Take a tour it will help to understand the place better.

I was determined to go to Gyeongbokgung palace (it is closed on Tuesdays). It was a perfect centerpiece for Seoul. I was looking forward to the changing of guards ceremony but was cancelled due to the frosty grounds (it snowed two nights ago). I was a bit disappointed but managed to see the palace complex. I was very careful not to tread on the slippery grounds (partly also I had sneakers that don't grip well with ice). I suggest not going to the palaces at winter time as activities are cancelled. Facing the palace was the modern Seoul. It was a perfect mix of the ancient and the modern Korea which has shaped the country. I ventured the palace by myself and they offer free tour guides on fixed times (usually in the afternoon). The information center which is on the gate going to the main palace was very helpful and I was thankful that. (The information center has staff that speak Korean, Chinese, Japanese, and English).
Other than the palace itself I think the other attraction is the changing guard ceremony. I just coudlnt get enough of it.

It was a very huge place and beautiful too. We were lucky to arrive a few minutes before the Changing of the Guard Ceremony. Unfortunately, due to time constraint, we were not able to explore the place. Make sure to spend at least 2 hours exploring the palace grounds and visiting the National Folk Museum.

The place is huge, but of course not China's Forbidden City's huge. This is the place where you'll have a glimpse of what the Emperors of Korea used to lived. Great place for photographs.You'll find people dressed in the traditional korean outfits outside of the maingate. Easily accessible via Subway.

review_title: A very grand Palace with a beautiful Pavilion and grounds.
review_body: I visited this Palace in late November 2014 after a day exploring Seoul at the end of a Korean business trip... Entrance fee is very cheap at KWon 3,000 (about GB£1.80) and there is plenty to see.The imposing Southern Gate ('Gwanghwamun') is a major Seoul landmark and over the years has been destroyed and rebuilt several times. The current gate was unveiled in 2010 after a 4 year reconstruction project!! Once through the gate you enter the Front Courtyard where you purchase your Palace entry tickets and there is often some form of traditional music and dance taking place.From the Front Courtyard you climb some steps and enter into the Palace complex where you see the huge two-tiered former throne room 'Geunjeongjeon Hall'... Look for the beautiful folding screen behind the wooden Joseon throne. From here, going North, you will see the 'Gangnyeongjeon Hall' which dates back to 1395 (reconstructed in 1995) which used to be the bed chamber of Joseon Kings.For me though the best part of my visit was the beautiful 'Gyeonghoeru', a Pavilion built in 1412 by King Taejong as a place to host banquets and State meetings. Set in the middle of a man-made lake it was a vision of tranquillity when I was there bathed in golden Autumn late afternoon sunlight. Take a walk around the lake and head north to the top of the Palace complex where you will find another lake with a very picturesque (and photogenic, see my images) two-storied octagonal structure called the 'Parujeong' which was built in 1888 and used as a library by King Gojong.All in all this is a Palace well worth a visit but it can get very busy... I would recommend going in the later part of the afternoon (I arrived at 15:30) when the crowds are a bit less and when the late afternoon light brings out the best of this special Seoul attraction.
10am is the time you must be there for the main event of changing of the guards, they do it every hour but 10am has the most number of guards who participates.

A historical place to visit while in Seoul. It is commonly packed with tourists, the area with all nice painted buildings. We strolled around the place roughly for an hour where we had many snap shots of the palace, of the trees and of the pond. Walking around the place might be exhausting but compensating with worthwhile experience. We were fortunate to witness the guard changing ceremony and their parade with all their traditional and colorful costumes and had some photo shots with the guards later. It was a wonderful cultural experience to be at Gyeongbokgung Palace.

review_title: Nothing special compared to the Forbidden City.
review_body: This palace doesn't have the grandeur of palaces like the Forbidden City or the intricacies of temples like Angkor Wat. It is very cheap to visit it. But it's only worth visiting if you have nothing better to do. The temples here aren't as interesting as the ones in Japan or China.
go with a volunteer tour guide. you will learn a bit of korean history esp on the joeson dynasty. It takes about 2 hours and the tour ends at the Blue House .

The place to be if you are a tourist and looking for a palace to view. Nicely painted buildings, details, and such. Packed with people. Lots of people. This was the only place that I encountered in Korea where the staff were actually not as polite as usual - don't know why. Must be all the foreigners.The tops of all the buildings were wrapped in wire mesh to keep the pigeons off, and the grounds have a drainage issue with lots of water on the walkways making in wet and slippery (ice !). Picturesque from a distance - try the "other" palace just 500 meters up the road if you are looking for pictures - Deoksugung Palace - it has a nicer feel to it and is a lot less busy.
My first snow experience is here. Fascinated to see all the snow beside the palace. Amazing view. It makes me love Korea more.
near the center of seoul. very accesible when you are inside you will feel like you are back to the old korea with the changing of guards and parade

This is such a pretty place to visit while in Seoul! Do spend the time to walk around the area, snap some photos and enjoy the lovely stroll! I was lucky to be there while they had the guard changing ceremony, try to catch that if you can :) There is a small fee (about KRW 3,000) to enter.

I fancy history and this palace made me fantasize of living during the Joseon Dynasty. I am a fan of the korean TV series "jewel in the palace" and this place was the actual scene location of the said series. unfortunately, the royal kitchen is under restoration during my visit few days ago and this fix is expected to be done by 2016. i suggest if you visit during autumn or spring. it was winter during my visit here and most of the trees and grass are dried/brown. Though the buildings are so colorful, and the changing of guards ceremony is entertaining.I suggest that you include Bukchon Hanok Village and Changdeokgung Palace tour on the day for this trip since these attraction sites are just located near to each other, esp. if you enjoy walking :)For tour guide map, visit: http://www.royalpalace.go.kr/html/eng/guide/guide02.jsp?dep1=1&dep2=2For info about this attraction: http://www.royalpalace.go.kr/html/eng/main/main.jspHow to get here?- take the subway and alight at "gyeongbokgung stn" (line 3, orange line)- If you want to include a visit in gwanghwamun square, alight at "gwanhwamun stn" (line 5, purple line), enjoy the park while walking towards the palace.- or you may avail of the bus tour packages. For more info, visit: http://english.visitkorea.or.kr/enu/SI/SI_EN_3_1_1_1.jsp?cid=264337Changing of guards ceremony: 10 a.m. - 3 p.m. (3 times per day, 10 a.m., 1 p.m., 3 p.m.); 11 a.m, 2 p.m., 4 p.m. : only the guard exiting ceremony (for more info, visit: http://www.visitseoul.net/en/article/article.do?_method=view&m=0003001006003&p=en&art_id=52624&lang=en)

This place is one of the largest and well known places in Korea. It is interesting to see all the different building and I also saw the changing of the guard. This ceremony is a must see when you go to the palace. I believe it happens around 10 am. You can easily access the Palace off the Seoul subway.

Even though most of the place has been rebuilt- it is still a wonderful cultural experience. Try to come before 3pm and at specific times in the courtyard where you buy tickets you can try on the traditional guard costumes. It is a lot of fun. Plus they have tours in a variety of different languages so make sure to come early if you would like to go on one.

The ceremony starts at 1100 , 1400 , 1530 hrs.After the ceremony, you can take pictures with the guards.There is admission fees into the palace. hence we did not purchase the ticket.We just watched the ceremony which takes about 20 min.

review_title: Historical Place in the Heart of the City
review_body: A beautiful history to listen to. Better take pictures first. Then I recommend to attend the guided tours which are available in different languages at a scheduled time. A ground exhibition is also performed by the palace guards. And after that, visitors can take pictures wearing the guard uniforms. By the way, the entrance fee is only charged when you go into the palace. But for the grounds outside it (but still part of the whole compound) where the exhibition takes place, it is free for all.

Make sure you get there by 11am and get a good spot to take pictures of the change of guards. It is a beautiful palace and it looked amazing in winter. The lakes were frozen and the sky was blue....gorgeous!

A large open plan area with a number of interesting buildings that give you the feeling of the architecture. Watch the colourful changing of the guard ceremony and then take in the museum. Here you will get an insight into the social history of the country. Finally, if the folk dancers and drummers are on, this is a must see session in the auditorium. It's really an excellent show. Be prepared to spend a half day there. You won't regret it.

Palace very well upkeep and when compared to China palacce,this is far from it..disvovered that most items are written in Han languages. .so perhaps back then korea had copy from China . winter is ice every where n lakes are frozen..palacces are fantasy n n ever get sick if visiting palacce.

review_title: Don't miss the changing of guards..
review_body: Huge area.. plan on spending at least 2 hours here, if you plan to cover the National Palace Museum and the Folk Museum. Don't miss the changing of guards ceremony.
I suspect even nicer in less cold seasons! We got lucky and saw the guards marching outside the palace entrance. Inexpensive to visit quite a bit to see.

The Gyeongbokgung Palace is a must see in Seoul. You can learn a lot about the history and culture of South Korea. The architecture and artwork are superb! It is also a lot of fun to see the guards in front of the palace. It's a very photogenic place with the mountains as a backdrop.

review_title: Reasonable Price and Nice Piece of Korean History
review_body: I have been to this Palace twice now, and have still not seen every bit of it. There are many really nice things up towards the front that give you a really nice view of the history of their old kings. But, after that, these palace grounds are large and spread out, so lots to see. Very reasonable price, I think around US $7. It is really well maintaned, and I recommend an optional guided tour, no additional cost, and available in English. The changing of the guard outside the grounds is pretty interesting as well, you can do that without entering the palace.

This is an amazing cultural treasure, and definitely requires a couple of hours of time investment to properly do it justice. Make sure you pay for the entrance to go in (it's ridiculously cheap--maybe $5?) and try to watch the changing of the guard. The colors of the costumes, along with the music is truly a magnificent experience.

5 visits to Seoul, I came here thrice! I specially visit the place again as my previous trip I came in early autumn and mid autumn. Very much wanted a view of the palace in winter! It's lovely, the only thing is it will be more beautiful if it snowed. Simply loved this attraction so much! A great way to spend a morning in Seoul...I'll be back here again in the other seasons.

review_title: a historical sight in the middle of a modern city
review_body: This place is huge, it’s impossible and pretty unfair to just squeeze an hour trip to this place. There are just so many things that left my curious soul wonders, how it was like hundreds years ago when the palace was first built, with its interesting and magnificent architecture – each with its functions and purposes. The palace then went through tests of time from various wars and attacks and some of what remains had been re-built and preserved impressively.The buildings after a while would felt the same and boring. So we escaped to the garden with wonderful colours of autumn, and landscape of the Bugak mountain on the background. The view was so beautiful, making a popular spot for wedding photoshoots and photography outings. I’ve been to the palace twice – each to different sides of the compound. During both times it felt like going back through time, and getting lost in the history of Korea.

review_title: Great for a half day visit
review_body: Had our reservations when deciding whether to visit Gyengbokgung or not. Having visited the Forbidden City and having heard this was the Korean equivalent, we thought we would end up seeing pretty much the same thing. Given we did not enjoy or like the Forbidden City all that much, that was worrisome.Luckily, despite similar styles (due to Korean history) we thoroughly enjoyed the visit to the palace. It is extremely accessible and it does not feel like you are seeing the same building or pavilion over and over again. It also did not feel particularly crowded at all and it was very easy to navigate. The grounds of the palace were also extremely nice to stroll in and it was definitely an added bonus to have the National Folk Museum adjoining to the palace. Even extra added bonus, the entrance/exit closest to the National Folk Museum is a stone throw away from the Bukchon area.Definitely recommended and would suggest to take half a day to visit the palace itself, the grounds and the National Folk Museum.

review_title: A truly beautiful place to visit
review_body: I visited this palace in the fall and was able to check out some really nice Korean history. The structures are amazing and well kept. And there was even a musical performance with traditional dancing. Located close to Insadong and other museums, it's a must visit for a traveler in South Korea.

Gyeongbokgung Palace is an awesome palace. In terms of scale, it is smaller than the Forbidden City in Beijing but equals it in splendour. One can't help but feel the rich history behind it and the traditions and ceremonies that it once held. Although it is Korean, there is a Chinese influence in the architecture and layout.While we were there, we were fortunate enough to catch the Changing of the Guard ceremony at 1pm. This takes place a few times a day. The palace is one of the top-rated places we visited in Seoul.

Also liked this palace. It was a couple of subway stops from Bukchon. A guard showed me where they were putting on a play. Enjoyed the buildings and the guards dressed up in traditional clothes. There in 4/13

review_title: Great place that you can know Korea history
review_body: If you want to know the history of this country, you must come here.

Impressive complex of beautiful buildings. Very busy with lots of tourists and Koreans (or especially because of?) on Christmas Day. Be sure and wait/plan for a tour in English as the tour guides are impressively informed and give you all kinds of history/cultural lessons that are unforgettable.

this palace is one of the palaces worth visiting...you can see the fine architecture in each of the pillars, colors of the palace..if you can catch the guided tour so much better to have a deeper understanding of the Palace's history...
The place I most wanted to visit in Seoul. Why Buckingham palace when you have this in Asia? I'd vote Gyeongbokgung any day. Don't miss the change of guard!

review_title: If you haven’t seen this palace, you haven’t been to Seoul
review_body: This palace is an absolute must see in Seoul, they have a guard change ceremony every day at 1pm except Tuesdays, really impressive. The museum is close by and free of charge, good café over there for a short break and coffee.

review_title: A lot smaller than China's but still interesting
review_body: The layout is very similar to China's palaces as it is based on China's principles. However it has it's own charateristics especially in the backhouse. Charming.

This is th only palace we've visited in Seoul. Overall, it was okay, nothing spectacular but full of history. I especially enjoyed the museum part and the opening march in the morning coz it showed a brief preview of what is was like during the early days.

review_title: If you are into palace, this is one with a long history.
review_body: It was relatively easy to find the palace by metro. We arrived at 2 pm just in time to watch the changing of the sentries at the gate. The entrance fee is considerably cheap. However, you can only look at the palace from the outside and are not allowed to enter the buildings. This was a disappointment as it is better to walk through the buildings. Because we didn't follow a tour, we were unable to understand the culture or history except by reading the description on the plaques or by looking at the Chinese characters on top of each building. It is a relatively big place with a lovely lake that was frozen when we were there. Before we left, we also saw the changing of the guards at 3pm. It was an interesting visit.

This palace is just an empty palace. To know more about the palace, please get a tour. Otherwise, you can buy the palace brochure for 500 won. Audio guides are available as well.Nothing much to see except for the huge area use to construct the palace, many are reconstructed back as it was damaged and of cause the guard changing ceremony for the first timers.Nevertheless, an eye opener for first timers.I went there during December, as the place is covered with mud and melted snow, it gets quite dirty for your shoes as well as for your legs (jeans). Please also take note that as the roof are constructed like in the olden days, they have a down slope roof, therefore melted snow (ice) will slide and drop down, please be careful when you are touring the palace especially if you have kids.

review_title: Piece of history, culture and romance.
review_body: What you see in the Korean dramas are as perfect as this palace. Amazing architecture and landscape. You'll feel like a royalty as you traverse the surroundings. Try finding the secret garden too. Hold her hand and have a nice walk.

Much like the certain areas of the Forbidden City in Beijing, these are sets of buildings once used by emperors/royalty but on a regular day, they are mostly empty halls/rooms. Preserved well, though.

wear comfortable shoes and maybe an umbrella if you are there during the summer. I have been here twice, on a fall and just this summer. I would say best time to see this place is during the summer when all the leaves are colorful. The area is situated in the middle of the city but it is pretty magical when you are inside. It's like you are transported to a different era. The place is very well kept. Don't forget to bring your camera!

review_title: The grandfather of all the Palaces
review_body: Even that this place is not recognized by UNESCO we found it quite impressive. There are plenty of things to see inside, to relax, think, learn... Definitely is the masterpiece of the Palaces in Seoul. My mouth waters when I think about this place again... The into drawback are the packs of tourist and even we visit with a freezing cold temperatures.

Again the palace had been mutilated by Japanese occupying forces. Infact the main frame of the palace was dismantled and a Japanese administration building was built right in the middle of the palace grounds. This building had just very recently been removed. Then they attempted to re create the original palace. The wood carvings on the ceilings are all gone, substituted with paper walls or just painted a plain green, To see what it had looked like, refer to the Forbidden City. The roofs are also recreated with cement instead of wood carvings and porcelain tiles and porcelain figurines. Very sad really. The Japanese occupying forces really even removed the historical past of Korea.

Certainly not the best palace we have ever gone to, the Forbidden City in Beijing is way better, but this palace is one of the best two that Seoul could offer. Granted, the architecture of the place was nice and grand. However, there were a lack of signs and enough explanations throughout the palace to explain what was in front of us. Try to go early to avoid the large amount of visitors.
This palace was featured in so many K-dramas (e.g. The Moon That Embraces The Sun)! Very pretty palace indeed and there is a lake somewhere in the palace!

First visit to this buildingBut too bad since we were joining a tour package and we dont have enough time to explore the whole area.But I love the detail of the building.. with red and green colour domination.I should go again one day.
It's not an old building, you can take some time to visit, but no need to stay for hours.

review_title: If you're interested in oriental palace architectures...
review_body: If you're interested in old palace architectures, this is the place for you. The area is not as grand and big as the Forbidden City in Beijing; but still need a good half-day effort to cover the compound. We were there in early Dec 2014. Although the temperature was a bit chilly, there were still many visitors; including a lot of local students. I would image the place must be packed during summer time. The National folk museum of Korea is adjacent to Gyeongbokgung, so you may plan to spend a whole day in the same area to visit both locations. Gyeongbokgund subway (No. 3 line) has a station just outside the palace. Suggest to start the visit early in the day.A near-by restaurant called Tosokchon that serves ginseng chicken soup is worth the visit for a meal as well; especially in winter. The hot soups will surely warm up your body in no time.
Beautiful architecture, managed to view the Guards' performance which was fun for the kids to do. Great photo opportunity. Lots of little shops and restaurants are located nearby too.

nice palace, can see some faint tint of chinese culture, been destroyed before however the stage pavillion is of original , so is the three chimneys located in the queen's garden. went during winter so it's of a calm serene feel but still fabulously grand.
full of tourist.. but like people say, you don't go to Seoul if you not go to this palace :)the palace is nice, even its crowded with tourist..Nice experience

This review is only somewhat helpful to those reading. I watched the changing of the guard, which was neat, and went inside the museum next door, but did not go inside the Palace (I felt it was a bit over priced and I was pressed for time). The changing of the guard is a popular attraction, so I figured it was worth mentioning here - it was an ok experience. They change approximately every 20 minutes if I recall correctly.

review_title: A palace that was burn down twice and rebuild twice, probably nothing is original.
review_body: We visited this palace during winter so it was really cold to walk around the palace. Since the palace was burn down by Japanese and during the Korean Civil war, all the structures were rebuild. Some of the parts were not rebuild because no one know what the original structure looks like. There were exchanging guards ceremony everyday which was a highlight for visiting the palace. Other then that, go to China visiting the Chinese Palace seem more educational.
It was a beautiful sight, snow falling and on the ground. Very busy at 10am and 3pm but inbetween a lot quieter. See Korean History.

The compound area is huge but the palace itself is empty. Nothing. Few pieces of furniture. Artwork? It's not even 100 years old. I was told 90% of the buildings was demolished during Japanese occupation during 1911, it so frustrating. Nevertheless, I was awed with the Change of Guard Ceremony. I think people does not care much about history as long as they can brag about it and take many as many pics around this palace. Compared to many palaces & castles I've been, this doesn't left much impression on me.

review_title: Nice restoration; fun changing of the guards
review_body: This has to be seen at least once to understand the grandeur of the palace and the surrounding buildings and grounds. If you see only one palace in Seoul, this may be the best. Our timing was good and we were able to see a fun reenactment of an ancient changing of the guard. The National Palace Museum and the National Folk Museum are both in the same complex (and these two museums are free; the palace itself has a modest entry fee).

review_title: Nice place to go in winter
review_body: Nice big place to learn about Korea's history. Do see the changing of guards ceremony and do consider the free guided tour provided.

review_title: Very different from a Western style palace
review_body: To me, if you've seen one Korean palace you've seen them all, so if you're going to see just one, make it Gyeongbokgung. Check before you go so that you can get a tour. There are only three English language tours a day. The palace is a huge maze of buildings and it's easy to get disoriented if you're going through it on your own. Also, you have to go to the souvenir shop to buy the guide booklet, but it's only 500 won.

We visited this beautiful palace last week (13/Dec) and it was absolutely beautiful.As it was just starting to get very cold, we happen to see the lake freezing up.No words can describe the beauty of this place so make it a place to visit if you are in Seoul.The price of entry is also very very cheap.. kids are free as well... and the palace is located next to its own subway station..So there is no reason to not visit this wonderful and beautiful palace...

This is a great-looking palace, spread over a huge area.The palace is a walking distance from the nearby Gyeongbokgung Metro station.The first courtyard (where the ticket counters are located) is where a lovely parade takes place on various intervals.The parade includes drummers, soldiers in traditional costumes, bag pipes and numerous flags.It's really worthwhile to wait for the parade (ask for the schedule at the ticket counter).The entrance ticket is apx. 3US$.Once you enter the palace's ground, through an ornate gate, you can see the main palace.While the palace itself is not accessible, it is possible to look inside.Continue through another lovely gate to the next palace and take a left, to see the stunning Gyeonghoeru pavilion over the small lake. It is absolutely stunning and provides some brilliant photo-ops.There's a small café near the pavilion, to take a short break before going further north, into the park-like area.The north part of the palace complex includes a lovely pond and a beautiful octagonal Chinese-looking pagoda in its middle, which used to be the king's library.Leaving the park, walking to the south will take you through a collection of huge vases.All in all, this is a brilliant palace complex to visit.Give yourself at least 60-90 minutes for exploration.
They maintain all of the artwork in its place beautifully... it was my first time in South Korea, I really miss the friendly people although the couldn't speak really good english.

You must see Gyeongbokgung when you are in Seoul. Admission fee is not much. Personally, I felt that a guide wasn't required; if you do your own basic research you'll still be able to appreciate it. You can easily spend 2-4h just walking around and admiring the palace.

We were there at around 11 in the morning in late autumn. Weather was good but the wind was quite strong.We walked from the Bukchon Hanok Village, where we stayed for a night. Took us about 20 minutes or so. If you are a foreigner travelling on own, best thing is to time your visit with the free guided tours. We thought we would go ahead without the tour and this is something we regretted, given the size of this place and lack of signboards to tell you any historical facts and your exact location as well. We found ourselves lost for an hour, ending up at some garden, smaller palaces and the National Folk Museum and had to go one big round to come out to the entrance.If you are planning to visit more palaces, suggest you take the Combination ticket, which will cover Gyeongbokgung, Chandeukgung, Chanseukgung (if I'm not mistaken) Deoksugung, and Jongmyo shrine which costs KRW10k (I recall it would be cheaper by KRW2k if you bought the tickets separately). Although we were in Seoul throughout the stay and decided we should visit most, we didn't and only managed to visit this, Chandeukgung and Jongmyo shrine so the Combination ticket was not worth it but could come in handy.I would prefer Chandeukgung, which is about 20 minutes walk away as it is much more interesting.

Amazing amount of shops in those 4-5 shopping complexes that open until 4.30am! My favourite shopping complex among all these is Migliore. You need keep shopping and learn about the price before buying because you may find another stall selling the same piece of clothing cheaper. High quality Korean clothes and fashion accessories at great prices

review_title: Not the nicest palace i'd visited
review_body: It's not as luxury and huge if compared to Beijing Zhi Jing Cheng. Overall just walk around and take come pictures.

review_title: The Changing of the Royal Guard
review_body: My main purpose is to watch the royal guards changing ceremony.I love to see guards wearing colorful clothings, with NO smiling face.Ritual are performed every day between 10am,1pm and 3pm in front of Heungnyemun Gate. Be there 30 minutes before ceremony started. You can enjoy photograph just next with guards, in 10 minutes session.

I really enjoyed visiting this palace and learned a lot about Korean history and culture. Try to come early to avoid to many tourists. Korean museum is very close and you can visit for free and reentry to the palace again.

Pros: Beautiful Palace, well-maintained, and has guides during specific timings. Sadly, I missed it. But it was a sight to see.Cons: There are many opened areas, I would suggest to bring along an umbrella or visit the Palace at a less sunny timing. The signboards around the Palace are pretty scarce, would help if there are more signboards to help introduce more to the tourists who aren't following the guides around.

It sits on top of the city's main road, on the skirt of the mountain hill, located wisely and strategically,in the heart of the Korean Nation. It is an oasis in the bustling city of Seoul. Once you are inside it feels as if you are somewhere totally different. It has the King's and Queen's premises and several other building compounds. What's interesting is, they are simply and efficiently designed. When you see this and the other historical buildings in the city and compare them with the modern buildings, the architectures of that time were way ahead of this century. The palaces suggest that those people knew how to built so many complex structures beautifully and aesthetically thousands of years ago, but they lost their memories somewhere along the time. I wish this kind of simplicity, efficiency and some of the aesthetics were used more often in their modern government institutions and establishments as well as residential high rises. There is a free guide tour in English every hour or so, you can join her and enjoy the history and the stories of the palace. Also there is a guards' changing ceremony, it is interesting to watch. Sorry that I can't remember the times. The tree leaves' autumn colors are adding more romanticism to the atmosphere if you visit in late October/beginning of November.

Not much explanation in English. We tried getting audio guides but they were not available. Doesn't feel so special especially if you have been to similar but bigger places in Asia like the forbidden city.

review_title: I believe it will look much better in spring
review_body: When we arrived there, it was just about time of changing the officer of the palace... so watching it feels like we went to joseon dinasty... Love it... But seeing all the trees with no leaves because of the season, so I'm thinking, that this palace will look alot more beautiful in spring or autum.
