I have visited here twice. It is much better in summer than in winter since in the winter, it is too cold to linger and take in the atmosphere and the historic plaques. It is rather extensive with a lot to see. You can spend a whole day there since on the grounds are the National Folk Museum and the National Palace Museum. It is also quite close to the Blue House, the residence of the President of South Korea.Down the road in front of the main entrance is the American Embassy and a long promenade where protesters gather.

Nice if you are into history and ancient architecture.Not too nice if walking around with kids due to uneven flooring slabs, plenty of steps.Good place for photography and watching the guards changing ceremony.Tosokchon is a hop and skip away though.

The palace is really easy to get to. You could take the subway line, and there is a stop directly next to the palace. I would recommend to come early as there are many tourist groups coming to this location at the later hours.Also, make sure to see the changing of the guards.

the palace is nothing to rave about, like most historical monuments in Korea, it was rebuilt recently, but the guides , who speak english, are so inventive and polite that they make the visit very pleasant

A vast collection of ancient Korean buildings, representing the culture of royalty in former days, with countless examples of historical architecture. Although surrounded by a very active city, once you step inside you feel transported to the way life was several hundred years ago. Much history can be learned, and at least a half day is needed to do justice to this ancient palace.
Sort of reminded me of the Forbidden City in Beijing on a smaller scale. Looks very vibrant beautiful. I understand that much of it burned at one point & had to be restored. They did a great job!

Great slice of history. Highly recommend to appreciate the extent of Korean documented history. And very well kept--the Koreans are obviously proud of this. The changing of the guard ceremony was fun, too.

review_title: A trip into ancient Korean legacy
review_body: Plan ur trip time carefully. Free english guided tour available at certain time(cant recall) pretty much strolling in the castle ground. The guards exchange ceremony is held in front of the castle gate (also at certain time of the day).

We visited this place though it was snowing. We went to the virtual images on the 2nd floor and had a virtual inter action with the present president of Korea. We shook hands and took pictures that were e mailed to us. Nice concept!

Like - Grandness, the authenticity of the place, the awesome ceremonial spectacle,free costumes (of ancient guards), coffee shop inside the palace square, iconic red pillars, and great architecture. For me, you've never really seen it, unless you've been here. Dislikes - too many tourists at times! Good thing, the place is huge so you could veer away as far as possible! The whole place closes by 5-6pm though. Not a perfect spot for sunsets, twilight, and all... Not too many signposts to indicate what you're looking at (guess I need to find a tour guide for this part, LOL).

Palace tour is one of the tour recommended in seoul as there is few of them , I have visit all I can say that they are all look same for me same style and design not much different , you can access them all by subway if you have free tour and if you use city tour then this palace is one of bus stop plan to visit at midday as frequently at midday they have some activity to watch there from that palace u can wake to the city center seoul station hope you enjoy the trip and this place there is entrance fees

We see the changing of the guards from the inside and had a tour here, we joined the english tour and the tour guide is good. Im a fan of some koreanovelas and i was able to learn the simple detail and their meaning.
The visit there was amazing, and in the winter, it makes for great snow angel-making grounds. And oh! It overlooks the Blue House (the Korean equivalent of the White House)
Very big place... in here like in a film Korean Dynasty.. There is a museum library inside this place, you need to visit it ...

review_title: A must go when in Seoul
review_body: This is a must if you are in Seoul as there are so much to see and do around the areaRecommend that you can start the morning walking around the strip just in front of the palace where there is a museum of sort underground.Then have boiled ginseng chicken lunch at a nearby restaurant (there is a famous one nearby) before heading to the Palace. At the Palace ground, you can witness the changing of guards, and sometimes traditional dance performance, and also a visit to the museum inside.Spend the late afternoon walking along the street at the right of the palace (when you are facing the main entrance) which are lined with boutique shops and restaurants. You can also walk up the hill and look at the traditional houses.

Worth the visit as the place was really grand and it was right on the heart of the city. Get a good idea of how the ancient palace was and how the royals lived. Nice buildings and a nice park right at the back. Too bad most buildings were only rebuilt in the 1990s.

Gyeongbokgung PalaceBuilt in 1394 as the main palace of the Joseon Dynasty(1392-1910)by its founder King Taejo, it is the most comprehensive and grandest of the five palace of the period. Gyeongbokgung, the oldest palace of the Joseon Dynasty, is located at the northern end of Seojong-ro Street. On its grounds stands the National Folk Museum of Korea, where visitors can brower the unique cultural and historical traits of Korea and the lifestyle of bygone days.Cheongwadae (The Blue House)This is the presidential residence of the Republic of Korea. Tours of Cheongwadae have been conducted since 1998.National Folk Museum of Korea.As the only national museum on folklore, it displays about 4,000 items on Korea’s traditional way of life. There are three permanent exhibition halls, two special exhibition halls, a shop and a reference room.

Lovely grounds and charming with autumnal colours, the largest pond is a highlight. The buildings are beautiful to look at.Attempted an English tour but this was a challenge to understand (we are English) so we wandered at our own leisure which was great.The Folk museum is a bizarre addition but worth a look around, particularly the Jean exhibition which will amuse Westerners with it's stylised curation.

review_title: nice walk at a beautiful place
review_body: We did not really walk through all details but we admired the setting and space of the complex, the colors of Korea, the culture... Sit there just for the nature, or a walk at the garden and its nearby streets would be nice enough to spend the day.

Well worth a visit and hopefully you will be as lucky as us to get a student guide that will show you around and be informative and all they want in return is to practice their english. These guides were waiting at the exit from the Metro Subway station.
This palace has an extensive garden, beautiful ponds and in November, the leaves in the park were turning yellow, red and gold. A nice quiet place to visit even with lots of people.

Prepare to spend hours in this palace as you proceed from one section to another. You will get to see many different ranks of sections that you saw from K drama. Pretty interesting with various spot to explore. This palace is huge so be prepare to have a little picnic in between your exploration by the pond to take a break to enjoy the scenery.
It's gigantic. It is closed on Tuesday- so take note. Oddly, there were quite a few places closed on Tuesdays.

It seems as though the tourist guides and hotel concierge have a limited list of suggested destinations in Seoul. However, Gyeongbokgung Palace is rightfully found on everyone's list. The historical lessons are very important and you will learn a great deal by visiting this site. But if relaxing in a beautiful park is what you really want to do, this is a great place for that as well. There is also a very nice folk museum. Try to plan your visit around the changing of the guards. This is really special experience.

review_title: A fantastic medieval palace right in the middle of a modern city
review_body: Built in 1395, this royal palace of the Joseon Dynasty is also known as Gyeongbok Palace. This is a fantastic palace situated right at the heart of modern Seoul downtown. A must-see for a visitor in Seoul, this palace showcases a medieval ritual of flag/march ceremony by modern soldiers trying to recreate the magic of ancient Korean empire.A guide is recommended for exploring other various parts of the palace including interesting anecdotes about first writing of Korea, or how medieval Koreans used to keep their palace rooms heated without air-conditioning/gas heating technology.

review_title: Worth the trip to visit the palace - 2 Nov
review_body: We reached the Palace around 11plus on a sunny day. It's the perfect timing to take nice shots under the hot sun despite there is cold wind. We tour around the whole palace & wanted to visit the Rose Garden but it was too tiring after walking for so long inside the palace itself.Each building structure is still in good condition and the beautiful scenary is unforgettable. Do have a heavy breakfast before you visit the palace in case you ended walking for hours without knowing it.We were so lucky to see the guard parade around 3pm and its magnificent before we decide to come out from the palace.

review_title: My first and favorite palace so far
review_body: I was only in Seoul for 3 days but this was the first palace I went to and my favorite out of all the ones I visited. It has the museum in the back which was free and fantastic.
Interesting and a good walk. Also many interesting things to see in the vicinity. I would recommend it.

The day I went was cold and rainy, but we still walked the palace grounds. We didn't have a tour guide, so we didn't have the history behind what we were looking at. I would recommend getting a tour guide if you do go.

The palace is a fantastic place. I understand it was rebuild after the Japanese destroyed the original but it is hard to tell. It looks fairy-tale like in its setting (esp. if you look towards the mountains). In the middle of a busy city, an oasis of tranquility. There are daily performances too.You have to do a lot of walking.

I had a great time walking around Gyeongbokgung. It is a massive ground with awesome architecture, courtyards and gardens which make for attractive photo opportunities. The site provides a quick glance into the history of the palace. I had a very peaceful time exploring the entire place and if you are willing, you can leave the hustle and bustle of larger groups by venturing deep into the gardens.

review_title: make me back in time to ancient korea
review_body: Because the Korean Dram Jewel In The Palace, i went to korea and my tour guide let us visit this palaceThis palace has huge area and the scent made me feel i was back to ancient Korea Dont forget to take a lot of picture there to prove u are already in one of beautifull palace at Joseon DinastyU can see at severall time an ancient soldier changes the duty like at Buckingham palace ( i forgot what time)
Great place to take photos. Big enough area so that you can get away from the tourist groups. We went in autumn and the leaves were nice reds and yellows.

review_title: Perfect for History and Architecture Buffs
review_body: The lieu is too picturesque during autumn, the weather is fine, but it's too crowded. It is best to save a half day of your travel itinerary in touring around. If you want to hear and learn more about the Joseon Dynasty and anything related to the Gyeongbokgung Palace, it is recommended that one should be in the area at around 11 AM. There are women in hanbok who will tour you around and explain details of the palace which the internet won't.

review_title: Leisurely stroll in well kept ground
review_body: Little of the original old palace remains, and the ground houses mostly reconstructed buildings and museums, but it's pleasant for a few hours' of walk and exploration nonetheless. Don't expect anything remotely approaching the grandeur of Beijing's Forbidden City, but what it has is well kept and presented.Despite the presence of numerous tour groups, the area is big enough that finding a quiet, scenic spot all to yourself is easy, all just a stone's throw from the bustle of city centre. The cultural park area to the east of site is free of charge and many Seoulites happily spend leisurely time there.

Beautiful place. Nice place to take pictures.went in winter(mid november). One of the palace building is closed to public during winter- open from april to sept(i hope my memory is not failing on me)Must go for the guided tour(available in English, Mandarin, Japanese, Korean). Last about 1 hour, which bring you through the palace and tell you the history of Korean royal family and the korean palace architecture. The one of the interesting attractions was the guards that stood outside the palace( something like the guards in Windsor castle(london)), but with colorful uniforms and more guards and korean musical and flags.. they did the marching (went at ~130pm so get to observe the change of guard ceremony ~2pm)Not necessary to buy the palace map if you go for the guided tour. the palace map cost 5000 won.

review_title: Changing of the Royal Guards during the Joseon Dynasty
review_body: This is a reenactment of the changing of the Royal Guards during the Joseon Dynasty. The ceremony itself can be seen from outside the palace on the street. To tour the palace, tickets are required. (I also enjoyed touring the palace.) The traditional costumes and ceremonial aspects of the ceremony were beautiful. I was told that research was done to make it historically accurate. The whole ceremony takes only about 15-20 minutes. For something that is fun to see and no cost, I would certainly recommend it for visitors to Seoul, South Korea!
If you do anything in Seoul, this is it. You can spend hours at Gyeongbok, and you can blow out your camera in the process. Recommend you take it slowly and explore all the nooks and crannies.

Huge courtyards! Beautiful place. You have to come here when it's sunny though.. Nice place to take pictures, i even saw a couple shooting there prewed pics here. The most interesting attractions was the guards that stood still like the guards in england, but with more colorful uniforms and hats..

review_title: Nice, but don't expect something extraordinary
review_body: The main and biggest royal palace in Seoul.It's nice, but don't expect anything spectacular. After a while you understand it's a series of similar looking courtyards and traditional palace buildings, that at least for the average tourist look similar (only differ in sizes). It's not a palace where you visit the interior of the rooms.The highlights there (for me) where:The changing of guard ceremony - the main ceremony is nice to watch once. The guards are dressed in different colors, carry different flags and weapons. They shout orders, the drum beats. But you quickly get the idea, and the ceremony is a bit long...And also there is a nice pond inside (you need to pass through several courtyards), near a building, and a picturesque view in the background. A good place to take pictures.About wheelchair accessibility: there are ramps there to enter from one courtyard to another. In some places they have stone paths at the perimeter of the yards. But I would advise to have assistance, as the middle of the yard is uneven and has stones or gravel. You can't climb to the palace buildings (steps). The stone path at the perimeter sometimes is occupied by people, sometimes you need to climb a step or the passage is narrow. So it's not easy there unless you have help.

beautiful place. huge place. there's a coffee shop inside. the cashier is pretty. i took pictures but she told me not to take pictures. it would be great to visit there in autumn - for the trees. this place has an entrance fee.
It is amazing that you will find red leaves inside when travel in Autumn.

Beautiful palace. We would have left much earlier if we didn't jump in with the English tour guide. Probably would have given a lower review if not for the guided tour. Without the tour there wouldnt have been much to see.
a palace with beautiful surroundings. we went there in autumn and really enjoyed the colourful trees

A wonderful place to see. I saw some previews of Korean telenovelas but I don't pay much attention to it. Seeing this place, now I appreciate it more. A huge place and lots of history in it. It's worth a visit or 2. Take your time.

At the entrance the change of guard is colorful, and inside is great ; in smaller scale reminding of the forbiden city in Beijing . Going on the left hand-side of the buildings toward the north are gorgeous gardens, even nicer that the secret gardens of the East Palace, then continue clockwise south to the entrance, pass the street, turn left and a few blocks away is Insa-Dong. Seniors entrance is free.
Nice and beautiful especially when we visited because its autumn season. Love the colors and palace. I also enjoyed the watching the changing of Royal guards
Excellent view of ancient history in a city that evolved around it! Grounds are well kept, convenient.

The Gyeongbokgung Palace is one of the key attraction in Seoul, its easily accessible via the seoul subway station "Chungmuro Station" and its just a 10 mins walk via the underpass. As we went there quite late around 4 PM We took the option of buying the 1 palace ticket. And we took the chance to explore the different parts of the astounding palace, unfortunately we didn't get to see the change of guard.As the Palace close around 6pm, if you are considering to explore the other palace as well, its advisable to get there early, as the entire compound of the palace might took abit of your time to explore.
one of the palace you can see in the compound. there is a pond in front where you can see fish. we dont know if we can see inside.. but most of the palace was for outside viewing only

I really love it palace and open something new everytime. You can stay inside, look at palace or wall and see mountain or modern high-rise buildings. It is really lovely, you can take free excursion or go through to see Blue House
Don't miss the chance to visit this lovely palace and walk it's very large grounds. Gives a great perspective of the history in the region.
Change of guard is worth watching.The museum or place inside is small, nothing much to be seen.Ticket for just 1 palace is 3,000Korean Won.
take a good camera much time and enjoy it .....its just soo beautiful .... alone to go around sea the nature and the buildings all those colors
A very nice and easy tour. Please make sure you have an excellent guide who understands the complete history of the palace. Everyday at 10am the changing of the guards ceremony is a visual treat.

Being a korean series fanatic, visiting a palace is a must-place-to-visit for me.The palace groound is really really huge. Visiting in the peak of autumn is an added value to the beauty of the place. There are benches that you can sit upon. I like the one that faces the moat. Make sure that you get to see the changing of guards ceremony (http://english.visitkorea.or.kr/enu/SI/SI_EN_3_2_1.jsp?cid=292853)Directions: Gyeongbokgung Palace Station (Seoul Subway Line 3), Exit 5Fee: 3000 won for adults

Had a very nice time here. The grounds are quite expansive, so put your walking shoes on. The English self guided walking tour was good. They didn't give you a lot of information at each site on the headset, so I would say that if you want more, sign up for a tour.

Yes! A very big one~~ We spend three hours here but still not able to make a round.. Maybe we stop too much. HAHAMy favourite band was here one the same time and day I was there.. But I missed them as the place is too big.. Visit the museum on the outside of the entrance before u left, U can learn lots regarding the palace there.. Two significant in one time.. Yeah! Gwanghwamun and Gyeongbokgung. Save the subway fare.. Plus, u can walk down to the Gwanghwamun Square to visit the King sejong statue and also the Admiral Statue..
Interesting architecture mainly the imposing gatesChangingc of the guards, 3 times a day.The pond is interesting too

review_title: Don't miss the changing of the guards
review_body: Great Palace, but tour is enhanced if take the audio guide. Check out the changing of the guard very interesting. Also Cultural museums on property are very interesting
It is a place you have to visit if you are in Korea. History and Korean tradition It is a place you have to visit if you are in Korea.

Visited this palace with my family on amazing autumn day in October. My wife attended the free guided tour and it was rather comprehensive. Connected to the subway and directions are clear. Worth a visit.

review_title: A must attraction to be visited in Seoul
review_body: Having a trip to Seoul isn't complete if you're not visit Gyeongbokgung Palace. You can see a history of South Korea. Try to explore all the places and you'll find the ancient feeling of South Korea. It's very big complex and you'll find many traditional houses of Korea. They have free guided tour to explore all the places, they provide English, Chinese and Japanese speaking guide. Please pay attention to the schedule, at that time my friend and i missed and we just explored by ourselves and naturally followed the crowd of group. hehehe.. There is a big beautiful pond inside. There are more building inside and some places you need to pay the entrance ticket again.

Come with an open mind and don't expect the palace to blow your mind off. This palace is not the most beautiful, impressive and ornate palace in the world but it has it's own charm. I guess ancient Koreans are not into manicured gardens and jaw dropping architecture. But there were beautiful gardens and the the palace is very well maintained. I had fun exploring the palace grounds and it was nice to find a spot to sit down, and enjoy the cool breeze and just relax for a bit. Visitors get to see a glimpse of how the royal family lived in the past. There's even performance on the changing of guards at the palace gates.And if you have the time, follow the tour. it was very informative and the guide was pretty jovial.

review_title: The largest of the five grand palances in Seoul... a must-see.
review_body: It sounds cliché... but you have not been to Seoul until you visit one of the five grand palaces built by the Joseon Dynasty. Gyeongbokgung Palace is the largest of the five. A must-see.

It was the only palace we visited in our trip and it was really big and gorgeous. We spend nearly half day at this palace and the National Folk Museum just next to the palace. It was the beginning of autumn and the view around the palace is so gorgeous. We followed a free English tour at 11am for an hour and our tour guide gave a very good explanation around the palace. Very informative indeed. Totally worth it and i would highly recommend a visit to the palace if you are visiting Seoul.

review_title: Crowded but the tour guide did a good job!
review_body: Learn a lot on the history of Gyeongbokgung Palace with the palace tour guide giving a good historical background of the palace ground. I already visited this place twice, once during a cold, chilly winter in December 2013 and this year in June. Never gotten sick of it. I am looking forward to the palace kitchen being overhauled!
Changing guards is daebak (Amazing!). I went during winter it was very cold but worth it. I didn't take any guide I suggest to just purchase the map and take your time to explore the huge palace.

The palace and the whole scenario is just beautiful. I visit it during autumn, it was a sunny day, so it was gorgeous to see the yellow and red foliage among the palace constructions. From the palace you can see a beautiful mountain full of colorful trees too. The change of guards is also a interesting thing to see.

Gyeongbokgung Palace is just a few minutes by foot to where we stayed. We booked for a free guided tour starting at 10am-11:30nn. We were 7 in the group including 2 kids. The guide gave us a very insightful overview of Seoul's history and it's architecture. The area is huge as well as the number of tourists. You can actually get inside and watch the changing of guards ceremony at the big open grounds just before the gate where you need to present the tickets. So if your schedule is really tight and just want some photos of the guard changing ceremony with their colorful outfits, just be there by 10am or 1pm, no need to purchase a ticket. Going out we passed by the Folk Museum and used the side exit that leads us to the Bukchon Hanok Village.

I visited many palace in Korea but this one was best one , when I entered the palace found a place which i could wear Korean dress for free and had 5 min time to take pictures with this beautiful dress . There is timetable for wearing dress so you have to wait in line for specific time , just 20 people each time can wear the dress not more . Don't miss cultural army marching in front of entrance too .
It's easy to get to Gyeongbokgung Palace by metro. The palace is big and has lots to see. I suggested not to go in winter cause it's too cold to explore the palace.
Amazing palace. The architecture and artistry are breathtaking. It is well preserved and well kept. Definitely a must see piece of history in Seoul.
This is the biggest palace in Seoul. However, it's overcrowded with tourists and tour groups. Highly recommended to visit during less busy period to soak in the atmosphere.

Beautiful and very well maintained. Continue along King Sejong Ave. and see the King's and also Admiral Yi's impressive monuments - against the background of the mountains surrounding Seoul. Amazing, considering that Seoul is a very large city.

Aside from the mesmerizing grandness and vastness of this place, the free shows (re-enactments) outside the palace gates does all the difference. It's not everyday that you get to be in a grandeur palace with ancient-looking guards performing right in front of you.This place should be visited by everyone who visits South Korea.

This place was well worth the time and walk. It's quite massive and full of history. You will find yourself taking photo after photo. If you have kids that don't like to walk much, make sure you have a stroller, etc. Highly recommend this spot.

When I visited this place in mid of October 2014, the troops parade has been started. I have to run fast to take their pictures. I was so happy to see them, feeling like in Joseon era. The whole building are amazing. I love the architectures of this palace.

ceremonial guards, gorgeous landscaped, well maintained grounds, organized and inexpensive. A lovely way to spend part of your day. Also if you just want to pass through on your way to other locals such as Bukchon and Samcheong. Enjoy

review_title: Seoul's well deserved n°1 tourist spot
review_body: GyeongBokGung is perfectly located, with the packdrop of the BukHanSan mountain on one side, and the modern buildings of JongNo on the other. This makes for stunning pictures and an amazing setting. Also noteworthy is the grand entrance from GwangWhaMun Avenue (with the statues of Admiral Yi Sun-Shin and King Sejong the great), as well as the changing of the guard at the front gate of the palace. The palace itself is very nice, large and extremely well maintained, with a nice natural area (with gardens, lakes) on the North Side. I'm "only" giving it 4 stars because as the "national touristic attraction of Korea" the palace itself doesn't rival in size with similar world renown landmarks in other cities (Forbidden City, Versailles...) and people with very high expectations could get disappointed a bit.

Like the other royal palaces in Seoul, this palace is actually a palace campus. It is the premier palace for the Joseon kings. It was destroyed in 1600s by the Japanese and rebuilt in 1800s. There were around 500 buildings inside the campus at that time. But the Japanese invaded Korea once again in early 20th century and almost all the buildings were destroyed. After the WW2 some of the most important parts were once again rebuilt. Nowadays it looks quite good. If you don't have much time, you should see this palace as the representative of the 4 royal palaces in Seoul. By the way, the palace offers free guided tours in Korean, English, Japanese and Chinese a few times a day. I strongly recommend you to join one of those tours.After the visit, I recommend you a walk towards the Gwanghwamun Square.

review_title: A nice palace to visit to combine with Insadong area
review_body: Gyeongbokgung Palace is the most famous palace in Korea and is well worth spending an hour or two wandering around the complex. Admission is cheap at only $3,000KW ($3) and has a few pretty buildings and traditional Hanok type houses inside. There is a Changing of the Guard ceremony which is fun to watch for a few minutes. The children section, which has mock-ups of traditional Korean shops and houses is fun for kids and there are a few galleries if you like this sort of thing.Definitely a fun day if you combine wandering around the Insadong area and Bukchon Hanok Village.
this is where I found a picture perfect view. I feel like I'm one of the Korean novella star. The place is huge. I find it hard to find the exit bec. they don't provide a map

review_title: A close step to Joseon Dynasty
review_body: It is a grand palace with major restoration after destroy during the Japanese invasion. There are tourist guides with multi language which you can join at your own interest. The english speaking guide have clear pronunctiation and easily to understand. By standing in the palace, you can imagine and position yourself like you are in the dynasty of Joseon. It is a good experience to feel the ancient noble arts.

review_title: The Palace where the Korea King reside~
review_body: This is a very grand palace made of wood with all the pretty engravings. Gyeongbokgung is the place where the King sits in. You will get to see the original seat where the king sit in in Korea.There are also guards standing outside the door and if you are lucky enough you will get to see them change shift and do some marching along the front door.

review_title: A great place to visit to check out Korean history
review_body: Gyeongbokgung palace was awesome! The grounds are beautifully kept and very large - we could have easily spent half the day walking around the paths to check out the gorgeous architecture. The grounds is connected to a museum that boosts some of the nations greatest artifacts. Keep in mind that this place can get very crowded with tourists and children on field trips, so I recommend trying to go during the week day. The cover price is fairly cheap (about $4 USD), but you can also purchase a ticket book that is good for the rest of the month to visit the other nearby Palaces in the area.

The courtyard portion does not require a fee and may be enough for most for the visit. Especially, to watch the changing of the guard. The entry price was reasonable, so probably worth it. A free English tour is available, but did not use it because of time constraints.

We arrived at the palace in time for the changing of the guard - a colourful ceremony that was brief enough for even the most impatient amongst us to enjoy. We then took a walk around the palace which is a shadow of its former self, having been burned down by the Japanese. What has been rebuilt is fine on the whole but there are some real highlights like the pagoda on the lake.

review_title: Good place to learn some Korean history, and enjoy the architecture.
review_body: For those who like Korean architecture, this is a treat.I joined an English guided tour hoping to learn more about the historical stuff behind the place. Unfortunately, the group was quite big, and the tour guide was using a tiny loud speaker, and so most of the time I couldn't hear what she said. Which was a shame. They could have use those wireless units or limit the size of the group.What you see here are just buildings, and no artifacts. For those you'll have to go to the museum.
Were lucky to catch glimpse of changing of guards. Was very colourful & interesting. One complaint though: very dusty as palace ground is sandy

Except for a few buildings this is a recreation but what a fabulous recreation. We took one of the English tours and it was really interesting. The building are absolutely amazing. It was crowded in the main areas but the grounds are so vast it was easy to find quiet places to photograph or relax. Don;t miss the changing of the guard ceremony it is picturesque and colourful
Wonderful place! This was truly a journey back in time.Be prepared to take 1.5 hours because the area is huge!I recommend checking out the surrounding area as well if you can still walk. ;)
Love, love, love the place - nice excursion, touch of the past - magnificent. I went to the place on my last day in KOREA AND WOULD NEVER FORGIVE, IF I WOULD NOT SEE

review_title: It's just okay. Other palaces are better IMO.
review_body: Gyeongbokgung is the largest palace in Seoul, and I did appreciate all the structures and the grand scale of things. However, I think other palaces are much more interesting. Gyeongbokgung feels like a tourist trap and has too many visitors. The landscaping here isn't all that exciting compared to, say, Changdeokgung, which was built in harmony with nature. I would recommend visiting this palace to experience the grandeur and the guard changing ceremony, but also take a look at other palaces around Seoul.

Go for the free English tours at 1130, 1330, 1530, instead of going in alone. After the tour ends, you can hang around and chill. The scenary (buildings, gardens, pond, mountains etc) is really pretty here, and because of its Confucian roots, the palace can resemble the Chinese forbidden city, but it looks more well-maintained than forbidden city. This is definitely a great place for nature lovers!

Lovely place. I especially liked the pond with the coy fish. There were a lot of noisy school kids at the gate that were shouting "Hello, hello" at western tourists which was annoying, but luckily the kids scattered around the large area after the gate so we could enjoy rest of the visit.
Went on a Chinese holiday so it was quite busy, but the grounds were clean and had lots of greenery.
This was such a great place to visit!! The buildings are lovingly and beautifully maintained and there was so much to see!! The history of Korea was fascinating, so much I didn't know!!

Though this Palace is Seoul's grandest, it was certainly not built on a grand nor large scale as BeijingForbidden City. What i am surprised was that the moment we exited the Metro station, we were met with a strong 'sand storm'! And this had continued throughout the next one hour or so when we toured the Palace! We were surprised as well as disappointed that the Korean Government did not invest in well paved roads inside their supposed grandest Korean Palace ! Instead, sands were seen everywhere, in between buildings and practically - everywhere! I would strongly suggest ladies to tie up your hair or at least wear a cap as well as put on your sunglasses! Maybe it was the time of the year we visited (October)? Anyway, you have been forewarned!
Want to know about Korean history and culture this is the place Lot of character and it portraits the life style of the kings.
English Tour:Gyeongbokgung Palace @ 10.30 amSecret Garden @ 11.30 amDo buy a combo or combined ticket for 10 000 won.
Not quite as par- like as the other nice palaces, but grander and very nice. Close to City Center, of course, and an easy walk.

The palace has been restored to some of it's former glory. The 48 - columned pavilion, Gyeonghoero, is outstanding. Do not miss the imposing Genjeongjeong with its spacious courtyard and surrounding corridors, illustrating the splendour of the dynasty. Check out the attractive lily pond, the island pavilion of Hyangwonjeon, the rock garden and the residential quarters.

We did not go inside the palace but seeing the 'Changing of the Guards' was cool. Be there by 930am to witness this ceremony. However, kindly ensure to respect their rules. You cannot have pictures taken near the guards... Just keep your distance. The palace ground is very spacious so take time to enjoy the place. The subway leading to the side entrance of the Palace has cool artsy stuff so take time to explore. Don't forget to also stand in front of the palace and just observe the city.
You will not regret visit this place.. enjoy everything about it! Love to see the nice traditional building, and they maintain them nicely and super clean!

This is the biggest palace in Seoul. In my opinion, it is not the most beautiful one. Changdeokgung palace is better. The layout of the buildings is not as aesthetic as Changdeokgung's. Landscaping is noting to shout about. However it has daily changing of guards display to keep visitors engaged. It is good for a stroll.

Relatively new for a palace. Only 200 years old. They have kept it well preserved. Easy and quick to go through. There are some features in this palace that is unique to Korea compared to other palaces in Asia.

As a keen photographer we stopped short of entering. There were literally thousand of people there when we went! Luckily the entrance gate had guards dressed in full regalia and I got some awesome photos of them! (free) and some art shots (close up) in the first courtyard. Worth a look as a photographer if it is very quiet, but there is a better temple (see my other tripadvisor review). Take your choice....

We had a great time here. Our tour guide was a plus as he gave us plenty of historic information as we walked around. I liked that this palace contained traditional furnishings in some of the buildings. We even saw the changing of the guards!!!

the entrance to the palace is just the beginning and is usuallycrowded. move further at the back where the pond is. its quiet and less busy in the forested area. there's a huge mountain in the background if you move past the pond.make sure you allot half-a-day to explore this palace to make the most out of it!
The Palace is well worth a visit. Although the lines for the ticket booth were long, they moved fast. Tickets cost 3000 Won for one museum. There is a nice park on the right hand side of the Palace.

review_title: Great way to spend half a day
review_body: The palace is quite huge so we were lucky to have followed a free English tour guide from the visitor center. We avoided the crowds as much as we could while still seeing all the major attraction the palace had to offer. The tour was almost an hour long but it gave us further insight to the history and lives of those living inside the Gyeongbokgung. The ticket also comes with free admission to the folk museum located within palace grounds.

The change of guards ceremony was not too bad, the palace is huge with lots of turning, prepare to walk alot to explore the whole palace, at the end of the palace, there is a free museum to visit. I highly recommend the museum if you wanna know more about korea history.
A must see while in Seoul...to complete your visit. Take the Seoul City Tour for the day which offers a trip to all palaces in the city.

there are many beautiful things to see here and with the mountains in the background it makes it even better. The audio guide is worth it, it tells you many things that you might have otherwise missed. The colours are so rich and clean. If you enjoy palaces you should go. The grounds are beautiful as well with flowers and ponds everywhere.
This is the big one with an entire garden area attached. Lovely. They usually have some sort of show so that the area gets very crowded. At the top of Gwanghwamun street.

review_title: Good to visit at least once
review_body: Nice reconstruction. We went at 10am for the change of the guards as we were told that was the most spectacular. It was nice that everyone had a good spot to take photos and nice backgrounds. English speaking tour did not have enough detail though.

Very near to the Museum and Cheongwadae (The Blue House). It was rather packed for it was a public holiday. The palace was well maintained and we managed to catch the changing of the guards....a colourful event. Near to subway station.

review_title: Worth visiting if you have the time
review_body: We did one of the free tours and found it useful for the history and background, making sure we saw all the highlights, and saving us from crowding around the information boards to read descriptions. Tours start just inside the ticket gate near the information booth on the right. Though the website (which also has the times) says the tour numbers are capped, they aren't in reality. You can see the changing of the guard at the front gate without buying a ticket or entering the palace, as it takes place between the front gate on the main road and in the courtyard before the ticket gate.

There are so many palaces that one can visit in Seoul alone, but Gyeongbokgung Palace should be THE go to palace. It is the largest one in Seoul. If you are not a palace person, going to this one will definitely be satisfactory. Like in most palaces in Seoul, you'll find here the famous pillars, well-manicured gardens, the intricate Joseon Dynasty design, well-restored hanoks and the must-see changing of guards. Walking around here can be very tiring, but it's going to be worth it because there's a lot of beauty to see. You will feel like you are away from the hustle and bustle of the city outside its walls.This palace is also very near one of many art and culture hubs in Seoul, Samcheongdong.There is a money changer right beside the ticket counter, but do not have your dollars exchanged here. Last time I was there 1USD=985krw. Have your dollars changed in Namdaemun Market or Myeongdong Shopping District instead.And again, do not miss the changing of guards ceremony. You can experience this even if you will not pay for the palace entrance (I think), so do not miss it!

Great palace, for reference it is much smaller than the forbidden city, but the gardens and the lake give something else to this palace.In my opinion it would be my first choice when comparing with Changdeokgung, nevertheless both attractions deserve a visit.I would set from 90 min to 2h for a good look around.

We visit the palace during the cultural week in Seoul, so there was an interesting exhibition in the front court of the palace of virtual and augmented reality where a traditional book comes to live, it was really nice. Also the traditional dance made with little robots was really nice. As part of this cultural festival, there was at night a light and sound free show displayed in the outer wall of the palace.The palace is huge and is worth visiting to get a glimpse of the cultural heritage of Korea.

If you are interested in seeing the cultural soul in Seoul, then pay a visit to the Palace. Changing of the guard, beautiful gardens, intricate building designs and a whole lot of beauty all add for a fun visit - takes about 2 hours to see everything. It is easily accessible from the subway and there is a lot to see in the area. Also close by is the Blue House, where the Korean President resides.

This was the first palace that I visited in my trip to Seoul, Korea. I expected the compound to be big, but I just never realized how really big it is. It's such a beautiful place. I was there early this Spring and there are blossoms everywhere. I wish I had more time to just sit down and just admire the beauty at the lake. Make sure you wear a good pair of shoes because there's lots of walking involved.

review_title: Good to see and get about
review_body: This place was good but just a little bit fake, everything was tooo perfect. The bricks the structure and the paint. I am not sure if this is a newer building. It was so hot, however it was relaxing.

It was an unintentionally visit for me. Been there since 2013, 13 hrs before my next connecting flight so that was the chance to get around in the city. The palace has nothing much to see, building style is the combination between Japanese and Chinese. I was not sure about the ticket price but it was worth for paying. If you wanted to pin this on your travel map that's fine, but for me once is enough.There is something else to see in Seoul.

review_title: Good example of Korean traditional culture
review_body: The palace is very accessible by train as a train station leads directly to the palace complex. A good time is visit is at 9 a.m. because you can watch the opening of the gates in the traditional way. We did not take the tour but was able to see the different parts of the palace, taking time to notice the cultural artifacts. We saw many Korean school children visit this palace, a testimony that the palace is important to Koreans.
Very relaxing to wander around and take your time to just look.If you prefer you can go on a guided tour.

Gyeongbokgung palace was the first royal palace built in 1395 during the Joseon Dynasty. But it was devastated by the Japanese Invasion of Korea in 1592 and the restoration began in 1990 and revealed what it is today. The palace consists of official quarters, living quarters and resting places. The most representative structures of the Joseon Dynasty, Gyeonghoe-ru Pavilion and Hyangwonjeong Pond are still relatively intact.I recommend you take a special trip to Gyeonghoe-ru Pavilion. For this tour, you must reserve in advance via internet or phone.

But didn't do tour. Investigate if you can go in without a tour. That would be great if you could. We were lucky to catch a traditional show in front of the palace during a cultural event. Also a laser show on the front wall/gate. Check for events there!

This palace is the most important one in Seoul, so a must-visit! The area is vast, access is cheap (KRW 3000, just over EUR 2) and has interesting buildings and history. The buildings and the area and park are nice, but it is a bit hard to get the information. I would recommend to take a tour with a guide.The buildings have rather sober interiors. I recommend to visit the National Palace Museum which is directly beside the Gyeonbokgung palace. There you will get some more tangible and visible details of Korea's history.

This palace is seriously run down by tours, and it gets super packed for the changing of the guard. It is really just a reconstruction and thus historically it is of limited interest. Changdeokgung is countless times more interesting to be sure to check out that one.

review_title: Beautiful place if you love history and peace & quiet
review_body: I could only spare a couple of hours for Gyeongbokgung Palace, and I recommend that you allot more time for this. It's a lot like the Forbidden City in Beijing, but I found there were more green areas where you can walk and just sit. Didn't take a guided tour, so I just figured out my own routte.To the left side of the main corridor, there's a larger area. One of the pavilions has a man-made lake in front of it, with benches along the edge. You can spend a few minutes sitting there, just taking it all in. There was also a Janggu exhibit. Janggu are those big jars where they store Korean sauce in. The exhibit was in one of the inner areas, and tells you about how they prepared the Korean sauce.In one of the inner areas, you might also find painters along one of the ponds. It gave off a very peaceful vibe.Went there in late September, so the weather was beautiful and I went on a weekday. There were more than a few kids on a field trip there, but it still wasn't crowded.
Nice view of the past. September was a good time of the year to visit - not to crowded. Majestic buildings, lots to see.
We were with a group, so we had a guided tour. Lovely grounds, nice views of the surrounding area. Interesting to see a palace in the middle of a bustling city!
Amazing complex of palace with extraordinary art and architecture. It also has colorful painting. Perfect when in bright day.
Very beautiful palace with a very tranquil feeling. Really worth a visit. So much history. The staff is very helpful.

We lives in modern city, it is very unlikely for us to see such palace. It really nice and spectacular. Lots of tourists visit too. Entrance fee: 8,000won (can only visit 1 palace)The palace book guide cost 500won whereby you buy and bring it with you. If you wanna to visit all the palaces, you can buy from here too (cost more). Recommend for those whom really likes historic buildings and not likely to see in own country.

review_title: This is a must see in Seoul
review_body: Definite must see for the cultural aspects. You'll need at least 3 hours here (if you walk fast). Go during a good lighting day there are lots of color & details.

I went to the palace in April 2014. Although it was very busy with lots of us ( turists ) I was able to enjoy the whole visit. You can rent the audioguides for few Won, just need to leave you ID with the officer, but I think it was really cheap, like 2-5 dolars per device. You can actually walk around and enjoy the most amazing historic places inside the place, and if you are K-Drama fan like me you will be transported to Faith ( drama starring Lee- Minho ) the rooms, the gardens, everythign was breathtaking. A recommended visit..You even have access to the front of the Blue House once in there, for not addictional cost ..Back again to K-dramas ( City Hunter starring Lee-Minho) If I ever visit Korea again I will go and make a more paceful visit, slower and take way more photos.Bring your camera along, or you will be missing spectacular picture moments.

review_title: A Good Place for Leisurely Visit
review_body: We asked the taxi driver for Changdeokgung but he took us here instead. Apparently Changdeokgung is closed on Mondays. This place is huge & simple, not much to see except for the Korean Folk Museum. We missed the National Museum, so make sure not to miss it. We also watched the palace guards marching in traditional costumes. Lots of photo opportunities. Overall a very good visit.

review_title: The best palace in my opinion
review_body: This is by far the best palace Ive been to among the five palaces. Especially the palace in the lake. Allot 2-3 hours when visiting this place as this is really breath taking.

review_title: Interesting place to visit while in Seoul
review_body: Seoul is a very interesting city in that there are palaces in the middle, while being surrounded by skyscrapers. This particular palace was incredibly majestic, and it seemed that even locals go there just to relax on the palace grounds. You can definitely spend a whole day exploring the different areas, and a guide book is only 50 cents CAD.
I really enjoyed learning the history and culture of South Korea, and this was a nice place to start, incredible workmanship and ingenuity, in a beautiful park like area..

Very big & crouded palace. From my visit, after doing pretty much all the palace section, I've came to realize that it pretty much looked the same.. Therefore, it's up to you guys to decide if it's really worth it. I did enjoyed the guard change !

review_title: Beautiful but quarters are not those King lived in
review_body: You don't need more than 1.5 hours to conduct a thorough visit of the Palace grounds. We knew exactly what we wanted to see, and the map we had made it easy to follow along. Looking at the map, you can proceed through each quarter in the numerical order indicated. You'll find yourself eventually graduating from the Southern wing of the Palace to the Northern one as you visit each quarter in that order. My favorite sights were the Hyangwonjeong pavilion and Gyeongheoru pavilion. I would also pay to see this place in the Winter when it's covered by snow. Finally, my understanding is the Palace was built, destroyed, and rebuilt several times over the past several hundreds of years. Keep in mind the quarters are as close a replica as it gets to those in which the King lived/held his meetings/etc... but they're not authentic.

This palace is huge and is very similar to the Changdeokgung palace. Although this palace does not have a secret garden like Changdeokgung, it has the change of guard ceremony, a two story feast building where the emperor entertained, and a pagoda(not accessible, but visible) in the background. Since the palace ground is vast, be prepared to spend at least 2 hours here if you want to see every inch, longer if you also want to visit the museum within. The palace is very well maintained, so well that the vibrantly painted colours robbed it of its authenticity. Because of that, I think Changdeokgung is more authentic, but the architecture is very similar. Come here for the grand palace experience, but be prepared to walk lots out in the open sun. In any case, I think it's a worthwhile experience in Seoul. :-)
The place is big but not much to see inside. Not recommend to go if the trip is short. You can just take a picture at the front door.

review_title: Huge grounds with lots to see
review_body: We loved the ease of access to all areas of the palace and temples. It was a lovely warm day and we enjoyed the exercise. The ornate buildings and statues were very cool and good information was available to read at each location. Nothing to dislike here.

I didn't actually go inside the complex (I did this for the other palace Changdeokgung Palace) but the exterior was really nice and I got to see the changing of the guards which was a really cool experience, so I recommend sticking around to see that if you can!

Area was huge, you could probably get lost if your sense of direction is not that good. We had a tour guide so it was easy for us to go to the other buildings. The area was reconstructed because it was damaged during the previous world war and a lot of construction is still ongoing when we went there (kitchen area being built). Very good work on the buildings though and all of the decorations done. You really need to checkout the golden dragon on the ceiling if you are there.
Very well kept & informative. Nice refreshment stop to rest up from alot of walking. Not allowed to enter the buildings but that is probably why they are in such god shape.

Book the secret garden tour as well, and book in advance. Its a long walk about 2.5 hours but easy to do and well worth the effort. The place has been kept in immaculate condition. I would highly recommend this tour while in Seoul.

The palace is old, and surprisingly small. Perhaps I just did not see too much into the history of the place. I noticed though that they have put more significance in places that would not have been significant had it not been for tourism purposes. But the facade of the building is interesting. It is a good place to visit one time. Just to get it out of your system. But not to revisit.

review_title: A must if you are in Seoul
review_body: Allow at minimum a half-day to explore the palace. It took me a full day, including the museums. Wear comfortable shoes and expect to walk a lot! It was a great introduction to Korean history.
located in the center of seoul, just near american embassy. the palace is majestic and, unlike the other great palace in the capital, you can have the chance to admire the guard exchange. recommend

review_title: Great place to visit if you're in Seoul.
review_body: A very large compound in the middle of Seoul, the contrast between the old palace roofs and the surrounding skyscrapers is impressive. The compound is very large, so be sure to take comfortable shoes along. It's very beautiful, there is lots to see and everything is well-kept.I found it less crowded than I had imagined it to be, it's very easy to reach by metro and the entrance fee is very low, around 3 USD.They have guided tours, although we always prefer to go on our own. You can't go inside any of the rooms or buildings, but it's still impressive to see it from outside. We were able to take millions of lovely pictures, and greatly enjoyed our visit.There is a great little Samgyetong place called "Tosokchon" not far, which is prized with selling the best Ginseng Chicken in Seoul. That's how we rounded off our day there.If you have time, if you like walking, and if you want to see the largest Palace in Seoul then this is the place to go.

review_title: Nice setting with interesting history to tell
review_body: Following the style of the Forbidden City in Beijing, Gyeongbokgung is much less impressive but what's great about it is the pine grove and white sand ground that make it feel so aged and natural. In ancient time, Korea didn't have a big forest to build a large palace as China did. The woods for the palace were delivered from China, to whom it used to submit. Thus the houses are much smaller, especially the doors are low and narrow. Interesting place to learn about the country.

review_title: It is a good place to learn more Korean history
review_body: It is a good place to learn more Korean history!! It is very big, you can spend half day to visit there.
You can pass this place. You could check out the guard changing ceremony if you like that kind of stuff.
A nice palace within the vicinity of the city. A pale comparison to Forbidden Palace in Beijing. But anyhow a nice place to visit when you visit Seoul. The Museum there is also very good.

review_title: The best part is getting there.
review_body: Lovely grounds but the ratio of strolling to special sights was not ideal, and it was easy to get lost. The best part really was getting there -- walking up the boulevard past two massive statues of war heroes, ideally when dark enough to see the entrance all ablaze.
Very important historical and quiet place I suggest for all travelers of Seoul.

Pretty palace with nice scenery. It is fine to go here just to look at the entrance, try on traditional clothing, take some photos and watch the guards. Don't really know what the tickets were for, all the fun was outside.

This place is really wonderful!! Just hope that it is not so hot like when I went! I would go back here so that is why I'm giving it an Excellent rating. And only $3 to get in - awesome! They have a beverages and gift shop if you need that. I want to go back for the free English tour in the early afternoon. There is quite a bit of walking around here so those with trouble walking should beware. Bring your camera. I walked here from the Folk Museum.

I was fortunate to visit the Palace in January, with snow on the ground and on a wonderful clear day.Firstly, there are the guards outside, in traditional uniforms - make sure you see the 'changing of the guard'.Then the palace itself, which has been lovingly restored (having been ford down by the Japanese when they occupied Korea). It is a lovely place just to walk around - and an incredible space within the middle of a modern city.Go to the national museum (adjoining the Palace grounds) after - to get an excellent picture of the history and culture of South Korea.

Amazing place to visit to know a bit of more Korean culture while in vibrant Seoul. Very easy to reach, just follow the direction of Palace going out of Gyeongbokgung subway station - the map is described on official website (http://www.royalpalace.go.kr/html/eng/guide/guide03.jsp?dep1=1&dep2=3). On the same website is the information about free tours in English. The ticket costs 3000 wons for the whole site and I advise to take one of those free guided tours, so you learn a bit more about culture, history and architecture. However, it was very difficult to get used to my guide, since she had a very strong Korean accent, it still gave me a small insight into the place. I've been there at around 13h and saw the ending of the traditional guard show, which was fantastic experience!
Really beautiful place, you can take good photos and enjoy the view. It's a must see in Korea, for sure.
There is a National Folk Museum inside where you can learn about history and culture about Korea. The Palace architecture is unique.
Love the guards at the front gate. Free dress up in guard costumes, cheap entry fee. Beautiful sceneries with mountains views behind the palace buildings.

The palace ground is really big and it is a great place for you to slow down your pace and walk around. I have been here a couple of time and no matter what season it is, it is a comfortable place. Once you get away from the bustling main entrance, the rest of the palace is very comfortable to explore on your own. The toilets are unexpectedly extremely clean.
It is one of the museums that shows Korean traditional palace. I heard that the actual palace was burnt by Japanese and it was rebuilt by Koreans.
i work in the city of seoul and having such a great tourist spot is just amazing. the trip was just a walk away from the hotel I am staying at I just joined in some of the tourist

review_title: One of many beautiful palaces in Seoul
review_body: While living in Korea, we traveled to and visited many sights. The palaces located in Seoul make it easy to travel a short distance to be transported back in time when emporers ruled. This one is beautiful in many season and relatively flat for those with physical impairments. And the admission cost is perfect for me as I'm a shoestring-budget tourist, by choice.

review_title: Wow this is a great place to visit and stroll
review_body: Three are not only king's and queen's office and living rooms, but also a large museum with full history of Korea. Beautiful gardens and pond make me feel peaceful and healthy while I and my family walk on unpaved ground

I visited the palace with a Korean friend of mine. He told that the palace has been destroyed and resurrected many times during Japanese and North Korean attacks. Seeing the quality of the buildings inside the campus was unbelievable considering the attacks. The repair work certainly has been fantastic.The palace is a typical of Medieval age Korean Architecture. Its huge, beautiful and elegant. I clicked a lot of pictures there. There is a small museum inside, which has a very interesting display of Korean civilisation starting from pre-historic period to medieval age. A must visit if you are in Seoul.
Be prepared to walk and walk and walk. Toilets are strategically located. Impressive maintenance of the gardens! Especially the trees! Keep up the good work!

We did Gyeongbokgung as a day trip/walk around several palace sites. We started at Deoksugung and walked up Gwanghwamun Square (currently filled with protesters which made it interesting).I think the actual Palace at Gyeongbokgung was closed when we visited. Or maybe we simple missed something. Enjoyed the museum though.

Gyeokbokgung palace is the biggest among the 5 palaces in Seoul. I recommend that you visit this and wait for the changing of the guards. Entrance fee is cheap, 3,000 won. It takes around 2-3 hours to fully explore the palace complex. Also, do not forget to try hanbok costumes.

I've been here with friends and Korean teacher for several years. That was so amazing Palace with large land and complex systems of King's Palace. You can come here by bus, underground or taxi quite advantage.

I cannot believe the bus loads of tourists I saw at this place. This is the most popular palace in Seoul. The backdrop on the mountain makes it more elegant and it is also close to Gwahamun Square. We paid US$3 to get in.The grounds is quite large and there are two museums on its premises. I love the ponds with pagodas in them. I also love the structure with no paint on them and even the display of the jars were beautiful. We were able to see the entire place except for the museums although we entered one of them. I also love the horsemen statue in the platform of the subway station near the palace.

This palace is unbelievably large. You definitely want to have a guide, whether a human guide or an electronic one. We were traveling with our own guide and we learned so much about the Korean people and the buildings in which their royalty lived. The buildings are beautifully painted, with very bright colors. Be sure to look at the ceilings in all the buildings because they are decorated very elaborately (inside and out). This is a "must see" in Seoul!

This is a popular tourist destination and it is also very central to Seoul.A few things you need to do here. They have parade on changing the guard once every hour so it is well worth watching. The buildings are nice and you can take beautiful photos. One particular spot was the building situated at the north western corner. It was built to entertain guests and it is surrounded by lake and trees. Beautiful.And also have a look at the important painting in the central building where the King administered. It is called the sun moon 5 mountains. It is directly behind the throne of the King and it has great significance as the holder of power. You can also find the painting on one of the Korean Won notes.So a place not to be missed plus it is so central to sejongdae ro. where you can see the great Admiral Yee statue and also King Sejong statue.

review_title: Take the guided tour. Watch changing of guards.
review_body: I suggest you take the guided tour because you would understand why the palace was created as such. Visit is not complete without witnessing the changing of guards. Be aware of the schedules for these two. The place is big and is full of people.

I took a guided tours to visit the Palace. Gyeongbokgung itself means "the palace blessed by Heaven". This is a complete historic building to let you learn more about Korean people way of life and their historical life. I would recommend to take guided tour because of not so much signage or maps available to allow self guided tour. If you are lucky, you will be able to see the Guard Change ceremony on the main gate. Behind this palace, there is a Presidential House called 'Cheonghwadae' or 'Blue House'. Prepare yourself for a lot of walking, from the main gate to the exit gate.

review_title: Go for a guided tour if you can (it's free)
review_body: I made it for a guided tour in English on time (1.30pm), so it really helped a lot. The tour took about 1hr 30mins. People with interests in architecture or photography will have a blast. You can hop into the museum next door and come back in for free with your ticket stub.The downside is that the palace and museum are filled with tourists and screaming kids, and its quite hard to get shots that you want without people in the background.

Good way to spend a couple of hours in Seoul. Guided tours are essential because there is not much in the way of signage or walking maps available to allow you to do a self guided tour. The complex is sprawling so without a tour guide you will have no idea what you're looking at. Be prepared for lots of walking. Interesting look inside the Korean imperial court during the Chosin dynasty.

I had the opportunity to visit this amazing compound during a 14 hour layover in Seoul. Awesome train ride from Incheon Airport into the city and voila! there you are all of the sudden facing this gorgeous monument surrounded by a modern world beyond it's walls.This 619-year old beauty is a must visit regardless of the length of your visit to Seoul. You will, without a doubt be inspired and in awe. From the ceremoniously dressed guards and the colors of the ceilings to the contrast of the beautiful mountains and modern buildings, this is one of the best preserved historical sites you will ever see.

review_title: Interesting visit to the old times
review_body: Actually got the 3 palace day pass and went to gyeongbokgung, cheongdukgong, the shrine and secret garden. Initially it was all pretty interesting with the architexture and all, but quickly got monotonous since all 3 palaces were almost the same. Advise: Go with the tour, you ll learn a lot more and feel more engaged, and skip on the other 2 palaces. One is more than enough. Shrine and secret garden good for taking pictures

This is unique place which a must visit place in Seoul. This is a palace spread over a large area where, you can feel the ancient times of Korea. I was there with a Korean friend where we managed to join the free guided tour (as I remember starts at 3:30 pm). If you have any interest on history or like to know some info about this palace, I recommend you to join this free tour where a guide English speaking guide takes the group for guided tour almost for a hour. Most of the things that you learn from this tour cannot be grabed by just walking around in this place.I’m not a big fan of Korean dramas, still I enjoyed this visit. If you are a fan of Korean drams related to historical event, this is a must visit place.Seoul museum is also located in the same premises, so you can visit there also.If you have some sort of an interest on history and have 1-2 hrs to spare, don’t miss this experience. This will give you a memory to recall that you visited Korea.If I happen to visit Seoul again, I will repeat this visit.

review_title: just go here and skip the other palaces
review_body: ... they all look the same. however this one has a massive scale, lots of palaces within palaces, and nice park area and museum around it. however if you've been to the palaces and temples in japan and china, the ones in seoul can't compare
Not really a person who likes historical buildings but be prepared to walk if you are going to explore the place as the whole place is HUGE!

This was similar to all of the rest of the palaces. However it had one of the buildings on a lake here, which was really pretty. This was extremely busy but worth a look round. It was a lot bigger than Changdeokgung Palace, however once you had seen one of the buildings you had seen them all!

Solemn and dramatic, the guards and the music along with blossoming trees make it beautiful. Check the schedule, come at 10 AM. Inside it's just a nice place to walk, we loved it. At the end take pictures with guards, they don't mind it.
This is the best of all the palaces in Korea. I strongly recommend a visit. Spend some time to explore the surroundings. You can easily walk to Insadong (another touristy spot in seoul), city hall...
you have to visit this place - it is very beautiful and peaceful. have a time for meditation. you can also find some quite place and have a picnik.

review_title: Not much information in English but good visit
review_body: Mainly just a big palace and cheap to gain entry.. A few little events going on soldiers marching about in traditional garb.. Not a bad spot to see but very little in the way of historical information that I could see.. Maybe I missed a booklet somewhere.
Super good palace and it is quite large. Slow down your pace while you visit this palace. Sit somewhere in the palace and that is really tranquillising. Mesmerising scene!

This is the 1st place i visit when i reach Korea. The palace has so many visitors and majority of them are the Koreans. If you ever watched an old Korean drama series and wish to feel how the era looks like, you have to visit this palace. The area are so big, and the buildings are as it should looks like. Great view.

The palace was very busy when we visited it. There are various tours that take place, and you can get a guided tour if you want. We chose to just stroll through the various buildings and gardens. It's a really well maintained complex, and the gardens around the palace are a great place to relax after you tour. There are information boards all around to read about about the various functions of the buildings you are viewing. It's very centrally located and is close to other attractions in the city. You also have great views of the mountains near Seoul.

We hired through Internet a free guide, from some group of volunteers and it was a very nice old man, Mr.Lee, who spent more than 2 hours explaining us everything about the palace and the buildings that compose the place. A good experience that I recommend everybody to do, cheap and worth it.

This was our first visit to a Korean Palace. Overall a good experience, the place grounds are extensive and there is alot of walking. Did not take a guided tour although that might have been better. The buildings all look the same and you cannot enter most of them. They have a formal changing of the guard every so often, we just happened to arrive when they were conducting it. Also at the end of the day (near 5PM) they have a ceremony with traditional dress and pomp and circumstance where teh guards march around and there is a marching band of sorts. We visited in late July which is quite warm in Korea but this day it was cooler with lower humidity. If you go in summer expect it to be very hot and humid. There is a fee to enter the palace grounds and another fee to be able to go to the pavilion which is in the middle of a small pond/lake. We did not visit the pavilion. The cost to enter for 2 adults and 1 child (11 years old) was around 10,000 Won. This cheap in my opinion.

Expansive palace based on Chinese architecture. Not a spectacular building but some parts looked quite nice. Most buildings do look the same and even though restored you cannot go in the buildings. Limited information on the boards outside with barely any context given.Changing of the guard takes place on the hour.Closed on Tuesdays.If you want to find out about the palace then get a guide, the visit Korea website has the times of tours.

The grounds are truly amazing and you can get a real feel for how life was in the past. Definitely recommend going and getting a tour if at all possible. Might be better to go in the warmer months, but was okay in the winter just dress warm. Easy enough access from the subway.
This palace was absolutely amazing, and was the most lovely sight during my trip to Japan and Korea last year. Definitely worth the trip.

review_title: All five palaces are basically the same...see this one
review_body: All five palaces are basically identical...you may as well go to this one as it is the biggest.Try and arrive or leave on the hour and you will get the changing of the guard show.The palaces are good but they are all the same...same layout, same style, same interiors...just five of them...

Gyeongbokgung Palace is the largest palace in Seoul. It is at the end of the main blvd. We watched the changing of the guard at the palace gate on the way in and on the way out a more elaborate changing of the guard ceremony was being held. The grounds are vast and there is also the Korean Folk Museum included with your admission price. It was a very hot day so going in the museum was very enjoyable. The museum was informative about Korean culture and was very interesting.we probably spent 2 1.5 hours at the palace complex.

This is only a small palace compared to others in Asia and not as interesting. The changing of the guard ceremony was very touristy and not the real thing like Buckingham Palace. The museum was only average also. I would only recommend this palace for its history.

It is a sprawling compound which encompasses many halls and living quarters plus 2 museums. Avoid going on weekends as there are many tour groups present! You could spend up to 3 hours walking the palace grounds and museums, all for an affordable fee of 3000won each. Be sure to bring a bottle as there are hardly any shops selling drinks.

I suggest to read a little about Gyeongbokgung before visiting the area. This way you will be able to appreciate the place more. The palace is huge and each building has it's own story to tell. Go to the large open space compound and you will see small erected rocks. Those are used to separate different ranks for ancient Korean officials. ”一” = grade one (highest rank)”二” = grade two "三” = grade three"四” = grade fourAnd lowerIf you see the center pathway, you will notice the center walkway is higher than the rest. The center walkway is walked by the king. The side pathways are for generals and scholars separately. You will notice huge ring like object on the floor at each side of the compound. It is used to pitch shelter if it rain. But it's only for Grade 1 to Grade 3 officials only.Read more and be Wow!

review_title: A Palace from Dramas and Movies
review_body: The Best Palace to visit in my opinion!! I love K-Dramas and K-Movies and you know, just the feelings of walking in the same place, being there and seeing everything with my own eyes is best to discribe as breathtaking and exciting. Worth to see for yourself!
one of my most favorite places we visited while in seoul. absolutely gorgeous palace. would love to visit again.

Saw a guard changing ceremony there.Is a good place for sightseeing and photo ops, LOL. Also, if you like the ancient Korean heritage, this is the place.The information are also clear and they are everywhere, so don't be afraid you've got lost :)Nearby, there are also a Children's museum (?) that you can also visit by paying some fees. I don't know much since I am just passing by, but I saw the sculpture on their front door. It seems nice.

review_title: Spacious peaceful, palace in the middle of Seoul
review_body: Beautiful once you walk through the grounds. Loved the National Folk Museum as it explained Korean life and why Koreans eat kimchi. It is large and it was very hot the day we visited so very tiring to walk around. Watched the guard ceremony. hotel bus too us here-subway home.

I visited this place as part of my short Seoul trip.I loved the amazing view from the statues on Sejong - it looks really great for a European who has never been to this type of Asian culture before. We spend there two hours of incredible walk - having a local friend who gave us some insight on Korean culture. Every part if completely different and worth of visiting - lake, buildings etc.The only negative aspect was the fact, that inside the buildings there is almost nothing - completely different from the collections inside the European castles.

The guard change adds a historic feel to the place as they really dress up for it. Overall the place is huge and is best seen with a guide, as you get insights into things you wouldn't otherwise pick up on your own (not many signs or explanations) or from your guidebook. Such as - who's the most powerful person in the palace? Hint: It's not the king!

review_title: Very large palace with two museums connected
review_body: This palace complex is very large. It is also pretty busy. We saw lots and lots of tourists from several countries. The National Folk Museum and Palace Museum are also here. You could probably spend an entire day here if you wanted to. We just spent a couple of hours. It's conveniently right off the subway as well.

This place is large so expect to spend more than an hour inside. Reached there just in time for the first changing of guards ceremony. Should watch if you have not seen it. There are guided tours for English and Chinese. Though it's not UNESCO certified, but it's the first palace build. Worth visiting if you just want to pick one palace to go to out of the many other palace around the area.

This is a nice palace located in central Seoul. The buildings are old and beautiful. You can also watch the changing of guards.
