We were told that this was at 1pm and 3pm, but when we arrived at 3 pm the ceremony was already finished. I think it began at 2.30 so heads up for that. You can also visit the folk museum of Korea which is just outside the area. The cost is 3000 won pp
coming from a country that nothing much historical monuments were still intact, these kind of places in S.Korea tickles my interest. took a lot of cool pictures here.

There are complimentary lockers for visitors to put the shopping bags. A big place to see, with restored furnishings. Easily accessible by train, with artifacts displayed along the passageway. The change of guards ceremony is very realistic

The palace inside it self has many restoration going on. The place is quite pack with people. The palace it self is colorful and the palace ground is peace and quiet. If your planing just a stroll around. It would be a great place.

I think the restoration has not ended yet, you can only walk on the outsides of the buildings and it has been restored from the ground so it has this feeling of being a little bit like a theme park.Said that it is still a nice play to walk inside and to compare it with European palaces, it is pretty different in concept.

This palace is a beautiful example of historical Korean architecture. It is wonderfully colorful and the palace grounds are a peaceful respite from the hustle and bustle of the city that surrounds it. Plan to spend at lease a few hours while there. The walkways are coated in small gravel so I recommend closed toed shoes. There are food and drinks available for purchase.
You can watch the changing of the guards free at the main entrance of the palace. It was captivating. Traditional Korean dress and customs on show lovely.

This is a must see place in Seoul! Our tour guide has so many interesting stories during our walk tour. It's a nice feeling of having a chance to glimpse Korea culture. The palace is so grand and there are multiplex structures besides it which is just as interesting to see...There is also a museum near the palace which you can do a quick tour.
This palace is right beside the Folk Museum of Seoul so you can spend a good half day here seeing both. Recommend if you want to see more then just a palace!

review_title: Must visit for Korean culture tour
review_body: Interesting history, the palace is very well conserve and maintain, lots of rebuilding, since some had been destroyed by Japanese occupation period. Very easy to come by subway, exit virtually inside the palace area. One of the must visit places in Seoul.
i liked the guide :) i learned lots of interesting facts about life in the palace and.... i like the trees :) beautiful walk one of the must sees of seoul

The biggest palace in Seoul. Very interesting architecture - something totally different from Europe. All the palaces in Seoul have almost the same style but never think that all the palaces there look the same. Gyeongbokgung is a palace with a multitude of small buildings that had different functions. Gyeongbokgung has the typical complex used by the king, other by the queen, but also a complex of building were the dead body of the royals were held until the burial, and other complex used to hold the tables of the dead royals for the mourning period (2 years) etc. I recommend to save an entire day for this palace because the Korean Folk Museum is within the grounds of this palace, and when you buy the ticket for Gyeongbokgung the museum is included in the price. Furthermore, I also recommend to join a guided tour, you will find more interesting things about the palace, the kings and queens, the rules and habits. However, if you enjoy more the freedom of looking around without someone calling you all the time, and want to take your time to take some good shuts, try to look for the metal panels that are in front of or near each building, in order to get some information about the use of specific building, when it was build, by orders of who and if there happened something important (at the ticket box you will not get a brochure with information about the buildings, you only get a map of the palace) Keep in mind, the ground of this palace is very extended! Also, you will walk on dusty soil, so use proper shoes. Don't use sandals or flip- flops if it is summer and you have sensitive feet. TIP: visit it on Monday because on Monday the other palaces are closed.

review_title: A great palace and grounds to visit
review_body: When I was in Korea 55 years ago, this location was the previous Japanese Headquarters Building. These grounds are amazing and I especially enjoyed the statues of the inventor of the Korean language and also the only Emperor to defeat the Japanese navy. If you had to choose between this and the Seoul Tower, go here.
Complimentary English guided tours provided- the tour guide was extremely professional and helpful. Most beautiful palace
Love it! Awesome view plus great architecture back in the olden days. We went on Wednesday and the admission was free. Yayyyy lucky us. Haha

We visited Gyeongbokgung palace on a very hot and crowded day on Chuseok (the largest Korean national holiday, similar to thanksgiving). It was extremely busy with many tourists and Koreans alike. The size of the grounds themselves were the most impressive to me. I loved the big pond/lake and the parks around the palace. There's not much to see of the palace itself but its still a good experience. We saw the changing of the guards in their traditional colourful uniforms.

3000 KRW to spend the whole day. You can op for a tour, or latch yourself with another tour (seen people doing that some time) pack some water and sandwich. It's hard to find food in the palace itself.

If you're in Seoul this is certainly worth a visit. It's amazing to see something so huge right in Central Seoul.I'd recommend a tour - it helps get a real appreciation for the site and it's history. Don't miss the changing of the guard - what a hoot!Some great photo opportunities here with the dramatic hills in the background.

Pro : Located in the city area. Accessible via metro.Pretty cheap admissions. Free guided tour available.Large compound. Quite a number of attractions to see.Historical. Learn how royalty lives.Nice garden. Great ambiance. Lovely pavilions.Con :Most of the buildings are re-built or replica as the original were destroyed/demolished.Huge compound. Lots of walking required.After a while, one building looks like another…
Large sprawling complex somewhat spoilt by mass tourism and careless juxtaposition of modern buildings. Make sure you catch the changing of the guard which is colourful and take a short English tour.
Enjoyed our time here. Only Few train stops from Myeongdong. Very serene. The place is well kept with beautiful gardens with mountain and lake backdrop. Loved the white and pink cherry blossoms

review_title: Great place to take first-time visitors
review_body: I love Gyeongbukgung,but maybe it's because it's the first palace I visited in Korea. The grounds are huge - the scope of the palace is really surreal. There is a changing of the guards ceremony with music. You cannot go inside and crawl around the palace, no, but you can look inside some of the rooms.The palace is also centrally located to the National Folk Museum (free and worth a visit) and Bukchon Hanok Village. Insadong isn't too far away either.

This was quite a nice and interesting place to visit. If you make it to the palace I recommend taking a tour, but it is still fun to explore on your own. when I went they were working on a few buildings but what is open is pretty amazing, especially if you are into history. And while there you might as well pop over into the national museum.

You must never give this place a miss if you want to know more about korean history. Visit both place.... The royal palace itself and not to forget the folklore museum.... You will make your journey complete

Seems like a must go place if you happen to be in Seoul but don't get your hopes high. Most of the buildings were reconstructed only 15 years ago so don't expect to see 1000 year old ancient palaces and the reconstructed buildings were modern and artificial looking.As we were about to leave, we just happened to catch the changing of guards ceremony, and it was pretty cool.

The guard changing ceremony (scheduled at certain time of the day) was a pleasure to see. I like it.!. The show takes 10 minutes and then you can go take pictures with them. Go with the guide and listen to history will make the visit more interesting than wandering around aimlessly. After the 30-40 minutes tour, then be free to wonder around. The place is huge, exploring all of the place (alone) took about 3 hours. Nice souvenir shop and cafe as well selling quite expensive items but of very high quality. Locker is provided FOC.

review_title: Most Important to visit in Seoul
review_body: This is the largest (huge) palace in Seoul and definitely everyone should visit the palace on their first visit, or even on the second if your coming in winter the palace is nice to see under snow cover. We got the Multi site tickets here which let us in to a lot of the temples around Seoul and saved some cash. The museum in the back was pretty interesting, not extremely exciting, but let you see a lot of props and artifacts of the time, showing how they lived and worked during the old era. The staff during the winter were nice enough to give out hand warmers on a bitter old day when we first came in January.

review_title: Good place to see a bit of Seoul
review_body: Our group went on a short trip to this palace, it was very easy to get to from the metro, even for people who don't speak a bit of Korean. We walked around, enjoyed the palace and gardens. It is close enough by some shopping as restaurants as well, so it is good place to make a day of sightseeing in Seoul.
Love the place. Everything is well maintained. Went there during winter so it was really beautiful looking at the buildings encased in snow.

review_title: Excellent place to learn about the Korean Chosun Dynasty!
review_body: This temple is extraordinary! It is surrounded by breathtaking, mountainous views, and packed full of information regarding Korean Chosun Dynasty. Hour longTours are available in several languages, including Korean (of course), English, Japanese and more. A must-see!

review_title: One of my favorite places in Seoul!
review_body: Lots to see at this palace! A piece of Korean history that will leave you in awe! Interesting and very peaceful. Ensure you get a chance to see the guards march and the traditional Korean singers and dancers. On top of all this, it was very affordable. Make sure you go:)!

review_title: Great visit, make sure you have enough time!
review_body: The complex was large and walking was very easy - just make sure you budget enough time to see it all. It takes a bit to get from building to building without feeling like you need to rush.

A very large complex to walk around so for best understanding take advantage of the free English guide who meets you outside the information office for on the hour departures. Her tour took about an hour and her knowledge really did help as she explained the history of the palace from first being built in 1395, later burned and abandoned for almost three centuries, occupied and destroyed by the Japanese and then the start of the rebuilding in 1867. Oh and that clever old way of central heating. The reconstructions did not distract from the visit and overall we came away with a great feel for how Royal Life might have been. Look out for the changing of the guard ceremony - effectively hourly - and combined entrance into the Folk Museum

review_title: Interesting. You should have a guide otherwise you wont get it
review_body: Architecture. The painting decorations on the wooden beams. I should have spent this day visiting the North and experience the thrill of being close to evil
Take your time to stroll down the Palace and enjoy the beauty of the nature and old Korean architecture. Such a peaceful place.

review_title: I wish our house has a secret garden too
review_body: Got a chance to visit The Secret Garden. It was quite lovely, although a bit of a hike. The Secret Garden area is wider than the Palace grounds itself, so try not to miss the tour there.The Changing of the Guard Ceremony is of course a must-see. You can take a photo with some of the guards for the short time that they are posted by the gate.
Come here early and plan to stay 3-4 hours. There are so many things to see ... some perfect places to take pictures.Make sure you are there for change of the guards.

review_title: Please dont pay to go in
review_body: You really dont have to go in to see the throne. The infrastructure is the same as from the outside. Catch the guard changing ceremony at the entrance. That's good. after the ceremony, remember to stay outside so that you can get a picture with the guards. After that, head back to the main area where you can get to dress up as a guard for free! Head there early as the booth closes quite fast after the ceremony.
It's one of the place to visit as one of the most beautiful palace. There's a lot of things to see and it is a huge area.

This is on my list of must see on my first day in Seoul and it didn't disappoint. True to its description, it's a grand palace with imposing gates, stunning throne hall and large lawns for leisurely walks. The palace is huge and doesn't have much information around so it's advisable to go with a tour guide. Either join the free tour given by the palace or sign-up for free walking tours from visitseoul.net. I think the latter is much better because the group would usually be much smaller than the ones who join the free tour by the palace.Once you're done touring the palace grounds you may want to check out the Blue House and National Museum which are both strategically located behind the palace. Oh! don't forget to checkout the changing of the guards at the from yard which happens like every hour or two.

review_title: Go for the guard change ceremony
review_body: We went specially to see the guard change ceremony. The guard change happens at 11am, 2pm and 4pm. Quite nice to view the ceremony and quite an experience taking photos with the guards.It is very easy to get to it. Just beside the MTR. The palace is very unlike what I had seen in Forbidden City in Beijing. It is less lavish, however, loved the huge architecture and the huge amount of space in the palace. With the mountain as backdrop, it was quite a tranquil and awesome sight to behold.Audio guide is available. It is running via GPS, thus, once you reached a certain area of the palace compound, the audio guide will start speaking. Found it to be brilliant as in some other countries, some audio guides work on number of steps or you will have to key in a certain code for it to explain. Good experience for the family.

Much bigger than I thought it would be. Did the free English tour which is offered several times a day. Would recommend the tour as it told stories behind the buildings. There are no signs describing the buildings if you go on your own. Changing of the guards was interesting to watch but seemed ingenuous and very fake formality. Folk museum was very good and would recommend. Also nice place to cool off at the back of the palace complex.
Good place to see in the heart of Seoul. Beautiful palace and lots of people. We got to see the beautiful palace.

review_title: Gyeongbokgung Palace was worth the visit
review_body: My first visit in Seoul was Gyeongbokgung Palace. We traveled there from Pyeongtaek by train and then subway. The subway brought us right to the palace. It was a warm day. We enjoyed watching the changing of the guards. They allowed tourists to pose for pics with the guards. I enjoyed the architecture. There were tours given in English but we did not have time to wait for it but would have liked to have gone. Water was sold for 1000 won which is roughly $1. The admissions was 3000 won per adult which is roughly $3 per person. This is worth a visit.

I lived in Seoul for one year before visiting this palace. I wish I would have visited sooner, this is the largest palace complex I have visited in the Seoul area. The palace, museum, and gardens make for an half day trip. We expected to spend about two hours on the palace grounds but actually stayed around four hours. I didn't get a chance to explore everything in that time. I will go back and visit again. If you want to visit a beautiful Korean cultural site I highly recommend this palace grounds.

I love this place during the winter. It's simply breathtaking. Gyeongbok Palace offers expansive royal grounds. A glimpse into the royal lifestyle during the Joseon Dynasty. They have changing off the guards, queens gardens, beautiful parks and tea houses all on the grounds. The colors and architecture are beautiful and it's really neat to have this piece of ancient history in the middle of the modern, urban, City Hall area, backdropped by glorious mountain peaks.
More than meets the eye. The park and buildings go on forever. I highly recommend going on the free English tour to get the most out of the visit.

Incredible palace! A huge, sprawling complex of various different painted wood & stone buildings, spread over a large area near the middle of Seoul. Me and my sister were lucky, in that we just happened to visit while the changing of the guards ceremony was taking place. Very interesting ceremony with lots of traditional Korean dress and instruments. We also happened on a day where entry to the palace was free, although it is normally not that expensive.Highly recommended for a nice chilled day out. We didn't visit the museum when we went there, but would like to if we go again.

Great architecture, nice clean parks, very near the presidential palace and the main square /street where the king statue can be seen. Also, you can wear a hanbok ( traditional korean costume ) for free in the middle of the square.
Things to bee seen : guards exchanging places, the palace and the most beautiful thing is the garden behind the palace overlooking the mountain.

review_title: Picturesque palace with lots of history
review_body: Beautiful, picturesque palace against a mountainous backdrop. Loads of history to take in as you stroll the huge palace grounds. The ceremony for the changing of the guards is well-worth a watch.

It's the biggest palace in Seoul and worth a trip. Lots of history on the inside, flanked by high-modernity on the outside. You can wander around for hours. Buy the 50-cent guidebook and take yourself on a nice walking tour of the place. It really helps to understand the Korean culture and its history, and its just a pretty impressive place. At the very back of the palace is a back exit that leads to the front of the Blue House, Korea's equivalent of the White House, where it president lives. You can tell where to go by the guards who search bags at the exit. Walk through and you can walk back in by showing your ticket.

review_title: One of the Best Attractions in S. Korea
review_body: This is our the first attraction we visited in S. Korea. The place is awesome. Surrounded by high rise buildings is a huge and well preserved palace. For just 3000 KWon, you not only see this picturesque palace but you can also see the National Folk Museum. It is worth every KWon. This tourist spot is also accessible, there is a subway connecting the palace. Dont miss the changing of guards ceremony.

Walking along the pathway leading to the gates of the Palace i notice a tree full of yellow Pears that demand a snapshot.We dont have this kind of fruit trees in Malaysia.After paying for the entrance fee by our guide,we enter into this huge garden with old Korean style buildings,ponds,trees and the National Folk Museum.Especially like the various artificial display of Kimchi dishes.Lots of historical artifacts and a great place for photos.In one of the buildings outside there's a room with a display of traditional Hanbok - Korean Clothings that you can wear and take photos with.Did not see the changing of the guards though.Located in the middle of modern Seoul, its a must visit place.

This historical palace is located right in the middle of modern Seoul and this is so cool to see the contrast of the past and the future.The palas has a very large area to walk and a lot of old buildings to see. The big building inside the lake is gorgeous. Do not forget to visit the nice souvenir shop. You may also have a cup of tea inside.If you are in Seoul, you must see this palace.

Yes, its touristy and crowded (the most tourists I saw in my 10 days in seoul) but its still a beautiful place to see, if you can catch the changing of the guards it will be all the better... i think its only twice a dayIts good to take a book with you or an audio guide so you know the history behind the buildings and the sections of this complexTICKETS - if you want to go to the other 5 main temples get the package deal for 10,000won

review_title: A Beautiful Palace in the Middle of the Modern City
review_body: It is a recommended place to visit, you can enjoy a traditional architecture in the middle of modern city

We went off to view what we thought would be just another palace, and it was a bit more. We arrived as they changed the guard giving a good photo opertunity. The place was buzzing but because of it's size was able to appear less packed. Everything is well maintained and vibrant in colour, spotlessly clean and of great historical value. The extensive grounds are well kept and worthy of a walk around time permitting. Recommended
Take a tour in between your shopping to see this palace and it is worth going. Not as grand as the China one but somehow good to understand the Korean culture.

This place was just breath taking! It is huge and the contrast of this palace against the backdrop of the modern city added to its excitement!It has been restored over the years and there were still new parts that were being restored (kitchen area in particular). This small part of construction did not take away from the jaw dropping effect of this place. The attention to detail, from the original stone taken back from Japan to the extreme detail in the painting, was simply beautiful! You need at least a few hours to properly explore this palace - which you can do at your own pace (with or without an audio guide (for an extra fee)) or join a guide for detailed information and history! You can then move straight onto the folk museum which is free of charge if you pay for the palace entry. We were also lucky enough to see the official changing of the guard - which was enriched in culture and more history!They have even built a train station directly at the palace (you get off and basically walk into the palace) which is great for convenience and makes it very cheap to get to. If you are struggling to decide on what to do or torn between what to see - you MUST see this!

Majestic palace right in the heart of the city. Fengshui dominates the place... The palace was built on sprawling grounds and to me it is the pulse of the city. As Korea does not have a royal family anymore this palace is not used now. The palace is so well maintained and cleanliness rules the day. Be prepared for a long walk thru the palace and stop to capture the artistic handiwork of yesteryears...

Beautiful palace with rich history. Absolutely loved the place. Stunning back drop. CHEAP entry, should definitely raise the admission price. Free entry to National Folk Museum.It has a very handy location. A definite must see!
This was the 2nd time I visited this place but it never failed to took my breath away. Everything was so beautiful n stunning!

review_title: A MUST see if its your first visit in Seoul, Korea
review_body: LOTS of history, lots of amazing Palaces and sight seeing places, and also a home of Kim Nam Jae's Hapkido gym. I highly recommend this place, and the famous chicken restaurants around it. Such as the Korean Chicken soup pass the Popeye's chicken place... ironically speaking.

review_title: Cheap and good to burn some time
review_body: The palace is very pretty. Not spectacular at all but very pretty and a nice place to kill some time. Went there today with my mother. It is packed and just empty shells of buildings. The highlight is the free folk art museum. Never the less enjoyed this palace with what could be a tranquil setting all for the price of $3

We reached this palace right a few minutes before the guards changing ceremony at the entrance, so if you can catch this, please do so! We explored this huge palace after that and it took us a lot of time to explore this place. There are free tours available if you are interested to join. One of the must go places in Seoul!

review_title: Nice palace to see in Korea
review_body: I took the free English tour which was great as you heard a lot more about the place. There are lots of photo opportunities and I would recommend going at a time where you can see the changing of the guard ceremony.

I bought the entrance tickets for 3000KW with English Tour. It has other languages as well but subject to availabilities. The tour guide brought us through most part of Gyeongbokgung Palace and it lasted for about an hour, it could have been longer but partly cause of the rainy weather we skipped some.For photos, do visit http://nkikichua.blogspot.sg/2014/03/wanderlust-seoul-korea-day-2.html :)

Must join the free tour!!! The tour guide was great, she told us about so many things that I otherwise wouldn’t notice. The palace was a bit crowded though and it would be better if the tour could be longer to go through more places. Anyhow, this is a must see location. If you are going to only 1 palace in Seoul, this is the one. Reserves at least half a day for this palace if you are joining the free tour and make sure you check the tour time before you go so that you wouldn’t miss it.

review_title: Average in comparison to similar sights
review_body: I suppose it's a must do if you are in Seoul but don't get too excited. There are free English speaking tours throughout the day, we caught the 11 am one. The tour had about 40 people to start with and 25 by the end. I guess some got board.The site itself is not that old as it was reconstructed in 1995 so don't go expecting ancient wonders. But it is a good place to visit to get some Korean culture.

Another side trip during a business trip in a cool winter season,,, getting around the place is quite challenging specially if one is not used to this kind of weather, great experience anyway specially seeing the traditional "changing of the guards",,,

When you get out from the metro subway you will find yourself stunts by the mega old architecture right in the middle of this seoul metropolitan city.It feel like you travel the time back to where the King and the glory of Korean history.One thing that I missed is the brief history or the explanation of the building meaning etc. If you like history means that you'll need a tour guide.Not far from this palace you will easily find the national palace museum thatbalso beautifully arranged.
Its like visiting a studio! A very interesting place to visit because you can wander around the palace and explore the history of the old and ancient Dynasty!

As said in the title, this palace is beautifully maintained. It's huge, so expect to spend a lot of time there, and although we had a difficult time finding the "entertainment hall in the pond", we were glad we found it. The whole place is like a maze without many signs, so make sure you have a good map or a guide. Most of the items are removed from inside the buildings but there are still things to see. It's worth your time. Parents with young kids, you need strollers for this.
We went with our tour and she tell us the story of the beauty palace at the end we watched the changing of the guards

This is the definitive sight to see if you are traveling to Seoul. If you have seen other palaces in your life, it might be somewhat underwhelming. If you have never been to anything like this before, you're in for a treat. The palace only costs $3 per person to enter, and it is extensive. Eat in advance, and enjoy the sights.If you arrive at a certain time, you will be able to see the guard change at the gate ceremony. This is an added benefit but not really necessary. There are English, Chinese and Japanese translations for those interested in a summary of what is happening, though. You can also view the guard change ceremony at other palaces in the Seoul area if you do happen to miss the one at Gyeonbokgung but still are interested in seeing it. As an aside, you do not need to actually pay the palace entrance fee to view the guard change ceremony, which is nice if you're just passing by and want to watch.About the palace itself: It is the largest of the five great palaces in Seoul, although I'm not sure about how it stands compared to other palaces in Korea. It is located near the northern end of the city, opposite of the N Seoul Tower. There are guided tours given of the palace, and I would definitely recommend coming during tour time, otherwise you will just be looking at buildings and have no idea what you are looking at! Like the gate guard change ceremony, the tours are given in Korean, Japanese, Chinese and English. They are given at different times, and each language tour is given at different frequencies (i.e. the English one is given about three times a day, while the Chinese one is only given once a day).The tour takes an hour, and you will see the majority of the palace grounds and buildings. I have done the tour twice, and both tour guides were excellent, and they each gave me different information, which was nice. After the tour, you are obviously free to go back and see anything you might have missed or wanted to spend more time doing. During the tour, you will have time for pictures, as well.After you have seen the palace, I recommend doing two things:1. The Blue House (Korea's equivalent of the White House) can be seen by leaving through one of the exits (near the northwest, next to the pond). That exit is as close as you can get to the Blue House (unless you schedule a tour, which takes a month or two in advance to schedule), so it is a good place to take pictures and see something you may otherwise never be able to see. As an aside, if you leave the exit, you can re-enter through the same way you left after you have seen the Blue House.2. There is a Korea folk museum near the back of the palace, towards the east. It is free with your palace entrance. You can spend anywhere between an hour or two (or more, if you so desire) looking at all of the stuff in there. It is extensive, and there are some pretty cool things in it. I recommend going there, taking a load off, grabbing a drink or snack and getting out of the heat (or cold!) for a little bit.Overall, if you're going to Seoul, you have to see the Gyeongbokgung. It is large, interesting and inexpensive (like most things in Seoul). Come for the free guided tour for an additional bonus.

review_title: To know more about the country, you must visit THIS!
review_body: Me and my mom went there in the morning to walk around the palace and we were surprise that there is also "Changing of Guards" in the front area of Gyeongbokgung Palace (you may ask the ticket vendors for the schedule as this is only appears few times a day). If you are going around, you must be wearing comfy shoes at least and try to bring water because you might be surprised how big the Palace is. If you are fond of watching Korean Soap operas, you might consider yourself living in them because the palace is well preserved that it really looks like you are seeing the past and the traditions. If you get tired just a halfway, please take a good rest then try to finish all the buildings as this might surprise you a beautiful view. We went there last Autumn and seeing the whole Palace amazed me. However, if you want to know more details for every building, it requires a tour guide.

review_title: Interesting building but need the tour guide
review_body: This is a grounds that contains a palace and various affiliated buildings. It was partially rebuilt in 1867. There is a modest 3000 won entrance fee so you are not risking much to go in. We toured the palace and grounds on our own. The replica buildings are magnificent and ornate but there is inadequate description of the history and contextual setting of the buildings. Also you can look into many of the buildings but you cannot actually go inside. We did not engage a tour guide as we wanted the freedom and informality to explore on our own but there is generally inadequate information (plaques, descriptions) to really appreciate the grounds and the replica buildings. If you really want to appreciate the site a tour guide is needed. There are some ramps for handicap access but there are also many steps. This destination is a work in progress as a tourist attraction but at modest cost it is interesting for a short time.

We attempted three times to go to Gyeongbokgung palace. Let me save you time a little bit of headache...IT IS CLOSED ON TUESDAYS! The second time we tried to visit President Obama was there so we couldn't go into the palace. The third time we finally got to see everything. It's a large compound so wear comfortable shoes and bring a camera. If you have one with a good zoom lens it will come in handy, as you can't actually go into many of the buildings. You can't miss this if you go to Seoul, the architecture is nothing you've ever seen. Breathtaking to see the details and colors used when everything was built. Buy a guide for 50 cents, it will give you information and a cheap souvenir to take with you. It's only a couple dollars for admission, worth it to walk the grounds. Don't miss the changing of the guard, the ceremony isn't very long but it's entertaining. You can take pictures with the guards on your way out.

This is the signature palace complex in Seoul with a myriad buildings in a range of smaller sections. There are many guided tours and at several specific times you can watch a colourful changing of the guard.The best by far is the picturesque little pavilion on the lake at the very end of the palatial complex: you may recognise it from many popular photos of Korea. This is the most beautiful and tranquil spot in the whole complex with most sight-seers running out of steam long before they get there, so you can enjoy it almost as if it's your own.

review_title: Very well maintained, watch guard changing ceremony
review_body: This palace is huge, We entered it from the back door the one facing the President's Blue house. The garden was breathtaking, The museum was so-so. It is well worth the entrance fee, because there are just too much to see. be sure to watch the guard changing ceremony that take place at 10 am at the main entrance. I think it last for about half an hour or so. There are so many palaces in Seoul, but this one is the probably the most visited and most beautiful.

This place is one of my favorite memories of Korea. I first came here in winter and it was such an experience to see the frozen over lake and pavilion. Recently I returned in the spring time and found the whole feel of the palace grounds changed, with the greens of spring. I'm sure it must be beautiful to see in autumn as well, with the changing colors of the leaves.If you enjoy experiencing history and olden-day culture, you will have good time here. I personally found that 3 hours was not enough to fully explore the extensive palace grounds and the folk museum. Sure, you can complete a walk-thru under 1 hour, but that is just like a stop-and-go kind of tour. Every palace is different and has its own story to tell. You may enjoy the palace a bit more with the help of a tour guide who is knowledgeable about the history of the palace - either the free timed tours or with a youth volunteer.I plan to return to Gyeongbukgung again, hopefully in the winter, to experience its understated grandeur and beauty again.

The palace itself is interesting that it has a lot of influence from Chinese architectural design - the Emperors seat is much better kept than the Forbidden city - clean n tranquil for relaxing walks n picture taking- nothing much to see except the changing of guards that is very interesting to take pictures with them :-)

It was the first palace that I visited in koreaI went on winter, so everything was covered in snow, was so pretty! I will try to go on spring when the flower blossom!It´s worth going! If you don´t have time you can visit only this palace.

Make sure you have sun protection because most of the areas in eh palace is not coveredWe had a free tour guide, one of the Korean high school students so it was great to learn a lot of the history and culture of the palace. There was a big sign outside the train station for free tour guides which we did not regret.We only spent about 1.5 hours here and that was enough
love the atmosphere here relaxing and traditional. museum located inside is also worth visiting. reasonable price

I will totally want to go back again next time, with a guided tour and 3 hours to spare. The whole palace is huge and not exploring all the corners are a waste imo. I just spent an hour to realise that I am only at one section of the palace! Its a total regret that I did not allocate enough time for this visit. However I learnt a lot during that short hour. The palace is worth visiting! Would advise to hire a guide to learn more about the place.

Nice manicured grounds with plenty if nice photo opportunities. If you come expecting to see anything original, you will be sorely dissapointed. Almost all the buildings were built in 1999 onwards as the originals were destroyed long ago. The buildings outside the palace grounds that house your Macdonalds is likely older.

review_title: the palace at night -- what a treat!
review_body: I visited Gyeongbokgung in November of 2010 and May of 2014. In 2010, I visited the palace as part of a tour and this year I had the opportunity to visit again, but at night (the palace is only opened at night during certain times of the year). Both experiences were great, just completely different. In 2010, the tour was a great opportunity to see so much of the palace grounds, plus the Folk Museum and learn a lot of history along the way. Our time in the palace this year was much shorter (simply based on our schedule), however it was amazing to see the palace transform as the sun set. Whether you have a few hours or maybe just 30 minutues, Gyeongbokgung is definitely worth a visit.

I had a 11 hour stop over in Seoul, South Korea. I took a 5 hours guided tour of Seoul during this time from the airport. This tour just cost $50. This included a traditional lunch in Seoul. I would surely recommend this tour if you are having a stop over.The Royal Palace of Seoul was part of the tour. For a history buff like me, it was a walk through history. Is is the biggest of the Grand Palaces. First constructed in 1395, later burned and abandoned for almost three centuries, and then reconstructed in 1867. Most of the palace is well preserved. And some parts have been beautifully reconstructed.It is a huge and beautiful complex in the heart of the city. So if you wish to really understand and enjoy the historical significance of the place you will need a minimum of 2-3 hours. I suggest you get a guided tour so that someone can explain the significance of each building and architecture there.Hope you get an opportunity to visit this magnificent and historical site.

review_title: Not my favorite palace in Seoul
review_body: I visited this palace as part of a day tour of Seoul so we had our own guide. That was helpful for providing extra information about the different areas of the palace. I am not sure if there is a brochure in english available here like at other palaces. At other places it was 500 won.This palace is nice. The grounds are well kept. The buildings are in good shape but they are also not very old. This palace was rebuilt after being destroyed by the Japanese. I did not find this palace as interesting as Changdeokgung. I think the buildings are very similar but the secret garden at Changeokgung makes it the more beautiful option.

review_title: Must if you're coming to Seoul
review_body: This palace ( ₩3,000) with the Folk Museum within (free entrance) gives you great insight into the Korean culture. The grounds are big so prepare to walk a bit. It is beautiful and has a scenic view of both the mountains and the downtown of Seoul!

review_title: Rooftop Prince drama comes to life!
review_body: I mean the palace from the drama comes to life :PA heavenly, peaceful place to tour with your friends, loves or families. Its soo huge that you need at least 2-3 hrs to tour every nook and cranny. The view is magnificent, beautiful lakes & temples, huge gardens with nice grass patch to lay on to relax under the cooling weather. Its gives a enchanted feeling of how royals, courts, servants etc used to lived. Guided tour will let you understand the stories of every path you walk, every temples you see. I miss out the museum that shows the history of Koreans back in the traditional era & the joseon dynasty tales so gotta be there early in order to explore all the places.

review_title: History you do not want to miss
review_body: The Royal Palace is situated in the heart of Seoul, South Korea and it is accessible by subway. It occupies an area of almost 700 thousand square metres and was built in the Joseon Dynasty back in 1395. It was destroyed two times over the years because of foreign invasion and occupation and has been rebuilt and restored by 2010. The Korean name of the Palace means " Palace greatly blessed by Heaven" and it was inhabited by the Royal family. The Palace compound is huge and is composed of many different structures for various purposes. I was most impressed with the Geunjeongjeon (throne hall) near the entrance where officials of different ranks would queue up along two lines of stone markers on the left and right of the open court signifying seniority during ceremonies, declarations and audience with the King. Attraction number 4, Gangnyeongjeon and Gyotaejeon, i.e. King's and Queen's quarter as well as number 12, Gyeonghoeru, a two storey pavilion sitting on a pond for royal banquets and entertainment are also worth checking out. I was extremely lucky because when I arrived at the main gate, there was a change of guards in traditional and brightly coloured uniforms which added a touch of humanity to the solemn structures behind the walls. I was told it was done on the hour during the day. The temperature during my visit was -7 degrees centigrade and as it is a vast span of land with lots of open space, make sure you wear enough warm clothings. It may be a better idea though to visit at warmer times. Please note that the Palace also closes for one day during the week, so check with your hotel before you make your trip.

If you have been to Forbidden City in Beijing, you will see the familiarities of these palaces and I was not in awe with Gyeongbokgung as I have visited some nice palaces in Asia. There is almost no tree in the inner court and it's really hot after a long walk, even though I visited in early May. Unless you are into history or culture, don't expect great scenery such as beautiful Chinese garden there.

review_title: See it to know more of South Korea
review_body: If you wanna know more about South Korea's culture, you should go here. It has temples, garden and a lot more about the country's origins. It is very huge that you need at least two hours to explore the place. I think it also has guided tours that could help you understand each location in this palace.

Before going, make sure the palace is open. We were there on a Tuesday but it was closed! The palace is in the midst of the modern Seoul, which makes it more interesting. It covers a large area (I don't know how many acres of land) and consists of a number of palaces. There is even a lake inside which adds to the serenity of the surrounding in spite of lots of visitors. The changing of guards is worth watching. The whole parade is about 10 minutes or a bit more. If you are not with a tour, get on the subway and get off at the palace station, the decoration inside the station is very unique. Besides the palace, there is also the museum where you can see interesting things too.

review_title: Palace in the night with a baby
review_body: We visited the palace in the night when it opens up for visitors for two weeks in spring. It was quite a unique experience and very beautiful. Call the tourist helpline to book the tickets for foreigners. The palace walkways are stony so the ride on the stroller would be bumpy for the baby however there are ramps in most places with steps. There is a small cafe in the premises so good place to eat and relax. The complex itself us not very big so easy to cover in two hours at a very relaxed pace. The ticket cost is KRW 3000. Very accessible by public transport

The building is very authentic. Two thumbs up for the maintanance effort. Even it's an old bulding but the cleaness is maintain very well.Try use hanbok in here, you'll love see yourself in Korean traditional clothes.For Korean Drama lovers, don't forget to visit the park behind Gyeongbokgung palace. Drama "Rooftop Prince" took a crucial and popular scene in that park.

Highlight of our visit is the free trial of old Korean costumes and the photo opportunity. Located within the city proper and near a train station so this should be a stop for every visitor. They also have some guards parade at specific periods but they are not really elaborate events. there is a section of the palace where you have to pay but we chose not to enter.

Located on the exact heart of Seoul. You dont have to go inside to fully enjoy the atmosphere. Theres two free museum (palace museum and folk museum) and the sidewalk around the palace is connectec to the presidential bluehouse. Westville and Northville are unique and hip neighborhood adjacent to the palace. On sundays farmers market and flea market opens right in front of thr palace.

We planned our visit around the time of the "Changing of the Guard" ceremony at 10am. We arrived about 15 minutes before to get a good spot. It is very colourful and quite spectacular and lasts about 20mins. Following the ceremony we purchased our ticket to enter to palace grounds. There are free English tours however we walked on our own. The grounds are magical. It is wonderful to see a royal palace over 700 years old. We entered from Gwanghwanun Square and continued up to the The National Folk Museum (which is free to enter). It is possible to exit near the museum and then walk to Bukchon Hanok Village. This palace is a must to see!
Not too bad, the place is huge and packed with lots of tourists. Yet another touristic spots. Nothing special about it. You may want to walk further down to Insadong street.

I visited this palace on a Saturday. If you come early, it is not so crowded. I entered via the east gate from Samcheongdong-gil, after a tour of the cute little area Bukchon, where ticket lines are far shorter and you get a prior glimpse at the National Folklore Museum ;)The gardens are just beautiful, as are the colorful buildings and a little pavillion in the middle of a little pond with a bridge leading to it. Although large parts of the Palace buildings were destroyed it is great to get an impression how the buildings looked in their former glory. Descriptions of various buildings and palace complexes are also in English, so it is very tourist friendly. Overall, a very nice palace, and after having seen both this and Changdeokgung Palace, I would recommend a visit to this palace more. And if you get lucky, you can see the guard change at Gwanghwamun main gate, which is very worth it with their colorful flags and costumes!

review_title: Not majestic but worth a short walk through
review_body: Buildings not as intricate or beautiful and grand as those in china. The Gardens blooming in spring were well maintained and enhance the otherwise unspectacular architecture. The guards at the entrance in bright red and blue and yellow were good for colorful photography. As structures have been rebuild and renovated from its original it appears too modern and artificial.

This is a strange place. First of all it had been completely destroyed by the Japanese (and many times before) and they only started reconstructing it in the 1990s - so the entire thing is only about 20 years old (and they are still adding buildings) and completely empty. Secondly it looks like a small Korean copy of the forbidden city in Beijing. With this in mind it is still an interesting visit as it gives an idea how the original palace might have looked like, if you have only time for one place I would recommend Changdeokgung, which is more authentic and imho more beautiful.

review_title: Great palace with vibrant colors and a lot of great history
review_body: We visited the palace on May Day so it was quite busy but the liveliness was also welcoming. The palace is in great condition with a few rooms you can see in and is in pretty good shape. I wish there was more information throughout of the history or tours that you can sync with your cell phones so you can learn the great history that happened there. With such a technologically advanced society, I think they could do more with that but otherwise, it was great. There were a lot of rock sculptures which were wonderful for pictures!!

review_title: Plan your times to see changing of the guards
review_body: The guard changes at 10, 11, 1,2,3 and 4. There are two different ceremonies. Interesting to see. Buildings were interesting. The country has such history and it is amazing to see this, in the middle of the city. Very easy to access from the Seoul Metro. The directions say 5 mins to walk from subway, but that may be from the platform. Once you get out of the station, you are there. Reasonable cost for admission. The ground can be uneven due to the large stones. Can be difficult with a stroller or wheelchair, if you are planning to go there.
Bring your camera and spend a few hours walking around the different buildings and parks. It can be crowded but worth a visit.

We wanted to tour Changdeokgung Palace on our last day in Seoul, but we learned too late that the only one of the five palaces open on Monday is Gyeongbokgung (which is closed on Tuesdays). So we set out in a steady rain to see what we could see.We walked from our hotel near N Seoul Tower, maybe a 45 minute stroll. The walk would have been shorter had we known precisely where we were going.We arrived just as the changing of the guard ceremony was ending, which was pretty cool. Their bright uniforms are impressive, and they replicate the original Josean guards' reds and blues and greens. Their somber countenances are unwavering. They'll permit you to stand close enough to take a photo, but they won't acknowledge you.Admission is only 3000 won (about $3 US). Though Ggyeongbokgung is older than the other palaces (originally built in 1395), there isn't much left to see because the Japanese intentionally destroyed most of the buildings during the occupation. Restoration only began again in the 1990s. The exterior wall stands, as does the inner courtyard structure and the main palace building, and some smaller outlying buildings. When it started downpouring rain, we spent some time sitting in the gift shop waiting for it to ease up. They have some really lovely artistic high quality souvenirs for sale, including pottery and inlay jewelry chests and ceramics. They're pretty pricey, but they're not trinkets. You can also buy coffee, hot cocoa, snacks.Gyeongbokgung is lovely, but it's pretty low key if you've seen palace sites in Bangkok or Beijing. A highlight of our visit was when one of the staff insisted we "come here" to see what he was pointing at. You can only see the golden dragon on the ceiling from one vantage point, and he wanted to make sure we saw it and got a good photo. We'd have missed it otherwise. We were hoping that most of the tour would be inside due to the rain. It wasn't. Because the rain wouldn't let up and our feet were already wet from traipsing across the muddy grounds, we didn't go to the water or explore the rest of the property.Hopefully Seoul will continue restoration of this site and eventually return it to its original splendor. I'll come back and revisit it.

I would first see the Changdeokgung Palace. The palace looks almost similar but this is the main palace and you just must see it. If you've taken the English tour in Changdeokgung Palace, you could skip it here. There are museums inside, which had good reviews. We just didn't have time to visit them.

review_title: Beautiful-try to catch the changing of the guard!
review_body: My second time to this attraction and it takes my breath away each time. Grounds are clean and well cared for, free torus are in a variety of languages and the changing of the guard is so much fun with the music, movement and yelling! This is also one of the few attractions in Seoul that is open on Mondays.

This is the first place I visited the moment I dropped off my bags at my hotel in Myeongdong. I was here quite early on a Sunday morning and coming out of the subway exit seeing the Palace museum and even just the rooftops of Gyeongbokgung palace with sunrise behind it was already enough to make me feel I am really in Seoul. The gates open at 9am and if you are planning to visit other palaces just buy the palace pack which costs around KW10,000($10) and this includes the tour of the secret garden in Changdeokgung palace which is another UNESCO heritage site. Take note of the scheduled openings because they are closed on Mondays so you have to plan which palace to visit on certain days. As you enter the main gate (Gwanghwamun gate) look up and see the colorful artistry painted on the ceiling of this entry and beyond this gate it is a majestic site. The admission office is located at the right side after you enter the main gate and where you can also get a tourist map of Seoul. They have scheduled tours depending on your language and there are small buidings on each side where you can sign up and garb up in hanbok or guard costumes and have your picture taken. They have posted times for this too so if you get the chance sign up for the block of time and see what you look like in Joseon garb. It took me around 2-3 hours and make sure you take a picture of the Gyeongheoru pavilion its on the west side of the palace where the king supposedly entertained foreign dignitaries and diplomats. It is very picturesque and set in a lake with mountains as your background. There was a lot of people but the gounds are vast that you won't feel claustrophobic. Don't forget to visit the National Folk museum and the childrens museum at the rear of the palace. Entry to the museum is free but I rented an audio guide to get a little bit more information on the displays, which cost me around $1.

If there was only one palace you visit in Seoul, make sure it is Gyeongbokgung. Well maintained and on extensive grounds, you'll also see many other gates, halls and paviions. Time your visit so you can see the Sumunjang (Royal Guard) Changing Ceremony at 10:00, 13:00, 15:00 (20 minutes). If you go at 11:00, 14:00 and 16:00 you'll see a shorter 10 minute 'Gate Guard Duty' ceremony.

One of the main reasons for visiting Seoul is for its rich history, dating back centuries to the Joseon Dynasty. There are fortresses, memorials, imposing city gates from ancient times, and grand palaces scattered around the city. I have visited each of the main palaces in Seoul on multiple occasions. I enjoyed all of them, although I do have a particular predilection for Gyeongbokgung Palace.Gyeongbokgung Palace was the largest and most important of the five grand palaces built, way back in 1395, although it has since been destroyed by Imperial Japan and then restored to something resembling its former glories. Nowadays it serves as one of Seoul’s main tourist attractions and as well as hosting the National Folk Museum of Korea inside its grounds, there are captivating ‘changing of the guard’ ceremonies held a few times each day, which is a great event to capture on video. Gyeongbokgung is located close to another of my favourite places in Seoul, namely Bukchon Hanok Village (a traditional Korean village of old). It is also located within easy walking distance from both the Cheonggyecheon area of downtown Seoul and the Myeongdong shopping district.

review_title: Take your time...and bring a picnic
review_body: All the guidebooks to Seoul will tell you that Gyeongbokgung is a must see, and this is absolutely true. The history of this palace is covered extensively elsewhere, and all the practical information required is in the excellent KTO page http://english.visitkorea.or.kr/enu/SI/SI_EN_3_1_1_1.jsp?cid=264337We bought an Integrated Ticket of Palaces which covers Changdeokgung, Changgyeonggung, Deoksugung, Gyeongbokgung and Jongmyo Shrine. This was excellent value at 10,000 won. It was lovely wandering around Gyeongbokgung by ourselves but our visit would have been enhanced had we joined an English speaking tour, so time your visit for one of these groups. There are seats by the lake in the middle, so it is perfectly possible to bring a picnic and enjoy the visit at a leisurely pace - most of the visitors are either in large tour groups or school children on a history outing. This means that the palace is always busy; however there is no reason, if you are an independent traveller, to rush around and not appreciate the beauty of the whole compound, including the National Folk Museum.If time permits, it is best to spend the whole day in this area as Insadong and Bukchon are close by, with its art galleries and independent craft shops. This is Seoul at its historical and cultural best and it would be a shame to factor in Gyeongbokgung as simply one more thing to cross off your Seoul 'to do' list.

Quite a mouthful to pronounce, Gyeongbokgung actually means "greatly blessed by heaven palace". Originally built in the 14th century, most of the buildings were destroyed over time but have now been faithfully reconstructed. Apparently some of the original buildings still exist. If you only have a day or two in Seoul make sure you visit this palace. The magnificent Gwanghwamun entrance gate overlooks a major square which is also worth visiting. The buildings take you back in time to the Joseon Dynasty and, if you're really into these kind of palaces, I suggest you take as much time as you like. We felt a couple of hours was enough for us but enjoyed roaming around and taking in the historic atmosphere which contrasted nicely with modern day Seoul. Better to get there as early as possible to avoid the crowds although make sure you see the changing of the guard. This colourful reenactment takes place 3 times a day, between 10 a.m and 3 p.m, and is well worth watching. The guards are dressed in royal uniforms and carry traditional weapons and musical instruments. For a moment you feel you are actually living in the 14th century.

review_title: Royal Palace, one of the biggest in Seoul
review_body: Only know two palaces in Seoul that is popular, Gyeongbokgung and Changdokgeung.When I went over, bumped into a lot of local students who were on study trip, so it's very crowded.Changing guard ceremony is quite a moment to see. After that you can take a photo shoot with the guard in front of the gate Gwanghaemun.It is the top tourist destination too. Easily reach by subway orange color.
Had a nice walk in the palace and also visiting the folk museum just outside the actual palace compound. Had a great lunch too in a traditional house in the district just east of the compound.

Was rather cold when I visited in early April. Very large grounds. Even with guided English tour, it was very tiring to walk around. The architecture and cherry blossoms were beautiful. Definitely worth a visit. Comes with free visit to the folk museum.
Surround by many visitor mainly from main land, the palace was well maintain and is looks totally Gorgeous to me. All the scene in Korea Historical drama come in live, and the feel just amazing .
All of it is worth to visit, you will experience new cultures and histories of South Korea. It is very unique and beautiful

If you have limited time in Seoul, I would recommend seeing this palace. Once you exit the subway exit, the palace is right in front of you. However, after a couple of minutes, things start looking the same. There are different buildings that you cannot enter. There is a history museum in the middle of the palace that is very well done; like Smithsonian type exhibits.
All of them are well worth the visitGives some idea of the longevity and uniqueness of the womderful Korean people and culture

Not sure if it will be every Sunday that they have the changing of guards as it will be boring if you goes there without any 'show' or even a tour guide to guide you along. We were greeted by a teacher before we reached the palace. She had offered her student to bring us around the palace for a tour as part of the boy's curriculum. The cute Korean boy was indeed very good and speaks very good English. Entrance to the palace = Won 3000 only.I enjoyed very much on every corner of this palace and after knowing the history behind it. I happened to be there during the cherry blossom and it was indeed very beautiful seeing the blooming flowers.

review_title: Don't miss the changing of the guard ceremony
review_body: This is a huge palace complex where the buildings do tend to look like one another. The changing of the guard ceremony was precision marching at its best. The costumes were very elaborate.

Schedule your visit during the changing of the guards as it makes the trip more worth it. The palace is huge and it gets tiring to look at the royal rooms after quite some time. Still, you should go and be amazed that this piece of tradition is smacked right in the center of a busy metro.

review_title: Yesterday's Palace in the Middle of Today's City
review_body: This place was amazing and quite large (area wise). We took the subway from Sangsu Station (Hongdae) to Gyeongbokgung Station which is right near the palace. Make sure you take exit 5 when leaving the subway station. The palace sits right behind Gwanghwamun Square which makes for a great photo op. We arrived the gate, and the first thing we stumbled upon was the changing of the guards which was pretty cool. You can take pictures with the guards to when they are stationary! Once we stopped posing with the guards, we entered the courtyard and headed toward the ticket counter. The price was really cheap (3,000 KRW = Approx 3 USD). We walked the grounds in it's entirety and was amazed by the detail and the scale of this complex. The cool thing is, if you look toward the mountain, you feel like you're actually in a time warp in the 1300's as their is no modern skyline. Finally, this is a one/two punch if you were to take advantage of it as the National Folk Museum of Korea is around the back of this complex. All in all, that is one of the few places where it is cool to go multiple times.

This Palace is easily accessed by the subway. Take Line 3 get off at Gyeonbogung Station then head towards Exit 5. Fee is 3,000 Won roughly $3 USD. Be sure to time your visit during the changing of the guards ceremony (11:00 14:00 16:00). The palace is closed on Tuesdays.

We took the English guided tour at 11.00 sharp. Lasted for just over 1 hour. Beautiful pictures within the Palace, with the cherry blossom trees in full bloom in the second week of April. The Korean guide, dressed in the traditional Korean costume, with her American accent and cute mannerisms kept you entertained with her well rehearsed structured presentation. Certainly, in terms of sheer opulence and beauty, the Palaces in Korea do not compare with the Maharaja Palaces in India or those in Europe, but a must for the Seoul visitor. You can purchase a combination ticket for 10,000 KRW ($10) to visit all 4 Palaces valid for 30 days. Dont miss the Changing of the Guard at 10.00am, 1.00pm, and 3.00pm sharp. Photo Op with the guards in their period attire at all times opposite the Main Gate.

review_title: Nice scenery in the back garden
review_body: Actually there was nothing much to see in the palace area but the garden behind near the folk museum is very scenic especially with cherry blooming in April.

This was a nice example of a palace from Korea's imperial past. It is not that big (as compared to something like the Forbidden City in China) but is worth a visit. I really just needed to stay on my feet and away from the bed in my hotel room for a bit and this was some nice light sight seeing. I opted to rent the audio tour for 1,000 won. It was nice but was not that detailed but was worth the low price.

2nd time that I have been to this palace. This time, we took my parents. It is one of the palaces that I recommend if you are in Seoul. It was a clear day so you could see the mountains making a great back drop along with some flowering cherry trees. They do a changing of the guard ceremony at various times so check the schedule. It is located so that if you have time you can go to multiple locations from the palace such as the National Folk Museum, Insadong, Bukchon Hanok Village, and other palaces. There is a fee of 3,000w for adults less for kids and you can also get a pass for other palaces. There was a restaurant near the subway exit in the palace, but you can walk to restaurants outside the palace as well. We took the subway.

This is a very nice example of an Imperial Palace. You can definitely see the Chinese influence. It is very similar to the Forbidden City in Beijing but on a much smaller scale.It is well kept and has a few rooms that you can enter after taking off you shoes, that was a nice change. Signage is very good, all had English on them so you could read about the item you were looking at. They also have an English brochure that provides basic information.We were there for the changing of the guard (1000) and that was very interesting. The costumes are colorful and interesting as well.I would plan a couple of hours to see at your own pace. I was on a tour so we rushed through and had little self discovery time.

Visited in last week of march with family. Situated in the heart of Seoul and also the biggest palace of Josen dynasty. Very we'll preserved. Lovely palaces and also was full of cherry blossom due to the onset of spring. Better to go with a guide to appreciate it better.The best part is the change of guard ceremony which happens twice a day. Not to be missed. If staying in seoul for longer time, people can volunteer to take part in the change of guard ceremony. Has some cafés and souvenir shops inside.

The palace is a really nice place and there is a lot to do in the surrounding area. They have a change of guard which is interesting to watch and gives you an insight into how things were done in the past. There are also a few museums near by, which are definately worth a visit! I think one was called the national folk museum or soemthing which is just behind the palace, I had a lot of fun there! The palace has a nice back drop of mountains, very pretty. You do need to spend quite some time here to see everything, so dont rush! Theres not a massive crowd of people, but I went during the week. It's very easy to get to. Very nice visit.

review_title: Beautiful historic palace with a few museums too.
review_body: Very historic place and well-preserved. Lots to see and do here, you can spend at least half a day. Unlike most tourist attractions in Seoul, this one is open on Monday!

review_title: Stay for the changing of the guard
review_body: The palace is pretty and worth wandering around for a little bit, but the highlight of the visit is the changing of the guard. Fanfare, music, and the loudest drum I've ever heard make for a great show! The colors are vidid and memorable.

This palace has fairly extensive grounds in the midst of the city. We enjoyed the changing of the guard and took a tour with an English-speaking tour guide. She was very informative but the group was rather large and her voice did not project well even with the microphone, so we did not learn all we could. Also, it's rather long for young kids at 90 minutes. Nonetheless, it was an interesting visit. We walked through Changdeokgung but enjoyed Changdeokgung's Secret Garden tour more than either palace.
Went on a Saturday afternoon - it was busy but the grounds are extensive and we enjoyed the stroll. Make sure to catch the changing of the guard!

I found the place very neat and clean and well managed. These place have some old monuments.these are pf Chinese style. This is a very beautiful place spent half of your day. Near by this one museum is there from where depict entire Korean historic culture form cloths to food to arms.

review_title: Large Palace in the City Centre
review_body: Went here on a Tuesday? and it was free of charge, not too many tourists at all. In scale of things much smaller than the palaces in China, but MUCH more comfortable to walk in. Definitely a must go!

review_title: THE Palace to visit in Seoul
review_body: When I was doing my research for our Seoul trip, I came across numerous palaces to visit. I told my husband however that I just chose 1 as we already have a full itinerary in our 7 days trip. Luckily I picked the best one! Place is huge, though there were lots of tourists, we didn't feel cramped as the grounds were vast and you can practically go anywhere! We went in February 2014, where snow already melted but the view is still stunning. We caught the changing of guards ceremony and enjoyed the spectacle. Definitely would recommend this to friends.
The grounds were well maintained, its easy access with the subway and it was relatively inexpensive. The royal dining room on the water was especially impressive.

review_title: I prefer this than Changdeokgung palace
review_body: Like everybody else before we went yo Korea I have this dilemma on what palace should I visit over the other between gyeongbokgung and changdeokgung so I decided we both go to both palaces to see which is which. Now that ive been to both palaces I can say now that this palace have much to offer than the changdeokgung palace though I never went to the secret garden coz during our time of visit, March, all the plants are still withered from winter so we decided to skip it. This palace offer a wider selection of scenery rathwr than stones and temples, plus you can wear here palace guards costume for free.
If you can choose only one of the many palaces in Seoul, make sure you choose this one! Its the biggest and the most beautiful.

review_title: A Guide makes this worth the time
review_body: So many years of history needs someone who can condense it so you can get a grasp of what this palace means to South Korea. Make sure you're there during the 'changing of the guard' to add to the excitement of standing in the courtyard of such a grand culture!Do wear comfortable shoes as you will do a lot of walking!! Explore and enjoy!!

There are free tours throughout the day in several languages, two of which are chinese and english. You can check the main website for the timing. The tour guide was really friendly and offered alot of good insight into the culture and symbolism of the palace and certain architectural features. I would recommend taking the tour and then wondering around on your own after. We went in winter so it was cold, and some parts of the palace were closed, so it would be better to visit during a different season. Overall, I really enjoyed the tour.

The palace is huge! To explore in depth, you will need 2-3 hours.I would recommend going in with a full stomach and use the free tour guide provided as there is no drink/food stall inside and not much or details of the culture and history of the palace if you walk around on your own.After the guided tour, we spent another hour at this place enjoying the peaceful surrounding and revisit the places where the guide bought us to take a closer look.

it is best to navigate the place with a tour guide so you can appreciate the history around it but going here by yourself is ok. i think there is a fee but our tour guide paid for it as part of the tour so i am not sure about the charges. the place is huge and as per the tour guide, it will take you 4 hours to tour the entire palace. the place was restored as it was damaged by the war but still looks ancient so i think that is a good thing as it still gives that old era vibe. there is a museum inside that explains the history of korea. there is also a changing of guard ceremony every 3pm except tuesdays. the guards have this nice traditional soldier attire that really gives that old korea look. you can also have your pictures taken with the guards. i particularly liked the roof. very artistic. the place is near bukchon and insa-dong area so if you are nearby that place, you can take a walk or a 5-10 minute cab ride.

review_title: In the heart of the historical center
review_body: The historical Gyeonbokgung is a reference point in the old historical town of Seoul. It is easily accessible and visitor friendly guides are available on site. The daily "changing of the guard", although just a turistic reenactment, is a good attraction for the children. During the Summer, it holds a nice "sound and light" spectacles and the occasional evening performances of past rituals in early Autumn are worth seeing.

review_title: If you want Korean culture, this is the place
review_body: I greatly enjoyed my visit to Gyeongbokgung - I'd recommend taking the (free!) English tour (I believe Korean, Chinese and Japanese are also offered if any of those happen to be your preferred langauge), as I feel that was the best way to learn all the little quirks of the palace and its history. They run twice a day, so check beforehand. Our guide was very knowledgable and dressed in traditional costume, which was a cute touch! I've seen a few reviews comparing this palace with the Forbidden City in Beijing - I've been to both, and I believe Gyeongbokgung is definitely different enough to warrant a visit (besides, comparing anything to the Forbidden City seems a little unfair!).Some of the buildings are only open from April onwards, and since I visited in March they were obviously closed - that was a little disappointing, but it didn't really take anything away from the experience. Make sure you see the changing of the guards - it happens every hour on the hour, so it's pretty easy to catch. The palace costs 3000W to visit, or you can by the combined ticket for 10000W (which I recommend, as it gets you into 5 locations across Seoul). Overall, I quite enjoyed myself!

review_title: if u want to feel ancient korea...(highly recomend)
review_body: if u want to feel ancient korea and their historical kingdom , go to this place.i am salute to korea govermenet, preserved this beautiful palace.when i am arrived at this place, there is replacing palace guard.very recomend !!

review_title: The changing of guards is a must see
review_body: We were there to witness the changing of guards awed us. You can also try on Hanbok for free near the entrance of the palace. Time: 10 a.m. - 3 p.m. (3 times per day, 10 a.m., 1 p.m., 3 p.m.) 4 p.m. only the guard exiting ceremonyyou can also check: http://www.visitseoul.net/en/article/article.do?_method=view&m=0003001006003&p=en&art_id=52624&lang=en

So enjoyed a couple hour guided tour of this amazing place. We were lucky enough to be there on a holiday so were able to see quite a few women dressed in their national costume and the looked lovely. Also got to see the Changing of the Guard which was a wonderful experience. So, try to go then to see the colorful guards and their ceremony.

Althoguh we didn't have time to walk all around the palace, it was pretty amazing and large in size. Also during the day, there are people in traditional costumes guarding the massive front door at Gwanghuamun and many people will take pictures with them although they are not allowed to move.

Gyeongbokgung palace is beautiful. The architecture is magnificent. I really enjoyed my time there. It's really really beautiful. The scenery is awesome too! This palace is really big, I think you can spend a whole day here. You can choose to explore the palace alone or by a group tour. Tips: Don't forget to check the schedule for The Changing of the guards ceremony

The Gyeongbokgung palace and the museum is well connected to the rest of Seoul using metro and buses and it is around 20 minutes on foot from Chandeokgung palace. This is really beautiful with its architecture, colors, several buildings, mountain backdrop. There is also tours available although I preferred to explore the place on my own.

review_title: Great quince tea in the Palace cafe
review_body: A pleasant morning walk in the vast grounds, admiring the intricate architecture of the Palace. Take a break in the Craft Shop and Cafe - We enjoyed a hot cup of quince tea with honey that energized us for more wandering around the gardens.
i had seen it on dramas before. ... but being there was ... the best experience of my life .... !!!!

review_title: Free english guided tour is great
review_body: The palace grounds are quite large, you could easily spend a half day or whole day exploring. We wandered around for 45 min on our own, but there are almost no signs indicating the history of the building or history. So we decided to take the free English tour. The tour is excellent, the guide takes about an hour and gave us a detailed and heartfelt description of the buildings, cultural significance. The tour is not just about the buildings but explains what was achieved in the buildings such as the creation of the korean language. We felt like we really learned a lot and had a better understanding of the Korean culture and it was Free! English Tours: 11am, 1.30pm, 3.30pm
There is plenty of room on the palace grounds to let kids run around. Overall it is very affordable and a nice place to visit in the heart of Seoul
An interesting place, amazing that it's been completely rebuilt. Join the free guided tour, you'll notice a lot of details that you would have otherwise missed.

review_title: Big and more grand than other palaces
review_body: Directions: Gyeongbokgung station (exit 5) or Gwanghwamun (exit 2). I went from the Gyeongbokgundg station and once you get out of the exit, you will go in from the side door of the palace.Admission fee: 3000 won (each person)If you want to know more about the palace, there are free English Tours at the following timings: 11am, 1.30pm, 3.30pm. The duration of the tour is 1hour. I did not take the tour and we just walked around the premises. The palace is really big. Thus, although there are loads of tour buses, you will not feel that it is very crowded. The instructions are far and few. Maybe it will be good to go for the guided tour or the audio guide. Although this palace is bigger and more grand than other palaces, i love Changdeokgung better.
