It is more tranquil and prettier.Anyway, the changing guard ceremony is held in front of the main gate every hour from 10:00 to 15:00 (i.e. 10am, 11am etc). You can see it as an experience. You can also take photos with the guards.Overall, if you only have time to go 1 palace, choose Gyeongbokgung if you like big and more grand palace and also to see the changing guard ceremony. Else, I will recommend going Changdeokgung instead.

Gyeongbokgung is so centrally located that it's easy to find yourself there on an outing in Seoul. I've been on multiple occasions, each time exploring different areas of the complex. The changing seasons add to experiencing the palace anew every couple of months. While you're there, check out the museum that is near the subway entrance.

About similar in structure to Changdeokgung palace, but Gyeongbokgung palace appears to me to be bigger in size, more vast. It's a beautiful palace, worth a visit and do make it in time for the change of guard ceremony as i did not see it at the other palace.

The ground are huge, the buildings very attractive although not original (those were destroyed in multiple wars). Fun to see but not very impressive, there is also very little written explanation on siteGo to Seoul History Museum first (15 min walk from palace), that helps a lot in understanding what you see

Only 300 yen entrance fee. Conveniently there's a money exchange place/ tourist info place right inside the palace next to the ticket booth. Although the palace itself is quite simple, the land area is massive. I like how right behind the palace there's a majestic mountain behind it. It's very picturesque from afar. And the contrast between nature & city makes it all that more interesting. The changing of the guard was sort of neat I suppose. They have 3 English tours available per day...but I'm so glad I didn't join it. It would have been unbearable in my opinion...especially if you're pressed for time.I just wish they had "MORE" English descriptions around the place for us to understand what different places were used for. They had a few captions here and there....but it was few and far between.

This is a nice historic place to visit. Small entree fee, big area to see how the King lived here for some hundreds years ago. Museum is included. After visit you can have a great walk to downtown Seoul.

My family and I were only able to go around half of the whole place but everything was so picturesque! Made me feel like I was part of the numerous history dramas Koreans would do. Haha! I suggest you check the schedules of their tours or make sure to get a map or just try your best not to get lost because it's a really big place. A bit disappointed because we weren't able to cover the whole thing but it was nice! They have a small museum inside so you better check that out as well!

Brings back memories of the Forbidden City in Beijing. Catch the changing of the guard on the hour, but make sure you don't get in their way because the route is not obvious.An interesting Palace, with lots of buildings. However, you do need a guide as there is very little explanation on the way round.Covers a big area in the centre of Seoul.

The whole complex is an interesting view into palace life in old Korea. Most the the building can be entered although not all rooms can be entered. There are tour guides that can provide additional insight. I will say I say this and Changeokgung on the ame day and I am not sure there is that much difference between the two to the untrained eye.

We visited this palace with our combined ticket. Again as with the other attractions in Seoul we joined the English tour which was good and also free. The palace was quite nice but similar to Cheongbokgung except for the pagoda in a lake which was quite pretty. we also managed to see the changing of the guards which was an elaborate and interesting affair and would recommend it.

review_title: For the foreigners:his one is a main palace!
review_body: We have 4 major royal palaces of Chosun dynasty? and actually other ones are bigger than this one.So someone can think, other ones are better.But if you study our history, than you can notice the importance of this one.When my buddies stop by Seoul, I always come to this one, rather than other palaces.(1~2day is not enough for you to see every palace, so if you are going to stay just one or two days, you have to choose the palace to see)This one is a major palace and it was burned during the Japanese colonial, so very important historic site.I recommend you to come here.I came here with my British friend just a few days ago, and he said it was great.

Personally I do not find this palace impressive in winter time as it looks bare. Visiting one palace is enough if time is short is Seoul. Following the guided tour is better to know about the historic aspect . We didn't get to see the lake. Taking photo outside the palace with the mountain in the background is gorgeous. Interesting to watch the guards changing ceremony.

review_title: Small Palace if you have visited Forbidden City.
review_body: It is like a shrunk-down version of Beijing's Forbidden City. Having just visited the Forbidden City in Beijing in March 2013, this palace was not really very impressive. But still it is well kept and gave good insights into the rich history of Korea.

The palace was huge and very crowded with locals and tourists. You should catch the guard changing ceremony, which was held several times a day. Luckily when we came, it was sunny thus we could take some pictures with the mountains background. Make sure to visit the lake near the back, as it was very gorgeous.

Firstly the palace is easily accessible with its own metro station next to the entrance. The entrance fee was very reasonable at the equivalent of around £3 - this included access to the Korean Folk Museum and other connecting palace attractions, make sure you don't miss out on these! The palace we originally thought was just the one main building with a very impressive surrounding area, however there were countless smaller and equally amazing palaces to be seen - we couldn't believe this was all included in the same entrance fee! You could easily spend a full day in this place, make sure you don't miss out :)

There are several UNESCO palaces in Seoul, we chose to visit Gyeongbokgung and if you're traveling with kids, visiting one palace is enough. The palace is huge and after awhile, we got to the point where we were just trying to find the exit. We timed our visit so that we could watch the changing of the guards which was pretty cool to see. If you're on a budget, you can watch this ceremony without having to pay the entrance fee.
Honestly, after seeing so many temples and palaces in Korea, they all start to look the same. The scale of this one sets it apart. The backdrop of mountains makes this one really special too.
Going to the museum on a cold winter day was perfect! Lots and lots of history. Miniatures, full scale, the have it all AND you're allowed to take pictures. It's huge!
It's only 3,00 won to get it, make sure you give yourself a good 2-3 hours to explore everything. There is a museum inside but it cost extra to get into that.

Gyeongbokgung is the biggest palace of Seoul. At some point during the day the public can take part on a traditional ceremony. It's a beautiful place in the heart of the city. Very cold in Winter though.

review_title: Only houses. Should have more than that
review_body: The place is huge but showing mostly houses and houses. They look almost the same without a whole lot of information displayed. Perhaps they can show some information about the royal family life or similar in order to give the visitors a better idea about how the emperors lived here will be better.

review_title: My Favorite of all the Seoul Palaces!
review_body: We visited this palace while we were living in the city and I had already visited two others before this one. This was my favorite because it had so much to see and everything was well maintained/restored. Take the tour as they have so much interesting information about the royalty who lived there. It's a long walk, so wear proper shoes and bring some water if it's hot outside. The Reflection Pond and Pavilion was absolutely my favorite place, so beautiful and quiet. Gyeongbok Palace (gung means palace) is a must see for any trip to Seoul.

This palace is huge! Better to take the free english tour provided there. Start at 11 am from the main entrance, after the ticketing booth. The changing of the guard ceremony is a bit overrated in my view. Same with the photo booth where you can try korean traditional costumes, its not worth it. Try those located in Bukchon for more traditional feelings, or the shrine close to Insadong (forgot what the name was, sorry). They have more varieties of costumes and less touristy.

review_title: Gyeongbokgung - Visit worthwhile for the guard changing
review_body: We visited two palaces - this one and the Changdeokgung Palace. I actually preferred Changdeokgung Palace to this one, but would still recommend a visit. The highlight is the Changing of the Guards, with their beautiful ceremony and colorful clothing/uniforms. We were in and out in about 45 minutes tops. The admission is 3000 won.
This palace is amazing, very picturesque and definitely worth a visit. The ground are also great. We went when it snowed so It added a nice touch to the views.

review_title: Architecture is similar to the forbidden palace
review_body: Ok, so if you have been to the Forbidden Palace in China this is very much a replica of that. Although the guards here are fantastic and colorful. You must see the changing of the guard and get you picture with these colorful characters.

This palace is no doubt one of the most reviewed in the web, however, I personally didn't find it any special.It wasn't as grand as I was expecting, it wasn't as pretty as I expected too. And perhaps of recent restoration, the palace didn't feel like anything from the ancient time.However, the guard changing from 10am-3pm hourly everyday could be one interesting thing for the tourists. Other than that, I will say it is just an average tourist attraction.

review_title: Had a hard time finding it, so glad I persisted!
review_body: If you get off at the right metro station, the palace is right there. If you fail to follow simple directions (like I did) and instead get off at the next stop, you may never find it. However, the grounds are extensive and difficult to hide and hence even the most dim amongst us may stumble upon it eventually.And I'm so glad I did. This was the highlight of my trip to Seoul. I found the spartan nature, the emphasis on science and nature hand in hand, the tragic story of the empress, utterly fascinating. And was fortunate enough to catch the changing of the guard just as I was leaving -- that's a don't-miss.Afterwards I took lunch at a little Korean pancake place I'd passed earlier in the day, while wandering aimlessly ... so that worked out, too ...

The palace area is very big. We took 1.5 hours just to explore. The palace building is quite same. But the area near the pond is very scenic. It's beautiful in winter, it's like a painting. If not for the cold, we could just sit and watch the scenery for long time.

this is my favorite palace among of bunch palace in seoul. it's really beautiful especially for the lake or pond. great view! well other than the beautiful lake, the building looks the same.if you want to visit it, make sure you come when there's changing of guards. it's really interesting

It is indeed an authentic palace but if you have been to the palces in China there is no need to visit this one. nice touch however is the museum on teh premises which has a lot of interesting artifacts from the past and items such as shoes, pots, pans clothes from hundreds of years ago.

The palace itself is very nice but I liked the lake area much more! It was frozen when we were there and quite a lit if tourist. The ticket price was not that expensive. The changing of guards was interesting fur the kids.

review_title: Wonderful to see but not worth paying to get inside..
review_body: I was excited to see the Gyeongbokgung Palace but ended up getting disappointed. The place was nice and vast however there is nothing much to see inside. There's a lot of buildings that look the same.

The most extensive palace in Seoul. Relative to the others this one charges 3000 vs. 1000 to get in, just a relative measure of the expectations.The changing of the guards was nice but we found the changing at Deoksugung was more elaborate but the site is there is less impressive.If you only go to one palace this is the one to go to.

The main attraction here is the changing of guards which happens every hour. Do wear comfortably as the palace area is quite huge with many small buildings and you need to walk a lot. This is the largest palace among all the palaces in Seoul. Admission fee is 3000 Won for adult. If you brought the Integrated pass (10000 Won), this palace admission fee is included.

review_title: great place to learn about history
review_body: It is recommended that you take a tour to fully understand the history of the palace. The architectures are great and well maintained. It is a very big place to explore, and do remember to put on anti slip shoes when visiting in winter as the place can get quite muddy and slippery when the ice melts.
Stupendously magestic! Took a lot of pictures! When you get here be ready with your cameras. There's an entrance fee of 3K won.

The architecture of the palace is beautiful and very clean area.It is said by the ticketing officer that Gyeongbokgung is one part the other palace which is located at the north.Nice palace in the heart of the city .

review_title: Feel the legacy of the Joseon Dynasty
review_body: I think it takes like full day if you want to see every bit of Gyeongbokgung.It tells you once we(Korea) have Dynasty that a period of peace and prosperity...yes we do have some dark era in that history as well.If you want to know about Korea, it's like the top of the MUST SEE list.Don't miss it.

review_title: Touristy, but still a must-visit for its architecture & history
review_body: Gyeongbokgung Palace complex housed some of the most amazing and beautiful architectural design I've ever seen. The main palace building and the pavilion behind it. A visit here during winter when the artificial lake and fields are covered white with snow would be breath-taking.

review_title: Beautiful but not much to do
review_body: Yes it's very pretty and it has changing of the guards show, which is really cool. But once inside there is a couple of nice buildings and a beautiful temple near the back. You can't go inside anything. And there isn't anything inside when you can peek inside. So you're basically walking around the outside. Go if you have time, or just stop to see the changing of the guard and heard to the other palace.

review_title: Fantastic architecture and well worth the visit
review_body: I was there on Christmas Day, so perhaps it was less crowded than usual - fantastic experience and very interesting to see the palaces within the palaces within the palace. Lots of walking and steps which are higher than comfortable for most modern people, so be aware if traveling with older people or children

review_title: A beautiful place in a crazy busy city.
review_body: Unfortunately when I went to see Gyeongbokgung it was raining, however it's beauty still left me in awe. Make sure to see this place when the weather is good as there's a lot of walking outdoors! and getting your feet soaked is not ideal. A great place to come to to learn more about the history of Korea and see some beautiful traditional architecture which I've found hard to find in Korea - but I may be looking in the wrong places. Definitely a highlight in Seoul, don't miss it.
Learnt more of the Koreans and their past through Gyeongbokgung. The palace area is beautiful. We love the museum which is located within the palace grounds.

The bigger palaces in Korea are definitely worth a visit - this palace has tours, and I would recommend that. Lots of interesting details to learn about the former lives of the royal family. The buildings are gorgeous and very colorful, definitely a highlight from our visit to Seoul.
Really great way to spend an afternoon visiting and learning about the culture. The temples were really beautiful decorated and entrance into the museum wasnt that much

The whole complex is massive and contains a lot of interesting stuffs that capture the likings of all taste. Well the major attraction of the place is the palace itself which is huge and massive and contains a good reflection to the royal traditions and history of Korean monarchy and what was even interesting was the guards in their traditional clothing that added to the aura of the whole place. I would have been completely lost at the place had it not been for my guide friend who knew his way around the palace and explained to me each and every stuff around the place and he even took me to the national and folk museum which is also part of this whole complex.

review_title: An amazing place...lots of interesting history
review_body: This was a breath-taking place. There was beauty everywhere you looked. The grand structures of the palace and surrounding buildings were fascinating. A terrific place for photos! The museum inside was very modern and had multi-media displays along with models, samples and preserved treasures from the past. It was interesting to be in a palace right inside a busting metropolis.

My favourite palace out of the few I visited. More grand, more spacious and I absolutely love the pavillons in the garden. Leaves changing colours are simply breath taking and every shot is postcard material. Would visit this place again when I visit Korea mext time.Validity of the ticket is one month so I will take my time to explore.
A must see when you visit Seoul. Don't miss the changing of the guard every hour on the hour as well as a free guided tour in English at 11 am!
the palace is the place where you can understand more on the history and also get to know the korean culture.
The palace and grounds are beautiful. It is a historical palace but also quite a relaxing place and escape from the city.

This is a nice place to be in, especially if you have a tour guide to explain to you about the history and whatever that took place in the palace many years ago. I was freezing when I was there (about 2 degrees?) and the scenery was pretty because the pond froze :D
Great place to visit during winter , the sight of the frozen pond is great. With not much visitors , you will be able to take great pictures in the palace grounds !

It was snowing during my visit to Seoul -cold! The palace ground and garden was simply breathtaking and serene with all the snow covered ground. My gal had fun making snow angels in snow! N had her 1st snow ball fight!! Was here in Spring n 2nd time in winter! lovely!!
The buildings are almost all the same designs but the main attraction is the Changing of the Guards. The palace though is much crowded compared to Changdeok Palace

review_title: Beautiful palace, although it was all rebuilt. Very informative tour!
review_body: Worth the visit, definitely try to go with an English tour (It is free). You will have a better understanding of Korean history, culture and architecture with the tour.
it was a great tour to touring around that place .. but sadly there is no original building , all are rebuild .. but anyway i did enjoy and ofcoz took lots of pictures ...

The palace complex provides you with history of Korea since the early centuries. Must visit for foreigners. It's also had so many photography spots. Try to come here at around 12 PM or 3 PM, you'll see the ceremony of guards changing of the Gwanghwamun gate in front yards.By the way, don't worry if you are visiting alone. Free tour guide held by the information staff are ready to serve you 3 times a day. English language is provided.You can also buy a combined tickets to this palace and other palace. Cheaper than you buy it one by one. The combination tickets available to use in 1 month period.

Take the free scheduled tours (nglish + other languages) available at the tourist information centre (on your immediate right once you enter the front/first gate). It's worthwhile. (find schedules on visitseoul.net website). Also, check out the Royal museum and the Folk museum. I think the entrance fee to the palace includes entry for these two museums.

It was snowing during my visit to Seoul and unexpectedly cold! The palace ground and garden was simply breathtaking and serene with all the snow covered ground. It was worth the visit especially with all the changing of guard parade show. Do go to the little cafe/shop in the palace ground and get a hot cup of drink and sit by the gardens to enjoy the scene! It is pleasantly calming and enjoyable against the cold winter ground.

review_title: Large palace, guard changing ceremony, close to folk museum.
review_body: We enjoyed walking the grounds and learning about the history of this palace and it's kings. Our whole family really enjoyed the guard changing ceremony, and in our opinion it is worth taking the time to see this if you can. After about 25 minutes of walking through the palace, our kids, ages 4 and 6 started to get bored. After walking through the palace, we were able to walk right over into the folk museum. A nice change that helped us to keep our kids interested (and also allowed them to warm up a bit!)
Large grounds, so be prepared to walk to see all the place has to offer. Hourly guards change are pretty cool too.

The palace is huge! The guard changing ceremony is not to be missed, it's every hour starting at 10 AM. Getting here is also easy, just get to Gyeongbok station on the subway. If visiting palaces is your thing, you may also opt for the 4 palace combination ticket (Gyeongbokgung+Changdeokgung+etc) at 10000 Won/pax. We just went to Gyeongbokgung and was just amazed at the beauty of this palace.

review_title: The palace examplifies the Koreans preservation of the "Ondol" floor heating technology
review_body: I enjoyed the feng shui influencing the palace's design...coupled with other intelligent building design features..

Nice for a pleasant walk in the old buildings and surrounding park. I like it because I am a history buff and liked the fact that I am visiting a UNESCO heritage site. This is the smallest of the 4 palaces on the UNESCO heritage list. Can see why it bored some people because there is really nothing much beyond the buildings.

review_title: A lot to see around it
review_body: This palace is definitely the largest of the five main palaces in Seoul so I would definitely recommend going to this one (once you've been to one they're all the same). It's not original but it's still interesting to see what it was like so long ago. This one is also in a nice location for close to a day's worth of sight seeing and has some more scenic areas (pagoda on the water, etc.). It's near the King Sejong/Yi Sun Shin museum as well as the Folk Village Museum on the other side. Additionally, Cheonggycheon is not too far either. The palace grounds can be quite crowded at times. The changing of the guard ceremony that happens a few times a day is a great thing to watch also.

2nd Palace we went to visit. It looked very good and the grounds were fairly quiet but most if not all of it was rebuilt in the 90's. The buildings are still beautiful and we enjoyed the quietness of the place and the blue sky (we came to Seoul to escape Shanghai pollution). It was very easy to get to using the metro. The kids got tired and bored after about an hour. Overall, worth the visit.

review_title: A little bit fake and a little bit monotonous
review_body: With only a few hours to spare on a brief business trip to Incheon I took the train into Seoul to see the Gyeongbokgung Palace. Yes its all pretty recently been recreated so its not the historical site that some reviewers seem to think it is. I'm sure the restoration is painstakingly authentic too but the fact remains that most of it has been rebuilt over the last 20 years or so.Having said that it's quite a pleasant place to wander around for an hour or two but there's little context in which to place the buildings for the casual tourist and the architecture of one building seems strikingly like the architecture of another. The size and structure varies but it does get wa little monotonous.In summary. Nice enough if you've a couple of hours to spare but only if you are actually visiting Seoul. I certainly wouldn't make a special trip for many hours just for this.

Although the palace was rebuilt, it stands on the original ground so it was still worth the visit. You could walk through the palace and imagine how grand it must have been in the past. We did not hire a guide and unfortunately, there wasn't many signs and explanations given. Would be good if there is some brief overview of history - translated of course. At the end of the palace, you can visit the National Folk Museum of Korea. Note that the time for change of guards stated was 10am and 3pm. We got there at about 245pm and the guards are already changing... nothing spectacular but still interesting to see the guards' solemn faces in traditional costume... seems like a real period drama.

We were at the Palace in early November and took advantage of the free English guided tour. The woman leading the tour did a fantastic job with the script. Very witty. The place is amazing, but makes one a little sad to find out it was all destroyed over the years, and is essentially a reproduction. There are many buildings, but not able to go into them. The one building only open certain times of the year. Worth the trip and the tour was the best part of visit.

Went to the Gyeongbokgung Palace on my first day of my 2013 Seoul Trip. The Palace was amazing and huge. Don't rush and go slow so that you can snap nice photo of the place. Spent at least 2 hours walking and enjoying the whole area. You will feel fascinated that it was located middle of the town. The time I went was Autumn and you can witness those beautiful autumn leaves. Recommended if you like historical site.

i like this palace. there were many tourists but you feel the solemnity and grace of the place. it was like time stood still and preserved it.there were few leaves on the trees outside because of winter but when you get inside it's wonderful. the color of the structures. the details. the fact that those beautiful decors were handpainted. it was amazing.most of the structures are closed to the public but on the center, there you see the throne room with the gold-painted dragon on the ceiling... i can only describe it as majestic.going around we saw this park-looking area which was said to be the playground of the royal children. it looked like in the movies and korean dramas. there was a pond and a beautiful old palace structure in the middle of it. trees around. there were squirrels and rabbits too. amazing!lastly, and the good part. near the entrance to the palace on the side, they let you wear the royal guards costume for free and you just have to be there and line up on the schedule hours. you can take fotos within the rental area for 10mins. and they help you dress up then help you take them off too. very nice people and clothes and palace.like a trip back in time.

Nice palace. Huge grounds. Probably better to view in spring or fall. It was too cold when I visited. You'd need a guide to explain what each building is about, not many signs for visitors to read the history
Be warn that you will spent hours fascinated by the beautiful gyeongbokgung palace. You can feel the grandest of the old King here.

review_title: good for a visit - not worth the price to go inside
review_body: there are some free areas - where you can take pics with guards ... but that is enough for the family to handle

I went to Gyeongbokgung in the late afternoon and arrived just in time to see the changing of the guards. There were a lot of tour groups regardless of what time of day. The palace was so big that we could explore on our own in peace despite the huge amount of people. There is costume rental service near the entrance should you be interested in renting a guard costume and taking pictures in the palace. It is no doubt a beautiful palace, especially as the night falls. A great place to explore and understand Korean culture. I would rent a hanbok ( Korean traditional costume) from insadong next time before I visit Gyeongbokgung. It is such a pretty place for photography. Definitely would recommend to friends and family.

There are some palace in Seoul, but if you don't have much time, you should at least visit Gyeongbokgung. There were much more buildings in the palace area in the history but most of them were destroyed. Anyhow, there is still a lot to see and the area is huge. Don't miss the guard change. If you are in Seoul in October, they have for about 2 weeks night opening. To avoid long waiting times, you better should apply online for such night opening.

The main palace, really beautifull. Don't miss the gards at the entrence and try to catch the changing of guards. Around you also have the National Folk Museum which is also nice. Any trip in Seoul should include this palace.

review_title: Transports you to a bygone era
review_body: We were debating whether to visit this palace or some other one while in Seoul since there are quite a few of them but I am glad we chose this one. The enormity of the place is what strikes you when you first step into the palace grounds. This place is huge and you need to spend at least an hour or two going here. We particularly enjoyed the beautiful architecture and the vastness of the place. There are several buildings within the compound and once you get around to the back of the palace you can also walk to the Folk Museum. The Folk Museum has separate tickets and is a nice place to visit too.

review_title: Great place for people watching and nice pictures
review_body: It was fun to walk around Gyongbokgung and adjacent areas talking pictures and observing locals. Although I was not familiar with the historical aspect of the place, it was interesting enough to just stop and contemplate.

The first palace built for the Josun Dynasty. Destroyed but rebuilt in th 1900s. Definitely worth a visit but do not expect it to be as big as the Forbidden City. The changing of guards ceremony is worth your time as well.

Very impressive palace and surrounding buildings. The best time to visit is around noon, to watch the change of the guards and then attend the 13h english guided tour. The guide was a very nice woman, who gives a lot of interesting information and is kind to answer all your questions! The gardens of the palace are also very beautiful, especially in autumn time. It's definitely worth a visit!

review_title: Not much things to do in the Palace
review_body: Compare to Beijing's The Forbidden City, the Gyeongbokgung palace is not very big. I was lucky to see the guard exchange ceremony and take some photo. The floor is uneven as they try to make it as original as possible. Just walk with care. Maybe you can bring some bread to feed the fish. The toilet is pretty clean but you need to walk some distance. From Gyeongbokgung palace, you can walk to Insadong. It will take you 10 mins walk.

I visited this palace on last Sunday and i trust me it is amazing. It is situated in the heart of city but still so calm and peaceful. Anyone visitng korea should visit this palace. To go there you can take subway. Either you should get down at Anguk or Gyeongbokgung station. It is at walk-able distance from both stations. About Palace : If you are visiting this palace, you should take out atleast 2-3 hours of your busy schedule.Entry fee for palace is 3500 KRW for one palace and for all three palace it is 9000 KRW. It is situated on large area. Following things you must do: - Please check English guide tour. It is free and very much informative. - Please check guard changing ceremony timing. It is must see thing at palace. - Visit party area of the palace which is situated inside lake. Take a picture with it. - Take a picture with guard. - Enjoy beautiful greenery at palace. Specially in autumn.To Eat : - There is some roadside food is available outside palace. You can try that on your own risk. It is good.

review_title: Its hard to believe that you are in the city
review_body: First of all, this is situated in a extremely large piece of land. I thought it was just one temple, you arrive and then that is it, but I was wrong. There are many temples here that are fascinating! going in autumn allowed me to see the area in such beautiful colours! The trees display such a variety of autumn colours giving the whole area the most amazing feel to it.
Even when it's busy, which is often, there's always somewhere quiet you can find for some quiet time. I love the gardens as much as the temples and buildings. An oasis of calm in the city.

review_title: An Oasis in the Middle of the City
review_body: We visited Gyeongbokgung Palace on a Sunday afternoon, it seemed as if everyone else did too so it was somewhat crowded.Once inside the palace grounds, it was like an oasis, one could hardly believe that you were still in Seoul. The mountains in the background and the pond and trees - the perfect backdrop for peace and quiet in the middle of a busy city.Huge place, several buildings, so be prepared to walk and walk. Very impressive structures, but could do with more restorative work as the wear and tear of nature and time were very evident. If you are a history buff or into architecture you wouldn't want to miss this tour. We had an excellent guide (Amy) who really made history come alive. Very interesting to hear the story behind the construction and the way of life of the Royal Family and its subjects.I really enjoyed this tour and would recommend.

review_title: A Deeper Perspective of Rich Korean Culrure
review_body: When we went to visit the Gyeongbojgung Palace, there was a fee tour. The tourist guide was very informative and it was a great way of understanding how Korea became great. I was amazed how intricate and grand the palaces were as one gate would unveil its beauty and grandiose majestic sights.
There was a parade of guards resembling the old korean era, the place is small but conveniently located near cityhall

This is a beautiful place, and for someone like me who is a real fan of history, it's even more interesting. If you're not into history or at least architecture then you might not enjoy it much, although I can't help but pity you for that, because you're missing out on a beautiful place. You can go from a typical busy, noisy and smelly city like Seoul, to a beautiful, tranquil place like this. I say 'tranquil' but it's a popular place to visit, so you need to contend with other people, especially on weekends. But if you're in Seoul then you really should check it out.
Very impressive from outside but I was a bit disappointed with the interiors of the buildings. The small lake and trees within the vicinity are quite nice.

A visit to Royal palace is worth and must when you are in Seoul City. Quite impressive architecture in a huge area are treat for the eyes and mind. We were there on Sunday and we could interact with the people in traditional outfits in the palace.

review_title: A must place to visit in Seoul
review_body: This Palace must be one of your 'must visit' list of places in Seoul, especially the Changing of the Guard Ceremony that is held daily except on Tuesdays. ( check their website for updated days and times)The ceremony is very colourful and is an excellent photo taking opportunity to view guards in full military regalia from the ancient times.Rest of the Palace is only interesting if you are into history and architecture.

This largest of the five grand palaces of the Joseon Dynasty has been lovingly restored since it was first destroyed by fire and then the Japanese during the occupation of the early 20th Century. A wonderful example of great feng shui, this beautiful palace illustrates "paesanimsu"... mountains behind and streams in front. Protected by the Bukhan Mountains to the north and fed by the Han River in front of the palace, this is an ideal setting for a royal palace. This huge complex is fun to explore, wandering from building to building and imagining the lives of royals and the commoners who served them some 600 years ago. We were told that Gyeongbokgung Palace is more influenced by Chinese architectural principles (more of a grid style), while Changdeokgung Palace is designed more from a traditional Korean layout.As a visitor, the changing of the guards is interesting and can make for good photos -- I would recommend a good telephoto lens to really capture the colorful outfits and facial expressions. The gate is most beautiful at night. I understand the Palace is open at night during the summer, this was not the case during our October visit. The Pavillion was interesting, though the lack of an English speaking guide during the "reservations only" tour limited some of the power of this part of the experience. Because of its location in the city, this site can become quite crowded... be patient and learn to go where the groups don't go. This may lead to little discoveries.Of the palaces in Seoul, Gyeongbokgung Palace is the largest and most impressive by sheer size. We personally thought that the Changdeokgung Palace was the most elegant and beautiful. I am glad we saw both.

review_title: Don't miss the changing of the guard
review_body: Wear your walking shoes and give yourself time as this place is huge. Walk all the way to the back and the back entrance/exit empties onto the street with the current presidential palace. It's heavily guarded and interesting to see. We watched craftsmen as they were re-constructing more structures on the grounds using original materials and techniques. Entry fee is only 3000 won and worth it.

This is the main palace and a large site full of beautiful buildings. We arrived in time for changing of the guard. We also visited the National Korean Folk museum - well worth a visit and on the same site.

Landscape is very nice there. I enjoyed my stroll with my husband in the palace. I saw the guard training wearing traditional palace costumes as we arrived there. We bought ticket at 3000 won only for 1 palace. If you expect to see the history of the architecture, you might be disappointed because the Japanese demolished almost the whole palace twice in the past, so what you see is all reconstruction of the buildings. You will be able to see only how it looked like before but nothing more beyond the appearance of the building. However, I appreciate the sceneries and the landscape of the palace. You can pay 10000 won to see all the other 3 palaces as well.

This palace gives you a quick background of the korean history. It is a huge palace with lot's of people visiting during weekends, so I suggest that you try as much as possible to squeeze it during your weekday stay. There's an english tour in the morning. Tickets are sold before the gate and you can buy a booklet of tickets for the other palaces in Seoul for 10,000 won.

review_title: Huge palace with beautiful autumn trees
review_body: I visited Gyeongbokgung palace in early November (not via tour). It's very easy to get to - get off the subway at Gyeongbokgung palace and take exit 5. Admission fees are 3000Won per person. The trees were very beautiful during this time and the temperature was just nice as well. One improvement they could have made was to provide more information about the history behind the palace. However, although it was not on my list of places to go in Seoul, I enjoyed the experience and would recommend it to others.

review_title: Be prepared to be awed....and walk a lot
review_body: Its like entering another era, walking around in an unfamiliar world. The exchange of guards is fun but nothing exceptional. Go for the audio guide, u have to leave yr passport with them, tho. Audio guide counter is very obscure, ask around.
a completely different world here right in the heart of the city. Easy to get to and also have the museum nearby. Architectural wonder. A MUST if you're in Seoul.

I visited this palace three times in three different seasons. and All of them still offer the same beautiful scenic view.we tried to go further back the palace , and found that the backside is very spacious. Inside the palace , u can freely take pics with the antique buildings. this place has two big ponds and the one near the backside is very beautiful. Admission is 3k Won but they offer integrated ticket for all palace in one day for 10k Won.

I loved it here - I visited twice :) The first time I walked aroun the grounds with a friend, and the second time I took advantage of one of the free English daily tours, which proved to be quite informative.Seoul consists of quite a number of palaces. I would definitely recommend Gyeongbukgung as it is one of the biggest. The other I would recomend is Changdeokgung becaues of its beautiful secret garden!
Awesome place to visit in conjunction with Gwangan Square, great place to take photos and see traditional Korean royalty dress.

We were disappointed to know that all the buildings were mere reconstructions. The paintwork was very bright and clear, making it obvious that they were recently painted. Thus, I did not fully feel the history within the walls. A nice site for picture-taking, anyway. Our tour guide failed to mention significant happenings in the palace, which added to my lack of appreciation of the place. There were many similar-looking buildings within the wall (the Kings's house, summer offices, winter offices, etc.) and after having seen a couple or so, I got tired of walking to and looking at the other similar buildings. The pagoda was beautiful, though.The site is a must-see in Seoul but I did not "feel" the history behind it.
Enjoyed going to their open market which displayed ocean products and meat products. Enjoyed prepared Korean side dishes, wish we would buy and take home
Though crowded, palace ground is large and comfortable for you to roam around and explore. Gardens and waterscape are well maintained and nice to hang around after a long walk.

This palace is in Seoul and very easy to get to, whether you are driving or taking public transportation. We drove and the parking was 3,500 won, about 500 yards from the entrance. Our family paid a total of 7,500 won for the four of us, and that totals 11,000 won for the trip (maybe $9). We spent a few hours walking, reading, taking pictures, and sightseeing throughout the palace grounds. I couldn't believe how many "buildings" there are throughout the palace, the highlight for me was the building surrounded by the fish pond, very, relaxing and a great place to sit and relax. There are bathrooms throughout the palace, and even a full blown reenactment "outside" (where you don't have to pay yet). We paid and followed the King in through the entrance, the kids loved it. BONUS - You can walk through the palace to the exit opposite of the entrance and see the Presidential Office of the President of Korea, this was pretty cool. Once you've seen enough, you can reenter the palace grounds with your ticket stub. After a few hours at the palace we enjoyed the market across the street. A great day had by the entire family!

review_title: If you go to only one palace it should be that one
review_body: Wonderful place to visit. Very quite towards the evening. During the day, the large amount of people is diluted is the vey big area of the park.It is from far the better maintained one and the garden is gorgeous.

I visited all the major palaces in Seoul, and this was my favorite. Once you've seen one you've basically seen them all, so if you're only going to visit one, choose Gyeongbokgung.At Gwanghwamum (the big gate near the road), you'll probably see some guards in colorful uniforms. Look closely and you'll notice that their facial hair is fake!

review_title: You have to take the free guided tour
review_body: This is the main palace and it is right in the middle of Seoul. Tickets are cheap. I think it was only $2 or something like that. Make sure to take the guided tour. Once you go past the place where you need to give your tickets, there is an office to the right. You wait outside for the tour guide. Tour times are posted outside the tour guide office as well as the ticket office. The tour lasts about an hour and takes you throughout the palace, explaining various locations and giving a lot of insight and history. The tour made our visit to the palace wonderful and we learned so much! I still can't believe that it was a free tour! After leaving the palace we walked to Insadong and back to our hotel in Myeongdong. That's how close the palace is to everything.

Make sure you book a free personal tour guide through the official Visit Korea website. Our guide was very knowledgeable and professional. Turn down the tip we offer her for the excellent service she provided.
I went here a couple times and it was enjoyable each time. Absolutely gorgeous and rich with history and culture. I recommend every visitor to Korea visits this palace.

review_title: A palace with many facets of beauty
review_body: A day visit at this palace which is in the center of the city gave me an opportunity to learn about lives and their beliefs in the old days. Walking through many beautiful buildings & gardens is quite a wonderful experience. I also like the palace guard in their vintage uniform. The place is crowded with tourists but I can always pause to shop for some souvenirs when I feel that there’s little room to move around. ^U^

before you visit, please make sure you check the schedule of the changing guard. the changing guard ceremony is awesome. all the guard wearing its traditional uniforms.the palace is huge and you be amaze by the building structure. if you watched korean old drama, you can see how the emperor palace. its the same.the secret garden is a must to see and the palace which is in the middle of the lake.

review_title: If have time to visit only 1 palace, this is it!
review_body: Easy to get to as it is located in the metro station that bears its name. It is the largest palace grounds as well as one of the most beautiful. Has guided tours in korean, mandarin chinese, english & japanese. Looks out for the palaces within the palace grounds especially the one located in the middle of the lake, and also the pagoda with the bridge on the water lily pond. Those will be your highlights. The palace is also located near the Blue House (or Cheongwadae) which is the presidential palace, and also a few museums and the Gwanghwamun Square.
If you have watched all those Korean period dramas, you will enjoy this place. Try to join the tour, there's english, japanese and chinese tour.

review_title: Definitely a must see when visiting Seoul.
review_body: This is my top rec whenever I have friends or family visiting. This is a must see to understand a little of Korean history and architecture in one place.

review_title: Easy stroll in the center of Seoul
review_body: What a nice place to escape the hustle and bustle of Seoul, It is a beautiful place to spend 2 or 3 hours in the afternoon. I highly recommend.
This place is huge! It was at the end of the street (from where my hotel was) and I had no idea from the outside that it was so big. The architecture was mind-blowing as we toured room after room.
Have performance at around 2 something. ... didnt manage to see everything because of renovation. ... regretted. ...
This palace is very beautiful. The rooftop is colourful and the painting is nice. The different buildings are beautifl. A good place to visit.

review_title: Very nice palace, architecture is superb!
review_body: Having searched the web, and read that it is the main and the largest of the Five Grand Palaces during the Joseon Dynasty, we got excited to see it and take photos for remembrance. It is out first time to vist a palace. I often see them only in K-dramas. To translate it in English, [Gung] means "Palace" and [Gyeongbok].means "Greatly Blessed by Heaven". And aren't we lucky because that day we even got the chance to witness the famous Changing of Guards. 'Twas really a nice experience despite too many people around and with the sun up and so hot! We had to brush elbows with the crowd to have a clearer view and to get better shots. I had one taken with a guard standing at the gate entrance. He was so serious and so stiff. Actually, I was scared at first but it was fun!We had a long walk before we reached the actual palace. The area is so big! And there was only a viewing window where you could have a look inside. I love the interiors. Very colorful and the architecture was superb and accurate. It was worth the visit!
Went to quite a few palaces in Seoul. This was one of the best, but they were all similar. We enjoyed the guards who put on a display at the front of the palace. The drum display was really good too.

I feel so overwhlemed on my very first visit to a Palace. I feel like i'm in a K-Drama while touring this magneficient palace. It will bring you back in time to the Joseon Dynasty. You will enjoy the tour guide's story about the palace, most especially if you are interested in history. I enjoy taking pictures here, i'd make sure that i got all the perfect photos in every part of the palace. I love the way the government of korea preserve the palace.

Amazing historical place and huge palaces. Recorded audio description in English is available with fees. People who are fan in History and architectures have to visit this place. Don't miss the costume change and taking photo while wearing them.
I like the buildings in this place .. actually its worth to visit .. the ticket is very cheap .. excellent view from inside for the mountain at the back
This is the best place to meet up with friend.. i just make appointment with my korea friend here.. and we meet up in chuseok! so many people in here.. and so crowded! hahahha

review_title: Big with some nice attractions and free entrance to national cultural folk museum.
review_body: I think this palace has the beauty of its kind though it could have been kept better. Lots of nice scenery here and there and there are hourly royal guard changing ceremony from 9am-3pm. It's the most famous and biggest palace in Korea. Here, other than visiting, the palace, you can meet tourists that can speak English, Korean ppl and students who actually visit the palace ( in which normally ppl in other countries won't be doing that) and you can get the feel of being a kind in such palace. However, I don't understand what is wrong with Koreans especially those from Seoul. Most of them are very unfriendly especially young pretty girls, couples and man in business suits. You try to speak to them even in Hangul, they will ignore you. Plus, it's surprising that their English are very poor. Even they themselves don't really speak to other Koreans they don't know. Usually it's couples speaking themselves which are abundant or girls in groups speaking themselves. That really annoyed me a lot and changed my impression of Koreans through drama. This is where you meets the reality of Koreans instead of those fantasies in drama. However, don't give up trying to ask for help if you need it because it's like striking a lottery where out of 50 people, there might be 1 who are willing to try to basically help you. I was a bit lucky to meet 2 Koreans who helped me to find my way to my hotel from the Gimpo Airport(terribly bad for tourist). Seriously, if S. Korea aims to earn travellers' money, please be more friendly and improve your English as it's the globally spoken language. Prepare for lots of walking if you are not joining a tour group though. No offence though.  Tips when looking for help: target for older uncle and auntie, and also not so cool and friendly looking ppl. I would say it's easier to approach guys in younger ppl.

I like the simplicity of its layout and design. Temples are painted the same which makes it appear to be very calming just like in a park. I admire the fact that it stands amidst the hussle and bussle of the city dwarfed by towering modern structures.Be there before 10am to see the changing of guards ceremony. It starts at the open space before you enter the palace to purchase tickets.

Everything about this place is amazing: the beauty, the location, the history, the technologies.My advice: take a guide. They will give you precious stories about the life in the kingdom and within the palace. Stay also for the staged ceremonies: it is very interesting for the kids.If you have time, walk all around the palace: there are plenty of art galleries, or just watch people passing by. Seoulites are always interesting to watch!
It's not as ornate & intricate as other palaces but the performances are pretty good. They provide free walking tours.

Once entering these walls it's easy to forget about the bustling city outside. There is much to see in this palace and the grounds are very relaxing. I visited here with a friend who lived in Seoul and found this very relaxing, the grounds very well maintained and it provides a glimpse into the ancient history and peaceful setting the grounds provide. Definitely a must visit.

review_title: The past, in the middle of the City
review_body: The Royal City is located in downtown Seoul. There is a fee for entering and they offer headsets that have a GPS mechanism and a guided tour, in English. I was lucky to be present for the changing of the guards. The Guards were clad in colourful regalia, and even thought there is no Royal Family present the guards take this ancient practice seriously. With the banging of a drum, they march and carry-on, quite interesting. The property is very interesting and the structure are virtually all open, so you can peek you head in and look right in. The headsets provide the history and provide insight into Royal like which, I must say, did not sound like a cake walk!! The history of the Court, scribes, Emperor and his various women is provided (and you can rewind). I walked along the back of the Banquet Centre and it was just like a dream with huge weeping willows and, I believe bonsais. Adjacent to the property is a museum that contains the various antiquities: furniture, clothing, jewelry, shoes, edicts and the like--you really should include this piece in your visit. It provides some insight into the customs and formalities of modern Korea.

I should not say this, but it was really bigger than my expectation. Since I have visit the ones in China, it's not something much to expect. But since, it still make us surprise by its story and the greatness of it.Should come, to know more about culture.

Magnificent structures and setting. One of my Seoul top 10. I actually liked seeing school groups from all over Korea there for field trips, and the reenactment band. I didn't like....can't think of anything.

Great complex. A guard changing ceremony happens during the day, definitely should be seen. I believe this place should be visited with a guide so every stone and building detail would make more sense.
Nothing interest seem like Korean movie look more interest .over all is okey for they mange developing staff.

review_title: A royal palace complex with interesting museums.
review_body: The entrance to the complex is reminiscent of the Forbidden City in Beijing on a smaller scale. A throne room, a hall for receiving the public, the queen's headquarters, a lake pavilion and many other buildings spark one's imagination in recreating the atmosphere of the Joseon rulers. A historical museum containing many royal artifacts and a folk museum of Korean culture and ethnography make for an interesting half day visit.

Alight at Gyeongbokgung Station where the 5 largest grand palaces are in Seoul. We dropped by National Palace Museum's cafe to have brunch before braving through the cold. We managed to witness the guards march when we were there too. We bought the entrance tickets at the info counter for our English Tour which cost 3000KW each and it will last for about an hour. The tour guide will bring you through the whole of Gyeongbokgung and explain to you in details what each of these palaces means.Managed to catch a glimpse of the fluffy cherry blossoms during the period when we were there. Overall, it's really a magnificent place rich in history in Korea. Worth visiting! For more on my trip to Gyeongbokgung, http://jacqsowhat.blogspot.sg/2013/06/seoul-korea-day-2.html

That was the only highlight of the palace. After seeing most of the palaces in Seoul, they all begin to look alike. This was my third visit and it was still crawling with tourist and the queue to get a ticket in was too long. However, it is still amazing to see such a huge part of history admist the modern buildings. First timers should definitely visit.

One of the best palace in Korea the architect is beautiful very similar to Summer Palace in China. The palace is huge you can spend up to one day there exploring the whole palace. I like Gyeongbokgung palace because at one of the corner the scenery is the best! http://loveanqila.blogspot.sg/2013/09/travelogue-gyeongbokgung-palace.html
magnificent palace grounds, interesting structures, plenty of history. also a common filming location for many korean costume dramas.

This little oasis is a nice break from the city. The grounds are massive and spending time by the small lake is a must. Try to get there during the changing of the guard as it is well worth seeing. Spending the very small amount needed to get a guide book is very helpful

review_title: Not to be missed on a visit to Seoul
review_body: I was pleasantly surprised with the Gyeongbokgung palace complex. True, I had read that this was a place not to be missed, and so I was expecting something rather grand. What I did not expect was how expansive the grounds of this palace really are, especially the gardens and peripheral structures to the rear (north). In fact, the gardens and ornamental lakes were where I spent most of my time, and I thoroughly recommend that you get away from the main palace buildings and to lose yourself in this green and peaceful gardenscape if you can.A few practicalities: I visited the palace on a Saturday afternoon, and to be honest the crowds weren't nearly as bad as I had expected (try doing the same thing at Beijing's Forbidden Palace, for instance). Still, a week day or early morning would definitely better for more solitude. The entrance fee of about US$3 is a real bargain, and you can get tickets valid for one month for about US$10 if you are staying in Seoul for a longer time. Try to arrive at the palace on foot and walk north on Gwanghwamun Plaza to get a really good idea of the grandeur of this magnificent palace, with the sharp granite mountains in the background.If you only get to see one thing in Seoul, make sure it's the Gyeongbokgung palace. You won't be disappointed!

Seeing any of the palaces in Seoul is a treat for the traveler. One can wander through the areas and imagine life in times of the kings. During this visit to Seoul, we had time for only one palace and choose Gyeongbokgung. My cousin, a first time visitor to Korea, was fascinated. I personally was sorry that I had not guided her to the Changdeokgung Palace instead. Gyeongbokgung is very dusty and open to the sun, which made for a hot visit. My memory of the Gyeongbokgung grounds was of a more serene setting. In addition, Changdeokgung is of course famouse for its garden area. If you have time to visit only one of the palaces, I would suggest Changdeokgung.

watched too much of k-drama and decided to visit this place. love it because have always wanted to visit the palace and get a feel of it. whole palace was very big and took us an hour plus to finish walking the entire palace. basically nothing inside and more of sightseeing.

review_title: A beautiful Palace Grounds and Structures
review_body: With only a day to spend in Seoul and my original plan to visit the DMZ area scrapped because of military exercises, I spent a few hours at this beautiful national treasure. Great for walking amidst beautiful trees, and simple but ornate buildings. The roof-lines and eaves of the structures were really impressive. Definitely suggest this be on the itinerary of a visitor to Seoul.

Gyeongbokgung (경복궁) Palace, which was built during the Joseon Dynasty, is one of the most visited palaces. Though much of the palace was destroyed during the Japanese occupation, it is still a wondrous place to visit; parts of it are being gradually restored. This palace is well maintained with tons of history and alot to experience besides the architecture. There is a changing of guard ceremony, as well as an opportunity to try on hanboks and take photos with the guards (in their brightly and eye-catching costumes). There is a free hourly tour in English, Korean, Chinese and Japanese with staggered timings. The free English guided tours are at 11.00am, 1.30pm and 3.30pm. You can get more information for the website. Unfortunately for us, we woke up late so we give the tour a miss and decided to roam about the palace ourselves with information booklet in hand. It would have been more meaningful with a tour.While we were at Gyeongbokgung (경복궁) we also managed to visit the National Folk Museum (admission is included in the price of the ticket). It was a nice change of pace to view how life was like in the past with the traditions and culture.Overall, it was a (half) day well spent touring the palace and museum (with lots of photos!), enjoying the interesting Korean architecture against the lovely spring backdrop and getting a better understanding of life during the Joseon dynasty period. Do check out my blog for more photos and the Gyeongbokgung Palace experience! ^^

One of a must go attraction in South Korea. It's cool to see the palace as before this I only managed to see it in Korean dramas. The only palace I've visited when I'm in Korea. I'm not sure if other palace is better. You might want to buy a package entrance ticket where you can get access to several palace.P/s: You can get 50% discounts on the entrance fee if you bring your ISIC card. Check the time for guard changing ceremonies if you feel bored by just looking at the building.

Well, I was there last few weeks during my summer exchange program in Seoul. I have never been to Beijing's Forbidden City, so I couldn't compare it with Gyeongbokgung which tourists like to do. Anyway, I would still recommend people who going to Seoul, to pay it a visit. To me, it is just so spectacular, especially this palace is surrounded by modern skyscrapers, and this makes it even more attention attracting. It didn't cost me much, I paid about 3000 won for a non-guided entrance, still it wasn't hard for me to get through its history though, over there I could get myself a copy of guide book, which briefed me all about the palace and it was provided in many languages.Right in front of the ticket purchase counters, there was a small room where you can find a notice board there which informing tourists about the slot of time when they will provide service of trying the Korean Traditional Costume. It's free and of course you've no right to choose which to put on. Each tourist is entitled for only 5 minutes with the costume on for photo shooting purpose.
Eye-opener, very well maintained palace with tons of history! Like the well-dressed guards at the front gate.

This palace was very nice, but very similar to other palaces. Close to surrounding stores, so you can do some shopping while there. Unfortunately the day I went it was a downpour rain, so inhibited seeing the full breadth of it.

review_title: Beautiful palace- plan ahead for full day in surrounding area
review_body: Gyeongbokgung is a beautiful palace. There are various activities that occur throughout the day, I just barely missed a traditional tea ceremony when I visited. There was a market out the front gate with everything you could imaging needing- rice, wines, honey, clothing, sporting goods, etc. I spent a few hours in the palace and the market. It is within walking distance to the National Folk Museum of Korea (with awesome children's museum) and Changdeokgung Palace. To get the most out of your time and Metro money, you can do them all in one day. Just bring lots of energy and plan to stop at the many coffee shops nearby.

This is worth visiting....if you have already visited the other palace then feel free to wlak through this yourself....history is similar and you enjoy the beautiful grounds. The day I went there was free entrance to the Natl' folk museum which you can reach from inside the palace.....the outdoor grounds were quite unique as there was a replica of what a typical street in a Seoul vilage would have looked like in the 70's....very cool!!

review_title: Huge area with a lot to see
review_body: Really nice area away from the noisy City. Perfect to take photos and to get lost on the area. To get access i recommend the ticket with four palaces and one shrine for 10.000 won. It is valid at least one month and a convenient way to see all the Tempels. If you are looking for a area for yourself you might go into left back part.

As a history lover, this place is a must visit. Korea has a very unique culture and well kept/maintained historical places. Very hassle as there are many tourists. You will have a good time taking pictures and enjoy the ambiance.
Get the self guided PDA tour and enjoy! Plan on spending anywhere between 1 hour to 3 hours. The museum is near-by too, if you have more time.

This was something that was nice to go to. Beautiful grounds and great backdrop of the mountains as you are in the heart of the downtown area. As for the palace, for historical reasons, it was a nice quick stop, didn't take to much time. I would say if you have sometime you can go.

Though it is a recently restored palace, you can still feel the history and grandness of the place. Perhaps I managed to catch the changing of the guard and saw people in period costumes so I was able to visualize Gyeongbokgung during its heyday. It is expansive and from the layout, it's like a smaller version of Beijing's Forbidden City. I also made a mistake of visiting Changdeokgung first and regretted it when I saw the 2 for 1 ticket. Don't listen to the Lonely Planet advice of visiting only Changdeokgung if you only have one palace to visit. For me, Gyeongbokgung is grander and more evocative of the past despite its newly-restored surroundings. Plus, there are other attractions around the area like the Folk Museum and the Innsadong shopping street.

Really great palace in central part of Seoul. We enjoyed the changing of the guard ceremony (in front of the main gate entrance), with lots of colorful costumes and interesting horns, etc. The palace grounds were quite extensive and when finally arriving at the actual palace itself, the architecture and decorations were quite impressive. I would like to learn more about the history of this place.

Palace will destroyed by fire1592. Reconstructed in 1867. Torn down between 1910 to 1945. Ongoing reconstruction since 1990. It looked quite new and empty. The palace was looted and destroyed in the war. Nothing interesting to see here historically. Could be better if there were people in period clothing, making food from old times, playing music from 1500s.

This is THE palace in Seoul. If you are there for the culture and history, you have to come here. Also, if you're planning to visit BOTH this palace and Changdeokgung down the street, come here FIRST!! You can get a 2 in 1 ticket deal, but only at the Gyeongbokgung ticket office. Unlike us who went to Changdeokgung first. (Dang it!) The main gate at the front (not where you get your tickets though strangely enough) is very impressive. Although we learned that it was just recently completed as the original was dismantled by the Japanese. The Japanese occupation really did a number on Korean cultural heritage and they're just getting around to finish resurrecting a lot of the structures in the palaces. So, a lot of it is not the original and so not very old at all. Unfortunately, if you go into these palaces without a tour guide it's difficult to get a sense of the history attached to the place even with a pamphlet. This palace is much grander than Changdeokgung. There are also a couple of museums attached to the grounds. Do not miss the Folk Museum!! Excellent!! We didn't have enough time to do a thorough tour of that. Also, found out way too late that we missed a whole section of the palace compound that was used as location for the K-drama "Rooftop Prince". (Dang it, again!!) Well, when it's so hot and you have 2 little children and severe jetlag on top of it all, you tend to run out of steam pretty quickly.

I have visited Gyeongbok Palace a few times. In my opinion, the best time to go is in late spring, so you can catch the gardens at their best. Fall is also a good time to go. If the weather permits, there is a place in the palace where visitors can try on traditional Korean clothes (hanbok) for free. I have visited other palaces in Seoul, but I think this one is the best (partially because of the gardens and partially because of the activities they have).

For me, it was a must for a tourist to visit this place. It was a huge and grand palace with many history behind. We joined the free english tour. The tour guide spoke a very good english and she was really care with us. She warned us about the slippery road at that time and patiently waited for us since we walked very slow in that icy road. The drink at their cafe was very nice and unique. We tried one type of drink made from sweet potato. We also had lunch there and it was nice and cozy place. The waiter also was very helpful and polite.

it was a great experience where you can see one of historical place in Korea however just only a small disappointed where all the rooms are locked instead of open to display some portray on how was the old time look like, its only the main hall with display of King chair in the middle area. You can see more history in detail inside museum which is connecting to Gyeongbokgung further at the back, this one is awesome, like some history I have seen in the movie. Overall it was great to be able to see it :)
I'm in Gyeongbokgung now and it's so beautiful! This is the main palace. Do bring an umbrella along because it gets really hot. With your bags in the lockers too.

Gyeongbokgung (means Palace Greatly Blessed by Heaven) is the main royal palace of the Joseon Dynasty where official ceremonies were held. It also served as the private quarters of the King and Queen. On a usual day, it costs KRW3,000 (RM8.57) per admission for adults.An unexpected agenda was that we bumped into local students who were volunteering free tour services in Gyeongbokgung Palace. Since it was complimentary, and we’ll be able to get more knowledge, we accepted the offer. He showed us around the palace and explained historical stories and architectural features in English.Besides that, the gardens are designed to preserve their natural state as much as possible, leading to a perfect harmony between nature and culture.More on blog post: http://www.kenwooi.com/2013/06/palaces-of-seoul.html
My husband and 6 year old son visited here two days ago and it was well worth it. They have a changing of guards that was interesting to observe. F

This is one of the five royal places in Seoul. Its a replica as the original was destroyed during the Korean civil war. If you have enough time its nice to walk around as it can be part of the combo ticket and for around 11 USD you can see all 5 palaces. Gyeongbokgung Palace was the main residence and palace of the royal family during the Joseon Dynasty (1392-1910), and boasts an impressive 600 years of history.Still if you have seen any other places and really do not have the time to see all of them this one is fairly similar to the others. What is really nice is the pond at the back of the complex. Also the changing of guards which is free is very nice and fun to see. One interesting thing is the last building complex at the back behind the pond where the Japanese assassins killed one of the last queens as she wanted to get the Korea closer with Russia and thus protect the country from the Japanese Empire. With the assassination the country started to fall into the Japanese sphere of interests

Enjoyed a visit here with my 3 year old and 1 year old sons. We explored the palace until we grew tired from the heat then we went to the children's museum that is within the complex. It is free and air conditioned.I was very impressed with how stroller/wheel chair friendly the majority of the compound was and with how nice the bathrooms were overall. If you think you may visit multiple palaces in Seoul over the course of a month, be sure to buy a book of tickets for 10000.00 KRW. It's an especially good savings if you go to Changdeokgung Palace and the Secret Garden.

the palace grounds are large and expansive with several separate building sites stretching much further back than one expects. however overall i wasn't that impressed with the palace. it was nice to walk around the grounds - well maintained - and check out the different buildings and admire the setup, but there certainly isnt a wow factor. they do try to create areas of interest, such as the changing of the guards and folk villages and museum areas. as the entrance fee is quite affordable it is probably worth checking out - w3,000 each.

If you ever visit Seoul and you want to check out one Palace, (too many palaces can be confusing), I suggest you visit Gyeongbokgung palace. It is the biggest and most famous. On you way to the palace, you can marvel at the huge statu of King Sejong , one of the most important leaders in South Korea's history.There is an hourly changing of the guards ceremony and it's an impromptu cultural event that you get to experience for free. To go there, just take the subway and get off at Gwanghwamun.

The Gyeongbokgung Royal Palace complex on the north side of downtown Seoul is a marvelous and beautiful site. Meticulously re-built after being destroyed by the Japanese imperial occupation army, the on-going reconstruction is revealing stunning buildings and layers of Korean history. Archeology is on-going, and can be observed during your visit.The gardens and trees are treasures along with the buildings.The small palace at the north-west corner, originally meant to be for the preparation of the dead and a place of mourning, is the best presented of the complex. The restoration is perfect, and being out-of-the-way keeps most visitors far away. It is serene and made for sensitive photography.Even during tourist high season it is not overwhelmed by visitors. he entry fee is so low it is almost free.Be aware that the reason the buildings look so good is that they have largely been re-built since 1989 under a half century plan to restore the entire complex. Almost everything was destroyed by the Japanese imperialists who sought to eradicate Korean history and culture.The fact that most buildings are not original is all that keeps this from being a true five-star attraction.You can walk to the main gate from City Hall.

I personally liked Changdeokgung Palace better. It felt a bit cozier and gave a better traditional feel. Gyeobgbokgung is worthwhile to spend an hour or two walking around, but it is large and open and it was HOT. Be there right when they open and you will have some of the central areas to yourselves. Not long after they open the tour groups come in mass and the whole character of the place changes. The palace is closed on Tuesdays so plan accordingly.

as previously metioned there is not much to see. If you have been to thailand or cambodia or other ccountries then you will be disappointed . The building its self is mainly a replica .Changing of the guards is good to watch and the entrance fee is cheap! Worth a visit if your in the city

review_title: Peek Into 12th - 17th Century Korean Imperial Life
review_body: The grounds themselves are barren. There is little to see in the main palace area besides the buildings. But that is okay, because the buildings and how they are arranged is interesting on their own. Luckily, we visited Seoul before Beijing (Forbidden City) and Bangkok (Grand Palace). A previous reviewer stated that Gyeongbok did not compare well with the scale of those types of palaces. I agree, to a point. This palace is in the middle (40%-50% done) of reconstruction. So I think we can cut them a little slack. Don't you think?Our English-speaking tour guide told us about the buildings, their uses, how the royal family moved between the buildings, and information on the day-to-day happenings that would have gone on. I highly recommend taking the guided tour in your language. I would never have gotten all of that information on my own. Definitely ASK you guide about the interesting things you see and are curious about. (Like the zodiac animals on the roofs) There are also information books inside the entrance. Look for them. The tour was a couple of hours and we could have stayed at least one more hour on our own. Definitely come prepared to walk. This is a big place. Towards the back, where the museum is, the garden and pond are nice to see. There is a changing of the guard ceremony as well. You should try to catch that. You can also take pictures with the guards outside. It is sort of like the royal guards in England. They do not move or react while you take pictures. This was a very interesting visit for me. Definitely worth seeing. Small children might get restless, but if you let them see and touch (what you are allowed to) you might keep them engaged with questions.

review_title: A True Sense of Korean Royalty-A Must-See!
review_body: This is a must-see in Seoul but be prepared to spend a lot of time there (a few hours)-it is really big so put on your walking shoes. I took a self-guided tour which allowed me to see the palace at my own pace but if I had to do it over again, I would have taken a guided tour (there are three English speaking tours per day-11am, 1:30pm, 2:30pm). Gyeongbokgung Palace is one of the “Five Grand Palaces” in Seoul and is the largest and most visited. It was the main palace in Seoul for 500 years and the kings and queens of the Joseon Dynasty would live here. Like the other Seoul palaces, this one was heavily damaged during the Japanese occupation and the Korean War so most of what you see is reconstructed but that doesn’t take away from the grandeur of the Korean architecture. The Royal Changing of the Guard ceremony (reenacted since 1996) is a must-see and happens three times a day (10am, 1pm, 3pm) inside the front gate.After you pay the admission fee, you can get a pamphlet which details each building you see. The highlights for me were the Gwanghwamun Gate (main gate), the Geunjeongjeon (main throne hall), Hyangwonjeong Pavilion, Geoncheongung, and the trio of Parujeong, Jibokjae, and Hyeopgildang. There were also two pleasant surprises for me.
