The National Folk Museum of Korea is located on the grounds of the palace and although I didn’t plan to visit the museum, I did a quick tour to get a taste of it. If you make it all the way to the far side of the palace by Sinmumun Gate (North Gate) and walk outside, you will see a heavily guarded blue building. This is the Blue House and is where the President of South Korea lives and works.I was able to visit three of the “Five Grand Palaces” in Seoul but if you only have time to visit one, Gyeongbokgung is the one to visit.
Mostly reconstructed but you get a sense of what it was like originally. Watch out for the tour groups!

Very nice palace. Great for taking pictures and learning about Korea's history. We had some trouble using English to purchase our tickets. Instead of getting the combo tickets for more than one palace, we just got a single palace ticket. It ended up being okay since we were tired enough after walking the grounds of Gyeonbokgung.We went ourselves, but there's also a variety of guided tours you can take. There's a lot of sand/gravel so keep that in mind when picking your shoes for that day.

Gyeongbokgung is a palace which is beautiful, well-maintained and very clean. It's large and was once reconstructed. The entry fee is W3000, which is for me reasonable. While walking around this place, I felt like I was in a journey to the past haha. For people who love historical things, this is a must go when you come to Seoul.

Gyeongbokgung was the main palace in the Joseon dynasty. It was not used for several centuries, and was not well treated by the Japanese. It was a miniature of the Forbidden City in Beijing. If you have been to Beijing, you will have a sense of déjà vu. A major difference was that a small pond in the back made the palace charming. You can think about the palace in another way. Give the fact that the entire Korean Peninsula is a small fraction of China, the palace is rather grandiose and splendid. One strategic episode is seared on Korean memory. During the Sino-Japanese war, a group of Japanese brutally killed the last queen of Korea and burned her corpse in the back of the palace compound. Why? The Korean king was weak, pulled in different directions. His father was pro-Japanese, and his capable wife was against Japan.
This palace is very beautiful, well-maintained. The rooftop is colourful and the painting is nice. The different buildings are beautiful. The lake is beautiful as well. A good place to visit.

review_title: visit to the royal palace in Seoul
review_body: It was really exciting to visit the royal place. I especially liked the Gate Guard Change ceremonies. I actually felt like i was in ancient times watching the royal guards perform so gracefully.

review_title: Massive acient palace in the middle of the city
review_body: It is a very good place to visit. Highly recommended. It is massive, so make sure you wear a good pair of walking shoes.

review_title: Largest palace in Seoul envisaging the long history of Korea
review_body: Interesting place to see the traditional architecture of Korean palaces of the Chosun dynasty.
If you are visiting Seoul you MUST visit the three palaces. They are within 10-15 minutes walk of each other and have amazing sights.

Gyeongbokgung is a great example of classical Korean architecture. It is excellently preserved/restored and the whole palace grounds are kept beautiful, clean, and tidy. Its also not too crowded, and can be a island of peace in the middle of the big city. Anyone interested in history should definitely go there.

history of this palace is great to know. place is veryyyy huge and the architecture of the houses which were all similar are aesthetically beautiful. the pathways even tell a story :) so does each of the houses. nice place to visit

It's a must visit place if u go to Korea. Went there last winter after a snowy night. Really beautiful as the ground all white. Feels like I taken back to decades ago. Pretty huge and there's a museum as well around the palace. Don't forget to take a picture with the guards in front of the gate.
Never get tired of this pearl of Classic Korean cultural masterpiece. I love it there and I always bring my friends there. Such a nice place to go

review_title: Interesting, but what you see is not what you think it is...
review_body: The palace will give you an interesting insight into the history of Korea, but this isn't what it appears. Firstly, most of what you see is actually a recreation, built from 1990 onwards. Secondly, the thing it is a recreation of was a reconstruction built in 1867. The original palace was destroyed by the Japanese in 1592...The English language tour we had was informative, but historically extremely naive. It would appear that the Korean Kings were all paragons of honesty and divine perfection. Forgive me for being suspicious, but I suspect (and history shows) that they were as complex and varied as any humans.

review_title: Magnificent palace and grounds, very accessible, right in the middle of Seoul
review_body: The grounds are extensive so allow plenty of time to wander around. Don't miss the colorful changing of the guard ceremony, mid-morning and early afternoons (check the palace website for times). Traditional Joseon dynasty palace consisting of imposing gates and high walls, courtyards surrounded by covered walkways, pavilion-style hall buildings with curved roof and decorated tiles, and to the rear, a beautiful garden with pool. Substantially rebuilt recently (after removal of some massive official building of the japanese occupation). Good decision, Korea! your history is great. Highly recommended.

review_title: Make this a must in your itinerary
review_body: This place is gorgeous. The architecture is really beautiful and you will feel that you are soaking in Korean history and culture. Do note that the grounds are huge and fairly open, so expect to be walking in the sun (or rain) to get from one building to the next. We also ended up standing in the summer sun to watch the changing of the guards ceremony. Thankfully, we had put on sunblock and brought an umbrella!
What a wonderful priviledge to be able to visit this palace. The MP3 commentary was amazing and added another layer to this experience.
Beautiful palace! Especially enjoyed the changing of the guards ceremony. It's so unique. Very well-maintained area. Convenient location (right at MRT station). Highly recommended.
The palace is very big, beautiful. The entry fee is reasonable. Don't miss the changing ceremony of the guard. I would recommend to take the tour guide or to read about the background before to go.
I love how Korean preserve their historical values and bring it to show the world. From here, I can really visualize how the changing guards ceremony truly was many hundred years ago!

review_title: Historical Site & a must if you visit Korea
review_body: The palace was big, great historical architecture & the landscape was lovely. The place was devided into several areas. We take our time to explore wonders of the palace. They're area's which is less crowded with marvelous landscape. On the left side of the palace far beyond there's a small souvenir shop. Do shop some stuff here because the item was not sold elsewhere. To get a great picture with great background please do focus your camera towards the back of the palace which has a great mountain landscape. I enjoy taking picture's in the palace. Other stuff already mention by other reviewers. Tips :- Difficult to move around with stroller. Another interesting place just nearby (bukchon Hanok village) & only take 5m by taxi.
The maintenance of facilities was perfectThere was the attraction, too and forgot time. It was fun

It is very nice and colorful place. We stayed there just for few hours during our transit in Seoul, but it worth for it. I can recommend this place, transportation from Incheon Int. Airport was quick and cheap as well (we took train/subway).
This place is huuuuge!!! If you can only visit one historical site, the Gyeongbokgung Palace is my first bet! Read up a little bit about its history, you'll appreciate it more. W 10,000 for adult.

I arrived in time for the guided English tour. Our guide spoke well in English and provided us with much information that made the visit memorable. She was also attuned to the needs of foreigners who were not used to the sweltering heat and often directed us to the shady spots as she explained the background of the places that we would soon visit. The palace grounds were clean but more directional signs could be made available. I was surprised to find several policemen near the exterior of the palace who were extremely helpful and provided me with directions to my next destination in clear English.

I visit this palace around 11.30am.Since at Korea it is very hard to find HALAL food, so I bring my own food and eat before I enter to this palace. There will be a changing guard ceremony at 1.30pm, so you don't miss it.You also able to try Korean Traditional costume, and during the time that I went there, the costume was Guard Costume.This is the biggest palace in Seoul. The fee is 3000 won per entry.In front of this palace, there is 3 monument. You can just cross the road and take pictures with it. And if you go straight, you can see famous stream in Seoul

This palace is the biggest among all the palace in South Korea. The palace has been restored to almost look alike of the royalty setting in the past. Definitely a must go attraction if you are very much interested in the history of Korean royalty. There is admission fee for this palace which is 3000 won per person. But they have like a combo ticket for admission to all the palaces in Seoul which cost at 10000 won per person. Gyeongbokgung not only provide you the experience to travel to the past but they also have a national folk musuem in the palace which is for free if you had paid the admission fee 3000 won.

It's been my long time dream to visit Gyeongbokgung T.T we spend more than two hours there (including guards-changing ceremony and walk around the palace). I think the price is around KRW3000. The view of this well-maintained historical site is so awesome and there are some other tourist sites nearby (museums, statue of Yi Sunshin & King Sejong etc), unfortunately one spot is being renovated so we pretty much couldn't see everything. Gyeongbokgung is must go place if you're in Seoul ^^

Nice historical palace. I would recommend the headsets to help in understanding the buildings. It took a few trys to understand how the headsets worked but so worth the information it provided. The changing of the guards is nice to photograph. A must visit is the Folk Museum towards the back of the grounds. The grounds are well manicured and it was wonderful to see the different plants and trees bloom. Don't forget to stop by and see the preserved Korean homes.

This palace is actually a reconstruction of the one that used to stand here. The original dates to the Joseon Dynasty. It is only one of several in Seoul, but it was the only one that I had a chance to visit. The architecture and the decorative art inside the buildings were beautiful. As you enter, you can pick up a very thorough pamphlet which explains the purpose of each of the buildings. This was you can tour yourself around and make sure you know what you are looking for at each of the many courtyards. Pamphlets are available in many languages, including English, and are quite informative. Behind the museum is the National Folklore Museum which was well worth the visit alone. You can enter the museum only from the western palace gate. The museum is free of charge, though there is a fee for the palace. The museum gives an excellent overview of the history of people on the Korean peninsula, dating back to prehistoric times. The signs in Gallery 1 all have good English translations, so it is really easy to understand what you are looking at and make sense of the timeline of Korea's past. Gallery 2 consists mostly of artifacts, which are displayed nicely but do not have as much information in English, so I enjoyed this section of the museum less.

the palace is very conveniently located from the train station as well as walking distance from the insadong market. There are tours in english language for the tourists but only till 3.30pm; although the palace opens till 6pm. its a great place for sightseeing and is extremely calm and serene.
The grounds are enormous, so I recommend taking one of the guided tours to focus on the most important parts and be able to appreciate it more fully. Visit the Palace Museum on the premises.

Very well maintained and lots of nice photo opportunities all over the place. Lots of quaint views of small temples and trees and little nooks and cranies showing Korean houses and pathways.The museum is nice to visit as well, very informative and clean :)

The concubines pavillion is the iconic structure here, surrounded by it's lilly pond moat. The grounds are extensive, and take a considerable time to stroll through. The entrance gates simulate a Royal Guard parade.

We went to Gyeongbokgung Palace via Subway Gyeongbokgung St. where we met volunteer kids tour guide. It is part of their assignment to become English tour guides for tourists. Our tour guide is warm and kind and he did even gave us quizzes (!) as to know our understanding on the Palace history. Overall, it's an awesome place with great architecture

review_title: Watch the changing of the guard
review_body: We arrived as the changing of the guard parade was going on, this was very interesting and I liked that you can have your photo taken with the guards afterwards. The Palace is very big and I only got to see some of the gardens and grounds but it was very beautiful. Allow lots of time to see it and there aren't many loos around the place so go before you start looking around. Don't miss the big garden.

review_title: Looks brand new but worth visiting
review_body: This place has been thoroughly restored and looks a bit too new, but it is quite spectacular, as is the surrounding scenery. Don't miss the changing of the guards ceremony, which seems to take place quite regularly.

review_title: one of the best historic sites in Seoul
review_body: The former royal palace Gyeongbokgung has been partially reconstructed after the Japanese empire destroyed it (info wikipedia), and it is one of the main attractions of the city when you are looking for history. It is located near a metro station, and besides the beautiful buildings you can also visit a museum and look into houses, shops, and a classroom like in the days of your (grand-)parents. It cannot compete with palaces like in Bangkok, Beijing or Japan, but still is worth a visit. The hourly changing of the guards is something you may not want to miss.
A haven in Seoul, beautiful. Quiet and well maintenance, very central and part of essential circuit of tourism

This place is nice and on the day we went (Sunday), it was pretty crowded. Beautiful buildings and being a fan of Korean historical dramas, it gave me a better glimpse into old Korea. Great place to bring the family as my niece and nephew enjoyed exploring the place.

Its a beautiful palace, I did a lot of walking here, especially with my husband is so romantic. When the royal guard changing their shift, it was interesting to watch as they played drum and some other kind of traditional music tools. Its a big place, if you intend to travel during summer time, remember to bring your hat.
Beautiful palace!Caught the subway there - breathtaking first view!Also, the first sight of the Gyeonghoeru Pavillion takes your breath awayTry to catch the changing of the guard

review_title: If you only have time for one palace, go for this one.
review_body: If you only have time for one palace, go for this one. The royal guard changing ceremony is fun to watch. There's a folk museum (or something like that which I did not visit) that my friend told me was fun having hands-on playing traditional craft. The gardens are pleasant to have a picnic in. Walk all the way to the back and you're see the Blue House from a far. There isn't much furniture in each palace though. But this palace is grander as compared to another I visited. Clear informative guide book given free at the entrance. There are free english tours at certain time slots that does a good job introducing the little details of the architecture.

review_title: Huge palace with lots of impressive buildings
review_body: My friend and I actually only planned 2 hours for Gyeongbokgung but turned out there wasn't enough time because the palace was HUGE!xD there were lots of buildings to visit and i don't think we finished walking the entire area because our feet were already sore from all the walking..haha. We walked around the palace without a guide but if you would like to know more about the palace and its history, it would be good to get one..they have Korean, Japanese, Chinese and English guides during certain time slots. If you're a fan of places with rich history and culture, then this place must not be missed!:)
Royal Guard Changing Ceremony that takes place only twice a day was fantiastic. The 3 museums in the palace were the among the best in the world and they were free.

This palace is large and has everything, including impressive buildings and enchanting pavilions. just let your imagination run. excellent with children, who can have breaks (with treats) by the Gyeonghoeru Pavilion pool and at the children museum. No need for a guided tour, and I would skip the unnecessary National Folk Museum of Korea (unless you're aiming for the children museum) and National Palace Museum of Korea.I used the exit through the National Folk Museum, and went up samcheong-ro towards the traditional houses of Hwa-Dong - it's a steep incline that's worth the effort.
Came at 10-is only to find out that the changing of the royal palace guard ceremony was taking place. Overall, a nice place to have a feel of the olden days.

This is a huge complex (probably the biggest of all palaces), with palace buildings, gardens, huge entry gate and guard parade. Very interesting and the view of the entry gate with the mountain in the background is good. The national folk museum is also situated in the grounds and is worth a look and was free at the time I went. Also if you go south of the gate along the central promenade of Sejongno Road, you will see Statues of the King and Admiral Yi. There is a free underground museum (entry at King's statue). Definitely worth visiting, especially the Admiral Yi exhibit.

review_title: Must See History... but all rebuilt
review_body: The Gyeongbokgung Palace is truly the crown jewel. Impressive 14c history and site. The entire site is dedicated to the museum. The most impressive part is the views... to the North, beautiful mountain views and the tops of the palace, same as 600 years ago. To the south, the modern skyline.Changing of the guards, on the hour, is impressive.The only downside is that the Palace is all recently rebuilt, so the buildings are 'too good to be true'. The restorations are very well done and still definitely worth the visit.Only 3 USD to enjoy, an extra 1 USD for electronic tour. Visited June 2013

review_title: recommend to go along with a guide
review_body: a very big palace and lots of walking required. not all the rooms and halls are opened for visitors to peek in. i recommend to go with a guide so that there is someone to explain about the history and stories behind the different areas. it was not so interesting reading off from the brochure yourself. there is a lot of tourists around so you might want to skip this place if you dislike crowds.
A big and grand palace with many buildings. There's also a change of guards parade at the entrance. Guided tours are available.

review_title: For first time travelers to Korea
review_body: If you are a first time traveler to Korea, it is a must to stop by this palace. Although it can be packed by tourists, they usually stay near the entrance. The whole complex is huge so you can explore if you have a lot of time.

Took a free guided tour offered by the city of Seoul and was pleased that it was only the tour guide and myself. After having visited ChangGyeongGung and ChangDeokGung (the two palaces east of GyeongBokGung) this palace was nice but extremely crowded on a Monday morning. Changing of the guards and visiting some of the buildings were nice, but again way too crowded.

review_title: old in the middle of modern, fascinating
review_body: This place is beautiful. I would like to have done a tour, but we visited as a last minute decision. So glad we did. I would recommend a guided tour if you can as we saw groups being guided into areas that others were not allowed to go. And I'm sure there are many stories to be told. The changing of the guards was interesting, and their weapons were something else.Seeing the very modern and chaotic Seoul outside of the palace is such a contrast. We were approached by some very friendly Korean locals who were so charming.Lots of walking to be had, so if you are limited with your abilities, you may want to organise a wheelchair, or accept that you may be limited with what you may see.We went on a sunny day (take sunscreen as there is little shade whilst walking around) and it was just beautiful, but I imagine it would be just as pretty in the middle of winter.Great photo opportunities here.As a side note... outside the palace a man sold me the best pineapple I have ever eaten in my life!!! It was a slice on a stick and was divine. You may need a napkin handy, as it is sooo juicy.

Go there early. It can get very hot in the afternoon. The palaces are not lavish but artistic and beautiful. Wish they had more facilities like drinking water fountain, benches etc. Changing guard ceremony is OK. Try pumpkin candy outside. Try taking the college student guides with you.

review_title: ancient in the middle of modern city
review_body: what a i love about this place is its location. located strategically in the middle of city, the hustle and bustle city.. so sad to listen their story.. they actually have a hundred building but during the war, it left only 10 building which 2 of the building are still original building. if you need tour guide, just wait in front of the tourist information at 11am for English tour guide. it takes one hour tour around the palace.. please prepare yourself with hat, sunblock, or anything could protect you from the sun.. you can see the changing guard in this palace starts at 10am, it takes 30min..

This old palace complex was quite huge and it was located right in the city. The wooden arches and buildings were beautifully carved and decorated. They were simply magnificent. Our tour guide Jenny gave us a superb history of the old Korean royalty and how they lived. So if you are interested in Korean royalty and cultural history, this place is a must

review_title: Huge place with wonderful scenery and waters!
review_body: A must visit. Just go for a walk around the lakes! Fish can be seen everywhere.... Many places to go through

Entrance ticket is only 3,000W, a fairly reasonable amount considering the effort they put in to maintain and restore the entire premise. Do try to catch the free English tour 3 times daily. I think it's 11am, 130pm and 330pm. THINK. My guide spoke pretty good English and provided a thorough explanation of the history of Gyeongbokgung palace. I do not recommend taking a self-guided tour around the palace as much of the information and history of the place will not be found !

Visited this place at the guided tour. It was worth. You can feel history and enjoy your visit even if day is hot. Was impressed to see heating system in old Korean buildings. Park was very nice place as well. Guardians show even could be more impressive as I ever seen. Colourful procedure, interesting show.

This palace teaches you a little more about Korean cultural in the early day. We were on a tour but it was hard to hear the tour guide and too many people to see some of the attractions there. I did enjoy learning more about Korea.

review_title: Must visit place if you're in SEOUL
review_body: At first I cant believe that such traditional and serene palace is exist in the middle of the busy Seoul. Inside this Palace complex there is a lot of other traditional building to see. If you love photography you would love this place. The palace building is huge with an authentic decoration. Also there is a lot of garden with beautiful scenery. Overall the palace complex is good and very attractive.

We were fortunate enough to visit the Palace when they lit up the place and allow visitors to come at night, so we spent half a day and the evening there. It was quite an experience as the Palace was packed with people. The Palace area is huge and the buildings are pretty however some may find the palace rather 'empty' and I do prefer Changdeokgung. The changing guards was quite fun to watch. For a good walk, go to Gwanghwamun Square and walk towards the Palace.

review_title: Beautiful Gardens and Changing of the Guards!
review_body: We made a quick stop here to really watch the changing of the guards which is a must see but I was really taken aback by the beautiful gardens here. If you have time you should check out the garden especially near the Queen's chambers which makes you feel like you're in an old love story.

Five six footer tall Korean guard will greet you at the front gate, faces are straight tough looking and their hands holding five different weapons will make you to expect more, and the huge tall gate with dragon designs gave me an excitement to see what's inside but as the time goes by and gets inside the first palace all I saw is green and it's clean, for me it's like park not a palace, but it's good looking park though. My advice is just don't expect more, I'd rather like the look of the small hanok villages than the big palace with nothing inside.
hit it up if you're in Seoul. lots of room to walk around and look at historical buildings. There are cultural activities on weekends as well

In the entire leadup to our Korea trip, Gyeongbokgung seemed like it would be THE palace to visit. Strangely enough, I feel like it may have been the one that we least explored. That may be due to the enormous size of the palace grounds. I also wasted too much time photographing the front areas of the palace and underestimated how much time was left in the day. You can really spend hours at Gyeongbokgung just relaxing in the various areas the palace has to offer.While we were in front by Gwanghwamun gate, we saw some sort of guard ceremony. At the time, I thought it was their "changing of the guard," but now that I'm seeing Youtube videos of the full ceremony, it can't have been it. Luckily, we caught the full "changing of the guard" at Deoksugung, so I'm good on that.Based on my limited anecdotal knowledge, it seems like Gyeongbokgung is the most popular palace to visit. It's right off the main city square and it has the impressive Gwanghwamun gate to mark the main entrance. If you can only visit one palace, I'd probably recommend Changdeokgung with its beautiful Secret Garden and slightly smaller crowds. However, Gyeongbokgung is enormous and impressive. You can't go wrong either way. Go see them both!

This is largest palace in Seoul, although maybe not the prettiest, but as this was the prime palace of Yi dynasty, it is worth every bit a visit. They also have several changing of guards ceremony which is interesting. Nearby there is a palace museum.
A must see in Seoul. A great insight in Korean past with monumental building in combination with small more intimate locations.

Great place to spend 1-2 hours roaming around in this beautiful palace. Do catch the guards changing ceremony (earliest at 10am). This place offers many spots for nice photos! Gyeongbokgung Palace Station (Seoul Subway Line 3), Exit 5.

We didn't do all the palaces of Seoul, but if you are going to do one of them it should be this one. Not on the scale of Forbidden City in Beijing, but still very impressive.Again very cheap entry fee, free 1 hour tour guides in different languages which was very informative, and the changing of the guard which is definitely worth the wait (many of these throughout the day) and great for photo ops with historical dressed soldiers.Next to this are 2 museums (Folk and the Palace museum). Both are interesting and depends if you have time in your schedule. Folk is included in Palace ticket.

The grandest of all five palaces in Seoul. Remember to take brochure near the entrance. There is free guided tour (in english, japanese, chinese) but the chinese speaking guide that we followed was too soft speaking, barely could hear what she said even she spoke with amplifier, so i suggest to walk on your own with a brochure. Sad that i was too engrossed walking around taking pictures & forgot to refer back to the brochure for understanding the details of the palace.Things to do: 1. Try hanbok for free. Need to register & wait for your turn. Closed during  lunch hour. Can try posing & taking pictures with the guards wearing  hanbok.2. Watch the guards changing ceremony every hour from 10am-4pm. All the  guards are really tall & fit. So funny that my nephew was so intimidated by  the guards that he asked me to carry him haha.
Very interesting place with many things to see. To hire a guide would not be a bad idea, otherwise one can read all in the travel guide.

Having just visited Gyeongbokgung while on a short holiday break in Seoul last week, I would say its a worthwhile visit historically.The entire infrastructure and size is comparable to Beijing's Forbidden Palace, though internally, many of the rooms are similar after a while. I have always have an interest in Korean historical artefacts, so while internally, it is not as elaborate in terms of design and ornaments decoration, the feel of how the royal palace was like in its heydays is still pretty interesting. Like all huge palaces, there are a labyrinth of the walkways, and it is easy to get lost if you are not following a map of the place.Be prepared for an average of 3 hours exploratory walk, if you are intending to cover the entire area. While there, be sure to visit the National Arts Museum, and the National Palace Musuem. A visit to both, together with the palace, gives a very good insight to the lifestyle of Korea during the Joseon dynasty period.

The first place I visited during my trip to Korea. Nice palace and definitely a must-visit in Korea.Too bad that I went during rainy day. The weather is so cold and the ground is a little bit muddy and we need to find a shelter inside a coffee shop to warm ourselves up.We missed out the guards changing ceremony as we were late. Anyway, we still able to see the guards changing their position and marching a little, not too shabby.

If you are a first time visitor in Seoul, then it's a must see. they have guard change every hour. the whole complex is huge so get about 3 hours in there...you can also visit the Korean folk museum, national palace museum, and blue house (presidential office) right next to it.

review_title: The Palace which is destroyed and build again and again
review_body: A true exmple of Korean spirit of persistance, perseverance and art.Huge wooden structures.....nicely decorated place yet exhibiting simplycity of Korean Emperors.They keep organising cutural shows there dipicting ancient traditions and stories as well. Which makes it a must go attraction in seoul.Nicely Managed place.......be ready to walk a long stretch to cover every part of it.

Access to this palace was very easy - just get off at the Gyeongbokgung subway station exit and its big entrance is right there.The palace structures were huge and the grounds were expansive.I particularly liked a spot near a small temple surrounded by water with swans. I can sit there for hours just taking the beauty of the whole place all in.

A must-see if you into history or culture. We visited in the morning and joined one of the few guided tours in English. Come here if you wish to learn about history and view the palace and ancient artifactsTips:The English tours are limited to a few timings per day so do plan ahead. The palace is a 10-15 min walk from the train station. You can't see it from the station but it is not difficult to find your way there.

Gyeongbokgung, the "Palace Greatly Blessed by Heaven" is one of the "must visit" attractions in Seoul. It is centrally located in the heart of Seoul and can be covered in half a day with the nearby Gwanghwamun Square, Admiral Yi Sun Shin Monument, King Sejong Memorial Hall and the Cheonggyecheon Stream.The nearest subway is the Gyeongbokgung Station at exit 5. We didn't use the subway. We were at Insadong, and we walked for about 10 minutes from Ssamji-gil and arrived at the Gwanghwamun Gate around 2:50 pm.At the time of our arrival, there is no "Changing of the Guards Ceremony". We were not disappointed because the tall Imperial Guards standing at the arched gateway in their costumes make awesome photos. Admission tickets at 3,000won each are purchased inside the grounds and you can photograph these guards or watch the changing ceremonies at the Gwanghwamun Gate for free without purchasing admission tickets.Free guided tour starts at the reception office inside Heungnyemun Gate. English tours are at 11.00am, 1.30pm and 3.30pm. Groups of 10 to 30 people require reservation. It is advisable to use a guide otherwise you'll be walking around and snapping pictures without a clue of what you are looking or photographing at.The Gyeongbokgung Palace has some Chinese architectural influence and it reminded us of the Forbidden City in Beijing. There are some cherry blossoms here and it was said that the Japanese, during their occupation, had planted some of the trees on sacred and offensive locations within the palace ground. After the occupation, these offending trees were destroyed. But today, the remaining cherry blossoms add a softer touch to the Palace and provide a lovely landscape.Gyeongbokgung Palace is a huge complex consisting of many areas, pavilions, ponds, halls, chambers and gates and will need about 2 to 3 hours of your time. The hexagonal Hyangwonjeong Pavilion looks impressive and it was a pity they barricaded the bridge to prevent entry. It could only be admired from across the pond. Hyangwonjeong Pavilion will look best during autumn.Lockers are available and smoking is not allowed anywhere in the palace area, except at designated sites.Date of visit: 19 April, 2013Season: SpringTemperature: 12°C

We only went to one palace and we chose Gyeongbokgung cos the reviews said that this was the most majestic :) We went early, just before 0900hrs. Taxis will drop you by the side entrance, but do walk to the front (Gwanghwamun Gate) for the changing of guards. There's a few museums within the area, the National Folk Museum which we went to and the palace itself was pretty interesting. For those who like architecture, its pretty great :)

This is one of the bigger palaces in Seoul. One could easily spend 2-3 hours walking around. They have Guided tours every couple of hours till about 3:30pm. If you miss this, definitely get an audio guide, it could get a bit confusing without one. Changing of Guards ceremony happens 10 - 3pm every couple of hours, dont miss it! The National Folk Museum located inside is a must visit if you are interested in knowing a bit more about their History, Culture & Traditions.

This Korean architecture of this expansive palace contrasts markedly with the contemporary Seoul skyscrapers. One highlight is the hourly changing of the guard parade. There's an English tour conducted periodically which is essential if you want to understand what the place is all about. I believe they also have an audio tour available as an alternative. Well worth seeing to get a flavor of Korean history and culture. There were surprisingly few westerners there when we visited.
Superb architecture. Very interesting mix of buildings, gardens and temples. It has a good restaurant and is just besides a metro station.

Very attractive place and of course it's one of the list of a must go in Seoul. Easy to reach and sparkling place to visit. Very helpful staff and nice people too. Don't know why I saw so many Thai people, even wonder if I were in the wrong country. I like the soldiers in the fancy old style clothes just like in the dramas. Good for all generations!

It was supposed to be grand but despite the vastness and a couple of displays of the old settings of the palace, I came away without feeling impressed. It did cross my mind what a big place for the workers to get from place to place in the compound.

Arrived there at 10AM and caught the Changing of the Guards. There is even a small free brochure, in English, about this event.At 11AM there was the English tour. This really added interest with the new perspective on the Palace and its place in Korean history. Well worth the trip.

review_title: Beautiful Sight on a Lovely May Day
review_body: It was my first time in Seoul so I definitely wanted to see one of the palaces. Gyeongbokgung was beautiful and the weather was superb. We happened upon free entry on May 4th. It was great to walk around and there were actually quite a few girls in traditional costume and they were wonderful to see against the historical backdrop. I also recommend visiting the National Folk Museum next to the palace grounds.
the grandeur and size make it impressive. you may try traditional clothes for free but you must line up for your turn. well worth it.

review_title: Old meets new in the city
review_body: This was a great spot to visit! The grounds were so beautiful and we really enjoy seeing the old buildings and palace. There is a large pond and even an exhibit of the large jars they would use to ferment food in for feasts. There is not air conditioning in many of the buildings, so summer time can be hot - bring water! If you go at the right time of day you can also see the ceremonial changing of the guard that was really interesting! One of the neatest things is that the entire site is located in the middle of the city so you can see sky scrapers right past the palace!
Time tour visit at main south entrance for one of the 4 daily guard changing inv ceremonies--- fun to see.
The area is immaculately preserved. They also make it so tourist friendly with the free Hanbok wearing and the changing of the guards ceremony for show.

review_title: Good to be there while in seoul.
review_body: If you are just going to Seoul for shopping, I'll say you may not like going to these historical places which can be a little dry. But it's highly recommended especially for 1st time visitors to take some time off to read, see and learn how is the history like and how much hv been destroyed after the war. Take your time to stroll the gardens to take the city stress away. Try on the guards uniform for a fun photo taking at no costs. Every country's historical buildings are to be respected for what they have been through with time. So we think its not a fair comparison to compare the different palaces. Just have an open mind to learn more of what was recorded during that era.
reminder of how imperialism - in this case Japanese tried to destroy the local narrative. Nice walk but ...

Korea is a place deeply entrenched in history. In Seoul, this main royal palace is part of that legacy. For a first time visitor in Seoul, I was awed by the magnificence of this grand place. I witnessed the changing of the guards which is a colorful ceremony and had a guided walk exploring the ceremonial hall, the king and queen quarters, the palace office and the peaceful garden by the lakeside. Upon exiting the palace, you will find the current Presidential Headquarters together with a museum which showcases Korea's culture and history.

I didn't find this as interesting as Changdeokgung palace but it is different. Catch the changing of the guards if you can and on a nice day it is very pleasant to wander around the building complex and the grounds.
The Palace was closed when I went on 30 April (not sure why) but it did look impressive from the outside.

I visited this and Changdeokgung palace. It's different. Although I prefer the Forbidden City in Beijing, palaces in South Korea is different in architecture and layouts. The garden is beautiful. Only went into Chandgeokgung palace. Skipped the secret garden as it was raining and didn't think I will get to appreciate the beauty of the garden (not that I know) without the sun!
A wonderful experience walking around the palace grounds, the National Palace museum is located right beside the palace representing the majesty of the 500 year history of the Joseon Dynasty.
English tour guide was excellent. The cherry trees had just started to bloom so the visitors from all nations and the native Koreans seemed to be more interested in the trees than the buildings.

review_title: Eye opener for those who watch Korean Drama
review_body: Make sure you do not miss the exchange of guards which start around 10am. It is almost an hour show and worth watching. Take note that this takes place outside Gyeongbokgung and you need not purchase a ticket to watch this!
Would have been even prettier if the cherry blossom trees had bloomed :( Very well kept and clean. The paint on the palace roof is still very vibrant.

This palace stands out at a main intersection. If you've already been to another of the big palaces like Changdeokgung, as I had, then it will look familiar. Nevertheless, they have a changing of the guard every 2 hours or so, which is very colourful and makes a good photographic opportunity especially on a bright sunny day. It's worth a look. Take note that it is closed on Tuesdays.
with a very good guide, one can learn a lot from this place. loved the "changing of guards" ceremony with actor-guards in complete costumes.

This palace is a "must see" for any trip to Seoul. The surroundings are absolutely beautiful with mountains in the background, manicured gardens and fish ponds. You can experience how the royal family used to live hundreds of years ago and then step out the gate into downtoen Seoul. Walking shoes a good idea due to the large area to be covered and the uneven surface area (ancient paving stones, not concrete). The changing of the guard ceremony also interesting as well as the exhibits of life in ancient Korea.

Gyeongbokgung is definitely a must visit tourist attraction when you're in Seoul. It's at the heart of Seoul and lets you experience the history of how life was like for South Koreans. The architecture of the buildings are amazingly beautiful. There are performances at the grand entrance, tours in different languages for free and it costs less than $3 to the admission fee. This place is definitely huge so make sure to wear walking shoes.

We were here a few years ago. The palace is really cool! We loved learning about the history and all the detail in the architecture. The guard ceremony was neat also. they have headsets to describe everything you are seeing. However, not long after we got there we met a teenage girl that wanted to practice her english so we let her be our tour guide! Loved this place, a great experience!
There are a couple of palaces in Seoul. Both are different enough to enjoy separately, but you must see at least one.

Gyungbok Palace was used as a King's place during Joseon dynasty. You can feel Korean royal family's life and there living standard. Also, you can enjoy beautiful nature in Gyungbok Palace. Don't forget other palaces around Gyungbok Palace like Changduk Palace or Changgyung Palace.

The changing of the guard that happens at 10am is free and was pretty cool to see. You need to pay 3000 won to get in to see the rest of the site but it is worth it.The site is very big and you also get access to the folk museum

review_title: amazing! so serene and so beautiful!
review_body: one of my favourite destinations in seoul, this is a MUST SEE! how beautiful the grounds are here, and so serene and relaxing in the heart of this very very busy city. great for a picnic lunch, be sure to allow yourself a few hours here to just relax, wander around and enjoy this quiet. really really magical!

Guide books advised us that the gate opening took place at 9am. This is incorrect. The gate opening takes place at 10am. You can catch them warming up at 9.45. It's worth watching though and try to get to the palace early to avoid the crowds. We got there for 9am and we got some lovely photos, tour groups start pouring in from about 9.30am. 11.30am is the first English tour.
plenty of phoyo opportunities with guards changing and the buildings and you can try on a uniform and watz around its very funny and worth doing and as always everyone is friendly
Prepare for a long walk if we want to explore the whole areas. The whole were very clean and well-maintained. The palaces have colorful detail and interesting pattern on many parts of them.

review_title: Lovely way to spend a sunny morning
review_body: We visited the palace as a family on a Sunday morning and spent appr 2 hours here. As has been mentioned in many reviews, a lot of parts of this palace are rebuilt due to destruction suffered during Japanese occupation. Nevertheless, it remains very impressive. Since we had our two children with us (10 and 15) we didn't opt for any tours (they tend to get bored easily) but just wandered around the grounds. There were plenty of information tablets near all major sites and all were available in English so no language barrier there.We arrived at appr. 10.50 and were able to take some shots of the kids with the colourful guards in front of the palace. The changing of the guards on the hour made for a lovely video shot.Once inside the gate the ticket booths were located towards the right hand side. When we went in there were only 2-3 people queuing in front of us so no delays in purchasing tickets. The grounds are huge so you can easily spend some hours just wandering about, taking scenic shots (and have them taken by Koreans of you as well!).We had a coffee outside the cafe in the sun which was lovely and priced similarly to the rest of Seoul. Overall a great place to start your sightseeing. Very easy to do and beautiful shots to get. I would make sure you go in good weather though since virtually all of it is outside (you will only be able to look inside the buildings from windows).

Due to the destruction of much of their heritage during several periods of Japanese occupation, Koreans are in many cases literally rebuilding their history. So many (parts) of their old temples and palaces seem a bit 'new'. Having said that, Gyeongbokgung was a lovely place to visit and see part of their architecture and heritage.

Gyeongbokgung Palace is one of the many attractions in Seoul. The place presents a vivid view of the life of South Korean royalty during the olden days. It is easy to get around the palace grounds because of multi-lingual signage all over the area (English, Korean, Japanese). There is also an audio tour provided to visitors who want to avail of it. The palace grounds is so vast. It has certain similarities with Chinese architecture.To get to Gyeongbokgung, you can take the subway or the bus. You can also take the Seoul City Tour Bus which has its last stop at Gyeongbokgung.

review_title: Private Tour Guide Enhanced our Experience
review_body: We visited this Palace on our first day in Seoul. It was the perfect introduction to Korea and antidote to jetlag. We walked for about three hours..you can spend even more time there. Bring water and snacks. Take time to rest and enjoy the beautiful lake .

The palace was not too big, 2 hour was enough to spend there.The things I like from this palace was, there were Hanbook rent for free, beside the cafeteria.But had to queue, since many local and tourist used this facility.

Wow ... What a great piece of architecture ad restoration. This palace is the largest and one of 5 palaces in Seoul. I joined a tour and this was one of the inclusions.It was good to have someone explain all the history and show me through. Wonderful colors and history.Look out for the changing of the guards - a parade of wonderful costumes, sounds and pagentary. Lots of people scrambling to get photos but wait until the end and you will get shots of guards leaving .I wish I had more time as tour only allocated an hour which also include the national folk museum. This is a must see if you have limited time. The other palace I saw was very similar ad I don't think it's worth doing two palaces.

Just use a jacket, long john, and sneakers, and ... you are ready to enjoy Gyeongbokgung Palace in winter. It may provide a slight different experience when we visited Gyeongbokgung Palace in the thickest snow in Seoul history in 2010. It was a little bit chilly, however, it was wonderful seeing the guards hand over ceremony. Do not forget to take pictures by wearing traditional guard costumes for free - a brilliant opportunity.

review_title: Great place to immerse your self in history
review_body: It was amazing to see how totality lived... And there day to day habits. The architecture is a sight to behold. I was amazing to see how Japan and chime ha influence in the way they developed there land and also to know that korea has been invaded by both but still in the end Korea fought through. Even if your not big into history the views, plant life, and entertainment is enough to take up your whole day. Don't forget to see the changing of the guards. And for 3,000 won you can't beat that... Plus free admittance to the national folk museum right next door.

review_title: A quiet palace in the middle of Seoul's hustle and bustle
review_body: I liked the fact that this complex was restored very well. Though it suffered a lot of damages due to the war and the Japanese occupation, I found this royal palace to be a more sober and enjoyable example compared to Beijing's Forbiddne City. More information available in english, less crowded, and very clean

This palace is spread over a huge distance.There are lots of buildings are beautiful. This is palace is worth seeing. On buying the entrance ticket we were given a map and an English guide. This was good as it allowed us to walk around the grounds at our leisure. the only problem is that my map reading skills are nil. It was quite cold when I went there but I can imagine this place would be amazing with blossoms.It ia worth seeing.

Definitely recommend this. See the changing of the guard, and they also do a little performance every hour. Recommend getting a tour. Its much more interesting as you hear about the kings and queens who lived in korea back in the days.

Great Place to be. Wonderful seeing the guards hand over ceremony in the morning. The views inside are great. Guided tours In Englishare even more fascinating. Dont miss the photo spot near the ponds inside.
Nothing exciting. Its ok but not a match for other parts of Seoul, dont go out your way to go. Kids were bored inside 5 munutes.

Its a very interesting place to visit. Especially if you get there to see the changing of the guards. It shoows you the historical way of the past, and afterwards you are allow to take pictures with the guards once they are in position at their post. I wish I could have seen it in the summer time when the trees and flowers would be at full bloosom.

A huge and impressive palace complex, which does bear some comparison to both the style and layout of Beijing's Forbidden City. The front gate guards change every hour on the hour, and offer a colourful photo opportunity. Line 3 to Gyeongbokgung, and exit 5 to the front gate.

Well kept, vibrant and well preserved. You will enjoy an afternoon stroll here and definitely enjoy visiting the museums. Nice souvenirs and reasonably priced. They have great views to take pictures of and is one of the palaces that you would think of revising.

My boyfriend and I came here after the one hour tour at Changdeokgung in the huge park east of here. We decided to stop in before lunch as the site is smaller on the map. Poor planning! This place is HUGE and has so much stuff inside! You really need to set aside a lot of time for this area! There are 3 museums in the area you can see (one is hidden under the statue of a man sitting on the street in front). After you check out the changing of the guards, you can check out tons of buildings on the inside. If you bring kids, this is definitely a full day! Luckily there is a variety of things here to do that keep it interesting. A must-see in Seoul!

review_title: Largest and Most Grand Palace in Seoul
review_body: If you will like to visit only 1 palace, may I suggest this one.English guided tours run 3 times a day, please check for the times.Its especially useful to walk around with an english speaking guide, it breathes life to the place.The palace grounds is the largest amongst the other palaces in Seoul. The spaces is majestic and grand. Located next to the Gyeongbukgung palace are a few museums, which is included in the ticket price of 3000won.There are guards dressed in traditional costume at the gates. There is a guard change ceremony which makes the visit interesting.

i have visited this amazing place at my second day in Seoul and it was -6C but still i spent hours around...lucky me i saw the changing guards ceremony in the morning and went around with a local tour guide which helpful to understand every spots inside the palaceits a huge complex, silent, clean (even icy everywhere) and brought me back to the past when i walked and sit silent inside the complex..when i was there, i took many pictures and i just couldn't stop to do it...it a must place to visit when you are in Seoul and spend more time around...for sure i will be back here if i visit Seoul in other season (it was winter)
Our family love to visit museums and historical landmarks. This palace is a really nice place to learn about the traditions of the Koreans. It is well preserved and worth a visit.

Gyeongbokgung is one of the 5 grand palaces of Seoul and very rightly so. It was mostly destroyed by the Japanese after the Korea occupation and so far they have only been able to restore half the buildings!It occupies a large area close to downtown and can be easily reached by subway - just stop at the station with the same name (line3).One of the highlights is the changing of the guards which happens every hour.It also houses the National Folk Museum, a comprehensive guide to the soul of Korean people, including the history of the ever present Kimchi. You should not miss both.

Do drop by this area and view the palace. It's huge and a lot of historic moments that you able to experience. Around it, there are other palaces as well. If you have time, can visit all, else just choose this one and it's good enough to leave good memory :)

review_title: See the Changing of the Guards
review_body: This is probably the largest palace in Seoul. The vastness of the grounds is imposing and certain structures are really fascinating. The main attraction, though, would have to be the changing of the guards that happen at 10am. Be sure to see it, as there's nothing quite like it. You can take the guided tour or go around on your own. It's not very difficult to go around, and the maps indicate which are the notable landmarks to visit. I thought it was fascinating, but despite being so large, it somehow pales in comparison to Cheongbukdong. It's still something to see, though.

It was ok, nothing overally special I didn't think, but then I was by myself. I watched the changing of the guard and then looked around the palace, might have been more beneficial if you got a guide.

As a largest palace in South Korea, there are many different palaces within the palace to view and take photographs. There is even a pond right behind the King's concubines' quarters that has a pavilion in the centre.The only thing I disliked about it was that I spent at least 3 hours exploring the palace, including the 2 museums within the palace.
Fantastic place so much to see and read about ,great help is the Guide book (in various languages ) Great place to spend the day .

review_title: Large Palace Grounds but Relatively Boring
review_body: It's kind of interesting to walk around the Palace grounds and imagine what live was like, but every building looks the same because they've all be recently rebuilt. It kind of lacks the feel of a historic site. Feel free to just watch the changing of the guard ceremony and take a picture for a guard or two, but don't spend more than an hour here. There better things to see.
A major cultural and tourist attraction. Not to be missed, along with the Palace museum,which houses artifacts and gowns of the royal family .

We arrived at 10am to see the changing of the guard ceremony which was really fun to see. Then we bought our tickets and waited for the start of the English tour. The grounds are massive, so allow enough time here. We only spent 30 minutes in the Folk Museum which was not nearly enough time, but we were in a hurry. I'm still amazed at how reasonable entrance fees are in Seoul--just three dollars US for this place. I highly recommend seeing this palace.

This palace is located at the base of a mountain on one side and the busy city of seoul on the other. It is beautiful to see the traditional Palace surrounded by the modern Seoul of today. This palace is large and takes a while to walk all the way through but the buildings are beautiful and the history is interesting. We missed the tour so we took one of the information booklets and did a self guided tour and it was great. There is a lot of information given in the booklet. The tickets are inexpensive and the changing of the guard is narrated in 3 languages. Definitely a must do in Seoul!
The massiveness of the palace, the kings swimming pool, and the change of guards is also a wonderful sight.

This is the #1 palace to see if you can only see one. Highly recommend the tour. Only a few english tours a day, so check your guide book or the website for schedule. If you can't make the tour, pick up a pamphlet at the information office, there isn't any signage on the grounds explaining what anything is. Changing of the guard happens every hour on the hour, that's worth seeing. Also recommend the integrated palaces ticket if you plan to visit a lot of palaces. It's a good value and saves the standing in line at every palace to buy tickets.

This palace is very beautiful and huge. If you are a kdrama lover, you'll find some parts of the palace that is used to shoot some kdramas. It was winter when we visited Gyeongbokgung, so it was very cold. You can just wander around by yourself or guided by available tour guides there.

review_title: Frankly, the palaces are much of a muchness
review_body: The National Folk Museum (in the grounds) is free. For those interested in Korean history and culture, it is a must. $3 to wander around the palace grounds is not bad value but adds little to your knowledge or understanding - it is merely a photo opportunity.
It is old palace of traditional ear in Korea.Pretty beautyful and attractive place.

review_title: not only for the history buffs
review_body: Definitely worth the visit. Best schedule is 3 pm changing of the guards with music and very choreographed procession, then quickly buy tickets and take the free guided tour in English. Our guide clearly loved that place /the guides are volunteers/ and even though she said it will be an hour, it was 1:40 overall. That gives you still a good hour until the closing time to soak up the atmosphere.it was quite damaged in the Japanese occupation, so they are rebuilding it, but its huge and not too crowded. A wonderful insight into the history of Chosen dynasty.

review_title: a good introduction to Korean traditional architecture
review_body: On a very short visit to Seoul we visited the grounds of this palace and a couple of rooms. I wish we had more time and better guidance to the variety of things to know about this palace.
Going to this palace end of february with a group tour. so we know about the history abaout this palace. What a nice palace.

This is the second time we have visited this Palace just to watch the parade of soldiers who perform the Changing of the Guard. They are wearing colorful costumes and march around some of the area of the huge forecourt. There are many performances on the hour and some are short - 5 minutes or so- and some are 20 minutes in length with photo opportunities available.

review_title: You just have to visit it when you are in Seoul
review_body: It was my second time visiting the palace and I am still fascinated by the beauty of this place. I would always revisit Gyeongbokgung. On a little side note, I was once in October and the other time in February, I would recommend going in fall, because in winter it is freezing cold!!! and the ways are quite muddy.

Although most of the buildings are rebuilt in recent years, there are various guard changing ceremonies held throughout the day. at 11am 1pm and 3pm there is a procession with drums and music and at 2pm and 4pm is a simpler guard changing ceremony.
Very interesting, clean. A great place to see the history of Korea. Very beautiful grounds, well kept, not crowded.

We learned a lot about the history of this palace and the effect that the poor relations with the Japanese has had on this treasure. Most of it has been rebuilt. Go on the hour when there is a changing of the guard.

review_title: Visiting during Lunar New Year season
review_body: It was only coincidental that we went during the eve of the Lunar New Year, but it was great that we did because we got to see some traditional performances outside the National Folk Museum just beside the palace grounds. We also got the chance to have a free photo-taking session dressed up in traditional Korean costumes. The palace and its grounds were also amazing, like you were in a Korean historical drama, and everything was covered with snow, so it was such a great scene to take in. We were also lucky enough to see the changing of the palace guards at Gwanghwamun. This is a must place to visit in Seoul!

this is the also one of the "must see" place when you go on city tour, at front of Sejong King Statue, go on there at 10.00 then you will see the guard changing ceremony, and after that you can taken your picture with them, it was great,,,

review_title: A must-see for first-time visitors to Seoul
review_body: The Gyeongbokgung Palace or the Palace Greatly Blessed by Heaven was built in 1395 and consists of several buildings including a Throne Hall, residences of the Crown Prince, the Concubines and Court Ladies, a library, a pavilion in the middle of a (frozen) pond, all surrounded by sprawling gardens. The property is beautifully maintained and there is so much history around it. This should be part of every first-time visitor's itinerary. Be sure to wear comfortable shoes as there is a lot of ground to cover. I went in January, at the height of the Korean Winter, but enjoyed the walking tour immensely, despite the cold. Get there early in the morning (I arrived before 10AM) to avoid the queue at the ticket booth and the crowds. Don't miss the colorful Changing of the Guards ceremony that happens daily at 11AM. At the end of the ceremony, there's an opportunity to have your photos taken with the guards. The entrance fee of KRW3000 -- roughly US$2.50 -- is a small price to pay to see this picturesque, historical attraction. From my personal experience, it's not necessary to pay to join a group or package tour to get to this attraction. It's easy to get to this place. I went on my own and didn't have any issues. From my hotel in Myeong-dong District, I took the Seoul Metro (move from Line 4 to Line 3) to get there. Exit 5 takes you right to the doorstep of the Palace Museum, a few steps from which you'll find the ticket booth for the Palace itself. When you get to the Palace, there are free information brochures in all languages and best of all, free guided tours. English tours are scheduled at 11AM and 1:30PM.
It was a lovely, cold day. I was a little underwhelmed by the signage and organization of the Palace, but I loved that the museum attached was free and well-done.

This is my second time visited this place,first time is at 2003.To me it is nothing much different.You can see a lot of tradisional Korea style building all the way.We walked a lot to see all the houses and palaces as the place is very big and spacious except the specific palace which need to buy another ticket.You have to pay more if you want to visit more palaces. We bought ordinary entrance tickets only.The first time I came is during summer time,the scenes are so-so.The second time is during autumn,the views are totally different because we can see very beautiful maple trees.

I saw the guard changing ceremony at 3 pm on a Saturday. There are several free English guided tour per day. I was on the last one of the day at 3:30 pm. The lady was really nice and showed us the most important part of the palace. The explanation gave us a good perspective about the life of palace. The tour lasts about one hour. If the weather was not freezing the day i was there, I am sure I will be more happy about the trip. The only indoor place is the folk museum on the side. Overall, I enjoyed the palace tour.

I've been here several times over the past decade as people have come to visit me in Seoul. My guests aren't usually too excited by the experience. I routinely ask locals if they've been and locals rarely have been more than 1 or 2 times in their lives.

Too bad that we went here in the afternoon that is why we missed the changing of guards. What I really like the most is the big landscape of the palace and the mountain views in the palace. When we where there the small room in the middle of the lake reminds me of Moon embraces the sun. I really want to go there but it is restricted to visitors. We were already tired at the time when we visited this palace so we spent a little time in here.

The name translates as the Palace of Shining Happiness. This palace has survived a lot of wars and rulers making is historical site a representation of how strong korea is as a nation and it's citizenry.The interesting folk museum and palace museum is housed here including beautiful traditional korean gardens.When in gyeongbogkung you must witness the royal changing of the guards that happens every hour from 10am - 3pm and of course have photos with the korean guards as well

The main attraction of going to Gyeongbokgung is to watch the changing of the guards. They say it is historically accurate, complete with exchange of passwords and stuff. It’s best to time your visit to watch the changing of the guards, and then go on the free guided tour which I think runs every hour. The tour guide gave lots of interesting information about the architectural features of the palace, like why there are three “lanes” going into the palace from the gates, or how the palace is heated during the winter months. She also gave told us a bit of history of Korea, the palace and the kings that occupied it. Overall it was 2 hours well spent. If you’re into walking a lot, Gyeongbokgung is walking distance from Insadong, Jongmyeo Shrine, Changdeokgung Palace, Gwanghwamun Square and Cheonggyecheon Stream. So from Gyeongbokgung there are quite a number of choices of places you can go to.

Visiting a palace is an essential item in your Seoul itinerary. Gyeongbok-gung is one of the top palace and it is worth a visit as it is within easy reach via Subway. Taking pictures with the guards are free and they are all dressed in traditional Korean Costume, if you time your visit correctly you can see the changing of guards too !

review_title: One place you must visit to know Seoul
review_body: The name translates as the Palace of Shining Happiness. This palace has survived a lot of wars and rulers making is historical site a representation of how strong korea is as a nation and it's citizenry.The interesting folk museum and palace museum is housed here including beautiful traditional korean gardens.When in gyeongbogkung you must witness the royal changing of the guards that happens every hour from 10am - 3pm and of course have photos with the korean guards as well

review_title: Changing of the Guard was neat to see
review_body: Worth a visit for a glimpse of historic Seoul. The changing of the guard (a few times a day) is fun to see and hear. The palace is wonderful to see juxtaposed between the mountain on one side and the modern city on the other. The place is massive. You could explore for hours easily.

Impressive, huge Korean style royal palace. A must see in Seoul, but beware visiting involves a lot more walking AROUND buildings than inside them, and January in Seoul is usually bitterly cold, so dressing appropriately is essential (i.e. at least skiing-type clothes). I enjoyed the visit in spite of the cold, although I expected it to be a lot more about interior decoration than it proved to be the case.

review_title: We had the chance to see the guards changing
review_body: We went there this Jan and we saw the ceremony of the guards changing. Really nice. The palace is huge and really nice altough not the originsl one - that was distroyed long time ago and they rebuild it after that. It is well preserved and you can feel the days of the dunasty.Also you have access to the national museum and there are lovely exhibitions. Go and visit!

Gyeongbokgung Palace is interesting in the fact that it layed in ruins for over 200 years! From the late 16th century until the mid 19th century Gyeongbokgung was abandonded, Changdeokgung Palace was the main palace of the royal family during this time. Therefore, it must be noted there is basically nothing inside the palace that dates before the major rebuilding period of the 1860's. So while there are a few buildings that are between 100 and 150 years old, sadly much of the palace was destroyed during the Japanese Colonial period. What we see today is a masterful reproduction of the original with a few important authentic Joseon buildings still remaining. Most of the buildings that we see are very recently built, just in the last 20-30 years.Nevertheless, I always enjoy my time here. For one, the palace has a grand atmosphere, the buildings are large and are built in classic Joseon architecture. My favorite palace is without a doubt Changdeokgung, in large part because it is the best preserved palace and the gardens are exquisite. I do feel however, that the two palaces compliment each other. Changdeokgung is the authentic Joseon palace, which is typically called the most "Korean" of all 5 Joseon palaces. Gyeongbokgung is really a product of the final years of the Joseon Dyansty, and the architecture is built in a style that is supposed to legitimize the Korean King as an Emperor.For anyone who enjoys history (like myself) you will enjoy Gyeongbokgung. I had plenty of time in Korea, so I was able to visit all 5 royal palaces on more than one occassion. If you only have time to visit one palace, visit Changdeokgung, but if you have more time, by all means enjoy the grand Gyeongbokgung Palace.

review_title: Still under renovation but the change of guards is interesting
review_body: Not much to see when you're inside the palace. As the palace was destroyed and burnt before, many parts are still under reconstruction. However, it's worth watching the changing of guards taking place at the entrance of the palace every hour of the day. You don't have to pay to watch this.

After repeated requests from our tour guide for a chance to don the Hanbok ( traditional Korean costume), my daughter and i finally got the opportunity to do so within the confines of the Gyeongbokgung Palace. It meant cutting short the palace tour proper and queuing up for about two hours at a designated place. When noontime came, the attendant advised us that they would be closing for lunch and would be resuming at 1 pm. Since we were already next in line, our Korean guide pleaded that we be allowed a few minutes extension since our bus was no longer capable of waiting for us much longer.They understood our predicament and finally conceded. My daughter and i were given the choice of color and kind of costume we wanted to wear. A costumed Korean "lady-in-waiting" assisted the both of us inside the dressing room. She asked us to remove our rubber shoes and produced two pairs of Korean shoes for us to wear . She then motioned us, one at a time to go up an elevated platform, to spread our arms as she went about fastening the costumes in a wrap-around fashion on top of our shirt and pants. Our guide ably took our souvenir shots wearing these costumes at the palace grounds. We boarded our tourist bus, happy at having completed the Hanbok experience..

This is a must-see if you want to learn and see old Korean style buildings. It is beautiful. Do not miss the change of the guards. Easy to combine with the shopping area (authentc Korean style) Insadong on walking distance.

Considering Korea has lots of these palaces, we aimed to see the best and chose Gyeongbukgong and we were definitely not disappointed. Our visit was like a time travel to the early days of how Korea was like.As a K-drama fanatic myself, it was definitely worth a visit if you go to Korea.
this is a beautiful palace, with traditional guards out front. there are several "changing of the guard" ceremonies throughout the day, make sure you stay for one of these.

Gyeongbokgung is a great palace, a traditional Korean palace open for tourists and citizens. There are several scenic palace and places for tourists, including a banquet place, and beautiful garden and lake with snow on the surface.

Gyeong-bok-gungThe magnificent Gyeongbokgung, which was first built in 1395, had a painful and bitter historical background. The Palace, or the complex, was actually destroyed twice under different circumstances during the period of 600 years. The present spectacular Palace complex was rebuilt to their past glory and splendor only as from 1990.The Palace complex is very important to the people of Korea, as it is a national symbol of sovereignty to them. Visitors should not just admire the beauty of the well-kept gardens, ponds and lakes, but spend time to appreciate the various structures, some of which were constructed entirely according to Korean architectural designs; others were built under foreign influences. Different palaces were also built to serve different purposes, such as grand halls for ceremonial functions, rooms for discussing affairs of the State with officials, halls for entertainment, rooms for reading and writing for the monarch, private quarters of the royalties, and for their servants.There are four main gates in the Palace Complex; the most famous gate will be the Gwang-hwa-mun, where traditional ceremonial changing of the guards is performed at fixed intervals. But most important of all, visitors should avail themselves the opportunity to visit the adjoining presidential ground, which was closed for many years for security reason, but opened to the general public only in early 2011.
i have been there for more than 3 times, in different seasons, winter is the best time to pay the visit, especially after the snow

review_title: A jewel in the middle of the city
review_body: Visited Gyeongbokgung late November so it was starting to get chilly. It is easily accessed via the Gyeongbokgung Palace station on Seoul Subway line 3. We were able to catch the Changing of the Guards. Don't forget to take tons of photos with the guards and the lovely red and yellow foliage.

Easy access from subway. The exit/entrance from subway was decorated to have a feel of the historic palace. A palace with cluster dwellings for the palace workers. Beautiful architecture and carvings made for good photography. They have a procession of guards at certain time of the day. They have FREE guides done by students in English! You can see them in their bright orange jacket. A few other museum around the palace grounds. This place is huge! Take us a few hours to cover the whole ground. Only our hunger for lunch stop us from covering the whole ground. There's a cafe in the museum building to have hot coffee. We head to Insadong for lunch which is nearby across the street. Visited in December 2012.

review_title: Lovely slice of history in a modern cityscape
review_body: The palace is a must stop if in the Insadong area. This is a Truly a photogenic stop with a piece of the past in the middle of a shiny modern city, complete with the mountains and trees framed perfectly by the design of the palace and surrounding gardens. It was a very cold outdoor walk for us on X-mas eve but worth it for the history and beauty. Warm up after in any of the nearby coffee or tea shops, there's even a Starbucks located just up the street. ;)I imagine summer and fall are the best walks here for the gardens and Koi ponds that were very frozen over at the time of our visit. A Lovely walk about.. back in time.

Just amazing when it's covered in snow ... we wanted to rent hanboks but was told that it was unavailable due to the weather. Very nice walk outside the palace along Samchongdonggil towards other museums and plenty of cafes to chill along the way ...

The snow doesn't stop anyone from visiting, I think it made the place more beautiful. Wear decent shoes in the winter though, because the paths were not all cleared of the snow and it was deep in a few places.

You may have watched some dramas and well reality is better than on tv. I went to Gyeongbok during fall and it was magical! The trees were turning red and yellow and with the mountains in the background everything seemed like a dream. It is one of the best place to go in Seoul! Very pretty.
Enjoy walking around at this palace, tickets include museums visits. Trees in the garden are very nice during my period of visit. Walking distance to InsaDong. Easy access to this palace

review_title: Wished they did not run of english guide books though
review_body: The palace grounds is nice and really big,but I wished they did not run of English guide books though because there are some beautiful structures that I have missed, especially the very photogenic pavillion. I enjoyed the hourly changing of guards ceremony as well.

review_title: Nice look back into Korea's dynastic past
review_body: Imagine large palace with interesting stories behind them.... hence, it'll be good if you manage to catch a guide that gives free tour at regular interval.Be sure to get there before 4pm or so (please check closing timing as it differs time to time) as ticketing close an hour before closing time... we missed it by ten minutes during our first trip there :(There's a National Palace Museum at the side with some interesting displays, taking about an hour or less to finish viewing, a good side visit if you have some time on hand,... or happened to missed the ticketing time (like us)
This is part of Gyeongbokgung Palace so I'm not sure why it has it's own post. The palace was beautiful.

Even on December 23rd when it is below 0C/32F it was packed--I have only one photo that does not have 10 other tourists in it.
